Knowledge Article: Question: How do I update my contact details?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can update your mobile number and/or email address via my cpf digital services – Account settings with your Singpass. An SMS or email One-Time PIN (OTP) will be sent to your new mobile or email address for verification before the changes can be submitted. Please note that any changes to your contact details will be subject to a 12-hour cooling period and you may be subject to enhanced authentication measures to verify your identity.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I inform CPF Board if I have changed my contact details?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can update your mobile number and/or email address via the Account Settings page with your Singpass. An SMS or email One-Time PIN (OTP) will be sent to your new mobile or email address for verification before the changes can be submitted. Please note that any changes to your contact details will be subject to a 12-hour cooling period and you may be subject to enhanced authentication measures to verify your identity.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I inform CPF Board of a change in my mobile number or email address?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can update your mobile number and/or email address via my cpf digital services - Account settings with your Singpass. Please note that any changes to your contact details will be subject to a 12-hour cooling period and you may be subject to enhanced authentication measures to verify your identity. If you are an employer, you should inform CPF Board of any changes to your principal place of business or contact details .

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to my MediSave if I do not use it?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Any unused MediSave savings will remain in your MediSave Account and grow with interest.   Learn more about  CPF interest rates .

Knowledge Article: Question: How is the Basic Healthcare Sum determined?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Basic Healthcare Sum is an estimate of your likely medical expenses from age 65 onwards. It is determined based on past trends in MediSave use by the elderly. It is meant to cater for your own basic subsidised healthcare expenses, as well as health insurance and long-term care insurance premiums during old age.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I work after age 65, do I still need to contribute to my MediSave Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As long as you continue to work, you will need to contribute to your MediSave Account (MA). The contributions will accumulate in your MA up to the Basic Healthcare Sum. Your MediSave savings will help you with your medical expenses during retirement.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I choose to receive both digital notification and a hardcopy MediSave transaction statement?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will not be receiving hardcopies of your MediSave transaction statement once you receive notifications digitally. This will aid us in our pursuit to reduce the use of paper.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is the Basic Healthcare Sum adjusted yearly?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To ensure that the Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS) remains relevant for every cohort, we need to adjust it regularly to keep pace with the growth in MediSave use by the elderly, especially with rising healthcare costs and expansions in MediSave uses. The BHS is adjusted yearly for cohorts below age 65.   The BHS for each cohort is fixed from age 65 onwards and the same BHS applies to them for the rest of their lives. This will help members save enough for their basic subsidised healthcare needs in old age, while providing some certainty on the amount they need to set aside in their MediSave Account for their old age.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I have to top up my MediSave Account to the Basic Healthcare Sum if I withdraw my CPF savings from age 55?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You do not have to top up your MediSave Account when you withdraw your CPF savings from age 55.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I do not have the Basic Healthcare Sum when I reach my Payout Eligibility Age and I intend to start receiving my retirement payouts, do I need to top up my MediSave Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will not need to top up your MediSave Account to the Basic Healthcare Sum in order to receive your retirement payouts.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens if I do not have the Basic Healthcare Sum when I turn age 65?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS) is the estimated savings you will need for your basic subsidised healthcare expenses in old age. If you have less than the BHS at age 65, you are not required to top up your MediSave Account (MA). However, you may choose to top up your MA using cash if you would like to build up your healthcare savings.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the Basic Healthcare Sum?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS) is the estimated savings you need in your MediSave Account for your basic subsidised healthcare needs in old age.   For CPF members below age 65, the BHS will be adjusted annually to keep pace with the expected growth in MediSave use by the elderly. This ensures that the BHS will stay relevant for each cohort when they arrive at retirement age.   Once CPF members reach age 65, their BHS will be fixed for the rest of their lives.   For CPF members aged below 65 in 2024 The prevailing BHS is $71,500, and will be adjusted yearly. For CPF members who turn 65 in 2024 The cohort BHS is $71,500 and it will remain fixed for the rest of their lives. The following table summarises the BHS for respective cohorts aged 65 and above in 2024:   Age in 2024 Year when cohort turned age 65 Cohort BHS (fixed for life) 65 2024 $71,500 66 2023 $68,500 67 2022 $66,000 68 2021 $63,000 69 2020 $60,000 70 2019 $57,200 71 2018 $54,500 72 2017 $52,000 73 and above 2016 or earlier $49,800

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I check the status of my Home Protection Scheme exemption application?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can contact your insurer to confirm if they have submitted the Home Protection Scheme exemption application to the Board. You may ask them to provide you with the application number (i.e. FormSG ID number).   Once your insurer(s) have submitted your application to the Board, you will receive notification of the outcome generally within five working days from the date it was submitted. Your insurer(s) will also be notified of the outcome.   However, if you haven't received any notification after this period and have confirmed that your insurer has submitted the application, you may write to us to check on the status of your application.

Knowledge Article: Question: As an employee, how much do I contribute to my MediSave Account (MA)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You contribute a portion of your monthly CPF contributions to your MediSave Account (MA) depending on your age group. You can refer to the  CPF contribution and allocation rates .

Knowledge Article: Question: What is MediSave?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediSave is a national savings scheme which helps CPF members save for future medical expenses, especially during retirement. Saving for future medical expenses is important, as the need for medical care and hospitalisation increases significantly as one grows older. It is important that you spend your MediSave savings prudently. MediSave can be used for hospitalisation and day surgery expenses. MediSave can also be used to pay for certain costly outpatient treatments like dialysis, cancer drugs and radiotherapy, as well as treatment for a number of chronic diseases like diabetes and hypertension. Those with severe disability can also tap on MediSave Care for their long-term care needs. You can refer to the  MOH website for the uses of MediSave and the withdrawal limits. Additionally, MediSave can also be used to pay the premiums of approved medical insurance schemes like MediShield Life. If you want additional coverage for your bills in private hospitals, or A and B1 ward types in public hospitals, you can use your MediSave to help pay for an Integrated Shield Plan from an approved private insurer. These plans are integrated with MediShield Life to provide additional medical coverage on top of MediShield Life. MediSave can also be used to pay the premiums of approved long-term insurance schemes like CareShield Life and ElderShield. For those under CareShield Life who would like additional coverage, you may also use your MediSave to help pay for Supplements from approved private insurers. You can refer to the CareShield Life website for more information.

Knowledge Article: Question: I received a call/email/SMS/WhatsApp message from the Board. Is it a scam?
Knowledge Article: Answer: It is crucial to remain vigilant and cautious when receiving calls/email/messages. CPF Board officers will never ask you to reveal your CPF balances, transfer funds to them or provide your banking credentials. If you receive such requests from anyone claiming to be a CPF Board officer, do not act on them. Immediately make a police report via 1800-255-0000 or www.police.gov.sg/iwitness and inform CPF Board. You can protect yourself against scams by doing the following checks: For email, ensure that the sender's email address is correctly spelt and ends with @cpf.gov.sg or @e.cpf.gov.sg Telephone calls from CPF Board officers will not begin with a prefix "+65". If a call has a prefix with a plus (+) sign, it is likely to be an overseas call and will not be from CPF Board. Telephone calls from CPF Call Centre will be made from 68454401. For WhatsApp, ensure that the sender is “CPF Board Text us” with the green badge. This is our official business account with the phone number 62023401. CPF Board Text us   For SMS, ensure that the sender is 'gov.sg'. Messages from CPF Board may contain links to the CPF website or other Government websites. Please check that the domain of such links end with ".gov.sg" before clicking on them. To ensure that you are notified of any transactions or updates to your CPF accounts, please check and update your contact details under Account Settings (Singpass required).

Knowledge Article: Question: Is there a maximum amount that I can save in my MediSave Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can save up to the prevailing Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS) in your MediSave Account if you have not turned age 65. The BHS from 1 January 2024 is $71,500 for all CPF members aged 65 years old and below in 2024. The BHS applicable to you will be adjusted yearly to account for increasing life expectancy and healthcare costs until the year you turn age 65. For instance, if you are aged 65 in 2024, the BHS that is applicable to you will be $71,500 for the rest of your life. The following table summarises the BHS for respective cohorts aged 65 and above in 2024:   Age in 2024 Year when cohort turned age 65 Cohort BHS (fixed for life) 65 2024 $71,500 66 2023 $68,500 67 2022 $66,000 68 2021 $63,000 69 2020 $60,000 70 2019 $57,200 71 2018 $54,500 72 2017 $52,000 73 and above 2016 or earlier $49,800

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the Basic Healthcare Sum when I turn 65 years old?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For each cohort turning 65 years old, their applicable Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS) will be fixed at that year's amount for the rest of their life. For instance, if you are aged 65 in 2024, the BHS applicable to you is $71,500 and it will remain unchanged for the rest of your life. The following table summarises the BHS for respective cohorts age 65 and above in 2024:   Age in 2024 Year when cohort turned age 65 Cohort BHS (fixed for life) 65 2024 $71,500 66 2023 $68,500 67 2022 $66,000 68 2021 $63,000 69 2020 $60,000 70 2019 $57,200 71 2018 $54,500 72 2017 $52,000 73 and above 2016 or earlier $49,800

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use MediSave to pay the remainder of my medical bill that is not covered under my pensioner benefits?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use your own or your approved dependants’ (i.e. spouse, children, parents, grandchildren and siblings) MediSave to pay the remainder of your medical bill that is not covered under your pensioner benefits, up to the MediSave withdrawal limits. The expenses incurred must be for medical treatments approved under the MediSave scheme.   If you would like to use your MediSave to pay the remainder of your medical bill, please inform the Medical Institution (MI). You will be required to complete the Medical Claims Authorisation Form (MCAF), which authorises the MI to use your MediSave to pay the bill. Please note that any amount above the MediSave withdrawal limits would need to be paid in cash.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the MediSave Grant for Newborns?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The MediSave Grant for Newborns is a grant given to all Singapore Citizen newborns in the child’s MediSave Account. Parents can use it to help defray their child’s healthcare expenses, such as MediShield Life premiums, recommended childhood vaccinations, hospitalisation, and approved outpatient treatments.   For more information on the MediSave Grant for Newborns, please visit madeforfamilies.gov.sg .

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my MediSave to pay for my siblings' insurance premiums for schemes such as MediShield Life, Integrated Shield Plans or ElderShield/ElderShield Supplement?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes. Since 1 June 2019, members may use their MediSave to pay for their siblings' insurance premiums.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use MediSave to pay for my overseas medical treatment if I am living overseas for the long term?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As MediSave is primarily meant for medical treatment in Singapore, it does not cover overseas medical expenses for those residing overseas for the long term. This is a common feature of national healthcare systems in many countries.        If you are residing overseas for the long term, please consider obtaining medical coverage to meet your overseas healthcare needs.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why was I notified of my MediSave deduction via a different notification mode before and after 12 June 2023?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As part of our continuous effort to enhance our members’ experience, we have made changes to the notifications we send. These changes were made to ensure alignment with other types of notifications that our members receive from us.   With effect from 12 June 2023, we have started notifying members of their MediSave deductions for medical expenses via email or SMS using their contact details maintained with CPF Board. You may verify that the notification is legitimate by checking that that the sender’s email address ends with @e.cpf.gov.sg, and the SMS sender ID is 'gov.sg'. The SMS will also begin with "Central Provident Fund Board".   If you have installed the CPF Mobile App and enabled push notifications, you will receive push notification alerts on your mobile phone as an additional notification.   We encourage you to keep your contact details updated so that you can receive timely notifications. You may update your mobile number and/or email address via the  Account settings  page on CPF website, after logging in with your Singpass. An SMS or email One-Time PIN (OTP) will be sent to your new mobile number or email address for verification before the changes take effect.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use MediSave to pay for the removal of my wisdom tooth?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use your MediSave savings to pay for the removal of your wisdom tooth incurred at a participating private dental clinic under the MediSave Scheme, provided that it is a surgical procedure. The day surgery limits are:   1) Day surgery Up to a maximum of $300 per day for daily hospital charges, including investigations, medicines and doctor's attendance fees. 2) Operation A fixed limit for operations ranging from $250 to $7,550 depending on the type of operations performed.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is not covered under the MediSave scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediSave generally does not cover optional and cosmetic treatments, accident and emergency (A&E) fees and non-medical treatments such as ambulance transport. Please approach the medical institution to find out whether your treatment can be covered under MediSave.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my MediSave for my siblings' medical expenses?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may use your MediSave to pay for your siblings' medical expenses, as long as they are Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents (SC/PR). You would have to provide proof to the medical institutions that your siblings are SC/PR (e.g. NRICs).

Knowledge Article: Question: I have saved the Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS) in my MediSave Account. What happens to my MediSave savings above the BHS?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediSave Account savings above the Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS) will be channelled to your CPF Special Account (SA) or Retirement Account (RA), depending on your age. The BHS cap and channelling are designed to avoid over-saving in MediSave Account and to supplement the member’s retirement savings, which can be withdrawn according to the CPF withdrawal rules. For members who have met the Full Retirement Sum (FRS)* in their SA or RA, the savings in excess of the BHS will be channelled to the Ordinary Account (OA). Savings in the OA can be used for other purposes such as housing repayment.   *FRS amount consists of SA balance and any active CPFIS-SA investments.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I revoke the authorisation for the use of MediSave savings for my own and/or family member(s) medical expenses?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you had signed the Medical Claims Authorisation Form (Single Institution), please approach the Medical Institution where you signed the form to revoke your authorisation.   If you had signed the Medical Claims Authorisation Form (Multiple Institutions), you can approach any Public Healthcare Institution to obtain a copy of the revocation form. Alternatively, you may also download this form , and mail the completed form to the address indicated below.   Attn: MCAF/ PFA Administrators Bukit Merah Central Post Office P.O. Box 680 Singapore 911536

Knowledge Article: Question: Why am I receiving digital notifications instead of the hardcopy MediSave transaction statement to inform me of a deduction from my MediSave?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As part of our commitment to protect members against fraudulent deductions and to reduce environmental footprint, we have transitioned to digital notifications to inform you of your MediSave deduction for medical expenses. You will receive notifications via one of the following modes:   a. If your email address is registered with CPF Board, you will receive an email notification; b. If you do not have an email address registered, but have a mobile number registered, you will receive an SMS notification.   If you have installed the CPF Mobile App and enabled push notifications, you will receive push notification alerts on your mobile phone as an additional notification.   These digital notifications will ensure that you are informed of any deductions made from your MediSave in a timely manner. If you wish to update your contact details, you may do so via the Account settings page on CPF website, after logging in with your Singpass.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens if my employer or insurer is paying part of my hospital expenses?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have given the hospital a Letter of Guarantee or Hospitalisation Identity Card at admission, the hospital will send the bill to your employer or insurer. Your employer or insurer will then work out the part of the bill to be paid by you. They will then ask you to sign a Medical Claims Authorisation Form (MCAF) if you wish to pay the amount from your MediSave Account (MA). When your employer or insurer returns the MCAF to the hospital, the hospital will arrange to deduct the amount from your MA. Some hospitals may request that you sign the MCAF at admission especially if your employer or insurer is paying only part of your hospital expenses.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use MediSave to pay for my dental implant?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use MediSave to pay for your dental implant insertion or removal as long as it is a surgical procedure.   For a dental surgery with insertion or removal of dental implants, you can use MediSave to pay for your dental implants, up to the following limits:   Insertion of Dental Implants Number of implant(s) inserted x $950 Operation limit of Table 2C Removal of Dental Implants Number of implant(s) removed x $450 Operation limit of Table 1C   For example, if you have to insert two dental implants, you can use up to $1,900 (2 x $950) for payment of your dental implants.

Knowledge Article: Question: I do not have enough MediSave to pay for my hospitalisation expenses. Are there other ways to pay for it?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you do not have sufficient MediSave for your hospitalisation expenses, you may consider tapping on one or more of your approved dependants' MediSave. Approved dependants refer to your spouse, children, parents, grandchildren and siblings. You must be a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident if you wish to tap on your grandchildren or sibling's MediSave.   It is important to note that while you can tap on your approved dependants' MediSave, the amount you can use is still subject to the MediSave withdrawal limits, which is applied on a per hospitalisation episode basis. If you still have outstanding hospitalisation expenses after using up to the MediSave withdrawal limit, you would have to pay the remainder in cash.   Alternatively, you or your approved dependants may use future MediSave contributions to pay for the outstanding hospitalisation bill if: The payer's MediSave Account is active (MediSave contributions received within the past three months); and The patient stayed in a B2 or C ward in a public hospital You must apply to the hospital on the day of or before you are discharged. This is not allowed for outpatient treatments.   For more information, please speak to the staff at the hospital's Business Office.   You should use your MediSave prudently to provide for your own and your approved dependant's hospitalisation needs. This is because you may require more medical care in your old age.

Knowledge Article: Question: I intend to use my approved dependant's MediSave for my hospitalisation expenses. Do I need to produce any proof of my relationship with my approved dependant?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will not be required to produce documentary proof of your relationship with an approved dependant at the point of admission. However, your approved dependant will need to complete a Medical Claims Authorisation Form to use his/her MediSave for your hospitalisation expenses, where he/she will be asked to declare his/her relationship with you.   You and your approved dependant may subsequently be asked to submit documentary proof of your relationship as part of an audit. Please note that legal action may be taken against any member who makes a false declaration.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I withdraw my MediSave in cash?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediSave is primarily designed to help Singaporeans save up during their working years for their healthcare needs in old age. Generally, MediSave cannot be withdrawn in cash and are instead paid directly to MediSave-accredited medical institutions for approved medical treatments.   However, under MediSave Care, severely disabled Singaporeans aged 30 and above may withdraw up to $200 per month in cash from their own and/or their spouse’s MediSave account(s). This is because long-term care needs vary significantly across such individuals, and cash withdrawals will provide patients and their caregivers the flexibility to decide on their desired care arrangements and long-term care services. You may refer to AIC’s website and our FAQs for more details on MediSave Care.   The Ministry of Health (MOH) will continue to review their financing policies to ensure that care remains affordable for our citizens, while MediSave balances are not depleted prematurely.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why am I receiving this notification from CPF Board? Is it legitimate?
Knowledge Article: Answer: This notification service notifies members that their monthly CPF transaction statement is ready for viewing. Notifications will only be sent to the email address that you have registered with the Board. You may  check or update your email address with your Singpass. To verify whether the notification is legitimate, check that the sender’s email address ends with @e.cpf.gov.sg. If you have downloaded the latest version of the CPF Mobile app, you will be directed to the CPF Mobile app upon clicking the link. If you have not downloaded the latest version of the CPF Mobile app, or you are viewing your statement on a desktop or laptop, you will be directed to our official CPF website (link starting with cpf.gov.sg) on your web browser to view your statement. Find out how you can protect yourself from phishing links .

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I inform CPF Board of a change in my address?
Knowledge Article: Answer: By default, CPF letters are sent to your residential address on your Singapore Identity Card. If you are residing at a new address and have been receiving your CPF letters at your old residential address, please apply for the change of your residential address (local or overseas) via Immigration & Checkpoints Authority’s (ICA) e-Services using your Singpass. Participating government agencies and statutory boards (including CPF Board) will be informed of the change in address through the One-Stop Change of Address Reporting Service (OSCARS) within one day. You will not be receiving an additional acknowledgement from CPF Board for updates via OSCARS. Please visit ICA website for more information.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the Government cash grants included in the Year-in-Review?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please refer to the table below for the participating schemes included in the Year-in-Review (YIR). The YIR shows a summary of the cash grants that you had received in the past 12 months before your birthday month through CPFB-administered Government schemes. You would have received separate notifications on your eligibility for the respective schemes.   Schemes Assurance Package and GST Voucher Lease Buyback Scheme Bonus Silver Housing Bonus Silver Support Training Commitment Award Workfare Income Supplement

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the Government cash grants included in the Yearly Statement of Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please refer to the table below for the participating schemes included in the Yearly Statement of Account (YSOA). The YSOA shows a summary of the cash grants you received through CPFB-administered Government schemes in the previous year. You would have received separate notifications on your eligibility for the respective schemes.   Schemes Assurance Package and GST Voucher Lease Buyback Scheme Bonus Silver Housing Bonus Silver Support Training Commitment Award Workfare Income Supplement

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if I receive mails from CPF Board that do not belong to me and my family member(s) at our address?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you received mails from CPF Board that do not belong to you and your family member(s) at your address, please state the reason for return, e.g. 'no such person' or 'change of owner', and drop the mail into SingPost's "Return Mail Here" mailbox. The undelivered mail will be returned to us.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use more than one of my approved dependants' MediSave for my hospitalisation expenses?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can tap on one or more of your approved dependants' MediSave for your hospitalisation expenses. Approved dependants refer to your spouse, children, parents, grandchildren and siblings. You must be a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident if you wish to tap on your grandchildren or sibling's MediSave.   While you can tap on your approved dependants' MediSave, the amount you can use is still subject to the MediSave withdrawal limits, which is applied on a per hospitalisation episode basis regardless of the number of payers. If you still have outstanding hospitalisation expenses after utilising up to the MediSave withdrawal limit, you would have to pay the remainder in cash.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why are MediSave withdrawal limits imposed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediSave is a national medical savings account to help Singaporeans pay for their hospitalisation expenses, especially in old age. In line with this, MediSave withdrawal limits are set to strike a balance between helping Singaporeans afford the co-payment for their ongoing treatments, and ensuring that they have sufficient savings for their future healthcare needs.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the healthcare hotline?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For healthcare-related enquires, you may call us at 1800 222 3399* / 65 6222 3399 (overseas) from Mondays to Fridays, 8.30am to 5.30pm (GMT+8, excluding public holidays). Alternatively, you can also write to us.   * Airtime charges will apply for mobile calls to 1800 service lines. Calls are free of charge only if made from regular land lines.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I am hospitalised, how much MediSave can I use to pay for my hospitalisation expenses?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For daily hospital charges 1 , you can use up to $550 per day from MediSave for the first two days of inpatient stays, and $400 per day thereafter.   If you had undergone a surgery, you can use your MediSave to cover part of, or the whole surgery cost. The amount of MediSave you can use depends on the complexity of your surgery, as listed in the Table of Surgical Procedures. You may refer to the  MOH website for more information on withdrawal limits for MediSave.   It is useful to note that you are considered hospitalised if you have been admitted for at least eight hours. This requirement does not apply to day surgeries.   1 Includes eligible Mobile Inpatient Care @ Home stays

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my MediSave for hearing aids?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediSave cannot be used for the purchase of hearing aids. This is because MediSave is primarily designed to help Singaporeans offset costly hospitalisations, day surgeries and selected outpatient treatments.   However, you may apply for the Seniors’ Mobility and Enabling Fund (SMF) which provides subsidies to eligible seniors for a range of assistive devices, including hearing aids. You can call the Agency for Integrated Care (AIC) at 1800 650 6060* or visit  AIC website for more details.   * Airtime charges will apply for mobile calls to 1800 service lines. Calls are free of charge only if made from regular land lines.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I choose to receive the hardcopy MediSave transaction statement instead?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Notification through hardcopy statements will result in a delay in informing you of deductions made from your MediSave account. It will also contribute to the usage of paper, which is not environmentally friendly.   We encourage members to join us in our efforts to go digital and reduce our environmental footprint, while enjoying the convenience of timely notifications.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I am 66 years old in 2024 and my applicable Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS) is $68,500. Am I allowed to maintain more than my applicable BHS in my MediSave Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can only save up to your applicable Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS) in your MediSave Account (MA). The BHS is designed to be enough for your basic subsidised healthcare needs in old age and to avoid over-saving in the MA.

Knowledge Article: Question: What types of hospital charges can be covered by my MediSave?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use your MediSave for your hospitalisation, surgery, and rehabilitation charges.

Knowledge Article: Question: As a bankrupt, can I still use my MediSave?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may use your MediSave to pay for your own or your approved dependants' healthcare expenses even if you have declared bankruptcy. Approved dependants refer to your spouse, children, parents, grandparents and siblings. Please note that grandparents and siblings must be Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents.

Knowledge Article: Question: I visited a clinic for an outpatient treatment that can be paid by my MediSave. How do I go about utilising my MediSave?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To use your MediSave to pay for your outpatient medical treatment cost:   1. Inform the clinic that you wish to use MediSave to pay for your outpatient medical treatment. The staff will require your NRIC/Passport. If you are paying for your approved dependant, please also produce his/her NRIC/Passport. Approved dependants refer to your spouse, children, parents, grandparents and siblings. Please note that your grandparents and siblings must be Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents.   2. The clinic may require information on how much MediSave is available for payment of the outpatient treatment. You will be able to obtain this information by logging in to your Healthcare dashboard under my cpf digital services with your Singpass. This is not needed if the clinic can check on your behalf.   3. You and the patient (if applicable) must sign a Medical Claims Authorisation Form to allow the clinic to use your MediSave to pay for the outpatient medical treatment bill.   4. If your employer or insurer is also paying for your outpatient treatment, please bring along your Letter of Guarantee or Employer Identity Pass (i.e. if your clinic has an existing arrangement with your employer or insurer).

Knowledge Article: Question: What outpatient treatments can be paid using MediSave and what are the withdrawal limits?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please refer to the MOH website for the list of outpatient treatments that can be paid using MediSave and their corresponding withdrawal limits.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are there additional charges for using my MediSave to pay for my medical expenses?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF Board does not impose any administrative fee for using MediSave.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my MediSave for Traditional Chinese Medicine?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are aged 60 and above, you may withdraw up to $300 per year from your own, or your spouse’s MediSave Account under the Flexi-MediSave scheme to pay for acupuncture treatment for lower back pain and neck pain at specialist outpatient clinics in public hospitals.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my MediSave to pay for my step/adopted children's hospitalisation expenses?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your step children are under your custody, they are considered your approved dependants, and you can use your MediSave for their hospitalisation expenses.   To use your MediSave for your adopted children, you need to submit legal documentary proof of your relationship to the hospital. If the legal process of adoption is still underway, you should submit the following documents to the hospital:   a. A lawyer's letter stating that the legal adoption is underway, and b. The birth certificate within one year of your child's date of birth.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my MediSave to pay for the medical treatments received by dependants other than my approved dependants (spouse, children, parents, grandparents and siblings)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediSave is meant to help you save for your personal or approved dependant's healthcare expenses incurred in any of the participating medical institutions (MIs) under the MediSave Scheme.   You can apply to use your MediSave for a dependant who is not your approved dependant, if the dependant is receiving treatment in a public healthcare institution or voluntary welfare organisation in Singapore. Please approach the medical institution's Business Office for more details on the eligibility criteria and the application process. Such applications will be considered on a case-by-case basis.

Knowledge Article: Question: I do not have enough MediSave to pay for my outpatient treatment expenses. How else can I pay for it?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you do not have sufficient MediSave for your outpatient treatment expenses, you may consider tapping on one or more of your approved dependants' MediSave. Approved dependants refer to your spouse, children, parents, grandchildren and siblings. You must be a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident if you wish to tap on your grandchildren or sibling's MediSave.   You may claim up to $700 (for patients with complex chronic conditions) or $500 (for non-complex chronic patients) per patient per year, and each MediSave claim is subject to a 15% co-payment in cash.   While you can tap on your approved dependants' MediSave, the amount you can use is subject to the MediSave withdrawal limits, which is applied on a per patient basis regardless of the number of payers. If you still have outstanding medical expenses after utilising up to the MediSave withdrawal limit, you would have to pay the remainder in cash.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my MediSave to pay for non-surgical dental treatments?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Dental treatments are generally not claimable under the MediSave scheme unless the treatment involves surgery and is performed due to medical reasons. Non-surgical dental treatments such as extractions, crowning, dentures or braces are not MediSave-claimable.   Please check with your dentist whether your dental treatments are claimable.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my MediSave for optional/cosmetic treatments like liposuction, orthodontics treatment or laser surgery to correct short-sightedness?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Generally, MediSave cannot be used for optional/cosmetic treatments. Please check with your attending doctor if the cost of your treatment can be covered by your MediSave.

Knowledge Article: Question: What if my hospital bill is more than what my MediSave can cover?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The MediSave withdrawal limits are generally sufficient to cover bills incurred in B2 or C ward types in a public hospital. This restriction is necessary to prevent premature depletion of your MediSave, as your MediSave savings are to last through your lifetime. This is particularly important as elderly people may require more hospital stays and medical care than younger ones. If there is any part of the hospital bill that MediSave is unable to cover, you will need to pay in cash.

Knowledge Article: Question: How are claim limits for MediShield Life and MediSave determined when more than one cancer drug is used in the treatment?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Patients who need more than one cancer drug treatment on the Cancer Drug List (CDL) in a month may claim up to the higher of the MediShield Life, MediSave and Integrated Shield Plan (IPs) claim limits applicable for the individual treatments.   For example, if a patient uses both Treatments X (MediShield Life claim limit of $2,000 & MediSave withdrawal limit of $600) and Y (MediShield Life claim limit of $1,000 & MediSave withdrawal limit of $600) in a month, the patient may claim no more than $2,000 from MediShield Life and withdraw no more than $600 from MediSave in that month.   Please consult your doctor if you wish to clarify the claim limit that will apply for your treatment.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will the revised chemotherapy benefits under MediShield Life and MediSave impact my claims from 1 September 2022?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Each cancer drug treatment on the Cancer Drug List (CDL) will have its own MediShield Life claim limits and MediSave withdrawal limits.   You may refer to the MOH website for the list of cancer drug treatments that are claimable under MediShield Life and MediSave, and their respective claim and withdrawal limits. Please also consult your doctor if you wish to find out whether the treatment that you are currently undergoing is on the list.   The CDL will only come into effect for Integrated Shield Plans (IPs) on 1 April 2023. If you have an IP, you will continue to be covered under your current policy terms until it is renewed on or after 1 April 2023.   For example, if your IP is up for renewal on 1 November 2023, the CDL and its revised limits will only apply then. Insurers may decide to cover treatments beyond the CDL under their riders, though the extent of coverage may vary. Your insurer should inform you of the details of your IP and rider coverage by end 2022.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is there a reduction in the MediSave withdrawal limit for daily hospital charges from $450 to $400 from the third day of hospitalisation?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The rebalanced MediSave withdrawal limits are designed to act in tandem with recent enhancements to MediShield Life to better support patients with short inpatient stays. As shown in the Table below, the total coverage under MediShield Life and MediSave for each additional day of stay has increased as a result of these changes, and patients who are covered under both schemes will not need to pay more cash for their hospitalisation bill.   Day MSHL claim limit (non-ICU) MSV withdrawal limit Total Previous Current Previous Current Previous Current 1 $700 $1,000 $450 $550 $1,150 $1,550 2 $700 $1,000 $450 $550 $1,150 $1,550 3 and beyond $700 per day $800 per day $450 per day $400 per day $1,150 per day $1,200 per day   MediSave withdrawal limits are designed to strike a balance between improving the affordability of current treatments, and ensuring that Singaporeans retain sufficient savings for their future needs. The rebalancing of MediSave withdrawal limits for daily hospital charges as shown above ensures that MediSave balances are not prematurely depleted.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have directed a medical institution to submit a claim on my behalf. However, I would like to make an amendment to that claim. What should I do?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please approach the medical institution that submitted the claim on your behalf for assistance.

Knowledge Article: Question: My approved dependant is a foreigner, while I am a Singapore Permanent Resident. He/She has incurred medical expenses in Singapore. Can I use my MediSave to pay for his/her bills?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may use your MediSave to pay for your approved dependant's medical bills, if it is a MediSave-approved treatment incurred at any of the approved medical institutions in Singapore. Approved dependants refer to your spouse, children, parents, grandparents and siblings. Please note that your grandparents and siblings must be Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents.

Knowledge Article: Question: Am I required to do any test submission before I start using my own payroll software to submit via CPF EZPay (FTP)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You are not required to do any test submission to CPF Board.   To know more about the CPF EZPay (FTP), you may refer to our  user guide (PDF, 3.5MB).

Knowledge Article: Question: Why does CPF Board refer my case to another organisation?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF Board is committed to providing the best possible assistance to those in need. To make sure you get the right kind of support, we’ll look at your situation and assess whether there are other organisation(s) with more appropriate assistance tailored to your needs. If the situation warrants, we will refer your case to our partner organisation(s) that have the right assistance programme(s) and expertise to better assist you. Please inform us explicitly if you do not want us to refer your case to our partner organisation(s). CPF Board is committed in ensuring your data is protected. You may refer to our privacy statement for more details.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is CPF LIFE?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF L ifelong I ncome F or The E lderly (CPF LIFE) is a national longevity insurance annuity scheme that insures you against running out of your retirement savings, by providing you with a monthly payout no matter how long you live.   Unlike investment products which are meant to grow our wealth, insurance products, like CPF LIFE, help to protect us against life's uncertainties.   With CPF LIFE, you can have peace of mind knowing that you will have a steady stream of lifelong income to support your retirement needs. This way, you can enjoy your golden years without having to worry about financial uncertainties, no matter what age you live to.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable during my overseas training?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable during overseas training if you are employed in Singapore but are required to go overseas for the training period.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on air passage?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are not payable on air passage for official purposes, e.g. meeting overseas clients, attending seminars, conferences and training. The reimbursement amount must not exceed the expenditure incurred.   CPF contributions are payable on air passage that increases your employee’s wages. Some examples are:   Home leave passage (air passage provided by you for your employees to visit their home countries) Cash payment in lieu of home leave passage Air passage provided to your employee to commence work in Singapore Air passages provided to your employee's family members

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on "per diem" payments?
Knowledge Article: Answer: “Per diem” payments refer to money paid to your employees for daily living expenses, and include the additional expenses incurred for living away from home. They may also be given for trips made by your employees to attend overseas training and conferences where the payments are meant to cover certain living expenses incurred overseas such as the cost of meals, transport expenses and other incidental expenses like laundry. “Per diem” payments that are given as a lump sum allowance: CPF contributions are payable on “per diem” payments that are given as a lump sum allowance as they increase your employee’s wages. “Per diem” payments that are given as reimbursements for official purposes: CPF contributions are not payable on “per diem” payments that are given as reimbursements for expenses incurred for official purposes (e.g. accommodation, meal expenses). As the employer, you must be able to prove that the reimbursements are for expenses incurred for official purposes. The amount reimbursed must not exceed the actual expenditure.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on benefit in kind?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are not payable on benefit given to your employee in kind, e.g. a commemorative watch or payment made directly by you to a service provider.   Such benefit in kind where no cash payment to your employee is involved would not be considered as wages because only remuneration in money granted in respect of employment attracts CPF contributions.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on bonus?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on bonus given to your employee, e.g. retention Bonus, 13 th month bonus, sign-on bonus, discretionary bonus.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on ang bao/red packet?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on the cash payment given to employee in the form of ang bao/red packet.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on bonus given to my employee by a third party e.g. my service partner?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on bonus given to your employee by a third party, e.g. your service partner, if the bonus is a reward for work done in respect of your employee’s employment.   Example   Company A is a marketing company partnering various banks to help increase its sales for personal loans and credit cards. Upon achieving specific monthly targets, the banks will give bonuses to the employees of Company A as a reward. Company A receives these bonuses from the banks and disburses to its employees.   Company A is required to pay CPF contributions on the bonuses given to its employees as the cash payments are wages given in respect of their employment.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the CPF Housing Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF Housing Scheme enables CPF members to use only their CPF Ordinary Account (OA) savings to:    Buy Housing and Development Board (HDB) flats Buy or build private residential properties in Singapore It's important to keep in mind that your Special Account (SA) and Retirement Account (RA) savings are intended to provide you with a source of  income during retirement and cannot be used for purchasing a flat or any other property.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the CPF LIFE plans available and which is the right plan for me?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There are three CPF LIFE plans to choose from – Escalating Plan, Standard Plan and Basic Plan.   Do plan for your retirement with inflation in mind. For example, if your monthly expenditure is $1,000 today, you may need about $1,500 monthly payouts to maintain the same lifestyle in 20 years’ time. Choose your CPF LIFE plan based on how willing you are to adjust your retirement lifestyle, as things become more expensive.     If you are worried about the rising costs of living, you can  consider the Escalating Plan which provides monthly payouts that start lower initially but grow by 2% every year for life. The growing payouts protects you against inflation and generally helps you maintain your retirement lifestyle. Read more about how the CPF LIFE Escalating Plan works .   If you are willing to live a more modest lifestyle and buy less as years pass, you may find the Standard Plan which provides steady payouts suitable for you. Payouts do not grow to protect you against inflation so you'll have to lower your lifestyle to buy less as things get more expensive in the years ahead. Payouts start higher than the Escalating Plan, but will eventually become lower than the Escalating Plan. Read more about how the CPF LIFE Standard Plan works .   If you don’t mind starting with lower monthly payouts which will be progressively lower later on, then the Basic Plan is good enough. The Basic Plan is a legacy plan carried over from the time CPF LIFE was first introduced in 2009. Compared to the Standard Plan which gives higher and steady monthly payouts, Basic Plan payouts are lower and will get progressively lower when your combined CPF balances eventually fall below $60,000. Read more about how the CPF LIFE Basic Plan works .   In all three plans, you will enjoy payouts no matter how long you live, your premiums will enjoy risk-free CPF interest rates , and any remaining CPF LIFE premium balance will be given to your beneficiaries, together with your remaining CPF savings when you pass on. In other words, you and your loved ones will always get back the premium that you have put into CPF LIFE.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable for my employee who is on overseas assignment?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable if your employee is employed in Singapore but required to go overseas for assignment, e.g. overseas business trip, meeting overseas clients, attending overseas seminars, conferences and training.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much MediSave can I use to pay for approved vaccinations for myself?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use up to $700 (for patients with complex chronic conditions) or $500 (for patients with non-complex chronic conditions) yearly per patient from your MediSave or your approved dependants' MediSave.   Approved dependants refer to your spouse, children, parents, grandchildren and siblings. To use your grandchildren's or siblings' MediSave, you must be a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident. The same yearly withdrawal limit applies for approved chronic disease treatments and health screening.

Knowledge Article: Question: What can I use Flexi-MediSave for?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Flexi-MediSave can be used for outpatient medical treatments (i.e. visits that do not involve a hospital stay or day surgery) received at polyclinics, public hospital Specialist Outpatient Clinics and general practitioner clinics participating in the Community Health Assist Scheme (CHAS).   Flexi-MediSave can cover consultation fees, selected tests and drugs, and other services such as physiotherapy, if ordered by your doctor for diagnosis or treatment of your medical condition.   It cannot be used for non-medical treatments, such as those for cosmetic or lifestyle purposes (e.g. hair loss, slimming etc). It also cannot be used to pay for items from the retail pharmacies, such as skincare products. Non-medical charges such as administrative fees are also not covered.   Flexi-MediSave cannot be used for dental treatments and admissions to the Accident and Emergency department.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is Flexi-MediSave applicable only to the Pioneer Generation or all elderly?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Flexi-MediSave applies to all elderly aged 60 and above.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I claim Home Protection Scheme benefits under medical grounds on behalf of my next-of-kin who lacks mental capacity?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As an appointed donee / deputy for your next-of-kin, you can claim his insurance benefits and withdraw CPF savings due to Reduced Life Expectancy by completing this form and submitting the required documents as listed in the form. The form will allow you to concurrently apply for both Home Protection Scheme (HPS) and Dependants’ Protection Scheme (DPS) benefits, as well as withdrawal of CPF savings .   Upon receipt of the completed form and supporting document(s), CPF Board and Great Eastern Life (for DPS) will review the application and follow up with you.   If you are not the appointed donee/deputy, you can write to us for further assistance.

Knowledge Article: Question: Who is the Public Trustee?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Public Trustee is a government body that acts as a trustee of the deceased's estate. It ensures that the assets of the deceased are distributed to the rightful beneficiaries.   If you require further information or clarification, please contact:   The Public Trustee's Office 45 Maxwell Road #07-11, The URA Centre (East Wing) Singapore 069118 Tel: 1800 2255 529 Website: pto.mlaw.gov.sg

Knowledge Article: Question: Who is the Public Trustee?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Public Trustee is a government body that acts as a trustee of the deceased's estate. It ensures that the assets of the deceased are distributed to the rightful beneficiaries.   If you require further information or clarification, please contact:   The Public Trustee's Office 45 Maxwell Road #07-11, The URA Centre (East Wing) Singapore 069118 Tel: 1800 2255 529 Website: pto.mlaw.gov.sg

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I check my Post-Secondary Education Account (PSEA) balance if I wish to repay my education loan using my PSEA savings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may call the 24-hour Post-Secondary Education Account (PSEA) hotline at 6260 0777 to check your account balance.   For more information on how to check the outstanding loan amount repayable under the CPF Education Loan Scheme, please refer to this FAQ .

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my CPF savings to repay the monies withdrawn under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF savings cannot be used for repayment of amounts withdrawn under the CPF Education Loan scheme.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is there a limit to the number of times I can use Flexi-MediSave for my outpatient treatments in a year?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There is no limit to the number of Flexi-MediSave claims you may make in a year. However, you can only use up to $300 in a calendar year.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the monthly instalment rate under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your monthly instalment rate under the CPF Education Loan Scheme will be stated in the repayment notification sent to you. Generally, the monthly instalment rate will enable you to fully repay your education loan within six years.

Knowledge Article: Question: My family member has passed on. How do I check if they were covered under the Home Protection Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To check if your family member was covered under the Home Protection Scheme, you may write to us and select “Housing/Property” as the Subject and “General Enquiry – Home Protection Scheme” as the Category .

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my sibling's Post-Secondary Education Account (PSEA) to repay my outstanding education loan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can only use your own Post-Secondary Education Account (PSEA) savings to repay your education loan.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to indicate the address of my nominees, if they do not live in Singapore?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Mailing address is required for foreigners to facilitate us in contacting them when distributing your CPF savings. Mailing address for Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents will be based on the address registered with Immigration & Checkpoints Authority (ICA).

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable for my employee who is employed to work overseas?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are not payable on wages given to your employee who is employed to work overseas.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable for full-time National Servicemen (NSFs)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are not payable for full-time National Servicemen (NSFs) enlisted for national service under the Enlistment Act as they are not employed under a contract of service .

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on cash prizes given in contests?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are not payable on cash prizes given to participants in contests where the cash payments are not given in respect of employment, e.g. Dinner and Dance, lucky draws, early bird draws.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on cash payments given to my employee for his personal car-related expenses?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on cash payments given for your employee’s personal car-related expenses, e.g. car loan interest, car parking fee, Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) fee, petrol, road tax, insurance, repair, servicing fee.   However, CPF contributions are not payable on reimbursement of expenses incurred by your employee for official purpose, e.g. the company’s car is used for work-related travel and you reimburse your employee the petrol expenses. The reimbursement amount must not exceed the expenditure incurred.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on encashment of flexible benefits?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on the cash payments given to your employee from unused flexible benefits.

Knowledge Article: Question: When do I have a CPF account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your CPF account is automatically created when a first top-up or CPF contribution is received.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on meal allowance or reimbursement?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on meal allowance given to your employee.   CPF contributions are not payable on meal reimbursement given to your employee for working beyond normal working hours, e.g. overtime and on non-working days. Otherwise, CPF contributions are still payable.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have used my MediSave for some outpatient medical treatments this year, and would like to know how much more I can use under Flexi-MediSave. How can I do so?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can check how much more you can use under Flexi-MediSave through:   a. my cpf digital services • Log in to your Healthcare dashboard using your Singpass • Select 'Utilisation of healthcare benefits' from the menu bar or scroll down to the 'Utilisation of healthcare benefits' section for 'Additional benefits for the elderly (Flexi-MediSave)'   b. CPF Mobile app • Download CPF Mobile app • Log in using your Singpass • Select 'Healthcare' from the menu bar for 'Flexi-MediSave'

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on winter wear and luggage allowances given to my employee?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on winter wear and luggage allowances given to your employee.   However, CPF contributions are not payable on reimbursements given to your employee for expenses incurred on winter wear and luggage for official overseas trips. The reimbursement amount must not exceed the expenditure incurred.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on tips?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on tips that you have collected and distributed to your employees.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on mobile phone subscription allowance or reimbursement?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on mobile phone subscription allowance. CPF contributions are not payable on mobile phone subscription reimbursement if your employee incurred the expenses solely for official purposes. Otherwise, CPF contributions are still payable.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I choose not to waive the repayment, what will happen to the repayments made to my CPF Ordinary Account under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Under the CPF Education Loan Scheme, the repayments will be credited to your CPF Ordinary Account and form part of your CPF savings which you can withdraw if you are eligible to do so under the current CPF withdrawal rules.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on the National Service (NS) make-up pay when I am away from work for NS training?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your employer should continue to pay CPF contributions on the total wages payable to you, as if you are not away for the NS training. The basic salary and fixed allowance components of your wages, as well as the variable allowances (e.g. overtime pay and allowances) typically paid to you on a monthly basis, as shown in payslips, would attract CPF contributions.   Example   Tim earns a basic salary of $2,000 and an average overtime pay of $800 every month. He went on NS training for one week in July.   Tim’s employer will have to pay CPF contributions on his typical total monthly wage of $2,800. The employee’s share of CPF contributions will also be based on the total wages of $2,800, and Tim’s employer is entitled to recover this from Tim’s wages.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I inform CPF Board if I changed my name?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We use the principal name registered in your NRIC to transact with you. Principal name usually excludes variants such as hanyu pinyin, married name and other aliases.   If you have updated your principal name registered in your NRIC recently, you do not need to inform us separately. Your name will automatically be updated in our records.   If you have not updated the name registered in your NRIC or would like to transact with us using your hanyu pinyin, married or other aliases, you will need to update your principal name in your NRIC first.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long does it take to update my particulars?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please refer to the table for the service standards in updating your particulars.   Service Normal Processing Time Update of Personal Particulars for Singapore Citizens/Permanent Residents 3 working days Merging of CPF accounts 7 working days

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on overtime pay?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on overtime pay given to your employee.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on gratuity and ex-gratia payments?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on gratuity and ex-gratia payments that are given in respect of your employee’s employment. For example, if the payment is to:   reward your employee's good performance, reward your employee for the completion of a contract/project, entice your employee to remain in employment, or recognise your employee's service with you. CPF contributions are not payable on the gratuity and ex-gratia payments if they are compensations given for termination or loss of employment.   Retirement gratuity given to retired employee who is subsequently re-employed   CPF contributions are not payable on retirement gratuity if it is given to your employee without any condition, i.e. it is given regardless of whether he is subsequently re-employed by you under a new employment contract.   However, CPF contributions are payable if it is given on the condition that he takes up the new employment with you. This cash payment will be considered as wages as it is given in respect of his new employment.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are wages payable to an employee who is on maternity leave classified as Ordinary Wages (OW) or Additional Wages (AW)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The monthly wages payable to your female employee who is on maternity leave are Ordinary Wages (OW).   If there are any bonuses payable to her during her maternity leave period, they are classified as Additional Wages (AW).

Knowledge Article: Question: What are Total Wages (TW)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Wages can be classified into Ordinary Wages (OW) or Additional Wages (AW). Total Wages (TW) is the sum of OW and AW.   CPF contributions are computed on TW payable to an employee in a calendar month, with different ceilings applied to OW and AW.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable by the holding company or the subsidiary company if I am seconded from the former to latter?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The employer who had entered into an employment contract with you is required to pay the CPF contributions.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on housing/rental subsidy?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on housing or rental subsidy given to your employee.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I apply for refund on my share of CPF contributions that was paid above the CPF wage ceiling(s)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will need to apply online for refund of CPF contributions paid above the CPF Wage Ceiling(s).

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable when I am on leave?
Knowledge Article: Answer: When you are on leave, you may still receive wages which attract CPF contributions. Some examples of wages that are given when employees are on leave are as follows: Paid Annual Leave Paid Sick/Hospitalisation Leave Paid Maternity/Paternity/Shared Parental/Childcare leave You can find out more about your leave entitlements on the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) website.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I be granted an exemption from the Home Protection Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Home Protection Scheme (HPS) exemption can only be granted if the applicant has appropriate, in-force private insurance policies that are sufficient to cover the outstanding housing loan (till end of the loan term) in the event of the applicant's death, terminal illness or total permanent disability, or age 65, whichever is earlier.   The types of life insurance policies (both traditional and investment-linked) that are acceptable for HPS exemption are:   Whole Life Term Life Endowments Life Riders (must be attached to a basic policy), and Mortgage Reducing Term Assurance (MRTA) / Decreasing Term Rider   The types of policies that are NOT acceptable for HPS exemption are:   Policies that are assigned or pledged as collateral Policies under Section 73 of the Conveyancing Law And Property Act (Cap 61) or under irrevocable nomination/trust arrangement Policies with loans attached Non-life insurance policies, such as business insurance policies, legacy insurance policies, health insurance policies or general insurance policies (e.g. personal accidental, fire or home contents policies) Policies that are priced in foreign currencies Policies from insurance companies that are not licensed by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, and; Group policies that are not portable

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable if I am working in Singapore for an overseas employer?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are required on wages payable to any Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident employee working in Singapore, even if the contract is signed overseas.   Employed directly by an overseas employer   You should research your prospective employer to ensure that it has legitimate business presence in Singapore and whether it is registered with Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA). You should also communicate your CPF rights clearly to the overseas employer before the start of your employment to avoid subsequent disputes. If your CPF contributions are not paid on time or discrepancies are found, please approach your employer for clarification immediately while documentary evidence is fresh. If your employer does not provide you with a satisfactory explanation, you can lodge a report with CPF Board.   Do note that enforcement actions would not be effective against an overseas employer with no presence in Singapore and is not registered with ACRA. CPF Board may not be able to assist you in such claims. You may wish to exercise caution when seeking employment with such employer.   Employed through an Employer of Record (EOR) to work for an overseas entity   You may consider working for an overseas entity through an EOR. An EOR serves as the employer, taking on employment-related roles such as paying salaries for its employees, withholding taxes, paying employment-related benefits, while its employees perform work for its client, e.g. an overseas company.   When you’re employed through an EOR to work for an overseas entity, the EOR is your employer and will be responsible for paying your CPF contributions. Do read through your employment contract with the EOR to ensure your rights are protected.   While it may be easier to take enforcement actions against an EOR located in Singapore compared to an overseas entity, you should still exercise caution when seeking employment with an EOR. The recovery of any unpaid CPF contributions depends on the EOR’s financial ability to pay up the arrears. Do check with the EOR early if any discrepancies are found in your CPF contributions, while documentary evidence is fresh and before your CPF arrears accumulate.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why do I still need to contribute to MediSave even though I already have enough savings for my healthcare needs?
Knowledge Article: Answer: With rising healthcare costs, it is important to have enough savings for your healthcare needs. Contributing regularly to MediSave will help you build up your savings over your working life. These savings can help you meet your own as well as your loved ones’ hospitalisation expenses under unforeseen circumstances.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why do I still need to contribute to MediSave as a self-employed person even though I have already bought insurance for myself?
Knowledge Article: Answer: All working Singapore residents are required to contribute to their MediSave as a form of savings for their own and their loved ones’ healthcare needs.   Many Singaporeans have bought private hospital insurance plans in the form of Integrated Shield Plans, or IPs. IPs comprise of two parts – MediShield Life (MSL) which is a universal basic health insurance plan, and additional private insurance coverage. MediSave can be used to pay the premiums for both MSL and private insurance, up to the current withdrawal limit.   Hence, private medical insurance serves to complement rather than replace your MediSave savings.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I have to pay my MediSave payable when I am no longer self-employed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You’re still required to settle any outstanding MediSave payable, as it is compulsory under the CPF Act to contribute to your MediSave Account for the years that you were self-employed.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have a partnership firm. Do all partners need to make MediSave contributions before renewing the business licence?
Knowledge Article: Answer: All partners (if they derive trade income) must fulfil their MediSave payable before the business licence can be renewed.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is new in the updated 'Apply for CPF Submission Number' form?
Knowledge Article: Answer: With this updated form, you can receive your CPF Submission Number (CSN) instantly upon completing the application for mandatory contributions. The user-friendly design and intuitive user interface would make it easier and more convenient for you to navigate and complete the form.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I view the status of my applications?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can simply log in to "Other employer services – Activities " using your Singpass and 2-Step Verification (2FA) to view the status of your online transactions.    With the improved "Activities" feature, you can stay updated on the latest status of your online transactions, such as whether your application has been received, is being processed, or has been rejected or approved.   As CPF Board is progressively updating some features, you may find that some online transactions performed previously are not available for viewing. Please write to us if you require any details which are not viewable.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the conditions for applying to limit my MediSave payable as a self-employed person?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can apply to limit your MediSave payable if your total employment income (excluding Additional Wages) for the year exceeds the maximum total annual income.   Additional Wages are wage supplements which are not granted wholly and exclusively for the month. Examples are the annual bonus, leave pay, incentive and other payments made at intervals of more than a month.   Please refer to the table below for the total employment income (excluding Additional Wages) that qualifies you to limit your MediSave contributions as a self-employed person.   Year Maximum Total Annual Income (excluding Additional Wages) 1993 - 2003 $72,000 2004 $66,000 2005 $60,000 2006 - 2010 $54,000 2011 $56,000 2012 - 2015 $60,000 2016 - 2022 $72,000 2023 $73,200 2024 $81,600 2025 $88,800 2026 onwards $96,000

Knowledge Article: Question: I have substantial balances in my Ordinary and Special Accounts. Can I use the available funds to offset my MediSave payable?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The three CPF accounts, Ordinary, Special and MediSave Accounts, serve different purposes. While Ordinary and Special Account savings are meant for retirement, your MediSave Account savings are for your healthcare needs. Thus, the balances in your Ordinary and Special accounts cannot be used to settle your MediSave payable.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is Unique Entity Number (UEN)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Unique Entity Number (UEN) is the standard identification number of an entity. The UEN is for registered entities while the NRIC is for Singapore Citizens and Singapore Permanent Residents. The UEN uniquely identifies the entity. For more information, please visit www.uen.gov.sg .

Knowledge Article: Question: If I do not have a Unique Entity Number (UEN), can I register with the Board to pay my employees' CPF contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can apply for a CPF Submission Number (CSN) as you are considered to be trading under your own name hiring Singapore Citizen or Singapore Permanent Resident employees in your own capacity.   Some examples of employers trading under their own name include hawker hiring a hawker assistant, or a person who hires a personal driver, gardener, or domestic worker.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my Unique Entity Number (UEN) to perform transactions with CPF Board? Why do I have to use my CPF Submission Number (CSN)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You must use your CPF Submission Number (CSN) to perform transactions with CPF Board. The CSN is the Unique Entity Number (UEN) + CPF Payment Code. The UEN alone is not sufficient to identify the different types of CPF payments made by you.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I start contributing CPF as a new employer?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will need a CPF Submission Number (CSN) to transact with CPF Board. You can refer to this guide to learn how to apply for a CSN and submit CPF contributions via CPF EZPay in five steps. Please give us your feedback and/or suggestions on the guide using the feedback form .

Knowledge Article: Question: What is CPF Submission Number (CSN)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF Submission Number (CSN) is a unique identifier used by employers to transact with CPF Board. This includes making CPF payments and making any request relating to employer matters.   A CSN consists of an  Unique Entity Number (UEN) or NRIC/FIN (if you’re trading under your own name) and a CPF Payment Code.   You will need to apply for a different CSN for each type of payment you are making. Some examples include mandatory CPF contributions, Voluntary contributions, MediSave contributions under the Additional MediSave Contribution Scheme.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the CPF Payment Code?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF Payment Code in your CPF Submission Number (CSN) identifies the different types of payments made by employers to the Board such as mandatory CPF contributions, Voluntary Contributions, and MediSave contributions under the Additional MediSave Contribution Scheme. You will need to apply for a different CSN for each type of payment that you are making.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can the employees' CPF Account information under the old company be transferred to the new company?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF Board is unable to transfer the CPF Account details of employees from the old to the new company. Employers must apply for a new CPF Submission Number (CSN) for the new company and inform the Board to cancel the old company's existing CSN. When submitting the first CPF payment under the new CSN, employers must provide the CPF Account information for all employees.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long does it take to process the “Apply for CPF Submission Number” online application?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Service Normal Processing Time Apply for CPF Submission Number – Mandatory contribution Immediately upon submission. Apply for CPF Submission Number – Voluntary contribution/Additional MediSave contribution Scheme Within seven working days.
