Knowledge Article: Question: I have ceased engaging employee(s) for a period of time. Can I use my previously issued CPF Submission Number (CSN) to pay CPF contributions for newly hired employee(s)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use the previously issued CPF Submission Number (CSN) to pay CPF contributions for your employee(s), provided that your UEN remains the same for your business entity or you are an individual trading under your own name.

Knowledge Article: Question: What if I am overseas and I am not able to personally handle the transactions when I buy a property?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may appoint someone with the legal authority to act on your behalf under the Power of Attorney.   By appointing someone under the Power of Attorney, you can ensure that your CPF savings and property matters are being taken care of even when you are unable to do so yourself.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the enhancements to the Employer Digital Services?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We have recently enhanced the Employer Digital Services to better meet employers’ needs. With a more intuitive interface and enhanced aesthetics, you can now experience a seamless journey for these applications:   Application Description Activities View submission status and details of past transactions for employers Account Settings Real-time access and update of employer’s contact and address details to receive important CPF Information. Apply for CPF Submission Number Enjoy instant registration of employers’ CPF Submission Number with a new user interface. Refund and adjustment of contributions paid Conveniently apply refund and adjustment of CPF contributions using a single form. Pay composition amount Effortlessly retrieve the composition amount details and pay with just a simple click upon login.   You may refer to this  video  for a walkthrough of the enhancement.   For more details on the enhancements, please refer to the below FAQs:   1 How can I view the status of my applications? 2 What is new in viewing and updating employer details in 'Account Settings'? 3 What is new in the updated 'Apply for CPF Submission Number' form? 4 How is the application process for refund and adjustment of CPF contributions improved? 5 How can I grant my staff access to 'Other Employer Services'?

Knowledge Article: Question: What is new in viewing and updating employer details in 'Account Settings'?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can view and update your employer particulars such as principal place of business address and contact details in the " Account Settings ".   With the new interface, you can conveniently view essential information at a glance; these include: the principal place of business, primary and secondary Singapore Standard Industrial Classification (SSIC) of your business, contact details of the owner or employer representative, and the person in charge of CPF matters.   Updates for mandatory contribution CPF Submission Numbers are instant. Moreover, you can now update the authorised officers’ email addresses in “Account Settings” for CPF submissions. There is no need to update separately in CPF EZPay.   Ensuring your particulars are up-to-date is crucial for receiving important CPF information timely. Do update your employer's details as soon as there are changes.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the Additional Wage (AW) ceiling?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Additional Wage (AW) ceiling limits the amount of Additional Wages that attract CPF contributions. The AW ceiling is applied on a per employer per calendar year basis. The AW ceiling is computed as follows:   $102,000 - Total Ordinary Wage subject to CPF for the year You can also compute the amount of AW that is CPF payable using the Additional Wage ceiling Calculator .   Find out more about AW and the AW ceiling .

Knowledge Article: Question: If I previously withdrew from my Retirement Account by pledging my property, what happens to my pledged property after I make a voluntary housing refund?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will need to refund the amount you previously pledged if the voluntary housing refund is not enough to meet the Full Retirement Sum in your Retirement Account. Check the amount you need to refund under “What happens if” of your Home ownership dashboard .

Knowledge Article: Question: I am the authorised payroll vendor representing the company, can I update the employer particulars on behalf of my client?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your Corppass Administrator has granted you access to the "CPF Services For Employers And Business Partners" e-Service via the Corppass portal, you can update the employer particulars on behalf of your client.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to update my employer's contact information at both the “Account settings” and CPF EZPay?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You are only required to update employer's contact details under “ Account settings ”.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have renounced my citizenship/Permanent Residency (PR) and noticed that my CPF savings has been used to pay my outstanding MediShield Life premiums. Can I request for a refund?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There is no refund of the CPF savings used to pay your outstanding MediShield Life premiums because insurance coverage had been provided to you before you renounced your citizenship/PR.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is it mandatory for all companies to apply for a CPF Submission Number (CSN) with the CPF Board?
Knowledge Article: Answer: All employers are required to apply for a CPF Submission Number with the Board before they can submit their CPF contributions.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I apply for an additional CPF Submission Number (CSN) for my MOM Work Permit or for payroll segregation purposes?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To apply for an additional CPF Submission Number (CSN) for MOM Work Permit purposes or for payroll segregation, please submit your application using the Apply for CPF Submission Number form.   Do note that you need to have obtained prior approval from MOM's Work Pass Division before proceeding with the application for additional CSN for MOM Work Permit purposes.

Knowledge Article: Question: When and how do I obtain my CPF Submission Number (CSN) as a new employer?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You should apply for your CPF Submission Number (CSN) as soon as you intend to hire your first employee. You will need your Singpass and entity's Unique Entity Number (UEN) to complete the application. You can refer to this guide  on how you start contributing CPF as a new employer.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to apply for a new CPF Submission Number (CSN) if my subsidiary company has a different Unique Entity Number (UEN) from the parent company?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You are required to apply for a new CPF Submission Number (CSN) if your subsidiary company has a different Unique Entity Number (UEN) from the parent company. To apply for a CSN, please submit your application using Apply for CPF Submission Number .

Knowledge Article: Question: I disagree with MediShield Life coverage. Please do not cover me under MediShield Life. How can I appeal against MediShield Life coverage?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediShield Life provides universal coverage to all Singapore Citizens (SCs) and Permanent Residents (PRs) so that they have assurance against large healthcare bills. MediShield Life is mandatory for all SCs and PRs, as by sharing in the national risk pool, Singapore residents collectively play our part in supporting our healthcare costs.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I decide how to invest?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You need to establish a balance between risk and return that you are comfortable with. When establishing this balance, you should consider all the followings:   Your risk tolerance  - the amount of risk you are comfortable with and can afford to take. Can you still sleep at night if your investments have temporary short-term losses? Do you have enough savings that you can financially afford to take some investment risk? Your investment time horizon  - How long will your assets be invested? Your CPF savings are for the long term. Unless you are close to retirement or have a short-term investment time horizon for other reasons, you should generally invest for the long term, but you need to decide what "long" means to you. Your overall financial situation - How much money will you need to sustain your lifestyle during retirement? Do you have other assets set aside for retirement besides your CPF savings? How are all of those assets invested? What are your financial commitments?

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my CPF savings for the same property after effecting a voluntary housing refund to my account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use your Ordinary Account savings for the same property after effecting a voluntary housing refund to your account so long as you still have an outstanding loan.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens if I make a voluntary housing refund when I am 55 years old and above?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The refund amount will be transferred to your Retirement Account (RA) to meet your cohort’s Full Retirement Sum (FRS). This transfer will help boost your retirement savings and provide you with a higher monthly payout upon reaching your payout eligibility age.   When you turn 55 years old, you can withdraw at least $5,000 or any amount in excess after setting aside your FRS. Check the amount you can withdraw by logging in to your Retirement dashboard .

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I invest in shares listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) as long as they meet the inclusion criteria under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Board welcomes the inclusion of shares listed on the SGX Mainboard as long as they meet the inclusion criteria. However, some companies who meet the inclusion criteria have not applied to be included under CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS), and CPF savings cannot be used for these shares. You can refer to SGX website for the list of shares included under the CPFIS.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have renounced my Singapore Citizenship/Permanent Resident status, what will happen to my MediShield Life cover?
Knowledge Article: Answer: When MediShield was replaced by MediShield Life, the Government had given concession to a small number of foreigners with MediShield cover to continue their coverage under MediShield Life.   With the closure of CPF accounts for all foreigners on 1 April 2024, you will continue to be covered under MediShield Life as long as you continue to pay your premiums.   If you are using your own MediSave Account to pay the premiums and no alternative payment arrangements are made, your MediShield Life cover will lapse.   I am (i) residing overseas or (ii) have renounced my Singapore Citizenship/Permanent Resident status. How do I pay my CareShield Life/ElderShield/MediShield Life premiums?

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I cancel or terminate my MediShield Life cover?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediShield Life provides universal healthcare coverage to Singapore Citizens (SCs) and Permanent Residents (PRs) regardless of their pre-existing medical conditions, for life. Coverage is mandatory for SCs/PRs and cannot be cancelled or terminated. With every Singapore resident collectively supporting our healthcare costs by paying premiums and pooling our healthcare risks under MediShield Life, we can keep annual premiums affordable to support payouts for those of us who incur unexpectedly large hospital bills.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am no longer a Singaporean or a Permanent Resident. What will happen to my Dependants' Protection Scheme cover?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your Dependants’ Protection Scheme (DPS) cover will be terminated as the scheme is only applicable to Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents.   Your DPS insurer will refund any unused DPS premiums for the current policy year to your CPF account. The unused DPS premiums will be paid to you along with your CPF savings, when you transfer your savings to your bank account.   If you wish to find out more, please contact your DPS insurer, Great Eastern Life at dps-sg@greateasternlife.com .

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I terminate my Dependants' Protection Scheme cover?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Coverage under the Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) is not compulsory. You can terminate your DPS cover any time by completing the opt out form. Please approach your DPS insurer, Great Eastern Life for the form.   Please consider the benefits of DPS carefully before you terminate your DPS cover. Continuing with your DPS cover will provide some financial protection for your family. If you decide to join DPS again in the future, you will need to submit a health declaration again and the cover will be provided subject to you being in good health then.

Knowledge Article: Question: Who will be covered under Dependants' Protection Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: All Singaporeans and Permanent Residents between age 16 and 65 can be covered under Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS).   DPS coverage is automatically extended to Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents upon a valid CPF working contribution between 21 and 65 years old.   Members aged 16 and above who were not extended a DPS cover automatically but wish to be insured can apply to join DPS with Great Eastern Life directly.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can the repayment of the CPF Education Loan and interest be waived, especially during economic downturns?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF is primarily for members' retirement needs. Hence, while you can take a loan from your CPF Ordinary Account (OA) for your own or immediate family's tertiary education, the principal amount withdrawn has to be repaid to your OA, with the interest that you would otherwise have earned had the monies been left in your OA. This restores your CPF savings so that your retirement security is not worse off compared to not having taken the education loan. Retirement security remains important, if not more so, during economic downturns.    A waiver of the repayment is only allowed if you have already met your retirement needs, i.e. you are 55 years old and above and have set aside the Full Retirement Sum in your Retirement Account.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are my MediSave Account savings covered under CPF Nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF Nomination covers all savings in your MediSave Account, including those in your Ordinary, Special and Retirement Accounts.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is Dependants' Protection Scheme compulsory?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Coverage under the Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) is not compulsory. Insured members can contact their existing insurer, Great Eastern Life or NTUC Income, to terminate their DPS cover any time by completing the opt out form.   Members should consider the benefits of DPS carefully before he/she terminates his/her DPS cover. Continuing with the DPS cover will provide some financial protection for the member’s family. If members decide to rejoin DPS in the future, they will need to submit a health declaration again and the cover will be provided subject to them being in good health then.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the claim exclusions for Dependants' Protection Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Claim benefits under Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) will not be payable if any of the following events occur within the first policy year of the cover: Member committed self-inflicted injury or suicide Member committed a criminal offence punishable by death The claim arose out of member's own intentional criminal act DPS benefits are also not payable if: Member was not in good health before the commencement of DPS cover Member provided false or misleading information The claim arose from wars or any war-like operations or participation in any riot

Knowledge Article: Question: Even though I have been granted access to all e-Services in Corppass, I am still unable to login to CPF EZPay. What should I do?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Before you can access CPF EZPay, your Corppass Admin or Sub-Admin must set up and assign “CPF EZPay” e-Service to your CPF Submission Number(s) in the Corppass portal.   This is required even if you are granted access to all e-Services in Corppass portal. This is because access for CPF submissions is controlled at CSN level for authorised users.   You can refer to our guide to learn how to set up and assign CPF EZPay in Corppass portal.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I make CPF back payments for my employees?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can make back payments into your employees’ CPF accounts through CPF EZPay or CPF EZPay Mobile.   CPF EZPay   You can submit CPF contributions as per normal via CPF EZPay but select the correct Month and Year for your back payments. Please note that changes made will be saved to your employee database in CPF EZPay for future CPF submissions.   If you do not wish to affect your employee database in CPF EZPay for future CPF submissions, you can make use of the Submit ad hoc CPF payments option to submit your back payments instead. Auto-computation is not available for this option. However, you can load employee details from submissions made up to six months ago.   Here’s how to use the Submit ad hoc CPF payments option in CPF EZPay:   Select CPF EZPay Select For UEN-registered entities or For individuals trading under own name and login with your Singpass. Key in your CPF Submission Number (CSN). At Submit Contribution , select CPF EZPay . Key in the Month and Year . Select Submit ad hoc CPF payments (For one-time CPF submission (no auto-computation), or other ad hoc payments e.g. late payment interest). Enter the contribution details for the affected employee. After completing all of the contribution details and the summary portion, click on Continue . Confirm submission by clicking on your pre-arranged payment mode with the Board (Direct Debit/PayNow QR).   CPF EZPay Mobile   You can also submit CPF contributions via CPF EZPay Mobile and make payment via PayNow QR by selecting the correct Month and Year for your back payments. You can refer to this guide on how you can make a submission.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I select my preferred deduction date now that the default direct deduction date is set at two working days after the submission date?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can select your preferred deduction date. Please click on the calendar icon under the Direct Debit option to change the date before submitting the contributions.

Knowledge Article: Question: When and how can I submit CPF contributions after obtaining my new CPF Submission Number?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may submit your CPF contributions via the following methods:   Submitting Your CPF Contributions via CPF EZPay Mobile   If your CSN application was submitted before 5pm, you can submit your CPF contributions via CPF EZPay Mobile the next day.   Submitting Your CPF Contributions via CPF EZPay   If your CSN application was submitted before 5pm, you can submit your CPF contributions via CPF EZPay two days later.   Note: For UEN-registered entity, please be reminded to perform a one-time setup at Corppass portal before you can login to CPF EZPay.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I check the status of my submission? What do the different Submission Status under the View / Amend / Delete Submission screen mean?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To view the status of your submission, please login to CPF EZPay and select View / Amend / Delete Submission option under Manage Records & Preferences section of the Main Menu .   Please refer to the chart below for the different submission status.   Submission Status What it means Draft This submission is incomplete and CPF has not received your submission yet. Submitted This submission will be processed after 5.15pm daily. Therefore, if there are any errors in the submission, you may amend or delete your submission before it is processed. Processed Submission was successfully processed.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the difference between the Administrator and Editor?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The table below summarises the roles of the Administrator and Editor within CPF EZPay.   Entity Type Administrator Role Editor Role UEN registered entities Update email addresses for ‘Persons in charge of CPF contribution matters’ (only applicable for employers holding CSN for voluntary contributions) Submit CPF contributions on behalf of the company      View previously submitted CPF contribution details Submit CPF contributions on behalf of the company View previously submitted CPF contribution details Individuals trading under own name Update email addresses for ‘Persons in charge of CPF contribution matters’ (only applicable for employers holding CSN for voluntary contributions) Add and Delete Administrator(s) /Editor(s) Submit CPF contributions on behalf of the company       View previously submitted CPF contribution details Submit CPF contributions on behalf of the company View previously submitted CPF contribution details

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I know if I have completed my CPF submission?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Once you have completed your submission, you will see an acknowledgement page called “CPF EZPay Acknowledgment”. You can view or save this page by clicking on the printer icon which you will be prompted to download a PDF. You will not be able to save or print this acknowledgment page if you closed your internet browser.   You will also receive an email acknowledgement if your email address is registered in 'Account settings'.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I check if my company has been successfully registered for CPF EZPay?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will be notified via your registered email address once your company has been successfully registered for CPF EZPay.

Knowledge Article: Question: Does CPF EZPay compute Additional Wage (AW) Ceiling?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF EZPay does not compute AW Ceiling as it does not track wages on an annual basis. You may use our  CPF Additional Wage Ceiling Calculator to calculate the AW Ceiling or do so manually.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am submitting CPF contributions via CPF EZPay. How can I link up my CPF data for the Auto Inclusion Scheme (AIS) under IRAS?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can visit IRAS website to sign up for the CPF Data Link-up Service.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I print the CPF EZPay acknowledgement if I have closed the browser?
Knowledge Article: Answer: It is not possible to print the "CPF EZPay Acknowledgement" page once you have closed the browser.   Instead, you may login to our CPF EZPay to view the status of your submission.   You will also receive an email from the Board within the day acknowledging the receipt of your submission.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is there a limit to the number of submissions I can perform each day using CPF EZPay?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There are different limits to the number of CPF submissions that you can perform each day.   CPF EZPay   You can submit up to 99 submissions within the day. If you try to make additional submissions, our system will prompt you with the message “A file with the same advice code has already been submitted”.   CPF EZPay (FTP)   Multiple file submissions within the same day are allowed, provided a different advice code is used in the submission file. If you are submitting a file using the same advice code or more than 99 files, you will be prompted with a message “A file with the same advice code has been already submitted. Please change the advice code and re-submit”.   For more information on how to assign an advice code, please refer to  CPF EZPay FTP guide (PDF, 3.7MB).

Knowledge Article: Question: I currently submit CPF contributions using my own payroll software. How do I switch to CPF EZPay?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are currently submitting CPF contributions within your payroll software, you are already registered for CPF EZPay as well. Simply login to CPF EZPay from our CPF website to submit your monthly CPF contributions using CPF EZPay.   Find out more  about the various ways you can submit your CPF contributions using CPF EZPay.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is CPF EZPay?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF EZPay is a free service provided by CPF Board where employers can submit their employees’ CPF contribution details and make payment electronically.   Find out how you can submit CPF contributions easily via CPF EZPay and make payment using Direct Debit .   To find out more about how to use CPF EZPay, you may refer to the User Guide (PDF, 2.0MB) or watch the Video Guide on YouTube.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the period for income declaration to IRAS?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you receive a notification (via letter/form/SMS) to file tax from IRAS, or you meet the requirement to file tax (i.e. NTI above $6,000 and/or Total Income above $22,000), please complete and submit the tax return to IRAS directly. The income tax filing period is from 1 March to 18 April annually.   If you do not receive a notification from IRAS or do not meet the requirement to file tax, you can declare your self-employed net trade income (NTI) to IRAS via myTax Portal which will be available from 1 March to 31 October annually for taxpayers to e-File tax returns.   Once IRAS has assessed your income for the year, your assessed NTI will be transmitted to the Board. You can check your updated NTI records by logging in to the Self-employment dashboard with your Singpass.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I apply for Corppass access to submit CPF contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: A UEN-registered entity can apply for Corppass access at the Corppass portal .   Before using CPF EZPay for the first time, you will need to perform a one-time setup in Corppass portal after you have obtained Corppass access. You can refer to this guide on how to set up and assign CPF EZPay in Corppass portal.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long will CPF Board take to process my application for CPF EZPay?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The service standard for processing CPF EZPay application is as follows:   Service Processing Time CPF EZPay Three working days

Knowledge Article: Question: The employee's name I submitted is different from the name in his/her NRIC, what should I do?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contribution will be credited to employee's CPF account based on NRIC despite the mismatched name. Any mismatch in the name and NRIC for new hires who are contributing their CPF for the first time with the employer will be flagged out once in the ROP. Employers are required to correct employee's name in the next CPF submission.   If you have paid CPF contributions to the intended employee   Please remember to update your employee's name as shown in his/her NRIC in your next CPF submission. Kindly note that matching is only done on the principal name, so you should not key in variants such as hanyu pinyin and aliases.   If you have paid CPF contributions to the wrong employee   Please request for refund   or  adjustment of CPF contributions immediately.   Any errors in CPF contributions should be rectified early while the documentary evidence is fresh. Request for refund or adjustment of CPF contributions Online must be made within one year from the date of payment of the CPF .   You can refer to the 'Payment Received on' field in the Record of Payment to determine the date of payment.

Knowledge Article: Question: How is the Year-in-Review different from the CPF Yearly Statement of Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Year-in-Review (YIR) is designed to give you an overview of your CPF account balances, inflow and outflow in the last 12 months from your birthday month. It also includes key milestones within the last 12 months and things to look out for in the next 12 months from your birthday month. You will also see a link to the CPF Retirement Planning Service which allows you to set your own retirement goal.   The CPF Yearly Statement of Account (YSOA) will give you an overview of your CPF transactions for the past calendar year.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the Year-in-Review?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Year-in-Review (YIR) is a personalised statement prepared for you on your birthday. When you open your YIR, you will see an overview of your CPF account balances, inflow and outflow and key milestones in the last 12 months from your birthday month. It will also inform you on what to look out for in the next 12 months. The YIR also includes useful resources and steps that you can consider to start your retirement planning. Your YIR will be refreshed every year on your birthday. You can access your YIR (Singpass required) if you have celebrated your birthday this year. Otherwise, you can look forward to receiving your YIR on your birthday. View the YIR guide on how to read your YIR.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I read my Year-in-Review?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can view the guide on the Year-in-Review (YIR) below:   Year-in-Review Guide (PDF, 0.56MB)

Knowledge Article: Question: I would like to check my past transaction records. How can I do so?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can access transactions up to the past 15 months via Singpass login at my cpf digital services .

Knowledge Article: Question: The format of my monthly transaction statement looks different from that received previously. Can I request to receive it in the previous format?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF Monthly Transaction Statement was redesigned to improve user-friendliness and experience across all devices. We understand that you would like to have your statement displayed in the previous format. You can view your statement in tabular form in the PDF version by using your laptop/desktop to access the link provided in the email notification and clicking on the PDF icon found on the top right corner of the statement page.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I view my employment contribution details in my Transaction History?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To view your CPF working contribution details, you can use the newly introduced filter options for “Employment Contributions” and “Self-Employed Contributions” under the Transaction History. These options allow you to display either one or both types of contributions, making it easier for you to track them.

Knowledge Article: Question: Where can I view my Contribution History?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We have introduced a new filter feature in the Transaction History that allows you to view your CPF transactions or CPF working contributions more seamlessly in a single statement. With this new feature, you can view your CPF working contributions in your Transaction History, by selecting the “Employment Contributions” and/or “Self-Employed Contributions” category(ies) in the Transaction History filter.   For more information on the new feature, please refer to the FAQ on ‘ How can I view my employment contribution details in my Transaction History? ’

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use MediSave savings for Assisted Conception Procedure (ACP) treatments?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediSave withdrawal limits for ACP treatments

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the Drive and Save (DAS) Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Drive and Save (DAS) Scheme is a tripartite co-contribution scheme initiated by the National Taxi Association (NTA) and the taxi industry, and supported by the Ministry of Manpower and CPF Board. DAS aims to enhance the welfare of all taxi principal hirers.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the Drive and Save (DAS) Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Drive and Save (DAS) Scheme is a tripartite co-contribution scheme initiated by the National Taxi Association (NTA) and the taxi industry, and supported by the Ministry of Manpower and CPF Board. DAS aims to enhance the welfare of all taxi principal hirers.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the MediSave Maternity Package?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The MediSave Maternity Package is a package that allows MediSave to be used to pay expenses incurred during delivery and pre-delivery medical expenses such as consultations, ultrasounds, tests, medications etc.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my MediSave for my maternity expenses?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediSave can be used to pay for the delivery and pre-delivery medical expenses.   Pre-delivery expenses have to be claimed under the MediSave Maternity Package. However, post-natal consultation fees cannot be claimed under MediSave.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is the threshold for total CPF contributions set at $140,000 to be eligible for the Silver Support Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: An eligibility criterion of $140,000 set for the Silver Support Scheme would include seniors who were earning lower wages through their working lives, and those who did not work due to reasons such as care-giving responsibilities and medical conditions.   The Total CPF Contributions threshold was increased from $70,000 to $140,000 in 2021 to strengthen support for seniors with lesser means. The Government will review the criteria from time to time, to ensure that the Silver Support Scheme is able to reach those who need it most.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is the age cut-off for total CPF contributions set at 55 for the assessment of eligibility for the Silver Support Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For the assessment of eligibility for the Silver Support Scheme, we do not look at CPF contributions after the age of 55, so as to encourage older Singaporeans to continue working and saving for retirement.   We have also set the cut-off age at 55 to provide a meaningful comparison across cohorts, which experience different sets of CPF withdrawal rules and wage adjustments after age 55.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why are my total CPF contributions used as a reflection of my lifetime wages in the assessment of eligibility of the Silver Support Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are proportionate to a person’s wage. They thus serve as an indicator of one’s ability to save.   We will look at the senior’s total CPF contributions by the age of 55 to assess his/her eligibility for the Silver Support Scheme. This refers to the sum of contributions to the Ordinary Account (OA) and Special Account (SA), as well as any CPF savings that had been withdrawn for housing, investment and education.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I receive SMS notifications on my Silver Support Payments?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We will send SMS notifications on Silver Support (SS) payments to the mobile number that you have registered with CPF Board.   To receive SMS notifications on your SS payments, you may update your mobile number via my cpf digital services – Account settings with your Singpass.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to apply for the Silver Support Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There is no need to apply for the Silver Support (SS) Scheme.   CPF Board will automatically review your eligibility for the SS Scheme every year. Eligible seniors will automatically receive SS every quarter.   Seniors who qualify will receive a notification from CPF Board in December of the preceding year.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much Silver Support will I receive?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Eligible seniors will receive Silver Support (SS) every quarter, depending on their household monthly income per person, and the type of HDB flat that they live in. Those living in smaller flats will receive higher SS.   HDB Flat Type Silver Support Per Quarter ^ Household monthly income per person not more than $1,300 Household monthly income per person is more than $1,300 and not more than $1,800 1- and 2-Room $900 $450 3-Room $720 $360 4-Room $540 $270 5-Room* $360 $180   *Live in and do not own a 5-room HDB flat.   ^ All Singaporeans aged 65 and above who are ComCare Long Term Assistance (LTA) recipients will receive SS of $360 per quarter, regardless of their flat type.   Silver Support will be enhanced in 2025. For the updated Silver Support payment from 2025, please refer to our  FAQs .   Eligible seniors will receive Silver Support (SS) according to the following schedule.   Payment Date For period 31 December of the preceding year January - March 31 March April - June 30 June July - September 30 September October - December   Those who turn 65 in the year will start receiving SS in the quarter they turn 65.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am a ComCare Long Term Assistance (previously known as Public Assistance) recipient who is receiving Silver Support. Can I qualify for higher Silver Support?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Seniors aged 65 and above on the ComCare Long Term Assistance (LTA) Scheme will automatically qualify for the Silver Support (SS) Scheme and receive a flat amount of $360 per quarter ^ , regardless of their HDB flat type.   The SS supplements the assistance that ComCare LTA beneficiaries receive, which includes monthly cash assistance to cover the recipient's daily living expenses, assistance with their medical bills at public healthcare institutions, and free or highly subsidised social services such as home help or Active Ageing Centres funded by the government.   ^ Silver Support will be enhanced in 2025. For the updated Silver Support payments in 2025, please refer to our FAQs here .

Knowledge Article: Question: I am a Pioneer Generation / Merdeka Generation member. Will I automatically qualify for the Silver Support Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Pioneer and Merdeka Generation members do not automatically qualify for the Silver Support (SS) Scheme.   The SS Scheme is meant for seniors who had low incomes during their working years and now have less in retirement.   The Pioneer Generation (PG) and Merdeka Generation (MG) Packages are one-off schemes to honour PG and MG seniors for their contributions in the early years of Singapore's nation-building.   PG and MG members will be means-tested for SS like all other seniors aged 65 and above, and those who meet the eligibility criteria will receive SS.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I qualify for the Silver Support Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Silver Support (SS) Scheme is meant to support seniors who had low incomes during their working years and now have less in retirement. To identify this target group, three criteria are used in tandem – lifetime wages, housing type, and the level of household support.   Singapore citizens aged 65 and above will be eligible for the SS Scheme if they meet all of the following criteria:   1. Low lifetime wages - Total CPF contributions* by age 55 is not more than $140,000. Self-employed persons should also have an average annual net trade income #  of not more than $27,600 when they were between the ages of 45 and 54; and   2. Housing type  - Live in a 1- to 5-room HDB flat; and do not own, or have a spouse who owns, a 5-room or larger HDB flat, private property or multiple properties; and   3. Low household support  - Live in a household with a monthly income per person of not more than $1,800.   Silver Support will be enhanced in 2025. For the updated eligibility criteria from 2025, please refer to our FAQs .   CPF Board will automatically review your eligibility for SS every year. Seniors who qualify for the Silver Support (SS) Scheme will receive a notification in December of the preceding year.   Eligible seniors turning age 65 will be notified of their eligibility in December of the year before they turn 65. They will start receiving SS in the quarter they turn 65.   In addition to the notification, all Singaporeans aged 65 and above can check their SS eligibility by logging in to the SS e-services using their Singpass.   *Total CPF contributions refers to the total sum in an individual’s Ordinary Account and Special Account, including the amounts withdrawn for housing, education and investment.   # Net trade income refers to the gross trade income minus all allowable business expenses, capital allowances and trade losses as determined by IRAS.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the Silver Support Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Silver Support (SS) Scheme is part of a wider suite of schemes (e.g. healthcare subsidies, GST voucher) that the Government has put in place to give seniors greater assurance in retirement.   It provides a quarterly cash supplement to seniors who had low incomes during their working years and now have less in retirement. The Government reviews the Scheme periodically to ensure that it continues to target deserving seniors.   Seniors who qualify for SS will automatically receive their cash supplement. There is no need to apply.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I check if I will be eligible for the enhanced Silver Support Scheme in 2025 onwards?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are eligible, we will send you a letter in December 2024 to inform you on your 2025 eligibility. Alternatively, you can log in to our SSS e-services end of December 2024 to check on your eligibility.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can Permanent Residents qualify for the Silver Support Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Only Singapore Citizens are eligible for the Silver Support Scheme.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is a senior not eligible for the Silver Support Scheme if he and/or his spouse together own a 5-room or larger HDB flat, private property or multiple properties?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The type of home owned is an indicator of the senior’s resources. Those who own a 5-room or larger HDB flat, private property or multiple properties are more likely to have more resources and access to additional retirement income. They would be less likely to require assistance through the Silver Support (SS) Scheme.   There are other schemes to help seniors cope with daily expenses, finance their healthcare needs and increase their retirement savings. Even if you do not qualify for the SS, you can still benefit from many of these schemes.   Those who need additional support can turn to other forms of assistance such as ComCare and MediFund. They may wish to approach a nearby Social Service Office for assistance.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I participate in the Drive and Save (DAS) scheme, will my Taxi Vocational Licence (TDVL) be automatically renewed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, your Taxi Driver Vocational Licence (TDVL) will not be automatically renewed if you participate in the Drive and Save (DAS) scheme.   Taxi principal hirers must have fully paid their MediSave contributions or are making monthly payments via GIRO to renew their TDVLs.   Your MediSave contributions and the co-contributions from your taxi operators will go towards meeting your self-employed MediSave payable.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is the threshold for household monthly income per person set at $1,800 to be eligible for the Silver Support Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Silver Support (SS) Scheme is meant for seniors who had low incomes during their working years and now have less in retirement.   The threshold of $1,800 ^ enables seniors who have little or no family support to benefit from SS.   ^ Silver Support will be enhanced in 2025. For the updated Silver Support eligibility criteria and payments from 2025, please refer to our FAQs here .

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I register for the Drive and Save (DAS) Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No registration is required for the Drive and Save (DAS) Scheme.   Taxi principal hirers who contribute at least $20 monthly to their MediSave Account will be eligible to receive a co-contribution of $20* monthly from their taxi operators.   *Terms and conditions apply

Knowledge Article: Question: I received a call/email/letter claiming they are from the Household Means Eligibility System (HOMES). Are they legitimate?
Knowledge Article: Answer: HOMES is a Government system supporting the Silver Support (SS) Scheme in conducting household means-tests, which are used to assess a senior’s eligibility for the SS Scheme. If you or your family member had asked for a reassessment of SS eligibility, and there is a need for further clarification regarding your household information, the HOMES team may contact you via phone, email or letter to find out more on your household circumstances.   If you are unsure of the authenticity of the mobile number that you have received, please call their hotline 6818 1422 for confirmation.   If you have any query on HOMES, you may visit the  HOMES website to provide your contact details and a brief description of your query.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am a self-employed person. How will the Government assess my eligibility for the Silver Support Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As it is not mandatory for self-employed persons to contribute to their Ordinary and Special Accounts, self-employed persons would naturally have made less CPF contributions than employees.   For seniors who were self-employed in their working years, we will consider their average annual net trade income, as determined by their annual income tax assessments, in addition to the total CPF contributions they made by the age of 55.   To qualify for the Silver Support Scheme, their average annual net trade income should be not more than $27,600 between the ages of 45 and 54. The average annual net trade income threshold was increased from $22,800 to $27,600 in 2021 to strengthen support for seniors with lesser means. The Government will review the threshold from time to time, to ensure that the Silver Support Scheme is able to reach those who need it most.

Knowledge Article: Question: What sources of MediSave contributions are eligible for Drive and Save (DAS) co-contribution?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediSave contributions 1  made by the taxi principal hirer to offset MediSave payable will qualify him for Drive and Save (DAS) co-contribution. CPF contributions received as an employee (from both employer and self) for taxi principal hirers who are concurrently employed, as well as government top-ups are excluded. 1  You may make payment for your MediSave payable via  Manage your MediSave payable  or  GIRO .

Knowledge Article: Question: I am a Board Member/ Director. Am I considered a self-employed person, and do I have to contribute to my CPF?
Knowledge Article: Answer: It depends on the nature of your relationship with the company, and the nature of the moneys received.   If you’re engaged as a Board Member or Director under a contract of employment (or Contract of Service) with the company, you’ll have to contribute to your CPF as an employee.   If you’re engaged in a business, profession or vocation of providing services as a Board Member or Director to companies, you’ll have to contribute to your MediSave as a self-employed person (SEP).   Please visit the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) website for the differences in treatment between employees and SEPs.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do you determine my housing type when assessing my eligibility for the Silver Support Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your housing type is based on your address as registered in your NRIC.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is HOMES?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The  Household Means Eligibility System (HOMES) is a Government system supporting public schemes, including the Silver Support Scheme, in their conduct of means-tests as part of their assessment in determining the level of assistance for them.

Knowledge Article: Question: What do I need to do to receive Workfare Income Supplement (WIS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are an employee, you do not need to do anything. Your eligibility for Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) will be automatically assessed based on the CPF contributions* made by your employer.   If you are a Self-Employed Person (SEP), you will need to:   • declare your Net Trade Income (NTI) from Work Year 2023 to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS). If you receive a notification (via letter/form/SMS) to file tax from IRAS, or you meet the requirement to file tax (i.e. NTI above $6,000 and/or Total Income above $22,000), please complete and submit the tax return to IRAS directly. The income tax filing period is from 1 March to 18 April annually.   If you do not receive a notification from IRAS or do not meet the requirement to file tax, you will need to declare your self-employed NTI to IRAS via  myTax Portal  which will be available from 1 March to 31 October annually for taxpayers to e-File tax returns; and   • make the full required MediSave contributions:   If your NTI is more than $6,000 You are required to make MediSave contribution to fulfil the liability under the Self-Employed Scheme (SES) . Your MediSave contribution is due 30 days from the date of issuance of the Notice of Computation (NOC) from IRAS or Notice of Contribution from CPF Board.  Estimate how much MediSave to contribute to receive WIS by using the WIS calculator for SEPs.   If your NTI is $6,000 or less You are not required to pay MediSave contribution under SES. However, in order to qualify for WIS, you will be required to make MediSave contributions within 2 years after the year you worked. E.g. if you worked in 2024, you will need to make the Medisave contributions by 31 December 2026. Please see the following for the required amount of MediSave contribution to qualify for WIS if your NTI is $6,000 or less, according to your age in the year you worked:   30 to 34 years 35 to 44 years 45 to 49 years 50 years and above $240 $270 $300 $315   If you have declared your income to IRAS and have yet to receive your NOC from IRAS by 31 January two years after the WY (e.g. by 31 January 2025 for WY2023), you may write to us  using your Singpass for the Board to assess your eligibility for WIS. Do note that you must also contribute to your MediSave by the specified timelines to receive WIS.   *Under the CPF Act, employers must contribute CPF if their employees earn more than $50 a month, regardless of whether the employee is employed on a permanent, part-time, contract or casual basis. If your employer is not contributing CPF on your behalf, please approach your employer to clarify on the discrepancies. If your employer does not provide you with a satisfactory response, you can lodge a report with CPF Board.

Knowledge Article: Question: Am I eligible for the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will be eligible for the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme if you:   i. are a Singapore Citizen;   ii. are at least 30 years old or older on 31 December of the Work Year or are a person with disability of any age;   iii. earn a gross monthly income 1 of at least $500 2 , but not more than $2,500 for the month worked and in the past 12 months 3 (average gross monthly income) as an employee; or have an average monthly income of at least $500, but not more than $2,500 as a Self-Employed Person (SEP).   If you are an SEP, you are also required to declare your Net Trade Income (NTI) and make your MediSave contributions to be eligible for WIS.   iv. live in a property with an annual value 4 of $21,000 and below from Work Year 2024 ($13,000 and below for WY2023), assessed as at 31 December of the preceding year;   v. own not more than one property; and   vi. if you are married,   you and your spouse together own not more than one property; and the assessable income of your spouse does not exceed $70,000 for the preceding Year of Assessment.   For work done in Work Year 2022 and earlier:   You will be eligible for Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme if you:   i. are a Singapore Citizen;   ii. are at least 35 years old as of 31 December of the Work Year;   iii. and earned a gross monthly income 1 of not more than $2,300 for the month worked and in the past 12 months 3 (average gross monthly income) as an employee; or had an average monthly income of not more than $2,300 as a Self-Employed Person (SEP).   If you are an SEP, you are also required to declare your Net Trade Income (NTI) and make your MediSave contributions to be eligible for WIS.   iv. live in a property with an annual value 4 of $13,000 and below, assessed as at 31 December of the previous year;   v. own not more than one property; and   vi. if you are married;   you and your spouse together own not more than one property; and the assessable income of your spouse does not exceeds $70,000 for the previous Year of Assessment.   Please refer to this  link to find out your WIS eligibility status. WIS will be enhanced in 2025. For the updated eligibility criteria from 2025, please refer to our FAQs here .   1 Includes basic salary and extra wages such as overtime pay, commissions and bonuses   2 Persons with disabilities, workers who qualify for ComCare Short-to-Medium-Term Assistance and caregivers of care recipients (generally include caregivers residing with care recipients who are medically certified to have permanent moderate to severe disabilities) will qualify for concessionary WIS, even if they earn less than $500. Eligible caregivers have started receiving concessionary WIS for Work Year 2023 onwards.   3 Defined as income earned in the past 12-month period ÷ Total number of months worked in the past 12-month period   4 Annual value is the estimated gross annual rent of the property if it were to be rented out, excluding furniture, furnishings and maintenance fees. It is determined based on estimated market rentals of similar or comparable properties.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme was introduced in 2007 as a permanent feature of Singapore's social security system. The support is targeted at lower-wage Singaporean workers whose earnings are in the bottom 20% of the working population, with some support to those slightly above, and is reviewed regularly to ensure that it meets the needs of Singaporeans.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the enhancements to the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) from 2025 onwards?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The enhancements to WIS, which will take effect from 2025 onwards, are as follows:   i. Qualifying monthly wage cap raised from $2,500 to $3,000 1 . This takes into account wage growth of Singaporeans.   ii. Higher annual WIS payments of up to $4,900 . Payments depend on age and wages, and have been enhanced across all age bands. Eligible employees can receive up to $4,900 per year in payments, compared to $4,200 per year today (refer to table below). Older workers and all persons with disabilities will continue to receive the highest payments. The payments for self-employed persons are set at two-thirds of employee payments and will be correspondingly increased.   1 In addition, the worker must earn an average gross monthly wage of not more than $3,000 in the past 12 months.   Maximum Annual Workfare Payment for Employees*   Age Band (For Work Done from 1 Jan 2023) (For Work Done from 1 Jan 2025) 30-34 $2,100 $2,450 35-44 $3,000 $3,500 45-59 $3,600 $4,200 60 & above $4,200 $4,900 All persons with disabilities $4,200 $4,900   * The payment amounts depend on actual wages. The payments for self-employed persons are set at two-thirds of employee payments.

Knowledge Article: Question: What will happen if I pay late or do not pay CPF contributions for my employees?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If we detect CPF non-compliance, which includes late payment and non-payment of CPF contributions, we will take enforcement actions to recover any CPF contributions owed to employees. We may charge late payment interest and impose composition amount on non-compliant employers. Please refer to the Recovery Process (PDF, 0.1MB).

Knowledge Article: Question: My employee owes me money. Can I use the amount owed to me to offset the employer's share of CPF contributions that is payable on his wages?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You are required to pay both the employer and employee’s share of CPF contributions based on the monthly wages payable to your employee at the prevailing CPF contribution rates.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much composition amount should I pay?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The composition amount is indicated in the letter of offer/notice to attend court. Please refer to the penalties that may be faced by employers who do not comply with the CPF Act .

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is household monthly income per person used as an indication of my household support for the Silver Support Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Silver Support (SS) Scheme is meant for seniors who had low incomes during their working years and now have less in retirement.   To automatically identify seniors who are eligible for SS, the Government has to rely on available data as broad indicators of an individual’s ability to save for retirement, access to resources and family support.   We have relied on the household monthly income per person as a broad indicator of the level of family support available.

Knowledge Article: Question: Who is a self-employed person?
Knowledge Article: Answer: A self-employed person (SEP) is someone who performs work for others under a contract for service.   If you earn an income by buying and selling goods or from providing professional or personal services, you’re an SEP. Examples of SEPs include hawkers, taxi drivers, freelancers, sole proprietors or a partner in a partnership.   Visit the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) website to read more on the definition of an SEP.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the purpose of the late payment interest?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The late payment interest, subjected to a minimum amount of $5, serves to deter employers from paying CPF contributions late for their employees.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I check the outstanding loan amount repayable under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are a CPF lender whose CPF savings have been withdrawn from your Ordinary Account (OA), you can log in to your Education dashboard with your Singpass and click on "Loans by your borrowers" to view the outstanding amount to be repaid to your OA.   Please note that the outstanding loan amount includes the accrued interest that would have been earned if the monies were not withdrawn for education. The borrower needs to repay the accrued interest to fully restore the savings in your OA.   If you are a borrower making repayments, you can check your outstanding loan amount by logging in to your Education dashboard with your Singpass.

Knowledge Article: Question: How does CPF Board calculate interest on late payment?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The due date for CPF contributions is on the last day of the calendar month. Enforcement action would be taken against employers who fail to pay by the 14 th of the following month (or the next working day if the 14 th falls on a Saturday, Sunday or Public Holiday). This includes imposing late payment interest charged at 1.5% per month commencing from the first day after the due date. The minimum interest payable is $5.   Example   XYZ Company made a CPF contribution of $3,000 for the month of October on 20 November . This payment is late by 19 days. Therefore, the amount of late payment interest will be:   = $3,000 x 1.5% x 19/30 (stop at the fourth decimal)*   = $28.50   *Number of days the payment is late/number of days in the month.   The final figure is to be rounded down to the nearest dollar, i.e. the cents should be dropped for the interest. Hence, the late payment interest payable will be $28.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why should I be jailed for non-payment of CPF contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF Board takes a serious view on employers who do not fulfil their CPF obligations to their employees. The jail term reflects the severity of CPF offences and serves as a strong deterrence to errant employers. It is also a reminder of the importance of employers’ legal obligation to pay CPF contributions correctly and promptly for their employees.   If we detect CPF non-compliance, which includes late payment and non-payment of CPF contributions, we will take enforcement actions to recover any CPF contributions owed to employees. We may charge late payment interest and impose composition amount on non-compliant employers.   If you fail to pay the CPF arrears, you will be taken to court. The court will order you to pay the contributions, interest as well as a court fine and/or be sentenced to imprisonment.   The penalties stipulated under the CPF Act for employers convicted of late payment offence are:   Up to $5,000 court fine and no less than $1,000 per offence and/or up to 6 months’ imprisonment for first conviction Up to $10,000 court fine and no less than $2,000 per offence and/or up to 12 months’ imprisonment for subsequent convictions

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is composition amount imposed on employer?
Knowledge Article: Answer: It is an offence under the CPF Act for late and/or non-payment of CPF contributions and late payment interest. The composition amount is offered to allow defaulting employers to settle their CPF offences out of court, after settling the CPF arrears.   Prosecution actions will be taken against employers who do not settle the CPF arrears and compound the offence out of court, before the deadline given.

Knowledge Article: Question: I incurred late payment interest for my employee's late CPF contribution as he did not inform me of his Singapore Permanent Resident status. Can I recover the interest from him?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The late payment interest is payable by the employer. It is an offence for employers to recover any sum in excess of the employee's share of CPF contributions from his wages.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I declare my net trade income from Work Year 2023 (Year of Assessment 2024) onwards?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For Work Year 2023 (WY2023) onwards All Net Trade Income (NTI) declarations for Work Year 2023 (Year of Assessment 2024) can be made with the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) by filing a tax return. There is no need to file separate declarations with CPF Board.   If you receive a notification (via letter/form/SMS) to file tax from IRAS, or you meet the requirement to file tax (i.e. NTI above $6,000 and/or Total Income above $22,000), please complete and submit the tax return to IRAS directly. The income tax filing period is from 1 March to 18 April annually.   If you do not receive a notification from IRAS or do not meet the requirement to file tax, you can declare your self-employed net trade income (NTI) to IRAS via myTax Portal which will be available from 1 March to 31 October annually for taxpayers to e-File tax returns.   Once IRAS has assessed your income for the year, your assessed NTI will be transmitted to the Board. You can check your updated NTI records by logging in to the Self-employment dashboard with your Singpass.   If you have declared your NTI with IRAS, you need not declare your income again to CPF Board.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why can't I access the online nomination witnessing request that was sent to me?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will not be able to access the online nomination witnessing request if:   the nomination application had expired (after seven calendar days from application date); the member making the CPF nomination has withdrawn the nomination; or you have already completed witnessing the nomination.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will my nominee(s) be notified when I make a nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your nomination is confidential. We will not disclose your nomination details to anyone, including your nominee(s). We will only contact your nominee(s) regarding the distribution of your CPF savings when you pass away.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens if one or all of my nominees pass away?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your nominee passes on before you, his/her share will be given to the surviving nominee(s) in the same proportion you have specified.   If there are no surviving nominee(s), your nomination is considered revoked and your savings will be transferred to the Public Trustee’s Office for distribution under the intestacy or Muslim Inheritance laws.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should you do if you want to nominate Majlis Ugama Islam Singapura (Muis), Mosques, or Madrasahs as your CPF nominee?
Knowledge Article: Answer: All CPF nominations must be to a legal entity. All mosques and madrasahs in Singapore are vested entities of Majlis Ugama Islam Singapura (Muis).   If you intend to nominate any mosque or madrasah, or Muis, appoint Muis as a nominee by indicating the Unique Entity Number (UEN) T08GB0028L in the ‘Registration number of organisation’ field.   Once done, inform Muis via this form  https://go.gov.sg/muis-cpfnomination . This will ensure that your CPF savings are directed to your intended entity.   For more information, please contact Muis at  https://www.muis.gov.sg/Contact-Info .

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens if I have children after making my CPF nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Childbirth does not change your existing CPF nomination. However, you should make a new nomination if you wish to include your child as one of the beneficiaries of your CPF savings.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use MediSave to fully pay for my chronic diseases treatment?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You only need to co-pay 15% of the bill for your chronic diseases treatment in cash before using MediSave to pay the rest. This is to help you conserve some of your MediSave savings for future healthcare needs.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is there a minimum age for making a CPF nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF members should be of sufficient maturity when they make a decision to nominate and bequeath their CPF savings. Therefore, a minimum age of 16 is set for making a nomination, in line with the minimum age to work and earn wages under the Employment Act.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is a legal entity?
Knowledge Article: Answer: A legal entity is a legal body capable of receiving monies, including CPF savings in its own right.   For an entity to be capable of receiving monies, it has to be recognised under the law as being capable of doing certain things in its own name and not in the name of its members, such as owning and holding property, suing others and being sued. Such entities would include societies registered under the Societies Act (Cap. 311), companies (including public companies limited by guarantee) registered under the Companies Act (Cap.50), and limited liability partnerships (LLP) registered under the Limited Liability Partnerships Act (/cap. 163A).

Knowledge Article: Question: What is ElderFund?
Knowledge Article: Answer: ElderFund is a discretionary assistance scheme, officially launched in end Jan 2020. It is targeted at assisting severely disabled lower-income Singapore Citizens aged 30 and above, who are not able to benefit from CareShield Life, ElderShield and Interim Disability Assistance Programme for the Elderly (IDAPE), and have low MediSave balances and inadequate personal savings to meet their long-term care needs.   Eligible Singapore Citizens can receive up to $250 in monthly cash payouts for as long as they remain severely disabled.   For more FAQs on ElderFund, please visit the AIC website .

Knowledge Article: Question: Who manages MediShield Life?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediShield Life is administered by the Central Provident Fund Board on behalf of the Ministry of Health.

Knowledge Article: Question: When will my MediShield Life coverage cease?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your MediShield Life cover will be terminated when you pass away or renounce your Singapore citizenship/Permanent Residency. Premiums for the unused period will be refunded to the premium payer’s MediSave Account.   The payer may view the refunded premium (if any) at Transaction history statement under “Contributions / Government Cash Grant / Government Top-up".

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the hotline for MediShield Life?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For MediShield Life enquiries, contact us at 1800 222 3399 /65 6222 3399 (overseas) from Monday to Friday, 8.30am to 5.30pm (GMT8 / excluding public holidays). You can also write to us .

Knowledge Article: Question: I have just obtained my Singapore Permanent Resident status. When is the start date of my MediShield Life cover?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your MediShield Life cover will commence on the date that Immigration Checkpoints Authority (ICA) grants you your Permanent Residency status.

Knowledge Article: Question: How does diversification helps to limit my risk in investing?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Diversification, or spreading your assets among several investments, helps you smooth out potential ups and downs of your investment returns. Even if one investment does poorly, the others may do better, thereby potentially improving your overall return. You can diversify your investments at two distinct levels by spreading your investments among:   different asset classes -   cash equivalents (e.g., fixed deposits),bonds and stocks and/or different markets - geographic regions, foreign countries, foreign currencies, industries and companies.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I deregister my self-employed status with CPF Board if I am no longer self-employed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You do not need to deregister your self-employed status with CPF Board.   You will only need to make MediSave contributions if you earn an annual Net Trade Income (NTI) of more than $6,000. Your MediSave payable will be computed based on your age and NTI declared.   If you are no longer in self-employment, please note that you will still need to settle any outstanding MediSave payable, as it is compulsory under the CPF Act to contribute to your MediSave Account for the years that you were self-employed.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I know if I am investing for the short term or long term?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The number of years you have to save and invest is called your "INVESTMENT TIME HORIZON" - it is the amount of time between when you invest and when you need to spend the proceeds of your investments. This spending can be for your retirement or for other financial commitments which you need to meet, such as to purchase a house or to pay for your children's education expenses.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I check if I am covered by ElderShield?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can check for your ElderShield or Supplement coverage through the CPF Board’s website. The steps are as follows:   a. Visit the CPF website .   b. Log in using your Singpass.   c. Hover over “my cpf” and click on “Healthcare” under "My dashboards".   d. Click on “Long-term care insurance” on the anchor links or scroll down to the “Long-term care insurance” section.   If you are covered under ElderShield, this section will inform you of the ElderShield Plan that you are covered under, i.e. ElderShield 300 or ElderShield 400.   If you are not covered under CareShield Life/ElderShield, this section will inform you that you are not covered under CareShield Life/ElderShield.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is there a hotline for the CareShield Life, ElderShield or MediSave Care schemes?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can call the Healthcare Hotline at 1800-222-3399. The operating hours are from Monday to Friday (excluding public holidays), 8.30am to 5.30pm. Alternatively, you can also write to us . For more FAQs on CareShield Life, please visit the CareShield Life website .

Knowledge Article: Question: How does each taxi operator know the Drive and Save (DAS) co-contribution amount?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Every month, CPF Board will inform the participating taxi operators of the details of eligible taxi principal hirers who have qualified for Drive and Save (DAS) co-contributions. Exact contribution amounts will not be revealed.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can CPF monies be used for rights and/or warrants?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You cannot use your CPF monies to purchase rights/warrants directly from the marketplace. However, if you are issued rights/warrants that arise from shares/investments that you currently hold, you may use your CPF monies to pay for the exercise price of these rights/warrants provided the underlying investments being taken up are included under the CPF Investment Scheme, subject to your available stock limit. For such cases, your agent bank will reach out to you on the details of the application.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I continue to use my CPF monies to pay for the quarterly bank charges even if I do not have $20,000 in my Ordinary Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use your Ordinary Account balance to pay for the quarterly agent banks charges, even if your Ordinary Account balance is below $20,000. The restriction on the use of the first $20,000 in Ordinary Account for CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account only applies to new investments, including payments for recurring single premiums (for insurance) and regular savings plans (for unit trusts).

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I participate in the CPF Investment Scheme while I am overseas?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can participate in the CPF Investment Scheme while you are overseas. However, there are some investments which would require you to be personally present. You may have to authorise someone to act on your behalf by way of a Power of Attorney if you are not able to handle the transactions yourself.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the role of agent banks under CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The agent banks are appointed to maintain members' CPF Investment Accounts under the CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA) as they have an extensive network of branches and facilities to support the investment and settlement of shares and bonds listed on the Singapore Exchange. The agent banks' electronic banking services such as ATMs are easily accessible and allow members to conveniently apply for shares or bonds during an IPO. The banks are also able to handle the complex processing of corporate actions such as bonus and rights issues, dividend payments and schemes of arrangement under the CPFIS-OA.

Knowledge Article: Question: Which of my CPF accounts can I use to participate under CPF Investment Scheme - Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA) or CPF Investment Scheme - Special Account (CPFIS-SA)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can only use your Ordinary Account (OA) savings for investments under CPF Investment Scheme - Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA), and your Special Account (SA) savings for investments under CPF Investment Scheme - Special Account (CPFIS-SA).   The instruments available for investments under CPFIS-OA and CPFIS-SA are different. You may not combine savings from your OA and SA to buy a product. However, you can transfer funds from your OA to your SA* to invest under CPFIS-SA. Such transfers are irreversible. The total savings in the SA including the amount withdrawn under CPFIS-SA cannot exceed the current full retirement sum after the transfer.   * Applicable only to members below age 55.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) Self-Awareness Questionnaire (SAQ)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) Self-Awareness Questionnaire (SAQ) helps you assess if you have basic financial knowledge and whether CPFIS is suitable for you. The SAQ starts with learning modules on investment concepts, products and charges under CPFIS. You will then log in with your Singpass to attempt a quiz.   From 1 October 2018, if you are a new CPFIS investor, you will need to take the SAQ before you can start investing under CPFIS. Agent banks and product providers will require you to declare your SAQ status and/or ask to view a copy of your SAQ status for verification. You can participate in the CPFIS once you have taken the SAQ, regardless of your SAQ results. You can check your SAQ status via my cpf digital services.   If you already have a CPFIS account, while you are not required to take the SAQ, you are still strongly encouraged to do so.

Knowledge Article: Question: Who is eligible for the Drive and Save (DAS) Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Under the Drive and Save (DAS) Scheme, all taxi principal hirers who make regular contributions 1  to their MediSave Account are eligible to receive co-contributions from participating taxi operators. Only contributions that can be used to offset MediSave payable are eligible for DAS co-contributions.   If you have outstanding MediSave payable, you may be eligible for DAS co-contributions from participating taxi operators if you make full payment or be on a monthly GIRO instalment plan of at least $20 for your MediSave payable.   If you do not have outstanding MediSave payable, you may be eligible for DAS co-contributions from participating taxi operators if you pre-pay your future MediSave payable by contributing at least $20 to your MediSave Account monthly.   1  You may make payment for your MediSave payable via  Manage your MediSave payable  or  GIRO .

Knowledge Article: Question: Will I receive Drive and Save (DAS) co-contributions if I make a lump sum payment?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You’ll receive Drive and Save (DAS) co-contributions of $20 monthly, provided you have contributed at least $240 into your MediSave Account in the past 12 months.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I engage in contra trading under the CPF Investment Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF savings cannot be used for contra trading as it may encourage speculative trading, and investors bear a higher risk of losing their monies. Hence, it is not suitable for long term investment and for retirement planning.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is there a minimum or maximum age for making or receiving top-ups?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There is no maximum age for making or receiving top-ups.   However, you will need to be at least 16 years old to be a giver of cash top-ups.   You can make cash top-ups to a child who is not yet 16 years old, and you can find out how to do so here .

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I continue to use my Ordinary Account savings to service my regular premium insurance bought before 1 January 2001, even if my balance falls below $20,000?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can continue to service the future premiums using your Ordinary Account savings, even if your balance falls below $20,000. This applies to you even after age 55 as long as you have set aside the Full Retirement Sum or the Basic Retirement Sum with sufficient property charge/pledge in the Retirement Account.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I purchase a regular premium insurance policy under CPF Investment Scheme?
