You would have to pay for the option fee in cash first at the time of booking an HDB flat.   If you are buying a resale HDB flat, you will have to pay for the deposit, i.e., option fee and option exercise fee, in cash.   For HDB flat with bank loan   You can only use your Ordinary Account savings to pay for the property after you have paid the following in cash:   a) minimum cash downpayment of at least 5% of the lower of the purchase price or the valuation price of the property at the time of purchase; and   b) the portion of the purchase price that is above the market value of the property; and   c) the lower of the purchase price or the valuation price of the property at the time of purchase, less the housing loan and approved CPF lump sum that will be paid towards the property; and   d) option fee at the time of booking an HDB flat (if you are buying the flat directly from HDB) or option fee and option exercise fee (if you are buying a resale flat)   You may refer to the  Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) website for more information on the minimum cash downpayment that you have to pay.   For private property   You can only use your Ordinary Account savings to pay for the property on completion of all legal documentation and after you have paid the following in cash:   a) a minimum cash downpayment of at least 5% of the lower of the purchase price or the valuation price of the property at the time of purchase; and   b) the portion of the purchase price that is above the market value of the property; and   c) the lower of the purchase price or the valuation price of the property at the time of purchase less the housing loan and approved CPF lump sum that will be paid towards the property.   You may refer to the  Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) website  for more information on the minimum cash downpayment that you have to pay.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my CPF savings to pay for the legal fees incurred when I buy a property? If so, how should I go about doing it?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use your Ordinary Account (OA) savings to pay for the legal fees incurred when you buy a property.   You will need to apply through HDB if you are taking an HDB loan, or through your lawyer if you are taking a bank loan.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I check my reimbursement status if I had previously made a claim to my insurer after using my MediSave and MediShield Life for my medical expenses?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can view the reimbursement details at cpf.gov.sg/healthcare .   Simply login to your Healthcare dashboard under my cpf digital services with your Singpass and proceed to 'Latest healthcare payments and claims' to view the recent transactions, or click on 'View past 15 months' for more transactions.   For claims with reimbursement, you will see the message "You have been reimbursed for this claim. View details". Click 'View details' to view the reimbursement details.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am making a reimbursement claim from my insurer/employer for my medical bills. Is it compulsory for me to provide a hardcopy healthcare payments and claims statement to them?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF Board does not require any documents from your insurer or employer to process the reimbursement. You need not provide hardcopy healthcare payments and claims statement to make a reimbursement claim. If your insurer or employer requires such a statement, they should accept a digital copy.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much do I need to refund to my CPF account if I am selling my property? Does the refund amount change when I turn 55?
Knowledge Article: Answer: When you sell your property, you will need to refund the CPF principal amount you withdrew with the accrued interest (P+I).   If you are below 55, the CPF housing refund is credited to your Ordinary Account (OA) and you can use your OA savings to participate in other CPF schemes or pay for another property.   If you are over 55 years old and have pledged the property to meet your retirement sum, you will also need to refund the pledged amount on top of the P+I. The CPF housing refund is used to top up your Retirement Account to your Full Retirement Sum. Any balance housing refunds will remain in your OA, and you can decide how to manage it.   You can find out more about your housing refund required on your Home ownership dashboard .

Knowledge Article: Question: I am above 55 years old. Before 1 July 2024, the balance CPF housing refunds are paid to me in cash after settling the Full Retirement Sum in my Retirement Account. After 1 July 2024, it is credited to my Ordinary Account. Why was the process changed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We understand that everyone has different retirement needs and the new process provides members with the flexibility to manage their balance housing refunds. With the refunds credited to the Ordinary Account (OA), members can continue earning risk-free interest rate on the balance CPF housing refunds. They would also have the option to:   Use the balance housing refund credited to the OA for the next property purchase or to pay another housing loan Transfer it to one’s Retirement Account to earn higher interest of up to 6% per annum. Find out  more . Withdraw it in cash for immediate needs. Find out  more . If you need to withdraw more than the default online Daily Withdrawal Limit of $2,000, find out  more . If you need to withdraw more than the maximum online Daily Withdrawal Limit, find out more . There is no change to the amount that members can withdraw before and after the process change.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am above 55. What can I do with my balance CPF housing refunds after meeting my Full Retirement Sum?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your balance CPF housing refunds after meeting your Full Retirement Sum will remain in your Ordinary Account. For the balance in your OA, here are three options you can consider:   Maximise your CPF savings by transferring the OA balance to your RA to receive higher payouts in retirement. Find out more about CPF top-ups. Keep the monies in your CPF accounts to earn risk-free interest rate.  Find out more about CPF interest rates. Withdraw your CPF savings for your immediate retirement needs any time after the refund is credited.  Find out more about withdrawals.  If you need to withdraw more than the default online Daily Withdrawal Limit of $2,000, find out  more . If you need to withdraw more than the maximum online Daily Withdrawal Limit, find out more .

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I apply for reimbursements for my MediSave and MediShield Life?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have utilised your MediSave and/or MediShield Life for medical expenses, and your employer or insurer has contractual obligations to reimburse you for your medical expenses, please approach them to find out how they can reimburse to your MediSave and MediShield Life.   Most employers and/or insurers will require one or more of the following supporting documents before they reimburse to your MediSave and MediShield Life:   i. Your finalised medical bill, which should show the breakdown of the bill and the source of payment i.e. payment made by cash, MediSave, Integrated Shield Plan or MediShield Life.   ii. MediSave/MediShield Life claims statement, which can be accessed online, for members with Singpass:   1. Login to your Healthcare dashboard under my cpf digital services with your Singpass   2. Proceed to 'Latest healthcare payments and claims' to view the recent transactions or click on 'View past 15 months' for more transactions.   For claims with reimbursement, you will see the message "You have been reimbursed for this claim. View details". Click 'View details' to view the reimbursement details.   iii. Hardcopy MediSave transaction statement, which is sent weekly to members who have used their MediSave to pay for medical expenses, for members without Singpass.   The “Hospital Registration Number” (HRN) found in the "Healthcare payments and claims" statement and the MediSave transaction statement will help your employer/insurer to identify the claim to be reimbursed. The HRN is a 13-character alphanumeric registration number that looks like this: 522016A02QL6E.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I transfer my Ordinary Account (OA) savings to my parents' OA so that I can help them pay their outstanding housing loan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You cannot transfer your Ordinary Account (OA) savings to your parents' OA to help them pay their outstanding housing loan. You can only use your OA savings to service a housing loan if you are an owner of the property.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my Ordinary Account savings to service the housing loan taken by my parent(s) and/or sibling?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use your Ordinary Account savings to service the housing loan only if you are the co-owner of the property.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much can I reserve in my Ordinary Account for my housing payments?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can request to reserve all or part of your Ordinary Account (OA) savings. When you start your monthly payouts under CPF LIFE or the Retirement Sum Scheme, your reserved OA savings will be transferred to your Retirement Account (RA) if you have not set aside your Full Retirement Sum. This transfer increases your RA savings and enhance your monthly payouts.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am over 55 years old and am planning to sell my property. How much do I need to refund to my CPF account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: When you sell your property, you will need to refund the CPF principal amount you withdrew with the accrued interest (P+I). If you have pledged the property to meet your retirement sum, you will also need to refund the pledged amount on top of the P+I. The refunded amount will be used to top up your Retirement Account, up to your Full Retirement Sum. You can find out the amount to be refunded by checking your Home ownership dashboard .

Knowledge Article: Question: I am earning close to the qualifying wage cap, why is my Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) so low?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To best support lower-wage workers, the WIS benefits are gradually reduced as the wage levels of the workers increase nearer to the qualifying wage cap. The gradual reduction ensures that the lower-wage workers do not see a sharp reduction in their WIS benefits when they upgrade their skills and begin to earn more. Taken together, the total amount of the income and the WIS benefits would still increase overall as one's income increases.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why are Singapore Permanent Residents (PRs) not eligible for the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme is only for Singaporean lower-wage workers. If you require financial assistance, please contact the  ComCare hotline at 1800-222-0000, or email Ask_SSO@msf.gov.sg .

Knowledge Article: Question: How is my income calculated for the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To be assessed for Workfare Income Supplement, we will calculate your income based on the income declared by your employer(s) for work done in that month.   For work done in Sep 2024 and earlier: To be assessed for Workfare Income Supplement, we will calculate your income based on the CPF contributions made by your employer(s) for work done in that month.

Knowledge Article: Question: As a self-employed person, how will I benefit from participating in Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Through making smaller and more regular MediSave contributions as and when you receive a service fee, Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) makes saving for your healthcare needs through your MediSave Account (MA) easier. MediSave savings can be used to pay for your out-of-pocket healthcare expenses and MediShield Life premiums.   As a self-employed person (SEP), there are many issues that require your attention. CAYE is an easy and hassle-free way to help free up more of your time. For your convenience, your CAYE contributions are automatically deposited into your MA whenever you get paid. This would also be helpful for SEPs whose income may be seasonal. CAYE can also help grow your money as you can start to earn an interest of up to 5% on your MediSave savings earlier.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am on no-pay/study/medical/maternity leave. Will I be considered as employed to qualify for Workfare Income Supplement?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For the purpose of Workfare Income Supplement (WIS), staff on study/medical/maternity leave will be considered as employees if you are still receiving a salary and CPF contributions from your employers.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am a contract / part-time employee. Will I be eligible for Workfare Income Supplement?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Contract / part-time employees are eligible for the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) if they meet the WIS eligibility criteria .

Knowledge Article: Question: I intend to seek treatment at a general practitioner (GP) clinic at my void deck. How do I know if I can use my Flexi-MediSave there?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Flexi-MediSave can be used at i. Polyclinics, ii. Specialist Outpatient Clinics in the public hospitals and national specialty centres, and iii. Medical general practitioner (GP) clinics participating in the Community Health Assist Scheme (CHAS) scheme. The list of participating CHAS medical GP clinics can be found at the following websites: CHAS Ministry of Health (under Healthcare Schemes & Subsidies > Community Health Assist Scheme)

Knowledge Article: Question: If I had used cash, MediSave and MediShield Life for my medical bill, is there an order in which my employer or insurer should perform the reimbursement?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Subject to the contractual obligations, your employer or insurer should perform the reimbursement in the following order: i. To reimburse you in cash, for the amount that you paid in cash ii. To reimburse the amount of MediSave utilised from your payer's or your MediSave Account, back to your payer's or your MediSave Account iii. To reimburse the amount utilised from your MediSave-approved Integrated Shield Plan or MediShield Life, back to the Integrated Shield Plan or MediShield Life This minimises your cash outlay and restores your MediSave Account savings.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if my employer overpaid my CPF contributions to CPF Board and did not refund my share to me?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your employer should refund your share of CPF contributions before applying to the Board for a refund of the excess CPF contributions paid in error. If you did not receive the refund, you can write to us and we will contact your employer on the refund.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have received a notification on the refund of CPF contributions paid in excess of the CPF Annual Limit but I have yet to receive my share of the excess contributions from my (ex-)employer, what should I do?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your (ex-)employer has been notified to refund your share of excess CPF contributions to you, if any. You should contact your (ex-)employer directly regarding the refund.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on referral fee given to my employee?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are not payable on referral fee given to your employee for recommending new staff to your company if it is not part of his official duties. CPF contributions are payable on referral fee if introducing new staff to join your company is part of your employee’s official duties.

Knowledge Article: Question: When is the due date for my CPF contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The due date for CPF contributions is on the last day of the calendar month. Enforcement action would be taken against employers who fail to pay by the 14 th of the following month (or the next working day if the 14 th  falls on a Saturday, Sunday or Public Holiday). This includes imposing late payment interest charged at 1.5% per month commencing from the first day after the due date.   If you are not paid your CPF contributions on time or accurately, you should approach your employer for an explanation and ask when your employer will be making the payment.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long does CPF Board take to process my application for refund of contributions paid?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Service Normal Processing Time Refund and adjustment of contributions paid Within one month upon receipt of the necessary information* *This excludes the two working days that banks require to credit the monies to your bank account.   As we are currently experiencing high volume of applications, a longer processing time may be expected for your application(s). Once your application(s) have been successfully processed, we will notify you on the details of the refund.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable for church workers?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable for church workers who are employed under a contract of service .

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on profit sharing?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on profit sharing given to your employees.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on service charge given to my employee?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on service charge collected by you from customers and given as incentive to your employee.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the service standards for processing applications relating to discounted Singtel shares?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please refer to the table for our service standards for processing applications relating to discounted Singtel shares.   Service Normal Processing Time Withdraw My Discounted Singtel Shares Upon Meeting CPF Withdrawal Conditions Within 15 working days (this includes the Central Depository's (CDP) processing time)    Transfer Discounted Singtel Shares (Division of CPF-related Matrimonial Assets) Within 15 working days* * Transferee must have a CPF investment account with agent bank

Knowledge Article: Question: What is Special Discounted Shares Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Special Discounted Share Scheme is part of the Government's asset enhancement programme to make Singapore a share-owning society, thus giving Singaporeans a greater stake in the country.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why are my discounted Singtel shares not reflected in my Central Depository (CDP) statement?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your discounted Singtel shares are held by the Board on your behalf. Your discounted Singtel shares would therefore be reflected in your CPF Statement of Account.

Knowledge Article: Question: I work for an overseas employer outside Singapore and have to return to Singapore for personal reasons during the COVID-19 period. Are CPF contributions payable while I work remotely in Singapore?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are returning to Singapore for personal reasons and will be working remotely in Singapore for your overseas employer during the Stay Home Notice (SHN) period or unable to return overseas after your personal trip due to COVID-19 travel restrictions, CPF contributions are not payable until 30 June 2021 since this is a temporary work arrangement due to COVID-19 restrictions. However, similar to other employees who are working in Singapore, CPF contributions are payable on wages given to employees who are working remotely in Singapore from 1 July 2021 onwards.   If you choose to continue working remotely in Singapore not due to COVID-19 travel restrictions, and your employer agrees with this work arrangement, CPF contributions are payable on your wages as they are given in respect of your employment in Singapore.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on honorarium?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are not payable on the honorarium given to a professional person who is not employed by you, e.g. Board Chairman, Non-Executive Director, Honorary Secretary and Auditor of a sports club.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on Long Service Award (LSA)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on cash award given to your employee in recognition of his long service.   However, to promote loyalty, CPF contributions are not payable on Long Service Award (LSA) that is given to your employee with at least 5 years of service and subsequent LSA for each 5-year period of service with you, up to the amount of your employee’s Ordinary Wages (OW) for the month in which the LSA is paid. In the event that there are multiple types of LSA given to the same employee, only the first LSA granted to the employee in each 5-year period can qualify for this exemption.   If the LSA exceeds the OW for the month, CPF contributions are payable on the amount in excess of OW. If your employee has no OW payable in that month, CPF contributions are payable on the entire LSA.   Scenarios Are CPF contributions payable? LSA amount is OW and below No LSA amount is more than OW Yes, on the amount of LSA exceeding OW OW is $0 Yes, on the entire LSA   The CPF treatment is the same even if the LSA is payable after your Singapore Citizen/Singapore Permanent Resident employee has left employment. Find out more if  CPF contributions are payable on Additional Wages payable to ex-employees after they have left employment .   Please see examples (page 5 under the header “Long Service Award) of whether a LSA attracts CPF.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the criteria for inclusion of Property Fund under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: In considering the inclusion of Property Funds under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS), the Board uses the following criteria:   The property fund is offered by a company that is incorporated in Singapore; The property fund is listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) Mainboard; The property fund is traded in Singapore Dollars; The company allows Agent Banks to appoint all CPF unitholders of the property fund as proxies to attend and vote at meetings. You can refer to the SGX website for the list of Property Funds included under the CPFIS.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are the dividends received from the discounted Singtel shares subject to tax?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Dividends received from your discounted Singtel shares are not taxable.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on reimbursements of employee/flexible benefits?
Knowledge Article: Answer: In general, CPF contributions are required on all employee benefits as the cash payments payable to your employees increase their wages. Some examples are reimbursements of childcare expenses, eldercare expenses, gym subscription fee, holiday expenses, personal insurance premium and personal mobile phone subscription fee.   However, CPF contributions are not payable on the following as they do not fall under the definition of “wages” in the CPF Act:   a) Reimbursements of medical and dental benefits   CPF contributions are not payable on reimbursements of medical and dental treatment expenses incurred by employee, their spouse and children if it is considered necessary by registered doctors, TCM practitioners, and/or dentist for the treatment or diagnosis of any illness (excludes solely aesthetic defect). This approach supports employment practices to provide medical and dental benefits for employees and their dependants beyond an employer’s statutory obligations, while ensuring that members have adequate CPF contributions for retirement. Some examples are reimbursements of medical consultation fee and medication prescribed by medical practitioner for treating illness, and scaling and polishing by dentist.   If the treatments, procedures or items are ordered by medical practitioners as part of medical or dental treatment, CPF contributions are also not payable even if they are performed by non-registered medical practitioners. Some examples are physiotherapy, chiropractic therapy, health screening, vaccination, health supplement and medical device. Otherwise, CPF contributions are payable if your employees go on their own accord.   If you are in doubt whether a certain treatment, procedure or item is medically required for your employee, you should check with a registered medical practitioner and apply the CPF treatment accordingly.   b) Reimbursements incurred for official purposes   CPF contributions are not payable on reimbursements incurred for official purposes . The reimbursed amount must not exceed the expenditure incurred. Similarly, any of the claims made under the employee/flexible benefit schemes that are for official purposes will also not attract CPF contributions. Some examples are reimbursements of course and exam fee, mobile phone subscription fee and professional membership fee that are required for work.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is tenancy-in-common?
Knowledge Article: Answer: A tenancy-in-common is a form of property ownership where each co-owner holds a separate and definite share in the property. However, all co-owners are entitled to the enjoyment of the whole property regardless of their share in the property.   In a tenancy-in-common arrangement, each owner can have a different ownership interest in the property. For example, one owner may own 50% of the property, while the other two owners own 25% and 25% respectively.   When a tenant-in-common dies, their share in the property does not automatically go to the other owners. Instead, it will be passed on according to their will. If they do not have a will, it will be distributed according to the Intestate Succession Act.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have an overdraft to buy a private property. Can I use my CPF savings to redeem the overdraft?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use your CPF savings to repay the overdraft if it was used solely to purchase the private property. To do so, you need to authorise your lawyer (by signing the Letter of Authorisation, Declaration, Consent & Agreement) to submit an online application on your behalf. Your lawyer will need to attach the following documents in the application:   Financier's letter of offer. Financier's letter to confirm that the overdraft was used strictly to buy the property or was partially used to buy the property. If the overdraft was used partially to buy the property, please attach the monthly statement of account of the overdraft account from the time it was disbursed for payment of the property to the date of application to use CPF savings. Financier's statement showing the current outstanding amount of the overdraft. Once the application is approved, you will need to get your financier to convert the overdraft facility to a housing loan.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on reimbursement given to my prospective employee for his payment in lieu of notice to his former employer for leaving the company before the end of notice period?
Knowledge Article: Answer: From October 2022, CPF contributions are not payable on the reimbursement given to your prospective employee for the payment in lieu of notice he made to his former employer in order to commence his employment with you earlier. This is in consideration of the fact that payment in lieu of notice is liquidated damages for the breach of contract.   For clarity, CPF contributions are also not payable if you make the payment in lieu of notice on behalf of your prospective employee directly to his employer. There is no change in the Board’s position on this.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my CPF savings to buy a SOHO (Small Office Home Office) unit?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF savings can only be used to buy residential properties. It is important to note that Small Office Home Office (SOHO) developments are approved by the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) for either office or residential use, but not for both.   You may use your CPF savings to purchase a SOHO unit if URA has approved it for residential use. However, if the unit is approved for office use, your CPF savings cannot be used for its purchase. Therefore, you are advised to check the approved use of the property before committing to any purchase.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will I be notified about the closure of my Special Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Upon the closure of your Special Account (SA), you will receive a letter on the amounts that have been transferred from your SA to your Retirement Account and/or Ordinary Account. You can also check the Transaction history .

Knowledge Article: Question: If I am aged 55 and above, when will my Special Account be closed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your Special Account will be closed by early 2025. More details on the implementation date will be shared in the second half of 2024.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I get back my title deed if I have fully redeemed my housing loan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The procedure depends on the type of property you bought and the loan you took.   For HDB flat with HDB loan   You will need to check with HDB directly on the title deed of your HDB flat.   For HDB flat with bank loan   You will need to check with your bank directly on the title deed of your HDB flat.   For private property   The Singapore Land Authority (SLA) will print and give you the title deed only if there are no outstanding mortgages, CPF charges, or other charges on the property. The CPF charge was created when you withdrew your CPF savings for the property to secure the refund of the principal amount withdrawn, including accrued interest, upon the sale of the property.   If there is still a CPF charge on the property, even if the mortgage and other charges are discharged, SLA will not print the title deed. Once the mortgage and/or other charges are discharged, you can liaise with SLA to obtain a copy of the title deed.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am a bankrupt. Can I withdraw my CPF savings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are a bankrupt, you can withdraw some of your CPF savings if you meet any of the following grounds for withdrawals:   a) You have reached  age 55.   b) You have a  reduced life expectancy due to a medical condition, as certified by an accredited doctor . Severe medical conditions that cause you to be permanently unfit for work or to lack mental capacity permanently can also be considered.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am buying an HDB flat and selling my existing flat at the same time. Can I apply for a contra facility?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are interested in using the refund from the sale of your current HDB flat to buy a new flat, you may check with HDB to see if you are eligible to apply for a contra facility. This will allow you to use the refund to offset the purchase price of your new flat.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on bursary and scholarship awards?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are not payable on bursary and scholarship awards given to your employee if they are genuine pre-estimates or reimbursements of expenses incurred for official purpose, e.g. you send your employee for further studies as part of his training. The cash award may include reimbursement of course fee, book fee, overseas living expenses, air tickets etc.   If you are using genuine pre-estimates, you must be able to show that the amount given to your employee is reasonable, e.g. there is a sound methodology to derive the quantum such as basing on recent cost or past receipts for similar expenses. Do note that any overseas living allowance should be reasonable based on the country of study, and cannot be simply based on your employee’s last drawn salary to qualify as a genuine pre-estimate. If you are giving reimbursements, the amount must not exceed the expenditure incurred.   If the cash payments are not genuine pre-estimates or reimbursements for official purpose(s), CPF contributions are payable.

Knowledge Article: Question: When is the latest age to start my monthly payouts?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The latest age you can start your monthly payouts is 70.   Find out what happens if we don’t receive your instruction to start your monthly payouts .

Knowledge Article: Question: Does the closure of my Special Account affect the retirement sum that I need to set aside?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your Full Retirement Sum (FRS) and Basic Retirement Sum (BRS) are determined when you turn 55 and will remain the same for the rest of your life. It is not affected by the closure of your Special Account.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have set aside my Full Retirement Sum with a mixture of property and cash. With the closure of Special Account (SA), which account will my SA savings be transferred to?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Once you have set aside the Full Retirement Sum (FRS), whether fully in cash, or with a mixture of property (up to half the FRS) and cash, your Special Account (SA) savings will be transferred to your Ordinary Account, where they remain withdrawable and will earn the short-term interest rate. No SA savings will be transferred to your Retirement Account to replace the portion of your FRS set aside using property.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am below age 55. How does the closure of Special Account affect me?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are below 55 in early 2025, you will not be immediately affected. Your Special Account (SA) will only be closed when you turn 55 when your Retirement Account is created. Read more on how your SA will be closed when you turn age 55 in the future.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will the auto-disbursement of Special Account and Ordinary Account savings benefit me?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To minimise any disruption to your payouts, we will automatically disburse your Special Account and Ordinary Account savings when your Retirement Account savings are depleted.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I defer my monthly payouts beyond 70 if I am not on CPF LIFE?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will not be able to defer your monthly payouts beyond 70. The purpose of your retirement savings is to provide you with a stream of retirement income.   If you have no immediate need for the payouts, you can consider investing them outside the CPF system. Do note that investing outside of CPF carries a certain level of risk and requires careful consideration.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am not on CPF LIFE. How will my monthly payouts be adjusted if there are changes to my retirement savings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We will review your payouts monthly to take into account the changes to your retirement savings. Your payouts will be revised in the following month after the inflows or outflows are made to your retirement savings.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I really need to be concerned about outliving my monthly payouts?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you should be concerned about outliving your monthly payouts. As we cannot predict how long we will live, it is not easy to determine how much we need for our retirement. For example, spending too much might result in you not having enough, while saving too much could end up depriving yourself.   With advancements in technology and healthcare, we can expect to live longer than previous generations. However, many people tend to underestimate their lifespan and fail to save enough for their retirement.   To enjoy peace of mind in your retirement years, you can join CPF LIFE which provides monthly payouts no matter how long you live.   On the other hand, if you are not on CPF LIFE, your monthly payouts will stop once your CPF savings run out.

Knowledge Article: Question: When can I start my monthly payouts if I am not on CPF LIFE?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You have the flexibility to decide when to start your monthly payouts, anytime from 65 to 70.   Note: If you are born before 1958, you are past your  payout eligibility age and can choose to start your payouts anytime.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long does it take to process my application to start my monthly payouts?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Our normal processing time for applications to start monthly payouts from retirement savings is three days to two weeks*.   * Your application may take up to two weeks to process if you have submitted multiple payout decisions via the Plan my monthly payouts service.   Monthly payouts will start at 65 or within one month (whichever is later) after your instruction is processed.

Knowledge Article: Question: How and when will I receive my monthly payouts?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will receive the monthly payouts in your bank account generally by the fourth working day of the month. You will generally receive your payouts earlier if your bank supports Fast And Secure Transfer (FAST).

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I choose to retain my Special Account and Ordinary Account savings instead of automatically disbursing them as payouts when my Retirement Account is depleted?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, you cannot choose to retain your Special Account (SA) and Ordinary Account (OA) savings. CPF is designed to provide you with an income in retirement. The auto-disbursement of your SA and OA savings ensures that you continue to receive a steady stream of retirement income even when your Retirement Account has been depleted.   With the monthly payouts, you also have greater flexibility for your daily living expenses or your monthly housing instalments (if applicable).   If you wish to retain the monies in your CPF accounts to earn higher interest, you should consider options outside of CPF.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I choose to retain my Special Account and Ordinary Account savings instead of automatically disbursing them as payouts when my Retirement Account is depleted?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, you cannot choose to retain your Special Account (SA) and Ordinary Account (OA) savings. CPF is designed to provide you with an income in retirement. The auto-disbursement of your SA and OA savings ensures that you continue to receive a steady stream of retirement income even when your Retirement Account has been depleted.   With the monthly payouts, you also have greater flexibility for your daily living expenses or your monthly housing instalments (if applicable).   If you wish to retain the monies in your CPF accounts to earn higher interest, you should consider options outside of CPF.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am a bankrupt and am planning to sell my property. How much do I need to refund to my CPF account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are a bankrupt and you sell your property, you will need to refund the CPF principal amount you withdrew with the accrued interest (P+I).    If you are aged 55 and above and have pledged the property to meet your retirement sum, you will also need to refund the pledged amount on top of the P+I. The CPF housing refund will be used to top up your Retirement Account, up to your Full Retirement Sum. Any balance housing refunds will remain in your Ordinary Account, and you can decide how to manage it .

Knowledge Article: Question: As a bankrupt, can I request to make a partial withdrawal and leave some monies in my CPF Account for my housing loan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you can request to make a partial withdrawal from your CPF account even if you are a bankrupt. This will allow you to leave some funds in your account to continue paying for your housing loan.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I have to refund the sale proceeds when I sell my property after my CPF account is closed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you have to refund your CPF principal amount withdrawn with accrued interest or amount you have pledged to refund if you have not transferred your CPF savings to your bank account upon renunciation, by the time you sell your property.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to the top-ups I had received in my Special or Retirement Account when I close my CPF account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Any remaining monies which you have received through CPF transfers and cash top-ups will be paid to you, along with your CPF savings, when you transfer your savings to your bank account. This is subject to  safeguards to prevent premature withdrawals .

Knowledge Article: Question: As a member or an ex-spouse, what are my options if I am an undischarged bankrupt under division of CPF savings in a divorce?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Court may still grant a transfer order or a charging order; similar to a member/ or an ex-spouse who is not an undischarged bankrupt.   If you are the ex-spouse, and payment is to be made to you under a charging order, please check with the Official Assignee whether you can receive the CPF savings.

Knowledge Article: Question: As a bankrupt, can I use my CPF savings to buy a Housing & Development Board flat?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use your CPF savings to buy a Housing & Development Board (HDB) flat as long as you are the owner of the HDB flat. You will need to contact HDB on this matter.

Knowledge Article: Question: Am I allowed to reserve my Ordinary Account savings prior to turning 55 years old for possible housing payments after I turn 55 years old?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To help members plan ahead, members who intend to reserve their Ordinary Account (OA) savings for housing payments beyond age 55 may submit a request to the CPF Board before the monies are transferred to their Retirement Accounts (RA). This applies to members who own existing properties or plan to buy new properties. You may submit your application anytime within 6 months before your 55th birthday, with at least 5 working days for us to process your application.   Please note that you will not be able to submit the application if:   You are 55 years old and above; or You have made a withdrawal of your CPF under the  Reduced Life Expectancy (RLE) scheme. When you start your monthly payouts under CPF LIFE or the Retirement Sum Scheme, your reserved OA savings will be transferred to your RA if you have not set aside your Full Retirement Sum. This transfer increases your RA savings and enhance your monthly payouts.   Find out how to apply to reserve your OA savings for your housing payment.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the CPF interest rates?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF Interest Rates (1 July 2024 to 30 September 2024)   Ordinary Account Special, MediSave and Retirement Account Interest Rate 2.5% 4.08% To help boost retirement savings, the Government pays extra interest on the first $60,000 of your combined CPF balances, which is capped at $20,000 for Ordinary Account (OA). Please refer to details on extra interest in the table below.   Age Extra interest Below 55 years old 1% per annum on the first $60,000 (capped at $20,000 for OA) 55 years old and above 2% per annum on the first $30,000, 1% per annum on the next $30,000 (capped at $20,000 for OA) Extra interest earned on OA savings go into your Special Account (SA) or Retirement Account (RA) to enhance your retirement savings. If you are participating in the CPF LIFE scheme, you will still earn the extra interest on your combined CPF balances, including the savings used for CPF LIFE.   Please refer to the respective links for more information on the  CPF interest rates and historical CPF interest rates (PDF, 0.15MB).

Knowledge Article: Question: After the transfer or sale of the matrimonial property has been completed pursuant to the existing court order, I reached a different agreement with my ex-spouse on the division of CPF assets. Can we undo the transfer or sale?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF Board has no power under the relevant legislation to reverse the transfer or sale of the property.   You might want to seek legal advice on this.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will the interest rates on savings in the Special, MediSave, and Retirement accounts be maintained at a floor rate?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To help CPF members grow their savings, the Government has decided to further extend the 4% floor rate for interest earned on all Special, MediSave, and Retirement accounts (SMRA) savings for another year until 31 December 2024.   SMRA savings will earn a minimum 4% interest rate per annum until 31 December 2024.   Please refer to our FAQ on how CPF interest rates are determined for more information.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can you explain the various premium components and computation for my MediShield Life Cover?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can refer to the MediShield Life Information Booklet for more information on the premium components and computation for more information.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my CPF savings for renovation and repairs of my property?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF savings cannot be used for renovation, improvement or repair work for your property.   If you are planning to renovate or repair your property, you will need to use your own cash savings to cover the costs. It is important to plan your finances accordingly and ensure you have enough cash savings to cover these expenses.

Knowledge Article: Question: I'm residing overseas and do not require MediShield Life, how do I withdraw from MediShield Life?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediShield Life provides universal coverage to Singapore Citizens (SCs) and Permanent Residents (PRs) so that they have assurance against large healthcare bills. MediShield Life is mandatory for all SCs and PRs, as by sharing in the national risk pool, Singapore residents collectively play our part in supporting our healthcare costs.   The MediShield Life Council (MLC) recognises that there is a small and distinct group of Overseas Singaporeans (OS) who live outside Singapore permanently, have no intention to reside in Singapore, and feel that they will not benefit from MediShield Life.   If you belong to the OS group, you can apply for a suspension of premium collection even though you will remain covered under MediShield Life. You can refer to the Suspension of MediShield Life Premium Collection for more information on the eligibility criteria and application process.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I continue to use my CPF savings for my existing private property housing loan if I am going to be made a bankrupt?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you own a private property and have used your CPF savings to pay for your property before being declared bankrupt, you can continue to use your CPF to service your housing loan.

Knowledge Article: Question: As a bankrupt, can I use my CPF savings to buy a private property or to pay for the housing loan of my existing private property?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are a bankrupt and wish to use your CPF savings to buy a private property or to start paying for the housing loan of your existing private property, you will need to obtain consent from the Official Assignee first.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I apply for the suspension of MediShield Life premium collection?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The MediShield Life Council (MLC) recognises that there is a small and distinct group of Overseas Singaporeans (OS) who live outside Singapore permanently, have no intention to reside in Singapore, and feel that they will not benefit from MediShield Life.   If you belong to the OS group, you can apply for a suspension of premium collection even though you will remain covered under MediShield Life. You can refer to the Suspension of MediShield Life Premium Collection for more information on the eligibility criteria and application process.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can overseas Singapore Residents return to Singapore if they do not pay their MediShield Life premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Overseas Singapore residents will still be able to return to Singapore even if their premiums are not paid. However, the Government may impose travel restrictions on defaulters leaving Singapore if sustained outreach to the insured has been ignored.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if my application for suspension of MediShield Life premium collection is approved and I later decide to relocate back to Singapore?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please inform the MediShield Life Team once you have relocated back to Singapore. Your suspension of MediShield Life premium collection will cease, and the accumulated sum of premiums suspended from collection, with compound interest, will be payable. You may refer to the Terms & Conditions for more information.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my CPF savings to purchase a short-lease 2-room Flexi Flat?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You must first set aside your Basic Retirement Sum in your CPF accounts before you can use any excess Ordinary Account savings to purchase a short-lease-2-room Flexi Flat. This ensures that you have a monthly income to support a basic standard of living during your retirement.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my CPF savings to pay for the Housing & Development Board upgrading costs?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use your Ordinary Account savings to pay the upgrading costs incurred under the Housing & Development Board Upgrading Programmes and Town Council Lift Upgrading Programme.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why did MediShield Life premiums have to increase in 2021 especially during the economic downturn?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Premiums did not change for the first five years of MediShield Life, in line with the Government’s earlier commitment. They need to be adjusted for the MediShield Life Fund to remain solvent and sustainable.   Premiums are priced by actuaries based on established actuarial principles, taking into account claims experience such as utilisation rates and cost of medical treatment, scheme benefits, among other factors.   There are three main reasons for the premium increases:   (1) The number of claimants has increased by about 30% and the annual payouts have increased by about 40% over the last four years. This accounted for the bulk of the premium increases i.e. about two-third;   (2) One-quarter of the premium increases is from refreshing the claim limits; and,   (3) The remaining 8% (or one-twelve) of the premium increases supports the benefit enhancements including those implemented since 2018, such as the extension of coverage to inpatient hospices and serious pregnancy complications.   The Government has committed up to $2.2 billion in premium subsidies and support over the next three years, to help Singapore Residents with their premiums.   Premium payment will be deferred until end December 2021, for those who have insufficient MediSave balances and are unable to pay their premiums due to the economic impact of COVID-19. If you need more help, you can also apply for Additional Premium Support  for assistance with your premiums.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why are MediShield Life premiums increasing as we get older?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediShield Life premiums are age-based (i.e. set in line with the risks for each age group).   With an ageing population, it is important to try to avoid intergenerational cross-subsidy, where the young has to pay for the old. If premiums were not priced by age, premiums will keep escalating as a growing number of elderly would need to be supported by a decreasing number of younger policyholders. This will impose an increasing burden on future generations and will not be sustainable. Instead, the Government provides subsidies and premium assistance to those who are unable to afford their premiums.   MediShield Life is different from the social insurance schemes in other countries, where the insurance contributions paid by the working population (e.g. through payroll taxes) are used to fund payouts, which are mostly used by the elderly or sick.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will MediShield Life premiums increase due to the increase in GST?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediShield Life premiums are inclusive of the prevailing GST rate.   In Budget 2022, the Minister for Finance announced that the GST rate will be increased from 7% to 8% with effect from 1 January 2023 and from 8% to 9% with effect from 1 January 2024. As GST is levied on MediShield Life premiums at the prevailing GST rate, the premiums will increase accordingly.   The new MediShield Life premium rate table (for policy periods on or after 1 Jan 2023) can be found on the CPF website, under View premiums .

Knowledge Article: Question: How often do I have to pay MediShield Life premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediShield Life cover is renewed yearly. Payers are notified about one month before cover renewal date and premiums are collected within a month after the cover is renewed.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my CPF savings to pay for the recess area of my HDB flat? If so, how should I go about doing it?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you can use your CPF savings to pay for the recess area of your HDB flat. The process to apply for this will depend on the type of loan you have taken.   For HDB loan   There are two ways for you to pay for the recess area of your HDB flat.   1. Submit an online application on  HDB’s website with your Singpass. Upon logging in, look under ‘e-Services > Residential > Living in a HDB flat > Application to Purchase Recess Area. Your application will be processed generally within three working days upon the receipt of your request from HDB.   2. Complete the CPF withdrawal form (PHS9) at HDB Branch. Please note that services at HDB office and Branches are by appointment only. If you wish to visit HDB Branches, you can book an appointment using the  e-Appointment system . Your application will be processed generally within three to five working days upon the receipt of your request from HDB.   For bank loan   Please  make an appointment to submit your request at any of our service centres. Do note that counter services at CPF Service Centres are available by appointment only.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the rationale for imposing Goods and Services Tax (GST) on MediShield Life premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We have a broad-based Goods and Services Tax (GST) system, with minimal exemptions as this approach helps to keep the GST rate relatively low. GST is a tax on domestic consumption of goods and services, and is payable on insurance contracts such as health, motor, and fire insurance. GST is therefore payable on premiums for MediShield Life.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is there an increase in premiums for everyone when most of us do not make claims from MediShield Life?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediShield Life is a health insurance scheme. It works by pooling financial resources from individuals in similar age cohorts to protect us from large hospital bills. Large hospital bills are rare, but the cost can be very high for those among us who fall seriously ill. Through MediShield Life, we can each pay a small amount yearly to not have to worry about a large bill if we are hospitalised.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I pay my MediShield Life premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can make a top-up via Top up MediSave Account using PayNow QR 1 .   You will be prompted to key in your Recipient’s NRIC/CPF Account Number if you are making a top-up to your loved ones.   If you require further assistance, you can call us at 1800-222-3399 (or +65-6222-3399 from overseas), Monday to Friday, 8.30am to 5.30pm Singapore time or write to us at  cpf.gov.sg/writetous .

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I have the option to top up more than the raised Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You are not able to top up more than the raised Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS). However, you may consider transferring the savings in excess of the raised ERS to your loved ones’ CPF accounts, or withdraw the savings and invest privately for potentially higher returns.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I check if my MediSave top-up is successfully credited?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can log in to view your Transaction history to check if your top-up has been credited into your MediSave Account. The top-up would be shown as ‘VOLUNTARY CON TO MEDISAVE A/C’ or ‘HEALTHCARE TOP-UP’.

Knowledge Article: Question: Am I paying double premiums for my MediShield Life and Integrated Shield Plan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You are not paying double premiums for your MediShield Life and Integrated Shield Plan (IP). There is also no duplicate coverage if you have purchased an IP through a private insurer. An IP consists of a MediShield Life component and an additional private insurance coverage component (please see below illustration).

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I find out more information about my dependants' MediShield Life covers?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are the premium payer for your dependants' MediShield Life covers, you will be notified about a month before the renewal of their covers.    You can also log in to Healthcare dashboard 'Coverage and premium details' for information on your and/or your dependants' MediShield Life premiums and subsidies.    If you are not the payer of your dependant(s)' MediShield Life cover(s), they or their payers will need to log in to Healthcare dashboard to check their coverage and premium information.

Knowledge Article: Question: What if I am unable to pay for my MediShield Life or CareShield Life (if applicable) premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Government helps Singaporeans with their MediShield Life (MSHL) and CareShield Life (CSHL) (if applicable) premiums through Premium Subsidies for the lower- to middle-income, Pioneer Generation and Merdeka Generation seniors. Those who are less well-off will qualify for higher Government subsidies. Your family members can also help pay for your MSHL and CSHL premiums with their MediSave. They can do so by submitting a Change Payer request for:   MediShield Life CareShield Life Additional Premium Support (APS) helps members who cannot afford their premiums after Government subsidies and have limited family support. Members who need APS may call 1800-222-3399 (or +65 6222 3399) from Monday to Friday, 8:30am to 5:30pm (GMT+8). No one will lose their MSHL and CSHL (if applicable) coverage due to financial difficulties.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to my MediShield Life cover if my premium payer passed away?
Knowledge Article: Answer: When your premium payer passed away, you will automatically be made the payer for your own MediShield Life cover. If you have insufficient MediSave, you will be notified to top up your MediSave or arrange for another family member to pay your premiums.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I reverse my top-up?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, cash top-ups and CPF transfers are irreversible. The top-ups/CPF transfers to your Special Account or Retirement Account savings earn a higher interest rate as the savings are locked in for the long-term. This is similar to the market practice where the interest earned on fixed deposits is higher compared to interest earned on savings deposits that are withdrawable anytime.

Knowledge Article: Question: I do not wish to pay the MediShield Life premium for my child as I am divorced. Why do I have to pay for his outstanding MediShield Life premium?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Parents are liable to pay for their child’s MediShield Life premiums until their child is 21 years old.   If you do not have custody and are not liable to maintain your child, please write to us with a copy of the court documents for assessment.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will premium recovery measures for MediShield Life include chasing the next of kin?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Premium recovery measures will not be levied on the next of kin. Members are responsible for their own MediShield Life premiums.   The Government will implement measures such as imposition of interest and penalty on outstanding premiums on members who default premium payments repeatedly.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am making a top-up to myself from overseas. How can I set up a Singpass account if I do not have a mobile phone number registered in Singapore?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you wish to set up a Singpass account for your top-up application but do not have a mobile phone number registered in Singapore, you may contact the  Singpass Helpdesk directly for assistance.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can the outstanding MediShield Life premiums be waived due to financial difficulty?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Members with financial difficulties may apply for Additional Premium Support (APS). APS helps members who cannot pay their MediShield Life premiums despite Government subsidies and have limited family support.   You can find out more on APS by calling 1800-222-3399 (or +65 6222 3399) from Monday to Friday, 8:30am to 5:30pm (GMT+8).   The Ministry of Health will assess each application to ensure that assistance is provided to members who need financial support.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I view the details of my outstanding MediShield Life premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can log in to Outstanding MediShield Life premium to view the breakdown of your outstanding premiums, interest and/or penalties.   If you do not have any outstanding premium for the previous policy years, but your dependants have, you will see a blank section below the premium summary table. Your dependants can view the breakdown of their outstanding premiums by logging into their own Healthcare dashboards.   If you and your dependants (if any) do not have outstanding premium, you will not be able to view this page.

Knowledge Article: Question: Who can pay for my MediShield Life premiums using their MediSave?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your spouse, parent, child, sibling or grandchild can help pay for your MediShield Life premiums using their MediSave.   Other family members (e.g. uncle, aunt, in-laws) can be your payer, if you meet the following conditions:   i. You are financially dependent on them,   and   ii. You and your spouse, parent, child, sibling or grandchild do not have sufficient MediSave for your MediShield Life premium   Your potential payer can take over paying your premium by submitting a Change Payer for MediShield Life .

Knowledge Article: Question: If there are insufficient funds in my MediSave Account, can I use my Ordinary Account/Special Account monies to pay for my MediShield Life premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, as savings in the Ordinary and Special accounts are primarily for your housing and retirement needs, while your MediSave is for your healthcare needs.   If you do not have sufficient MediSave to pay your premiums, you will be invited to apply for Additional Premium Support (APS) .

Knowledge Article: Question: I have paid my outstanding MediShield Life premiums in full. Why do I still receive a notification asking me to pay my premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may have received the notification as the payment for your MediShield Life premium has not been processed. You can log in to view your Transaction history and check your payment status. Please disregard the notification if you have made full payment.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I find out my child's outstanding MediShield Life premiums as I am unable to view it from the 'Outstanding MediShield Life Premium' section of my Healthcare dashboard?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can only view the MediShield Life premiums of the dependant(s) whom you are currently paying for in your Healthcare dashboard or if the premiums are paid from your child's MediSave Account.   If your child’s MediShield Life premium is paid by the other parent or another payer, please write to us at  www.cpf.gov.sg/writetous  with your child’s name and birth certificate/NRIC number.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can the Board refund the amount of outstanding MediShield Life premiums recovered from my/my child's MediSave if we qualify for Additional Premium Support?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Additional Premium Support (APS) is provided to members who have insufficient MediSave and limited family support to pay their outstanding premiums.   The Government will pay your/your child's outstanding and future premiums at the point of APS qualification for the next two years. Hence, there is no refund of any outstanding premiums recovered prior to your APS qualification.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I track the status of my request to pay for my dependant's MediShield Life premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can log in to Activities  to track the status of your request to pay your dependant(s)' MediShield Life premiums.   For subsequent policy renewals, you will receive a premium notification about a month before the policy is renewed. You can also log in to Healthcare dashboard 'Coverage and premium details' for information on your and/or your dependants' MediShield Life premiums and subsidies.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much MediSave can I use to pay for my family member's outstanding MediShield Life premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can pay your insured family member's outstanding MediShield Life premiums in full using your MediSave.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why do I have to pay for my child's outstanding MediShield Life premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Under MediShield Life Act/Regulations, parents are liable to pay for their child’s MediShield Life premiums until the child is 21 years old.   We will deduct your child's outstanding premiums from your or the other parent’s MediSave Account. If you have insufficient MediSave savings, you can top up your child’s or your MediSave Account to pay your child’s premiums.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why do I have to pay MediShield Life premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediShield Life provides universal coverage to Singapore residents for life, regardless of their pre-existing health condition. Members uphold their collective responsibility by paying their premiums on time to ensure that MediShield Life is able to meet its commitments and pay out claims to its members.   Defaults on premium payment will translate to bad debts to the MediShield Life Fund and result in higher premiums for all.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I claim tax relief for top-ups to my MediSave Account to pay MediShield Life premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Top-ups to MediSave Account to pay MediShield Life premiums are considered voluntary contributions.   Eligible members will enjoy tax relief. You can refer to the IRAS website for details on the eligibility criteria and amount of tax relief for voluntary MediSave contributions.

Knowledge Article: Question: When will the deduction from my MediSave Account take place after I submit the Change Payer request?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If the insured has outstanding MediShield Life premiums, the deduction will be made from your MediSave Account soon after you have submitted the request.   Thereafter, the insured(s)' MediShield Life premiums will automatically be deducted from your MediSave Account once a year, within a month after the Insured(s)’ cover renewal date.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can the deadline be extended to pay my outstanding MediShield Life premium?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You should make payment for your MediShield Life premiums before the deadline. If you face difficulties in paying your outstanding premiums, you may apply for Additional Premium Support (APS). APS helps members who cannot pay their MediShield Life premiums after Government subsidies and have limited family support.   You can find out more about APS by calling 1800 222 3399 (or +65 6222 3399) from Monday to Friday, 8.30am to 5.30pm (GMT+8).   Alternatively, you can:   1. Apply for a " Apply / Change GIRO for Payment of MediShield Life Premiums " to pay your outstanding premiums by instalments; or   2. Seek a family member's help to perform " Change Payer for MediShield Life " to pay your outstanding premiums.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why am I identified to pay for my own MediShield Life premiums when my payer has been paying my premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You have been identified to take over paying your own premiums because there are sufficient funds in your MediSave Account. This helps to preserve your previous payer’s MediSave for his/her own healthcare needs. We have notified your previous payer. If the previous payer or a new payer wishes to help with your premium payment, he/she can submit a Change Payer for MediShield Life.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am (i) residing overseas or (ii) have renounced my Singapore Citizenship/Permanent Resident status. How do I pay my CareShield Life/ElderShield/MediShield Life premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can pay your CareShield Life/ElderShield/MediShield Life premiums by:   1) Asking a Singapore Citizen/Permanent Resident family member to perform a Change Payer to take over the premium payments using his/her MediSave.   MediShield Life:  Change Payer for MediShield Life Cover CareShield Life/ElderShield:  Change Payer for CareShield Life/ ElderShield   2) Telegraphic Transfer Please note the following:   i. Indicate “CSHL/ESH/MSL for <premium payer’s name, CPF Account Number/NRIC>. For example, CSHL/ESH/MSL for XXXX, S1234567B. Note: Remittance amount should include the total outstanding premiums and any prevailing bank charges. Charge Type should be ‘OUR’ for bank account holder to bear all charges.   ii. Our bank details are as follows: Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation Limited OCBC Centre 65 Chulia Street Singapore 049513 SWIFT CODE: OCBCSGSGXXX Bank Code: 7339 Beneficiary Name: Central Provident Fund Board Beneficiary Account No: 501-600001-001

Knowledge Article: Question: Would payments made via the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) online submission mode be debited from the corporate service buyers' bank account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, payments made via the Contribute As You Earn online submission mode would be debited from the corporate service buyers’ bank account via direct debit.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are corporate service buyers required to make MediSave contributions under Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) for vendors who are both an employee and self-employed person?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Corporate service buyers are required to make MediSave contributions via Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) for vendors who provide their services as self-employed persons, regardless of whether they are concurrently an employee.    If payment is made to the vendor’s company (which hires the vendor as an employee), CAYE is not required. The vendor will continue to receive employee CPF contributions from his/her employer.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I view and pay my/my dependant(s)'s CareShield Life/ElderShield and MediShield Life premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can log in to your Healthcare dashboard to view your or your dependant(s)’s CareShield Life/ElderShield and MediShield Life coverage and premium information under the “Long-term care insurance” and “Health insurance” section respectively.   Paying your premiums Premiums are fully payable by MediSave. If you do not have sufficient MediSave, you can pay the premiums by:   1) Performing a voluntary top-up to your MediSave Account via the Top up MediSave Account  online form.    MediSave top-ups are generally credited within 3 working days and will be automatically deducted for premium payment(s). You may view the MediSave top-up(s) and premium deduction(s) in your Transaction history at cpf.gov.sg .   As MediSave top-ups could be deducted for healthcare premiums and medical expenses based on when deductions are due, please ensure that you have sufficient MediSave for all payments.   2) Asking a family member to perform a Change Payer request to take over the premium payment using his/her MediSave.   More payment options are available in the link below:   I have renounced my citizenship/am residing overseas with no local bank account. How do I pay my outstanding MediShield Life premiums?

Knowledge Article: Question: Are all corporate service buyers required to participate in Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: It is mandatory for all Government Procurement Entities (GPEs), including all Ministries, Departments, Organs of State and Statutory Boards as corporate service buyers, to participate in Contribute As You Earn (CAYE).

Knowledge Article: Question: Will my MediSave be deducted if the amount is less than my/my dependant's outstanding MediShield Life premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The amount deducted from your MediSave Account will be your/your dependant’s outstanding premium, or your MediSave balance, whichever is lower.   If you have insufficient MediSave for premium payment, please click on the link below to view the payment options.   How can I view and pay my/my dependant(s)'s CareShield Life/ElderShield and MediShield Life premiums?

Knowledge Article: Question: Why do my household members have different subsidy amounts for MediShield Life Premium Subsidies?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your household members may have different subsidy amounts for MediShield Life Premium Subsidies due to the following reasons:   a. Age-based Premium Subsidies structure - Subsidy amounts are higher for older insured members, as compared to younger insured members, for those with the same subsidy eligibility. b. Maximum subsidy for selected group identified - You or your household member may have been assessed previously and are eligible under other Government assistance schemes (e.g. Public Assistance Scheme).   c. Assessed separately - Information from your application and/or renewal for other healthcare subsidy schemes (e.g. Community Health Assist Scheme) will be used for the eligibility checks for MediShield Life Premium Subsidies.   Selected household member(s) may have been assessed separately due to extenuating circumstances, e.g. those living overseas and are unable to provide consent in the previous applications.   If you and your household wish to be reassessed for MediShield Life Premium Subsidies, please write to us at www.cpf.gov.sg/writetous  or call our hotline at 1800-222-3399.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will I be eligible for MediShield Life Premium Subsidies for the lower- to middle-income for the rest of my life?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Premium Subsidies are provided to help the lower- to middle-income households with their MediShield Life premiums as long as you meet the eligibility criteria. Pioneer Generation Subsidies are applicable for the rest of the Pioneer's life. The Government will ensure that the process for subsidies is as simple and convenient as possible, so that those who meet the eligibility criteria can get the subsidies easily.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will I receive premium subsidies if my child / payer is paying for my MediShield Life premium?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will receive the subsidies you are eligible for regardless of who is paying your MediShield Life premiums. You can login to Healthcare dashboard 'Coverage and premium details' to check your eligible subsidies.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why are my wages reflected as $0 on my CPF Contribution Alert?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your wages are reflected as $0 as your employer has either declared it as $0 or omitted to declare your wages. You should approach your supervisor or company HR for an explanation. The discrepancy could be due to an administrative error, and your employer should rectify it as soon as possible.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I receive the CPF Contribution Alert via CPF Mobile app?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can enable personalised notifications at CPF Mobile app Settings page.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I stop receiving the CPF Contribution Alert via CPF Mobile app?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can disable personalised notifications at CPF Mobile app Settings page.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I check whether my CPF contributions are correct?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use our CPF contribution calculator to check if your CPF contributions are correct by keying in the wages indicated in your payslip. The Employment Act requires your employer to provide you with an itemised payslip.

Knowledge Article: Question: The wages declared are correct, but I did not receive the correct amount of wages. What should I do?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your employer did not pay you the correct amount of wages, you can lodge a report through MOM Workright hotline at 1800-221-9922 or email mom_lrwd@mom.gov.sg.

Knowledge Article: Question: I received a notification informing me that my CPF contributions have been credited. What is this notification about?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF Contribution Alert is a notification service to inform CPF members (Singapore Citizens and 3rd year onwards Singapore Permanent Residents) when their monthly CPF contributions are credited. For example, you will be notified when your CPF contributions for the month of September 2022 have been credited any day between 1 September 2022 to 31 October 2022. CPF members can receive the notification via   their registered email address; or push notification via CPF Mobile app. CPF members will need to enable personalised notifications within the mobile app’s settings to start receiving the alert. With the CPF Contribution Alert, you can conveniently verify the wages declared and CPF contributions paid by your employer against your pay slip. If there are any discrepancies or if you have any clarifications, please approach your supervisor or company’s HR immediately so that any error can be rectified early while documentary evidence is fresh. If CPF contributions were paid in error, your employer will need to submit an adjustment or refund request immediately, and no later than one year from the payment date. Find out more information on the CPF Contribution Alert.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is it important for my employer to declare accurate wages for me to CPF Board?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are computed based on your wages. It is therefore important that your employer declares accurate wage information to CPF Board so that the correct amount of CPF contribution can be verified. It is an offence under the CPF Act to knowingly provide false information to CPF Board. If convicted, a first offender may be fined up to $5,000 or jailed for up to 6 months, or both.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I cancel my online application under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can cancel a pending application by accessing ‘Activities’ section on the CPF website after logging in with your Singpass.

Knowledge Article: Question: Would I receive any notification to start repayment under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We will send a repayment notification to you to inform you to start repayment. It will state the outstanding CPF education loan amount, the date to start repayment and the monthly instalment rate. For your convenience, you are encouraged to repay via GIRO.
