Refer to this FAQ on how to apply for GIRO to authorise monthly deductions from your preferred bank account for your monthly repayment to the CPF lender's Ordinary Account.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I verify that the CPF Contribution Alert email I received is legitimate?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF Contribution Alert is a notification service to inform CPF members who are Singapore Citizens and 3rd year onwards Singapore Permanent Residents when their monthly CPF contributions are credited. Members will receive the email notification at the email address registered with the Board. You may check or update your email address which you have earlier registered with us using your Singpass. If you have the CPF Mobile app installed, you will be directed to view your details via the app.  To verify if the CPF Contribution Alert email you received is legitimate and avoid falling prey to phishing scams , Ensure that the sender's email address is correctly spelt and ends with "@e.cpf.gov.sg" . Ensure that the hyperlinks or links you click on has a domain ending with “.gov.sg” .

Knowledge Article: Question: What are Ordinary Wages (OW) and Additional Wages (AW)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For wages to be classified as Ordinary Wages (OW) for the month, it must satisfy both conditions below:   The wages are due or granted wholly or exclusively in respect of an employee’s employment during that month; and The wages for that month are payable* by 14 th of the following month. Wages which are not classified as OW will be Additional Wages (AW) for the month. Example of OW: monthly salary Example of AW: annual performance bonus *Please note that the payable date refers to the date where company is contractually obligated to pay employee the wages. Do note that the Employment Act (EA) also imposes certain requirements on the timing for salary payment if employee is covered under EA. If there are circumstances that resulted in administrative delays in payment e.g. new employee joins after payroll cut-off date, you should use the payable date to determine the classification of wages.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the changes to the CPF salary ceilings from 1 September 2023?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF monthly and annual salary ceilings have been updated periodically in the past to keep pace with rising salaries. We are updating the monthly salary ceiling now, so that the CPF system continues to remain relevant in meeting the retirement needs of the broad majority of resident employees. The CPF monthly salary (i.e. Ordinary Wage) ceiling will be gradually raised from $6,000 to $8,000 by 2026 for all employees. The increase will take place in four steps, as shown in the Table below, to allow employers and employees to adjust to the changes. Table: Changes in CPF salary ceilings     CPF Ordinary Wage ceiling CPF annual salary ceiling   From 1 Jan 2016 to 31 Aug 2023 $6,000 $102,000 (no change) From 1 Sep to 31 Dec 2023 $6,300 (+$300) From 1 Jan to 31 Dec 2024 $6,800 (+$500) From 1 Jan to 31 Dec 2025 $7,400 (+$600) From 1 Jan 2026 $8,000 (+$600) Employees who are earning above $6,000 will benefit from this change. The annual salary ceiling, which limits the total amount of Ordinary Wages and Additional Wages that attract CPF contributions, will remain at $102,000 at this juncture. It will be reviewed periodically to ensure it continues to cover the broad majority of CPF members. The CPF Annual limit will also remain at $37,740.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is overtime (OT) pay classified as Ordinary Wages (OW) or Additional Wages (AW)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For wages to be classified as Ordinary Wages (OW) for the month, it must satisfy both conditions below: The wages are due or granted wholly or exclusively in respect of an employee’s employment during that month; and The wages for that month are payable by 14 th of the following month. Wages which are not classified as OW will be Additional Wages (AW) for the month. The overtime (OT) pay has to be apportioned to OT performed in each calendar month before classification. Please see examples below. Example 1 : OT performed in a calendar month S/N OT performed Payable date for OT pay Classification CPF payable by a 1 to 30 Apr 10 May OW for Apr 14 May b 1 to 30 Apr 30 May AW for May 14 Jun *Please note that the payable date refers to the date where company is contractually obligated to pay employee the wages. Do note that the Employment Act (EA) also imposes certain requirements on the timing for salary payment if employee is covered under EA. If there are circumstances that resulted in administrative delays in payment e.g. new employee joins after payroll cut-off date, you should use the payable date to determine the classification of wages. Example 2: OT performed across two calendar months, e.g. 25 Mar to 24 Apr S/N OT performed Payable date for OT pay Classification CPF payable by a 25 Mar to 24 Apr 30 Apr OT pay from 25 Mar to 30 Mar = AW for Apr* OT pay from 1 Apr to 24 Apr = OW for Apr 14 May *As CPF contribution is computed based on calendar month, the OT component from 25 Mar to 30 Mar can only be classified as OW if it is payable by 14 th of the month following Mar i.e. 14 Apr. Since the OT pay is only payable on 30 Apr, it does not fulfil the second condition for it to be classified as OW.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable if I have been contributing to my Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR) employee's pension scheme in his home country?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are mandatory for your Singapore Permanent Resident employee working in Singapore regardless of any contributions to another pension scheme in his home country.

Knowledge Article: Question: I was told by my dentist that I cannot use my Flexi-MediSave for my dental treatments. Why is that so?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Flexi-MediSave is meant to help with recurrent outpatient medical expenses, which many older Singaporeans have raised as a key concern due to significant accumulated bill sizes over the longer term.   Dental expenses are not covered under Flexi-MediSave as they are less frequent and patients already benefit from generous government subsidies – for example, at CHAS dental clinics and public institutions such as the polyclinics and National Dental Centre.   Nevertheless, patients can use MediSave under the MediSave limits for day surgeries for selected complex dental procedures.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is Flexi-MediSave only applicable to elderly members aged 60 years old and above?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediSave is meant to help Singaporeans pay for their more costly medical expenses, especially after retirement. Older Singaporeans usually incur more healthcare expenses as outpatient medical treatments tends to be more expensive for them, while having lower or no income if they have retired. The Flexi-MediSave scheme helps them by allowing them to use MediSave more flexibly to reduce their out-of-pocket expenses for outpatient medical care.   The Ministry of Health (MOH) will regularly review Flexi-MediSave and other financing policies to ensure that outpatient care remains affordable for all Singaporeans.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long do I have to pay my Home Protection Scheme premium?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will only need to pay the premium for 90% of your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover period. For example, if your HPS cover period is 30 years, you will only need to pay premium for 27 years.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use the monies in my CPF Special Account to pay the annual renewal premium for my Home Protection Scheme cover if I do not have sufficient savings in my CPF Ordinary Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Home Protection Scheme premiums can only be paid from the savings in your CPF Ordinary Account, and not from your CPF Special Account (SA) savings. The SA savings are meant for retirement needs as they may be the only source of funds that members can turn to for financing their living expenses in old age.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much premium do I need to pay for my Home Protection Scheme cover?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can calculate your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) premium online using the HPS Premium Calculator .   Find out more:   Where can I check the premium payable to renew my Home Protection Scheme cover?

Knowledge Article: Question: Why does the status of my Home Protection Scheme cover show “pending renewal” in the Home ownership dashboard when I have sufficient monies in my CPF Ordinary Account for the premium?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The deduction of premiums for the renewal of Home Protection Scheme (HPS) covers takes place on a weekly basis.   If your HPS cover renewal date falls between the weekly deduction runs, the status of your HPS cover will show as "pending renewal" in the Home ownership dashboard. Once the premium has been successfully deducted, the status of your HPS cover will change to "Active".   In the event that you do not have enough Ordinary Account (OA) savings to pay the premium, we will inform you to top-up the premium shortfall.

Knowledge Article: Question: When will my Home Protection Scheme cover start?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover will start when all the following conditions are met: You have obtained legal ownership of the flat i.e. legal documents are signed and keys are collected. You have executed the loan document with HDB or the approved mortgagee and are legally responsible for the loan. You have declared your health and have been accepted for cover under HPS. You have paid the HPS premium. Deduction of the premium from your Ordinary Account will take place generally within two weeks from the legal ownership date of your flat.

Knowledge Article: Question: Where can I check my current Home Protection Scheme cover details?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can check your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover status, current sum assured, and the share of your Annual Premium HPS cover under “Protection against losing your home” in the Home ownership dashboard using your Singpass.   You can also find comprehensive information regarding your HPS cover on the HPS certificate that was sent to you when your HPS cover was issued or adjusted.   If you have an outstanding housing loan and you do not see the "Protection against losing your home" section in the Home ownership dashboard, it means that you are not insured under HPS. You are strongly encouraged to apply for an HPS cover online , using your Singpass, to protect you and your loved ones from losing your HDB flat in the event of death, terminal illness, or total permanent disability.   Please note that you will be ineligible for a new HPS cover if: You are 65 years old and above, or Your previous application for HPS cover had been rejected due to your health condition.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will I be kept informed on my Home Protection Scheme cover details?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We will send you a Home Protection Scheme (HPS) certificate generally within one to two weeks after your HPS cover has commenced and you have paid the premium.   The HPS certificate will include information such as the amount you are insured for, your share of the cover, the policy start and end dates, the address of your insured flat, and your annual premium.   You can also view your HPS coverage status under “Protection against losing your home” via the  Home ownership dashboard .

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I reserve monies in my CPF Ordinary Account to pay the annual renewal premium for my Home Protection Scheme cover?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The monies in your CPF Ordinary Account (OA), including your incoming CPF contributions, will automatically be reserved up to a period of two months for the full Home Protection Scheme premium amount, when you do not have sufficient funds in your OA at the time of HPS cover renewal.

Knowledge Article: Question: Where can I check the premium payable to renew my Home Protection Scheme cover?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Home Protection Scheme (HPS) charges a level premium rate (i.e. same amount annually throughout the policy term). This means that you pay the same annual premium throughout your HPS coverage period. You can find the premium amount on your HPS certificate, which was sent to you when the HPS cover was first issued to you.   Your HPS premium is deducted from your CPF Ordinary Account every year during your policy anniversary month. You can also check the premium payable by viewing the previous premium deductions  online using your Singpass or from the Yearly Statement of Account.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long will I be insured under Home Protection Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will be insured under Home Protection Scheme for the term of your loan or up to age 65, whichever is earlier.

Knowledge Article: Question: How are my CPF contributions allocated to my CPF accounts?
Knowledge Article: Answer: When you’re younger, more of your CPF contributions are allocated to your Ordinary Account (OA) to support your home purchase. As you grow older, more CPF contributions are allocated to your Special Account (SA) and MediSave Account (MA) to meet growing retirement and healthcare needs respectively. You can view the CPF allocation rates for details.   When you move to the next age group, the change in allocation rates is applied from the first day of the month after your birthday.   Example:   If you turn 35 years old on 13 January 2024, Your allocation rates for January 2024 will be based on the “35 years and below” age group; and Your allocation rates for February 2024 will be based on the “Above 35 to 45 years” age group.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I pay my CPF contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As an employee, you need not do anything as your employer is required to pay the employer’s and employee’s share of CPF contributions to CPF Board on a monthly basis. Your employer will deduct the employee’s share of CPF contributions from your wages.   You may refer to the table below to find out if you and/or your employer need to pay CPF contributions based on your total wages per month.   Total wages per month CPF contribution by employer CPF contribution by employee Up to $50 No No Above $50 to $500 Yes No  Above $500 Yes Yes You can use the CPF contribution calculator to check if your CPF contributions are correctly paid by your employer.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long does it take to process the applications relating to Home Protection Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please refer to the table for our service standards for processing applications relating to Home Protection Scheme (HPS).   Service Normal processing time Apply for Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover / To adjust HPS cover Five working days (Upon the receipt of your loan information from your mortgagee). Longer time will be required if: We are unable to obtain loan information from your mortgagee through electronic arrangement with the Board*, or We need to further assess your eligibility for an HPS cover. The processing time for applications submitted at the same time by the owner and his/her co-owner may differ as each application is processed and assessed individually. *Mortgagees currently participating in electronic arrangement with the Board include: DBS Bank Ltd Hong Leong Finance Limited Housing & Development Board Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation Limited Standard Chartered Bank (Singapore) Limited The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation Limited United Overseas Bank Limited Termination of HPS Cover Five working days Exemption from the HPS Five working days (Upon receipt of your HPS Exemption application from your insurer(s)) Longer time may be required if: i) you are using multiple private policies from different insurers; ii) you have applied for an exemption share of cover lower than 100%. Pay HPS Premium Shortfall PayNow QR: Generally be processed almost instantly Authorise the Use of Ordinary Account Savings for Insured’s HPS premium Three working days Claim HPS benefits on Death Ground / Medical Ground Upon receipt of all required information, we will process the application generally within five working days.

Knowledge Article: Question: For CPF contributions paid in excess of the CPF Annual Limit, how do I derive the employee's share to be refunded to me?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For example, if you are a Singaporean Citizen who is below 55 years old and has received a total of $40,000 of CPF contributions for 2023, the excess contributions to be refunded to you can be estimated based on the calculation below:   Step 1: Total excess CPF contributions refunded to the employer = Total CPF contributions paid – CPF Annual Limit = $40,000 – $37,740 = $2,260 Step 2: Employee’s share to be refunded = (Total excess CPF contributions refunded ÷ applicable CPF contribution rate) x applicable employee CPF contribution rate = ($2,260 ÷ 37%) x 20% = $1,221* (cents should be dropped) You can also verify the above estimated employee’s share of refund by computing the difference between the total employee’s share of contributions paid and employee’s share of contributions payable. The employee’s share of contributions payable can be computed using the Additional Wage ceiling Calculator .   1 This rate is applicable for an employee who is a Singapore Citizen or Singapore Permanent Resident (3rd year onwards) and is 55 or below.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is Home Protection Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Home Protection Scheme (HPS) is a mortgage-reducing insurance that protects you and your loved ones from the risk of losing your HDB flat in the event of unforeseen circumstances like death, terminal illness, or total permanent disability.   HPS is designed to ensure that your loved ones can continue to live in the flat without worrying about the financial burden from any unforeseen circumstances. It insures members up to the age of 65 or until the housing loans are paid up, whichever is earlier. As a member, you will be covered until the age of 65 or until your housing loans are fully paid off, whichever comes first.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I am concurrently employed by more than one employer, can I choose to contribute CPF for one of my employments only?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are concurrently employed by more than one employer, all your employers must pay CPF contributions based on the wages payable to you. This is because the Ordinary Wage (OW) ceiling is applicable on a “per employment” basis.   However, if your total OW from your employers exceed the current OW ceiling , you may apply to limit your share of contributions. There will be no change to the employer’s share of CPF contributions . All your employers will have to pay the employer's share of CPF contributions on the OW at the prevailing rate, subject to the OW ceiling. As contributions are payable monthly, the approval cannot be backdated and it will only take effect once CPF Board’s approval has been granted.   You can submit an online application (via Singpass) to limit your share of CPF contributions.   *Please note that the below examples are for illustration purpose only. Please refer to the above links for the latest current OW ceiling and CPF contribution rates applicable.   Example 1: For month of June 2023 Current OW ceiling = $6,000 CPF contribution rate for employee’s share = 20% Employee’s share of CPF contributions based on current OW ceiling = $6,000 * 20% = $1,200 a) Salary with Employer A = $6,100 b) Your employee’s share of CPF contributions paid by employer A = $6,000 (current OW ceiling) * 20% = $1,200 c) The amount of employee’s share of CPF contributions you want employer A to contribute on your OW = $1,200 a) Salary with Employer B = $2,000 b) Your employee’s share of CPF contributions paid by employer B = $2,000 * 20% = $400 c) The amount of employee’s share of CPF contributions you want employer B to contribute on your OW = $0 Example 2: For month of June 2023 Using the same OW ceiling of $6,000 as example. Employee’s share of CPF contributions based on current OW ceiling = $1,200 a) Salary with Employer A = $8,000 b) Your employee’s share of CPF contributions paid by employer A = $6,000 (current OW ceiling) * 20% = $1,200 c) The amount of employee’s share of CPF contributions y ou want employer A to contribute on your OW = $1,000 a) Salary with Employer B = $2,000 b) Your employee’s share of CPF contributions paid by employer B = $2,000 * 20% = $400 c) The amount of employee’s share of CPF contributions you want employer B to contribute on your OW = $200 Note: The value in (c) should  not exceed (b) for the respective employer, and the sum of (c) across all employers  must be equal to the maximum CPF payable on OW (i.e. prevailing OW ceiling x employee’s share of contribution rate applicable to you)  Please also take note that whenever there are change(s) to the circumstances which may affect your CPF contributions on your OW, such as, but not limited to: changes to current OW ceiling your total combined OW falls below the current OW ceiling changes to employment status (e.g. new or left employment, no longer concurrently employed by 2 or more employers) changes to contribution rates crossing over to another age group as different contribution rates apply to different age group you  must inform  all your affected employers the revise apportionments of your employee’s share of CPF contributions, if applicable. Please see below Example 3 for better illustration of circumstance change(s). Example 3: OW ceiling adjustment change from $6,000 to  $6,300 For month of September 2023 Employee’s share of CPF contributions based on current OW ceiling = $6,300 * 20% =  $1,260     a) Salary with Employer A =  $6,100 b) Your employee’s share of CPF contributions paid by this employer A = $6,100 * 20% = $1,220 c) The amount of employee’s share of CPF contributions you want this employer A to contribute on your OW = $1,220 a) Salary with Employer B = $2,000 b) Your employee’s share of CPF contributions paid by this employer B = $2,000 * 20% = $400 c) The amount of employee’s share of CPF contributions you want this employer B to contribute on your OW = ($6,300 * 20% = $1,260) - $$1,220 (Employee's share under Employer A) = $40 In the event of any circumstance change(s) (i.e. the above example illustrate change to OW ceiling), the employee (applicant) has to revised the apportionments by using the applicable rates and inform all affected employers of the new revised apportionments.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the objective of CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Central Provident Fund (CPF) offers a comprehensive range of schemes and services. The CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) gives you the opportunity to invest your CPF savings in a wide range of investments to enhance your retirement nest egg.    Investment objectives and goals differ from person to person. The CPFIS reflects this by making different types of investments available to CPF members. Under the CPFIS, you can invest your CPF savings in shares and loan stocks, unit trusts, government bonds, statutory board bonds, bank deposits, fund management accounts, endowment insurance policies, investment-linked insurance policies, exchange traded funds and gold.   However, the CPF Board does not specifically endorse any product providers or investment products included under the CPFIS. All investments come with risk and you may lose all or a portion of the amount invested. If you are not confident of investing on your own, you may consider leaving your money in your CPF accounts, which earns risk-free interest.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) comprises the CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA) and CPF Investment Scheme-Special Account (CPFIS-SA). The scheme gives CPF members an option to invest their CPF savings, while meeting the long term objective of financial security in their old age.   Important Notes:   Members are advised to exercise prudence when they invest their CPF savings under the CPFIS. No one can guarantee that investments will always be profitable or that investment products included under CPFIS will always earn a profit. The CPF Board does not specifically endorse any product providers or investment products included under the CPFIS. All investments come with risk and you may lose all or a portion of the amount invested.   CPF members have to decide for themselves how to invest their savings and what risks to accept. If members are not confident of investing on their own or do not wish to risk their savings, they can always keep their money with the CPF Board and earn the risk-free interest.

Knowledge Article: Question: Which digital advisors can give advice to CPFIS members?
Knowledge Article: Answer: EndowUs and MoneyOwl are the two digital advisors currently allowed to give advisory services. However, MoneyOwl will stop their operations by December 2023. Please refer to their press release on 31 Aug 2023 .

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the service standards for processing applications relating to CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please refer to the table for our service standards for processing applications relating to CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS).   Service  Normal Processing Time Withdraw CPF investments  Within 3 working days Update Stock / Gold Limits  Within 2 working days Transfer CPFIS Sale Proceeds (Division of CPF-related Matrimonial Assets)  Within 15 working days

Knowledge Article: Question: What has happened to MoneyOwl?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MoneyOwl has announced that they will stop their operations by December 2023 and will transfer their business to iFast, which already holds the records of all their clients. You can find more details by reading MoneyOwl's press release dated 31 Aug 2023 .

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I check if I am eligible for licence application or renewal?
Knowledge Article: Answer: It depends on whether you are a self-employed person or a non-self-employed person.   For self-employed persons You can check if you are eligible for licence application or renewal by logging in to the Self-employment dashboard  using your Singpass. You can apply for your  Singpass online if you do not have one.   Your licensing agency, real estate company or financial institution may request for a copy of your MediSave payable statement. To retrieve your MediSave payable statement, click the PDF function icon at the top right of the MediSave payable statement after logging into Singpass.     Refer to this  guide  for step-by-step instructions on retrieving your MediSave payable statement.   For non-self-employed persons You can check if you are eligible for licence application by logging in to the  Self-employment dashboard  using your Singpass through ‘ Check your status ’ under Hassle-Free licence application/ renewal. You can apply for your  Singpass online  if you do not have one. You will be able to view a message indicating your licence application eligibility. Your licensing agency, real estate company or financial institution may request for a screenshot of the message to facilitate your application.     Refer to this  guide for step-by-step instructions on retrieving information on your eligibility for licence application.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am holding two types of licences (e.g. LTA and ACRA). Do I have to contribute to MediSave for both licences?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The MediSave payable is based on your annual net trade income (NTI) derived as a self-employed person and not the number of licences. If you have a total yearly NTI of more than $6,000 from your licence(s), you are required to make contributions to your MediSave Account.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to my investments made through MoneyOwl?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your investments made through MoneyOwl will stay with iFast. Even with the transfer of business from MoneyOwl to iFast from 25 Oct 2023, you can access and trade using the iFast platform instead of MoneyOwl. They will be reaching out to you with more information about the transfer.

Knowledge Article: Question: Who is eligible to receive the dollar-for-dollar matched MediSave contribution from the Government?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Self-employed persons who have made contributions from 1 January 2020 to 31 December 2021 under Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) are eligible to receive the one-off matched MediSave contributions.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is risk-return tradeoff?
Knowledge Article: Answer: All investments are subject to risk. Risk refers to the possibility that an investment could lose value or not gain any additional value because of swings in the financial markets.     All inve stments have a risk-return tradeoff. Historically, lower-risk investments -   like cash equivalent (e.g. fixed deposit) investments -   have typically offered lower potential for long-term growth and investment return. Higher-risk investments - like stock investments -   have typically offered greater potential for long-term growth and investment return.   By understanding the risk associated with various investment options, you can choose investments that best match your risk tolerance and personal circumstances.

Knowledge Article: Question: Who is eligible to participate in the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: All CPF members who are at least 18 years old; are not undischarged bankrupts; and have more than $20,000 in their Ordinary Account (for investment under CPFIS-Ordinary Account) and/or have more than $40,000 in their Special Account (for investment under CPFIS-Special Account). From 1 October 2018, as a new CPFIS investor, you will need to take the Self-Awareness Questionnaire (SAQ) before you can start investing under CPFIS.

Knowledge Article: Question: Should I maintain a consistent strategy in investing?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Once you have decided on the right investment mix to meet your investment objectives and goals, you should try to maintain a consistent strategy. In general, you should only change your strategy if your personal circumstances have changed.   As tempting as it may be to "bail out" if your investments take a dive, financial experts generally suggest that you stay fully invested. If you try to "time the market", you run the risk of getting caught in the trap of "buying high" and "selling low".   If you hold on to your investment, chances are good that its value may eventually go back up, and that it may end up being worth more than when its value dropped.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the CPF allocation rates from 1 January 2024?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The increase in the CPF contribution rates from 1 January 2024 will be fully allocated to the member’s Special Account to provide a bigger boost to their retirement income. You may refer to the CPF allocation rate table (PDF, 0.1 MB) for more details.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have just obtained my Singapore Permanent Resident status. Do I need to contribute CPF?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, CPF contributions are payable from the day you obtained your Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR) status. In the first two years of obtaining the SPR status, you and your employer will contribute to CPF at graduated rates to help you adjust to the lower take-home pay. However, you and your employer have the option to apply jointly to CPF Board to contribute at higher rates .

Knowledge Article: Question: If my employee is under multiple employment, is he/she required to contribute to the Self-Help Group (SHG) fund via all his/her employers?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You are expected to deduct your employee’s contributions to the Self-Help Group (SHG) from his/her wages. However, your employee can choose to contribute through one employer only by informing his/her SHG.

Knowledge Article: Question: My child is paying for my chronic disease treatment under the MediSave500/700 scheme. Can I also tap on my spouse's Flexi-MediSave to pay for the co-payment?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If both you and your spouse are aged 60 years old or above, you can use your spouse's Flexi-MediSave for the 15% co-payment.   Also, if you have reached the withdrawal limit for chronic disease treatment, you can tap on your own or your spouse's Flexi-MediSave to continue reducing the cash payment, provided that you have not reached the $300 withdrawal limit.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are there different CPF contribution rates for Singapore Permanent Resident employees of different nationalities?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF contribution rates are applied consistently to all Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR) employees regardless of their nationalities.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I terminate my standing instruction to use my CPF Ordinary Account savings to pay for my co-owner's Home Protection Scheme premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please write to us if you wish to revoke your standing instruction to use your CPF Ordinary Account savings to pay your co-owner's Home Protection Scheme premium shortfall.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I renew my licence if I have been making Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can renew your licence so long as you have no outstanding MediSave payable or are on a monthly GIRO instalment plan.

Knowledge Article: Question: What if my banking app is unable to scan the PayNow QR for my top-up application?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are having trouble scanning the PayNow QR code for your top-up application, you should reach out to your bank for assistance.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on bonuses given to my employees for their employment in Singapore if they are currently posted overseas?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are not payable for your employees posted to work overseas.   As such, CPF contributions are not required on bonuses paid when your employee is posted overseas. It does not matter if the bonus is granted on account of his employment in Singapore prior to the overseas posting.   Similarly, if your employee is currently working in Singapore, any bonuses that becomes payable during this period would attract CPF contributions.   The above CPF treatments apply only if there is no change in employer, i.e. you are still the employer, despite the change in country of employment for your employee.   Where the Singapore employer and the overseas employer are different legal entities   CPF contributions are payable if:   a. Your employee has terminated the employment contract with you in Singapore and started a new employment with an overseas employer; and   b. The bonus is payable by you for your employee’s employment in Singapore.   CPF contributions are not payable if:   a. The employee has terminated the employment contract with the overseas employer and started a new employment with you in Singapore; and   b. The bonus is payable by the overseas company for employment overseas.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is there a minimum amount I need to top up to be eligible for the matching grant?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There is no minimum amount of cash top-up needed to be eligible for the matching grant. However, you are encouraged to top up at least a total of up to $600 in the year to receive the maximum grant.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much CPF contributions should I receive?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Use our  CPF contribution calculator to calculate the amount of CPF contributions you should receive from your employer.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I am paying via Direct Debit, when will CPF Board deduct from my bank account after my CPF submission?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Direct Debit deduction will only take place after you have submitted your CPF contribution details. If you are submitting via CPF EZPay, you will see the deduction date in the "Deduction On" field below the "Direct Debit" button.   If you have set up Electronic Standing Instruction (ESI) within CPF EZPay, the deduction date will be the 3rd working day from the 14th of the following month (or the next working day if the 14th falls on a Saturday, Sunday or Public Holiday). Please remember to maintain sufficient funds for successful deduction. If your deduction fails, there will be a 2nd deduction seven calendar days later (or next working day if it falls on a public holiday). This may result in late CPF submission and incur late payment interest.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on training allowance given to your trainee under the SGUnited Traineeship Programme if you are the host company?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are not payable on training allowance for your trainee under the SGUnited Traineeship Programme so long as he is not employed under a contract of service . You and your trainee may enter into an employer-employee relationship at any time, including upon completion of the programme, in which case, CPF contributions would be payable on wages given to your employee.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long does it take to update entity's particulars?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Service Normal Processing Time Update Employer's Particulars – Mandatory contribution CPF Submission Number Immediately upon submission. Update Employer's Particulars – Voluntary contribution/Additional MediSave contribution Scheme CPF Submission Number Within three working days.   An email notification will be sent to both the owner (or employer representative) and the person in charge of CPF contribution matters once the employer particulars have been updated.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I pay my employees' SHARE donations?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You are expected to deduct the SHARE donations from your employees’ wages and pay the SHARE donations together with the CPF contributions.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is there a 12-hour cooling period?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The 12-hour cooling period is a safeguard that provides members sufficient time to take action to prevent any unauthorised adjustments to the CPF online Daily Withdrawal Limit, or changes to important personal information and bank account details from taking effect. The 12-hour duration is aligned with industry practice.   To minimise any delays when making withdrawals, we advise you to plan ahead and regularly ensure that your bank account and contact details are updated with the Board.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am aged 65 years old, and I would like to use my Flexi-MediSave to pay for my father's outpatient medical treatment cost at a polyclinic. Can I do so?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Flexi-MediSave can only be used for your own or your spouse's outpatient medical treatment expenses.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will I receive any notification after payment has been made to the institution under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you (i.e. the CPF account holder) have used your CPF savings to pay for the tuition fees, you should receive a notification generally by the following month after the payment has been made to the institution.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why does the CPF lender need to login to endorse my online application under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF lender must endorse your CPF Education Loan Scheme application using his/her Singpass to consent to the withdrawal of his/her CPF savings for your tertiary education.

Knowledge Article: Question: I've used up my Flexi-MediSave limit of $300, but my spouse needs medical treatment too. Can I use my MediSave for his/her medical bills?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Each elderly patient can use up to $300 of Flexi-MediSave in a year. Even if you have already used up $300 from your MediSave Account for your own outpatient treatment, you can use another $300 of Flexi-MediSave for your spouse's outpatient treatment, provided that your spouse is also aged 60 and above and has not used his/her own Flexi-MediSave limit.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I make a one-time authorisation to use my MediSave for my loved one's medical expenses in different Medical Institutions without signing a new form at each Medical Institution?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will need to authorise the use of your MediSave for your loved one's medical expenses by signing the Medical Claims Authorisation Form (Single Institution) at each Medical Institution. This is to reduce the likelihood that your MediSave is used for subsequent treatments at the same institution and/or other institutions without your knowledge.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use CPF savings for my full-time subsidised local degree course if I have previously used CPF savings for my first subsidised diploma course?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use CPF savings for your degree course as long as it is an approved full-time subsidised course under the CPF Education Loan Scheme, subject to the available withdrawal limit .

Knowledge Article: Question: Apart from the Ordinary Account savings, can I use my savings from other CPF Accounts under CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Only Ordinary Account savings can be used under the CPF Education Loan Scheme.

Knowledge Article: Question: I visited a clinic for an outpatient medical treatment that can be paid by my Flexi-MediSave. How do I go about using my Flexi-MediSave?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To use your Flexi-MediSave for your outpatient medical treatment cost:   Inform the clinic that you wish to use MediSave to pay for your outpatient medical treatment. The staff will require your NRIC/Passport. If you are paying for your spouse, please also produce his/her NRIC/Passport. The clinic may require information on how much MediSave is available for payment of the outpatient treatment. You will be able to obtain this information by logging in to your Healthcare dashboard under my cpf digital services, with your Singpass. You and the patient (if applicable) will need to sign a Medical Claims Authorisation Form to allow the clinic to use your Flexi-MediSave to pay for the outpatient medical treatment bill. If your employer or insurer is also paying for your outpatient treatment, please bring along your Letter of Guarantee or Employer Identity Pass (i.e. if your clinic already has an existing arrangement with your employer or insurer).

Knowledge Article: Question: My Singapore Permanent Resident status was reinstated with a new Re-Entry Permit. Which issue date should I refer to determine my CPF contribution rates?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions will be payable from the day your Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR) status was reinstated. However, to determine the year of SPR status, you should refer to the date indicated on your valid Entry Permit (Form 5/5A) issued by the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority of Singapore (ICA).

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is my email address required for the online application under CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: An email* with a link will be sent to the CPF lender's email address provided in the application form the next day if the application is in order. The lender* must log in through the provided link or the Endorse CPF education loan form in the CPF website, using his/her own Singpass, in order to approve the withdrawal of their CPF savings for your tertiary education. Hence, providing a valid and correct email address is important.    If the borrower provides an incorrect email address in the online application form, the borrower will need to cancel the initial application. Once their cancellation request has been processed, they will need to submit a new application with the correct details within the specified application period.   *This is not applicable if you are applying to use your own CPF savings for the tuition fees payment.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will I be given a medical certificate for my Home Protection Scheme medical examination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Board’s panel clinics, which conduct the Home Protection Scheme medical examination, will not issue a medical certificate for the medical examination. However, you can ask the clinic to issue a time chit as evidence of your attendance and duration at the clinic.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I send my enquiry via text messaging?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Thank you for your interest in using our text messaging service. You can access the text messaging through WhatsApp if your question cannot be found in our FAQs.   Our text messaging service is available: Monday - Friday: 8:30am to 5:30pm Saturday, Sunday and public holidays: Closed Eves of Christmas, New Year and Chinese New Year: 8:30am to 1:00pm

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I lodge a report for non-payment or underpayment of CPF contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For discrepancies in CPF contributions :   If you suspect any non-payment or underpayment of CPF contributions, you may use the CPF calculator  to verify the CPF contribution rates applicable to you. Please note that certain types of payments do not attract CPF contributions, you may click here to find out more.   If there are discrepancies, you should approach your employer immediately, while the documentary evidence is fresh. Your employer is expected to rectify the errors without delay.   If your employer does not provide you with a satisfactory response, you can lodge a report with CPF Board. Please enclose all available supporting documents to support your claim (e.g. pay slips and employment contract). Claims made without any supporting documents would require a longer time to investigate.   If you would like to lodge a report, please click here . Please note the likelihood of recovery for any non/underpayment of CPF contributions beyond 1 year is low as the parties’ recollection of the facts or availability of evidence may diminish over time.   For discrepancies in CPF contributions and employment-related claims:   If you have any salary and dismissal related claims, you should try to resolve the dispute amicably with your employer first. If your employer does not provide you with a satisfactory response, you should file your claims with the Tripartite Alliance for Dispute Management (TADM) .   The Board will compute the CPF contributions based on the amount of wages due and payable once TADM has concluded your claims.

Knowledge Article: Question: I want to pay for my outpatient treatment for chronic disease using MediSave. How can I do so?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To use your MediSave for your outpatient medical treatment cost:   1. Inform the clinic that you wish to use MediSave to pay for your outpatient medical treatment. The staff will require your NRIC/Passport. If you are paying for your approved dependant, please also produce his/her NRIC/Passport. Approved dependants refer to spouse, children, parents, grandparents and siblings. Please note that your grandparents and siblings must be Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents.   2. The clinic may require information on how much MediSave is available for payment of the outpatient treatment. You will be able to obtain this information by logging in to your Healthcare dashboard under my cpf digital services, with your Singpass.   3. You and the patient (if applicable) will need to sign a Medical Claims Authorisation Form to allow the clinic to use your MediSave to pay for the outpatient treatment bill.   4. If your employer or insurer is also paying for your outpatient treatment, please bring along your Letter of Guarantee or Employer Identity Pass (i.e. if your clinic already has an existing arrangement with your employer or insurer).

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I appeal to use the new $300 Flexi-MediSave limit for my outstanding medical bills or for any treatments incurred before 1 June 2021?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will not be able to use the new $300 Flexi-MediSave limit for any treatments received before 1 June 2021.   The new limit will only be applicable for treatments received on or after 1 June 2021.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I have used up other MediSave limits - for example, for scans or for cancer drug treatment, can I use Flexi-MediSave to pay?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are already using MediSave to pay for outpatient treatment but have reached your withdrawal limit, you can use Flexi-MediSave to further lower your cash payment, provided that treatment was sought at a polyclinic, public specialist outpatient clinic or general practitioner clinic participating in the Community Health Assist Scheme (CHAS).   Flexi-MediSave cannot be used for cancer drug treatments using cancer drugs that are not on the Cancer Drug List.   However, as Flexi-MediSave covers a much wider range of outpatient treatments than other limits, you may want to save the use of your Flexi-MediSave for treatments that are not already covered by MediSave so as to lower your total cash payments.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use different bank accounts to repay my education loans for two different courses?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Only one bank account may be maintained for repayments under the CPF Education Loan Scheme. If you submit a GIRO form for repayment using a new account, deductions for all the courses that you are repaying will be made from the new account.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I report invalid CPF contributions from employers whom I did not work for?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can lodge a report with CPF Board by clicking here  if you have received invalid CPF contributions from employers whom you did not work for.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have used my MediSave for some outpatient treatments of my chronic disease this year, and would like to know how much more I can use. How can I do so?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can check how much more MediSave you can use for outpatient treatments of your chronic disease through:   a. my cpf digital services   • Log in to your Healthcare dashboard using your Singpass   • Select "Utilisation of healthcare benefits" from the menu bar or scroll down to the "Utilisation of healthcare benefits" section for "Treatments for chronic illnesses (MediSave500/700)"   b. CPF Mobile app   • Download CPF Mobile app   • Log in using your Singpass   • Select "My Healthcare" from the menu bar for "Outpatient Treatment"

Knowledge Article: Question: If I have used $500 from my MediSave account for my treatment under MediSave500, can I still withdraw from my family members' MediSave accounts to pay for my treatment?
Knowledge Article: Answer: From 1 January 2021, each patient is eligible to withdraw up to $700 (for patients with complex chronic conditions) or $500 (for non-complex chronic patients) for their own treatment, regardless of how many MediSave accounts are being withdrawn from.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am a patient with a complex chronic condition. Will I enjoy the higher withdrawal limit of $700 under MediSave500/700 even after my condition improves?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The MediSave500/700 withdrawal limit is a yearly limit. This means that you will continue to be able to withdraw up to $700 in the new year if you have had visits for two or more conditions listed under the Chronic Disease Management Programme (CDMP), or one CDMP condition with complications in that year.

Knowledge Article: Question: How is my CPF interest computed and credited into my accounts?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF interest is computed monthly. It is credited to your respective accounts by the following year and compounded annually.   CPF balances used for interest computation are affected by the transactions in your account. For instance, contributions (including refunds) received this month start earning interest next month. Withdrawals/deductions in this month will not earn interest from this month onwards.   There are strict procedures in place to ensure the accuracy of members’ CPF accounts and transactions (including interest payments). To further ensure that our system is sound and robust, our statutory auditor performs regular reviews of formulas and computations in our systems for accuracy, and conducts independent verifications of the transactions and account balances.

Knowledge Article: Question: How was the MediSave500/700 withdrawal limit sized?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The MediSave withdrawal limits are generally sized to cover subsidised bills, so that the healthcare costs remain affordable.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I withdraw the matching grant?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, the top-up and matching grant are meant to boost your retirement savings for higher monthly payouts, hence they cannot be withdrawn in a lump sum. They will be paid out to you as part of your monthly payouts in retirement.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I apply to port my Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover to my new flat, instead of applying for a HPS cover?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We can only consider porting the previous Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover for members who are not eligible for a new HPS cover. Therefore, you must apply for a new HPS cover first.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the personal income tax relief cap and why is there a cap on this relief for cash top-ups made?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The personal income tax relief cap sets a limit on the total amount of tax relief you can claim.   Even though each relief serves a good purpose, some individuals may end up with a significantly reduced taxable income when multiple reliefs are combined. Therefore, tax relief on cash top-ups is also subjected to the personal income tax relief cap.

Knowledge Article: Question: When will my eligibility for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme be assessed and do I need to apply?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We will assess your eligibility for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme (MRSS) annually at the beginning of the year. You do not need to apply as your eligibility is automatically assessed.   If you are eligible, we will notify you via email or post. You can also check your eligibility through the MRSS eligibility checker .

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I check my top-up limits?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can check your top-up limit in your Retirement Dashboard .   Find out how the top up limit is computed .

Knowledge Article: Question: When will I receive the matching grant?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme and have received cash top-ups in that year, you can expect to receive the matching grant in your Retirement Account at the beginning of the following year.

Knowledge Article: Question: Who can I receive top-ups from?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Cash top-ups   You can receive cash top-ups from anyone, including yourself, your family, employers or any member of the community.   CPF transfers   You can receive CPF transfers only from yourself or your loved ones .   You must be a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident to receive a top-up.

Knowledge Article: Question: Who are considered my loved ones?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your loved ones refer to your parents, parents-in-law, grandparents, grandparents-in-law, spouse and siblings.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is PayNow QR?
Knowledge Article: Answer: PayNow QR is a convenient and faster way for you to make payments by scanning a QR code using your mobile banking app. It is also secure as it adopts the same high security standards adopted by the Singapore banking industry for fund transfers such as FAST and GIRO.   You can use PayNow QR if you have accounts with any of the following banks in Singapore: Citibank Singapore Limited, DBS Bank/POSB, HSBC, Maybank, OCBC Bank, Standard Chartered Bank, United Overseas Bank, Bank of China, and Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Limited.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I apply for internet or mobile banking?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Applying for internet or mobile banking is easy and convenient. To get started, you can refer to the digital banking resources compiled by Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA). This list provides a comprehensive guide on how to apply for internet or mobile banking with various banks in Singapore.   You can also visit any SG Digital community hub to enjoy one-on-one guidance from IMDA’s digital ambassadors, who would be happy to assist you in setting up your internet or mobile banking account and answer any questions you may have.

Knowledge Article: Question: How are CPF interest rates determined?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Savings in the Ordinary Account (OA) earn the 3-month average of major local banks’ interest rates, subject to the legislated minimum interest of 2.5% per annum. This is reviewed quarterly.   Savings in the Special, MediSave, and Retirement Accounts (SMRA) earn the 12-month average yield of 10-year Singapore Government Securities (10YSGS) plus 1%, subject to the current floor interest rate of 4% per annum. This is reviewed quarterly.   Please refer to the CPF interest rates and MOF website for more information.   Computation of CPF OA Interest Rate and HDB Mortgage Rate for 1 July 2024 to 30 September 2024     Average banks' interest rate from February 2024 to April 2024 0.45% (see note)  CPF OA interest rate for July 2024 to September 2024  2.50% per annum  (legislated minimum rate)  Plus:  Fee to cover Cost of Loan Administration  0.10% HDB mortgage rate for July 2024 to September 2024  2.60% per annum   Note: 12-month deposit rate (% per annum) Savings Rate (% per annum) Average (% per annum) Month / Year DBS 1 OCBC 2 UOB 3 DBS 4 OCBC 5 UOB 6 Using the 80FD:20SD formula 29 Feb 2024 0.0500 0.1000 1.5000 0.0500 0.0500 0.0500 0.4500 31 Mar 2024 0.0500 0.1000 1.5000 0.0500 0.0500 0.0500 0.4500 30 Apr 2024 0.0500 0.1000 1.5000 0.0500 0.0500 0.0500 0.4500   1 Balances of $20,000 to < $50,000 2 Balances > $20,000 to $50,000 3 Balances < $50,000 4 Balances > $10,000 to $100,000 (AUTO-SAVE Account) 5 Entire Account Balance (EASI-SAVE Account)  6 Balances > $15,000 to $100,000 (UNIPLUS Account)   Computation of CPF SMRA Interest Rate for 1 July 2024 to 30 September 2024     Average yield of 10YSGS from May 2023 to April 2024  3.08% Plus : 1.00% 1.00% Computed CPF SMRA interest rate for July 2024 to September 2024  4.08% CPF SMRA interest rate floor for July 2024 to September 2024  4.00% CPF SMRA interest rate for July 2024 to September 2024  4.08% per annum   Source: Yields of 10-Year Singapore Government Securities are obtained from  mas.gov.sg/bonds-and-bills   1 Please refer to the historical CPF interest rates (PDF, 0.15MB) for more information on past RA rates.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I derive the breakdown of employer and employee's contributions indicated on my Yearly Statement of Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The breakdown of the employer and employee's CPF contributions is meant to be indicative as general assumptions were used in the derivation. They are derived based on the amount submitted by your employer(s) in the past year as well as the assumptions below:   1. Employee is a:   Singapore Citizen; or 3rd year and onwards Singapore Permanent Resident; or 1st and 2nd year Singapore Permanent Resident who has jointly applied with employer to pay full employer and employee CPF contribution rates;  2. Employee with multiple employments did not apply to limit their share of contribution on Ordinary Wage;   3. Multiple CPF contributions made by the employer in the particular month were calculated on a per transaction basis rather than on an aggregated basis;   4. The following are excluded in the breakdown:  Adjustment(s) and refund(s) requested by employer(s); Voluntary CPF contributions made by your employer(s) or yourself; and MediSave contributions as a Self-employed Person.  To determine the exact breakdown of your CPF contributions based on your total wages per month; please use our  CPF contribution calculator .

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I check my CPF account balances, contribution, transaction records, including records beyond 15 months?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can login to my cpf digital services or CPF Mobile app via your Singpass to view your account balances and 15-month CPF statements.   For records beyond 15 months, you can refer to your last 10 years of Yearly Statement of Account on my cpf digital services . Please note that we do not provide the service of retrieving CPF statements beyond the past 10 years.   Please refer to this guide (PDF, 0.28MB) on how to view and save your statement on your mobile device.   If you do not have a Singpass and/or 2FA, please visit the Singpass website to obtain one.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I save and download a copy of my CPF contribution details?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There are two ways where you can download your CPF contribution details:   1.       Log in to  CPF Mobile app with your Singpass > Select the menu option on the top left-hand corner > Select ‘Transaction History’ > Select the filter icon > Select ‘Employment Contributions’ and/or ‘Self-Employed Contributions’ options under Transaction Type and the corresponding month range > Click ‘Apply’ > Select “Generate PDF” on the top-right hand corner to download a copy of your CPF working contribution details.   2.       Log in to   my cpf  digital services with your Singpass > Select ‘ my cpf ’ > Select ‘Transaction history’ under My statements > Select the filter icon > Select ‘Employment contributions’ and/or ‘Self-employed contributions’ options under Transaction types and the corresponding month range > Click ‘Apply’ > Select PDF icon on the top right-hand corner to download a copy of your CPF working contribution details.

Knowledge Article: Question: I would like a hardcopy of my monthly transaction statement. Where can I get it?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As part of our efforts to go green, you may view, download and save your monthly transaction statement via the link provided in our notification. We strongly encourage you to view your monthly transaction statement online to enjoy a richer and more interactive user experience. If you require your transaction history for the past 15 months, you may login to my cpf digital services via your Singpass. You can also watch the  instructional video  in your preferred language on how to access your CPF statements online.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I save or download a copy of my Digital Yearly Statement of Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: On the Digital Yearly Statement of Account (YSOA) page, click on “PDF icon” to view, download and save a copy of your YSOA. You can also download a copy of your statement to view on your mobile device.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why can't I see my Year-in-Review?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will be able to view your Year-in-Review (YIR) from your birthday.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I make my MediSave contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There are several ways you can contribute to your MediSave. The most convenient way is via GIRO, which allows automatic monthly deductions from your bank account.   Payment mode Details GIRO Using  my cpf digital services ( list of participating banks ) Log in with your Singpass. Submit the Set up GIRO for MediSave contributions application. Check the status of your GIRO application via Activities. Mail (for other banks) Download and complete the  Apply for GIRO for MediSave Contributions  form (FORM SE GIRO (PDF, 0.6MB)).             Mail it to the address printed overleaf of the GIRO application form. We will notify you of your GIRO application status once the bank has processed it. PayNow QR Request for an instalment plan or pay your MediSave payable in full via the  Manage your MediSave payable  form. NETS/ CashCard Pay by NETS or CashCard at any SingPost branches. You may view your MediSave contributions on the Self-employment dashboard. To access  my cpf  Digital Services – Self-employment dashboard, please log in to the  CPF website  using your Singpass.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I check my voluntary top-up limit to my CPF accounts?
Knowledge Article: Answer: When you make a cash top-up online, you will be shown the amount of top-up you can receive before you reach the top-up limit.   You can follow these steps to check how much you can top up to your CPF accounts:   Go to the Top up CPF accounts form Log in with your Singpass Select “I wish to make a top-up to Myself” under “Recipient details” Your top-up limit will then be displayed.   If the total mandatory CPF contributions and voluntary top-ups exceed the CPF Annual Limit in the calendar year, the excess voluntary top-ups will be refunded without interest the following year. Therefore, do remember to consider your mandatory CPF contributions which you will be receiving for the calendar year, before making voluntary top-ups.   If you are making a top-up on another person’s behalf, please check with your recipient directly on the amount he can receive.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can an overseas insurance company disburse the approved claim to my MediSave Account by telegraphic transfer or only by cheque?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your insurer may submit reimbursements to MediSave and MediShield Life electronically via cpf.gov.sg . To access the MediSave/MediShield Life Internet Reimbursement service, please log on to cpf.gov.sg and go to Employer => Tools and services => MediSave/MediShield Life reimbursements.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on Annual Wage Supplement (AWS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on Annual Wage Supplement (AWS) given to your employee.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the minimum age to qualify for CPF contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As an employee, you are required to pay CPF contributions as long as you are a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident, and are employed in Singapore under a contract of service .

Knowledge Article: Question: How much CPF savings do I need to join CPF LIFE?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There is no minimum amount of CPF savings required for joining CPF LIFE. However, it is important to consider how much savings you have in your Retirement Account (RA) as this will determine how much monthly payouts you will receive.   If you join CPF LIFE with a low RA balance (which is used to pay for the premium for your CPF LIFE plan), you may receive a low monthly payout which may not be enough to support your retirement needs. You can consider topping up your RA and use the Monthly payout estimator  to estimate your monthly payout to see if it is worthwhile doing so before you join CPF LIFE.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I determine the year of my Singapore Permanent Resident status for the purpose of CPF contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The year of Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR) status determines your CPF contribution rates as an SPR. The first year rate applies from the day you obtain your SPR status. This refers to the date indicated on your entry permit (Form 5/5A) issued by the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority of Singapore (ICA). It ends on the last day of the month of your first anniversary of SPR conversion. The second and third year rates apply from the month following the anniversary of your conversion to an SPR. Example If you have obtained your SPR status on 15 January 2020, the start and end dates for first, second and third year of obtaining SPR status are shown in the table below:

Knowledge Article: Question: How are the CPF LIFE premium and payout for each plan calculated?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF LIFE premium and payout levels are determined by an independent actuarial consultant. They are dependent on factors such as:   Retirement Account savings used to join CPF LIFE Sex; Age; CPF interest rates; and Mortality rates

Knowledge Article: Question: How was the employee's share of CPF contributions indicated on my CPF Contribution Alert being derived?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your employee’s share of CPF contributions on the CPF Contribution Alert is derived by applying the applicable CPF contribution rate to the total CPF contributions made by your employer. The computation is performed on a per transaction basis, and is not aggregated if your employer had made multiple CPF contributions for you in a particular month. It also does not take into account if you had applied to limit your employee’s share of contribution on Ordinary Wages for multiple employments. As the employee’s share of CPF contributions indicated on the CPF Contribution Alert are meant to be indicative, please use our CPF contribution calculator to determine the exact breakdown of your employee's share of CPF contributions based on your total wages per month.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have just converted from a Singapore Permanent Resident to a Singapore Citizen. When should I apply the CPF contribution rates applicable to Singapore Citizens?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF contribution rates for a Singapore Citizen will apply from the date you have converted to a Singapore Citizen. For Ordinary Wages (OW), your employer will need to pro-rate your OW and apply the appropriate rates to determine your CPF contributions. Your employer can write to us for assistance on the computation if the OW for the month exceeds the OW ceiling or if the pro-rated wages are below $750. For Additional Wages (AW), your employer will need to apply the applicable contribution rate depending on when the AW is payable to you. Example: Assuming you are in your second year of Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR) status and become a Singapore Citizen on 15 June 2020: For OW   The second year SPR rate should be applied on the pro-rated wages for the period 1 June to 14 June 2020. The Singapore Citizen rate should be applied on the pro-rated wages for the period of 15 June to 30 June 2020. For AW   The second year SPR rate should be applied on the AW if it is payable between 1 June and 14 June 2020. The Singapore Citizen rate should be applied on the AW if it is payable between 15 June and 30 June 2020.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will changes to my Retirement Account affect my CPF LIFE monthly payouts?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Changes to your Retirement Account (RA) can affect your monthly payouts. This is because your RA savings is one of the factors in determining your CPF LIFE payouts .   Outflow from your RA, such as lump sum withdrawals will reduce your CPF LIFE monthly payouts. On the other hand, inflows to your RA, such as top-ups, or refunds from selling your property or investments will be automatically used to increase your CPF LIFE premium, and allow you to receive higher monthly payouts.   If you have started receiving your CPF LIFE monthly payouts, we will inform you of any revision in your monthly payouts in the following month after the outflow/inflow of funds.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if my employer has overpaid my CPF contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your employer has overpaid your CPF contributions, please inform your employer immediately to rectify the errors early while documentary evidence is fresh. Your employer can apply online, for a refund or adjustment of the overpaid CPF contributions immediately and no later than one year from the payment date.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the deadline to make Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions must be paid to the self-employed person (SEP) no later than the day that the service fee was paid to the SEP. For example, if you pay your SEP vendor his net service fee on 8 March 2023, you will need to pay his CAYE contributions by 8 March 2023.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens if the MediSave contributions I made via Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) are lower than my MediSave payable for the year?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your total CAYE contributions are lower than your MediSave payable for the latest year, you will be required to top up the remaining amount. You’ll be notified accordingly, and you can choose to make payment via a lump-sum payment(s) or sign up for monthly GIRO instalments.   Example: Based on his estimated income of $21,000 for 2023, Sam contributed $2,100 via CAYE. In the following year, he declared that he earned a higher NTI of $30,000 for 2023. As such, Sam’s MediSave payable for his work done in 2023 is $3,000. Sam will have to top up the shortfall of $900.   This example is illustrated within the table below: Estimated 2023 NTI $21,000 CAYE contributions in 2023 $2,100 (After 2023 NTI declaration) Declared 2023 NTI $30,000 MediSave payable for work done in 2023 $3,000 Shortfall Sam has to top up $900 (i.e. $3,000 - $2,100)

Knowledge Article: Question: If I do not intend to renew my licence, do I need to settle my outstanding MediSave payable?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You’re required to pay your outstanding MediSave payable even if you do not intend to renew your licence.

Knowledge Article: Question: How does the CPF LIFE Basic Plan work?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF LIFE Basic Plan is a legacy plan carried over from the time CPF LIFE was first introduced in 2009. Many members would find the Standard or Escalating Plan more suited to their needs.   If you opt for the Basic Plan, about 80-90% of your Retirement Account (RA) savings will be directly used to provide payouts until age 90. The remaining 10-20% will be deducted as your CPF LIFE premium when you join CPF LIFE and used to provide payouts from age 90 for the rest of your life. As less is used for your CPF LIFE premium, the monthly payout will be lower compared to the Standard Plan.   The monthly payouts under Basic Plan will get progressively lower when your combined CPF balances eventually fall below $60,000. This is because the extra interest earned on the first $60,000 of your CPF balances is credited to your RA and factored into your monthly payouts. As your balances are withdrawn over time to provide you with monthly payouts, the amount of monthly payouts and extra interest will decrease when your balances fall below $60,000.

Knowledge Article: Question: How does the CPF LIFE Standard Plan work?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF LIFE Standard Plan provides level payouts. This plan is suitable for members who are comfortable with buying less and maintaining a modest lifestyle to cope with rising prices.   Compared to the CPF LIFE Escalating Plan, the Standard Plan provides higher payouts at the start but it doesn't increase over time to keep up with the rising prices. Hence, the payouts will eventually be lower than Escalating Plan payouts.   Under this plan, all your Retirement Account savings will be deducted as CPF LIFE premium when you join CPF LIFE.   Your CPF LIFE monthly payouts will first be paid from your CPF LIFE premium. When your CPF LIFE premium is depleted, you will continue to receive the monthly payouts from the interest that you and other CPF LIFE members have accumulated, no matter how long you live.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I view my CPF contributions details in the CPF Contribution Alert email?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have downloaded the latest version of the CPF Mobile app , you will be directed to the CPF Mobile app upon clicking the link. If you have not downloaded the latest version of the CPF Mobile app, or you are viewing on a desktop or laptop, you will be directed to your web browser to view the details.

Knowledge Article: Question: How does the CPF LIFE Escalating Plan work?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF LIFE Escalating Plan is a suitable option if you want to protect your retirement income from rising prices. Under this plan you will receive payouts that increase by 2% each year. Although the payouts start lower, they will eventually become higher than the Standard Plan and Basic Plan payouts. The Escalating Plan gives you peace of mind knowing that you can generally maintain your standard of living even as the cost of living goes up during your retirement years.   For example, if you start with a monthly payout of $1,000 when you turn 65, it will increase by 2% each year and reach around $1,500 when you are 85. The 2% increase takes place every year in the same month that you receive your first payout.   Under this plan, all your Retirement Account savings will be deducted as CPF LIFE premium when you join CPF LIFE, which can be anytime from 65 to 70.   Your CPF LIFE monthly payouts will first be paid from your CPF LIFE premium. When your CPF LIFE premium is depleted, you will continue to receive the monthly payouts from the interest that you and other CPF LIFE members have accumulated, no matter how long you live.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is joint-tenancy?
Knowledge Article: Answer: A joint-tenancy is a form of property ownership where all co-owners have an equal interest in the property, regardless of the individual owner's contribution to the property purchase.   This means that upon the death of a joint-tenant, his interest in the property will automatically pass on to the remaining co-owner(s), regardless of whether he has made a will.

Knowledge Article: Question: Who do I have to pay Skills Development Levy (SDL) for?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You have to pay Skills Development Levy (SDL) for all your employees working in Singapore, including:   employees employed on permanent, part-time, casual and temporary basis foreign employees on work permits and employment pass holders SDL is payable to the SkillsFuture Singapore Agency (SSG) for foreign employees.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why was my MediSave instalment amount changed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The instalment amount for self-employed contributions will change if the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) has assessed/reassessed your net trade income.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is a contract of service?
Knowledge Article: Answer: A contract of service is an agreement in which one person agrees to employ another as an employee, and the other person agrees to serve the employer as an employee. The agreement can be in writing, verbal, expressed or implied. Please refer to the Ministry of Manpower website for more information on a contract of service.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on Supplementary Retirement Scheme (SRS) allowance if I deposit directly into my employee's SRS account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on Supplementary Retirement Scheme (SRS) allowance as it can be accessed by your employee any time (with a 5% penalty for early withdrawal). The CPF treatment is the same regardless of whether it is deposited directly into your employee's SRS account or you pay to him in cash.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the fastest way to make a cash top-up?
