As a result, we paid higher prices for many cancer drugs as compared to other countries such as Australia, South Korea and the United Kingdom.   The changes to cancer treatment financing allow us to negotiate lower prices for cancer drugs and ensure that cancer treatment costs and insurance premiums remain affordable for Singapore residents in the long term.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I apply for MediSave Care?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To apply for MediSave Care, you may submit an application to the Agency for Integrated Care, and arrange for a disability assessment by a MOH-accredited severe disability assessor.   For more FAQs on MediSave Care, please visit the CareShield Life website .

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I still receive top-ups if I have started my monthly retirement payouts?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you can receive top-ups as long as you have not reached the current Enhanced Retirement Sum .   Find out  how much top-ups you can receive .

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the changes to the CPF contribution rates for senior workers that will take effect from 1 January 2025?
Knowledge Article: Answer: From 1 January 2025, the CPF contribution rates for employees aged above 55 to 65 will be increased to strengthen their retirement adequacy. The changes apply to wages earned from 1 January 2025: For employees earning monthly wages exceeding $750 Employee's age (years) 2024 CPF Contribution Rates from 1 Jan 2025 Total   (% of wage) Total   (% of wage) By employer   (% of wage) By employee   (% of wage) 55 and below 37 37 17 20 Above 55 to 60 31 32.5   (+1.5) 15.5   (+0.5) 17   (+1) Above 60 to 65 22 23.5   (+1.5) 12   (+0.5) 11.5   (+1) Above 65 to 70 16.5 16.5 9 7.5 Above 70 12.5 12.5 7.5 5 Note: Figures in brackets () denote increase in rates a) With the closure of Special Account, the increase in the CPF contributions for employees aged above 55 to 65 will be fully allocated to the Retirement Account (RA), up to the Full Retirement Sum (FRS), to help senior workers save more for retirement. If employees have set aside the FRS in their RA, these contributions will be channelled to their Ordinary Account. b) For those earning monthly wages of more than $500 to $750, the employee contribution rates continue to be phased in. c) There are no changes to the graduated contribution rates for first and second year Singapore Permanent Residents. You may refer to the complete CPF contribution rate tables from 1 January 2025 (Tables 1 to 5) (PDF, 0.17 MB) for more details.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is MediSave Care (also known as MediSave Withdrawals for Long-Term Care)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediSave Care is a long-term care scheme which was launched on 1 October 2020. Under MediSave Care, Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents aged 30 and above with severe disabilities will be able to make monthly cash withdrawals from their own and/or their spouse’s MediSave for their long-term care needs.   After setting aside a minimum amount to ensure adequacy for other medical expenses, Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents with severe disabilities will be able to withdraw up to a total of $200/month from their own and/or their spouse’s MediSave. The table below shows the MediSave balances and corresponding monthly withdrawal quanta.   Table: MediSave Balances and corresponding Monthly MediSave Withdrawal Quantum for Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents aged 30 and above with severe disabilities. 1   MediSave Balance Monthly Withdrawal Quantum $20,000 and above $200 $15,000 and above $150 $10,000 and above $100 $5,000 and above $50 Below $5,000 Nil   1 Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents with severe disabilities can withdraw from their spouse's MediSave Account, if they have insufficient MediSave balances, and their spouse has MediSave balances of $5,000 or more. Withdrawals from their spouse's MediSave will also be subject to the same MediSave balance thresholds. The total withdrawal from their own and/or spouse's  MediSave is capped at $200/month.   For more FAQs on MediSave Care, please visit the CareShield Life website .

Knowledge Article: Question: How much can I claim from MediShield Life?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediShield Life has features such as claim limits, deductible and co-insurance. As such, the amount you can claim from MediShield Life for your bill can only be finalised after the Board processes the completed claim information submitted by the medical institution. In the meantime, you can use the MediSave and MediShield Life claims calculator to estimate the maximum amount you can withdraw from your MediSave and / or claim from MediShield Life.

Knowledge Article: Question: Which court orders are required to be submitted to the CPF Board for the purpose of division of CPF assets in a divorce?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please submit the court order to the Board if the CPF-related orders pertain to the following:   1. Transfer of property with zero or partial CPF refunds to the outgoing owner; or   2. Division of other (i.e. non-property) CPF-related matrimonial assets such as transfer of CPF savings from Member A to Member B or payment (charging) of Member A’s CPF savings to Member B; or   3. Division of property (with full, partial or zero CPF refunds) and other (i.e. non-property) CPF assets.   Please refer to Annex B (PDF, 522KB) for examples of court orders that are required to be submitted to the CPF Board.   You may also wish to know the types of court orders not required to be submitted to CPF Board.

Knowledge Article: Question: Am I eligible for tax reliefs when I make a cash top-up to my/my loved ones' retirement savings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can enjoy tax relief if you are a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident and make cash top-ups within the current Full Retirement Sum for yourself, your loved ones or employees.   Find out more about the amount of tax relief you can enjoy .   Find out more on the conditions to qualify for tax relief .

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my MediSave to pay for my approved dependant's renal dialysis?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your approved dependant’s MediSave is insufficient for their own renal dialysis, you may apply to use your MediSave to pay for their renal dialysis treatment costs, provided you: are an active MediSave contributor; and have sufficient MediSave balances to support your own healthcare needs (subject to CPF Board’s assessment) Approved dependants refer to your spouse, children, parents, grandparents and siblings. Please note that your grandparents and siblings must be Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents.   To use your MediSave to pay for your dependant’s renal dialysis, please complete the online form " Apply to Use MediSave for Outpatient Renal Dialysis Treatment of Approved Dependant " using your Singpass.   We generally aim to notify you of the outcome within three working days via email.

Knowledge Article: Question: What do I need to do to receive the matching grant under the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme this year, you will receive the matching grant if you receive cash top-ups during the year. The cash top-ups can be made by anyone, including yourself, your family, employers or members of the community.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much MediSave can I use for my maternity expenses?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Under the MediSave Maternity Package, you can use your MediSave for pre-delivery medical expenses, delivery expenses and daily hospital charges.   Each MediSave Maternity Package has a different MediSave withdrawal limit, depending on the delivery procedure (e.g. caesarean or vaginal delivery). If you do not wish to claim for pre-delivery expenses, you can still use your MediSave savings for the delivery procedure and daily hospital charges. Each delivery procedure has a different withdrawal limit.     You may refer to the details on the withdrawal limits for maternity expenses  (PDF, 0.1MB).

Knowledge Article: Question: I intend to visit a clinic/hospital. How do I know if I can use MediShield Life coverage in that clinic/hospital?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can refer to this list of medical institutions participating in MediShield Life  (PDF, 0.4MB).   To make a claim, please inform the staff handling your hospital admission or outpatient treatment that you wish to do so. The staff will submit your claim for you after your authorisation.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on advance salary given to my employee?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on the salary due to your employee in each calendar month. For advance salary that is not due to your employee but was given earlier, you are not required to pay CPF contributions on it yet. You will have to pay CPF contributions for the amount in the month it is payable to your employee.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable for volunteers?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are not payable if the volunteers are not employed under a contract of service .

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on cash rewards given to my employees who report on safety lapses and incidents in the workplace?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on cash rewards given to your employees who report on safety lapses and incidents in the workplace if the employees are required to do so as part of the job scope. Otherwise, CPF contributions are not payable.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the MediShield Life deductible?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The deductible is the fixed amount payable by the insured each policy year before any payout from MediShield Life. The deductible is payable only once every policy year. The deductible paid can be accumulated if there is more than 1 claim in the policy year. The deductible ranges from $1,500 to $3,000 of the claimable amount depending on age and ward class as shown in the table below.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the criteria for inclusion in the Cancer Drug List?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Generally, the Cancer Drug List comprises of drugs that are clinically proven and more cost-effective in treating a particular cancer.   A drug is clinically proven if it is registered with the Health Sciences Authority (HSA) for the particular clinical indication and has met the required standards of safety, quality and efficacy. A drug is cost effective if it provides good value in treating the particular cancer as compared to the existing standard of care, in terms of health benefits to the patient and cost.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I check the amount that I can top up to my Retirement Account to reach the raised Enhanced Retirement Sum in 2025?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may check your top-up limit on your Retirement Dashboard in early 2025 once the Enhanced Retirement Sum is raised .   Find out how the top-up limit is computed .

Knowledge Article: Question: Who is eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will be eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme if you are a Singapore Citizen and meet the following criteria. Your eligibility is assessed annually.   ? Age 55 to 70 (both inclusive) as of 31 st December of the assessment year. ? Retirement Account (RA) Savings* ?Less than $102,900^. ? Average Monthly Income ?Not more than $4,000. This covers a majority of senior workers. ? Annual Value of Residence ?Not more than $21,000. ? Property Ownership ?Own not more than one property.   *RA savings refer to the cash set aside in the RA (excluding amounts such as interest earned, any governments grants received), plus retirement withdrawals. If you are turning 55 in the assessment year and your RA has not been created at the time we assess your eligibility, your total Special Account and Ordinary Account savings will be assessed instead.   ^Current Basic Retirement Sum for 2024.   Find out  how you can check your eligibility for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme .

Knowledge Article: Question: Why are CPF transfers not eligible for tax relief?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are tax-deductible. Therefore, when they are transferred from one CPF account to another, they will not enjoy tax benefits.   Consider topping up using cash to enjoy tax relief while boosting your retirement payouts. Find out the conditions to enjoy tax relief .

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I make cash top-ups to my child's CPF retirement savings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To make cash top-ups to your child's CPF retirement savings (regardless his or her age), simply: 1. Indicate your identification number as the giver of the cash top-up in the application 2. Indicate your child's identification number as the recipient 3. Select the relationship as "Others"   Do note that givers of cash top-ups need to be at least 16 years old and cash top-ups to children will not qualify for tax relief. Find out more about the types of cash top-ups which can enjoy tax relief.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I check the status of my cash top-up and/or CPF transfer application?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can check the status of your online application via Activities . Once your cash top-up and/or CPF transfer application is successful, you will be able to find the details of the transaction on your  Retirement Dashboard under the Retirement Sum Topping-Up History section .   If you have submitted multiple applications, you can also review the status of each application under  Activities . This will help you identify which transactions have been successfully processed, and you can also submit a new application if necessary.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use MediSave to pay for my colonoscopy screening?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use your MediSave to pay for colonoscopy screening at all public healthcare institutions and approved private hospitals and medical institutions , provided you are aged 50 years old and above and it is a day surgery procedure. The day surgery limits are:   1) Day Surgery Up to a maximum of $300 per day for daily hospital charges, including investigations, medicines and doctor's attendance fees. 2) Operation A fixed operation limit of either $950 or $1,250, depending on the type of operations performed.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why am I not allowed to transfer my CPF savings to my children?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your CPF savings are meant to support your retirement needs. Your children would be able to accumulate savings in their working years. Hence, it is more important to prioritise your own retirement savings and ensure that you have sufficient funds to support your retirement needs.   Find out how you can use cash to top up your child's CPF account .

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable for my hawker assistant?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable for your hawker assistant who is employed under a contract of service .

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on ex-gratia payment?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Ex-gratia payment is a cash payment given in gratitude without any contractual or legal obligation. CPF contributions are payable on the ex-gratia cash payment that is given as a token of appreciation for your employee's past services/contributions to you. CPF contributions are not payable on the ex-gratia payment that is given as a compensation for your employee’s loss of employment.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the minimum age for your employees to qualify for CPF contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your employees are required to pay CPF contributions as long as they are Singapore Citizens or Singapore Permanent Residents, and are employed in Singapore under a contract of service .

Knowledge Article: Question: I do not have a Singpass account. How will I be notified of my MediSave deduction?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will be notified of your MediSave deduction digitally via your contact details maintained with CPF Board.   We strongly encourage you to update your contact details with us using Singpass to obtain timely notification of your MediSave deduction.   Having a Singpass account provides added convenience and security when accessing Singapore government services. You can register a Singpass account by following the instructions on the  Singpass website .

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on personal car loan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are not payable on personal car loan given to your employee if it is not tied to his employment. CPF contributions are payable if you agree that your employee need not pay back the loan or for the loan to be written off, e.g. given as a cash gift to your employee or you imposed conditions that are tied to employment (such as your employee must clinch a deal with a client or he has to work overtime for the next few months). In such cases, the cash payment is given in respect of employment.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on cash payment given to my employee for personal insurance?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on cash payments given to your employee to purchase his personal insurance.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on wages given to my employee who has passed away?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on the wages payable to your employee who has passed away.

Knowledge Article: Question: I intend to seek treatment in a hospital. How do I know if I can use my MediSave in that hospital?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please refer to this list of medical institutions or day surgery centres (PDF, 0.4MB) participating in the MediSave scheme.   To use your MediSave, please inform the staff handling your hospital admission that you wish to do so. The staff will submit your claim for you after your authorisation.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I choose how much I want to withdraw from my retirement savings if I have an alternative pension/annuity?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The amount that can be withdrawn from your retirement savings will depend on the monthly payout you are receiving from your pension/annuity. You can withdraw your retirement savings in full if the pension/ annuity monthly payout is more than the minimum monthly payout.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long will the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme last?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Matched Retirement Savings Scheme was implemented in 2021 and will last for five years for a start.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will my monthly payouts change after topping up?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are on CPF LIFE , topping up your Retirement Account will allow you to enjoy higher monthly payouts for life. If you are not on CPF LIFE , the top-ups will generally allow you to receive higher payouts or receive payouts for a longer time.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will the top-ups to my retirement savings be used?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Top-up monies will form part of your retirement sum and give you higher monthly payouts in retirement . As such, top-up monies cannot be withdrawn as a lump sum, withdrawn from your Retirement Account savings using property, or transferred to your loved ones.   Additionally, top-up monies cannot be used for other CPF schemes, such as withdrawal for immediate retirement needs , withdrawal on exemption from setting aside a retirement sum , and other CPF schemes for education, investment, insurance, housing etc.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why am I not able to top up my Special/Retirement Account beyond the current Full Retirement Sum (FRS) (below 55) or Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS) (55 or above)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF savings are meant to provide for a basic level of retirement.   If you are below 55, you can top up your Special Account up to the current Full Retirement Sum (FRS) to build up your retirement savings. If you wish to save beyond the FRS, you can choose to tap on the Supplementary Retirement Scheme , where contributions are also eligible for tax relief.   If you are 55 or above, retirement becomes a higher priority. As such, members have the option to voluntarily top up beyond the FRS up to the current Enhanced Retirement Sum for higher payouts. This could help the middle-income group better meet their retirement needs.   Find out more about  what the retirement sums are .

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on encashment of leave?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on cash payment given to your employee for encashment of his leave.

Knowledge Article: Question: When should I submit my application for my top-up to be processed within the same month?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are making a cash top-up Both your application and payment should be made by the following timings:   Payment mode When payment should be made PayNow QR   Within last day of the month   OCBC Digital (available for applications via CPF Mobile app only) Online GIRO Your GIRO instruction will take effect in the same month If you submit both: GIRO application ; and Standing Instruction within the first seven days of the month.   To have your cash top-up processed quickly, we encourage payment via PayNow QR or OCBC Digital. Your cash top-up will generally be credited  almost instantly upon successful payment.   If you are making a CPF transfer You should submit your application before the 5 th last working day of the month.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on death benefits given to my employee's next of kin?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are not payable on death benefits given to your deceased employee's next of kin.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I retrieve my healthcare payments and claims statement online?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can view your healthcare payments and claims details (containing information such as the name of patient, hospital registration number (HRN), hospitalisation period, etc), with transaction dates within the last 15 months at cpf.gov.sg/healthcare .   Please follow these steps:   1. Login to your  Healthcare dashboard under my cpf digital services with your Singpass   2. Proceed to 'Latest healthcare payments and claims' and select 'View past 15 months'   3. Select the period you require and click 'Search'.   4. Select the PDF icon at the top-right-hand corner of the page to save/print the statement.   Here is a  step-by-step guide on how you can retrieve the healthcare payments and claims statement.   Please note that you need not provide hardcopy healthcare payments and claims statement to make a reimbursement claim. If your insurer or employer requires such a statement, they should accept a digital copy.

Knowledge Article: Question: Who are the eGIRO participating banks for the GIRO online application?
Knowledge Article: Answer: eGIRO (Electronic GIRO) is a joint initiative by The Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) and Participating Banks with the support of the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to digitise the GIRO application process and significantly reduce the turnaround time for setting up a GIRO arrangement.   Please see table below for the eGIRO participating banks for GIRO online application. ABS is working with the industry to onboard more banks onto eGIRO service and we will update this table accordingly.   eGIRO Participating Banks   DBS/POSB Overseas-Chinese Banking Corp (OCBC) United Overseas Bank Limited (UOB) Maybank Bank of China The HongKong and Shanghai Banking Corporation Ltd (HSBC) Standard Chartered Bank Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Limited (ICBC) Citibank Singapore Limited

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens if the CPF Board deems that the CPF nomination was made whilst the member lacked capacity?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If the CPF Board deems that the CPF nomination was made whilst the member lacked capacity within the meaning of section 4 of the Mental Capacity Act 2008, the Board will invalidate the nomination. The previous CPF nomination (if any) made by the member would remain valid (assuming the member did not lack capacity when he made the previous CPF nomination). The member's CPF savings would be distributed in accordance with the intention of the member in his previous valid CPF nomination. If there is no previous valid CPF nomination, the CPF savings would be paid to the Public Trustee for distribution in accordance with intestacy laws.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should you do if you are going to nominate or have nominated Special Needs Trust Company (SNTC)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are going to nominate SNTC as a nominee, you should contact SNTC to find out the procedures to observe. This is especially important if you have specific intentions as to how you want your CPF savings to be used or allocated by SNTC (e.g. to benefit a specific SNTC trust beneficiary). If you have already nominated SNTC in your nomination and have yet to inform SNTC, please contact SNTC via enquiries@sntc.org.sg or office hotline 62789598 to inform them of your nomination.   Please ensure that SNTC is kept informed of your intentions as CPF Board is not in a position to enforce or ensure that the organisation will apply the CPF savings received in the manner you intended.

Knowledge Article: Question: Who can make a CPF nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can make a CPF nomination as long as you are a CPF member, at least 16 years old and must not lack mental capacity. Members who are bankrupt or have disabilities (e.g. visual impairment) can also make a CPF nomination.   If you are critically ill and want to make a CPF nomination, we would advise that a medical practitioner be present with you at the time the nomination is made. Doing so would provide better assurance that your nominees will receive the CPF savings in the manner you intended.   The medical practitioner should also provide a medical certificate stating that you possess the mental capacity to make the nomination.   Notwithstanding the above, we encourage CPF members to make their nominations as early as possible and review them regularly, and not leave nomination making until they are nearing end of life.

Knowledge Article: Question: How should I notify the CPF Board of my overseas marriage in relation to my CPF nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can notify us by completing the form Notification of Marriage in relation to CPF Nomination . We may require generally up to five working days from the submission of the completed form (including all supporting documents) to act on the marriage notification. If you have a CPF nomination made before this marriage, your nomination will be revoked.   You are strongly encouraged to make a new? CPF nomination ?after your marriage if you want your CPF savings to be distributed according to your wishes.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am a homemaker/babysitter. Can I qualify for the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Allowances received for carrying out family support roles such as babysitting and general caregiving for dependants are considered transfers within the family. They are not external sources of income derived from employment, hence it would not be appropriate to consider these transfers for Workfare Income Supplement scheme. The Government recognises that such family roles are important. There are other forms of government support for these roles, such as the Marriage and Parenthood package which provides broad-based support for couples to raise and care for their children.   Employee/Self-Employed Persons who are also caregivers (generally include caregivers residing with care recipients who are medically certified to have permanent moderate to severe disabilities) could qualify for concessionary WIS, even if they earn less than $500. For more information, please refer to our FAQs  here .

Knowledge Article: Question: Why are CPF Investment scheme (CPFIS) investments not distributed to nominees in the CPF nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) investments are not covered under CPF nomination. When a member passes away, his CPFIS investments 1 and any cash balance in his Investment Account will form part of his estate. Doing so allows beneficiaries of the estate to decide how best to manage these assets, including the preferred timing for the sale of assets such as unit trusts and stocks. These decisions should be made by the beneficiaries as the decisions could affect the value of the CPFIS investments. CPF monies covered under CPF nomination can then be disbursed quickly without having to await the beneficiaries’ decision on the CPFIS investments.   1 Except for insurance policies where the policyholder has made an insurance nomination with the respective insurance company. The nominated beneficiaries can contact the insurance company to claim the death benefits.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is CPF nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: A CPF nomination allows you to specify who will receive your CPF savings and the proportion of your savings each nominee will receive when you pass away. Your nominee(s) will receive your CPF savings in cash.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why do Self-Employed Persons receive only two-thirds of the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) received by employees?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF contribution made by Self-Employed Persons (SEPs) is comparatively less than employees who earn the same amount. SEPs are only required to contribute to their MediSave Account whereas employees need to contribute to all their CPF Accounts (Ordinary, Special and MediSave Accounts).

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I monetise my property and which option is suitable for me?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Here are some ways to monetise your property for additional source of retirement income:   Silver Housing Bonus scheme If you own an HDB flat and do not mind moving to a 3-room or smaller flat, you can consider the  Silver Housing Bonus scheme .   Lease Buyback Scheme If you prefer to live in your existing flat, you can consider the  Lease Buyback Scheme .   Rental You can consider renting out a spare bedroom, or your entire property if you have an alternative accommodation. If you own a HDB flat, find out more about renting out a flat/bedroom .   If you own a private property, consider speaking to a financial institution or advisor to learn about the different products available in the market that can help you monetise your property and supplement your retirement income, while ageing in place.   As with all financial decisions, it is important to understand the nature of the monetisation option, and assess your situation and retirement needs before deciding if the option is suitable for you. You may use  HDB’s Enquire Housing Monetisation Options e-Service to check your eligible Housing Monetisation options.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have already made a will. Do I still need to make a CPF nomination for my CPF savings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you will still need to make a CPF nomination as CPF savings are excluded from your estate and therefore cannot be covered by a will.   Excluding CPF savings from your estate protects your savings from any creditor claims on outstanding loans that you may have after your demise. This ensures that your CPF savings are fully preserved for your loved ones.   You are encouraged to make a CPF nomination to distribute your CPF savings according to your wishes.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am a freelancer/conducting a home business (e.g. baking, sewing). Can I qualify for the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To qualify for Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme, please declare your net trade income as a self-employed person and contribute to your MediSave Account. You will also need to meet the WIS eligibility criteria in order to qualify for WIS. To conduct a home business, you need to follow the guidelines under HDB's Home-Based Small-Scale Business Scheme. Please refer to the Housing Development Board's website for more information.

Knowledge Article: Question: I submitted a CPF nomination form under my old account. Do I need to make a new CPF nomination if I have merged my CPF accounts?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You do not need to submit a new CPF nomination form. If you have a valid CPF nomination form under your old CPF account, the CPF nomination status will automatically be updated in your new account. Hence, you do not need to make a new CPF nomination under the new CPF account unless you wish to change your nominee(s).

Knowledge Article: Question: My net trade income in a work year was negative. Can I trade the losses to offset my income in the following year to qualify for the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) is based on your net trade income earned in the work year and does not include previous year's losses.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why must self-employed persons (SEPs) contribute to MediSave to receive Workfare Income Supplement (WIS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: A key principle of the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme is that each recipient has a personal responsibility to save for his future needs, with the government providing additional support. Self-employed persons (SEPs) are required to contribute to their MediSave Accounts as they do not receive regular MediSave contributions from employers. It is important to contribute regularly to ensure enough savings for healthcare needs. This is especially important during old age, when SEPs may have stopped working. WIS is intended to supplement, not replace the MediSave contributions made by the SEPs.

Knowledge Article: Question: My net trade income is less than $6,000. How much MediSave contributions am I required to make in order to be assessed for concessionary WIS?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Self-Employed Persons (SEPs) who earned an annual net trade income of less than $6,000 1 are not required to pay MediSave contributions. However, in order to be assessed for concessionary Workfare Income Supplement (WIS), SEPs still have to meet the following MediSave contribution amounts, according to their age in the year they worked:   30 to 34 years 35 to 44 years 45 to 49 years 50 years and above $240 $270 $300 $315   SEPs are required to contribute to their MediSave Accounts as they do not receive regular MediSave contributions from employers. It is important to contribute regularly to ensure enough savings for healthcare needs. This is especially important during old age, when SEPs may have stopped working.   WIS is intended to supplement the MediSave contributions made by the SEPs.   1 SEPs earning exactly $6,000 will still need to make voluntary MediSave contributions to qualify for general WIS payments (i.e. non-concessionary WIS).

Knowledge Article: Question: Why do employees receive monthly Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) payments while Self-Employed Persons receive their WIS once a year?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The incomes of employees are automatically computed based on their monthly CPF contributions from their employers. This enables CPF Board to assess their Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) eligibility automatically and disburse their WIS on a monthly basis. On the other hand, the net trade income (NTI) of a Self-Employed Person (SEP) is assessed over an entire year and can only be determined the following year after the current year has ended.

Knowledge Article: Question: Who can be my witnesses for my CPF nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your witnesses must be two different individuals who:   are at least 21 years of age; must not lack mental capacity; and are not any of your nominee(s). If you are making an online nomination, your witnesses must have a valid Singpass.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why are overtime pay and bonuses included in Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) assessment?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Basic salary, overtime pay, and bonuses are part of a worker’s total income that will help support the worker and his or her family. Given that the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) is intended to supplement the income of lower-wage workers, it is most useful to assess the total income in determining one’s eligibility for WIS.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is there a limit to the number of nominees I can appoint?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There is no limit to the number of nominees you can appoint.   If you are nominating up to 15 nominees, you can submit an online application. If you are nominating more than 15 nominees, please visit our CPF Service Centre to make a nomination.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is covered by CPF nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can refer to the infographic below to find out what a CPF nomination covers.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why should I make a CPF nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: By making a CPF nomination, you have the flexibility to decide who should receive your CPF savings upon your demise. Your nominee(s) will also receive your CPF savings more quickly (generally within five weeks), with no fees charged.   If you do not make a CPF nomination, the Public Trustee’s Office (PTO) will distribute your CPF savings according to intestacy or Muslim Inheritance laws. Under this process, beneficiaries will need to provide documentation to prove their relationship with you. As time and effort is required to identify and verify your eligible beneficiaries, the entire process may take up to six months and it will incur an administrative fee which will be deducted from your CPF savings. This means your beneficiaries will receive less of your CPF savings.   With a CPF nomination, CPF Board will generally take less than five weeks to distribute your CPF savings to your nominee(s). Make a CPF nomination so that your CPF savings are swiftly distributed to your loved ones when you are no longer around.

Knowledge Article: Question: To qualify for Workfare Income Supplement (WIS), what is considered income?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Employee income is based on the definition of Gross Wages under the CPF Act:   Total Gross Wages = Total Ordinary Wages + Total Additional Wages   Where:   Ordinary Wages (OW) are wages due or granted wholly or exclusively in respect of an employee's employment in that month, and payable before the due date for payment of CPF contributions for that month e.g. monthly salary.   Wages which are not classified as OW will be Additional Wages (AW) for the month e.g. annual performance bonus.   Total Wages are the total amount of an employee's wages for any calendar month, which is the sum of his OW for the month and the AW paid to him in that month.

Knowledge Article: Question: I worked as both an employee as well as a self-employed person (SEP) in the work year. When will I receive my Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) for the work year?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will receive monthly Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) payments based on your employee income if you meet the WIS eligibility criteria for the work year (WY).   If you are also an eligible dual status worker (DSW) who has worked concurrently as an SEP and employee in the year, you may receive additional WIS if your combined employment and net trade income results in a higher WIS payment. You will receive the additional WIS payment after you have declared your income and made the required MediSave contributions.   You will receive WIS once a year for work done as an SEP in the preceding year. The earliest payment for SEPs/DSWs for a particular WY will be on 30 April WY+1*.   *Payment via PayNow NRIC-linked bank account or bank crediting will be credited by end of the month while payment via GovCash will be on the 3rd of the following month.

Knowledge Article: Question: How is the 12-month average gross monthly income (AMI) criterion computed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The 12-month average gross monthly income is defined as:   Sum of income earned in the past 12-month period ÷ Total number of months worked in the past 12-month period   To qualify for WIS:   a) Your 12-month average gross monthly income must not exceed $2,500; and   b) Your gross monthly income must not exceed $2,500.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is Faraid the only way to distribute a Muslim's estate?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Faraid is not the only way to distribute a Muslim’s estate. There are various Islamic legacy planning tools available. CPF nomination for example, is a valid form of hibah (gift), that Muslims can consider when planning for their legacy.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have made the required MediSave contribution to qualify for Workfare Income Supplement, why is my payment still not reflected in the MediSave Payable page after logging into e-Services?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Contributions made each month will be updated in e-Services on the 9th working day of the following month.

Knowledge Article: Question: What constitutes a second property for Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: All types of properties e.g. Housing & Development Board flat, private property and non-residential property, are taken into account in determining the eligibility for Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme.

Knowledge Article: Question: If a valid CPF nomination has been made, can a Faraid heir who has not been nominated claim a portion of the deceased member's CPF savings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No. According to a fatwa by the Islamic Religious Council of Singapore (Muis), CPF nomination is a valid form of hibah (gift). Thus, when a nomination has been made, only the nominee(s) is entitled to the CPF savings. A Faraid heir who has not been nominated does not have a legal claim over the CPF savings.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to make a CPF nomination if I want my CPF savings to be distributed according to Faraid?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You are strongly encouraged to make a CPF nomination even if you want your CPF savings to be distributed according to Faraid.   You can do so by nominating your Faraid heirs and their shares accordingly – try using the Syariah Court’s Faraid Calculator to determine who your Faraid heirs are and their allocated shares. However, it is worth noting that according to a fatwa by the Islamic Religious Council of Singapore (Muis), CPF nomination is a form of hibah (gift). You may thus give any amount of your CPF savings to whoever you wish (including non-Faraid heirs or legal institutions).   Making a CPF nomination allows your CPF savings to be distributed swiftly and conveniently to your nominee(s).   Unnominated CPF savings will be held by the Public Trustee’s Office (PTO). Family members must initiate the claims process, retrieve the deceased’s Inheritance Certificate from the Syariah Court, and provide other necessary paperwork. The distribution process can take up to six months, and administration fees will be charged by the PTO and Syariah Court.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am a Person with Disability/Comcare Short and Medium Term Assistance recipient/ caregiver of a care recipient and I am earning less than $500 per month. How much Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) will I receive?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will qualify for concessionary WIS if you are a Person with Disability (PWD), ComCare Short-to-Medium Term Assistance recipient, or a caregiver of a care recipient 1 and earn less than $500 per month, while meeting the rest of the WIS eligibility criteria.   For employees, you will receive a flat concessionary payment, based on age:   Age in Work Year 30 to 34 years 35 to 44 years 45 to 59 years 60 years and above and all PWDs Monthly concessionary Workfare payment $50 $75 $120 $130 Self-employed persons (SEPs) will receive two-thirds of the WIS payments received by employees after they have made the required MediSave contributions.   1 This generally includes caregivers residing with care recipients who are medically certified to have permanent moderate to severe disabilities.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can the minimum income criterion be waived for workers who want to work more but are unable to?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The minimum income criterion of $500 per month was introduced from 2023 to encourage workers to work more regularly or take up higher-paying jobs.   $500 per month is achievable for most regular workers. At an hourly wage of $10.50 1 , workers who work 3-hr daily shifts for 16 days a month would already earn more than $500 per month.   We recognise that some want to work more but are unable to do so due to their personal circumstances or are in greater need of support, such as Persons with Disabilities (PWDs), ComCare Short-to-Medium-Term Assistance recipients and caregivers of care recipients 2 . Such workers will continue to qualify for concessionary WIS, even if they earn less than $500 per month.   1 based on Local Qualifying Salary requirement for part-time workers from July 2024 onwards   2 This will generally include caregivers residing with care recipients who are medically certified to have permanent moderate to severe disabilities.

Knowledge Article: Question: Who are considered eligible caregivers for concessionary WIS?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To be eligible for concessionary WIS as a working caregiver, individuals must fulfill all 4 criteria below:   a) Their care recipients qualify for selected Agency for Integrated Care (AIC) schemes 1 ;   b) They are related household members of the care recipient (i.e. related by blood or legal relations to the care recipient, and staying together at the same address);   c) Their care recipients are not residing in nursing homes; and   d) They meet all other eligibility criteria for WIS, except the $500 minimum income threshold.   Eligible caregivers have started receiving concessionary WIS payments for work done from 2023 onwards.   CPF Board will automatically assess caregivers’ eligibility for WIS. Caregivers do not need to notify CPFB Board that they are a caregiver nor submit any supporting documents.   If you are a caregiver and have recently moved in with your care recipient, you are required to update your residential address in your NRIC with ICA . If you have already done so but have yet to receive concessionary WIS payments, please contact  CPF Board .   1 The schemes from Agency for Integrated Care (AIC) are: Home Caregiving Grant, Pioneer Generation Disability Assistance Scheme, Interim Disability Assistance Programme for the Elderly, ElderFund, MediSave Care, CareShield Life Claims, and ElderShield Claims. These AIC schemes are for individuals who have permanent moderate to severe disabilities.

Knowledge Article: Question: As a self-employed person, how will the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) scheme affect me?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) helps you save for your healthcare needs through smaller and more regular MediSave contributions each time you receive a payment. There is no change to your MediSave contributions payable as it would still be based on your actual Net Trade Income.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to make a CPF nomination if I have made my Islamic Will?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF savings do not form your estate and cannot be covered under an Islamic Will.   You are strongly encouraged to make your CPF nomination to ensure that your CPF savings are distributed swiftly and conveniently to your nominee(s) without any administrative fees.   Unnominated CPF savings will be held by the Public Trustee’s Office (PTO). Family members must initiate the claims process, retrieve the deceased’s Inheritance Certificate from the Syariah Court, and provide other necessary paperwork. The distribution process can take up to six months, and administration fees will be charged by the PTO and Syariah Court.

Knowledge Article: Question: As a self-employed person who provides services to Government agencies, how will I be enrolled into Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You’ll be automatically enrolled into Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) when you receive a service payment from a Government agency you have provided services to as a self-employed person (SEP). You’ll receive a notification from CPF Board when you receive your first payment via CAYE. Subsequently, you’ll also receive a notification each time you receive a payment via CAYE.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is my spouse's Assessable Income for the preceding Year of Assessment used to determine my Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) eligibility for the current work year?
Knowledge Article: Answer: This is to allow potential Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) recipients to receive WIS earlier despite the time needed by the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) for the processing and transmission of Assessable Income (AI) to the CPF Board.   The AI for the previous Year of Assessment (YOA) is used to assess one's WIS eligibility for the current year. E.g. we will use your spouse's AI for YOA 2022 to assess your eligibility for 2023 WIS.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do residents in welfare homes qualify for Workfare Income Supplement (WIS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Residents in welfare homes registered with the National Council of Social Service/ Ministry of Health/ Ministry of Social and Family Development will qualify for Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) if they meet all of the other WIS eligibility criteria .

Knowledge Article: Question: How is the Annual Value (AV) requirement for Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) decided and what address is used to determine the AV in WIS?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Annual Value (AV) threshold of $21,000 from Work Year 2024 (was $13,000), covers all HDB flats, as well as some smaller private residences. In general, Singaporeans staying in larger properties with AV above the cut-off tend to have greater access to household wealth, and therefore would not be eligible for the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme.   The AV will be based on the address reflected in your NRIC. Under the National Registration Act, you must report a change of address within 28 days of moving at the Immigration & Checkpoints Authority (ICA) website .

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I make a CPF nomination if I am overseas?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can make an online nomination using your Singpass.   Your witnesses need not be physically present with you to verify your intention to nominate. However, your witnesses must have a valid Singpass to complete the witnessing for your nomination.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the Annual Value (AV) of a property and why is the AV of my place of residence used to assess my eligibility for Workfare Income Supplement (WIS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Annual Value (AV) is the estimated gross annual rent of the property if it were to be rented out, excluding furniture, furnishings and maintenance fees. It is determined based on estimated market rentals of similar or comparable properties. It can be found on the property tax bill you receive each year.   AV serves as a housing criterion that targets lower-wage workers with less household wealth.   For more information on the computation of AV, please visit the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) website .

Knowledge Article: Question: Does Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions qualify for tax relief?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Similar to other forms of self-employed CPF contributions, Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions will qualify for tax relief based on the date of payment. CAYE contributions made in a calendar year will qualify for tax relief in the following year. For example, relief on CAYE contributions made between 1 January 2024 and 31 December 2024 will qualify for tax relief in the Year of Assessment (YA) 2025 subject to the assessable net trade income (NTI) for this YA.   The CPF relief allowable to self-employed persons (SEPs) for his MediSave and voluntary CPF contributions, including CAYE contributions, will be capped at 37% of his NTI assessed or CPF relief cap of $37,740 or the actual amount contributed by SEP whichever is the lowest. There is no tax relief for your mandatory or voluntary CPF contributions if your assessed NTI for the year of assessment is zero or negative.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is my spouse's income and property ownership used to determine my eligibility for Workfare Income Supplement (WIS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To ensure that Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) is targeted at recipients with limited access to household wealth, you will not qualify for WIS if:   the assessable income of your spouse for the preceding Year of Assessment exceeds $70,000; or you and your spouse together own two or more properties.

Knowledge Article: Question: When should I make a CPF nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We encourage you to make a CPF nomination as soon as you begin to accumulate savings in your CPF account. As you progress in life, you should also review your nomination regularly, especially after major life events (marriage, childbirth, divorce etc.) so that your nomination continues to fit your intention.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have nominated an organisation to receive my CPF savings when I pass away. What else should I do to ensure the organisation can receive my CPF savings when I pass away?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You are encouraged to inform the organisation that you have nominated them in your CPF nomination. This will allow the organisation to be informed as to how they should use your CPF savings.   This is especially important if you have specific intentions on how you want your CPF savings to be used or allocated, as this will then allow the organisation to be informed of your intentions and to keep proper records that they have been nominated to receive your CPF savings.   In addition, the organisation will also be able to advise you as to whether they have been nominated correctly in your CPF nomination as different organisations may have different formal requirements to how they should be identified in a CPF nomination. Alternatively, you can check with them how they should be specified in your CPF nomination before you make your nomination.   Please note that CPF Board is not in a position to enforce or ensure that the organisation will apply the CPF savings received in the manner you intended. This is strictly a private arrangement between you and the organisation.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are companies who bid for jobs with corporate service buyers required to participate in Contribute As You Earn (CAYE), even if it is operated by a single person?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Contribute As You Earn is not applicable to companies registered under the Companies Act, based on Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority’s (ACRA) definition.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why am I not allowed to do a CPF transfer to my extended family members (e.g. uncles/aunts/cousins)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF system is meant to provide for and safeguard your individual retirement adequacy. Hence we must be careful when considering allowing CPF transfers to extended family members, beyond immediate family members such as your parents, spouse and siblings. Meanwhile, you can consider using cash to top up to your extended family member's CPF account instead.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long will it take for my top-up to be credited via PayNow QR?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Top-ups via PayNow QR are generally credited almost instantly, upon successful payment.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) scheme affect my income declaration to IRAS for tax purposes?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There will be no change to Self-Employed Person (SEP)’s declaration of income for tax purposes. SEPs should continue to declare his annual income earned up to 31 st  December of the preceding year in the Income Tax Return for the current Year of Assessment (YA). For example, the SEP needs to declare his gross income for services provided between 1 January 2024 and 31 December 2024 in Income Tax Return for YA2025, even if it is invoiced only in January 2025. This is regardless of when the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions for the said services are made.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I terminate my GIRO arrangement as a self-employed person?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may submit an online application Terminate GIRO for MediSave contributions  using your Singpass if you wish to terminate your GIRO arrangement as a self-employed person.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are small value payments exempted from Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, the payments from small value purchases are not exempted from Contribute As You Earn (CAYE).   However, buy-and-claim purchases are exempted from CAYE. This is because such purchases are usually for goods or services that are very small in value which the staff is prepared to pay in advance and seek reimbursement thereafter.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I nominate a trust fund to receive my CPF savings for the benefit of my nominee?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF members are not allowed to nominate a trust fund as it is not a legal entity which is capable of receiving monies.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am turning 55 later this year. How can I top up if my Retirement Account has not been created yet?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your Retirement Account has not been created yet, you can top up to your Special Account (SA). Cash top-ups to your SA will be considered for matching grants under the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I withdraw the top-up monies if I have the Full Retirement Sum, or the Basic Retirement Sum if I own a property?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will not be able to withdraw the top-up monies as the higher interest rate and tax incentives are given to encourage members to build up their retirement savings. Allowing withdrawals after members have enjoyed these incentives would defeat the purpose of the topping-up scheme.

Knowledge Article: Question: If my nominee is a bankrupt, can he still claim my CPF savings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your nominee was or is an undischarged bankrupt, we are legally obliged to inform the Official Assignee (OA) and transfer the nominated monies to the OA upon his instructions. This is by virtue of the laws in Singapore relating to bankruptcy which vest the property of a bankrupt in the OA upon the making of a bankruptcy order.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to my CPF savings if my nominee is below 18 years old?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your nominee is below the age of 18 at the time of claim, his share will be transferred to the Public Trustee's Office and held-in-trust until he reaches 18 years of age.   Alternatively, you can nominate a trustee/trust company to receive your CPF savings on behalf of your beneficiary who is a minor.   You are advised to make arrangements with the trustee/trust company on how to channel your CPF savings to your intended beneficiaries. Please note that we are not in a position to enforce or ensure that the trustee/trust company will apply the CPF savings received for the benefit of your intended beneficiaries. This is strictly a private arrangement between you and the appointed trustee/trust company.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Under the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) scheme, a MediSave contribution is required as and when a self-employed person (SEP) earns a service fee. Every time a service fee is paid to the SEP, the corporate service buyers (CSBs) or intermediaries making the payment will first deduct and credit a portion of the service fee to the SEP’s MediSave Account, before paying the remainder of the service fee to the SEP.   CAYE does not change the amount of MediSave contributions SEPs have to make based on their net trade income.   SEPs who provide services to government agencies are automatically enrolled into CAYE.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why do I need CPF LIFE?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Nobody can predict how long anyone will actually live. Therefore, planning how much of your retirement savings to use for living expenses is a dilemma – Spend too much and you might not have enough if you live longer than you thought; spend too little and you might deprive yourself from fully enjoying your hard-earned savings.   With increasing advances in technology and healthcare, you are likely to live longer than your grandparents’ or parents’ generation. Therefore, you cannot predict how long you will live by looking at how long your parents or grandparents live. Otherwise, you may underestimate your lifespan and find your savings depleted with many more years to live when you are no longer able to work.   With CPF LIFE, you do not need to worry about being caught in such a situation but have the assurance of having a steady stream of income, no matter what age you live to.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will participating in Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) affect my MediSave contributions payable?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Self-employed persons (SEPs) are required to contribute to their MediSave Account (MA) if their annual Net Trade Income (NTI) is more than $6,000. Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) does not change the amount of MediSave contributions you have to make based on your NTI. The only change concerns how the contributions are made. Under CAYE, the agency/company you provided a service to will help you contribute into your MA each time it makes a service payment to you.   Your CAYE contributions are based on your estimated annual revenue and expenses. Thus, CAYE contributions are an estimate of your MediSave payable. After you declare your NTI for the year, your MediSave payable will be computed.   If your total Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions are higher than your MediSave payable for the latest year, your excess CAYE contributions will be used to offset your outstanding MediSave payable from previous years 1 . Any remaining CAYE contributions will then be refunded to you.   If your total CAYE contributions are lower than your MediSave payable, you’ll be required to top up the remaining amount. You’ll be notified accordingly, and you can choose to make payment via lump-sum payment(s) or sign up for GIRO instalments.   1 This will take effect for CAYE contributions made from 2023. Please write to us if you do not wish to use your CAYE contributions to offset your outstanding MediSave payable from previous years.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can my nominee be below 18 years old?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, your nominee can be of any age.   If your nominee is below 18 years old at the time of claim, his share will be transferred to the Public Trustee's Office (PTO) and held-in-trust until he reaches 18 years of age.   Visit PTO's website to find out important information (such as admin fees) related to shares belonging to a minor nominee.

Knowledge Article: Question: If my nominee passed away, what do I need to do next?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your nominee(s) passes on before you, his/her share will be given to surviving nominee(s) in the same proportion you have specified.   If there are no surviving nominee(s), your nomination is considered revoked, and your savings will be transferred to the Public Trustee’s Office for distribution under the intestacy or Muslim Inheritance laws.   We encourage CPF members to review their nominations whenever there are changes to their circumstances, such as death of nominee, and make a new CPF nomination if necessary. This will allow them to reallocate the shares to surviving nominee(s) based on their wishes, or even include new nominees.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have adjusted my Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contribution rate. When will the updated rate take effect?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Generally, your updated Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contribution rate will apply to service fees paid from the next day.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I make recurring monthly or yearly top-ups conveniently via GIRO?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can make small and recurring cash top-ups via GIRO by following the steps below:   Step 1:  Set up a GIRO arrangement Step 2: Please allow one day for your GIRO bank account to be updated in the Board's record. Thereafter, please submit a request to make recurring cash top-ups for retirement .   Please note that you must complete both steps for recurring cash top-ups via GIRO to be successful.   Currently, the online application to set up a GIRO arrangement is only available for these participating banks .   If you encounter any difficulties in setting up GIRO, you may write to us  for assistance.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why do I need witnesses when I make a CPF nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Disputes on who should receive your CPF savings may sometimes arise after you have passed on. That is why you have to appoint two witnesses who can attest that you have made your nomination willingly and calmly. Your witnesses cannot be your nominee or an organisation.   Witnesses do not need to know your nominee(s)’ details to perform their roles as witnesses. Where necessary, your witnesses can help us understand how the nomination was made so that we can distribute your CPF savings according to your wishes.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will self-employed persons who provide services to the private sector be mandated to participate in Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Government, as a service buyer, has piloted Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) since 1 January 2020. There are currently no plans to extend CAYE into the private sector. Nonetheless, companies in the private sector are encouraged to voluntarily adopt CAYE.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have contributed up to the maximum mandatory contributions for the year. Do I still have to make Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you’ve made Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions up to the maximum MediSave payable for the year, your applicable CAYE contribution rate will be 0%. This means that you will receive your service fee in full, and CAYE contribution will no longer be deducted from your service fee.   However, you’ll still be required to make good your outstanding MediSave payable (if any) via lump-sum payment(s) or GIRO instalment plan.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to apply to be eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme when it is enhanced from 2025?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You do not need to apply as your eligibility is automatically assessed annually at the beginning of the year.   If you are eligible, we will notify you via email or post in early 2025. You can also check your eligibility through the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme eligibility checker in early 2025.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can my nominee be my witness?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your nominee cannot be one of your witnesses, to prevent a conflict of interest.

Knowledge Article: Question: Who must participate in Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: SEPs who are individual freelancers or sole proprietors and were awarded jobs with Government agencies will automatically be enrolled into CAYE.   Private companies are also encouraged to voluntarily onboard CAYE to help the SEPs who they have contracted with, save for their healthcare and retirement needs in an easier manner.

Knowledge Article: Question: I would like to nominate an organisation to receive my CPF savings when I pass away. Are there any requirements for the type of organisation I can nominate?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can nominate an organisation if it is a legal entity capable of receiving monies, including CPF monies, in its own right.   For an entity to be capable of receiving monies, it must be recognised under the law as being capable of doing certain things in its own name and not in the name of its members, such as owning and holding property, suing others, and being sued. Such entities would include companies (including public companies limited by guarantee) registered under the Companies Act 1967 and limited liability partnerships (LLP) registered under the Limited Liability Partnerships Act 2005.   You may also nominate societies registered under the Societies Act 1966.   You can check if the organisation has been registered as a society, company, or LLP via the following websites:   Registry of Societies (for registered societies) ACRA's BizFile page (for companies, LLPs) Alternatives if the organisation is not a legal entity   If you would like to nominate an organisation that is not a legal entity or registered with the Registry of Societies (ROS), you can consider the following alternatives:   Discuss with the organisation on nominating a person holding an official position (e.g. General Manager or Chief Executive) within the organisation, or Nominate a trustee/trust company to receive your CPF savings on behalf of the organisation. Please note that the person holding an official position in the organisation or the trustee/trust company will receive the CPF savings in his/its own right. Members are encouraged to make arrangements with the said person or the trustee/trust company on how to thereafter channel their CPF savings to the organisation.   Please also note that CPF Board is not in a position to enforce or ensure that the said person or the trustee/trust company will apply the CPF savings received for the benefit of the member’s intended beneficiaries. This is strictly a private arrangement between the member and the person or trustee/trust company.   If you require further clarification, you can write to us for assistance.

Knowledge Article: Question: Does the interest earned on my retirement savings form part of the retirement sum that I am required to set aside at age 55?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, the interest earned on your retirement savings does not form part of the retirement sum that you are required to set aside at 55.

Knowledge Article: Question: What if I am in financial hardship and is unable to set aside monies for MediSave via the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We understand that some self-employed persons (SEPs) may be facing financial difficulties and may not be able to cope with Contribute As You Earn (CAYE). Thus, if you do not have outstanding MediSave payable or are contributing via GIRO instalments, you may set your CAYE contribution rate to 0%. This means that you’ll receive your service payment in full, and CAYE contribution will not be deducted from your service payment. Please  write to us if you wish to apply for a 0% CAYE contribution rate. CPF Board will assess your eligibility and inform you of the outcome in writing.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to my existing CPF nomination when I make a new one?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your new CPF nomination will supersede any earlier CPF nomination which you have made. The Board will follow your latest instruction in your new nomination.

Knowledge Article: Question: What if I prefer making MediSave contributions through the current payment modes (e.g. GIRO)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The small and regular MediSave contributions made through Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) help self-employed persons (SEPs) to reduce the MediSave contributions payable in the following year (after SEPs declare their Net Trade Income and have their MediSave payable computed).   If you’ve made your MediSave contributions in full or are on GIRO instalment plan, you’ll be allowed to set your CAYE contribution rate to 0% and receive your service fee in full.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to my CPF nomination upon marriage?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your CPF nomination will be revoked upon marriage. When you get married, you will form a new family nucleus. Your nomination is revoked upon marriage so that you can reconsider your bequeath intentions based on your new family nucleus. This practice is similar to wills, which are also revoked upon marriage under the Wills Act.   You are strongly encouraged to make a new CPF nomination after your marriage if you want your CPF savings to be distributed according to your wishes.   Do I need to notify CPF Board of my marriage ?

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if there is a change in employee's particulars?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please ensure that your affected employees inform the Board of any changes in their personal particulars which include:   1. Change in name 2. Change in Passport/ Identity Card / Special Pass number 3. Change in Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR) or citizenship status   Your employee who has been issued with a new Singapore Identity Card will be given new CPF account. The new CPF account number is the same as his new Singapore Identity Card number. You should therefore pay CPF contributions into the new CPF account, and inform your employee to contact CPF Board to merge his previous CPF account (if any) with the new CPF account. This is to ensure that only one CPF account is maintained for the employee concerned. Submission of CPF contributions to accounts with an SA/SB/SD/SF/TC/TF prefix will be rejected.

Knowledge Article: Question: When and how should I inform CPF Board about changes to my particulars?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For Singapore Citizens/Permanent Residents, you do not need to inform us separately as your latest particulars will automatically be updated in our records.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to notify CPF Board if I get married after making my CPF nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your marriage is registered with the Singapore Registry of Marriages (ROM) or Registry of Muslim Marriages (ROMM)   You do not need to notify us of your marriage. However, any CPF nomination you had made previously will be revoked upon your marriage. You are strongly encouraged to make a new CPF nomination so that your CPF savings will be distributed according to your wishes.   If your marriage is not registered with ROM or ROMM   You will be required to complete the Notification of Marriage in relation to CPF Nomination form so that we are informed of your marriage. If you have a CPF nomination made before this marriage, your nomination will be revoked.   Alternatively, you can make a new nomination after getting married if you do not wish to notify us of your marriage. This new nomination will supersede any previous nomination you had made before your marriage.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is my CPF account number?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are currently/were previously a Singapore Citizen or a Permanent Resident, your CPF account number is the Unique Identification Number (UIN) stated on your NRIC, Citizenship Certificate, or entry permit (e.g. S1234567F or T1234567F).   Otherwise, your CPF account number could begin with the letter ‘S’ or ‘T’, followed by the letter ‘A’, ‘B’, ‘C’, ‘D’ or ‘F’ (e.g. SA123456D or TC987654B).

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is there Additional Withdrawal Limit (AWL) for Integrated Shield Plan (IP) premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediSave is sized to help Singaporeans with lifelong healthcare expenses. These include hospitalisation bills and healthcare insurance premiums.   The premium you pay for your Integrated Shield Plan (IP) consists of both the MediShield Life (MSL) and additional private insurance components. MSL premiums can be paid fully using MediSave. However, premiums for the additional private insurance component are significantly higher than MSL. As such, the Additional Withdrawal Limit (AWL) strikes a balance between the use of MediSave for higher private insurance coverage and preserving MediSave for future healthcare expenses during retirement. You should consider whether co-paying the higher IP premiums using cash is affordable over the long term.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I change my CPF nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can make a new nomination online at my cpf Online Services.   If you cannot find witnesses to witness your online nomination, you can visit the ServiceSG Centres. Officers at the ServiceSG Centres can act as witnesses for your online nomination. Click here for the list of ServiceSG Centres locations and its operating hours.   Alternatively, you can visit any of our CPF Service Centres and complete the CPF Nomination Form in the presence of our Customer Service Executives (CSEs) who can act as your witnesses and clarify any questions you may have. You can book an appointment with us through our CPF Appointment Service at the CPF website. The appointment can be made on your preferred date and time, subject to the availability of appointment slots.   Your new nomination will supersede your earlier nomination.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my MediSave to pay for my family members' Integrated Shield Plan (IP) premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use your MediSave to pay Integrated Shield Plan (IP) premiums for your family members. They include your spouse, parents, children, grandparents and siblings.

Knowledge Article: Question: My foreign employee has obtained his Singapore Permanent Resident status. How do I compute CPF contributions on his Ordinary and Additional Wages for the month?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable once your foreign employee obtains his Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR) status. Please ensure that your employee informs you when he becomes a SPR. For Ordinary Wages (OW), you will need to pay CPF contributions on the pro-rated OW. For Additional Wages (AW), CPF contributions are required depending on when the AW is payable to your employee. Example Assuming your employee obtains his SPR status on 15 March 2022 and he receives OW and AW for March 2022. For OW CPF contribution is required on the pro-rated wages from 15 to 31 March 2022. For AW CPF contribution is not required on the AW if it is payable while the employee was a foreigner i.e. before 15 March 2022. CPF contribution is required on the AW if it is payable on or after 15 March 2022.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to my CPF nomination upon divorce?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Divorce does not revoke a CPF nomination. This treatment is similar to that of wills (which are not revoked upon divorce).   Some members may still wish to bequeath their CPF savings to their ex-spouse and/or children via their existing nominations, and therefore, it is best for members to review their latest personal circumstances and update their nomination accordingly.   You can make a new nomination online .

Knowledge Article: Question: Five out of my 20 staff have salary revision this month and I have already submitted the CPF contributions using the previous template. Should I re-submit the correct details for all the staff?
