Knowledge Article: Answer: You should pay the shortfall of the CPF contribution for the five affected staff only.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I calculate CPF contributions on Additional Wages (AW) paid before the end of the year/last month of employment?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To determine the CPF contributions on Additional Wage (AW) payable, the AW ceiling has to be first calculated. The AW ceiling sets the maximum amount of AW on which CPF contributions are payable per year.   You can use the current year's Ordinary Wages (OW) to estimate the AW ceiling whenever AW are payable. Alternatively, you can also estimate the AW ceiling using previous year’s OW.   Once the employee’s total OW for the year are known, usually at the end of the year or in the last month of employment, you should re-calculate the AW ceiling based on the total OW subject to CPF contributions. You can refer to these  examples  and the AW ceiling calculator on the computation of the AW ceiling.   After re-computing the AW contributions: Any shortfall in the CPF contributions after the re-computation should be paid together with December's contributions or contributions for your employee's last month of employment, whichever is applicable. If you have overpaid the CPF contributions, you can apply for a refund .

Knowledge Article: Question: Can a blind person make a CPF nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: A blind person can make a CPF nomination if he wants his CPF savings to be distributed according to his wishes.   If he chooses not to make a CPF nomination, his CPF savings will be transferred to the Public Trustee's Office (PTO) for distribution to his family members under the Intestate Succession Act or the Inheritance Certificate (for Muslims). This ensures that the welfare of his dependants is provided for.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I make a new nomination instead of notifying CPF Board of my marriage?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can make a new nomination if you do not wish to notify us of your marriage. The new nomination will supersede your previous nomination (if any).

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I pay using CPF EZPay Mobile?
Knowledge Article: Answer: After submitting the CPF contribution details via CPF EZPay Mobile, employers can pay via PayNow QR (supports personal or corporate accounts of participating banks).

Knowledge Article: Question: Where do I submit the completed CPF nomination form?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We encourage you to make your CPF nomination online at my cpf Online Services.   Alternatively, you can visit any of our CPF Service Centres and complete the CPF Nomination Form in the presence of our Customer Service Executives (CSEs) who can act as your witnesses and clarify any questions you may have. You can book an appointment with us through our CPF Appointment Service at the CPF website. The appointment can be made on your preferred date and time, subject to the availability of appointment slots.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to my existing Integrated Shield Plan (IP) when I apply for a new IP?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your existing Integrated Shield Plan (IP) will automatically be terminated when your new IP commences. This ensures you will only pay premiums for one IP, as medical claims can only be paid from one IP at any one time. Your insurer will refund any unused premium for the remaining cover period of the terminated IP.   Before you buy a new IP, you should check if your new insurer will cover all your pre-existing medical conditions. While the MediShield Life component of your new IP will continue to cover you for life, including any pre-existing medical conditions, private insurers generally will impose exclusions i.e. they generally do not pay claims for pre-existing medical conditions that you already suffer from before the start of your IP.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if excess contributions have been made on Additional Wages (AW)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If contributions have been made in excess of the AW ceiling, you should apply for a refund by selecting ‘Refund of payments made in excess of Additional Wage ceiling’ in the online application.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I have to join CPF LIFE?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will be automatically included if you are a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident born on 1 January 1958 and after*, and have at least $60,000 in your CPF retirement savings when you start your monthly payouts.   *If you are born between 1 January 1958 and 30 April 1961, and had at least $40,000 in your Retirement Account when you reached 55, you would have to join CPF LIFE.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I change my CPF nomination? Is there a limit to the number of times I can change my nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you can change your CPF nomination by making a new nomination . Your new nomination will supersede your existing nomination.   There is no limit to the number of times you can change your nomination.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens if I do not inform the CPF Board of my marriage in the required manner?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If we are not informed of the marriage in the required manner , the distribution of your CPF savings will follow your existing nomination, which may not be your latest bequeath intention to distribute your CPF savings.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF LIFE payouts guaranteed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF LIFE payouts are not guaranteed, but they are designed to be stable. Any adjustments to CPF LIFE payouts are expected to be small and gradual. CPF LIFE is a self-sustaining insurance scheme where payouts are matched to premiums. Guaranteeing a minimum payout would require higher premiums.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the Basic Retirement Sum, Full Retirement Sum and Enhanced Retirement Sum applicable to me?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Basic Retirement Sum (BRS), Full Retirement Sum (FRS) and Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS) provide a guide on the CPF savings you need to set aside to receive your desired monthly payouts in retirement. Read on to find out what are the retirement sums applicable to you.   Basic Retirement Sum and Full Retirement Sum   Your Basic Retirement Sum (BRS) and Full Retirement Sum (FRS) are dependent on when you turn 55 and will remain the same for the rest of your life.   To help you better plan for your future, here are the retirement sums that are applicable to members who turn 55 from 2024 to 2027:   If you turn 55 in Your BRS is Your FRS* is 2024 $102,900 $205,800 2025 $106,500 $213,000 2026 $110,200 $220,400 2027 $114,100 $228,200 *The FRS is set at 2 times of the BRS.   See the Full Retirement Sums since 1995 (PDF, 35.1KB). You can also find out how the retirement sums are determined and why the retirement sums are increasing yearly .   Enhanced Retirement Sum   If you are 55 and above, you can choose to top up your Retirement Account (RA) up to the current Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS) for higher monthly payouts, regardless of when you turn 55. Here are the ERS amounts for 2024 to 2027:   Year 2024 (Current) 2025 2026 2027 Enhanced Retirement Sum $308,700 $426,000 $440,800 $456,400   The ERS is currently set at 3 times of the BRS. From 2025, the  ERS will be raised to 4 times the BRS to provide members an option to voluntarily top up more to their RA in order to receive even higher monthly payouts in retirement.   As the ERS is increased every January, you can continue to make further top-ups to your RA every subsequent year.   Did you know? You can find out how much you can top up by logging in to your Retirement dashboard .

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I have to submit the employee(s) bank statement(s) if I have already indicated the bank account details on the application form for refund of CPF contributions paid in excess?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To better protect employees from scams, we will only accept bank accounts where CPF Board is able to perform automated bank account verification with the bank directly. This ensures that payment will only be made to a bank account belonging to the employee.   If your employee(s) use DBS Bank Ltd (DBS), Post Office Savings Bank (POSB), United Overseas Bank Ltd (UOB) or Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation Ltd (OCBC), you do not need to submit any supporting documents for the CPF refund application.   However, if your employee(s) are using any other banks’ accounts, the refund will be made via cheque.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should be the amount indicated on the refund application form for Wages and Contribution Paid?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You are required to declare the actual wages and contributions paid to allow accurate computation of excess CPF contributions.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I apply the Additional Wage ceiling for the following scenarios: a) Employee A is working for two companies concurrently? b) Employee B is transferred from another entity?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Additional Wage (AW) ceiling is applied on a per employer per calendar year basis.   As such, if your employee is working for two companies concurrently or if your employee is transferred from another entity, you must apply the AW ceiling separately.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I be exempted from CPF LIFE?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are automatically included under CPF LIFE, you cannot be exempted from CPF LIFE unless you have a pension or commercial annuity that pays the same or higher monthly payout as CPF LIFE. For more information, please refer to the conditions for withdrawing your retirement savings .

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if I have already submitted a refund application prior to the refund initiated by the CPF Board in the following year?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No further action is required by you. The CPF Board will notify the employer on the refund details after the transaction is processed.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I apply for refund of excess CPF contribution paid above Additional Wages (AW) ceiling?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can submit the refund application for excess CPF contribution paid above Additional Wages (AW) ceiling online .

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I choose to join CPF LIFE if it is not mandatory for me?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you can choose to join CPF LIFE as long as you are a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident, at any time from 65 to one month before you reach 80.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I refund the employee's share of excess CPF contributions if the employee has already resigned?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may wish to liaise directly with the resigned employee on the employee’s preferred mode of payment.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I request the CPF Board to refund the employee's share of excess CPF contributions directly to my employee?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The employer is required to refund the employee's share of excess CPF contributions, if any, directly to the employee.   To save employers the administrative hassle of refund application, the CPF Board will be refunding the excess contributions above the CPF Annual Limit automatically to the employer from February 2024 onwards.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why must refund or adjustment of CPF contributions paid in error be made immediately and no later than one year from the date of payment of the CPF contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Any errors in CPF contributions should be rectified early while the documentary evidence is fresh. To encourage employers and employees to check their CPF contributions and come forward to rectify errors as soon as possible, any request for refund and adjustment of CPF contributions paid in error must be made immediately and no later than one year from the date of payment of the CPF contributions.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why must refund or adjustment of CPF contributions paid in error be made immediately and no later than one year from the date of payment of the CPF contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Any errors in CPF contributions should be rectified early while the documentary evidence is fresh. To encourage employers and employees to check their CPF contributions and come forward to rectify errors as soon as possible, any request for refund and adjustment of CPF contributions paid in error must be made immediately and no later than one year from the date of payment of the CPF contributions.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have made duplicate CPF submissions for the same month in error. Can I request refund of the payment made for the incorrect submission?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You should apply for a refund by selecting ‘Refund of payment made for entire submission’ in the online application. The application has to be made immediately and no later than one year from the date of payment.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have paid excess CPF contributions above the Additional Wage (AW) ceiling and the CPF Annual Limit, how can I apply for a refund in these situations?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions above the Additional Wage (AW) ceiling   If you have paid excess CPF contributions above the AW ceiling, you should apply for a refund by selecting ‘Refund of payments made in excess of AW ceiling’ in the online application.   CPF contributions paid in excess of the CPF Annual Limit   From February 2024, any CPF contributions paid in excess of the CPF Annual Limit will be refunded automatically. This applies to excess contributions paid from year 2023. The automatic refund of excess made in current year will only take place (in phases) the following year. Notifications will be sent after the refund is processed.   However, there is no need to wait for the annual automatic refund. If you have paid excess CPF contributions above the CPF Annual Limit, you should apply for a refund promptly. You can do this  online by selecting ‘Refund of payments made for 1 employee’.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I have an existing regular premium insurance policy bought using cash, can I continue to service the future premiums using CPF under the CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: With effect from 1 January 2001, CPF savings cannot be used for new regular premium insurance policies, regardless of whether the policies are converted from cash or newly bought from insurance companies.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to refund the employee's share of CPF contributions to employee before applying for a refund of the contributions paid in error/on conditional wages repayable?
Knowledge Article: Answer: It is the employer’s responsibility to ensure that the employee’s share of CPF contributions is deducted correctly. Therefore, the employer must refund the employee’s share of CPF contributions (where applicable) to employee before applying for the refund. If the refund application is successful, both employer’s and employee’s share of contributions will be refunded to the employer.

Knowledge Article: Question: I received a Final Reminder notification regarding my outstanding CareShield Life/MediShield Life premiums, will the amount payable still be increased?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Final Reminder notification shows the amount of your outstanding CareShield Life/MediShield Life premiums as at the date sent.   Please pay your full outstanding premiums by the deadline indicated in the notification. Otherwise, the amount payable will increase as the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) will impose compounded interest of 4% and penalties of up to 17% on your outstanding premiums. To do so, please click on the link below for the payment options.   How can I view and pay my/my dependant(s)s' CareShield Life/ElderShield and MediShield Life premiums?

Knowledge Article: Question: With the closure of the Special Account and the raising of the Enhanced Retirement Sum, how much is the maximum amount that I can have in my Retirement Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: From 1 January 2025, the Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS) will be raised to four times of the Basic Retirement Sum to allow members 55 and above to save more in the Retirement Account (RA) and receive higher payouts , if they wish to do so.   With the change, the ERS in 2025 would be $426,000 1 , up from $308,700 in 2024. Hence, if you are aged 55 and above in 2025, you can save up to $426,000 in the RA.   1 This is the limit for the savings set aside in the RA (excluding amounts such as interest earned, any government grants received, plus retirement withdrawals).

Knowledge Article: Question: With the raising of the Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS), does the Government plan to also raise the Basic Retirement Sum (BRS) and Full Retirement Sum (FRS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Full Retirement Sum (FRS) will continue to be set at 2 times the Basic Retirement Sum (BRS). As the BRS is adjusted annually, the FRS will correspondingly be adjusted annually.

Knowledge Article: Question: What does it mean to appoint agents to recover outstanding MediShield Life premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) will take enforcement actions against members with outstanding MediShield Life premiums. This may include appointing agents like employers, banks or tenants in member's properties to recover the outstanding premiums.   IRAS will inform members and their agents of the appointment in writing. The appointed agents will pay the premiums to the MediShield Life Fund on behalf of the member.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much tax relief can I enjoy when I make cash top-ups?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can enjoy an equivalent amount of tax relief for cash top-ups made in each calendar year of up to:   $8,000 if you make a top-up to yourself; and an additional $8,000 if you make a cash top-up to your loved ones . Please note that only cash top-ups up to the current Full Retirement Sum (FRS) are eligible for tax relief. Log in with your Singpass to find out how much you can top up to yourself. If you make cash top-ups to your loved ones, please note that the tax relief does not apply to your recipients. Find out the  conditions to qualify for tax relief .   If you are an employer making cash top-ups on your employees’ behalf, you will receive an equivalent amount of tax deductions for the cash top-ups. Additionally, your employee can receive up to $8,000* of tax relief per calendar year.   * Includes any tax relief that the employee would enjoy for cash top-ups made to himself.   From 1 January 2025, givers of cash top-ups that attract the matching grant (up to $2,000 per year) under the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme (MRSS) will no longer receive tax relief. Find out more on how this works .

Knowledge Article: Question: Why have I received a notice from the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) informing me that I owe MediShield Life and/or CareShield Life premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: IRAS is authorised under the MediShield Life Scheme Act and the CareShield Life Scheme Act to carry out enforcement actions to recover MediShield Life and CareShield Life premiums.   Fully pay your outstanding premiums by the deadline indicated by IRAS to avoid further enforcement actions or apply for assistance to help you pay the premiums. To do so, please click on the link below for the payment options.   How can I view and pay my/my dependant(s)'s CareShield Life/ElderShield and MediShield Life premiums?

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I choose to opt-out of the online Daily Withdrawal Limit?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As part of CPF Board’s ongoing efforts to safeguard CPF members’ savings against unauthorised online withdrawals, all members aged 55 and above will be subject to the online Daily Withdrawal Limit. You can set the Daily Withdrawal Limit to your preferred amount, from $0 up to $200,000.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens if I choose not to pay my outstanding MediShield Life and/or CareShield Life premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For those who have the means but choose not to pay their MediShield Life and/or CareShield Life premiums despite reminders, a strong set of premium recovery measures will be taken.   The premium recovery measures include: Appointment of defaulter’s agents (such as the defaulter’s employers, banks and tenants) to recover the outstanding premiums Offsetting outstanding premiums against one-off Government surplus-sharing transfers (e.g. Growth Dividends) Recovery from CPF monies that are being withdrawn in cash Imposition of travel restrictions in certain circumstances Legal action to recover the arrears Those who persistently delay premium payment may be imposed compounded interests of 4% and penalties of up to 17% on outstanding premiums.   The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) and the CPF Board are the recovery bodies responsible for imposing premium recovery measures under the MediShield Life Scheme Act. You should fully pay your outstanding premiums to avoid enforcement actions. Please refer to this link to find out how to view and pay for your/your dependent(s)’s outstanding MediShield Life premiums.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will I still receive the full matching grant of $600 if my retirement savings exceed the current Basic Retirement Sum after topping up?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you will receive the full matching grant of $600 as long as you are eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme for the year, and the total amount of cash top-ups you received was at least $600.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will my cash top-ups or CPF transfers be refunded to me if the recipient passes away?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Cash top-ups and CPF transfers will generally be treated as gifts to the recipient. Any unused cash top-ups and CPF transfers will be paid to the recipient's nominees based on his  CPF nomination . This is subject to safeguards to prevent premature withdrawals .

Knowledge Article: Question: Will interests and penalties be imposed or waived if I made partial payment for my outstanding premiums before the deadline in IRAS' notice?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Interests and penalties will be imposed if full premium payment is not made by IRAS' notice deadline.   Compounded annual interest of 4% and penalties of up to 17% may continue to be imposed so long as the MediShield Life and/or CareShield Life premiums remain outstanding.   Fully pay your outstanding premiums to avoid enforcement actions. To do so, please click on the link below for the payment options.   How can I view and pay my/my dependant(s)s' CareShield Life/ElderShield and MediShield Life premiums?

Knowledge Article: Question: If I have renounced my citizenship, will interest and penalty still be imposed on my outstanding MediShield Life premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You need to pay your MediShield Life premiums incurred prior to your renouncement date of your citizenship. If your premiums remain outstanding, compounded interest of 4% and penalties of up to 17% will be imposed and enforcement actions will be taken.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have renounced my citizenship and applied to withdraw my CPF savings. Will my application be affected if I choose not to pay the outstanding MediShield Life and/or CareShield Life premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your withdrawal application will be processed even if you have outstanding MediShield Life and/or CareShield Life premiums.   However, you are advised to fully pay your outstanding premiums to avoid enforcement actions by the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS). To do so, please click on the link below to view the payment options.   I have renounced my citizenship/am residing overseas without local bank account. How do I pay my outstanding MediShield Life premiums?

Knowledge Article: Question: If I have renounced my Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Resident status, is CPF Board authorised to recover my outstanding premiums from my CPF savings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) will carry out enforcement actions on members with outstanding premiums. This includes the imposition of compounded interest of 4% and penalties of up to 17% on your outstanding premiums. IRAS will also appoint agents, such as CPF Board and banks, to recover your outstanding premiums from your CPF savings or bank accounts.   Pay your outstanding premiums in full to avoid enforcement actions. To do so, please click on the link below to view the payment options.   I have renounced my Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Resident status/am residing overseas without a local bank account. How do I pay my outstanding MediShield Life premiums?

Knowledge Article: Question: Can the interest and penalty be waived if I partially paid my outstanding premiums before the deadline in Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore's (IRAS) notice?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Interest and penalties will be imposed if full premium payment is not made by IRAS' notice deadline.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I apply for Lease Buyback Scheme or Silver Housing Bonus scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can apply for the Lease Buyback Scheme or the Silver Housing Bonus scheme through HDB:   Silver Housing Bonus scheme   Lease Buyback Scheme

Knowledge Article: Question: Why should I consider monetising my property?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can consider this option if your property can be an additional source of retirement income. It is an option to consider if your CPF and personal savings are not enough to provide you with your desired monthly payouts in retirement. Find out more about the  different ways you could monetise your property . You may use HDB’s Enquire Housing Monetisation Options e-Service to check your eligible Housing Monetisation options.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the CPF planner - retirement income?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF planner - retirement income is an online tool that helps members set their retirement income goals, visualise their projected retirement savings and payouts and simulate the impact of actions they can take to achieve their goals. Members may also perform selected transactions such as making retirement top-ups.   With the planner, retirement planning is easy with just a few steps, and takes only minutes to complete.

Knowledge Article: Question: Who can use the CPF planner - retirement income?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF planner - retirement income is available for members from age 16 up to 4 months before 65. Members who are reaching or have reached 65 can use the Plan my monthly payout service to make key decisions related to their payouts.

Knowledge Article: Question: I live in a private property. Are there ways for me to monetise my property without selling my home?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can consider speaking with your financial institution or advisor on the available products in the market that allow you to monetise your private property to supplement your retirement income while ageing in place.   As with all important financial decision, it is important to understand the nature of the product and assess your own risk tolerance and retirement needs/preferences before deciding if the monetisation option is suitable for you.   Alternatively, you can consider renting out a spare bedroom, or your entire property if you have an alternative accommodation. This can provide you with an additional source of retirement income.

Knowledge Article: Question: I turned 55 before 2016 and joined CPF LIFE at 55. Will the premium deducted for CPF LIFE continue to earn interest?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, regardless of the age that you join CPF LIFE, the amount deducted from your Retirement Account savings for the CPF LIFE premium continues to earn CPF interest rates with the floor rate of 4% and up to 2% extra interest on the first $60,000 of your combined CPF balances. The interest earned is factored into your monthly payouts, allowing you to receive higher lifelong payouts compared to other annuities offered in the market.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are CPF LIFE premiums invested in and are the investments safe?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF LIFE premiums are invested in Special Singapore Government Securities (SSGS), which are safe instruments because they are issued and guaranteed by the Government, and shielded from financial market fluctuations.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to the CPF interest earned on my CPF LIFE premium?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your CPF LIFE premium will continue to earn CPF interest rates, which is added to your monthly payouts to increase the amount you receive, compared to if there were no interests earned. These payouts continue for life, even after your initial premium is exhausted, ensuring lifelong financial security in retirement.

Knowledge Article: Question: Does my CPF LIFE premium continue to earn interest?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, your CPF LIFE premium will continue to earn CPF interest rates with the floor rate of 4%, and up to 2% extra interest on the first $60,000 of your combined CPF balances. The interest earned is factored into your monthly payouts and you receive a higher payout from the start.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why do I need to log in with my Singpass to access the CPF planner - retirement income?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To use the CPF planner – retirement income , you will need to log in using Singpass because:   Your latest CPF account balances are used to project your retirement savings and monthly payouts; and Your retirement income goals and the details you provide will be saved for future visits to the planner, making it easier for you to keep track of your retirement planning.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I change from a legacy plan (Basic, Balanced, Plus or Income Plan) to the Standard or Escalating Plan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Basic, Balanced, Plus and Income plans were introduced when CPF LIFE was first launched in 2009. Under these plans, extra interest earned on the first $60,000 of your CPF balances is credited to your Retirement Account (RA) and factored into your monthly payouts. As your balances are withdrawn over time to provide you with monthly payouts, the amount of monthly payouts and extra interest will decrease when your balances fall below $60,000.   If you are currently on any of the above legacy plans, you have the option to change to either the Escalating Plan  or  Standard Plan . Changing to the Escalating Plan will provide you with increasing payouts over time, while changing to the Standard Plan will provide you with level payouts. You can  make the change anytime.   It is important to note that:   Once you have changed to the Standard or Escalating Plan, you cannot change back to a legacy plan. All your RA savings, including the premium refunded from your legacy plan, will be deducted as CPF LIFE premium when the Standard or Escalating Plan is issued to you.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is the increase in CPF LIFE Escalating Plan payouts fixed at 2% per year and not matched to actual inflation rate?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF LIFE Escalating Plan payouts are not specifically matched to actual inflation in each year so that the increase in payouts is predictable and stable.   By fixing the increase at 2% per year, CPF LIFE can provide some protection against inflation while keeping premiums at a more affordable level. Additionally, the 2% increase is meant to be a conservative estimate of the average inflation rate over time, which can vary from year to year.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the breakeven point for my CPF LIFE plan i.e. the age when my CPF LIFE premium is fully depleted, and should it matter?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Unlike investment products where we would aim to maximise returns, CPF LIFE is a national longevity insurance annuity product that aims to protect us against the possibility of having nothing to live on when our retirement savings are used up. As we cannot predict how long we will live, it is not relevant to consider the age when our CPF LIFE premium is fully depleted.   If you pass away before your CPF LIFE premium is depleted, your beneficiaries will always get back any remaining CPF LIFE premium that you have put into your plan.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the hospitalisation and outpatient treatment benefits under MediShield Life?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediShield Life covers expenses incurred for hospitalisations and certain approved outpatient treatments, such as kidney dialysis, cancer drugs and radiotherapy for cancer.   The benefits under MediShield Life are shown in these tables . They are designed to cover subsidised bills incurred for hospitalisations in Class B2/C wards and subsidised outpatient/day surgery treatments in public hospitals. Patients who seek non-subsidised treatments in Class A/B1/B2+ ward types in public hospitals or private hospitals will also be able to benefit from MediShield Life. However, as such non-subsidised bills are much higher, MediShield Life will cover a smaller portion of the bill.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am going for a day surgery. How do I know if I can use my MediSave in that clinic/hospital?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can refer to this list of medical institutions or day surgery centres (PDF, 0.4MB) participating in the MediSave scheme.   To use your MediSave, please inform the staff handling your hospital admission that you wish to do so. The staff will submit your claim for you after your authorisation.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I enable/disable push notifications on my mobile device?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For General Notifications, go to your device settings to turn on notifications.   For Personalised Notifications, tap on the ‘side menu’ icon located on the top left corner of the app and select ‘Settings’. Toggle the switch to enable personalised Push Notifications.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why am I not eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme if my retirement savings are above the current Basic Retirement Sum?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Matched Retirement Savings Scheme is designed to help senior Singapore Citizens with lower retirement savings save more and boost their retirement payouts. If your retirement savings are more than the current Basic Retirement Sum, you will not be eligible for the scheme as it is intended to provide additional support to those who need it the most.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I stop receiving my hardcopy Yearly Statement of Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As part of our efforts to go green, we have transformed the Yearly Statement of Account (YSOA) into a digital statement. If you wish to go green and stop receiving a hardcopy YSOA, please submit a request to us. Singpass login is required.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I voluntarily top-up to my Ordinary Account only?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Voluntary top-ups cannot be made solely to the Ordinary Account.   You can make voluntary top-ups to: Special / Retirement Account only under the Retirement Sum Topping Up Scheme (RSTU) (tax relief available). MediSave Account only (tax relief available) CPF accounts Voluntary top-up is applicable to Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents only.   You can  find out more on which voluntary top-up is applicable to you.   To make a top up to MediSave Account and/or CPF accounts, you are required to be up-to-date with your MediSave payable (paid in full or on an active GIRO plan) under the Self-Employed Scheme . You may make payment for your MediSave payable via the  payment modes .   Tax relief is only applicable to self-employed persons, based on their assessable net trade income for the year of assessment. Find out more about tax relief for self-employed persons .

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I voluntarily top-up to my Ordinary Account only?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Voluntary top-ups cannot be made solely to the Ordinary Account.   You can make voluntary top-ups to: Special / Retirement Account only under the Retirement Sum Topping Up Scheme (RSTU) (tax relief available). MediSave Account only (tax relief available) CPF accounts Voluntary top-up is applicable to Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents only.   You can  find out more on which voluntary top-up is applicable to you.   To make a top up to MediSave Account and/or CPF accounts, you are required to be up-to-date with your MediSave payable (paid in full or on an active GIRO plan) under the Self-Employed Scheme . You may make payment for your MediSave payable via the  payment modes .   Tax relief is only applicable to self-employed persons, based on their assessable net trade income for the year of assessment. Find out more about tax relief for self-employed persons .

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is payment via eNETS discontinued with effect from 23 April 2023?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF Board regularly reviews the services and payment options we provide to our customers. Payment via eNETS had been discontinued from 23 April 2023 because payments made by customers via eNETS are unable to be updated in the members’ accounts instantaneously. Customers can use PayNow QR or OCBC Digital via our digital services on CPF Mobile to make payment and these transactions will be processed instantaneously.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to my CPF LIFE plan when my CPF account is closed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your CPF LIFE plan will be terminated and you will receive your CPF LIFE premium balance (if any) together with your CPF savings when you transfer your savings to your bank account.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will I receive the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) payment?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will receive the cash portion of Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) via your PayNow-NRIC-linked bank account. To check your PayNow-NRIC-linked bank account details, please approach your bank.   If you do not have a PayNow-NRIC-linked bank account with a PayNow-GIRO-participating local or foreign bank in Singapore but have provided your DBS/POSB, OCBC or UOB bank account to the Government previously, you will receive your cash portion of WIS via bank transfer. You can check and update your bank account details registered with us by logging in to our e-services with your Singpass.   Otherwise, the amount will be credited to you via GovCash. GovCash is a payment mode that allows Singaporeans to receive their benefits from Government agencies more quickly and conveniently. You are encouraged to link your NRIC to PayNow with a PayNow-GIRO-participating local or foreign bank in Singapore to receive your benefits earlier*.   *If you have linked your NRIC number to your bank account after the 16th of the month or submitted your bank account details after the 14th of the month, your updates will only be effective in the following month.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I change the mode of payment for my Workfare Income Supplement (WIS)? / I have already registered for PayNow-NRIC to receive my Government cash benefits. Do I still need to provide my bank account details?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No further action is required from you if you have already registered for PayNow-NRIC with the participating banks. You are encouraged to register for PayNow-NRIC with a PayNow-GIRO-participating local or foreign bank in Singapore to receive your WIS payments earlier. Payment will be made by default to your PayNow-NRIC-linked bank account.   If you do not have a PayNow-NRIC-linked bank account, you can update your bank account details by logging in to our WIS  e-services with your Singpass. Payment instructions received will be used for future government benefits. The Government will be validating the bank account details that you have registered. If you have closed your bank account, ceased being a joint account holder, or have provided the wrong bank account details, we will inform you to update your bank account details. You will receive a notification sent to your Singpass app. If you do not have the app, a letter will be sent to your NRIC address. This notification will not be sent via SMS, WhatsApp or any other platforms.   If you have not linked your NRIC to PayNow or have not provided a valid bank account to the Government, you will receive future Government cash benefits via GovCash. GovCash is a payment mode where you can withdraw your Government benefits in cash from OCBC ATMs.   Citizens who are on GovCash will receive their cash benefits 2-3 weeks later than those who have linked their NRIC to PayNow or have provided a valid bank account.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I pay my MediShield Life and/or CareShield Life premiums by instalment through GIRO?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediShield Life and/or CareShield Life premiums are generally paid using MediSave. You can use your own or your family member's MediSave Account to pay your premiums.   Currently, GIRO instalment payment is only extended to members with insufficient MediSave to pay their outstanding premiums.   We will deduct the monies from your bank account on the 15th of the month (or the next working day if 15th falls on a Saturday, Sunday or Public Holiday).   Do ensure that you maintain sufficient funds in your bank account for GIRO deductions. Some banks may charge an administrative fee for each unsuccessful deduction.   How do I apply for a GIRO payment plan for my/my dependant’s outstanding MediShield Life premiums?

Knowledge Article: Question: When can I expect to receive my CPF savings upon account closure?
Knowledge Article: Answer: In view of the recent surge in applications, the average processing duration is about 18 weeks. We seek your understanding on this matter.   a. Online applications This is the fastest mode, with average processing time of about 12 weeks from the point of form submission. The processing duration may be longer if additional supporting documents are required.   b. Applications by post or in-person The average processing time is about 18 weeks from the time we receive all required documents. Please note this excludes the time taken to transfer your CPF savings to your bank account, which depends on the payment mode:     Bank transfer via Interbank GIRO to a bank account in Singapore:  Two working days; Telegraphic transfer:  Five to twelve working days; or Cheque:  The time taken for the cheque to reach you will depend on your country’s courier service. We would like to emphasise that the Board conducts thorough checks on each application, including additional steps to verify the member’s identity especially for members without Singpass to ensure that the CPF savings are disbursed correctly. These stringent measures are in place to safeguard your savings and maintain the security of your CPF account.   Please only contact us to check on your account closure status if you have yet to receive a response from us after five months from the time you requested the Board to close your account . We seek your understanding that we will not be responding to any enquiries prior to that.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am a bankrupt and I do not have monies to pay the MediShield Life premiums for my child/dependant and myself. Will there be interest and penalty imposed on me?
Knowledge Article: Answer: A claim will be filed with the Private Trustee or Official Assignee for outstanding MediShield Life premiums (including interest and penalties) incurred prior to the date of your Bankruptcy Order.   You are required to pay any MediShield Life premiums incurred after the date of your Bankruptcy Order. Bankrupt parents/guardians remain liable to pay for their child/dependant's premiums.   If you face difficulties paying the premiums, you may apply for Additional Premium Support (APS). APS helps members who cannot pay their MediShield Life premiums after Government subsidies and have limited family support. Find out more information on APS by calling 1800-222-3399 (or +65 6222 3399) from Monday to Friday, 8.30am to 5.30pm (GMT+8).   The Ministry of Health will assess each APS application to ensure that assistance is provided to members who need financial support. They will notify you of your APS application status.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long does it take to process applications relating to the Self-Employed Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The applications relating to the Self-Employed Scheme will generally be processed within the service standards as stated in the table below. We strive to process all submitted applications within the service standard and will let you know if more time is needed.   Service Normal Processing Time Manage your MediSave payable Online : 12 working days Manual : 15 working days Refund of CPF/MediSave contributions by self-employed person Online : 12 working days Manual : 15 working days   This includes time needed to liaise with other parties or seek clarification on your refund application. Adjust self-employed contributions Make full payment for your MediSave payables a.  Payment via PayNow / OCBC Digital: Will generally be processed almost instantly b. Cash: 10 working days   Note: Please note that cheque payment is no longer accepted for Self-Employed contributions with effect from 1 January 2024. Self-employed person income declaration form Online : 8 working days Manual : 10 working days

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I take over my/my dependant(s)' MediShield Life premium payment or change payer?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have a valid Singpass and sufficient funds in your MediSave Account, you can submit a Change Payer for MediShield Life request online to take over your/your dependant(s)' MediShield Life premium payment.    If you need help with the request, contact us at 1800 222 3399 or write to us .

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I enable personalised push notifications on multiple mobile devices?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, you can only enable personalised push notifications on one mobile device at any time. If you had already enabled personalised push notifications on one device, enabling it on another device will disable the personalised notifications on your older device.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will I be notified of the MediShield Life premium deduction?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can access your Transaction history to check the MediShield Life transactions from your MediSave Account.   You can also log in to Healthcare dashboard 'Coverage and premium details' for details of your and/or your dependants' MediShield Life premiums and subsidies.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I provide or update my mobile number to receive SMS notification on my Workfare payment?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We will only send SMS notifications on Workfare payments to the mobile number that you have registered with CPF Board. To receive SMS notifications, you may update your mobile number via my cpf digital services - Account Settings with your Singpass.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the benefits of using Direct Debit to pay for my CPF contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will enjoy the following benefits if you pay CPF contributions via Direct Debit:   Full control of your payments - Payment is within your control, as you may set the payment deduction date after you have submitted your CPF contribution details. Save time - You do not need to provide your payment details each time you pay CPF contributions.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long does CPF Board takes to credit the payment for CPF contributions and late CPF interest?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The service standards for crediting of payment for CPF contributions and late CPF interest are: Service Processing Time CPF contributions submission Within three working days

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I receive SMS notifications and stop receiving hardcopy notifications for the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To receive SMS notifications, register your mobile number with CPF Board via my cpf digital services - Account Settings with your Singpass.   If you wish to receive notifications of your Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) by SMS instead of hardcopy letters, please log in to the e-Services with your Singpass and opt-in to SMS at “Notification”.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have already made payment via the Top up MediSave Account form. Why do I still see outstanding MediShield Life premiums under the 'Outstanding MediShield Life Premium' section of my Healthcare Dashboard?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please allow 3 working days before checking again, if you made the payment for your outstanding MediShield Life premiums just recently. You can view the premium deduction in your Transaction history at cpf.gov.sg .

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is the option to withdraw GovCash only available in $10 denominations and what can I do with my balance GovCash?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Currently, the minimum withdrawal amount at the ATMs is $10. Hence, GovCash withdrawals can also be made in $10 denominations. If the balance in your GovCash is less than $10, you can accumulate your balance monies before your next withdrawal. Alternatively, you can also transfer the balance to your PayNow NRIC-linked bank account or utilise them to make payments at any merchants with PayNow/NETS QR code, or transfer to your friends by scanning the PayNow QR code using the LifeSG mobile app.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if I do not want to receive my payments via GovCash?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There are two options for you if you do not wish to receive your payments via GovCash:   Option 1: Register for PayNow-NRIC with one of the participating banks We encourage you to register for PayNow-NRIC with a PayNow-GIRO-participating bank. The list of PayNow-GIRO-participating banks in alphabetical order are: Bank of China, CIMB, Citibank, DBS Bank / POSB, HSBC Bank, ICBC, Maybank, OCBC Bank, RHB Bank, Standard Chartered Bank, Trust Bank and UOB Bank. If your preferred bank is on this list, you may contact your bank for specific details on how to register your NRIC on PayNow. After you have linked your NRIC to PayNow, future Government benefits that you are eligible for will be automatically credited to your PayNow-NRIC-linked bank account.   Option 2: Register your bank account details Alternatively, you can choose to receive your payments via crediting to your bank account. To do so, you may login to the  e-services  using your Singpass, select “Bank Account Submission” and update your POSB/DBS, OCBC or UOB bank account details.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if I do not want to receive my payments via GovCash?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There are two options for you if you do not wish to receive your payments via GovCash:   Option 1: Register for PayNow-NRIC with one of the participating banks We encourage you to register for PayNow-NRIC with a PayNow-GIRO-participating bank. The list of PayNow-GIRO-participating banks in alphabetical order are: Bank of China, CIMB, Citibank, DBS Bank / POSB, HSBC Bank, ICBC, Maybank, OCBC Bank, RHB Bank, Standard Chartered Bank, Trust Bank and UOB Bank. If your preferred bank is on this list, you may contact your bank for specific details on how to register your NRIC on PayNow. After you have linked your NRIC to PayNow, future Government benefits that you are eligible for will be automatically credited to your PayNow-NRIC-linked bank account.   Option 2: Register your bank account details Alternatively, you can choose to receive your payments via crediting to your bank account. To do so, you may login to the  e-services  using your Singpass, select “Bank Account Submission” and update your POSB/DBS, OCBC or UOB bank account details.

Knowledge Article: Question: My employee joined my company in July 2021. Do I have to take into account the Additional Wages (AW) that were paid to him by his ex-company when I compute the AW ceiling?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As employee’s Additional Wage (AW) ceiling is computed on a per employer per year basis, you do not need to take into account of past AW paid to him if his ex-company is a different entity.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much MediSave can I use to pay for my own or an approved dependant's day surgery bills?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use your MediSave: Up  to $300 per day for ward charges; and Between $250 and $7,550 for your surgical procedures, depending on the type of procedures performed. You can use up to the same withdrawal limit for each approved dependant. Approved dependants refer to your spouse, children, parents, grandparents and siblings. Please note that grandparents and siblings must be Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the priority of Home Protection Scheme deduction if my family member has authorised the Board to deduct my premium from their CPF Ordinary Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Home Protection Scheme (HPS) premium will first be deducted from the available balance in your CPF Ordinary Account (OA) followed by your family member's OA.

Knowledge Article: Question: What if I do not wish to participate in Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Self-employed persons (SEPs) who have completed a job with Government agencies will be automatically enrolled into CAYE. CAYE will not apply to SEPs who completed jobs with the private sector.   The CAYE scheme helps SEPs save for their healthcare needs through smaller and more regular MediSave contributions each time they receive a service payment. This helps to reduce the MediSave payable in the following year (after SEPs declare their Net Trade Income and have their MediSave payable computed). CAYE will help with the upkeep of current MediSave obligations and prevent snowballing of the payable.   You can choose to set your CAYE contribution rate to 0% if you’ve made your MediSave contributions in full or are on GIRO instalment plan.   If you’re in financial hardship and unable to set aside monies for your CAYE contributions, you may write to us . We will assess your request and inform you of the outcome in writing.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I still make payment for my outstanding MediShield Life premiums after the deadline stated in the Final Reminder notification?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We advise you to pay your outstanding MediShield Life premiums before the due date to avoid enforcement actions.   Please click on the link below for the payment options.   How can I view and pay my/my dependant(s)'s CareShield Life/ElderShield and MediShield Life premiums?

Knowledge Article: Question: My cancer drug treatment is on a 3-weekly cycle. Is the cancer drug limit sufficient for months when I need to undergo 2 rounds of treatment?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For cost-effective cancer drug treatments on 3-weekly cycles, the MediShield Life (MSHL) claim limits have typically been sized to cover the post-subsidy costs of two treatment courses in a month.   For other cancer drug treatments, the MSHL claim limit has been sized to cover up to the monthly cost of the cost-effective alternative.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is the government sending SMS notifications instead of hardcopy letters?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Moving to SMS notifications is part of the Government's efforts to provide timelier and more responsive services to the public. It also allows us to be more environmentally friendly. With SMS notifications, you can quickly and easily receive details of your Workfare payments, including the mode of payment and payment date, instead of having to wait for hardcopy letters. If you are on hardcopy notification and would like to switch to SMS notification, please log in to the  e-Services with your Singpass and opt-in to receive SMS at "Notification".

Knowledge Article: Question: Why are the excess voluntary top-ups only refunded in the following year?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF Annual Limit (AL) consists of both the Mandatory Contribution (MC) from your employer and Voluntary Contributions (VC) paid by you, if any. You are allowed to top up VC up to the CPF Annual Limit (AL) of the year.   As the MC for December can be paid by January of the following year, any excess VC top-ups made for the preceding year can only be finalized and refunded in the following year.   If your mandatory and voluntary CPF contributions have exceeded the CPF Annual Limit during the year, you can  write to us to request for refund of the excess voluntary top-ups.

Knowledge Article: Question: How and when will I receive Workfare notification on the amount I am receiving?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will be notified via letters and/or SMS nearer to the payment dates. You can also login to the e-Services with your Singpass to check your payment. To receive the notification earlier via SMS, please log in to the  e-Services with your Singpass and select "Notification" to opt-in to receive SMS.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I tell if the Workfare SMS I received is authentic?
Knowledge Article: Answer: With the recent rise in scam and phishing attempts, it is important to verify that the message received is genuinely sent by an official source.   From 1 July 2024, all government SMS communications will be sent under the sender ID “gov.sg”. The SMS begins with the full name of the sending agency (i.e. “Central Provident Fund Board”) and ends with “This is an automated message sent by the Singapore Government”. It means you should not reply to the message.   This is only an example of a Workfare SMS. The actual SMS received may be different.   Here are some tips on how you can protect yourself against phishing SMSes purporting to be sent from CPF Board:   Check the SMS is sent by “gov.sg”to the mobile number registered with CPF Board. If you are unsure of whether you had registered your mobile number, please login to the CPF website with your Singpass and check your  account settings . Verify the last four characters of the masked NRIC number are the same as your NRIC number. We will never ask you to reply to the Workfare SMS nor direct you to a non-Government website. Do report any suspicious SMS spoofing to  CPF Board .   Be Cautious, Pay attention to scams and don't be the next victim of Fraud.

Knowledge Article: Question: For those with serious pre-existing conditions, why do they have to pay Additional Premiums for MediShield Life?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Those with serious pre-existing conditions pay a higher MediShield Life premium as a reflection of the higher risks they pose to the pool and to fund part of their coverage. The Government will support most of the cost of extending MediShield Life coverage to all Singapore Residents.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why does my Healthcare dashboard state that my MediShield Life premiums may be recovered from my bankruptcy estate?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Outstanding MediShield Life premiums incurred prior to your bankruptcy date may be recovered from your bankruptcy estate. These premiums will therefore not be reflected as outstanding premiums payable in your Healthcare dashboard. To pay your outstanding premiums incurred prior to the date of your Bankruptcy Order, please obtain approval from the Private Trustee or Official Assignee. You can contact them at 1800 225 5529 (during office hours) or visit www.mlaw.gov.sg .

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the upcoming enhancements to the Silver Support Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Silver Support will be enhanced in 2025. From 1 January 2025:   (i) Payments will be raised by 20%. Quarterly payments will increase by 20% for those who meet the current eligibility criteria.   (ii) Criterion for household monthly income per person will be raised. Singaporeans aged 65 and above who live in a household with a monthly income per person of not more than $2,300 and meet all other eligibility criteria will be eligible for the SSS (the current criterion is $1,800). Payments will continued to be tiered.   The enhanced quarterly payments from 1 January 2025 are in the table below.   HDB Flat Type 3 Enhanced Silver Support payments from 1 January 2025 1 Total CPF contributions of not more than $140,000 by age 55 2 Household monthly income per person of $1,500 or less Household monthly income per person of above $1,500 but not more than $2,300 1- and 2-Room $1,080 $540 3-Room $860 $430 4-Room $650 $325 5-Room 4 $430 $215   Note: 1. All Singaporeans aged 65 and above who are ComCare Long Term Assistance (LTA) recipients will receive SS of $430 per quarter, regardless of their flat type.   2. Self-employed persons should also have an average annual net trade income of not more than $27,600 when they were aged 45 to 54.   3. Senior should not own, and not have a spouse who owns, a 5-room or larger HDB flat or private property or multiple properties.   4. Senior may live in, but do not own, a 5-room HDB flat.

Knowledge Article: Question: Which CPF payments will I receive in the bank account provided under my Account settings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The bank account provided under your Account settings will be used for CPF payments such as: Withdrawals of CPF savings from age 55 Monthly payouts Withdrawals of Housing Refund from sale/transfer of property Cash bonus received under Silver Housing Bonus scheme Cash bonus received under Lease Buyback Scheme Withdrawals of deceased member’s CPF savings This does not include long-term care payouts (e.g. CareShield Life, ElderShield and MediSave Care) where application is made through the Agency for Integrated Care, and Government payments (e.g. GST Vouchers, Workfare Income Supplement and Silver Support Scheme).

Knowledge Article: Question: Does CPF Board disburse the CPF Housing Grant (CHG) and who is eligible for the CPF housing grant?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF Housing Grant (CHG) is disbursed by HDB. If you are looking for information on CHG and the eligibility criteria to apply for CHG, visit HDB's website .

Knowledge Article: Question: Will my new CPF working contribution partially pay off my outstanding MediShield Life and CareShield Life premiums if I am on a GIRO payment plan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, your new CPF working contributions will be used to pay your outstanding MediShield Life and CareShield Life premiums. This helps to reduce the outstanding amount and avoid enforcement actions.   The monthly instalment amount of your current GIRO payment plan remains unchanged. The payment plan will automatically end earlier when your outstanding premiums are fully paid.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens if the amount of MediSave contributions the self-employed person has made via Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) is higher than his MediSave payable for the year?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The self-employed person (SEP)’s MediSave payable for income earned in the year will be computed after the SEP has declared his actual income in the following year.   If the self-employed person (SEP) has outstanding MediSave payable from previous years, his excess CAYE contributions will be used to offset those payables 1 . Any excess thereafter will be refunded to him. He can also choose to retain the excess CAYE contributions in his MediSave Account (MA).   Example:   Based on his estimated income of $22,000 for 2023, Sam contributed $2,200 via CAYE. In the following year, he declared that he earned a lower Net Trade Income of $19,000 for 2023. As such, Sam’s MediSave payable for his work done in 2023 is $1,900. Hence, he has excess CAYE contributions of $300 for the year. Sam also has an outstanding MediSave payable of $100 incurred in 2022 which would be offset by the excess CAYE contributions, leaving a final excess amount of $200. This amount will be refunded to him 2 . He can also choose to keep this $200 in his MA.   This example is illustrated within the table below:   Estimated 2023 NTI $22,000 CAYE contributions in 2023 $2,200 (After 2023 NTI declaration)   Declared 2023 NTI $19,000 MediSave payable for work done in 2023 $1,900 Outstanding MediSave payable for 2022 $100 Amount Sam will receive as a refund $200 (i.e. $2,200 - $1,900 - $100)     1 This will take effect for CAYE contributions made from 2023. The SEP may write to us if he does not wish to use his CAYE contributions to offset his outstanding MediSave payable from previous years.   2 Sam may also choose not to use his CAYE contributions to offset his outstanding MediSave payable of $100 incurred in 2022. In this case, he will be refunded $300 instead.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is there an error message stating that I am not paying for my family member's CareShield Life/ElderShield/MediShield Life coverage when I tried to stop premium payment?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you encountered an error message stating that you are not paying your family member's CareShield Life/ElderShield/MediShield Life premiums, it could be due to several reasons:   1. Not the Payer: The error may arise if you are not the payer for your family member's healthcare insurance.   2. Coverage Under Integrated Shield Plan (IP) or Supplement Plan: If your family member has an Integrated Shield Plan or Supplement Plan, please contact the insured's private insurer directly for payer arrangements.   3. Inactive Coverage: Your family member's healthcare coverage is inactive.

Knowledge Article: Question: For corporate service buyers who currently do not have an account with OCBC, are they required to open an account with the appointed bank, OCBC, if they wish to opt for bank mode payments?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You do not need to have a bank account with OCBC for Contribute As You Earn (CAYE). However, you'II need to obtain and complete a Host-to-Host (H2H) application form from OCBC to establish a H2H file transfer link-up with the bank.

Knowledge Article: Question: How is my voluntary housing refund used to set aside my Retirement Sum if I am 55 years old and above?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The refunded amount will be used to meet your cohort's Full Retirement Sum (FRS) if you’re 55 years old and have not met the FRS. Please refer to the example below on how the voluntary housing refund is used to meet your FRS.   Example   Assumptions:   1. You turned 55 years old in 2023   2. Your cohort’s Full Retirement Sum is $198,800   3. You have received less than $30,000 in housing grants   Current RA balance $98,800 Current OA balance $100,000 Principal amount withdrawn for the property and the accrued interest (P+I) $500,000   If you make a voluntary housing refund of $200,000   New RA balance The vHR of $100,000 is used to top up to RA to meet the cohort’s FRS $198,800 New OA balance The remaining vHR of $100,000 remains in OA after topping up RA to meet FRS The balance in OA can continued to be used for housing payments $200,000 Revised P+I The vHR of $200,000 is used to reduce the P+I $300,000

Knowledge Article: Question: Will payments to sub-contractors be under Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Contribute As You Earn is not applicable to sub-contractors because they do not have a direct contractual relationship with corporate service buyer.

Knowledge Article: Question: Would I have duplicate coverage if I buy an Integrated Shield Plan (IP) as I am covered under MediShield Life now?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There is no duplication in coverage. Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents are automatically covered under MediShield Life, for no matter how long you live. You will continue to be able to tap on MediShield Life benefits when you buy an IP because Integrated Shield Plan (IP) comprises both your MediShield Life component and the additional private insurance component.

Knowledge Article: Question: When can I start receiving my CPF LIFE payouts?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can choose to start receiving your CPF LIFE payouts anytime between the ages of 65 and 70. Consider starting later as your monthly payout will increase by up to 7% for each year that you defer starting.   CPF Board will send you a notification three months before your 65th birthday to explain your options and guide you in choosing your CPF LIFE plan. Your payouts will automatically start when you turn 70 if you have not instructed CPF Board regarding your payouts by then.

Knowledge Article: Question: My spouse and I received the Final Reminder notification regarding our child's outstanding MediShield Life premium. Whose MediSave would the premiums be deducted from?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your child is below 21 years old, his/her outstanding MediShield Life premiums will be deducted in the following order:   1. Child's MediSave, followed by 2. Father’s MediSave, followed by 3. Mother’s MediSave

Knowledge Article: Question: My employees do not wish to contribute to the SHARE programme. What can they do?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your employees can contact the HR department to cease the payroll deduction.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is a PayNow NRIC-linked bank account and how do I register for it?
Knowledge Article: Answer: PayNow is a secure funds transfer service that enables you to receive payment conveniently in your preferred bank account with only your NRIC number. It adopts the same high security standards as other trusted funds transfer services like FAST and GIRO.   You can register for a PayNow NRIC-linked bank account if you have a bank account with the PayNow participating banks in Singapore, which can be found on the Association of Banks in Singapore's  website .   If your bank is a PayNow participating bank, you may refer to your bank's website for specific details on how to link your NRIC to PayNow.

Knowledge Article: Question: Under a transfer order, do I need to set aside my retirement sum before my ex-spouse can receive their entitlement?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The transfer of CPF savings to your ex-spouse can take place without you setting aside your retirement sum* first. This gives your ex-spouse certainty over the amount they can receive and they can use them immediately for approved purposes such as housing, investment and education. Your ex-spouse may also withdraw the CPF savings when they are entitled to.   In the event of a transfer of CPF savings upon the making of housing refunds pursuant to a disposal of the property, the Board will first transfer the amount to your ex-spouse. Thereafter, the remaining refunds will be used to make up your retirement sum, up to your applicable Full Retirement Sum. Any balance housing refunds will remain in your Ordinary Account, and you can decide how to manage it.    *Only applies to members aged 55 and above.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I agree to my employee's request not to be paid CPF contributions so that he can get higher take-home pay?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You should not agree to your employee's request not to be paid CPF contributions so that he can get higher take-home pay. Failure to pay CPF contributions to an employee (i.e. Singapore Citizen or Singapore Permanent Resident who is employed in Singapore under a contract of service) is an offence under the CPF Act.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I change the bank account to pay for my MediShield Life and/or CareShield Life premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes. You will need to submit a new GIRO application with the new bank account details. The new application will generally be processed within 21 working days. We will continue to deduct your outstanding MediShield Life and/or CareShield Life premiums from the current bank account until the new GIRO application is approved.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens if the Direct Debit deduction is unsuccessful?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Direct Debit payment may be unsuccessful for various reasons, such as payment exceeding your bank's payment limits or due to insufficient funds. We will inform you of the unsuccessful Direct Debit deduction, and will make the deduction seven calendar days after the date of the first unsuccessful deduction. Late payment interest may be incurred.   Please make sure you maintain sufficient funds in your bank account or change your payment limits with your bank before the second deduction attempt. Some banks may charge an administrative fee for unsuccessful deductions.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have an ongoing GIRO payment plan. Can I continue to pay my next MediShield Life and/or CareShield Life premium by instalments?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have insufficient MediSave for your next MediShield Life and/or CareShield Life premium, the premium will be automatically included in your ongoing GIRO payment plan. You do not need to apply for a new GIRO payment plan. We will send you a notification on the revised GIRO payment plan when this happens.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the benefits of using CPF EZPay Mobile?
Knowledge Article: Answer: By using CPF EZPay Mobile, you will enjoy:   Fuss-free submission of your CPF contribution details via any mobile platform Option to load the employee details and email address from the previous submission Mobile optimised screen for positive user experience Secure payment via PayNow QR

Knowledge Article: Question: Under a transfer order, can I request the monies to be paid to me in cash, instead of transferring to my CPF account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Under a transfer order, the monies can only be transferred from your ex-spouse’s CPF account to your designated CPF account. If you wish to receive the monies in cash, you may consider applying to the Courts for a charging order instead.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I make additional or back pay CPF contributions for my employees if I am submitting CPF contributions via Electronic Standing Instructions (ESI)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: On top of your existing Electronic Standing Instructions (ESI) arrangement, you can make additional or back payments of CPF contributions for your employees by performing an additional submissions via the steps below:   At ESI Main Menu, select Perform Additional Submission . Select the Month and key in the Year you are submitting for and click Continue to proceed. Enter the contribution details for the affected employee (key in only the shortfall CPF amount) but enter the full wages earned for the month. After completing all the contribution details and the summary section (key in CPF late payment interest, if applicable), click on Continue. Verify the contribution details and click Direct Debit to complete the payment. You will see the online acknowledgement screen after the submission is completed successfully. An email will also be sent to your email address(es) registered with the Board.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use the CPF savings immediately upon the receipt of the transferred monies from my ex-spouse?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you can use the CPF savings for approved purposes such as housing, investment and education. You may also withdraw the CPF savings when you are entitled to do so.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I top up my MediSave to fully pay off the outstanding MediShield Life and/or CareShield Life premiums if I am on a GIRO Payment plan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you can pay your outstanding MediShield Life and/or CareShield Life premiums in full by performing a voluntary top-up to your MediSave Account via the Top up MediSave Account online form.    You can log in to your Healthcare dashboard to view your or your dependant(s)’s CareShield Life/ElderShield and MediShield Life coverage and premium information under the “Long-term care insurance” and “Health insurance” section respectively.   MediSave top-ups are generally credited within three working days and will be automatically deducted for premium payment(s). Your GIRO payment plan will automatically end when you do not have any outstanding premiums.   You may view the MediSave top-up(s) and premium deduction(s) in your Transaction history at cpf.gov.sg.   As MediSave top-ups could be deducted for healthcare premiums and medical expenses based on when deductions are due, please ensure that you have sufficient MediSave for all payments.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why can't I find the OCBC Digital option in CPF Mobile?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The OCBC Digital option is only available if you have installed the OCBC Digital app on your mobile devices. You will be able to select the OCBC Digital option under the 'Payment Mode' page in CPF Mobile after confirming the transaction details.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why do I have to effect the transfer or sale of investments under the division of CPF savings in a divorce? What happens if I do not come forward to effect the transfer or sale of investments?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You are solely responsible for presenting the court order and completing the necessary forms at the relevant financial intermediaries to effect the transfer or sale of investments because the financial intermediaries require authorisation and instruction from the owner, i.e. you. If you do not sign the transfer form, your ex-spouse may apply to the Court for the Registrar of Court to sign the transfer form on your behalf. Your ex-spouse will need to furnish the required information (eg, Divorce Petition number, both of your names, contact numbers, CPF account numbers, Investment Account numbers, names of agent banks, name of your investments, name of financial intermediaries, etc) to complete the transfer form. If you do not sell the investments as ordered, and the investments are such that they cannot be sold without instruction being given personally by you (as required by the financial intermediaries), your ex-spouse may request for the Court Order to be varied to transfer your investments to them instead. As this depends on the nature of the investments, your ex-spouse should make the necessary enquiries with the financial intermediaries concerned before obtaining the appropriate order.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can the cash balance in my Investment Account be transferred under the division of CPF savings in a divorce?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Cash balances in your Investment Account can be transferred but you have to initiate the transfer of cash balance from your Investment Account to your Ordinary Account first before CPF Board can transfer the balance to your ex-spouse's Ordinary Account.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I submit an application to transfer CPF Investment Scheme investments sale proceeds in a divorce?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will need to submit the following: The court order; and An application to transfer your CPF Investment Scheme investment sale proceeds here .

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I get additional payouts from buying Integrated Shield Plan (IP)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: In the majority of hospitalisation bills, you are unlikely to get additional payout from your Integrated Shield Plan (IP) if you stay in B2/C wards in public hospitals.

Knowledge Article: Question: What do I need to do to receive payment under a charging order?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will first need to submit the court order for the division of CPF assets via the online service "Submit Court Order for Division of CPF Assets".
