We will write to you and your ex-spouse once we have reviewed the court order.   When your ex-spouse is entitled to withdraw their CPF savings, we will write to you to inform you of the withdrawal procedure.   Once we receive your withdrawal application and the necessary documents, we will process the application and the monies will be paid to you within 10 working days through Inter-Bank GIRO and 15 working days via Telegraphic Transfer.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is a private Integrated Shield Plan (IP)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: A private Integrated Shield Plan (IP) is an optional medical insurance plan provided by private insurance companies which offers additional benefits on top of MediShield Life. You will need to pay higher premiums using MediSave and cash when you are older.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I specify the CPF account in which my ex-spouse is to receive the CPF savings under a transfer order?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For the court order to be workable, it must specify which of your CPF account(s) the transfer of CPF savings are to be made from. There is no need to specify which CPF account(s) your ex-spouse is to receive the monies in. This is because the transfers will be done in accordance with Regulation 3 of the Central Provident Fund (Division of Fund-Related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings) Regulations which specifies the CPF accounts of the receiving party.   Please refer to the table below for more details:   From member's CPF account To ex-spouse's CPF account Ordinary Account Ordinary Account Special/Retirement Account Special Account (if below age 55) *Retirement Account (if age 55 and above) MediSave Account MediSave Account   * Any amount in excess of the Full Retirement Sum that your ex-spouse needs to set aside in their CPF Retirement Account, will be transferred to their Ordinary Account.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will there be any fees for unsuccessful deduction of MediShield Life and/or CareShield Life premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF Board (Billing Organization) will not impose any charges for unsuccessful deductions of MediShield Life and/or CareShield Life premiums. However, some banks will impose service charges as an unsuccessful deduction may be treated like a bounced cheque. Please contact your bank for further details on the fees and charges (if applicable).

Knowledge Article: Question: I am currently paying my mortgage, but my flat only lasts me till 85 years. Will there be a change in the amount of CPF that I can use to pay for my mortgage?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There will be no change to the amount of CPF that you can use to pay for your mortgage for your existing property as the changes will apply only to properties purchased from 10 May 2019.

Knowledge Article: Question: I cannot remember if I had instructed that I want/ don't want to claim tax relief for my cash top-ups to my spouse or sibling in my application. How can I check?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may check your past top-up applications by logging in to the CPF website and checking under “my cpf” > “Activities”.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will interests and penalties be imposed on my outstanding premiums if my GIRO application was submitted before the deadline on Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore's (IRAS) notice?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Interest and penalties will not be imposed on your outstanding MediShield Life premiums if CPFB receives your GIRO application before the due date stated in IRAS' notice.

Knowledge Article: Question: If my late parent(s) had used their CPF savings for their property, do I need to refund the CPF savings used by them upon disposal of the property?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, you do not have to refund the CPF savings used by your late parent(s) and the accrued interest to their CPF accounts upon disposal of their property.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the obligations that my ex-spouse assumes when my investments are transferred to them under the division of CPF savings in a divorce?
Knowledge Article: Answer: When your investments are transferred to your ex-spouse, they will be subjected to the CPF Investment Scheme rules (e.g. investments are subject to stock and gold limits, types of investments CPF savings could be used) so as to ensure their own retirement adequacy.   If your ex-spouse sells the transferred investments, the sale proceeds will be credited to their Ordinary and, or Special Accounts, where applicable. The amount will be subject to CPF rules and can only be withdrawn when they meet the withdrawal conditions under Section 15 of the CPF Act.   Your ex-spouse will have to pay bank charges for the transferred investments that they continue to hold in their Investment Account. Such charges can be paid using their Ordinary Account savings.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens if I don't have sufficient funds in my GIRO account for MediShield Life and/or CareShield Life premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you do not have sufficient funds in your GIRO account for MediShield Life and/or CareShield Life premiums, the GIRO deduction will be unsuccessful and a second GIRO deduction attempt is generally scheduled on the 15 th of the next month for two months’ instalments.   The GIRO payment plan will be suspended if there are two consecutive unsuccessful deductions. Interest and penalties may be imposed on your outstanding premiums and re-activation of the GIRO plan will be assessed on a case-by-case basis.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can CPF EZPay calculate the CPF contributions for Singapore Permanent Residents (SPRs)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF EZPay is able to calculate CPF contributions for SPRs. You will need to key in the SPR Start Date and select the Type (e.g. GG - Graduated or FG - full CPF contributions rates). This will allow CPF EZPay to track the SPR status of your employee and auto-update the CPF contribution to be paid (e.g. from SPR Year 1 to Year 2 or Year 2 to year 3).

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the criteria to be fulfilled by my ex-spouse before my investments can be transferred to them under the division of CPF savings in a divorce? What are the options if my ex-spouse cannot fulfill the criteria?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Before your investments can be transferred to your ex-spouse, they must be a CPF member who is Singaporean or Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR) and 18 years old and above. If your ex-spouse is below 18 years old, they can consider requesting the Court to order your investments to be liquidated and the sale proceeds to be transferred to their CPF accounts.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why do I need to have lease coverage until age 95 for maximum CPF usage?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The required lease coverage of at least 95 years recognises the increasing life expectancy of Singaporeans.   Nevertheless, if the remaining lease of the property does not cover the youngest co-owner until the age of 95, you can still use your CPF savings at a pro-rated amount.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is ElderShield?
Knowledge Article: Answer: ElderShield was first launched by the Ministry of Health in September 2002 as a severe disability insurance scheme which provides basic financial protection to those who need long-term care especially in their old age. It provides a monthly cash payout for up to 72 months to help pay out-of-pocket expenses in the event of severe disability.   ElderShield was offered to eligible Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents (PRs) who had a MediSave Account when they turned 40 years old in 2019 or earlier.   For more FAQs on ElderShield, please visit the CareShield Life website

Knowledge Article: Question: I have an ongoing GIRO payment plan. My MediShield Life and/or CareShield Life cover has been renewed and has incurred new outstanding premiums. Will interest be imposed on me?
Knowledge Article: Answer: New interest will not be imposed on the outstanding MediShield Life and/or CareShield Life premiums under your ongoing GIRO payment plan. Your existing GIRO payment plan will be auto-renewed to include the new outstanding premiums. You will be notified of the revised instalment to be paid.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why did the Government review the rules on CPF usage for purchase of residential properties with shorter leases?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The rules on CPF usage for purchase of residential properties with shorter leases were updated to meet the changing needs and higher life expectancy of Singaporeans. Instead of focusing on the remaining lease of the property, the rules focuses on whether the remaining lease of the property can cover the youngest buyer until age 95.   This change gives Singaporeans greater flexibility to purchase a home that can last for life, while ensuring that their retirement adequacy is protected.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am in the midst of finalising my property transaction. How do I know if I fall under the old rules or the new rules?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The new rules will apply to you if:      - For HDB flats: Your date of application on the HDB website is from 10 May 2019.    - For private properties: Your Option to Purchase or Sale & Purchase Agreement (in the absence of an Option to Purchase) exercised date is from 10 May 2019.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens if my GIRO application is rejected or the GIRO deductions are suspended for MediShield Life and/or CareShield Life premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We will impose new interest and penalties on your outstanding MediShield Life and/or CareShield Life premiums if your GIRO application is rejected or GIRO deductions are suspended.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will I receive hospitalisation subsidies if I choose A ward type in public hospital or choose to go to a private hospital?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will not receive any hospitalisation subsidy in an A ward type in a public hospital or at a private hospital. Hence, if you are inclined to stay in an A ward in a public hospital or go to a private hospital for treatment, you should consider an Integrated Shield Plan (IP) that covers the cost for the particular ward/hospital type.

Knowledge Article: Question: I made a top-up to my MediSave for payment of CareShield Life premium. Has the top-up been credited?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may view the top-up you made to your MediSave via Transaction History at cpf.gov.sg (Singpass login is required).

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need a private Integrated Shield Plan (IP)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: All Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents are covered under MediShield Life no matter how long you live, regardless of age or health condition. MediShield Life helps to pay for large hospital bills and selected costly outpatient treatments such as dialysis and chemotherapy for cancer. It is sized for subsidised treatment in B2/C wards of the public hospitals.   You do not need an Integrated Shield Plan (IP) if you plan to stay in B2/C wards in public hospitals which are heavily subsidised. In fact, majority of Singaporeans, even those who had bought IP, chose to stay in B2/C wards. In particular, eight in 10 seniors choose B2/C wards when they are hospitalised.   If you buy an IP but choose to stay in B2/C wards in public hospitals, you might want to reconsider whether you should pay for additional private insurance.   However, if you are firm in choosing B1/A wards in public hospitals or seeking treatment at private hospitals, you can consider getting an IP that matches your ward preference. If so, you should be prepared to pay additional premiums for the additional coverage.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to apply for MediShield Life?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents are automatically covered under MediShield Life. No application is required.   You will receive a cover issuance or renewal notification about one month before the start or renewal of your MediShield Life cover. The notification will inform you of your MediShield Life premiums and subsidies. If you have children under 21 years old, you will receive their MediShield Life notifications.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is the minimum lease period set at 20 years? Why am I not allowed to use my CPF savings to buy a property with a lease of less than 20 years when it can last me till 95?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We recognise that the previous minimum lease period (MLP) of 30 years for CPF usage contributed to anxieties on the saleability of older properties and have lowered this to 20 years. This is the same as the MLP for obtaining a HDB loan. There will still be a MLP of 20 years to ensure prudent use of CPF savings. Nevertheless, most properties today are still young and far away from this MLP of 20 years.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will my MediSave Care withdrawal limit automatically change as and when my MediSave balance changes?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The eligible withdrawal quantum for MediSave Care is based on the MediSave balance at the point of withdrawal, if the individual has authorised to withdraw the maximum quantum. The table below shows the MediSave balances and corresponding monthly withdrawal quanta.   MediSave Balance Monthly Withdrawal Quantum $20,000 and above $200 $15,000 and above $150 $10,000 and above $100 $5,000 and above $50 Below $5,000 Nil   For more FAQs on MediSave Care, please visit the  CareShield Life website .

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I avoid falling prey to malware scams?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can take the following actions which were mentioned in the Joint Advisory by CPF Board, GovTech and the Singapore Police , to protect yourself against malware-related scam:   Only download applications from official app stores to avoid malware being installed, especially for android users; Exercise the greatest of caution when turning on the phone’s accessibility services or allowing access as doing so will weaken the security of the phone; Always expeditiously update the mobile phone with the latest security patches. For more information, visit www.scamalert.sg or call the Anti-Scam Helpline at 1800-722-6688.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I change the payer for my/my dependants' Integrated Shield Plan (IP) premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As your Integrated Shield Plan is administered by the private insurer you have chosen to cover you, please approach your insurer (PDF, 0.4MB) directly to make the change.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I change or reset my Singpass password online?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To change or reset your Singpass password, please complete the following steps: Visit Singpass website Select 'Log in' Select ‘Reset password’ (under the ‘Services’ tab) Follow the instructions on the website to complete the changing or resetting of Singpass password If you require further assistance, please contact the Singpass Helpdesk directly.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I did not apply to use my CPF savings when buying my HDB flat, can I now use my CPF savings for monthly instalments?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you can use your CPF savings for the monthly instalment of your HDB flat. Since this is the first time that you are utilising your CPF savings for your HDB flat, we will need you to provide further information and documents related to your housing loan, such as details of your financier details and outstanding housing loan amount. To submit your request, please use this Application Form .

Knowledge Article: Question: I am an Integrated Shield Plan (IP) policyholder. Am I eligible for MediShield Life Premium Subsidies or Additional Premium Support (APS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Integrated Shield Plan (IP) policyholders will be able to receive MediShield Life premium subsidies if they meet the eligibility criteria. However, they are not eligible for Additional Premium Support (APS), as APS is targeted at those with financial difficulties. Should you have difficulty paying your premiums, you may wish to consider terminating your IP and applying for APS.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens if I do not pay my Integrated Shield Plan (IP) premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you do not pay your Integrated Shield Plan (IP) premiums within your insurer’s stipulated Grace Period, your insurer will terminate your IP coverage and you would lose the additional private insurance coverage. However, you would continue to be covered under MediShield Life and pay the lower MediShield Life premiums. You may wish to refer to your IP policy contract for details on the Grace Period.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is our CPF usage capped based on the youngest co-owner's age? When the youngest co-owner relinquishes ownership of the flat, will our CPF usage limit increase?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF usage is capped based on the age of the youngest co-owner that purchased the property using his/her CPF. This encourages families to buy properties with sufficient lease to cover all co-owners for life.   If the youngest co-owner decides to relinquish his or her ownership of the flat, we will update the CPF usage limit based on the age of the next youngest co-owner and will send a written notification to all co-owners.

Knowledge Article: Question: My family members are covered with free Integrated Shield Plan (IPs) provided by a private insurer. Do I still need to pay MediShield Life premiums for them?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your family members are covered with free Integrated Shield Plans (IPs), please check directly with your insurer (PDF, 0.4MB) who is administering the IPs if you still need to pay MediShield Life premiums for them.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long does it take to process the application for withdrawal of my CPF savings and for the monies to be paid to my bank account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The service standards to process your withdrawal application are stated in the table below:   Service Normal processing time Withdrawal of CPF savings for immediate needs PayNow NRIC-linked bank account: Once you have updated your registered bank account with CPF Board to your PayNow NRIC-linked bank account via Account settings and completed the 12-hour cooling period, the payment is generally immediate upon the submission of your withdrawal application Other bank accounts: Generally up to five working days after date of submission Withdrawal of Retirement Account savings with HDB/private property pledge Generally up to seven working days after date of submission/charge has been lodged   Members whose applications require additional verification checks (e.g. members with outstanding tax liabilities and/or pending information from our service partners) will have longer processing time and will not be able to withdraw their CPF savings via PayNow.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is there a limit to the number of family members that I can help pay Integrated Shield Plan (IP) premiums using my MediSave?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There is no limit to the number of family members you can use your MediSave to pay for Integrated Shield Plan (IP) premiums. However, you should consider the long-term affordability of IP premiums for your family members and whether you will have enough MediSave savings for your own medical needs especially during your retirement years.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable for seaman?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable for a master, a seaman or an apprentice in any vessel if he is a citizen of Singapore and employed under a contract of service or other agreement entered into in Singapore. However, CPF contributions are exempted for a seaman who is a Singapore Citizen and is employed: in a Swedish ship on terms and conditions of service applicable to Swedish seamen; or in a Norwegian ship on terms and conditions of service applicable to Norwegian seamen; or by the East Asiatic Co. Ltd. of Denmark on terms and conditions of the agreement between the Danish Shipowners’ Association and the Seamen’s Union in Denmark. CPF contributions are not payable for a seaman who is a permanent resident of Singapore.

Knowledge Article: Question: What will happen if I have insufficient MediSave to pay for my Integrated Shield Plan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your insurer will notify you of the outstanding amount payable for your Integrated Shield Plan and advise you how to make payment to the insurer. Please contact your insurer if you require further assistance.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable by the holding company or the subsidiary company if the employee is seconded from the former to latter?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The employer who had entered into an employment contract with the employee is required to pay the CPF contributions.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I check the amount to be refunded to my CPF account upon the sale of my property?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can check the amount to be refunded to your CPF account after selling your property by accessing your  Home ownership dashboard  on the CPF website.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable for Limited Liability Partners (LLP)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable for partners of Limited Liability Partners (LLP) who are employed under a contract of service .

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my MediSave to purchase an Integrated Shield Plan (IP) for my family member who is a foreigner?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Integrated Shield Plan (IP) coverage for Singaporeans and Permanent Residents include the MediShield Life (MSL) component. You can use your MediSave to purchase a similar non-integrated healthcare plan for your foreign dependent. However, such plans for foreigners will not have the MSL component. Please approach your insurer to advise on the plans offered.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable by the holding company or the subsidiary company if my employee is seconded from the holding company to the subsidiary company?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The employer who had entered into an employment contract with the employee is required to pay the CPF contributions.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I have to pay Additional Premium (AP) for pre-existing conditions if I have an Integrated Shield Plan (IP), and would these conditions be covered after AP is paid?
Knowledge Article: Answer: An Integrated Shield Plan (IP) comprises two parts, namely the MediShield Life (MSL) and the additional private insurance component. MSL is sized for B2/C wards at Government hospitals, while the additional private insurance is sized for A/B1 wards at Government hospitals and private hospitals.   The 30% Additional Premium (AP) for serious pre-existing medical conditions is only applicable to the MSL component of your IP premiums.   For the additional private insurance coverage component, it will be separately assessed by your IP insurer. Generally, private insurers exclude pre-existing medical conditions from their coverage. You should contact your IP insurer (PDF, 0.4MB) to find out more.

Knowledge Article: Question: As I am covered under an Integrated Shield Plan (IP), why are there two transactions made in my Yearly CPF Statement of Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: An Integrated Shield Plan (IP) is made up of two components, namely:   1.   The MediShield Life component – reflected as MSL, and   2.   The additional private medical insurance component – reflected as PMI.   Hence, there would be two transactions reflected for any deduction/refund of IP.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to inform the Board to terminate the housing monthly instalment from my CPF account if my housing loan is fully paid by the Home Protection Scheme claim?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You do not need to do anything. If your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) sum assured has fully paid off your outstanding home loan, CPF Board will work with your mortgage provider to stop deducting money from the CPF accounts of all the joint-owner(s).

Knowledge Article: Question: I have received a call claiming to be from MediShield Life. What should I do if this is a scam and my contact details are shared with external agencies?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The MediShield Life Team does not contact members to request sensitive personal information or engage any external agencies to call members on MediShield Life matters. The MediShield Life Team will not disclose members’ contact details to external agencies without members’ consent.   If you receive an unexpected phone call from someone who claims to be from the MediShield Life Team, please be vigilant and do not provide your sensitive personal information (E.g. Singpass ID/password, bank account or credit card details). When in doubt, you may end the conversation with the individual and check with the organisation which the caller claims to represent directly. To verify the authenticity of such calls, you can call us directly at 1800 222 3399 or  write to us .

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is the MediShield Life claim limit for a particular combination treatment not the sum of all the claim limits for individual drugs in that combination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If a particular combination treatment is cost-effective, the MediShield Life (MSHL) claim limit is sized to be sufficient to cover the post-subsidy cost of the entire combination in Public Healthcare Institutions (PHIs). In some cases, the claim limit for the entire combination is the same as the highest-cost drug in that combination because the cost of the other drugs in the PHIs are low and can therefore be adequately covered by the same claim limit.   If a particular combination treatment is not cost-effective, the MSHL claim limit is pegged to the highest individual claim limit of the drugs in the combination. Doctors and patients are encouraged to use treatments that have been assessed to be cost-effective, for which MSHL claim limits have been sized for.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why was the payment for my Integrated Shield Plan (IP) / MediShield Life (MSL) unsuccessful even though there are sufficient funds in my MediSave Account (MA)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The funds in your MediSave Account (MA) may be reserved for other healthcare payments, such as ElderShield/CareShield Life premiums, hospitalisation bills, or premium payments for your dependents’ healthcare policies. These may have resulted in insufficient funds in your MA to pay for your Integrated Shield Plan / MediShield Life.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I have to submit employment information for Home Protection Scheme claim?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, for claims under Home Protection Scheme, you are required to inform your employer to fill in this form as we require your employment information. The employment information will allow CPFB to accurately determine your claim event date and amount of claim benefits. Your employer would require a Corppass to login.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I check the status of my Home Protection Scheme claim application on terminal illness or total permanent disability?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To check the status of your Home Protection Scheme claim application on terminal illness or total permanent disability, you can login to CPF website, click on ‘my CPF’, followed by ‘ Activities ’.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have recently bought an Integrated Shield Plan (IP). Why was there more than one deduction made from my MediSave Account (MA) this year?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The first deduction from your MediSave Account (MA) was for the renewal of your MediShield Life (MSL) coverage, which is mandatory for all Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents. When you buy an Integrated Shield Plan (IP), there would be another premium deduction for the additional private coverage component. There will be a pro-rated refund of the MSL premiums for the remaining unused MSL policy year.   For example, your MSL coverage period was 01 January 2020 to 31 December 2020 and the annual MSL premium of $435 was deducted in January. You subsequently purchased an IP in February 2020 with an annual premium of $600. After you purchase the IP, the unused premium from your MSL coverage of $398.75, would be refunded back to your MA.   *PMI  = Private Medical Insurance/Additional private insurance coverage portion of an Integrated Shield Plan

Knowledge Article: Question: Will the other eligibility criteria for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme be changed from 2025?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, there are no changes to the other eligibility criteria.   You will be eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme (MRSS) in 2025 if you are a Singapore Citizen and meet the following criteria. Age 55 or above as of 31 st December 2025. Retirement Account (RA) Savings* Less than $106,500^. Average Monthly Income Not more than $4,000. This covers a majority of senior workers. Annual Value of Residence ?Not more than $21,000. Property Ownership Own not more than one property.   * RA savings refer to the cash set aside in the RA (excluding amounts such as interest earned, any government grants received), plus retirement withdrawals. If you are turning 55 in the assessment year and your RA has not been created at the time we assess your eligibility, your total Special Account and Ordinary Account savings will be assessed instead. ^ Basic Retirement Sum for 2025. Find out  how you can check your eligibility for the MRSS .

Knowledge Article: Question: Who will receive the claim benefits under the Home Protection Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: When a claim is made under the Home Protection Scheme (HPS), the benefits will be paid to the Housing & Development Board or the mortgagee directly, to settle the outstanding housing loan, up to the insured sum.   If the claim is admitted under death ground, the HPS claim benefits will be paid in a lump sum.   If the claim is admitted under medical ground, the member’s housing instalments (based on the share of HPS cover) may be paid by HPS for up to two years before a review of the member’s eligibility to claim the remaining insured sum in full is carried out.   If the HPS sum assured is more than the outstanding loan, the excess amount will be paid to the insured member’s CPF Ordinary Account.   You may find out more on what happens to the CPF savings for deceased members .

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I recover the employee's share of CPF contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As an employer, you need to pay both the employer’s and employee’s share of CPF contributions to CPF Board. You are entitled to recover the employee’s share of CPF contributions when paying your employee’s wages for the month. For example, the employee’s share of CPF contributions for January can only be deducted from the employee’s wages in January. It is a serious offence to recover or attempt to recover any amount more than what is allowed from your employee’s wages. If you failed to recover the employee’s share of CPF contributions due to your error (e.g. system glitch, omission of CPF contributions due to employer's oversight, wrong computation of employee's share) before paying your employee’s wages for the month, you cannot recover the employee’s share of CPF contributions from subsequent months’ wages. However, if the failure to do so was not due to your error, you must do the following before you can recover the employee’s share of CPF contributions from wages payable by you to your employee:   you have paid the CPF contributions to the Board, and you have either forwarded your employee’s written consent to CPF Board, or obtained CPF Board’s written permission on the matter. This must be done within six months from the time the employee’s share of CPF contributions should have been recovered.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will I know the amount of premiums that I need to pay for my/ my dependents' Integrated Shield Plan (IP)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your insurer administering the Integrated Shield Plan (IP) will notify you of your premium details before your policy is renewed. You can log into your insurer's web portal to check your IP premium amount or approach your insurer (PDF, 0.4MB) directly for further clarifications.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the benefits of contributing to MediSave by GIRO?
Knowledge Article: Answer: GIRO allows you to contribute to your MediSave Account over a period of 12 monthly instalments. It is most convenient as the contributions are automatically deducted from your bank account and you can easily monitor them. Contributing to MediSave by GIRO also provides a hassle-free licence application and renewal process.   You may apply to pay via GIRO online ( list of participating banks ) or by mail (for other banks).   Payment mode Details GIRO Using  my cpf digital services ( list of participating banks ) Log in with your Singpass. Submit the Set up GIRO for MediSave contributions  application. Check the status of your GIRO application via Activities. Mail (for other banks) Download and complete the  Apply for GIRO for MediSave Contributions  form (FORM SE GIRO (PDF, 0.6MB)).             Mail it to the address printed overleaf of the GIRO application form. We will notify you of your GIRO application status once the bank has processed it.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable for students?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable for students who are employed under a  contract of service and are Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents earning total wages of more than $50 per month. CPF contributions are exempted on wages (e.g. allowances, bonus, overtime pay) payable to certain classes of student employees. Find out more about who you need to pay CPF contributions for (PDF, 0.2MB) under the header “Students”.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much Retirement Account savings do I need for my desired CPF LIFE monthly payout?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can easily use the Monthly payout estimator to estimate the amount of Retirement Account savings you need, based on your desired monthly payout and choice of payout start age.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to my Retirement Account savings when I join CPF LIFE?
Knowledge Article: Answer: It is dependent on the CPF LIFE plan you choose. If you opt for the Escalating or Standard Plan, all your Retirement Account (RA) savings will be used as your CPF LIFE premium.   If you opt for the Basic Plan, about 80-90% of your RA savings will be directly used to provide payouts until age 90. The remaining 10-20% will be deducted as your CPF LIFE premium when you join CPF LIFE and used to provide payouts from age 90 for the rest of your life. As less is used for your CPF LIFE premium, the monthly payout will be lower compared to the Standard Plan. The Basic plan payouts will also decrease correspondingly as your balances are withdrawn over time to provide you with monthly payouts and earn less extra interest*.   * The extra interest is earned on the first $60,000 of your CPF balances and is used to increase your payouts.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable for my employee during his overseas training?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable during overseas training if your employee is employed in Singapore but is required to go overseas for the training period.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have not joined CPF LIFE yet. How can I increase my future monthly payouts?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There are a few ways to increase your future CPF LIFE monthly payouts:   Topping up your Retirement Account (RA) under the Retirement Sum Topping-up Scheme You or your loved ones can make cash top-ups and CPF transfers to your RA up to the current Enhanced Retirement Sum by logging in with your Singpass at  cpf.gov.sg/rstuform . The more RA savings you use to join CPF LIFE, the higher your monthly payouts. Deferring your monthly payouts (up to 70) Consider deferring your payouts if you are still working or have other income. Your monthly payouts will increase by up to 7% for each year that you defer. If you choose to defer until 70, you could get up to a 35% increase in payouts as your CPF savings would have accumulated more interest. You will only need to decide your CPF LIFE plan when you wish to start your payouts. The latest age you can start your payouts is 70, after which they will automatically begin. Monetising your property If you own a property, you can also consider monetising your property . You can use the  Monthly payout estimator  to find out how much RA savings you need, or the age you need to start your payouts to get your desired monthly payout.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable for employees of General Conference Corporation of Seventh-Day Adventists?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are exempted for employees who are employed by the General Conference Corporation of Seventh-Day Adventists under a contract of service or other agreement entered into outside Singapore and who are not domiciled in Singapore.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable for my employee who is seconded or posted to work overseas?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are not payable for your employee who is seconded or posted to work overseas as wages given in respect of overseas employment do not attract CPF contributions.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable for my employee who is on no pay leave?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on the total wages earned by your employee in each calendar month, less any no pay leave he has taken in that month.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on Restrictive Covenant payment?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are not payable on Restrictive Covenant payment given to your employee to comply with specific contractual obligations after he has left your employment, e.g. to restrain him from entering into an employment with another company in the same industry or to join your competitors after he left your employment.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I get the letter from Immigration & Checkpoints Authority confirming the cancellation of my Singapore Permanent Residency?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To obtain the letter from Immigrations & Checkpoints Authority (ICA) confirming the cancellation of your Singapore Permanent Residency, you may submit your request via ICA | Feedback .   *If you are a Malaysian, you are not required to obtain the letter from ICA.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable for Operationally Ready National Servicemen (NSmen) during NS training?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Under the Enlistment Act, CPF contributions are payable for your employees who are Operationally Ready National Servicemen (NSmen) during their NS training, based on their usual civilian income. You have to pay CPF contributions based on the total wages typically payable to them in each calendar month, as though as they are not away for NS training. Besides basic salary and fixed allowance components of your employee’s wages, the variable allowances (e.g. overtime pay and allowances) typically paid to the NSman on a monthly basis would also attract CPF contributions. You have to bear the full employer's share of CPF contribution, and you are entitled to recover the full employee's share from their wages.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I declare my annual net trade income online as a self-employed person?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For Work Year 2023 (WY2023) onwards All Net Trade Income (NTI) declarations for Work Year 2023 (Year of Assessment 2024) can be made with the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) by filing a tax return. There is no need to file separate declarations with CPF Board.   If you receive a notification (via letter/form/SMS) to file tax from IRAS or you meet the requirement to file tax (i.e. NTI above $6,000 and/or Total Income above $22,000), please complete and submit the tax return to IRAS directly. The income tax filing period is from 1 March to 18 April annually.   If you do not receive a notification from IRAS or do not meet the requirement to file tax, you can declare your self-employed net trade income (NTI) to IRAS via myTax Portal which will be available from 1 March to 31 October annually for taxpayers to e-File tax returns.   Once IRAS has assessed your income for the year, your assessed NTI will be transmitted to the Board. You can check your updated NTI records by logging in to the Self-employment dashboard with your Singpass.   For Work Year 2022 (WY2022) or earlier If you were not issued a Notice of Assessment (NOA) by IRAS and wish to declare NTI for work years prior to 2023, you can write to us using your Singpass.   If you have declared your NTI with IRAS, you need not declare your income again to CPF Board.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable for my employee who went on absence without leave (AWOL)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contribution are not payable if your employee is not entitled to any wages during the period he was absent without leave (AWOL). CPF contributions are payable on the total wages given to him in that calendar month if he had worked certain days before AWOL.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will I be able to return to Singapore for work if I have closed my CPF account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For enquiries on work permit or employment pass application, please contact Ministry of Manpower at 6438 5122 or send your enquiries to them using the  online feedback service .   For enquiries on applying for Permanent Residency in Singapore, please contact the Immigration & Checkpoints Authority at 6391 6100 or email them .

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable for Shatec students engaged in trainings approved by Shatec Institutes?
Knowledge Article: Answer: With effect from 1 March 2018, CPF contributions are payable for Shatec students employed under a contract of service .

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable for part-time, casual or temporary employees?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable for part-time, casual or temporary employees who are: Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents, Engaged under a contract of service , and Earning total wages of more than $50 per month.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable for my employee who is seconded or transferred from overseas to work in Singapore?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable for your employee who is a citizen or permanent resident of Singapore if he is working in Singapore and earning total wages of more than $50 a month.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on financial assistance given to my employee?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on cash payments given to assist your employees who are facing financial difficulties.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on retention cash incentive given to my employee to encourage him to continue his employment with me?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on cash incentive given to your employee for retention of your employee's employment.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to my CPF savings if I have an outstanding CPF education loan when my account is closed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have used another CPF member’s CPF savings for your education and have an outstanding CPF education loan owed to him, your CPF savings may be used to pay the education loan before the remaining CPF savings are transferred to your bank account. In the event that your CPF savings are not sufficient to cover your full education loan, your repayment liability remains even after your CPF account is closed.   If you  have used your  CPF savings for your education or your child/spouse/siblings/relative’s education , the repayment of all such outstanding CPF Education Loans to you will be waived.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I switch to a lower Integrated Shield Plan (IP) / terminate my existing IP?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can instruct your private insurer (PDF, 0.4MB) to assist you in switching or terminating your Integrated Shield Plan (IP). You will continue to be covered under MediShield Life.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on cash payments given to my employee if they are not paid through the payroll system?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on wages given to your employee and not payable on non-wages, e.g. reimbursements incurred for official purposes. The CPF treatment is the same regardless whether they are paid through the payroll system.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on cash payment given to your employee for self-improvement courses?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on cash payment given to your employee for self-improvement courses.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I nominate part of my CPF balances under the Special Needs Savings Scheme, while nominating the rest under the CPF cash nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes. You can decide the percentage of your CPF balances to be nominated under the Special Needs Savings Scheme, and the remaining CPF savings to be nominated under the cash nomination rules for other beneficiaries.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I know if I/my dependants are covered under MediShield Life (MSL) or Integrated Shield Plan (IP)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can log in to your Healthcare dashboard to view your/your dependants’ MediShield Life or Integrated Shield Plan coverage information. The information is available under “Health insurance – Coverage and premiums details”.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I consider when I purchase or review my Integrated Shield Plan (IP) coverage with my insurer?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Buying and maintaining an Integrated Shield Plan (IP) is a significant lifetime financial commitment. The degree of protection you need evolves and changes with your circumstances and age. As you reach your retirement years, your earning power is likely to reduce while your premiums will rise sharply and your priorities may shift. Depending on your hospital/ ward preferences, you may not want to pay additional premiums for an IP. You should consider the following carefully:   Are you likely to choose to seek treatment or be hospitalised at a public or private hospital? If you intend to go to a public hospital, will you choose a B2/C ward (six to eight beds) or Standard B1 ward (four beds) or A ward (single bed), taking into account affordability? If you intend to stay in B2/C wards, you need not buy an IP. This is because MediShield Life is generally sufficient as payouts are pegged to B2/C wards after government subsidies. The deductible and co-insurance can be paid via MediSave, as well as any remaining co-payment subject to the MediSave withdrawal limits. If you prefer to go to a private hospital, assess your means and ability to pay the additional premiums throughout your lifetime . Your annual premiums will increase sharply with age, which means that your premiums will be much higher in your retirement years. Based on the median premiums for each IP plan type, you can potentially save a significant sum. You may also refer to the checklist   when reviewing your IP coverage.   Did You Know? Your private medical insurance premiums could be ~5 times of your MediShield Life premiums for someone in their 70/80s. Click this link to find out more.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on payments given to my employee for his involvements in ad-hoc projects?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable for all payments given to your employee in respect of his employment, i.e. for his services or work done.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on cash awards?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on any cash awards given to your employee that are given in respect of employee’s employment. Some examples are:   Best Employee Award Commendation Award Good Customer Service Award Good Quality Service Award Innovation Award Outstanding Performance Award Productivity Award If the award given is not related to the employee’s employment, CPF contributions are not payable. For example, a patent award is given to the winner of a design competition and the competition is not related to employee’s employment.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I disable my online CPF withdrawal?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can activate the CPF Withdrawal Lock to instantly disable your online CPF withdrawal. This activation sets the Daily Withdrawal Limit to $0. Please refer to the  three simple steps to activate the CPF Withdrawal Lock.

Knowledge Article: Question: Which CPF account would the premium be refunded to if my family member has used their CPF savings to pay for my Home Protection Scheme premium?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your family member (that is your spouse, parent, child or sibling) has used their CPF Ordinary Account (OA) savings for your Home Protection Scheme premium, any premium refund will be paid into your OA.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I pay my Home Protection Scheme premium by instalments?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Home Protection Scheme premiums cannot be paid by instalments. The premium is structured to be paid yearly so that the scheme remains viable and the premiums kept affordable for all insured members.   You can find out more on the  available payment options .   Alternatively, please  write to us if you need more time to make your premium payment.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is OCBC Digital?
Knowledge Article: Answer: OCBC Digital is a payment mobile app to allow OCBC customers to transfer funds and receive funds, as well as make payment to organisations. For more information, do visit OCBC Digital.

Knowledge Article: Question: What if I do not have enough savings in my CPF Ordinary Account to pay the annual premium for Home Protection Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you do not have enough savings in your CPF Ordinary Account (OA) to pay the Home Protection Scheme (HPS) premium, we will notify you to make a cash top-up to your OA.   You will have a grace period of two months to pay the premium for your HPS policy. If you are still unable to pay the premium by the end of the grace period, your HPS cover will end.   You can pay your HPS premium shortfall via the following means: PayNow at CPF website , or Cash at any Singapore Post branch offices You may wish to note that the HPS premium top-up, which is credited to your OA, is considered a voluntary contribution and is subject to the prevailing CPF Annual Limit .   If you have incoming working contributions that will be credited into your OA within the grace period and can cover your premium shortfall, you may choose not to take any action. We will deduct the shortfall from your new working contributions.   Alternatively, your family member (that is your spouse, parent, child or sibling) who co-owns the flat with you can authorise us to use their CPF OA savings to pay your HPS premium online using their Singpass.   Please note that your HPS cover will end if we are unable to deduct the premium by the end of the grace period.

Knowledge Article: Question: When will the matched MediSave contributions be paid?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The matched MediSave contributions will be paid in four tranches, based on the following schedule:   Tranche Based on Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions made between To be paid in 1 1 January 2020 and 30 June 2020* 3 rd quarter 2020 2 1 July 2020 and 31 December 2020* 1 st quarter 2021 3 1 January 2021 and 30 June 2021* 3 rd quarter 2021 4 1 July 2021 and 30 December 2021* 1 st quarter 2022 * Both dates inclusive CPF Board will notify the eligible self-employed persons of the payment via a notification. If you wish to update your contact details, you can do so via logging on to my cpf digital services using your Singpass.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens if the MediSave contributions I made via Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) are higher than my MediSave payable for the year?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have outstanding MediSave payable from previous years, your excess CAYE contributions will be used to offset those payables 1 . Any excess thereafter will be refunded to you. You can also choose to retain the excess CAYE contributions in your MediSave Account (MA).   Example: Based on his estimated income of $22,000 for 2023, Sam contributed $2,200 via CAYE. In the following year, he declared that he earned a lower Net Trade Income of $19,000 for 2023. As such, Sam’s MediSave payable for his work done in 2023 is $1,900. Hence, he has excess CAYE contributions of $300 for the year. Sam also has an outstanding MediSave payable of $100 incurred in 2022 which would be offset by the excess CAYE contributions, leaving a final excess amount of $200. This amount will be refunded to him 2 . He can also choose to keep this $200 in his MA. This example is illustrated within the table below:   Estimated 2023 NTI $22,000 CAYE contributions in 2023 $2,200 (After 2023 NTI declaration)   Declared 2023 NTI $19,000 MediSave payable for work done in 2023 $1,900 Outstanding MediSave payable for 2022 $100 Amount Sam will receive as a refund $200 (i.e. $2,200 - $1,900 - $100)   1 This will take effect for CAYE contributions made from 2023. Please write to us if you do not wish to use your CAYE contributions to offset your outstanding MediSave payable from previous years. 2 Sam may also choose not to use his CAYE contributions to offset his outstanding MediSave payable of $100 incurred in 2022. In this case, he will be refunded $300 instead.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can Muslims nominate a non-Faraid heir to receive their CPF savings after they pass?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes. According to a fatwa by the Islamic Religious Council of Singapore (Muis), CPF nomination is a valid form of hibah (gift). You may thus nominate whoever you wish, non-Faraid heirs or even legal institutions for charitable purposes.   Learn more about nominating legal institutions here .

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is the Home Protection Scheme premium not refundable if I did not make a claim?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Home Protection Scheme (HPS) premiums paid for past policy years are not refundable. This is because you have received insurance protection during the period of cover and would have been eligible to receive the HPS benefits in the event of a claim.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I insure my dependent under Integrated Shield Plan (IP), but insure myself under MediShield Life and vice-versa?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you can choose to cover yourself under MediShield Life and get Integrated Shield Plan (IP) from different private insurers for your dependents, or vice versa.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am paying the Integrated Shield Plan (IP) premiums for my dependants. Why is this information not reflected on my Yearly CPF Statement of Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your dependants’ details would not be reflected if you are not using your MediSave to pay for their Integrated Shield Plan (IP) premiums. However, you can log in to your Healthcare dashboard to view your dependants’ coverage information. The information is available under “Health insurance - Coverage and premiums details”.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I check my withdrawable amount?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can check the amount you can withdraw by logging in to your Retirement dashboard .

Knowledge Article: Question: How is the application process for refund and adjustment of CPF contributions improved?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will only need to complete a single form to apply for a refund or adjustment of CPF contributions paid instead of having to look through multiple forms.   It is important to rectify any errors in CPF contributions early while the documentary evidence is fresh. Please apply immediately and no later than one year from the payment date.   In the past You need to identify the correct form to submit your request. Now There is only one form to use and submit your refund/adjustment request. 1. Application for Adjustment of CPF Payment Refund and adjustment of contributions paid 2. Refund of Excess Contributions above the Additional Wage Ceiling and/or Voluntary Contribution Limit 3. Refund of CPF Contributions Paid (Ministry/Statutory Board) 4. Refund of CPF Contributions Paid

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I pay the Home Protection Scheme premium?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Home Protection Scheme (HPS) premium is automatically deducted from your CPF Ordinary Account (OA) annually.   You can check and view the deduction from your CPF account  online using your Singpass. The deduction will also be reflected in your Yearly Statement of Account.   If your OA balance is not enough to pay the premium, you will be notified to top up your OA within a grace period of two months. If you have incoming working contributions that will be credited into your OA within the grace period and can cover your premium shortfall, you may choose not to take any action. We will deduct the shortfall from your new working contributions.   Alternatively, your family member, who is your spouse, parent, child, or sibling, who co-owns the flat with you can authorise the use of their OA savings to pay your premium shortfall.

Knowledge Article: Question: My nominees have changed their personal particulars (e.g. names, addresses or passport numbers). Do I need to update the changes in my CPF nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your nominee is a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident   You do not need to update the changes in your CPF nomination.   For name changes, the Board will request your nominee to present document(s) e.g. Deed Poll, as proof of their name change when they apply to withdraw the CPF monies after your demise.   If your nominee is a foreigner   You should make a new CPF nomination with their latest particulars. This will help us identify and contact your nominee easily to distribute your CPF savings.

Knowledge Article: Question: How is the Home Protection Scheme premium calculated?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Home Protection Scheme charges a level premium rate (i.e. same amount annually throughout the policy term) and is calculated based on several factors:   Outstanding housing loan on the flat* Loan repayment period Type of loan (HDB concessionary or market rate) Age and gender Percentage share of cover of the outstanding housing loan *The computation of the level premium takes into account the monthly reduction in the housing loan.   Premiums are generally higher for greater share of coverage, larger loan amounts, or longer repayment periods. The premiums would be lower for younger persons and females, due to lower mortality risk.

Knowledge Article: Question: How often can I withdraw from my CPF savings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There is no limit to the number of withdrawals you can make, as long as you are eligible and have withdrawable savings .   You can view your Retirement dashboard to check your eligibility and the amount you can withdraw.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the Special Needs Savings Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS) allows parents of children with special needs to nominate their child to receive a regular stream of fixed payouts from their CPF savings in the event of the parent’s demise.   CPF members interested to nominate their children under SNSS can approach the Special Needs Trust Company for more information.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will my witnesses know the details of my CPF nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your CPF nomination details will not be made known to your witnesses. Your witnesses will only need to declare that they are aware of your intention to make a nomination and specify how the witnessing request was communicated to them.   Making your nomination online provides added privacy and confidentiality, as your witnesses will not be able to see your nomination details.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will this wrap fee cap affect my investments?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Wrap fee is typically paid by redemption of units in your CPF-funded unit trust investment. With effect from 1 October 2020, you should not be paying more than 0.4% per annum in wrap fee from your CPF-funded investment.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to my CPF account if I am no longer a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your CPF account will be closed and you are required to transfer your CPF savings to your bank account. To transfer your CPF savings, please refer to the steps mentioned in this  FAQ .

Knowledge Article: Question: Do Fund Management Companies/insurers need to submit a new undertaking in view of the new Total Expense Ratio caps?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There is no need to submit a new undertaking. The previous undertaking continues to be valid for existing List A funds under CPF Investment Scheme.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if my Home Protection Scheme cover has lapsed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover has lapsed, you will need to apply for a new HPS cover. This is so that you can receive the financial protection provided by HPS on your outstanding housing loan.   Your eligibility for the new HPS cover is subject to approval and you being in good health.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the Daily Withdrawal Limit for online withdrawals?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Daily Withdrawal Limit is a limit that all CPF members aged 55 and above can set to determine the maximum daily amount they can withdraw online. The current maximum Daily Withdrawal Limit for online withdrawals is $200,000. There is no change in the current withdrawal rules under withdrawals for immediate needs for members aged 55 and above .

Knowledge Article: Question: What will happen to my Home Protection Scheme cover if I do not pay the annual premium?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you do not pay the annual premium for your Home Protection Scheme (HPS), your coverage will lapse and you will no longer be protected by HPS. This means that in the unfortunate event of death, terminal illness, or total permanent disability, you will not be able to make a claim under HPS.   You will need to reapply for an HPS cover if you wish to be covered under HPS in future. However, please note that your eligibility for the new HPS cover will be subject to approval and you being in good health at the time of application.   It is important to ensure that your HPS premiums are paid on time to avoid any lapse in coverage.

Knowledge Article: Question: My employee and I do not wish to apply for refund. Can the excess CPF contributions be retained in the employee's CPF account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For CPF contributions paid in error or on conditional wages, the refund application must be submitted to the Board within one year from the date of payment of CPF contributions or date wages are repayable to the employer respectively. Hence, if you do not wish to apply for the refund, you would not be able to do so subsequently.   However, if the excess contributions are paid above the CPF Annual Limit, they should not be retained and must be refunded to the employer/employee.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I view the status of my voluntary housing refund application?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can check the status of your voluntary housing refund application online via Activities . Once your application has been successfully processed, the refunded amount will be credited to your CPF account. You can then view the details in your 15-months Transaction History by logging in to my cpf digital services or CPF Mobile app via your Singpass. Additionally, you will receive an email notification once your application has been processed.   Please note that the amount refunded will be used to reduce the principal amount withdrawn for your property and its accrued interest.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I make a cash top-up for my Home Protection Scheme premium?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can make a cash top-up for your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) premium via the following means: PayNow at CPF website , or Cash at any Singapore Post branch offices You may wish to note that the HPS premium top-up is considered a voluntary contribution and is subject to the prevailing CPF Annual Limit . Alternatively, your family member (that is your spouse, parent, child or sibling) who co-owns the flat with you can authorise us to use their CPF OA savings to pay your HPS premium online using their Singpass. Find out more on how to top-up the Home Protection Scheme premium shortfall via PayNow QR .

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the Social Help and Assistance Raised by Employees (SHARE) Programme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The SHARE programme is a voluntary monthly giving programme run by Community Chest, the philanthropy and engagement arm of the National Council of Social Service.   CPF Board collects your employees’ SHARE donations on behalf of Community Chest, from your employees’ wages made through the company payroll.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is there any deadline for me to pay for the monthly instalment shortfall for my property?
Knowledge Article: Answer: It is important to pay off your monthly instalment shortfall for your property as soon as possible to avoid penalty fees from your financier. We recommend that you check with your financier directly to confirm any specific deadline for payment. Late or non-payment of instalments can result in additional fees and charges, so it's best to stay on top of your payments to avoid any unnecessary financial burden.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use more than one of my family members' CPF Ordinary Account savings to pay my Home Protection Scheme premium shortfall?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have a Home Protection Scheme (HPS) premium shortfall, you can only use the CPF Ordinary Account savings of one family member (spouse, parent, child, or sibling), who is a co-owner, to pay the premium at any given time.   If you need help with subsequent HPS renewal premiums, you can approach another family member who is also a co-owner for assistance.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will the new admission criteria be applied to existing funds under CPF Investment Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The new criteria will apply to existing funds from 1 January 2011. To help members make better informed investment decisions, the Board will, in due course, step up its member education efforts and also avail relevant information on the performance and expense ratios of existing funds.

Knowledge Article: Question: Where can I find the list of the Board's panel of law firms?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can refer to the list of law firms appointed by the Board (PDF, 0.1MB) to find a firm to handle legal matters relating to your property.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the reasons for the Board selecting these new criteria for new funds which wants to be included under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The new criteria cover issues that the Board is most concerned with, such as quality, consistency of performance relative to peer group and investment costs.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will all my Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme (ASPFAIS) Part V Insurance Policies be transferred to CPF Investment Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: All your Part V insurance policies will be transferred to your CPF Investment Scheme Investment Account with the agent bank.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the priority of the Home Protection Scheme deduction if I am also using my CPF savings to pay my monthly housing instalments?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are also using your CPF savings to pay your monthly housing instalments, the payment of HPS premium takes priority. This is to ensure that you remain financially protected by HPS for your outstanding housing loan.   During the premium grace period, your CPF Ordinary Account (OA) savings will be reserved for the HPS premium payment. This means that you will not be able to use your OA savings for any payments, including the monthly housing instalments, until your HPS premium is paid.   We recommend that you make alternative arrangements with your mortgagee on the shortfall in your monthly housing instalments during this period.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens if I make a loss on my investments? Do I have to make good the loss?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You need not make good your investment loss. However losses will reduce your retirement nest egg.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my MediSave to pay for outpatient treatment of chronic diseases?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use MediSave for outpatient treatments of the chronic diseases listed below.     The Ministry of Health (MOH) regularly reviews the list of conditions covered under the Chronic Disease Management Programme, to ensure that they continue to meet the needs of Singaporeans.   For more information, please visit the  Ministry of Health website.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the CPF payment services available for PayNow QR and OCBC Digital?
Knowledge Article: Answer: PayNow QR and OCBC Digital payment options are available for all payment services in CPF Mobile. You may use PayNow QR or OCBC Digital to top up Special Account/Retirement Account (SA/RA Top-Up) or refund funds used for your housing (Housing Refund).

Knowledge Article: Question: Will there be a charge levied on members for Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There will be no charge levied on members for making a CPF nomination under Special Needs Savings Scheme.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I make a top up for my spouse/parent/child/sibling's outstanding Home Protection Scheme premium?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you co-own the flat with your spouse/parent/child/sibling, you can authorise us to use your CPF Ordinary Account (OA) savings to pay the insured’s premium shortfall. You can do this online by logging in with your Singpass.   Once the application is approved by the Board, the premium will be deducted from the available balance in the insured’s CPF OA first, followed by your CPF OA.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can anyone access my CPF account information while I am still alive?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No. Your CPF account information is confidential. No one will be able to access your CPF account information while you are alive.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is online nomination? How is it different from submitting a hardcopy nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Online nomination allows you to submit your CPF nomination online, anytime, anywhere, without the need for your witnesses to be physically present to sign the hardcopy form. The process is simple and takes place entirely online:   You log in with your Singpass and submit the online nomination form with the required details. Inform your witnesses so that they are aware of your intention to make this nomination. Your appointed witnesses are notified by email and/or SMS to perform witnessing. The appointed witnesses log in with their Singpass and affirm your intention to make the nomination.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are there any charges for the MediSave/MediShield Life Internet Reimbursement (IR) service?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The MediSave/MediShield Life Internet Reimbursement service is free.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is my CPF nomination still valid if one or both of my witnesses pass away?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, your nomination will remain valid.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why are only certain individuals allowed to pay my Home Protection Scheme premium using their CPF Ordinary Account savings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Home Protection Scheme (HPS) premiums are consumptive in nature, which means that when your family member (who is your spouse, parent, child, or sibling) uses their Ordinary Account (OA) savings to help with your HPS premium payment, they will have less CPF savings for their retirement.   This is why only certain family members, who are co-owners of the flat, are allowed to use their CPF OA savings to pay your HPS premium. By doing so, they can help to secure the family home while limiting the impact on their retirement savings.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I indicate my nominee's share of my CPF savings as a fixed amount instead of a percentage?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No. In the event that your CPF savings are insufficient to meet this fixed amount you had specified in your nomination, we will not be able to distribute your CPF savings according to your wishes.   Indicating nominee(s)’ entitlement as a percentage of your CPF savings will allow us to distribute your CPF savings to your nominee(s) according to your wishes, regardless of changes to your CPF balances. The total entitlement for all nominees must sum up to 100%.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will I be informed if I do not have enough CPF savings for the monthly housing loan deduction?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will not be informed if you do not have enough CPF savings for the monthly housing loan deduction.   It is important to keep track of your CPF savings to ensure that you have enough for your monthly housing loan deduction.   You can check the amount deducted for your housing loan by viewing your CPF online statement. This statement provides a detailed breakdown of your CPF contributions and withdrawals, including any deductions made for your housing loan.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I still make a CPF nomination if I am seriously ill?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you can do so provided you are conscious and must not lack mental capacity when making the nomination.   You can consider appointing a doctor to be one of your witnesses in your nomination. You can request your doctor to write a memo stating that you have the mental capacity to make a CPF nomination and submit it to us.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am using an iOS device (iPhone or iPad) to submit my online nomination, and I was not able to submit my nominee's particulars. How can I resolve this?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are using an iOS device (such as iPhone or iPad) to submit your nomination, the “Smart Punctuation” feature in iOS may prevent you from submitting your nomination. You can disable the feature by performing the following steps on your device: Settings > General > Keyboard > Turn off Smart Punctuation.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I apply for Direct Debit to pay my company's CPF contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have a bank account with any of the eGIRO  participating banks , you should apply for Direct Debit Authorisation (DDA)  online. The processing takes only minutes. If you are using a corporate bank account, your approver must approve the eGIRO request within your bank’s internet banking portal within 48 hours before the application expires. We’ll notify you once your application is processed.   To apply for DDA online, follow the following steps: Login with your Singpass Specify your designated bank for the payment through the online application. Login to your bank’s internet banking portal, select the bank account and approve the eGIRO request. You will receive a notification when your application is successful. If you do not have a bank account with any of the eGIRO participating banks, you can make payment via PayNow QR . If your bank is not an eGIRO or a PayNow participating bank, please write to us for assistance.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I apply to be insured under Home Protection Scheme if I do not have any outstanding housing loan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Home Protection Scheme (HPS) benefits are used to pay off the outstanding housing loan in the event of a claim. If you have not taken any housing loan to buy your HDB flat, HPS is not applicable to you.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if I encounter problems with the online nomination service?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are encountering problems, you can troubleshoot most errors by performing the following steps:   Avoid copy-pasting the details from another program or app as there might be hidden characters that might get copied. Key in the nominee’s particulars directly instead. If you are using an iOS device (such as iPhone or iPad), disable the “Smart Punctuation” feature in iOS (iOS device Settings > General > Keyboard > Turn off Smart Punctuation). This feature might create unrecognisable characters in the application form. Avoid opening multiple browser tabs. Use only one browser tab and clear your browser cache. Consider using a different device to submit your nomination if submission via your original device is still unsuccessful. If you are still facing problems after performing the above troubleshooting steps, you can write to us so that we can look into it.   Alternatively, you may visit any of our CPF Service Centres to make a nomination in-person.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am concerned of the state of my health, and would like to go for some health screenings. Can I use my MediSave for them?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use your MediSave to pay for your own or your approved dependants' outpatient scans or health screenings at the participating medical institutions (PDF, 0.4MB). Approved dependants refer to your spouse, children, parents, grandchildren and siblings. Please note that your grandchildren and siblings must be Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents.     The use of MediSave for mammograms are for female patients aged 50 years or above. This is in line with recommendations from the Screening Test Review Committee from The Academy of Medicine Singapore.   You may also use MediSave for colonoscopy if you are 50 years old or above, according to the withdrawal limits in the image above.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the difference between Home Protection Scheme , HDB Fire Insurance and Home Insurance?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you own a Housing & Development Board (HDB) flat, it is important to understand the different types of insurance available to you. Here's a breakdown of the three main types:   Home Protection Scheme (HPS): This is a type of mortgage-reducing insurance that protects you and your loved ones from losing your HDB flat due to the inability to make mortgage payments in the event of death, terminal illness or total permanent disability.  HPS is administered by CPFB and insures members up to age 65 or until the housing loans are paid up, whichever is earlier. HDB Fire Insurance Scheme: This insurance, which is administered by HDB, helps to cover the cost of reinstating damaged internal structures, fixtures, as well as areas built and provided by HDB in the event of a fire. This can help to relieve the financial burden of repair work for flat owners.
