Home Insurance: It is also known as Home Content Insurance or Homeowners Insurance, which covers a residence and helps in paying for repair or replacing one’s belongings if they are damaged by perils such as fires, vandalism, burglary and more. Home insurance can be purchased from private insurers.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is there an administrative fee when I submit my nomination online?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There is no administrative fee to make a CPF nomination.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to my unused CPF transfers and cash top-ups to my recipient upon his demise or if he closes his CPF account upon leaving Singapore?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Cash top-ups and CPF transfers will generally be treated as gifts to the recipient. Any unused cash top-ups or CPF transfers will be paid to the recipient's beneficiaries upon his demise, or to the recipient himself if he closes his CPF account and withdraws his CPF savings upon leaving Singapore. This is subject to safeguards to prevent premature withdrawals.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much CPF monthly payout can I receive if I top up to the raised Enhanced Retirement Sum in 2025?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF monthly payout amount will depend on several factors, including when one sets aside the Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS) and when one starts payouts. The ERS in 2025 will be $426,000. A male member turning 55 years old in 2025 can receive about $3,330 per month of CPF LIFE payouts at age 65 under the CPF LIFE standard plan, if he chooses to top up to the raised ERS. This is up from about $2,530 today. You can use the Monthly payout estimator  to estimate your payouts if you top up to the raised ERS.

Knowledge Article: Question: Where can I purchase fire insurance for my HDB flat?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are looking to purchase fire insurance for your HDB flat, you can reach out to the Housing and Development Board (HDB) for assistance. They will be able to provide you with more information on the process and requirements.

Knowledge Article: Question: Where can I check and view my Home Protection Scheme premium deduction?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can check and view the Home Protection Scheme premium deduction from your CPF Ordinary Account online using your Singpass. The deduction will also be shown in your Yearly Statement of Account.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is Provident and Tax (PAT)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Provident and Tax (PAT) is a platform offered by CrimsonLogic for employers to submit their employees' monthly CPF contributions to CPF Board and yearly income forms to Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) online.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long does it take to process applications relating to CPF nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please refer to the table for our normal processing time for applications relating to CPF nomination.   Nomination Manual Transaction E-Transaction Making a nomination Four working days upon receipt of application Request to view my nomination details online Note: For hardcopy based nominations only. For online nominations, the details will be available immediately after it is processed. Not applicable Four working days Request to revoke my existing nomination(s) Four working days upon receipt of application Not applicable

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I pay CPF late payment interest if I am submitting CPF contributions via Electronic Standing Instructions (ESI)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For CPF contributions that are submitted via Electronic Standing Instructions (ESI), you can make payment for CPF late payment interest by performing an additional submission via the steps below: At ESI Main Menu, select Perform Additional Submission . Select the Month and key in the Year you are submitting for and click Continue to proceed. Scroll down to the summary section and key in the outstanding CPF late payment interest amount under ‘2. CPF Late Payment Interest’. Click Continue . Verify the payment details and click Direct Debit to complete the payment. You will see the online acknowledgement screen after the submission is completed successfully. An email will also be sent to your email address(es) registered with the Board.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can MediSave be used for a deceased member's last hospitalisation bill?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The deceased member's MediSave can be used fully, without being subjected to the existing MediSave withdrawal limits to pay the last medical bill, if the member has passed away during his hospitalisation.   If the deceased member had not signed the Medical Claims Authorisation Form (MCAF) before his death, his spouse, parent or child aged 21 and above, or Donee/Deputy appointed under the Mental Capacity Act, has to quickly sign the MCAF on behalf of the deceased member to authorise the hospital to submit a claim, before the deceased's CPF funds including MediSave, is disbursed to his nominees or the Public Trustee Office.    If the deceased member does not have a spouse, parent or child aged 21 and above, or Donee/Deputy, a next of kin (NOK) who has been taking care of the deceased can inform the hospital of his intention to sign the MCAF on behalf of the deceased member. The hospital will then seek approval from MOH on behalf of the NOK, before the NOK signs the MCAF.   If more than one MediSave Account (MA) holders had authorised the use of their MediSave to pay the medical bill of the deceased member before his demise and one of the MA belongs to the deceased, the protocol on the use of MediSave from the various accounts are as follows:   The deceased member's MediSave will be used first to pay off the last medical bill without being subject to the MediSave withdrawal limits. If the deceased member's MediSave is not sufficient to pay the last medical bill, the MediSave from the other account holder(s) can then be used, provided that the MediSave withdrawn from the deceased member's account does not exceed the MediSave withdrawal limits. Example whereby the MediSave withdrawal limit has been reached Patient passes away with a final hospitalisation bill of $5,000, after staying in the hospital for five days without surgical treatment.   Patient's MediSave Balance = $4,000   $4,000 can be paid from the patient's MediSave and the remainder of $1,000 must be paid by cash. The patient's spouse, child, parent, grandchild or sibling's MediSave cannot be used as the maximum MediSave Withdrawal Limit of $2,300 has been reached. Example whereby the MediSave withdrawal limit has not been reached Patient passes away with a final hospitalisation bill of $5,000, after staying in the hospital for five days without surgical treatment.   Patient's MediSave Balance = $1,500   $1,500 can be paid from the patient's MediSave and a further $800 can be paid from the MediSave of the patient's spouse, child, parent, grandchild or sibling, up to the maximum MediSave Withdrawal Limit of $2,300. The remaining $2,700 of the bill needs to be settled with cash.

Knowledge Article: Question: What types of property can be covered under the Home Protection Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The types of property which can be covered by Home Protection Scheme are:   Housing & Development Board (HDB) Flat You are eligible to apply for an HPS cover if you own an HDB flat with an outstanding housing loan.   Privatised Housing and Urban Development Corporation (HUDC) You are not eligible for an HPS cover as privatised HUDC are not considered public housing.   It is recommended that you purchase equivalent private insurance to cover your outstanding housing loans.   However, if you have applied for a HPS cover before 1 November 1998, special concession has been made to allow you to continue your HPS coverage as long as you do not refinance your housing loan or change the ownership of your HUDC flat.   Executive Condominium (EC) or Private Property You are not eligible for an HPS cover as EC and private properties are not considered public housing.   It is recommended that you purchase equivalent private insurance to cover your outstanding housing loans.

Knowledge Article: Question: How many nominees can I specify in my online nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can specify up to 15 nominees. If you wish to nominate more than 15 nominees, you can make a nomination at our CPF Service Centres.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to be insured under Home Protection Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: It depends on whether you are using CPF savings or cash to service your monthly housing instalments.   For members who are using CPF savings to service their monthly housing instalments You need to be insured under HPS and your eligibility for HPS coverage is subject to approval and you being in good health.   If you are not eligible for an HPS cover due to serious pre-existing medical condition, you may still use your CPF savings to pay your monthly housing instalment.   For members who are using cash to service their monthly housing instalments You are strongly encouraged to apply for an HPS cover if you are an owner of the flat and do not have adequate financial protection for your share of outstanding housing loan.   Your eligibility for HPS coverage is subject to approval and you being in good health.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why should I make my CPF nomination online?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Online nomination is convenient – you can make your nomination anytime, anywhere. Your personal information is protected as your witnesses will not be able to see your nomination details.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I submit an organisation as my nominee in my online nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you would like to nominate an organisation, select 'Registration No.' under the ‘Select identification type’ field and indicate the organisation’s unique corporate registration number (such as Unique Entity Number (UEN)) in the ‘Registration number of organisation’ field.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I check the status of my application for refund and adjustment of contributions paid?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can check the status of your application for refund and adjustment of contributions paid.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I check the status of my application for refund and adjustment of contributions paid?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can check the status of your application for refund and adjustment of contributions paid.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is there no tax relief for top-ups made to my children or non-immediate family?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Tax relief is an incentive given to encourage members to build up retirement savings for themselves or their immediate family members, particularly older Singaporeans who may have less retirement savings.   Your children have more time to accumulate savings in their working years for their own retirement needs. Hence, there is no tax relief for top-ups made to your children or non-immediate family members.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will the restriction on investments for the first $20,000 in Ordinary Account and the first $40,000 in Special Account affect me?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The first $60,000 of your combined CPF accounts earns an extra 1% interest. To enable members to earn extra interest, only monies in excess of $20,000 in your Ordinary Account (OA) and $40,000 in your Special Account (SA) can be invested.   However, you can continue to service your agent bank fees and regular premium insurance policies (excludes recurring single premium insurance policies or regular savings plans for unit trusts) even if your OA balance falls below $20,000.   If you have already made investments using your OA or SA balances, you are not required to sell these investments.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I am eligible for Matched Retirement Savings Scheme this year, will I be automatically eligible in the following years?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, your eligibility for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme is assessed annually. We will notify you at the beginning of the year if you are eligible.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am age 55 and above. How will the closure of Special Account (SA) affect my eligibility to voluntarily transfer my CPF savings to top up my own/loved ones' retirement savings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There are no changes to the eligibility rules on the transfer of CPF savings to top up your own/loved ones' retirement savings.   When your Special Account is closed, your withdrawable SA savings (if any) will be transferred to your Ordinary Account (OA), and your available CPF savings for such top-ups will increase accordingly. You can check these amounts available for such top-ups via the Retirement Dashboard, after we complete the closure of your SA in early 2025.

Knowledge Article: Question: Where can I seek help regarding my GovCash withdrawal?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Singaporeans who require assistance with their GovCash withdrawals can visit a NEW ATM located at selected OCBC branches (refer to OCBC website for latest list of NEW ATMs) during the branch operating hours, and OCBC Digital Ambassadors will be available to assist you.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if my facial recognition at the ATM with GovCash functions is unsuccessful?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are unable to verify your identity via Singpass Face Verification at the ATM despite repeated tries, you may visit a NEW ATM located at selected OCBC branches (refer to  OCBC website  for latest list of NEW ATMs) during the branch operating hours, and OCBC's Digital Ambassadors will be available to assist you.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I be sure that I'm witnessing a legitimate nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: It is your responsibility as a witness to ensure that the CPF member making the nomination has specifically requested for you to witness his nomination. You should check with the member to affirm his intention to make a CPF nomination before proceeding to witness his nomination.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can you re-send my Payment Reference Number to me so that I can perform my GovCash withdrawal?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can log into the e-services with your Singpass to view your Payment Reference Number (PRN) by selecting “GovCash PRN” that is found at the menu on the left. This will only be available after the payment has been made through GovCash.

Knowledge Article: Question: When do I have to choose my CPF LIFE plan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You only need to choose your CPF LIFE plan when you wish to start receiving your CPF LIFE monthly payouts.   If you are automatically included in CPF LIFE , you can start your payouts any time from 65 to 70 and choose your CPF LIFE plan then. If you do not choose a plan before 70, you will be automatically placed on the CPF LIFE Standard Plan and your payouts will start at 70.   If you are not automatically included in CPF LIFE, you can choose your CPF LIFE plan when you wish to join the scheme, any time from 65 to one month before you turn 80.   To help you better decide on which CPF LIFE plan is suitable for you, find out more details on what are the CPF LIFE plans available .

Knowledge Article: Question: Who is eligible to make a nomination online?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF members who are aged 16 and above, and have a valid Singpass, are eligible to make a nomination online.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is PayNow and how do I link my NRIC to PayNow?
Knowledge Article: Answer: PayNow is a secure funds transfer service that allows customers to receive money into their bank account via NRIC/FIN and/or mobile number.   With PayNow, the recipient’s bank information will be kept private. The recipient will need to provide their mobile number or NRIC/FIN to the sender to send money. Other PayNow users will not have access to your personal details unless it is provided by you.   To receive government benefits via PayNow, you will need to link your NRIC to PayNow. PayNow-Mobile number is not accepted. You can register for PayNow-NRIC if you have a bank account with the following participating banks in Singapore:   Bank Bank of China CIMB Citibank DBS Bank / POSB GXS Bank HSBC Bank ICBC MariBank Maybank OCBC RHB Bank Standard Chartered Bank Trust Bank UOB   The list of PayNow-GIRO banks is updated as of 28 Aug 2024.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is it safe to make my CPF nomination online?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There are multiple layers of checks in place so that CPF members can make their nomination online in a safe and secure manner.   A Singpass is required to log in securely to my cpf digital services to make your online nomination. Singpass has multiple layers of security measures in place, including Two-Factor Authentication (2FA) login. We will also send SMS and email notification alerts to your registered mobile number/email address when you make your nomination online.   The combination of these measures will provide a safe and secure environment for you to make your nomination online.   You are also encouraged to adopt good security practices such as not sharing your Singpass credentials with others and changing your passwords regularly.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I withdraw my savings earlier if I am sick?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you can withdraw your CPF savings earlier if you are certified by an accredited doctor to meet any of the following medical conditions:   Reduced life expectancy Due to illness, your life expectancy has been severely reduced.   Permanently unfit for work You are permanently unfit for any form of employment.   Permanently lack mental capacity As defined in the Mental Capacity Act, you permanently lack the mental capacity to make decisions.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is there a deadline for me to witness an online nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you have seven calendar days from the time you receive the SMS/email notification request to complete the witnessing.   If you cannot complete the witnessing in time, please inform the CPF member, as the nomination application will expire and the CPF member will need to submit a new application.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will I be charged if my friend conducts manipulative share trading using my CPF and trading accounts (given by me previously) without my knowing?
Knowledge Article: Answer: This will depend on the outcome of investigations.  However, you should always protect your password and not allow other people to transact in your name without your knowledge or your approval.

Knowledge Article: Question: I received a request to witness an online nomination from someone I do not know. What should I do?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Do not complete the witnessing process. Please contact us immediately so that we can follow up with the CPF member.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I accept gifts and/or rebates from my service providers when investing under CPF Investment Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: All gifts and/or rebates arising from investing under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) must be converted to cash and refunded back to your CPF Ordinary and Special Accounts respectively. You are not allowed to receive gifts and/or rebates direct from your service provider as this will result in a leakage of CPF funds. Alternatively, you may also receive rebates in the form of additional units of investments under the CPFIS.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the options available to me if I foresee that I do not have sufficient CPF to continue paying the instalments on my regular premium insurance policy?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you foresee difficulties in paying your future premiums using CPF, you may wish to consider the following options after consulting your insurance advisor:   Pay the instalment using cash. Any proceeds from your insurance policy will then be apportioned according to the amount of premiums paid using cash and CPF; Change the payment frequency from yearly to half-yearly or even to quarterly or monthly, subject to the insurance company’s agreement, so that a lower premium will be deducted per payment; Reduce the sum assured, thus reducing the amount of premium payable; or Convert the policy to a paid-up policy. After you have decided on the option, you need to liaise with your insurance company on the payment of the premium.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why can't witnesses view the CPF member's nomination details?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The role of a witness is to affirm the CPF member’s intention to make a CPF nomination. There is no need for witnesses to know the nomination details to perform their role as witnesses.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will I be eligible for MediShield Life Premium Subsidies?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will receive MediShield Life Premium Subsidies (up to 50%) if you meet the following eligibility criteria:   Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident. Household monthly income per person of $2,800 and below Living in a property with an Annual Value of $25,000 and below. Those who are either older, have lower income or live in residences with lower Annual Value will enjoy higher subsidy rates. Individuals who own multiple properties will not be eligible.   Permanent Residents will receive half of the subsidy rates applicable to Singapore Citizens. This is aligned to the subsidy policy in public healthcare institutions.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to refund the transferred CPF savings if I decide to obtain Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Residency again after I have closed my account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you decide to reinstate your Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Residency after closing your CPF account, you are required to refund your CPF savings with accrued interest. The amount to be refunded includes:    Savings transferred to your bank account upon account closure; Savings used for participation in CPF schemes (e.g. CPF Investment Scheme); Contributions that should have been paid prior to account closure (e.g. outstanding MediSave liabilities for self-employed persons); Savings used to clear past debts upon account closure (e.g. tax arrears, education loan).

Knowledge Article: Question: When do I need to submit the documents (medical certification and employment information) to support my application for Dependants' Protection Scheme claim?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Both your doctor and employer are required to submit the completed medical certification form and your employment information respectively to CPF Board within 90 days of your application. The medical certification form and employment information will be used to process claims under Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) and Home Protection Scheme (HPS), if you have applied for both.   Please note that your application will be cancelled if we do not receive the supporting documents by the given deadline.   If you are applying for DPS benefits only, you can submit the supporting documents to the Great Eastern Life directly.

Knowledge Article: Question: What supporting documents do I need if I am making a nomination at the CPF Service Centre?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You are strongly encouraged to bring along photocopies of your nominee(s)’ identification documents (such as NRIC or foreign identification document) indicating their particulars.

Knowledge Article: Question: Am I covered under the Dependants' Protection Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can check the status of your Dependants' Protection Scheme coverage via: - your yearly CPF Statement of Account - the " Providing for your loved ones " dashboard by logging in with your Singpass If you do not have a Singpass, you can apply for one at the Singpass website .

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I apply to be exempted from Home Protection Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are using CPF for your monthly housing instalments, you can apply to be exempted from the Home Protection Scheme (HPS) provided your private insurance coverage is enough to cover your outstanding housing loan against death, terminal illness and total permanent disability until the end of your loan term or age 65, whichever is earlier.   Here is what you need to do: Contact your private insurance provider to submit your application to be exempted from HPS. Submit supporting documents to your insurer that show details of your current* housing loan, such as the commencement date, balance loan amount, balance term of loan and mortgage rate. You can find this information on your housing loan statement. *Within six months of the submission date of your exemption application.   We will only accept applications submitted by insurers. Once we receive your application and necessary documents from your insurers, we will assess your eligibility for exemption from HPS and inform you of the outcome generally within five working days.   If you are successful in the exemption application, your existing HPS cover will be terminated. You will receive a full premium refund credited to your CPF Ordinary Account (OA), provided that the exemption application is received by the Board within one month from the issuance of the HPS cover. Otherwise, a pro-rated refund will be credited to your OA upon the termination of your HPS cover.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have been requested to witness an online nomination. What do I need to do?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As a witness, you will need to declare that you are aware of the CPF member’s intention to make a nomination and specify how the request was communicated to you.   If you are ready with this information, please login with your Singpass to complete your witnessing.   You can view the video guide for more information on being a witness for a CPF nomination online.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I make a Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS) nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Special Needs Saving Scheme (SNSS) caters to Persons with Special Needs (PSN) who are nominated by their parents to draw a fixed monthly payout from the parents' CPF savings upon the parents' demise.   For more details on SNSS, please visit SNTC's website .

Knowledge Article: Question: Where can I find more information about discounted Singtel shares?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can refer to the Singtel website for more information.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will CPF investors benefit from the reduced Total Expense Ratio (TER) caps?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Expenses on investment have a significant impact on returns. Hence, reducing Total Expense Ratio caps will lower the expenses that CPF investors have to bear and increase a fund's per-unit net asset value. This will enable CPF members who have invested in the fund to accumulate their retirement savings faster.   The following example illustrates the impact of expense ratio:   Amount invested: $10,000 over 30 years, with annual return of 5% 1 Total expense ratio of the Fund decreases from 1.95% to 1.75% Savings =  $1,475 (or 6% more in his retirement savings) Expense Ratio of 1.95% Expense Ratio of 1.75% Net investment value after 30 years $24,629 $26,104 Savings $1,475   1 Assumes no front end load

Knowledge Article: Question: Is there a limit on the CPF transfers that can be made to my ex-spouse's CPF Accounts under the division of CPF savings in a divorce?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There is no limit on the CPF transfers if so ordered by the Court. It is up to the Court to decide on the division of CPF savings and how much your ex-spouse's entitlement is.   Before the Court grants the court order, you should ensure that the Court is kept informed of any changes to the amount of CPF savings available for division or any planned utilisation of your CPF savings (e.g. deductions for housing payments) that would affect the division of the same.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I appoint or change Administrator for CPF EZPay?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To appoint or change Administrator for CPF EZPay, please refer to the following options:   For UEN-registered entity   Your Corppass Admin or Sub-Admin can appoint or change your Administrator by assigning the “CPF EZPay” e-service to another authorised officer within Corppass portal. Please refer to this guide (PDF, 1.5MB) for more information.   For individual trading under own name   Your existing Administrators within CPF EZPay can add new Administrators. Please refer to our user guide (PDF, 3.7MB) for more information.   If you only have one Administrator who has left, you will need to write to us stating your reason for addition/removal of Administrator for us to assist you.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I view my CPF contribution details in CPF EZPay?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can save a copy of the CPF contribution details by following these steps:   Select CPF EZPay Select For UEN-registered entities or For individuals trading under own name and login with your Singpass. Key in your CPF Submission Number (CSN). At Manage Records & Preferences , select View / Amend / Delete Submission Click on the Submission Date to view the Contribution details. You will be directed to the View Employer Submission Page . To save this page, click on the Printer icon. You will be prompted to download a PDF file which you can save. IMPORTANT! If you wish to print a copy of the contribution details only, please do not use the Amend submission function as it will result in the withdrawal of your submitted file.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is there an electronic submission mode I can use if I don't have a Singpass account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use CPF EZPay Mobile to submit CPF contributions for 10 or fewer employees and pay via PayNow QR.   If you need to manage more employees, you should use CPF EZPay for your CPF submissions. You are encouraged to apply for Singpass or visit any of the Singpass counters located islandwide in-person.   If you are a UEN-registered entity, you will need Corppass access and perform a one-time setup before using CPF EZPay. Please refer to this guide for the steps.

Knowledge Article: Question: What will happen to my Home Protection Scheme cover if I have refinanced my housing loan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have refinanced your housing loan, e.g. from a Housing Development Board (HDB) loan to a bank loan or a change in mortgagee, you do not need to apply to adjust your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover. We will automatically adjust your HPS cover if your loan quantum and/or repayment period has reduced. A new HPS cover will be issued to you based on the latest loan details and the premium for the new cover will be deducted from your CPF Ordinary Account.   If your loan quantum and/or repayment period has increased, we will write to you to inform you to apply to adjust your cover. Please note that any increase in your HPS coverage is subject to approval and you being in good health.   If there are no changes to your loan quantum and/or repayment period, no adjustment to your HPS cover is required. We will update our records to reflect your new mortgagee.   Find out more: What will happen to my Home Protection Scheme exemption if I have refinanced my housing loan?

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I check the status of my nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can check the status of your online nomination at cpf.gov.sg/MyActivities using your Singpass.   We will send you an email/SMS once your nomination is routed to your witnesses. Upon the completion of witnessing by your witnesses, we will generally process your nomination within 4 working days. You will also receive an email/SMS of the status.   Once your online nomination has been processed, you will receive one more email/SMS notification on the final status of your nomination.   If you wish to view the details of your nomination, you can then access the information at cpf.gov.sg/viewnomdetails .

Knowledge Article: Question: What does the Board's investment consultant look for when evaluating fund management companies (FMCs), insurance companies or their products?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please see the evaluation criteria provided by the Board's investment consultant.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I submit CPF contributions for my employees?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can submit your CPF contributions easily using CPF EZPay with Singpass. Enjoy hassle-free submission by making use of the auto-computation feature or set up an Electronic Standing Instruction (ESI) for recurring monthly submissions.   If you have 10 or fewer employees and would like to submit your CPF contributions on-the-go, you can do so using CPF EZPay Mobile . Simply download the app on your mobile phone to get started.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why do I need to update contact details to update my bank account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Notifications via SMS or email will be sent to you whenever there are updates to your bank account. As such, you will have to register or update your contact details under Account settings to receive these notifications and prevent any unauthorised updates from taking effect.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I had bought two private properties, which property will my CPF savings be used to service the monthly instalment first?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There is no specific order of deduction on which property will be paid first. We will deduct the amount from your Ordinary Account to pay the monthly instalments as requested by you. It is important to ensure that you have enough savings in your CPF account to cover the monthly instalment deductions.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my Special Account savings to pay my housing loan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As your Special Account savings are meant for retirement, only your Ordinary Account savings can be used for housing payments such as mortgage payments, down payments, and monthly instalments.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I have more than one CPF Submission Number (CSN), can I use CPF EZPay?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use CPF EZPay if you have more than one CPF Submission Number (CSN). There is no limit on the number of CSNs. However, you must apply for Direct Debit for each CSN.

Knowledge Article: Question: My employee has renounced his Singapore Citizenship/Singapore Permanent Resident status in a month. Do I need to pay his CPF for the entire month?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your employee has renounced his Singapore Citizen/Singapore Permanent Resident (SC/SPR) status, you would need to pay CPF contributions for him for the period when he is still a SC/SPR. CPF contributions are not required from the day your employee becomes a foreigner. For Ordinary Wages (OW), you will need to pay CPF contributions on the pro-rated OW. For Additional Wages (AW), CPF contributions are required depending on when the AW is payable to your employee. Please ensure your employee informs you when he renounces his SC/SPR status. Example Assuming your employee renounces his SC/SPR status and becomes a foreigner on 10 January 2022 and he receives OW and AW for January 2022. For OW CPF contribution is only required on the pro-rated wages for the period 1 to 9 January 2022. For AW CPF contribution is required on the AW if it is payable to the employee between 1 to 9 January 2022. CPF contribution is not required on the AW if it is payable on or after 10 January 2022.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long does it take to process the refund of the excess payment made to the Housing & Development Board or the bank of my housing loan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please refer to the table for our service standards for processing the refund of the excess payment made to HDB or the bank.   Service Normal Processing Time Process the refund of excess payment made to HDB or the bank The funds and refund details are transmitted through the electronic link-ups with HDB or the banks : Within three working days   The funds and/or refund details are transmitted to us by other means : Within fifteen working days

Knowledge Article: Question: How can a donee/deputy make or revoke a CPF nomination for members who lack mental capacity?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For CPF members who lack capacity under Section 4 of the Mental Capacity Act ("MCA"), only the Courts can make or revoke a CPF nomination on their behalf.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the maximum monthly instalment amount that can be used for my property?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The total monthly CPF deduction for all owners must not exceed the total monthly repayment amount approved by your financier.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have used cash to pay for my housing monthly instalment shortfall. Can I apply to pay with my CPF savings, and get a cash refund from my financier?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you can apply to use your CPF savings to pay the monthly instalment shortfall. However, please note that getting a cash refund from your financier is not guaranteed and is subject to their approval. It is important to check with your financier directly to see if they are able to refund the cash paid before you apply to use your CPF savings.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why did I receive an SMS message from CPF Board informing me that I checked my nomination details when I did not do so?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you received this SMS when you did not check your nomination details, it could be possible that   the previous owner of your mobile number had forgotten to update his/her latest mobile number with the Board; you had given consent to your loved ones to register the same mobile number with the Board. For (1), you can write to us if you wish to remove the contact details of the other party from your rightful contact details.   For (2), you can directly ask the other member to update his/ her contact detail via my cpf digital services - Account settings with their Singpass.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I do not have enough CPF savings to pay for my property, can I top up my CPF account with cash to make up the shortfall?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you do not have enough CPF savings to pay for your property, you can still make a voluntary contribution to your CPF account. This is subject to the CPF Annual Limit.   The voluntary contributions will be apportioned and credited to your Ordinary, Special, and MediSave accounts and is based on the CPF allocation rates.   As only Ordinary Account savings can be used for housing repayments, you may consider paying the shortfall in cash to your bank (if you are taking a bank loan) or to the Housing & Development Board (HDB) (if you are taking an HDB loan) directly.

Knowledge Article: Question: Does the Board impose a penalty for unsuccessful housing deductions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Board does not impose a penalty for unsuccessful housing deductions.

Knowledge Article: Question: When is the monthly housing loan deducted from my CPF account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The date of deduction for your monthly housing loan from your CPF account depends on the type of property and loan you have.   Type of property and loan taken Date of next deduction Housing & Development Board (HDB) flat (HDB loan) The deduction is on the Sunday between 6th and 12th (including both dates) of the month. HDB flat (Bank loan) The deduction is between the 11th and 14th (including both dates) of the month. Private property / Executive Condominium The deduction is on the first or last working day of the month, depending on the bank’s due date. Note: If you are using your CPF savings to pay for the upgrading cost of your HDB flat, the deduction is on the Sunday, between the 6th and 12th (including both dates) of the month.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can parents determine the amount of monthly payouts for their nominated child with disabilities?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Parents can determine the amount of monthly payout for their nominated child with disabilities at the point of application, subject to a minimum payout of $250 per month with a minimum duration of at least one year.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I check my CPF nomination details?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can view your CPF nomination details at cpf.gov.sg/ViewNOMDetails with your Singpass.   If your nomination details are not available online, you can write to us regarding your request. You will be able to view your nomination details generally within four working days. An email will be sent to inform you once your nomination details are available for online viewing.   If your nomination was made some time back, we strongly encourage you to make a new nomination as your circumstances might have changed. You can easily make a nomination online .

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I ensure I am notified of my MediShield Life premiums payable?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To ensure that you are notified of your MediShield Life premiums payable, you can update your residential address with ICA or at the nearest Neighbourhood Police Post. Once updated, participating government agencies and statutory boards like the CPF Board will be informed of the change in address through the One-Stop Change of Address Reporting Service (OSCARS).   You can also log in to Healthcare dashboard  'Coverage and premium details' for information on your and/or your dependants' MediShield Life premiums and subsidies.   You will receive digital notifications regarding your MediShield Life if you have registered your email address and mobile telephone number. For example,   a. If your email address is registered with CPF Board, you will be notified via email;   b. If your email address is not registered, but your mobile number is registered with CPF Board, you will be notified via WhatsApp or SMS depending on whether you have given consent to receive WhatsApp notifications;   c. Additionally, if you have installed the CPF Mobile app and enabled push notifications on your mobile phone, you will receive the CPF Mobile app push notification alerts. This is an additional notification alert.   You can log in to the CPF website and update your contact details under Account Settings .   If you do not have the CPF Mobile app, and did not register your email or mobile number with us, you will continue to receive hardcopy MediShield Life letters.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I change my address to receive MediShield Life letters to one not registered under ICA/OSCARS as I am concerned of missing letters or others opening my letters?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediShield Life letters are sent to your residential address registered with the Immigration Checkpoints Authority (ICA)'s One-Stop Change of Address Reporting Service (OSCARS). It is an offence for another person to wilfully open letters not addressed to them or to intentionally prevent letters from reaching the recipient under the Postal Services Act.   As part of our efforts to facilitate timelier and up-to-date notifications, you will start to receive MediShield Life notifications digitally in place of hardcopy letters from end 2021.   To receive timely notifications on MediShield Life matters, update your contact information with the following steps:   1. On the CPF homepage ( cpf.gov.sg ), click “Login” to log on to my cpf digital services with Singpass   2. Click the dropdown button from the top right panel and select "Account settings"   3. Select “Update” to update your contact information. An SMS or email One-Time PIN (OTP) will be sent to your new mobile number or email address for verification before the changes take effect.   You can also log in to Healthcare dashboard to check your MediShield Life premiums and subsidies.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the maximum amount of top-ups I can receive?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The maximum amount of top-ups you can receive depends on your age and amount of CPF savings you have. You can easily check your top-up limit in your Retirement Dashboard .     You can refer to these examples  on how the maximum top-up amount is computed.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can the Board automatically deduct the monthly instalment shortfall for my property from my co-owner's CPF account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We are not authorised to automatically deduct the monthly instalment shortfall from your co-owner's CPF account for your property.   It is important for all owners to communicate and come to an agreement regarding the division of payment responsibilities.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will I be able to access the CPF account information of a deceased CPF member?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If CPF Board is notified of the death before 1 February 2024   If the deceased member had appointed authorised persons in his/her CPF nomination, only the authorised persons can access his/her CPF account information.   If CPF Board is notified of the death on or after 1 February 2024   Nominees and family members who are eligible beneficiaries under intestacy laws will be able to access a deceased member's CPF account information.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I have to join CareShield Life?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident born in 1980 or later, you will automatically join CareShield Life on 1 October 2020 or when you turn 30, even if you have any pre-existing conditions or disabilities.    If you are a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident born between 1970 and 1979, you will be automatically enrolled in CareShield Life from 1 December 2021, if you are currently covered under the ElderShield 400 (ESH400) scheme and have not developed severe disability at the point of auto-enrolment. You can opt out of CareShield Life by 31 December 2023 if you do not wish to join the scheme and you will automatically be placed back onto your ESH400 scheme. Those who are not auto-enrolled can choose to join CareShield Life. If you are an ElderShield insured in this group, you will have a 60-day free-look period from the commencement of your CareShield Life coverage, for you to consider your decision. If you choose to opt out, you will be given a full premium refund and automatically be placed back onto your original ElderShield 300/400 scheme. You will not be able to opt out from the scheme after the applicable opt-out/free-look periods.    For more FAQs on CareShield Life, please visit the  CareShield Life website .

Knowledge Article: Question: What is CareShield Life?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CareShield Life is a long-term care insurance which provides financial protection against long-term care costs of Singaporeans in the event of severe disability. CareShield Life will provide you with better protection and assurance for basic long-term care needs with: 1. Lifetime cash payouts , for as long as the insured is unable to do three or more activities of daily living (ADL). 2. Increasing monthly payouts , at $649/month in 2024 and increases annually until age 67 or when a successful claim is made, whichever is earlier;   3. Government subsidies to make it affordable , with no one losing coverage if they cannot pay premiums; 4. Premiums can be fully paid by MediSave . If you are a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident born in 1980 or later, you will be automatically covered on 1 October 2020 or when you turn 30, even if you have any pre-existing conditions or have developed severe disability.   For more FAQs on CareShield Life, please visit the CareShield Life website .

Knowledge Article: Question: What CPF account information can my nominees and eligible family members under intestacy laws access, upon my demise?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your nominees and eligible family members can access the following information:   CPF account balances and past 15 months' transaction history Nomination details CPF schemes which you have participated in

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I instruct CPF Board to disallow my nominees or family members from accessing my CPF account information, upon my demise?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No. Allowing your nominees and family members to access your CPF account information make it easier for them to reconcile your CPF account information and settle any post-demise matters relating to your CPF account.   This practice is also aligned with industry standards on matters such as for estate distribution under wills and distribution of assets by the Public Trustee’s Office, where details of the distribution can be provided to all beneficiaries.   Please be assured that your CPF information remains confidential while you are alive. Your nominees and family members who are eligible beneficiaries under intestacy laws can only access your CPF account information after you have passed away.

Knowledge Article: Question: With the GST increase, what is being done to help Singaporeans cushion the impact of premium increase?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Government has announced the enhanced Assurance Package for GST to cushion the impact of the planned GST increase for at least 5 years for most Singaporean households. This includes MediSave top-up of $150 each year from 2023 to 2025, for Singaporeans aged 20 years and below, or 55 years old and above, which may be used to offset the premium increase.   The Assurance Package for GST also includes cash payouts of $700 to $1,600 over five years, for all Singaporeans aged 21 years and above.   Older Singaporeans aged 65 and above, whose residential address is a property that does not exceed an Annual Value of $21,000 and who own only one property will also continue to receive an annual MediSave top-up of up to $450. This is beyond the transitional support covered by the Assurance Package.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I instruct CPF Board to allow person(s) who are neither my nominees nor family members who are eligible beneficiaries under intestacy laws, to access my CPF account information, after my death?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, you cannot instruct the Board to allow any other persons other than your nominees or family members who are eligible beneficiaries under intestacy laws to access your CPF account information, upon your demise.

Knowledge Article: Question: How are MediShield Life claim limits sized when more than one cancer drug is used in the treatment?
Knowledge Article: Answer: In general, the MediShield Life (MSHL) claim limits for cost-effective treatments are set based on the post-subsidy bills for subsidised patients in Public Healthcare Institutions (PHIs).   The Cancer Drug List (CDL) includes treatments that involve a single drug or multiple drugs (i.e. combination treatments). For combination treatments, the applicable MSHL claim limit depends on whether the combination treatment has been assessed to be cost-effective:   If the combination treatment is cost-effective , the MSHL claim limit is sized to be sufficient to cover the post-subsidy cost of the entire combination in PHIs. If the combination treatment is not cost-effective , it may be listed on the CDL subject to negotiations with the drug companies. However, the claim limit would be pegged to the highest individual claim limit of the drugs in the combination. Doctors and patients are encouraged to use treatments that have been assessed to be cost-effective.

Knowledge Article: Question: My Singapore Permanent Resident employee obtained his Singapore Citizenship in the middle of the month. When will the contribution rates for a Singapore Citizen apply?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF contribution rates for Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR) will apply on your employee’s wages until your employee obtains a Singapore Citizenship. Once your employee has obtained a Singapore Citizenship, the Singapore Citizen rates will apply. For Ordinary Wages (OW), you will need to pro-rate your employee’s OW and apply the appropriate rates to determine the CPF contributions. You can write to us for assistance on the computation if the Ordinary Wages for the month exceeds the Ordinary Wage ceiling or if the pro-rated wages are below $750. For Additional Wages (AW), you will need to apply the applicable contribution rate depending on when the AW is payable to your employee. Example   Assuming your employee is in the second year of Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR) status and becomes a Singapore Citizen on 15 June 2020. For OW   The second year SPR rate should be applied on the pro-rated wages for the period 1 June to 14 June 2020. The Singapore Citizen rate should be applied on the pro-rated wages for the period of 15 June to 30 June 2020. For AW   The second year SPR rate should be applied on the AW if it is payable between 1 June and 14 June 2020. The Singapore Citizen rate should be applied on the AW if it is payable between 15 June and 30 June 2020.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I stop the MediShield Life premium payment for a dependant's premium?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To stop paying MediShield Life premiums for your dependant(s), submit a Stop Payment for MediShield Life . Your dependant(s) will take over paying his/her own premium from the next policy year.   If your child is under 21 years old, you will not be able to submit an online stop payment request unless the child has sufficient savings in his/her MediSave Account, or another family member takes over the premium payment. Parents are responsible for their children's MediShield Life premiums until they turn 21 years old. If you have been discharged from the liability of maintaining your child after your divorce, please  write to us and provide the relevant court documents.   If you have questions, you can call us at 1800 222 3399 or write to us .

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I find out if I am covered under a medical insurance plan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You are covered under MediShield Life if you are a Singaporean or Permanent Resident.   If you are covered under an Integrated Shield Plan (IP), your premium payer will be notified by your private insurer with details about your premiums and subsidies. You will receive applicable subsidies for the MediShield Life portion of your IP, if you meet the eligibility criteria.   You can log in to Healthcare dashboard 'Coverage and premium details' to check the coverage and premium information for yourself and the dependant(s) you are paying premiums for.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are trailer fees?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Trailer fees are fees payable to distributors (including financial advisors) who sell the fund to the investors. The trailer fees are generally paid out from a fund’s annual management fees (which is part of the total expense ratio 1 ) by the fund manager or product provider to distributors. As such, trailer fees are not additional cost to end investors.     1 The expense ratio refers to the ongoing costs of operating a fund by fund managers/insurers expressed as a percentage of the fund's average net assets. Operating costs include investment management fees, trustee fees, and audit fees, etc.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is Wrap fee?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Wrap fee is an ongoing fee charged by a financial adviser to an investor, for providing bundled investment services, including advisory, brokerage and administrative. The fee is usually charged as a percentage on the market value of assets under management of the financial adviser.   Wrap fee is consumptive and erodes returns on investment funds. As CPF monies are meant for retirement and to prevent our members from paying excessive wrap fees, CPF Board has capped wrap fees at 0.4% per annum with effect from 1 October 2020. This is in line with the Board's continuing efforts to lower the cost of investment for our members.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I invest in Fixed Deposit in foreign currency under the CPF Investment Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Foreign currency Fixed Deposits are not included under the CPF Investment Scheme.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long does it take to process voluntary top-ups applications to my CPF accounts?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The application relating to voluntary top-ups to CPF accounts will be processed as stated in the table below.   Service Processing Time Top up CPF accounts Almost immediately If the top-up amount is not reflected in your CPF accounts, please check your CPF account balance after five working days as more time may be needed to process the transaction. Such cases are extremely rare and may arise due to intermittent network connectivity issues beyond CPF Board's control.   Please alert us immediately if your payment is still not updated in your CPF account balance after five working days.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am currently holding investments under the CPF Investment Scheme-Special Account (CPFIS-SA). Do I need to do anything?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You do not need to take any immediate action. You can continue to hold your existing CPFIS-SA investments until you decide to sell them or until they mature.   You can view your SA Portfolio by logging in to my cpf digital services with your Singpass > Select my cpf > My dashboards > Investment.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is there a limit on the file size for each submission via CPF EZPay (FTP)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For better performance, we have limited the file size to 2 mega-bytes. You will not be able to send the file if it exceeds the file size limit.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am aged 55 and above. What happens to my CPF Investment Scheme-Special Account after my Special Account is closed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are aged 55 and above, you can continue to hold your existing CPF Investment Scheme-Special Account (CPFIS-SA) investments until you decide to sell them or until they mature. Upon sale or maturity, your proceeds would be paid to your Retirement Account (RA) up to your Full Retirement Sum (FRS), with any remaining balance paid to your Ordinary Account (OA).   Before the closure of SA , CPF savings in SA can be used to invest after setting aside the FRS in your Retirement Account. With the closure of SA, your SA savings would be transferred to the OA once you have set aside the FRS in your RA and you can use them to invest under CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA).

Knowledge Article: Question: I have appointed authorised person (AP) in my nomination to access my CPF account information upon my demise, but I can no longer see the appointed AP under my nomination dashboard. Do I need to make a new nomination to appoint AP again?
Knowledge Article: Answer: From 1 February 2024, nominees and eligible family members under intestacy laws will be able to access your CPF account information after your passing.   This change brings greater convenience to members and makes it easier for their loved ones to settle matters relating to the deceased member’s CPF accounts.   Your appointed authorised persons will still be able to access your CPF account information upon your demise if they are your nominees or eligible family member. Else, your information will not be disclosed to them.

Knowledge Article: Question: How would I know if I would make a gain or loss if I were to sell my discounted Singtel shares now?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For sale of discounted Singtel shares, you can use the  weighted average cost (WAC) method to determine whether you would make a gain or loss.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am prescribed a drug that is not on the Cancer Drug List. Can I claim under the Cancer Drug Services Limit?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The cancer drug services limit is meant to cover ancillary services that patients may require as part of their cancer drug treatment.   If the drug you are prescribed is a supportive medication to manage the symptoms and side effects of your cancer drug treatment (e.g. antibiotics to reduce risk of infection, pain medication or anti-nausea medication), it is claimable under the Cancer Drug Services limit.   However, if the drug is used for the treatment of the cancer / tumour itself (e.g. chemotherapy, immunotherapy or targeted therapy), it should be claimed under the Cancer Drug Treatment limit instead. Cancer Drug Treatments that are not listed on the Cancer Drug List are not eligible for MediShield Life, MediSave and Integrated Shield Plan claims and should not be claimed under Cancer Drug Services limit.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why am I receiving a notice on potential vulnerabilities when I launch CPF Mobile?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To safeguard your data, CPF Mobile is equipped with security features to prevent scammers from accessing your CPF account. Access to CPF Mobile is disabled and a notice on potential vulnerabilities is displayed when we detect vulnerabilities such as malware from non-official app stores, risky apps, or jailbroken/rooted devices.   To address these potential vulnerabilities, you will need to remove malicious or risky apps from your device. You should be able to log in to CPF Mobile after doing so.   If the notice does not specify the app(s) affecting your access to CPF Mobile, you can find out which app to uninstall by scanning your device with V-Key Diagnostic app by V-Key Inc. This can be downloaded from the Apple App Store and Google Play Store . Upon running the V-Key Diagnostic app, a pop-up notification will appear if there are malicious apps installed on your mobile device.   If the notice indicates that CPF Mobile is being run on a virtual space, please remove CPF Mobile from the virtual space app. Reinstall CPF Mobile app outside of the virtual space and you should be able to launch it.   To better protect yourself, please only download apps from official app stores to avoid malware being installed. You can read up more on how to avoid falling prey to malware scams .   For further assistance, please write to us with a screenshot of the notice.

Knowledge Article: Question: What will happen to my CPF LIFE unused premium and interest when I pass away?
Knowledge Article: Answer: In the event of your passing, any CPF LIFE unused premium (i.e. CPF LIFE premium balance), together with your remaining CPF savings, will be refunded to your loved ones.   The interest on your CPF LIFE premium that has not been paid to you is pooled and goes towards providing monthly payouts for surviving CPF LIFE members. This is part and parcel of risk-pooling, similar to other types of insurance, and it ensures that all CPF LIFE members can receive payouts for as long as they live.

Knowledge Article: Question: When will I receive my CPF LIFE monthly payouts?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will receive the monthly payouts in your bank account generally by the fourth working day of the month. You will generally receive your payouts earlier if your bank supports Fast And Secure Transfer (FAST).

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I cancel my CPF LIFE plan after I have joined?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can only cancel your CPF LIFE plan if you are withdrawing your CPF savings for the following reasons.   You have a reduced life expectancy due to a medical condition, as certified by an accredited doctor . Severe medical conditions that cause you to be permanently unfit for work or to lack mental capacity permanently can also be considered. You have closed your CPF account as you are a non-Singapore Citizen or a non-Permanent Resident. You are fully exempted from setting aside the retirement sum in your Retirement Account because you are receiving a monthly pension / annuity payout.   Upon cancellation of your CPF LIFE plan, you will receive a refund of your CPF LIFE premium balance. If your CPF LIFE premium has been fully paid to you as monthly payouts, there will be no remaining premium balance to refund.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am going to start / I have started receiving my CPF LIFE monthly payouts. Can I still defer to receive higher payouts?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The latest age that you can defer your CPF LIFE monthly payouts to is 70. Your monthly payouts will increase by up to 7% for each year of deferral.   You can use the Plan my monthly payouts service to defer your payouts after 65, up to 70.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am reaching 65. What are the monthly payout options that I can choose from?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You have the flexibility to start receiving your monthly payouts anytime between 65 and 70. However, if you do not submit any instructions on your payouts by the time you turn 70, your monthly payouts will automatically start on your birthday month.    In addition, you may have some CPF savings which are withdrawable for your immediate needs. Instead of withdrawing the amount in a lump sum, you can consider the following: Use the withdrawable amount (in part or in full) to increase your monthly payouts; or Retain the savings in your CPF account to earn interest, and withdraw them when the need arises. If you choose to retain your CPF savings, any additional withdrawable savings from 65 in your Retirement Account will be transferred to your Ordinary Account in the month you start your payouts, for your future withdrawal.   Eligible members can use the Plan my monthly payouts service to find out more about their monthly payout details, provide their payout instructions and confirm their bank account details.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will my CPF LIFE monthly payouts be adjusted and when will payout adjustments be effected?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We want to ensure that your CPF LIFE monthly payouts are sustainable over the long term. As such, our actuarial consultant reviews them yearly and take into account the following:   Deviations in mortality experience. If more people live longer than expected in the long term, the monthly payouts might be lower, and vice versa. Deviations in interest rates. If interest rates are higher than expected, the monthly payouts might be higher, and vice versa. The revised payout, if any, will take effect every July of the year. We will notify you if there is an adjustment in your monthly payouts. Rest assured that any changes are expected to be small and gradual.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the latest age to join CPF LIFE?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are not automatically included in CPF LIFE , the latest age to join CPF LIFE is one month before you turn 80.   If you are automatically included in CPF LIFE, find out when you have to choose your CPF LIFE plan .

Knowledge Article: Question: I am on CPF LIFE even though I am a foreigner. Can I continue to keep my CPF LIFE Plan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The purpose of the CPF system is to help Singapore Citizens (SC) and Permanent Residents (PR) retire with peace of mind. In line with this, CPF members who are not SC or PR will have to close their CPF accounts and their participation in CPF schemes such as CPF LIFE will cease.   You may close your CPF account and transfer your CPF savings to your bank account at any time. If you do not do so by 31 March 2024, your CPF account will be automatically closed in April 2024.   Find out more about closing your CPF accounts .

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I defer the start of my CPF LIFE monthly payouts beyond 70?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The purpose of CPF savings is to provide members with monthly payouts in their retirement. Hence, you will have to start your CPF LIFE monthly payouts, including any Additional Monthly Payouts (AMP), latest by age 70.   We understand that some members think of their savings in CPF as an investment to enjoy the interest rates. If you have no immediate need for the payouts, you can consider investing them outside the CPF system. Do note that investing outside of CPF carries a certain level of risk and requires careful consideration.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am currently under CPF LIFE and have deferred my monthly payouts. What should I do if I want to change my payout start age?
Knowledge Article: Answer: It depends on whether you are starting your payouts at an earlier age or later age.   For members who want to start payouts at an earlier age If you wish to receive your payouts earlier (for example, currently deferred and will start at age 69, but wants to start at age 67 instead), please let us know only one month before your desired payout start date, and not anytime earlier, via the Plan my monthly payouts service. For members who want to start payouts at a later age We will send you a notification three months before your original payout start date. If you prefer to delay your payouts to a later age (for example, currently deferred and will start at age 68, but wants to start at age 69 instead), you can submit your request via the Plan my monthly payouts service when you receive the notification.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use the CPF planner - retirement income if I am self-employed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you can. The CPF planner - retirement income can be used by all CPF members of the relevant age groups . You can input your monthly net taxable income (NTI) under the monthly salary field. Please note that the projections are based on employee/employer contributions from employment using the salary figures provided. Hence, there may be some limitations to the projections for self-employed members.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am currently receiving Additional Monthly Payout (AMP). Will my AMP be converted to higher CPF LIFE monthly payouts automatically?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will continue to receive Additional Monthly Payout (AMP).   Starting from November 2021, any new Retirement Account inflows will automatically be used to increase your CPF LIFE premium. This will allow you to receive higher monthly payouts for life, providing you with greater financial security during your retirement years.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I request a higher CPF LIFE monthly payout based on my current Retirement Account balance?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If there are no new inflows into your Retirement Account (RA), we are unable to increase your CPF LIFE monthly payout. This is because CPF LIFE payouts are determined by an independent actuarial consultant based on various factors, including your RA savings used to join CPF LIFE.   Find out how changes to your RA can affect your monthly payouts

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to my CPF nomination if I lose mental capacity after making my nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your CPF nomination will not be affected and remains valid even after you lose mental capacity.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I make or revoke a CPF nomination on someone's behalf?
Knowledge Article: Answer: A CPF nomination must be made or revoked by the CPF member personally.   However, if a CPF member lacks capacity under Section 4 of the Mental Capacity Act ("MCA"), only the Courts are allowed to make or revoke a CPF nomination on behalf of the member.   An interested party can apply to the Court to do so, and the court would decide in the interest of the member who is lacking capacity, whether to accept the application to make or revoke a CPF nomination on his behalf.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much Singtel dividends did I receive in 2022?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Singtel declared and paid dividends in January, August and December. If you had discounted Singtel shares in your CPF account during these periods, you would have received Singtel’s dividends in your Ordinary Account. Please check your CPF statement.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I appoint someone to make or revoke my CPF nomination on my behalf before I lose mental capacity?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No. Only the Court is allowed to make or revoke a CPF nomination on behalf of the member, under Section 4 of the Mental Capacity Act 2008.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is there revised criteria for new funds under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Currently, new funds applying for admission under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) are evaluated based on a number of factors such as the capability of the fund managers, the investment philosophy of the fund, its key decision makers, the appropriateness and quality of its research and analysis, its portfolio construction and implementation, and its past performance. While this screening mechanism has helped to ensure a minimum standard for the funds under the CPFIS, more stringent criteria have been introduced so that funds under the CPFIS would better meet the objectives of CPFIS, which is to help members invest for the long-term for financial security in old age. In addition to setting a higher evaluation benchmark based on the current screening mechanism, the Board will also consider the funds' expense ratio. The latter will help lower the investment cost for members over the longer term. Funds submitted for admission under the CPFIS should also preferably have a performance track record of at least 3 years as this will allow the Board to better assess whether the funds are able to give consistently good performance against the benchmark.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the different evaluation factors for admission into CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) under the old and new entry criteria?
Knowledge Article: Answer: New funds will continue to be evaluated according to existing evaluation factors. However, new funds will have to meet a higher benchmark, and henceforth funds admitted to CPF Investment Scheme will be among the top 25 percentile of funds. In addition, new funds will have to meet an expense ratio criterion pegged at the median of all funds in the same risk class. New funds should preferably also have a track record of at least 3-years.     Supplementary Information   The specific aspects of the investment process that are looked at during the evaluation process for Unit Trusts and Investment-Linked Insurance Policies include the following: Investment Philosophy; Key Decision Makers; Research and Analysis; Portfolio Construction; Implementation/Trading; and Past Performance.

Knowledge Article: Question: How are the new Total Expense Ratio (TER) caps determined?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The new Total Expense Ratio (TER) caps are determined based on the FY2012 median TERs (for the relevant risk categories) of CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) List A funds, and taking into account industry feedback. Median TERs were also used in 2008 when CPF Board first implemented TER caps for funds under the CPFIS.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is CPF Board reducing the Total Expense Ratio (TER) caps?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Reducing the Total Expense Ratio caps is part of CPF Board's continuous efforts to lower the cost of investing under the CPF Investment Scheme. This would help enhance returns, hence enable CPF members who have invested in the fund to accumulate their retirement savings faster.

Knowledge Article: Question: What proportion of funds applying for admission into CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) has been successful? What is the target under the revised criteria?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Fund managers would generally assess the quality of their funds using the published CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) evaluation criteria before applying for inclusion under CPFIS. Thus far, funds within the top 50 percentile in their global peer group 1 have been successful in their application for admission into CPFIS, and the majority of funds that have applied for admission into CPFIS have been admitted. New funds will need to meet a higher criterion - i.e. they must be among the top 25 percentile of funds. Going forward, we do not expect a significant change in the success rate of application as managers would continue to assess the quality of their funds against the CPFIS evaluation criteria before application. 1 This refers to comparison of funds of similar asset class/strategy on a world-wide basis.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I increase or decrease the premiums to be paid for my Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme (ASPFAIS) Part V insurance policies?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Academic Staff Provident Fund (ASPF) members are not allowed to make any changes to their Part V insurance policies that will cause an increase in premiums with effect from 28 December 2006 (i.e. the date that National University Singapore issued the official "Dissolution Notice" to all its members). However, if the increase in premiums is due to attained age at renewal of the policies 1 , or conversion of the policies 2 , you can use your CPF monies to pay the higher premium. ASPF members can make any changes to their Part V insurance policies that will result in a decrease in premiums, as long as the insurance companies allow it. 1 When a member exceeds a certain age, he may have to pay a higher premium to renew his insurance policy. In such an instance, he can continue to use his CPF monies to pay the higher premiums. 2 A member's insurance policy contract may allow him to convert: (1) a rider to a new whole life policy, endowment policy or investment-linked insurance product (ILP); or (2) a whole life policy to an endowment policy or vice versa.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can a patient claim for cancer drug services from the Cancer Drug Services limit if he is receiving a treatment that is not on the Cancer Drug List?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, patients may claim for cancer drug services from the annual Cancer Drug Services limit even if the service was rendered for a cancer treatment not on the Cancer Drug List (CDL) (i.e. the claim limit is not specific to treatments on the CDL).

Knowledge Article: Question: Can a patient claim for cancer drug services from the Cancer Drug Services limit if he is receiving a treatment that is not on the Cancer Drug List?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, patients may claim for cancer drug services from the annual Cancer Drug Services limit even if the service was rendered for a cancer treatment not on the Cancer Drug List (CDL) (i.e. the claim limit is not specific to treatments on the CDL).

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I take a policy loan on my Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme (ASPFAIS) Part V insurance policy?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Policy loans are not allowed for Part V insurance policies under the CPF Investment Scheme.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I pledge my Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme (ASPFAIS) Part V insurance policy?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Pledging of Part V insurance policies is not allowed under the CPF Investment Scheme.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can my insurance policy continue to run on Automatic Premium Loan (APL) and/or Extended Term Insurance (ETI) after the transfer to CPF Investment Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Automatic Premium Loan and Extended Term Insurance are allowed to continue after the transfer of your Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme (ASPFAIS) Part V insurance policy to CPF Investment Scheme.

Knowledge Article: Question: How may I repay the Automatic Premium Loan (APL) of my Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme (ASPFAIS) Part V insurance policy?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may repay the Automatic Premium Loan (APL) by paying cash to the insurance company directly. The cash balance in your CPF Investment Scheme Investment Account cannot be used to repay the APL.
