Knowledge Article: Question: What happens if the CPF Board finds out that the CPF nomination was made whilst the member lacked capacity?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If the Board is informed of any facts or circumstances which may affect the validity of the CPF nomination and has evidence and supporting documents to ascertain the fact that the member lacked capacity at the time of making the CPF nomination, the Board will invalidate the CPF nomination made by such a member.   Anyone, who is of the view that the CPF nomination is invalid on the grounds that the member lacked capacity at the time the said CPF nomination was made, could also apply to Court to set aside the nomination.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I change the life insured under my Part V insurance policy under Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme (ASPFAIS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The life insured must be the CPF member whose CPF savings are used to pay premiums.

Knowledge Article: Question: When should I invest in broadly diversified investments and when should I invest in narrowly focused investments?
Knowledge Article: Answer: After you have made your decision on how much to invest in the three basic types of investments: cash, bonds and stocks (i.e. based on the amount of equity risk you are comfortable with), for most CPF members, investing in broadly diversified investments within that equity risk category should generally help minimise investment risk. In other words, investing in broadly diversified investments should help reduce risk compared with investing in narrowly focused investments in the same equity risk category.   However, there could also be reasons for investing in narrowly focused investments. You enjoy riskier investments, even when the odds are not necessarily in your favour. You are happy to take on the extra downside risk of not diversifying because of the potential for higher returns, although you are aware that a positive result is not guaranteed.   For investments in the same equity risk category, it is reasonable to expect potential rewards over the long term to be very roughly the same for both a broadly diversified investment and a narrowly focused investment. However, you may want to accept the higher downside risk of a narrowly focused investment if you think that a narrowly focused investment may give better results in the short term.   For example, if you are confident about the recovery of the Japanese economy in the short term, you may wish to invest in a Japan focused unit trust even though this unit trust has higher risk than a better diversified global equity unit trust.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the criteria for inclusion of Gold Exchange Traded Funds (ETFs) under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: In considering the inclusion of Gold Exchange Traded Funds (ETFs) under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS), the Board uses the following criteria:   The gold ETF is backed by physical gold that meets the London Good Delivery Rules issued by London Bullion Market Association (or other equivalent globally accepted standards); The gold ETF is offered by a Singapore-incorporated company (for locally constituted gold ETF authorized by MAS) or through a local representative (for foreign gold ETF recognized by MAS); The gold ETF is listed on the SGX; and The company allows Agent Banks to appoint all CPF unitholders of the gold ETF as proxies to attend and vote at meetings.   What are the criteria for a local representative to offer foreign Gold ETF?   The criteria for a local representative to offer foreign Gold ETF are:   Must be a company incorporated in Singapore; Must provide CPF Board a copy of the representative agreement evidencing the appointment of the representative by the foreign gold ETF issuer or marketing agent; Provide evidence of indemnity mechanism (such as back-to-back agreement) put in place between the representative and the foreign issuer/marketing agent, allowing the representative to have recourse to the foreign issuer/marketing agent if the latter does not discharge its duties, obligations and responsibilities with due care and in good faith; Have good regulatory compliance record in Singapore; and  Have sound financial position.   Which Gold ETFs are included under the CPFIS?   List of Gold ETFs included under the CPFIS:   SPDR Gold Shares (under SGX trading name "GLD US$" and "GLD SG$")

Knowledge Article: Question: How does CPF Board ensure that changes to CPF nomination of members who lack mental capacity, are done in their best interest?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The treatment of CPF nominations has been aligned with that of wills under the Mental Capacity Act 2008 (MCA).   Safeguards are in place under the MCA as the Court in making decisions on behalf of a member who lacks capacity, has to take into account what is in the member's "best interests". This includes taking into consideration the member's past and present wishes and feelings, his beliefs and values that would likely influence his decision if he had the mental capacity. The Court will also have to take into account the views from persons who were close to the member.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will I receive any notifications after the transfer of my investments from my Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme to CPF Investment Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will receive a letter from your agent bank, informing you of the details of the investments being transferred from your Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme (ASPFAIS) Investment Account to your CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) Investment Account. You will also receive a letter from National University of Singapore after the transfer. You can also view your Special Account (SA) investment holdings (combination of ASPFAIS-SA and CPFIS-SA) in your SA portfolio statement anytime using your Singpass via my cpf digital services .

Knowledge Article: Question: Apart from Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS), how else can parents set aside money for their child under the CPF system?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Parents can also set aside money for their child by topping up to the Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS) nominee's CPF accounts based on current CPF rules. These top-up monies will enjoy CPF interest rates and will be set aside specifically for the child's retirement needs instead of being disbursed under the SNSS.   For parents who are under the CPF LIFE scheme, and have made a Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS) nomination, they can opt not to receive their monthly CPF LIFE payouts, and retain the monies in their Retirement Account (RA).   To do so, members can inform the Board of their intention in writing at least 2 months before their Payout Eligibility Age (PEA) or anytime after they have reached their PEA. In the request, members should indicate their name, NRIC number, signature and their intention to retain their CPF LIFE payouts in their CPF Retirement Accounts (RA) for the benefit of their SNSS nominee(s).

Knowledge Article: Question: After the merger of Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme (ASPFAIS) and CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS), will the transfer be reflected in any of my CPFIS statements?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The transfer will be reflected through the change to the net amount withdrawn .  Your net amount withdrawn under the Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme - Ordinary Account (ASPFAIS-OA) will be merged with your net amount withdrawn under the CPF Investment Scheme - Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA).  A footnote will be permanently shown in your "CPFIS Stock & Gold Limits Computation" statement, informing you of the amount transferred from your ASPFAIS-OA. For your investments made under Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme -Special Account (ASPFAIS-SA), they will be transferred to your CPF Investment Scheme - Special Account (CPFIS-SA). You are able to view your combined investment holdings in your SA portfolio statement.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I cancel the payment after I have confirmed the payment utilising my GovCash on the LifeSG mobile app?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, your GovCash balance will be deducted upon successful payment.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I know if the merchants allow me to make purchases using my GovCash?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can only make purchases using GovCash at merchants that accept PayNow/NETS QR code using the LifeSG app. You can look out for the PayNow/NETS logo on the SG QR label that is displayed by the merchants.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is there a specific time frame for me to withdraw/utilise my GovCash?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can choose to withdraw/utilise your GovCash at your convenience. However, you are encouraged to withdraw/utilise your GovCash as the intent of the scheme is to supplement your income and retirement savings.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can both parents nominate the same child with disabilities?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Both parents of an eligible child with disabilities can participate in the Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS). The child with disabilities will then receive separate streams of payout from each parent’s CPF savings upon the parent’s demise.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I help a beneficiary with medical condition (e.g. physically immobile or mentally incapacitated) to withdraw their GovCash monies?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can help a beneficiary with medical condition (e.g. who is physically immobile or mentally incapacitated) to withdraw their GovCash monies if you are:   Aged 21 years and above; and A next-of-kin, or caregiver, or appointed donee under the Lasting Power of Attorney (LPA), or court-appointed Deputy of the beneficiary To help with the withdrawal of the GovCash monies, please bring the following documents and visit any OCBC-New ATM during branch operating hours, where OCBC Digital Ambassadors will be available to render assistance: a) Original documentary evidence stating the beneficiary's medical condition (e.g. doctor's memorandum, medical report or court order). The date of the document(s) should not be more than 1 year from the withdrawal date, unless it specifically states that the patient's condition is permanent or the condition is known to be permanent (e.g. bedridden, immobile, physically incapacitated, disabled, intellectually disabled, autism, down syndrome, cerebral palsy, etc); b) A photocopy of the beneficiary’s NRIC; c) Your original NRIC; and d) Beneficiary’s GovCash Payment Reference Number (PRN)   You may be required to sign a Letter of Indemnity at the bank, witnessed by the bank officer.

Knowledge Article: Question: How fast can a Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS) nominee receive the fund into their bank account after the death of member?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For Special Needs Savings Scheme cases, the payment will commence in the following month upon receipt of the completed application form and supporting documents. The payment is generally processed on the 12th of every month until the monies due to the nominee are exhausted.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is there a need to fill in the policy number and claim number of my employee/platform worker/insured in the E-File excel file for the MediSave/MediShield Life Internet Reimbursement?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The policy number and claim number fields were added in response to companies’ requests to track their MediSave/MediShield Life Internet Reimbursement submissions and correlate with their records. These two   fields are not compulsory.

Knowledge Article: Question: What will happen to my stock & gold investment limits arising from the merger of Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme and CPF Investment Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme stock & gold investment limits will be merged with your CPF Investment Scheme stock & gold investment limits.

Knowledge Article: Question: After the transfer of my Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme investments to CPF Investment Scheme, what will happen to the sale proceeds if I subsequently sell those investments?
Knowledge Article: Answer: All the sale proceeds will be refunded to your CPF Accounts. You can subsequently withdraw the monies subject to CPF withdrawal rules.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why do I need to open a CPF Investment Scheme Investment Account now to 'hold' my Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme (ASPFAIS) Investment?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Academic Staff Provident Fund (ASPF) Part V Scheme does not fall under the purview of the ASPF Investment Scheme. Under the ASPF Part V Scheme, the policies were bought under the name of National University Singapore (NUS). NUS had been paying the premiums directly to the insurance companies, after deducting the monies from members' ASPF Ordinary Accounts, without going through the agent banks. As the CPF Board does not have such a scheme, Part V insurance policies have to be transferred to the CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA) instead. Under the CPFIS-OA, you need to have a CPFIS Investment Account to hold your investments, including the transferred Part V insurance policies.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my CPF monies to service the premiums of my Part V Insurance Policy under Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme (ASPFAIS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use your CPF monies in your Ordinary Account to service the future premiums of your policies (including endowment, whole life or rider policies, and regular premium policies).

Knowledge Article: Question: How will the new Cancer Drug Treatment benefit under MediShield Life and MediSave impact my claims from 1 September 2022?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediShield Life and MediSave will only cover treatments on the Cancer Drug List (CDL) from 1 September 2022. Each cancer drug treatment on the CDL will have its own MediShield Life claim limits and MediSave withdrawal limits.   You may refer to the CDL  for the list of cancer drug treatments that are claimable under MediShield Life and MediSave, and their respective claim and withdrawal limits. Please consult your doctor if you wish to find out whether the treatment that you are currently undergoing is on the CDL.   The CDL will only come into effect for Integrated Shield Plans (IPs) on 1 April 2023, upon renewal or application. If you have an IP, you will continue to be covered under your current policy terms until it is renewed on or after 1 April 2023.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will the new Cancer Drug Treatment benefit under MediShield Life and MediSave impact my claims from 1 September 2022?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediShield Life and MediSave will only cover treatments on the Cancer Drug List (CDL) from 1 September 2022. Each cancer drug treatment on the CDL will have its own MediShield Life claim limits and MediSave withdrawal limits.   You may refer to the CDL  for the list of cancer drug treatments that are claimable under MediShield Life and MediSave, and their respective claim and withdrawal limits. Please consult your doctor if you wish to find out whether the treatment that you are currently undergoing is on the CDL.   The CDL will only come into effect for Integrated Shield Plans (IPs) on 1 April 2023, upon renewal or application. If you have an IP, you will continue to be covered under your current policy terms until it is renewed on or after 1 April 2023.

Knowledge Article: Question: How is Special Needs Savings Scheme different from CPF nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Unlike a CPF nomination, where the member’s CPF savings are distributed in one lump sum, CPF savings under Special Needs Savings Scheme will be distributed to the nominee on a monthly basis, based on the amount specified by the CPF member, until the bequeathed savings run out.   This enables parents to set aside CPF savings for the long term care of children with special needs.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if my wrap account currently charges me a wrap fee of more than 0.4% per annum?
Knowledge Article: Answer: With effect from 1 October 2020, your wrap fee payable will be capped at 0.4% per annum. You should contact your financial adviser or Investment Administrators if you continue to pay more than the capped rate after 1 October 2020.

Knowledge Article: Question: What type of investor will be affected by the wrap fee cap?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The wrap fee cap will affect CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) investors who have wrap accounts with any of the 4 CPFIS-included Investment Administrators.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have transferred money from Investment Account back into my CPF Ordinary Account. When does the CPF interest computation start?
Knowledge Article: Answer: When you transfer money from your Investment Account to your Ordinary Account, you will start to earn CPF interest on the transferred amount from the following month onwards.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will my CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) investments be sold or liquidated when I apply to withdraw my CPFIS investments upon meeting CPF withdrawal conditions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Applying to withdraw your CPFIS investments will not result in liquidation of your investment holdings. If your withdrawal application is approved, your agent bank and/or product providers will contact you on the transfer of your investments to you.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I find out my own profit/loss on CPF Investment Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may refer to the portfolio statement sent to you by your agent bank or your product provider. If you have sold your investments, the difference between the cost and sale proceeds is your profit/loss. If you have not sold your investments, the difference between the cost and market value is your profit/loss.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I withdraw my investment profits?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Profits made from investments under the CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account and/or CPF Investment Scheme-Special Account are not withdrawable as the purpose of investing is to grow your savings for retirement. However, the profits can be used for other CPF schemes, subject to the terms and conditions of these schemes.

Knowledge Article: Question: I would like to change how much my child can receive monthly under the Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS), how can I make the change?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Under the Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS), parents can revise the monthly payout by submitting a new nomination indicating the new amount.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are my investment profits, interest earned from investments and dividends received taxable?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your investment profits, interest earned from investments and dividends are not taxable under the CPF Investment Scheme.

Knowledge Article: Question: What does the CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA) Total Profits/Losses statistic measure?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA) Total Profits/Losses statistic provides a complete representation of the investors total portfolio performance. It takes into account not only the realised profits or losses of investments that were sold, but also the unrealised profits or losses of investments that members held during the reporting period.

Knowledge Article: Question: What constitutes "offences" under the CPF Investment Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Manipulating investment transactions so that a member may siphon his CPF savings in cash thereby withdrawing the savings prematurely, is an offence under CPF Investment Scheme.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much MediSave can I use for my outpatient treatments of chronic diseases?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use up to $700 (for patients with complex chronic conditions) or $500 (for patients with non-complex chronic conditions) yearly per patient from your MediSave or your approved dependants' MediSave.   Approved dependants refer to your spouse, children, parents, grandchildren and siblings. To use your grandchildren's or siblings' MediSave, you must be a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident.

Knowledge Article: Question: How are manipulative investment transactions detected?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF Board continually monitors the trend of various CPF Investment Scheme transactions. The Singapore Exchange also monitors irregularities in share transactions. Transactions that look suspicious are referred to the Commercial Affairs Department for investigation.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will I run the risk of unknowingly breaching CPF laws while trading or investing under the CPF Investment Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As long as your intention is to invest for the medium to long term, and you did not siphon out any CPF savings by receiving cash for your investment transactions whether through manipulated transaction prices or cash rebates, it is unlikely that you will breach the CPF laws for manipulative transactions.

Knowledge Article: Question: Arising from the merger of Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme and CPF Investment Scheme, do I need to inform my broker or any of the product providers of my new CPF Investment Account number?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your agent bank will inform the respective product providers, except stockbrokers, of your new Investment Account number. Agent banks would not be able to inform the stockbrokers on your behalf because agent banks do not know which stockbrokers you have trading accounts with. You will need to inform all your stockbrokers about your new CPF Investment Scheme Investment Account number. If your stockbrokers use the outdated investment account number, your CPF trades will fail and you will need to settle your trades using cash.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the sequence of disbursement for Special Needs Saving Scheme's monthly payout from CPF account? (i.e. which of the deceased's CPF account will be disbursed first?)
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF savings nominated under Special Needs Savings Scheme will be paid via monthly payouts, starting from the lowest interest earning account, i.e. the Nominee Ordinary Account (NOA) first before moving to Nominee Special Account (NSA) and then Nominee Retirement Account (NRA).

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I transfer my CPF Investment Account under CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account from one agent bank to another? If so, must I sell my investments first?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may transfer your CPF Investment Account from one agent bank to another. You need not sell your investments, except for your investment in gold bought from your agent bank (excluding gold Exchange Traded Funds). All your investments and cash balances will be transferred along with your CPF Investment Account. To transfer your CPF Investment Account, you need to apply at the bank which you intend to transfer your account to.

Knowledge Article: Question: Who should I contact if I want to know more information on the Special Needs Savings Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may contact the Special Needs Trust Company (SNTC) who is the appointed scheme administrator.   Parents can visit SNTC’s SNSS website . Alternatively, SNTC can be contacted via phone at 6278 9598 or via email at enquiries@sntc.org.sg for more information.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can parents cancel their Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS) nomination after making one?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Parents can cancel their Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS) nomination by making a new CPF nomination.   The new nomination will supersede the SNSS nomination which they have made earlier.   To make a nomination, you can do so online using your Singpass.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I close my CPF Investment Account under CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will have to sell all your investments first before instructing your agent bank to close your CPF Investment Account.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to pay accrued interest if I used my CPF savings for CPF investments?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You do not need to pay back the accrued interest on the CPF savings used for your CPF investments.

Knowledge Article: Question: If there are adjustments under CPF Investment Scheme in my Ordinary or Special Account, what interest rate will be used?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Any adjustments under the CPF Investment Scheme in your Ordinary or Special Account will be based on the CPF interest rates for the respective account. The interest rate will not include the extra 1% interest that is paid on the first $60,000 of your combined balances.

Knowledge Article: Question: What interest rates will be paid on the monies for Special Needs Savings Scheme nominees?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The nominated monies will continue to earn the same CPF interest, including extra interest, in the SNSS nominee’s account, as the rate earned by CPF members.   Extra interest is paid on the first $60,000 of the combined balance of the parent(s) who nominated the child under SNSS and the child’s own CPF savings, with up to $20,000 from the child’s Ordinary Account.   Please refer to CPF interest rates for more information on the CPF interest rates.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens when I sell my discounted Singtel shares?
Knowledge Article: Answer: When you sell your discounted Singtel shares, the sale proceeds will be refunded to your CPF Ordinary Account and form part of your CPF savings.

Knowledge Article: Question: Where can I find more information on Singtel's Scrip Dividend Scheme, as announced by Singtel on 12 November 2020?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For financial year ending 31 March 2021, Singtel has paid interim dividend at dividend rate of $0.051 per share. The scrip shares were offered at $2.422 per share. For more information, please visit the  Singtel website .   If you had opted for scrip shares, the number of scrip shares issued to you, in respect of your shareholdings as at 27 November 2020 (‘Record Date’), was calculated as follows: Number of scrip shares issued = Number of discounted Singtel shares (at Record Date) x Dividend rate Issue price of scrip share

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the MOE Post-Secondary Education Account (PSEA)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Post-Secondary Education Account (PSEA) is part of the Post-Secondary Education Scheme to help parents save for their children’s post-secondary education. The PSEA is administered by MOE and is opened automatically for all eligible Singaporeans.   Funds in your Post-Secondary Education Account (PSEA) can be used to pay for your own or your siblings’ approved programmes in MOE's list of approved institutions .   It can also be used to repay approved financing schemes such as loans under the CPF Education Loan Scheme and MOE Tuition Fee Loan taken for studies in autonomous universities, polytechnics, ITE (Diploma), and art institutions.   To check your PSEA fund balance, you can call the MOE’s 24-hour automated PSEA hotline at 62600777 to check your balance. Latest PSEA balance information will be updated every Wednesday.   Closure of PSEA The PSEA will be closed around the middle of the year in which you turn 31. Any unused funds in the PSEA will be transferred to your CPF-OA. Once transferred to CPF-OA, it cannot be reversed to PSEA and will be subjected to CPF-OA usage rules.   For student who took up CPF Education Loan or MOE Tuition Fee Loan to finance their education, you may consider using PSEA funds to repay your outstanding education loan before it’s transferred to your CPF-OA.   Alternatively, you can opt to transfer the balance to your sibling’s existing PSEA (if applicable) when you receive the transfer option letter from MOE in the year you turn 31 years old.   For more information on PSEA, please visit MOE PSEA website

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the MOE Tuition Fee Loan (TFL)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Students in polytechnics and autonomous universities can apply for the MOE Tuition Fee Loan (TFL) to cover a portion of their tuition fee. Click on the image below for a quick guide on MOE TFL.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF Education Loan Scheme is a loan scheme which allows you to use your Ordinary Account (OA) savings to pay for your own, children’s, spouse’s, siblings' or relatives' subsidised tuition fees.   Only full-time subsidised diploma??/degree courses at Approved Educational Institutions (AEIs) are covered under this loan scheme. The student would need to start repaying the principal amount withdrawn plus the accrued interest in cash, to your CPF account, one year after graduation or termination of studies, whichever is earlier.   If the institution or course does not fall under this scheme, you and the student can consider taking up a loan with the commercial banks or approaching the institution for other financial assistance options.

Knowledge Article: Question: What courses are covered by the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Only approved full-time courses that are subsidised by the Ministry of Education (MOE) and conducted locally at the approved educational institutions are covered by the CPF Education Loan Scheme. To determine your eligibility for the MOE subsidy, please check directly with your educational institution that you will be enrolling with.   Undergraduate Courses   The CPF Education Loan Scheme covers all approved full-time subsidised undergraduate courses leading to a degree at the following institutions:   Nanyang Technological University (NTU)*, National University of Singapore (NUS), Singapore Management University (SMU), Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT)*, Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD), Singapore University of Social Sciences (SUSS), Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts (NAFA)*, LASALLE College of the Arts (LAS)*. *The approved degree programmes offered by these institutions in partnership with local or overseas universities are also included under the CPF Education Loan Scheme.   Diploma Courses   The CPF Education Loan Scheme covers approved full-time subsidised diploma courses at:   LASALLE College of the Arts (LAS), Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts (NAFA), Nanyang Polytechnic (NYP), Ngee Ann Polytechnic (NP), Republic Polytechnic (RP), Singapore Polytechnic (SP), Temasek Polytechnic (TP), Institute of Technical Education (for students pursuing an approved Technical Engineer Diploma (TED) or a Technical Diploma)*. *The approved diploma programmes offered by these institutions in partnership with overseas universities are also included under the CPF Education Loan Scheme.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to pay additional fees due to trailer fees disclosure by my product/service providers? Is there any action required of me (as a CPFIS investor)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You do not need to pay any additional fees. No action is required from you (as a CPFIS investor) given that trailer fees are paid by the fund manager or product provider to distributors.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to the deceased member's CPF savings used for CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If the deceased member’s CPF savings had been used under the CPF Education Loan Scheme for himself or someone else, the withdrawn monies, including accrued interest, do not have to be refunded to his account.

Knowledge Article: Question: Who can I approach if I want to know more on the trailer fees of the CPF Investment Scheme products?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can approach your product/service provider or financial advisors for more information on trailer fees.

Knowledge Article: Question: I intend to take a loan to finance my education and I will repay it promptly upon my graduation. Which is better for me - the MOE Tuition Fee Loan (TFL) or CPF Education Loan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The MOE Tuition Fee Loan (TFL) is a better option as it is interest-free during the course of study, unlike the CPF loan where interest starts to accrue from the time of withdrawal. This means that if you repay the loan fully right after graduation, you will not incur any interest at all for the MOE TFL. For scenarios comparing the two loans, please refer to the following document:   Comparing the CPF Education Loan Scheme and MOE Tuition Fee Loan If you are unable to repay your MOE TFL due to further studies or financial difficulties due to unemployment or medical condition, you may appeal to defer repayment and interest. Your appeal will be considered on a case-by-case basis. While CPF may also allow for deferment in challenging times, the interest continues to accrue as it is essential to completely restore the savings meant primarily for retirement. For more information on the MOE TFL, please refer to this link .

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) admission criteria for funds?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The admission criteria for the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) funds are:   Top quartile of global peer group Total Expense Ratio lower than the median of CPFIS funds in respective risk class 0% sales charge Preferably track record of 3 years These criteria aims to raise the quality and lower cost of investments for funds included under the CPFIS. You can refer to the reports on the performance of the CPFIS funds.

Knowledge Article: Question: How does CPF Board currently assess whether funds admitted are still suitable to remain in CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: When determining if a product is suitable to be under CPF Investment Scheme, the emphasis so far has been on past performance and the competency of its investment professionals. Re-evaluation will be required for Fund Management Companies/Funds that have undergone material changes in the organisational structure, fund structure or management team.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the alternative options available to finance my tuition fee besides the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Besides the CPF Education Loan Scheme, there are  other ways to finance a tertiary education in Singapore. You may want to consider the following factors when deciding on the best option to finance your studies:   Eligibility There are different eligibility criteria for each financing option. For example, in order to be eligible for the MOE Tuition Fee Loan, an applicant needs to be a recipient of the MOE Tuition Grant. For more information on your eligibility, you may refer to the relevant websites (for example, MOE and banks) that provide details of the various financing options.   Amount of coverage for tuition fee The various financing options may not cover up to 100% of your tuition fee. You may want to refer to the respective website of the various financing options to find out how much coverage is provided for your tuition fee.   Rate of interest The rate of interest varies across different loans, so you may want to compare the rate of interest to find out which loan is most suitable for you. It is also important to know when interest will start accruing for your loan. For example, for the MOE Tuition Fee Loan, there is no interest accrued during the course of your study; whereas for the CPF Education Loan scheme, interest starts to accrue as soon as the CPF savings is deducted from a member’s account.   Repayment It is important to know when you are expected to start the repayment of your tuition fee loan and how you will finance the repayment of your tuition fee loan (i.e. minimum monthly repayment amount). You may also want to compare the maximum repayment period for each loan.   Find out whether MOE Tuition Fee Loan or CPF Education Loan is better for you .

Knowledge Article: Question: What can members do if the funds in which they have already invested do not meet the new standards set by the Board following re-evaluation?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Members who have already invested in such funds can continue to remain invested in the funds, or consider switching to other funds or selling out of the funds if the funds no longer meet their investment objective.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why do I need to provide the NRIC or a unique identification number of my nominees in my CPF nomination form?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The NRIC or a unique identification number of your nominees will facilitate the Board's identification of your nominees which allow them to claim your CPF savings swiftly and easily.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why do I need to provide the NRIC or a unique identification number of my nominees in my CPF nomination form?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The NRIC or a unique identification number of your nominees will facilitate the Board's identification of your nominees which allow them to claim your CPF savings swiftly and easily.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will this harmonisation affect the funds included under CPF Investment Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: All CPF Investment Scheme funds that have not met the stricter admission criteria and that wish to be able to take in new CPF monies from 1 January 2011 need to be re-evaluated.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are directors who receive director fees covered under Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No. Under the Income Tax Act, directors of companies are considered as “employee” for income tax purposes. Directors’ fees are therefore taxable as employment income and would not be covered under Contribute As You Earn.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will the re-evaluation affect the funds that I am holding under the CPF Investment Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Re-evaluation will not affect the funds that you are holding. However if by  December 2010, the funds which you are holding do not meet the stricter criteria, or if your Fund Management Company (FMC) / insurer chooses not to have the funds re-evaluated, you will not be able to purchase more units of such funds with your CPF monies.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is it compulsory to keep switching funds under the CPF Investment Scheme if the funds which I am holding do not meet the stricter criteria?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can opt to hold on to your existing funds without switching.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will I know whether the funds that I am holding under the CPF Investment Scheme do not meet the stricter criteria by December 2010?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If the funds do not meet the stricter criteria by December 2010, the respective Fund Management Company(FMC)/insurer will be required to inform their CPF clients in writing, and to offer their clients three options, by December 2010.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I transfer my discounted Singtel shares for division of matrimonial assets?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To obtain an application form to transfer your discounted Singtel shares for division of matrimonial assets, please write to us .

Knowledge Article: Question: Where can I see my special dividend as declared by Singtel on 10 November 2022?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Singtel declared a special dividend of $0.05 per share for financial year ending 31 March 2023. According to Singtel, the special dividend will be paid in tranches. The first S$0.025 will be paid along with the interim dividend in December 2022, while the remaining S$0.025 will be paid out together with Singtel’s final dividend in August 2023. The special dividend in both tranches is payable based on their respective book closure dates. For more information on Singtel’s special dividend, you can refer to Singtel website .   If you have discounted Singtel shares in your CPF account during these periods, you will receive Singtel’s special dividend along with your interim/final dividend in your Ordinary Account. Please check your CPF statement.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why did Singtel pay interim dividend in December 2022?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For financial year ending 31 March 2023, Singtel has decided to pay interim dividend earlier in December, instead of the following January. From 2023 onwards, Singtel will declare and pay dividends in August and December. For more information on Singtel’s dividend payments, you can refer to Singtel website .

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is Singtel's dividend rate(s) not reflected in my Yearly Statement of Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can find Singtel’s dividend rates in Singtel website or the dividend table on CPF website. If you have discounted Singtel shares in your CPF account, you would have received Singtel’s dividends in your Ordinary Account. Please check your CPF statement.

Knowledge Article: Question: Where can I find details of all Singtel's dividends paid in 2022?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can find Singtel’s dividend rates in Singtel website or the dividend table on CPF website. If you have discounted Singtel shares in your CPF account, you would have received Singtel’s dividends in your Ordinary Account. Please check your Ordinary Account transaction history for dividend(s) received.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the financing options from MOE and the educational institutions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can refer to the table for the useful websites on financial assistance offered by MOE and the Approved Educational Institutions:   Institute of Technical Education Institute of Technical Education Institute of the Arts LASALLE College of the Arts (Diploma) LASALLE College of the Arts (Undergraduate) Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts Ministry of Education Ministry of Education Polytechnics Nanyang Polytechnic Ngee Ann Polytechnic Republic Polytechnic Singapore Polytechnic Temasek Polytechnic Universities Nanyang Technological University National University of Singapore Singapore Institute of Technology Singapore Management University Singapore University of Social Sciences Singapore University of Technology and Design

Knowledge Article: Question: Will my discounted Singtel shares be sold or liquidated when I apply to withdraw my discounted Singtel shares upon meeting CPF withdrawal conditions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Withdrawing your discounted Singtel shares will not result in liquidation of your shares. It is a request to the Board to transfer the discounted Singtel shares to your CDP securities account. Once the shares have been transferred, you will receive a statement from CDP and the Board.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I choose to retain my excess Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions in my MediSave Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you can choose to retain your excess Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions in your MediSave Account. You may apply to do so by logging in to the  Self-employment dashboard using your Singpass.

Knowledge Article: Question: Where can I check the number of discounted Singtel shares in my CPF account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can login to my cpf Online Services with your Singpass and check the "Discounted Singtel shares" section in the Investment dashboard.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why are my current discounted Singtel shareholdings different from the quantity I purchased in 1993 and/or 1996 even though I did not sell the shares?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Singtel performed capital reductions on 1 September 2004 and 1 September 2006. In the 2004 capital reduction, Singtel cancelled 1 in every 14 of its shares, with the resultant shareholding rounded-up to the nearest 10 shares, where applicable. Singtel then reimbursed you S$2.36 for each cancelled share. In the 2006 capital reduction, Singtel cancelled 1 in every 20 of its shares, with the resultant shareholding rounded-up to the nearest 10 shares, where applicable. Singtel reimbursed you $2.74 for each cancelled share. Both reimbursements were credited into your CPF Ordinary Account. You were then informed, in writing, of the capital reductions in September 2004 and September 2006.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the dividends rates declared by Singtel for the discounted Singtel shares to-date?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may refer to Singtel website or our dividend table for rates declared by Singtel.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I transfer my discounted Singtel shares to another person?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your discounted Singtel shares can only be transferred into a CDP securities account under your name after you have set aside the Full Retirement Sum (FRS) in your Retirement Account at age 55.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have previously obtained a degree and will study for a full-time diploma course which is not subsidised by the government at SP/NP/TP/NYP/RP/NAFA/LAS/ITE. Can CPF savings be used for the diploma course?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As your selected diploma course is not subsidised by the government, CPF savings cannot be used even if it is a full-time course offered by an approved educational institution.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have previously obtained government subsidies for my first diploma, hence my second diploma is not subsidised. Will I still be able to use CPF savings for my second diploma?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As you are not eligible for government subsidies for the second diploma, CPF savings cannot be used even if it is a full-time course offered by an approved educational institution.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I apply for the use of my Post-Secondary Education Account (PSEA) funds?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For payment of approved fees and charges, you can withdraw the Post-Secondary Education Account (PSEA) funds by establishing a Standing Order with MOE or by submitting ad hoc withdrawal applications as and when withdrawals are to be made. The form to use will depend on the approved institution you are in. You should consult the approved institution you are studying in on which form to use.   For more information on PSEA, please visit MOE PSEA website .

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I transfer the cash balance from my CPF Investment Account to my Ordinary Account (OA)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can do the transfer via your agent bank's ATMs, internet/phone banking or over the counter.   Please note that if your CPF Investment Account has been inactive (i.e. no investment transactions) for two consecutive months, your agent bank will automatically transfer the cash balance to your Ordinary Account (OA) by month end*.   Likewise, if you have been unsuccessful in your Initial Public Offering (IPO) application, your agent bank will automatically transfer the unused CPF monies to your OA by month end*.   * The monies will be transferred on the third last working day of the month. In the event that the third last working day falls on a Saturday, the transfer will take place on the second last working day of the month.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if I think the information in my CPF statement is incorrect?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please notify us immediately via Write to Us if you think that the information is incorrect. Please note that it is your responsibility to carefully review your CPF statements.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I apply for the MOE Tuition Fee Loan (TFL)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To apply for MOE Tuition Fee Loan (TFL), please follow one of the following steps below:   SMU Students To approach SMU NTU and NUS Students To approach OCBC or DBS All other students To approach DBS   For more information on MOE TFL, please visit  MOE TFL website or approach your institution.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will there still be a range of funds for CPF investors to choose from?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The lowering of the Total Expense Ratio (TER) caps would not have significant impact on the choices of investment under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS). The Board will work with industry players towards complying with the new TER caps, to give CPF members continued choice in terms of the range of funds available under the CPFIS.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is the 3 years track record for new funds applied at the fund level or based on the experience of Fund Management Companies?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The preference for a 3 year performance track record is generally applied at the fund level. Fund managers should preferably show a minimum track record so that they can be better assessed on their ability whether they are able to give consistently good performance against the benchmark for the specific fund they manage.   In the case of indexed funds or Exchange Traded Funds, the 3 year track record is applied differently. The focus will be on the fund management company's technology or systems and processes that they have established to perform the rebalancing functions to track indexes closely 1 and their ability to consistently maintain a low cost structure for the index funds they have under management. 1 Low tracking error

Knowledge Article: Question: What do I need to consider before deciding which education loan to take?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may need to consider the following before deciding on a loan type for your education:   What other loan options are you and the student eligible for besides the CPF Education Loan Scheme? How much CPF savings can you use under the CPF Education Loan Scheme? Is it sufficient to fully finance the course? If using CPF, how would it affect your housing needs (if any) and retirement planning? How does the estimated loan repayment period affect the total interest to be paid?

Knowledge Article: Question: Do all CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)-included Unit Trusts/ILP sub-funds charge trailer fees?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Trailer fees is subjected to the business agreements between product providers and their distributors (including financial advisors). Some funds may not have trailer fees payable to distributors.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much Ordinary Account (OA) savings can I use under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use your Ordinary Account (OA) savings up to the Available Withdrawal Limit under the CPF Education Loan Scheme. The Available Withdrawal Limit is either 40% of your accumulated OA savings 1 , or your remaining OA balance 2 , whichever is lower. The amount that can be used is also subject to the tuition fees payable.   If you are 55 years old or older, you need to set aside the Full Retirement Sum (FRS) in the Retirement Account before you can use the remaining savings in the OA up to the Available Withdrawal Limit. The FRS can be set aside fully with cash, or with cash (i.e. at least the Basic Retirement Sum) and property.   The Available Withdrawal Limit will change if there is a new withdrawal, repayment or refund in your OA. You may check the amount of CPF savings that can be used for education by logging in to your  Education dashboard with your Singpass.   1 Made up of your current OA balance plus any OA savings that were previously withdrawn for education and investment, excluding the amount used for housing   2 After setting aside any amounts reserved for housing or other schemes (if any).

Knowledge Article: Question: When is the application period for the approved educational institutions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may refer to the Application schedule to apply for CPF education loan for the application period of the approved educational institutions.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much of tuition fees can be paid using Ordinary Account (OA) savings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your Ordinary Account (OA) savings can be used to pay up to 100% of your own, your spouse’s, your children’s, or your siblings’ tuition fees. However, if you are paying for your relatives’ tuition fees, the percentage of tuition fees that can be paid using your OA savings is:   • 10% if your relative(s) is studying at a university;   • 25% if your relative(s) is studying at a polytechnic or pursuing an approved Technical Engineer Diploma (TED) or a Technical Diploma at Institute of Technical Education (ITE); or • 50% if your relative(s) is studying at an art college. To pay the remaining tuition fees, the student can consider the MOE Tuition Fee Loan Scheme, subject to eligibility.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will the Board sell the discounted Singtel shares due to the nominee?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Currently, we will sell the shares due to the nominee if:   i. we are unable to transfer these shares to the nominee;   ii. the nominee has instructed us to sell these shares;   iii. the nominee is an undischarged bankrupt;   iv. the nominee has passed away;   v. no instruction has been received from the nominee even after six weeks from the notification of the member's death; or   vi. there exist such other circumstances as may be prescribed in the Special Discounted Shares regulations.

Knowledge Article: Question: Whose CPF savings can I use under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You and/or the student can apply for this loan scheme if you meet the following conditions:   You are using your Ordinary Account (OA) savings to pay for your own, children’s, spouse’s, siblings’ or relatives’ tuition fees. You have sufficient OA savings and Available Withdrawal Limit to be used under the CPF Education Loan Scheme. The course registered is a full-time subsidised diploma/degree course at an Approved Educational Institution (AEI) . Please note that there is a limit on the percentage of tuition fees that may be paid using your sibling’s or relative’s CPF savings.   In approved cases where a sibling's CPF savings is used, up to 100% of tuition fees may be paid.   In approved cases where a relative's CPF savings is used, up to:   10% of tuition fees may be paid, if the student is studying at a university 25% of tuition fees may be paid, if the student is studying at a polytechnic or pursuing an approved Technical Engineer Diploma (TED) or a Technical Diploma at an Institute of Technical Education 50% of tuition fees may be paid, if the student is studying at an art institution.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to the deceased member's CPF LIFE premium?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The deceased member's CPF LIFE premium balance (if applicable) will be paid to his nominee(s) together with his CPF savings.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to my CPF savings when I turn 55?
Knowledge Article: Answer: When you turn 55, we will transfer your CPF savings, up to your Full Retirement Sum (FRS), to create your Retirement Account (RA). The savings in your RA is meant to provide you with payouts in retirement. Your Special Account (SA) savings will be transferred first , followed by your Ordinary Account (OA) savings.   From early 2025, the SA will be closed for members aged 55 and above to be in line with the principle that savings set aside for retirement should continue to earn long-term interest rates, while savings that can be withdrawn at any time should earn the short-term interest rate.   If you have savings in SA when the SA is closed, it will be transferred to the RA, up to your FRS, so that you can receive higher retirement payouts. Once you have set aside your FRS in RA, the remaining SA savings will be transferred to the OA and can be withdrawn at any time.   If you do not have enough RA savings to make up the FRS and have used your CPF savings for your property, we will use your CPF savings withdrawn for your property (including accrued interest) to meet your FRS. The maximum amount that can be used is your Basic Retirement Sum. When you sell your property, you will have to restore your RA up to your FRS with your sales proceeds.   It is not mandatory for you to top up your RA if you are unable to set aside your FRS . However, you may wish to top up your RA for higher monthly payouts. You can also enjoy tax relief for cash top-ups up to the FRS. After your SA is closed in early 2025, you can also opt to transfer your OA savings to the RA up to prevailing ERS to earn long-term interest rates and receive higher retirement payouts.   Did you know? You can use the Monthly payout estimator  to estimate how much you need to top up to reach your desired monthly payouts.   If you are born in 1958 or after and wish to start your monthly payouts, there will be another transfer of your SA and/or OA savings, up to your FRS, to your RA , if you have not met your FRS. This transfer allows you to receive higher monthly payouts.   Find out more about the retirement sums .

Knowledge Article: Question: If I have terminated my insurance policy bought using CPF, can I reinstate the policy and pay the outstanding premiums and future premiums using CPF?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You need to liaise with your insurance company on the reinstatement of the policy. Upon reinstatement, you may pay the outstanding and future premiums using CPF. However, no CPF can be used to pay any outstanding interest owing to the insurance company.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I find out more information on Account Closure for non-Singaporeans and non-Permanent Residents?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For more information, please call us at 6776 6776.

Knowledge Article: Question: What information do I need to prepare before applying to use CPF savings under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Before you submit your application online under the CPF Education Loan Scheme:   Check the application period for the institution you are applying to use CPF to pay your tuition fees. Ensure you are accepted by the tertiary institution and confirm that it is an approved educational institution under the CPF Education Loan Scheme. Get ready your CPF account number or NRIC, telephone number and email address. Find out the CPF account number or NRIC, telephone number and e-mail address of the CPF lender, whose CPF savings you are applying to use under the CPF Education Loan Scheme. Discuss with the lender on the percentage of the tuition fees you may pay using his/her CPF savings. Ensure you and the lender have your own Singpass and valid email accounts. You can refer to the following  FAQ for more information on the courses covered by the CPF Education Loan Scheme.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much CPF savings can I withdraw?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can check the amount you can withdraw by logging in to your Retirement dashboard .   Generally, when you turn 55, you can withdraw at least $5,000 or any amount in excess after setting aside your Full Retirement Sum (FRS) .   If you are born in 1958 and after, when you turn 65, you can withdraw an additional amount of up to 20% of your retirement savings. See more details on the withdrawal rules .   You can also apply to withdraw your Retirement Account savings down to your Basic Retirement Sum (BRS) if you own a property in Singapore with remaining lease that lasts you until you are 95 or older. You have the flexibility to set aside your FRS with a mixture of property (up to half your FRS, which is the BRS) and cash.   Please note that you cannot withdraw cash top-ups or CPF transfers, as well as government grants such as CPF LIFE Bonus or Deferment Bonus as they are designed to boost your retirement payouts. Find out how your withdrawable amount is computed .

Knowledge Article: Question: How much CPF savings can I withdraw?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can check the amount you can withdraw by logging in to your Retirement dashboard .   Generally, when you turn 55, you can withdraw at least $5,000 or any amount in excess after setting aside your Full Retirement Sum (FRS) .   If you are born in 1958 and after, when you turn 65, you can withdraw an additional amount of up to 20% of your retirement savings. See more details on the withdrawal rules .   You can also apply to withdraw your Retirement Account savings down to your Basic Retirement Sum (BRS) if you own a property in Singapore with remaining lease that lasts you until you are 95 or older. You have the flexibility to set aside your FRS with a mixture of property (up to half your FRS, which is the BRS) and cash.   Please note that you cannot withdraw cash top-ups or CPF transfers, as well as government grants such as CPF LIFE Bonus or Deferment Bonus as they are designed to boost your retirement payouts. Find out how your withdrawable amount is computed .

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I still apply for CPF Education Loan Scheme after the application period had closed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: All applications under the CPF Education Loan Scheme should be submitted within the application period. You may refer to the Application schedule to apply for CPF education loan for the application period of the approved educational institutions.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I have to submit supporting documents to prove the relationship if I am applying to use my parent's, spouse's, siblings' or relatives' CPF under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Supporting documents to verify the relationship between you and the CPF lender is not required at the time of application under the CPF Education Loan Scheme. However, we may request for such documents to verify the relationship for audit purposes.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will a fund be excluded from CPF Investment Scheme due to not meeting the Total Expense Ratio cap subsequent to the inclusion?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The fund will remain under CPF Investment Scheme (as List B fund) but it will not be allowed to take in CPF new monies. However, the company will have to provide the fund’s investors with options to hold, redeem or make free switches within 3 months from informing the CPF Board of not meeting Total Expense Ratio caps.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will taxi principal hirers who participate in the Drive and Save (DAS) scheme have their Taxi Vocational Licence (TDVL) be automatically renewed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Taxi Driver Vocational Licence (TDVL) will not be automatically renewed.    Taxi principal hirers must have fully paid their MediSave payable or are making monthly payments via GIRO to renew their TDVLs.   MediSave contributions and the co-contributions from taxi operators will go towards meeting their self-employed MediSave payable.

Knowledge Article: Question: When must the CPF lender endorse the online application submitted under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF lender must login to the link provided in the email or the Endorse CPF education loan form in the CPF website, using his/her own Singpass, within 14 days from the date the application was submitted, and click 'Yes, I agree to let the student use my CPF savings' if he/she wishes to withdraw his/her CPF savings to pay for the borrower's tuition fees. The online application will be automatically rejected if no action is taken by the lender after 14 days.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I request an instalment plan for my MediSave contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can request for an instalment plan for your MediSave contributions via the  Manage your MediSave payable  form.   Please note that your request is subject to the Board’s approval. You may be required to provide additional information or supporting documents, if necessary.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can a fund downgraded to List B resume accepting CPF monies once the fund's Total Expense Ratio meets the cap subsequently?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The fund would be upgraded to List A, and can take in CPF monies if its audited Total Expense Ratio meets the cap subsequently.

Knowledge Article: Question: What will happen to my Single Premium Home Protection Scheme cover if there are changes to my outstanding housing loan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your loan repayment period or loan amount has reduced, your Single Premium (SP) Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover will be terminated. We will issue you an Annual Premium (AP) HPS cover based on your new outstanding housing loan. Any surrender value of your SP HPS cover will be paid to your CPF Ordinary Account.   However, if the changes to your housing loan result in an increase in your HPS cover, such as an increase in cover period or sum assured, obtaining an additional AP cover will be subject to you being in good health. If you are not eligible for the additional cover, you will remain insured under your SP cover.   Do I need to inform the Board to adjust my Home Protection Scheme cover if I make a partial repayment of my loan?

Knowledge Article: Question: How frequent will CPF Board assess whether a fund can or cannot take in CPF monies?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF Board will assess whenever a fund’s audited financial statements become available (i.e. yearly basis for most funds). A company that wishes to have its fund assessed more frequently may submit to CPF Board the fund’s semi-annual audited financial statements according to its accounting period. The company must ensure that all subsequent published Total Expense Ratios (TERs) of its funds are also in line with the TER cap.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to inform the Board to adjust my Home Protection Scheme cover if I make a partial repayment of my loan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: It depends on the type of loan that you took to purchase your flat.   For Housing & Development Board (HDB) Loan You do not need to inform us of the partial repayment of your housing loan, regardless of whether you are using cash or CPF savings for the partial repayment.   Your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover will be automatically adjusted when we are notified accordingly by HDB. Your existing HPS cover will end and any unused premium will be paid to your CPF Ordinary Account. A new HPS cover will be issued to you based on the latest loan details after partial repayment. The premium for the new cover will be deducted from your CPF Ordinary Account.   For Bank Loan If you are using cash to make a partial repayment of your housing loan, please submit your application  online  using your Singpass to adjust your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover. We will then write to your bank to obtain your latest loan details. Your HPS cover would be adjusted based on the latest loan detail as at application date. No backdated adjustments will be made. It is important to promptly inform us of any partial repayment made in cash, so that your HPS cover can be promptly adjusted. Otherwise, you may end up being over-insured or under-insured, which would not be to your benefit.   If you are using your CPF savings to make a partial repayment of your housing loan, you do not need to inform us of the partial repayment. We will adjust your HPS cover automatically.   Upon adjustment, your existing HPS cover will end and any unused premium will be paid to your CPF Ordinary Account. A new HPS cover will be issued to you based on the latest loan details after partial repayment. The premium for the new cover will be deducted from your CPF Ordinary Account.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is the premium for my new Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover higher than my old HPS cover even though I have made a partial repayment of my loan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your Home Protection Scheme premium is higher than before because you had extended your repayment period to a longer tenure, after you made the partial repayment of your loan.   Find out more: How is the Home Protection Scheme premium calculated?

Knowledge Article: Question: Currently CPF Board does not allow members above 80 to join CPF LIFE. What will happen to my Retirement Account inflows after I turn 80?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are currently under CPF LIFE, your Retirement Account inflows will automatically be used to increase your CPF LIFE premium even after 80, so that you will receive higher CPF LIFE monthly payouts for life.   The cut-off age of 80 only applies to members who are not under CPF LIFE.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is there an age limit for existing CPF LIFE members to increase their CPF LIFE premium?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Existing CPF LIFE members can increase their CPF LIFE premium at any age which will help to increase their CPF LIFE monthly payouts.

Knowledge Article: Question: How accurate are the projections within the CPF planner - retirement income?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The results and/or estimates provided in the CPF planner - retirement income are intended to be used for illustrative purposes only and should not be regarded as advice by CPF Board or used as a substitute for financial advice.

Knowledge Article: Question: What if I am unable to find two witnesses to witness my nomination online?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can make an appointment at any of our CPF Service Centres to make a CPF Nomination if you cannot find two witnesses online. Our Customer Service Executives will assist you to complete your nomination, and also act as your witnesses. Alternatively, you may visit any of the ServiceSG Centres to make your online CPF nomination. ServiceSG officers will act as your witnesses for your online nomination.   View the list of ServiceSG Centres locations and its operating hours.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is there a limit to the number of top-ups I can make or receive in a year?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There is no limit to the number of top-ups you can make or receive as long as the recipient can still receive top-ups .   It is important to note that once you make a top-up, it cannot be reversed. Therefore, we advise you to review that you have sufficient cash or CPF savings for other expenses before making the top-up.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I wish to make both a CPF transfer and a cash top-up to myself / my loved one, which should I do first?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you wish to enjoy tax relief on your cash top-up to help you or your loved one up to the Full Retirement Sum, please make the cash top-up first, before the CPF transfer. If you prefer using your CPF savings over cash, please make the CPF transfer first.   You may wish to take note that only cash top-ups to self and loved ones within the Full Retirement Sum can enjoy tax relief. Learn more about  tax relief .

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the roles and responsibilities of a CPF volunteer?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Unlike conventional volunteering, there is generally no upfront time commitment and CPF volunteers have the flexibility to choose when or how they would like to share CPF information with people around them. However, do take reference to our code of ethics, by being impartial and objective when sharing information about CPF and to keep yourself updated on CPF matters.   As the CPF Volunteering (CPFV) initiative grows, we are also expanding the opportunities in which volunteers can contribute their personal stories, skills etc. As a volunteer, you may have the opportunity to star as our guest speaker in CPF webinars or participate in other co-creation efforts. Active and interested volunteers can also reach out to us to suggest possible collaborations.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I show my appreciation to the CPF Board staff who recommended this e-service to me?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may provide the referrer’s details of the staff in your application form. Alternatively, you can also express your appreciation for our CPF officer by submitting a compliment through our website. Simply visit cpf.gov.sg/writetous and select "Compliments/Feedback" from the drop-down list of options.

Knowledge Article: Question: What do I need to do on 14 July 2023 for my CPFV app?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will need to update the CPFV app from 14 July 2023 to keep up with the latest happenings and updates in the app. If you do not update the app, you will not be able to access its latest content.

Knowledge Article: Question: When will the maturity proceeds of my investments be credited to my CPF accounts?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The maturity proceeds for investments under CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA) and CPF Investment Scheme-Special Account (CPFIS-SA) are handled differently:     CPFIS-OA   Upon maturity of your CPFIS-OA investments, the proceeds will be credited into your CPF Investment Account generally within one week. You can check with your agent bank to know if the proceeds have been credited.     CPFIS-SA   Upon maturity of your CPFIS-SA investments, the proceeds will be credited into your SA generally within one week. To check whether the proceeds have been credited, you can view your CPFIS statement by logging into:   my cpf Online Services with your Singpass > Select my cpf > My dashboards > Investment; or the 'CPF Mobile' app with your Singpass.

Knowledge Article: Question: I did not see interest credited into my accounts in my monthly transaction statement. Why is this so?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Interest is computed monthly, credited and compounded annually. For more details, please refer to the FAQ on ' How is my CPF interest computed and credited into my accounts '.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I save or download my monthly transaction statement?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can download and save a PDF copy of your monthly transaction statement by using your laptop/desktop to access the link provided in the email notification. You can also access your online 15-month transaction history via the CPF Mobile app or CPF website to download and save your monthly transaction statement from there.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I read the full content of push notifications?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can view the full content of the push notification via three ways: Tap on the banner and it will bring you to view the full content of the notification. Before logging into the app, tap on the ‘bell’ icon located at the top left corner. After logging into the app, tap on the ‘bell’ icon located at the top left corner of the side menu.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I check my CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) details?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There are various ways in obtaining the details of your investments under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS):     CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA) You can either refer to your CPF Investment Scheme statement sent by your agent bank or contact them directly.     CPF Investment Scheme-Special Account (CPFIS-SA) You can view the details of your investments by:   logging into my cpf digital services with your Singpass > Select my cpf > My dashboards > Investment; accessing the 'CPF Mobile' app with your Singpass; or visiting any CPF Service Centres personally with your identity card.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have forgotten my CPF Investment Account Number. How can I go about checking this?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To check your CPF Investment Account Number, you can:   login to my cpf Online Services with your Singpass > Select my cpf > My dashboards > Investment; access the ' CPF Mobile ' app using your Singpass; check your CPF Investment Scheme Statement sent by your agent bank; or contact your agent bank directly.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use CPF savings to place Fixed Deposits under the CPF Investment Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use your CPF savings to place Fixed Deposits (FD) with any of the four Fixed Deposit Banks (DBS, Maybank, OCBC and UOB) under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS).   Please approach the Fixed Deposit Banks directly to check if they are offering any FD under CPFIS, their FD rates and for placement of the FD. You can place the FD even if the Fixed Deposit Bank is not your CPFIS-OA agent bank.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is there a minimum interest rate for CPF Investment Scheme Fixed Deposit (FD) that FD Banks must offer?
Knowledge Article: Answer: With effect from 1 May 2007, Fixed Deposit (FD) Banks must offer a minimum effective interest rate that is at least the prevailing CPF interest rate for new placements or roll over of any CPF Investment Scheme FDs. In this way, members will not be worse off than leaving their monies in the CPF Accounts.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I delete the messages in the notification list?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can delete the message by tapping on the ‘Bin’ icon in the notification detail page.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why are Total Expense Ratio (TER) caps reduced for CPF Investment Scheme funds?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The purpose of CPF Investment Scheme is to provide alternative investment to help CPF members build up their retirement savings. As expenses of investment have a significant impact on returns, a regular review of the Total Expense Ratio (TER) caps is important as high expense ratio would erode investment returns for CPF members. Where feasible, TER caps should be kept low to increase the fund’s per-unit net asset value and enable CPF members to accumulate their retirement savings faster. This is in line with the efforts by regulatory authorities in other countries to reduce the cost of funds to investors.

Knowledge Article: Question: How does the company I contracted with know my Net Trade Income information and/or Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contribution rate?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The company which you have contracted with will not have access to your Net Trade Income information. CPF Board will only inform the company of the amount that they would have to deduct from your service fee and transmit to your MediSave Account.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have applied to purchase Treasury Bills (T-bills) at primary auction under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS). When would my CPF savings be deducted for the purchase?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your CPF savings for T-bills purchase under CPFIS would be deducted only upon the successful allotment of the T-bills. In so doing, CPF members will continue earning CPF interest on their CPF savings, in case full or part of their T-bills application is unsuccessful. The deductions are done after the auction date (i.e. the date where the allotment of your T-bills purchase has been finalised) but before the issue date of the T-bills.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do top-up monies form part of the required $40,000 that needs to be set aside before I can invest my Special Account monies?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Top-up monies form part of the $40,000 that needs to be set aside in the Special Account (SA) before you can use the excess for your investment. However, top-up monies cannot be used for investment. For example, if you have $100,000 in your SA, of which $90,000 are top up monies you received in your SA, only monies in excess of the $90,000 (i.e. $10,000) can be invested. Please refer to this FAQ for further information on usage of top-up monies.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I disable personalised notifications before I sell my mobile device?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can disable personalised notifications at the app settings page. It is recommended that you uninstall CPF Mobile before selling your mobile device.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I withdraw my CPF savings?
