Knowledge Article: Question: Can I transfer my share in the property to my ex-spouse?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you can do so if the Courts decide to make such an order. The amount of CPF refunds, who is required to make those refunds and at what point in time the refunds need to be made will depend on whether the court order provides for full, partial or no CPF refunds to your CPF account upon transfer of your share in the property to your ex-spouse.   We set out the CPF refund details in the table below:   Transfer of property with full CPF refunds Transfer of property with partial or no CPF refunds (A) At point of transfer of property from you to your ex-spouse Required amount to be refunded to your CPF account: 1) Your CPF principal amount withdrawn for the property with accrued interest, and 2) Your pledged amount if you are aged 55 years old and above and have pledged the property to make up your retirement sum Required amount to be refunded to your CPF account: Partial or zero amount as directed by the court order (B) Upon subsequent disposal of property by your ex-spouse Required amount to be refunded to your CPF account: N.A. Required amount to be refunded to your ex-spouse’s CPF account: 1) Your ex-spouse’s CPF principal amount withdrawn for the property with accrued interest, and 2) Your ex-spouse’s pledged amount if they are aged 55 years old and above and has pledged the property to make up their retirement sum.   In addition: 3) Portion of the required CPF refund not refunded to your CPF Account at the point of transfer of property; 4) Interest that would have accrued on (3) as at the date of your ex-spouse’s subsequent disposal of the property, and 5) Your pledged amount if you are aged 55 years old and above and have pledged the property to make up your retirement sum

Knowledge Article: Question: I have issues with my Singpass. What should I do?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Singpass is an authentication service governed by GovTech. CPF Board is one of the government agencies using Singpass and its two-factor authentication (2FA) service.   If you have any Singpass issues (e.g. unable to login via Singpass, forgot Singpass password, unable to receive SMS OTP), please contact the Singpass Helpdesk directly.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I still have to contribute to MediSave as a self-employed person even though my MediSave balance has reached the Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As a self-employed person (SEP), you are still required to make MediSave contributions even if you have met the Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS). This is the same for employees.   The MediSave amount above the BHS will be transferred to your CPF Special Account (SA) or Retirement Account (RA), which have interest rates equal or higher than that of the MediSave Account. The BHS cap and overflow arrangement are intentionally planned to avoid over savings in MediSave and to supplement your retirement savings. These overflows which end up in your SA or RA can be withdrawn according to the withdrawal guidelines. For members who have met the Full Retirement Sum in their SA or RA, the savings in excess of the BHS will be transferred to the Ordinary Account (OA). Savings in the OA can be used for other purposes such as housing repayment.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I choose to transfer more savings from the Special Account to the Ordinary Account since I am still servicing my housing loan/education loan etc.?
Knowledge Article: Answer: When your Special Account (SA) is closed, the savings in your SA will be transferred to the Retirement Account (RA), up to your Full Retirement Sum to increase your retirement payouts. Any remaining savings that are withdrawable on demand will be transferred to your Ordinary Account (OA).   You may use the portion transferred to your OA for your housing loan/education loan (subject to applicable limits) or choose to withdraw them anytime for your immediate needs. You cannot choose to allocate more SA savings or your future RA contributions to your OA to service your housing/education loan, etc.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions rounded to the nearest dollar?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The total contributions for the calendar month should be rounded off to the nearest dollar. Cents should be dropped for amounts less than 50 cents. Amounts of 50 cents and above should be treated as an additional dollar. You are entitled to recover the employee’s share of CPF contributions when paying your employee’s wages for the month. The cents should always be dropped for the employee’s share of CPF contributions. You can use our CPF Contribution Calculator to calculate the CPF contributions applicable to your employees. You can also use CPF EZPay to auto-compute your CPF contributions for greater convenience!

Knowledge Article: Question: What if I made more than one payment using the same QR code?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You should only use the generated QR code for one payment as the QR code generated is unique. If there is more than one payment, the subsequent payment will be refunded to you.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the minimum requirement to access CPF Mobile on my mobile device?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF Mobile is compatible with Apple iOS 13.4, Android 10 and above. Keeping your Operating System (OS) updated is crucial to maintain the security of your mobile device and ensure compatibility with our mobile app. Furthermore, up-to-date OS improves performance and offers a better user experience.   You can update your OS via the following steps: For iPhone users: Go to Settings > General > Tap on “Software Updates” For Android users: Go to Settings > System > Tap on “Software Update”

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I benefit from electronic payments?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can benefit in the following ways with electronic payment modes: Easy and convenient Faster processing time Secure and seamless transaction

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I invest after I am discharged from bankruptcy?
Knowledge Article: Answer: After your discharge from bankruptcy, you can continue to invest your CPF savings if you are at least 18 years old, subject to the investment thresholds and limits set by the Board.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long does it take to process voluntary top-ups application to my MediSave Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The application relating to voluntary top-ups to MediSave Account will be processed as stated in the table below.   Service Processing Time Top up MediSave Account Almost immediately   If the top-up amount is not reflected in your CPF accounts, please check your CPF account balance after five working days as more time may be needed to process the transaction. Such cases are extremely rare and may arise due to intermittent network connectivity issues beyond CPF Board's control.   Please alert us immediately if your payment is still not updated in your CPF account balance after five working days.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I withdraw my sale proceeds or investment profits from my discounted Singtel shares?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The sale proceeds and investment profits form part of your CPF savings. You can apply to withdraw them from age 55 if you meet the withdrawal conditions . For more information on how you can withdraw your CPF retirement savings, please refer to this FAQ .

Knowledge Article: Question: Would other members receive my CPF notifications if they have registered the same contact detail(s) as me?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Members will receive CPF notifications at their email address and/or mobile number registered with us.   Other members can receive your CPF notifications only if they share the same email address or mobile number as you.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) allowed to recover unpaid taxes/ MediShield Life premiums when I withdraw my CPF savings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Taxes go towards funding of government expenditure; and to support the government's economic and social programme to ensure quality growth and an inclusive society. Most taxpayers pay their taxes on time. To encourage voluntary compliance where every taxpayer contributes their fair share of tax, there are penalties if taxes are not paid on time. Actions to recover the unpaid taxes may include appointment of agents such as CPF Board.   Under the law, IRAS is empowered to appoint CPF Board as an agent for the recovery of unpaid taxes/MediShield Life premiums. IRAS would have informed you that CPF Board has been appointed as agent to recover the unpaid taxes/MediShield Life premiums when you withdraw your CPF savings.   You may approach IRAS at 6356 7012 to discuss alternative arrangements to settle your unpaid taxes/MediShield Life premiums before submitting your withdrawal application.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I submit more than one nomination online within the same day?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can only submit one nomination within the same day. This includes the nomination that has had its witnessing process completed that day.   If you wish to submit a new nomination, you may withdraw the current one if your witnesses have not witnessed it. If both your witnesses have already witnessed your nomination, you can submit a new nomination after your earlier nomination is processed. Your new nomination will supersede your earlier nomination.   How can I withdraw my online nomination?

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the voluntary top-up limit to my MediSave Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The maximum amount you can voluntarily top up to your MediSave Account is the difference between your Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS) and your current MediSave balance. Once your BHS has been reached, no further voluntary top-ups can be made to your MediSave Account. If you exceed your BHS from the top-up, the full amount of your top-up will be refunded to you.   You can check your top-up limit with these steps .

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I get a document that shows I do not have a CPF account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can login to my cpf digital services via your Singpass. You will see a message "No information can be displayed here as you do not have a CPF account."   You can click on located above the graphic, to save or print a copy.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why are my transactions not included in my Year-in-Review?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Year-in-Review (YIR) gives you an overview of your CPF account balances, inflow and outflow in the last 12 months from your birthday month. If the transactions happened more than 12 months from your birthday month, it would not appear.   For a detailed list of transactions, you may refer to your transaction history to access transactions up to the past 15 months.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am a foreigner. I can't seem to be able to login to CPF digital services using my Singpass, why is it so?
Knowledge Article: Answer: With the discontinuation of the OneKey Token from 1 April 2021, foreign CPF members will no longer be able to access CPF digital services using the Singpass which was registered under their CPF issued account numbers (e.g. SA987654C or TC123456A) previously.   Foreign CPF members with CPF issued accounts and are currently holding FIN may apply for a new Singpass under the FIN to access CPF digital services for their CPF SA/SB/TC account. You may refer to the Singpass website at  singpass.gov.sg  for the steps to apply.   CPF members who do not meet the above criteria may  Write to Us  for assistance.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do when I see the Security Warning Message?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can click "Yes" to proceed with your intended transaction. However, the message will appear when you login the next time. For a long-term solution, please do the following: Click on the 'View Certificate' button. Click on the 'Install Certificate' button. Click on the 'Next' and 'Finish' buttons as required to accept and install the certificate. Click "Yes" when you see 'Do you want to ADD the following certificate to the Root Store?' Click 'Ok' as required. Click 'Yes' to the Security Alert warning which may still be being displayed.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my CPF savings to build my own house?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use your CPF Ordinary Account (OA) savings to repay the loan taken for the self-construction of your house. However, the total CPF savings allowed for the construction loan and the existing loan taken to buy the property cannot exceed the new value of the property.   To apply for the use of your CPF savings, you will need to authorise your lawyer (by signing the Letter of Authorisation, Declaration, Consent & Agreement) to submit an online application on your behalf after the issuance of the Temporary Occupation Permit. Your lawyer will need to attach the following documents in the application:   Contractors' breakdown of construction costs; Valuation report of the completed property prepared by a licensed valuer. Valuation report prepared by the financier will be considered on a case-by-case basis. The Board reserves the right to re-assess the value of the property, if necessary; Original receipts to show evidence of the payment made from your own savings (if you are applying for reimbursement); Outstanding amount of the construction loan; Bank’s Letter of Offer for the construction loan; Bank’s letter of Offer for the conversion of the construction loan to a housing loan; and Temporary Occupation Permit Please note that if you already own a property (HDB flat or private property) bought with your CPF savings and wish to build another house on a vacant land, you can only use the excess balance in your OA after setting aside the applicable  Basic Retirement Sum in your CPF accounts. This helps to provide you with a monthly income to support a basic standard of living during retirement. Take note that usage of your CPF savings is only applicable if the remaining lease of the house or your existing property bought with CPF savings can cover you till 95 years old.   If the remaining lease of the house or your existing property bought with CPF savings does not cover you till 95 years old, you can only use the excess balance in your OA after setting aside the applicable  Full Retirement Sum .

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I calculate CPF contributions on Additional Wages (AW) when an employee resigns?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your employee resigns in the current year, the Additional Wages (AW) ceiling has to be recalculated based on the actual Ordinary Wages (OW) subject to CPF, paid up till the last month of employment. For more information, please view Examples  (PDF, 0.6MB) on the computation of the AW ceiling.   You should then pay any shortfall in CPF contributions together with your employee's contributions for his last month of employment. If there are any excess CPF contributions, you should submit a refund application online .

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I check whether I have any MediSave payable as a self-employed person?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can check your MediSave payable by logging in to the Self-employment dashboard using your Singpass.   You can apply for your  Singpass online if you do not have one.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I view my child's CPF statements online?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can view your child’s Transaction History statement as well as the MediSave and Healthcare Insurance Claims and Reimbursement statement (if applicable) for the last 15 months online if:   1. You and your child are Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents, and   2. Your child is below the age of 21 and has received CPF contributions (including Government Grants such as MediSave Grant for Newborns).   Simply login to my cpf Home > Child Dashboard with your Singpass to access this information.   If you do not see your child’s name listed in the Child Dashboard, you can  write to us with the following supporting documents and we will be happy to assist.   Supporting documents required: Birth certificate of your child Citizenship certificate if your child was a foreigner at birth (where applicable).

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if the funds that I am holding under the CPF Investment Scheme do not meet the stricter criteria by December 2010?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will be given options by the Fund Management Companies (FMCs) or insurers to hold, redeem or switch your units, for free, into other CPF Investment Scheme funds that are eligible to take in new CPF monies from 1 January 2011. If you decide to switch funds, please consider whether the new funds match your investment objective and risk profile (PDF, 0.2MB).

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I voluntarily refund a portion of the CPF savings I used for my property?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you can apply to make a voluntary housing refund of any amount up to the total CPF principal amount you have withdrawn for the purchase of your property, including the accrued interest. Please refer to the guide below to check for the maximum amount of refund that can be made.    Your refund will be used to reduce the principal amount withdrawn for your home, followed by the interest accrued on your withdrawals.

Knowledge Article: Question: What will CPF Board do with members or third parties who are found to have conducted manipulative transactions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Under the law, CPF Board is empowered to recover CPF savings that is siphoned or withdrawn prematurely under such circumstances, with interest. The member could also be prohibited from making further withdrawals for a period of one year or more as the Board may determine, from the date of the contravention or from the date of the making of any false representations or furnishing of false information.   The Board takes a serious view on any attempts to siphon CPF savings prematurely and will not hesitate to take legal action against CPF members and intermediaries or other parties who collaborate to do this. Third parties will be charged under the Penal Code. The Board may issue a Notice to Attend Court (NTA) to such persons. Please refer to the NTA form (PDF, 0.2MB) for a sample.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I have to provide my bank account details to CPF Board if I do not have any upcoming payments from CPF Board?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No action is required from you if you do not intend to make any withdrawals or do not have any upcoming payments from CPF Board.     However, if you expect upcoming payments from CPF Board, e.g. monthly payouts or refunds, please provide your bank account details to CPF Board so that you can receive your payments to your registered bank account. If you are nearing age 70 and have not already started your monthly payouts, you should expect to start receiving your monthly payouts when you turn 70 years old, and will need to provide your bank account details to receive your payouts to your registered bank account.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I hold a fund under the CPF Investment Scheme that does not meet the stricter criteria, when must I exercise the switching option?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Funds that are unable to meet the stricter criteria can only take in new CPF monies till December 2010, and you will be given up till 30 June 2011 to exercise the switching option.   In addition, a fund may decide to cease taking in new CPF monies earlier. If this happens, you have to exercise the switching option within the timeframe stipulated by the Fund Management Company/insurer in its communication letter to you.

Knowledge Article: Question: My mobile number/email address is outdated. How can I update my records in Singpass?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To update your mobile number/email address with Singpass, please complete the following steps:   Login to the  Singpass website Select ‘Menu’ > ‘Update profile’ (under the ‘My Account’ tab) and follow the instructions on the website to complete the updating of your mobile number/email address Please ensure that you have access to your mobile phone/email as a One-Time Password (OTP) will be sent to your updated mobile number/email address for verification.   If you require further assistance, please contact the  Singpass Helpdesk  directly. The operating hours are from 8am to 8pm (Mondays to Fridays) and from 8am to 2pm (Saturdays) excluding Sundays and public holidays.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I make further changes to my contact details while my current request is still in the 12-hour cooling period?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you can submit further changes to your contact details via the Account settings page with your Singpass.   Please note that your most recent request will supersede the previous submission and the changes will take effect after the 12-hour cooling period.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is there a need to provide mobile number/email address to CPF Board?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For greater convenience and faster updates on your personal CPF matters, you will be receiving digital notifications via email or SMS from us.   You are encouraged to update your mobile number and email address with us to receive digital acknowledgements for your transactions.   If you do not have an email address, you may want to create a Gmail, Yahoo mail, Outlook or Hotmail address. Please visit their websites for details on how to create an email address for free.

Knowledge Article: Question: I received an SMS/email informing me that I will receive CPF notifications via my Singpass registered email address and/or mobile number. Is this legitimate?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your Singpass contact information was shared with us so that we can update you on your CPF matters in a timely and efficient manner. This is part of the whole of government effort to provide you with a seamless digital experience.   If you prefer us to contact you via a different email address or mobile number, you can update your mobile number and/or email address via the  Account settings  page with your Singpass. An SMS or email One-Time PIN (OTP) will be sent to your new mobile number or email address for verification before the changes can take effect.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I make a partial withdrawal of my CPF savings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you can withdraw your savings partially and leave the remaining in your CPF accounts to earn risk-free interest rates* of up to 6% per annum . Your withdrawable savings can be withdrawn any time later, whenever you need them.   If you decide to withdraw a partial amount, your savings will be paid from your CPF accounts in the following order:   Retirement Account (if applicable) Special Account Ordinary Account *Based on the current 4% interest rate floor on Special and Retirement Account monies.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can my company apply for the new fund to be included under the CPF Investment Scheme if its last audited Total Expense Ratio (TER) does not meet the TER cap?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your company can apply to include the fund under List A if it undertakes to cap the TER of the fund with effect from the date it is launched for CPF subscription. The Letter of undertaking is attached below: FMCs Insurers UT Inclusion of new fund under List A (PDF, 0.2MB) ?ILP Inclusion of new fund under List A (PDF, 0.2MB)

Knowledge Article: Question: What is an E-Xperience Guide and how do I register to be one?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF Board has launched the E-Xperience Space at the Bishan Service Centre, Tampines Service Centre and Woodlands Service Centre with a dedicated area for guiding and training members on the use of the Board’s digital transaction services. Volunteers who are keen to become an E-Xperience Guide should complete both E-Xperience Training (Beginner and Advanced) topics, including the challenges, in the Learn Module on the CPFV app.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am a FIN holder. How do I access CPF digital services?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may login to CPF digital services using your Singpass registered under your FIN.   If you have a CPF issued account (e.g. SA987654C or TC123456A) and your FIN is updated with us, you will be prompted to select your transaction profile (either CPF issued account or FIN) after you log in.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will the deceased member's CPF savings be paid to me?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your share of the deceased member’s CPF savings will be paid to you via: PayNow to your PayNow NRIC-linked bank account; or Bank transfer via Interbank GIRO to your bank account

Knowledge Article: Question: Who are the family members eligible to access the CPF account information of a deceased CPF member?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Family members, as defined under the Intestacy or Inheritance law distribution rules, will be eligible to access the information.   a. If the deceased member is a Muslim: The eligible family members under the Muslim Inheritance law will be based on the Certificate of Inheritance issued by the Syariah Court.   b. If the deceased member is a non-Muslim: The eligible family members will be based on the Intestate Succession Act distribution rules, in the following order:   If you have Eligible family members will be Spouse and Children Spouse and Children [1] No Spouse Children [1] No Children Spouse and Parent No Children No Parent Spouse No Spouse No Children Parents No Spouse No Children No Parents Siblings [2] No Spouse No Children No Parents No Siblings Grandparents No Spouse No Children No Parents No Siblings No Grandparents Uncles and Aunts [1] If Children have passed away, the eligible family members will be their children (i.e. Grandchildren) instead. [2] If Siblings have passed away, the eligible family members will be their children (i.e. Nephews and Nieces) instead.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will I be further involved after making a report on wrongdoing?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We may contact you for more information after you made a report on wrongdoing. Please ensure that you have the necessary evidence or supporting documents if you are being contacted.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will my login credentials remain the same after the transition to the new CPFV app?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You do not need to re-submit your user information. However, when you download and enter the updated CPFV app, you are required to enter your mobile number and email address that were used in the app’s previous version. OTPs will be used in place of passwords moving forward. All past and present password data are not stored in the CPFV app nor able to be accessed by us.

Knowledge Article: Question: What information do I need to provide when I report a wrongdoing?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We have outlined the key information to provide when you report a wrongdoing by following the 4Es:   1. Elaboration of the wrongdoing: Describe the nature of the wrongdoing. Include when and where it occurred, who was involved, whether any money or assets are involved.   2. Evidence: Provide any evidence you may have, such as photographs and emails, that support your claims of wrongdoing.   3. Eyewitnesses: If there are witnesses to the wrongdoing, provide their names and contact information so that they can be contacted for further information.   4. Essential contacts and your identity: Providing your identity and contact information will allow us to verify your claims and follow up on any additional information if required. Reports made anonymously may lack credibility and hinder follow-ups.   Please be assured that all reports will be treated with confidence and every effort will be made to ensure that confidentiality is maintained throughout the process.

Knowledge Article: Question: What if I need a treatment which is not on the Cancer Drug List (CDL), or is on the CDL but unsubsidised, and I cannot afford the treatment without insurance?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We encourage you to discuss with your doctor if there are suitable alternative treatments on the Cancer Drug List (CDL) that are subsidised and covered by insurance. However, if switching treatments is not feasible, there is support to help you if you face difficulty affording your treatment.   If you are a subsidised patient, you can approach a Medical Social Worker (MSW) in your public healthcare institution (PHI) for financial assistance such as MediFund. If you are a private patient, you can approach your doctor to refer you to a PHI for subsidised care. The PHI’s medical team will review your treatment plan and provide financial counselling (e.g., eligibility for subsidies) before you decide whether to transfer.   To help existing patients during this transition, MOH will provide additional financial support for all PHI patients without an Integrated Shield Plan (IP), and who had started treatments that are unsubsidised or not on the CDL before 1 September 2022. Insurers, on their part, will continue their current coverage until 30 September 2023 for patients with IP that are being renewed between 1 April 2023 and 30 September 2023, and who are on a course of cancer drug treatment as of 31 March 2023.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I read my Digital Yearly Statement of Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can view the guide on the Digital Yearly Statement of Account (YSOA) in your preferred language below:   YSOA Illustrated Summary Guide – English (PDF, 0.38MB)   YSOA Illustrated Summary Guide – Malay (PDF, 0.39MB)   YSOA Illustrated Summary Guide – Mandarin (PDF, 0.43MB)   YSOA Illustrated Summary Guide – Tamil (PDF, 0.37MB)

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I cancel a CPF nomination I made earlier?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can cancel your CPF nomination by making a new CPF nomination. The new nomination will supersede the nomination which you have made earlier.   To make a nomination, you can do so  online using your Singpass.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the assumptions used in the projections within the CPF planner - retirement income?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For more information on assumptions used within the CPF planner - retirement income, refer to our  detailed notes .

Knowledge Article: Question: Is Skills Development Levy (SDL) payable for students on vacation job?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For information on whether Skills Development Levy (SDL) is payable for students on vacation job, please visit this  webpage for more information on SDL.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I calculate the Additional Wage (AW) ceiling and the amount that attracts CPF contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Additional Wage (AW) ceiling sets the maximum amount of AW on which CPF contributions are payable per year. An employee's AW ceiling is computed on a per employer per year basis.   You can access the following resources to help you with the computation:   a.  AW ceiling Calculator   b.  Examples on the Computation of the AW ceiling (PDF, 0.6MB)

Knowledge Article: Question: Why are the excess voluntary top-ups refunded with no interest?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The excess voluntary top-ups can only be determined after all your mandatory contributions have been received for the year. This is usually after the month of January in the following year. The interest on the excess voluntary top-ups which should not be earned by the member will be returned to the Board.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on the amount that I've deducted from my employee's wages due to lateness?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may deduct your employee’s wages for being absent from work. However, the amount of deduction cannot exceed the period of absence. The authorised salary deductions are listed in the Employment Act. CPF contribution are payable on the nett wages after deduction, i.e. CPF contributions are not payable on the amount deducted where your employee did not earn any wages as he was late for work. The deduction should reduce the wages for the month in which your employee was late for work, and not the month where the deduction was made. Example Your employee was late for work on the last day of January, and the deduction of $30 was made only in February’s payroll. You should:   Pay CPF contributions on the full wages of $2,000 for February Re-calculate the wages for January, i.e. pay CPF contributions on wages of $1,970 ($2,000-$30). If you have already paid CPF contributions on the full wages of $2,000 for January, you can refer to the process to apply for a refund.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I request for a CPF volunteer's contact details after an event if I have further queries?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Our volunteers are not allowed to share their contact details. If you have further queries, please contact us via our  customer service channels .

Knowledge Article: Question: I am a government pensioner receiving lifelong medical benefits. Is the Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS) applicable to me?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS) for government pensioners will differ from other CPF members in their cohort, depending on the coverage of their Post-Retirement Medical Benefits Schemes. The BHS is not applicable to government pensioners under the Fixed Amount on Ward Charges Scheme (FAW). The working contributions allocated to their MediSave Account and MediSave top-ups will be channelled to their other CPF accounts. Pensioners under the Co-payment on Ward Charges Scheme (CPW) have a lower BHS than other CPF members in their cohort. Thereafter, any working contributions allocated to their MediSave and MediSave top-ups will be channelled to their other CPF accounts. Pensioners under the Comprehensive Co-Payment Scheme (CCS) and MediSave-cum-Subsidised Outpatient (MSO) Scheme will have the same BHS as other CPF members in their cohort. Dependants of pensioners will have the same BHS as all other CPF members in their cohort.

Knowledge Article: Question: As an employer, how do I apply to the Board for a single Additional Wage (AW) ceiling if my employees were transferred to another related company during the year?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Additional Wage (AW) ceiling is computed on a per employer per calendar year basis. However, you may apply for a single AW ceiling for transferred employees within two related companies, if:   1. Both employers are related;   2. Your employee has been informed on the application; and   3. The Terms & Conditions of the employment contract remain unchanged.   Please note that this application is only for transferred employees whose mandatory CPF contributions have exceeded/will exceed the AW ceiling.   To apply for a single AW ceiling, you may submit an online request

Knowledge Article: Question: Why doesn't CPF Mobile offer all the services found on CPF website?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF Mobile and CPF website complement each other to serve different needs of our customers as we deliver a multi-channel digital experience. CPF Mobile provides easy access to popular services such as viewing account balances to allow one to access CPF information on the go, while the website allows customers to access the full suite of CPF digital services.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I make a CPF nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can make a CPF nomination online or at our CPF Service Centres.   Online   You can make a CPF nomination online by logging in to my cpf digital services with your Singpass. Making your nomination online is convenient as it can be done anytime, anywhere. You will need to prepare your Singpass, as well as the particulars of your nominee(s) and witnesses .   If you cannot find witnesses to witness your online nomination, you can visit the ServiceSG Centres. Officers at the ServiceSG Centres can act as witnesses for your online nomination. See the list of ServiceSG Centres locations and its operating hours.   At CPF Service Centres   Alternatively, you may visit any of our CPF Service Centres to make your CPF nomination. Please make an appointment at least one working day in advance, as counter services at CPF Service Centre are available by appointment only. Our Customer Service Executives will act as your witnesses for your nomination. Find out what are the supporting documents you need to bring along with you .

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I calculate CPF contributions on Additional Wages (AW) when there is a change in Age Group during the year?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The change in CPF contribution rate should be applied from the first day of the following month after your employee’s birthday month. For example, if your employee’s 55 th birthday falls on 15 January 2021, the change in CPF contribution rate for age above 55 to 60 years old will be applied from the month of February 2021 and the subsequent months.   Any shortfall in CPF contributions on Additional Wages (AW) should follow the applicable rate for the month in which the AW were paid. The shortfall should be paid together with December’s contributions or contributions for your employee’s last month of employment, whichever is applicable.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why does my child not have a MediShield Life cover to claim for the hospitalisation bills incurred before he passed away?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We are sorry to hear of your child's demise. The MediShield Life claims can be submitted by the medical institution and will be processed if your child was a Singaporean/Singapore Permanent Resident.   Please contact us at 1800-222-3399 or  write to us with your child's details.

Knowledge Article: Question: Who needs to declare their health status under MediShield Life and CareShield Life?
Knowledge Article: Answer: All new Permanent Resident (PR) applicants who have received In-Principle Approval for their Singapore Permanent Residence application are required to declare their health condition before proceeding to complete Formalities with ICA.   The health status declared will not affect their application for Singapore Permanent Residence.   All PR applicants, regardless of age, will be covered under MediShield Life. However, if the PR applicant is found to have serious pre-existing health conditions, he/she may be subjected to Additional Premiums of 30% for MediShield Life for 10 years, because of his/her higher health risks.   If the PR applicant is born in 1979 or earlier and obtained permanent residency status on or after 1 October 2020, he/she will be insured under CareShield Life if he/she does not have severe disability. From 1 November 2021, PR applicants may be required to go for disability assessment under CareShield Life before being allowed to complete Formalities with ICA.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will I be eligible for MediShield Life Premium Subsidies if I earn more than $2,800?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The $2,800 figure refers to the household monthly income per person, which is based on the total income earned by a family staying in the same residential address, divided by the number of members of that family.   If the total income earned by family members is $10,000, and there are four members in the family, then the household monthly income per person is $2,500, and the family would qualify for subsidies.   Up to two-thirds of the population would qualify for Premium Subsidies. This is a fairer way of calculating the need for subsidies, because a family with more members may need more support, even if the total income they make is quite high. This is because the amount they can spend on each family member will be lower if there are more family members.   Families in a lower household income category will get a higher subsidy rate. In this way, we give more help to those who have less resources and need more help. This is part of being a compassionate and inclusive society.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am a Pioneer Generation member (Pioneers). How much subsidies will I receive for my MediShield Life premium?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Pioneers Generation Subsidies range from 40% at age 65 to 60% at age 90.   The Government is committed to helping Pioneer Generation seniors aged 80 and above in 2014 by fully covering their MediShield Life premiums. This is done through a combination of Pioneer Generation Subsidies and MediSave top-ups. For younger Pioneers, their MediShield life premiums will be about half of the MediShield premiums after Pioneer Generation Subsidies and MediSave top-ups.   You can login to Healthcare dashboard 'Coverage and premium details' to check your coverage, premiums and subsidies.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why am I receiving subsidies even though I have withdrawn from the eligibility check for MediShield Life Premium Subsidies?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There are different types of MediShield Life premium subsidies.   The eligibility check process was used to determine eligibility for MediShield Life Premium Subsidies for lower- to middle-income Singapore Residents.     If you did not participate in the eligibility check, the Government will still compute the MediShield Life Premium Subsidies for your household. However, it will be based on existing information in Government records, which may not be up-to-date. For individuals who miss the date to confirm their household information and wish to make changes, please call 1800-222-3399 for further assistance.   Pioneer Generation Subsidies and Merdeka Generation Subsidies are given based on your Pioneer Generation and Merdeka Generation statuses, and are applied automatically to your MediShield Life premium.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will employers similarly receive support for the increase in CPF contribution rates from 1 January 2023?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Similar to the support provided in 2022, the CPF Transition Offset (CTO) will provide transitory wage offsets to alleviate the rise in business costs due to the increase in CPF contribution rates for senior workers. Find out more about CPF Transition Offset .

Knowledge Article: Question: Can the premium recovery measures for MediShield Life be waived?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Premium recovery measures cannot be waived as premiums must be paid timely. These measures are only imposed if the member defaults on premium payments repeatedly.   By paying on time, members do not cause others to shoulder their premium debts. You can write to us at www.cpf.gov.sg/writetous if you need assistance with premium payments.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will checks be conducted for new Singapore Residents who are covered under MediShield Life?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For new Singapore Residents who are covered under MediShield Life, we will have a range of checks, including reviewing medical records after they are covered. They are required to declare their health status upon receipt of the In-Principle Approval (IPA) letter from the Immigration Checkpoint Authority of Singapore (ICA).   If they are identified to have serious pre-existing medical conditions, they will be subjected to 30% Additional Premiums for 10 years. Those who make false health declarations will be guilty of an offence under the MediShield Life Scheme Act and will be liable to pay penalties.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am required to pay CPF contributions for a bonus to an ex-employee. Would CPF contribution for the bonus be contributed for his last month of employment or the month when it is due or payable?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If the bonus is due and payable in a particular month after your employee leaves employment, CPF contribution for the bonus should be contributed for that month.   However, if the bonus payment was a result of an oversight as it was payable to your employee in his last month of employment or earlier, you should indicate that particular month as the contribution month. Please note that interest will be levied on any late payments.   Find out more if CPF contributions are payable on Additional Wages payable to ex-employees after they have left their employer’s employment .

Knowledge Article: Question: Does the Cancer Drug List also apply to inpatient cancer drug treatments under MediShield Life and MediSave?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Currently, the Cancer Drug List does not apply to inpatient cancer drug treatments as these are covered separately under the inpatient claim limits for MediShield Life and MediSave, together with other costs incurred during the inpatient stay.

Knowledge Article: Question: Does the Cancer Drug List also apply to inpatient cancer drug treatments under MediShield Life and MediSave?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Currently, the Cancer Drug List does not apply to inpatient cancer drug treatments as these are covered separately under the inpatient claim limits for MediShield Life and MediSave, together with other costs incurred during the inpatient stay.

Knowledge Article: Question: If my treatment is not on the Cancer Drug List (CDL), will I still be covered under MediShield Life and MediSave?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediShield Life and MediSave will only cover treatments on the Cancer Drug List (CDL) from 1 September 2022.   For Integrated Shield Plans (IPs), the CDL will only come into effect from 1 April 2023 onwards, when an existing policy is renewed, or a new policy is purchased. If you have an IP that is being renewed between 1 April 2023 and 30 September 2023, and are on a course of cancer drug treatment as of 31 March 2023, insurers have committed to preserve your current IP coverage until 30 September 2023.   Riders will cover treatments beyond the CDL, though the extent of coverage may vary. Your insurer should inform you of the details of your IP and rider coverage by end 2022.

Knowledge Article: Question: If my treatment is not on the Cancer Drug List (CDL), will I still be covered under MediShield Life and MediSave?
Knowledge Article: Answer: MediShield Life and MediSave will only cover treatments on the Cancer Drug List (CDL) from 1 September 2022.   For Integrated Shield Plans (IPs), the CDL will only come into effect from 1 April 2023 onwards, when an existing policy is renewed, or a new policy is purchased. If you have an IP that is being renewed between 1 April 2023 and 30 September 2023, and are on a course of cancer drug treatment as of 31 March 2023, insurers have committed to preserve your current IP coverage until 30 September 2023.   Riders will cover treatments beyond the CDL, though the extent of coverage may vary. Your insurer should inform you of the details of your IP and rider coverage by end 2022.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens if I have to change treatment in the middle of the month? Does it mean that the new treatment is not claimable?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For patients who have to switch treatment in the middle of the month, both treatments would be claimable up to the higher of the MediShield Life, MediSave and Integrated Shield Plan claim limits applicable for each individual treatment.

Knowledge Article: Question: My witnesses are residing in a different country from me. Can I appoint them as witnesses for my CPF nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you can make an online nomination and appoint them as your witnesses as long as they meet the criteria to be a witness and have a valid Singpass.   Once you have decided on your witnesses, you should contact them and inform them of your intention to make a nomination. You should request that they confirm this when asked to do so by CPF Board.

Knowledge Article: Question: What do I need to do before I sell or transfer my property?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are planning to sell or transfer your property, there are a few matters you need to complete beforehand. The steps you need to take depend on the type of property you own.   For HDB flat   You will need to check with HDB to see if you are eligible to sell or transfer your flat. Once you have received their consent, either HDB or your lawyer (if you have one) will check with the Board on the amount, if any, that needs to be refunded to your CPF account.   For private property   You will need to instruct your lawyer to obtain consent from the Board before you sell or transfer your property.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long does it take to process the refunds from sale of my property to my CPF account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please refer to the table for our service standards for processing the refunds from the sale of your property to your CPF account   Service Normal Processing Time Process refund from sale of property to CPF account Within fifteen working days upon receipt of funds This includes the time to clear cheque/cashier's order.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I did not use my CPF savings for my property, do I have to top up my Retirement Account upon sale of my property?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You do not have to top up your Retirement Account as you have never used your CPF savings for the property purchase.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is there any accrued interest on the amount of CPF savings used for my property?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Interest will accrue on the amount of CPF savings that you have used for your property. You are required to refund the accrued interest together with the CPF principal amount withdrawn when you sell, transfer or dispose your property.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am not taking any loan to buy my property. Must I still produce a valuation report if I want to use my CPF savings to buy my property?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Even if you are not taking a loan to buy your property, you will still need to produce a valuation report if you want to use your CPF savings to purchase the property. This report helps us determine the maximum amount of CPF savings you can use for your property.   If you are buying an HDB flat, we will only accept the valuation determined by HDB, which should not be more than three months from the date of your application.   If you are buying a private property, we will only accept a valuation report conducted by a licensed valuer, which should also not be more than three months from the date of your property purchase.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I check my outstanding Housing & Development Board (HDB) loan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For issues related to your Housing & Development Board (HDB) flat, such as checking your outstanding HDB loan, please visit HDB's website .

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I make a CPF nomination if I am a bankrupt?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Even if you are bankrupt, you should make a CPF nomination if you want your CPF savings to be distributed according to your wishes.   If you do not make a CPF nomination, your CPF savings will be transferred to the Public Trustee's Office for distribution to your family member(s) in accordance with the intestacy laws or inheritance certificate (for Muslims) in Singapore. This ensures that the welfare of your dependants is provided for.

Knowledge Article: Question: The courts ordered my ex-spouse and I to make our CPF refunds from our respective share of sale proceeds. My share is insufficient. Can I waive the shortfall in refund?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, full requisite CPF refunds must be made in accordance with CPF legislation upon the sale of the property in a divorce. If your (or your ex-spouse’s) respective share of sale proceeds are not enough to cover the required refunds to your CPF account, you will need to make up the shortfall in cash.   If you and your ex-spouse are unable to proceed with the sale of the property, please seek legal advice on how your proprietary share in the matrimonial asset can be satisfied.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long will CPF Board take to give effect to the court order?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Upon receipt of your court order, the Board will generally take two to three weeks to give effect to the court order. As court orders differ in complexity, the CPF Board will need to review the relevant orders and will keep the lawyers and parties informed on the progress of the matter.   We will upload the replies to you and your ex-spouse via your registered email address in our record or  Mailbox for members. An SMS will be sent to the Mailbox recipient's mobile number in our record. For law firms and the Legal Aid Bureau, we will reply via their registered email address.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have made a voluntary refund. Do I still need to refund to my CPF account when I sell my property?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The amount that you have to refund upon selling your property depends on how much you have voluntarily refunded:   If you have fully refunded all the CPF savings you have withdrawn for your property with accrued interest, you do not need to make any refunds If you have partially refunded the CPF savings you have withdrawn for your property with accrued interest, you will need to refund the balance CPF savings you have used with interest When a property is sold, the selling price will generally will be used to pay the following in this order:   1. Outstanding housing loan 2. Required CPF refund 3. Other sale expenses, e.g., legal fees; If the selling price (including the option monies) after paying the outstanding housing loan is not enough to make the required CPF refund, you do not need to top up the shortfall in cash as long as the property is sold at market value.   However, the option monies (e.g. option fee and option exercise fee) received from your buyer in cash upon the sale of your property are considered part of the selling price and need to be refunded to your co-owner’s and your CPF accounts before the transaction can be completed.   The refunded amount will be returned to your co-owner's and your CPF accounts in the following proportions:   Amount returned to owner A’s CPF Account: Amount returned to owner B’s CPF Account:

Knowledge Article: Question: Will the deceased member's CPF savings be used to pay his income tax liabilities?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, the deceased member’s CPF savings will not be used to pay his income tax liabilities. This is because CPF savings do not form part of the deceased member’s estate.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to the deceased member's property bought using his CPF savings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF savings used to buy the property need not be refunded to the deceased member’s CPF account. The property will form part of his estate if it is held in tenancy-in-common or passed on to the remaining surviving owner(s) if it is held in joint tenancy.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have bought an annuity in place of the retirement sum when I turned 55. Will my nominees receive the remaining guaranteed sum from my annuity when I pass away?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you had bought an annuity in place of the retirement sum when you turned 55, your nominees will receive the remaining guaranteed sum from your annuity when you pass away.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have bought an annuity in place of the retirement sum when I turned 55. Will my nominees receive the remaining guaranteed sum from my annuity when I pass away?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you had bought an annuity in place of the retirement sum when you turned 55, your nominees will receive the remaining guaranteed sum from your annuity when you pass away.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I have not made a CPF nomination at the point of my passing, what will be distributed to my family under intestacy laws?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have not made a CPF nomination at the point of your passing, we will pay the savings in your Ordinary, Special, MediSave and Retirement Accounts to the Public Trustee’s Office for distribution to your family member(s) in accordance with the intestacy laws or inheritance certificate (for Muslims) in Singapore.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I have not made a CPF nomination at the point of my passing, what will be distributed to my family under intestacy laws?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have not made a CPF nomination at the point of your passing, we will pay the savings in your Ordinary, Special, MediSave and Retirement Accounts to the Public Trustee’s Office for distribution to your family member(s) in accordance with the intestacy laws or inheritance certificate (for Muslims) in Singapore.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to authorise specific person(s) to access my CPF account information when I pass away?
Knowledge Article: Answer: From 1 February 2024, nominees and eligible family members under intestacy laws will be allowed to access your CPF account information, after your passing.   With this change, there is no longer a need for you to authorise your loved ones to access your CPF account information upon demise.

Knowledge Article: Question: How is the CPF contribution rate applied when my employee moves to the next age group?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The contribution rates of your employee aged above 55, 60, 65 or 70 years shall be applied from the first day of the month after the month of his 55 th , 60 th , 65 th or 70 th birthday. Example: Your employee’s 55 th birthday falls on 13 January 2024. CPF contribution rate For wages earned in January 2024 (55 years and below) For wages earned in February 2024 (Above 55 to 60 years) 37% of total wages (>$750) (Employer's share = 17%; Employee's share = 20%) 31% of total wages (>$750) (Employer's share = 15%; Employee's share = 16%) Note: The employee is deemed to have attained 55 years of age on his 55 th birthday and would be classified in the "55 years and below" age group; and deemed to be above 55 years old on the day after his 55 th birthday. As the contribution rates are applicable on a monthly basis, he will be classified in the "Above 55 to 60 years" age group in the month after his 55 th birthday i.e. month of February 2024.

Knowledge Article: Question: What will happen to my CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) investments if I leave Singapore permanently and withdraw all my CPF monies?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA), we will inform the agent bank to close your CPF Investment Account. The agent bank will contact you for the withdrawal of your investments and cash balance (if any) in your CPF Investment Account. Your investments will be transferred* to your own name and you may thereafter continue servicing your investments using cash or liquidate them as you wish and have the sale proceeds paid to you directly.   * Central Depository (Pte) Ltd (“CDP”) imposes a transfer fee of $10.00 (excluding GST) for every share counter transferred from your CPF Investment Account to your CDP Account.   For CPF Investment Scheme-Special Account (CPFIS-SA), we will inform your product provider(s) to transfer your investments to your own name and you may thereafter liquidate them as you wish and have the sale proceeds paid to you directly.   Once withdrawn, your CPFIS investments and cash balance in your CPF Investment Account will no longer be protected from any claims by your creditors and/or the Official Assignee.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on COVID-19 allowance given to my employees to defray their transport, meal, lodging and utility expenses as they are required to work at a different location?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on COVID-19 allowance given to your employees.   CPF contributions are not payable on cash payment given to defray your employees’ transport, meal, lodging or utility expenses if they are required to work at a different location (not their normal place of work) provided that the following conditions are fulfilled:   a. The payment is provided in the form of reimbursement based on actual expenditure of which proof must be shown;   b. The reimbursement does not increase the employees’ wages; and   c. Your employees are only entitled to such reimbursements based on their continued attendance at employment and work in Singapore of which transport, meal, lodging and utility expenses would be incurred due to the COVID-19 situations, e.g. lockdown, Work From Home, Leave Of Absence or relocation to other site.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long will it take for the withdrawal amount to be refunded to the deceased's CPF account if the PayNow transaction was unsuccessful?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The amount will be returned to the deceased's CPF account generally within two working days.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the changes to the CPF contribution rates for senior workers that will take effect from 1 January 2024?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To strengthen senior workers’ retirement adequacy, the Tripartite Workgroup on Older Workers had recommended in 2019 that CPF contribution rates for senior workers aged above 55 to 70 years be raised gradually to help senior workers save more for retirement. The first two steps of increases took effect on 1 January 2022 and 1 January 2023. The Government continued to raise the senior worker contribution rates in 2024 with a long-term target to have the full increase rolled out by 2030. The changes to the CPF contribution rates from 1 January 2024 are shown below: For employees earning monthly wages exceeding $750   Employee's age (years) CPF Contribution Rates from 1 January 2024 2023 Total (% of wage) Total (% of wage) By employer (% of wage) By employee (% of wage) 55 and below 37 37 17 20 Above 55 to 60 29.5 31 (+1.5) 15 (+0.5) 16 (+1) Above 60 to 65 20.5 22 (+1.5) 11.5 (+0.5) 10.5 (+1) Above 65 to 70 15.5 16.5 (+1) 9 (+0.5) 7.5 (+0.5) Above 70 12.5 12.5 7.5 5 (a) The increase in the CPF contribution rates is fully allocated to the Special Account to help senior workers save more for retirement. (b) For those earning monthly wages of more than $500 to $750, the employee contribution rates continue to be phased in. (c) There were no changes to the graduated contribution rates for first and second year Singapore Permanent Residents.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the retirement sums - Basic Retirement Sum (BRS), Full Retirement Sum (FRS) and Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Planning for your retirement is easier with the retirement sums – Basic Retirement Sum (BRS), Full Retirement Sum (FRS), and Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS). They provide a guide on the CPF savings you need to reach your desired monthly payouts in retirement .   The BRS is meant to provide you with monthly payouts in retirement to cover basic living needs, excluding rental expenses.   The FRS is two times of BRS and can provide you with higher monthly payouts that also cover rental expenses. That is why when you turn 55, your CPF savings up to your FRS is set aside in your Retirement Account (RA) to provide you with monthly payouts in retirement.   If you own a property in Singapore with remaining lease that lasts you until you are 95 or older, you have the flexibility to meet your FRS with a mixture of property (up to half your FRS) and cash, and can apply to withdraw part of your RA savings down to your BRS using your property .   If you wish to receive even higher payouts for your desired retirement lifestyle, you can choose to set aside more by making a top-up , up to the current ERS . The ERS is the maximum amount that you can top up to your RA, and is increased yearly for those who wish to receive higher payouts. From 2025, the  ERS will be raised from 3 times the BRS to 4 times to enable members to voluntarily commit more savings for even higher payouts. To find out how much you can top up, log in to your  Retirement dashboard .   See what are the retirement sums applicable to you .   Ultimately, how much you set aside depends on your CPF balances and desired monthly payouts. It’s important to plan ahead by assessing how much payouts you need to meet your expenses in retirement. Find out using the  Monthly payout estimator .

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the retirement sums - Basic Retirement Sum (BRS), Full Retirement Sum (FRS) and Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Planning for your retirement is easier with the retirement sums – Basic Retirement Sum (BRS), Full Retirement Sum (FRS), and Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS). They provide a guide on the CPF savings you need to reach your desired monthly payouts in retirement .   The BRS is meant to provide you with monthly payouts in retirement to cover basic living needs, excluding rental expenses.   The FRS is two times of BRS and can provide you with higher monthly payouts that also cover rental expenses. That is why when you turn 55, your CPF savings up to your FRS is set aside in your Retirement Account (RA) to provide you with monthly payouts in retirement.   If you own a property in Singapore with remaining lease that lasts you until you are 95 or older, you have the flexibility to meet your FRS with a mixture of property (up to half your FRS) and cash, and can apply to withdraw part of your RA savings down to your BRS using your property .   If you wish to receive even higher payouts for your desired retirement lifestyle, you can choose to set aside more by making a top-up , up to the current ERS . The ERS is the maximum amount that you can top up to your RA, and is increased yearly for those who wish to receive higher payouts. From 2025, the  ERS will be raised from 3 times the BRS to 4 times to enable members to voluntarily commit more savings for even higher payouts. To find out how much you can top up, log in to your  Retirement dashboard .   See what are the retirement sums applicable to you .   Ultimately, how much you set aside depends on your CPF balances and desired monthly payouts. It’s important to plan ahead by assessing how much payouts you need to meet your expenses in retirement. Find out using the  Monthly payout estimator .

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I choose to transfer my CPF savings partially when my CPF account is closed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, your CPF savings will be paid to you in full.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I have to go to Singapore to cancel my Permanent Resident status if I am closing my CPF account upon leaving Singapore?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To check the procedure for cancelling your Permanent Resident status for the purpose of closing your CPF account upon leaving Singapore, you can contact Immigration & Checkpoints Authority (ICA) at 6391 6100 or  email  them.

Knowledge Article: Question: What can I do if I have not received my cheque or my cheque has expired?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please notify the Board via Write to Us  if you have not received your cheque within four months from the point of form submission.   Should there be any exceptions, please note that you will need to bear all administrative charges following the re-issuance of the cheque.

Knowledge Article: Question: What if a non-Singapore Citizen or non-Permanent Resident with a CPF account has passed away before he had closed his account and transferred all his CPF savings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The next of kin will have to  inform CPF Board of his passing  with the original death certificate. Thereafter, the deceased’s remaining savings will be  distributed to his beneficiaries , depending on whether he had made a valid CPF nomination before his passing.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens if I am unable to pay CPF contributions on time due to COVID-19?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The due date for CPF contributions is on the last day of the calendar month. Enforcement action would be taken against employers who fail to pay by the 14 th of the following month (or the next working day if the 14 th falls on a Saturday, Sunday or Public Holiday). This includes imposing late payment interest charged at 1.5% per month commencing from the first day after the due date. Timely payment of CPF contributions is important for employees to meet their housing, retirement and healthcare needs. Nevertheless, we appreciate that the COVID-19 situation is extremely challenging and difficult for businesses in some sectors. Apart from the support measures announced by the Government at Singapore Budget 2020, companies facing cash flow issues can explore the following options to keep their businesses viable: Tapping on training support schemes to send their employees for training and upskilling and receive absentee payroll funding ; Making adjustments to work arrangements with or without wage cuts; Making direct adjustments to wages; or Putting employees on no-pay leave. Employers can refer to the Tripartite Advisory on Managing Excess Manpower and Responsible Retrenchment for guidance on the appropriate measures to cope with cash flow issues and manage excess manpower. You may also wish to look out for the additional support measures for workers and businesses in response to the COVID-19 pandemic that the Government announced at Singapore Budget 2021:   COVID-19 Resilience Package .

Knowledge Article: Question: Why are the employee's contribution rates lower/different for those earning total monthly wages of more than $500 but less than $750?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For employees earning total monthly wage of more than $500 but less than $750, the employee’s share of CPF contributions are computed based on phased-in rates to avoid a sudden drop in the employees’ take home pay when there is an increase in wage. You can use our CPF Contribution Calculator to calculate the CPF contributions applicable to your employees.

Knowledge Article: Question: When will the top-ups received in my CPF Special/Retirement Account start to earn interest?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you receive a cash top-up this month, it will start earning interest in the next month.   For CPF transfers of existing CPF savings, you will start earning interest in your account from this month. However, if the CPF savings are fresh injections, it will start earning interest in your account from the next month.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have set up a new company and transferred my existing employees to that company. Do I need to apply for a new CPF Submission Number (CSN)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will need to apply for a new CPF Submission Number (CSN) in order to make CPF contributions for a new company. The CSN is made up of the Unique Entity Number (UEN) and CPF Payment Code, which are unique to the entity.   You can apply for a new CSN on the CPF website, and once processed, a new CSN will be issued. Please provide the employees' account information when making the first payment under the new CSN, as CPF Board is unable to transfer the details from the old CSN. Refer to the " Apply for CSN and Setup CPF EZPay Quick Guide " for more information on CSN application.   You will also need to inform the Board if you cease to engage any employees under the old UEN to prevent late payment penalties.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why was the cash top-up to my / my loved one's Special or Retirement Account refunded or partially refunded?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your top-up was refunded as you / your loved one had received other inflows at the same time as the cash top-up was made. These inflows had resulted in you / your loved one to meet the current Full Retirement Sum or Enhanced Retirement Sum (for members age 55 or above).

Knowledge Article: Question: I was ineligible for Matched Retirement Savings Scheme for the past few years after turning 71 years old. With the lifting of the age cap of 70 from 2025, will my eligibility be revised for the past few years?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, the enhancements start from 2025. With the lifting of the age cap, eligible seniors above 70 can make cash top-ups and receive the same amount of MRSS matching grant as those aged 55 to 70. The Government has also increased the annual matching grant amount to $2,000, compared to $600 before.

Knowledge Article: Question: I received Matched Retirement Savings Scheme matching grants in the past, before the $20,000 lifetime cap takes effect in early 2025. Will the past matching grants count towards this $20,000 lifetime cap?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The enhancements to the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme are effective from 2025 and thus, the lifetime cap will only be applied from 2025 onwards. Matching grants received in the past for cash top-ups made prior to 2025, will not count towards the $20,000 lifetime cap.

Knowledge Article: Question: When should I submit the application for excess contribution on Additional Wages?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You should submit it when the employee's Total Wages for the year are known, usually after the contribution payment for December or in the last month of employment.

Knowledge Article: Question: My Singapore Permanent Resident employee contributed CPF at a higher rate than stipulated ones in his previous employment. Am I required to pay CPF at the higher rate?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The higher contribution rate ceases upon a change of employment within the first two years of obtaining Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR) status i.e. the rates will go back to the graduated rates . Therefore, there is no need to contribute CPF at higher rates.   If you and your SPR employee wish to contribute at higher rates, you can submit a joint application with your SPR employee based on your entity type:   For UEN-registered entities   For individuals trading under own name

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if I am unable to pay my employees their CPF contributions on time?
Knowledge Article: Answer: It is the employer’s obligation to ensure that CPF contributions are paid on time and to communicate the CPF contributions payment dates to your employees. Your employees have the right to check with you on the non-payment of their CPF contributions, including asking for an explanation and when you will be making payment. CPF contributions are important to employees for their housing, healthcare and retirement needs. Information on the payment date and amount of CPF contributions will help them to manage their financial needs and commitments.   If you are unable to pay your employees their CPF contributions on time, you have to ensure that the CPF arrears are paid as soon as possible and that the CPF contributions are accorded priority amongst the company’s outstanding payments. You should also inform your employees beforehand the reasons for being late and when they can expect the payment.   CPF Board takes a serious view of employers who default on CPF contributions. The due date for CPF contributions is on the last day of the calendar month. Enforcement action would be taken against employers who fail to pay by the 14 th of the following month (or the next working day if the 14 th falls on a Saturday, Sunday or Public Holiday). This includes imposing late payment interest charged at 1.5% per month commencing from the first day after the due date.   Find out more on your obligations as an employer under the CPF Act and the Employment Act at the  Workright website .

Knowledge Article: Question: With the increase in Ordinary Wage ceiling from September 2023, how should I compute the Additional Wage ceiling?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your employee is earning monthly Ordinary Wages (OW) that are above $6,000, the estimated Additional Wage (AW) ceiling for the year 2023 should be $102,000 – ($6,000 x 8) – ($W x 4) where W is capped at the Ordinary Wage (OW) ceiling of $6,300 from September 2023.   For example, if your employee’s monthly OW is $7,000, the estimated AW ceiling for 2023 will be $28,800 instead of $30,000. You should pay CPF contributions on the AW up to $28,800.   If your employee is earning monthly OW that are $6,000 or below, the estimated AW ceiling will not be affected by the increase in OW ceiling.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the benefits of receiving my CPF savings via PayNow?
Knowledge Article: Answer: With PayNow, you can generally receive your CPF savings in your NRIC-linked bank account   almost instantly . It is also hassle-free as you do not need to provide bank account details or supporting documents for us to verify your bank account.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long will it take for me to receive my CPF savings via PayNow?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your application is successful, you will generally receive the payment in your NRIC-linked bank account  almost instantly .

Knowledge Article: Question: How can my family member authorise the Board to deduct my Home Protection Scheme premium from their CPF Ordinary Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your family member (that is your spouse, parent, child or sibling) who co-owns the flat with you can authorise us to use their CPF Ordinary Account savings online using their Singpass to pay for your Home Protection Scheme premium.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I check if my property lease is able to last me until I am 95?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can check the remaining lease of your HDB property via the Housing and Development Board (HDB) website , or the Singapore Land Authority (SLA) website for private property.

Knowledge Article: Question: When can I apply to pay CPF contribution at a higher rate for my Singapore Permanent Resident employee?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can start applying from the day your employee become a Singapore Permanent Resident.

Knowledge Article: Question: Must I contribute CPF at a higher rate for my Singapore Permanent Resident employee?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You are not required to contribute CPF at a higher rate for your Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR) employee who is in the first two years of his SPR status. However, you are required to contribute CPF at the graduated rates.   If you and your SPR employee wish to contribute at higher rates, you can submit a joint application with your SPR employee based on your entity type:   For UEN-registered entities   For individuals trading under own name

Knowledge Article: Question: What if I lose my Home Protection Scheme (HPS) certificate containing my HPS cover details?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You would not need to provide the Home Protection Scheme (HPS) certificate as a supporting document for any purpose, including making a claim under HPS. You can view your HPS coverage information under “Protection against losing your home” via the Home ownership dashboard .   Alternatively, if you require further clarification on your HPS coverage details, you may  write to us and select “Housing/Property” as the  Subject and “General Enquiry – Home Protection Scheme” as the Category .

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I contribute more CPF for my employee who just obtained his Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR) status?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You and your employee can contribute CPF at higher rates in the first two years after your employee has obtained Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR) status.   There are two options available:   1. You and your employee both contribute at full rates; or   2. You contribute at full rates while your employee continues to contribute at graduated rates.   You can submit a joint application with your SPR employee based on your entity type:   For UEN-registered entities   For individuals trading under own name
