Knowledge Article: Question: If my property is co-owned, does my co-owner need to be present at CPF Service Centre when I am making the property pledging withdrawal?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, only you need to be present at CPF Service Centre. However, you must bring along the original completed co-owner consent form.

Knowledge Article: Question: How does the closure of Special Account affect my voluntary top-ups to my three CPF accounts?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are below age 55, your voluntary top-ups to three accounts will continue to be allocated to the Ordinary Account (OA), Special Account (SA), and MediSave Account.   If you are aged 55 and above, the portion of voluntary top-ups that goes to your SA currently will be allocated to your Retirement Account (RA) up to the Full Retirement Sum. Once you have set aside the Full Retirement Sum in your RA, it will be allocated to your OA.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I update CPF Board of any changes to my entity's particulars?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can update the particulars of your entity as follows:   (i) Principal place of business and contact details:   Login using your Singpass and go to  Account settings . You can update your business address or contact details of the owner/employer representative and persons in charge of CPF contribution matters.   If you are an individual trading under your own name, you can only update the particulars for your own CSN.   (ii) Employer name:   Write to us to update the details if you have recently made changes to the entity's name through your Unique Entity Number (UEN) issuance agency or the Immigration & Checkpoints Authority.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to my CPF LIFE plan if I am approved to withdraw under the Reduced Life Expectancy scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are approved to withdraw your retirement savings under the Reduced Life Expectancy scheme, you can decide whether to:   (i) terminate your CPF LIFE plan and receive a refund of the premium balance (if applicable); or   (ii) keep your CPF LIFE plan and receive monthly payouts for as long as you live.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if I have omitted or under-paid to the Self-Help Groups (SHGs)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have omitted or underpaid to the Self-Help Groups (SHGs), please refer to the following SHGs to find out how to back pay the contributions.   For Chinese Development Assistance Council (CDAC) Fund, Eurasian Community Fund (ECF) and Singapore Indian Development Association (SINDA) Fund   Please back pay starting from January of the current year, even if there were omissions for past years. Please include the omitted amounts in your next contribution submission to CPF Board.   For Mosque Building and Mendaki Fund (MBMF)   Please back pay starting from the day it was omitted (including past years’ omissions). Please include the omitted amounts in your next contribution submission to CPF Board.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have made a PayNow QR payment but I am not able to see an immediate update to my CPF balance(s). Why is my CPF account balance(s) not updated immediately?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Such cases are extremely rare and may arise due to intermittent network connectivity issues beyond CPF Board's control. As a result, the status of your PayNow payment may be delayed, and your CPF account balance(s) may not be updated instantly. Please do not worry as your CPF account balance(s) will be updated within 3-5 working days and you will receive an email notification if you have registered your email address with us. Please check your CPF account balance(s)/E-form status again after 3-5 working days and alert us immediately if your payment is still not updated.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long does it take to process my application to withdraw my retirement savings using my pension/annuity?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We will pay your retirement savings to your bank account generally within seven working days after we have received all necessary information. However, we may require more time if we need additional information/documents such as outstanding tax liabilities with IRAS.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have set up a GIRO arrangement to make top-ups to my spouse or sibling before 16 February 2024. With the increase in income threshold from $4,000 to $8,000, how can I amend my instructions for the GIRO arrangement to claim tax relief?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The increase in income threshold for tax relief for cash top-ups to spouse or sibling will apply to cash top-ups made on 1 January 2024 or after. If you have a GIRO arrangement to make regular cash top-ups to your spouse or sibling and instructed to not claim tax relief previously, you can submit an application to amend your instructions to claim tax relief for top-ups from 2024 onwards.

Knowledge Article: Question: I made a cash top-up to my spouse/sibling between 1 January 2024 and 16 February 2024 and instructed that I did not wish to claim tax relief. With the increase in income threshold from $4,000 to $8,000, how can I amend my instruction to claim tax relief?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can submit an application to amend your instructions to claim tax relief for top-ups made in 2024, if your recipient’s income in 2023 is between $4,000 and $8,000 (inclusive). If you indicated that you have a GIRO arrangement to make regular top-ups to your spouse or sibling in the application, your instructions for the GIRO arrangement will also be amended to claim tax relief for future GIRO top-ups. Please note that other conditions to qualify for tax relief apply .

Knowledge Article: Question: How long does it take to process my top-up application?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please refer to the table for our normal processing time for processing top-up applications:   Top-Up Via Payment Mode Normal Processing time Processing Deduction and Crediting Cash PayNow QR OCBC Digital Almost instantly Online GIRO (participating bank users) Upon successful application to set up GIRO to make cash top-ups, please allow one day for your GIRO bank account to be updated in the Board's record. GIRO deduction will take effect from the following month upon successful application of your recurring cash top-ups. If you are updating your GIRO bank account, find out more on the GIRO deduction for your existing recurring top-up arrangements . We will deduct the monies from your bank account on the 15 th of the month (or the next working day if 15 th falls on a Saturday, Sunday or Public Holiday). Your top-up will be credited within seven working days after we receive your payment. Note: Please ensure that you maintain sufficient funds in your bank account for GIRO deductions. Some banks may charge an administrative fee for each unsuccessful deduction. CPF Transfer   - Five working days upon receipt of application

Knowledge Article: Question: Am I allowed to submit another online nomination if my previous nomination is still pending action from my witnesses?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You cannot submit another nomination if you have an existing nomination pending witnessing. However, if any of your witnesses has not completed their witnessing, you can withdraw your nomination and submit a new one.   How can I withdraw my online nomination?

Knowledge Article: Question: Is the CPF payout eligibility age linked to the retirement/re-employment ages?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF payout eligibility age is not linked to either the retirement or re-employment age.    Today, you can start your CPF payouts at any time from age 65. There is no link to the current retirement age of 63* or the re-employment age of 68. Even if the retirement age and the re-employment age are raised, the CPF payout eligibility age would remain unchanged.    * The current retirement age and re-employment age of 63 and 68 will be raised to 64 and 69 respectively from 1 July 2026.   For more information:    Information on the  CPF Payout Eligibility Age   Information on the retirement age   Information on re-employment age   (source: Factually  website)

Knowledge Article: Question: Is the CPF payout eligibility age linked to the retirement/re-employment ages?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF payout eligibility age is not linked to either the retirement or re-employment age.    Today, you can start your CPF payouts at any time from age 65. There is no link to the current retirement age of 63* or the re-employment age of 68. Even if the retirement age and the re-employment age are raised, the CPF payout eligibility age would remain unchanged.    * The current retirement age and re-employment age of 63 and 68 will be raised to 64 and 69 respectively from 1 July 2026.   For more information:    Information on the  CPF Payout Eligibility Age   Information on the retirement age   Information on re-employment age   (source: Factually  website)

Knowledge Article: Question: What is my payout eligibility age?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your payout eligibility age is the age where you can start receiving your retirement monthly payouts.   If you were born in 1954 or later, your payout eligibility age is 65. This means that you can start receiving your monthly payouts any time between the ages of 65 and 70.   If you were born before 1954, the table below shows your payout eligibility age.   Year of birth Payout eligibility age Before 1944 60 1944 to 1949 62 1950 and 1951 63 1952 and 1953 64   Please note that  your payout eligibility age is not linked to your retirement or re-employment age . You can still receive payouts from your payout eligibility age even if the retirement age or re-employment age is raised.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I claim the CPF savings of a family member who has been missing for many years?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will first need to obtain a presumption of death certificate, which declares the person as presumed to be dead, from the Court. This is in line with industry practice where a person is treated as alive until the person has been officially reported as deceased. For any financial assistance in obtaining the presumption of death certification from the Court, you can contact the  Legal Aid Bureau .   If the missing person is a Singapore citizen or Permanent Resident,  after having obtained the presumption of death certificate, the missing person should be reported as deceased with the Immigration & Checkpoints Authority (ICA).   Once this is done, his CPF savings will be distributed to his appointed nominee(s) if he has a valid nomination. Otherwise, his CPF savings will be forwarded to the Public Trustee’s Office  for distribution according to  intestacy  or  Muslim Inheritance laws .   If the missing person is a foreigner who holds a CPF account, the following documents have to be submitted at any of our CPF Service Centres:   i. the original presumption of death certificate; ii. the missing person’s original passport (if any); iii. an original letter from the relevant authority confirming the missing person’s identity number (if the presumption of death certificate does not bear the missing person’s identification details); iv. documentary evidence of your relationship with the missing person; and v. your original identity card/passport and contact details.   If the death reporting is submitted via post from outside of Singapore, all the documents mentioned above have to be certified true by an official from a  Singapore Overseas Mission  with their official seal/stamp duly affixed.   Once the missing person is officially reported as deceased, his CPF savings will be distributed to his appointed nominee(s) if he has a valid nomination. Otherwise, his CPF savings will be forwarded to the Public Trustee’s Office  for distribution according to  intestacy  or  Muslim Inheritance laws .

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I view my CPF Yearly Statement of Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can view, print and/or download your CPF Yearly Statement of Account via Singpass login at  my cpf digital services . For non-Singapore Citizens and non-Permanent Residents, please refer to our FAQ on how you can request information regarding your CPF balances, CPF interest earned or, your CPF transaction statement for more information.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much CPF savings can I transfer to myself or my loved ones?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can easily check the maximum amount of CPF savings you can transfer in your Retirement Dashboard .   If you would like to learn more how the amount shown on your Retirement Dashboard is computed, please refer to the table below.   Do note that the actual amount of CPF savings you can transfer may also depend on your recipient's available top-up limit .   Recipient of CPF Transfer Available CPF Savings for Transfer If you are below 55 If you are 55 or above Self Any amount of your Ordinary Account (OA) savings to your Special Account (SA). Any amount of your Ordinary Account (OA) savings and Special Account (SA) savings to your Retirement Account (RA) * . Spouse Your OA savings after setting aside the current Basic Retirement Sum (BRS) 1 . Example (PDF, 72KB) Your CPF savings 4 after setting aside your Basic Retirement Sum (BRS) 5 . Example (PDF, 72KB) Parents and/or grandparents If you own a property 3 , you can transfer your OA savings after setting aside the current BRS 1 , provided you can meet the current Full Retirement Sum (FRS) with your OA savings, SA savings, the net amount withdrawn for investments 2 and property 3 . If you do not own a property 3 , you can transfer your OA savings after setting aside the current FRS 1 . Example (PDF, 91.7KB) If you own a property 7 , you can transfer your CPF savings 4 after setting aside your BRS 5 , provided you can meet your Full Retirement Sum (FRS) with your OA savings, SA savings, RA savings 6 , net amount withdrawn for investments 2 and property 7 . If you do not own a property 7 , you can transfer your CPF savings 4 after setting aside your FRS 5 . Example (PDF, 91.7KB) Siblings, parents-in-law and/or grandparents-in-law Your OA savings after setting aside the current FRS 1 . Example (PDF, 25.9KB) Your OA savings after setting aside your FRS 5 . Example (PDF, 25.9KB)   Find out what are the  retirement sums applicable to you .   * Your SA savings will be transferred first, followed by your OA savings.   1 Can be set aside using your OA savings, SA savings and net amount withdrawn for investments 2 .   2 Refers to amounts withdrawn for (i) an active investment account under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)-OA, and (ii) investments under the CPFIS-SA and discounted Singtel shares that have not been completely disposed of.   3 Refers to the CPF savings used for property, including accrued interest (P+I). If you have set aside the BRS and own a property bought using CPF savings, the P+I can be considered towards meeting the FRS for making CPF transfers to your parents and/or grandparents. The property you own must have remaining lease that can last you to at least 95 years old.   4 Your OA savings will be transferred first, followed by your SA and then your RA savings 6 , if applicable. You can write to CPF Board to specify the CPF accounts from which to transfer to your spouse, parents and/or grandparents. Please note that if you use your RA savings 6 for the transfer, the sum of your RA savings 6 and property 7 may be less than your FRS. As a result, when you make a withdrawal from your OA and SA, a portion of the savings will be used to meet your FRS in the RA.   5 Can be set aside using your OA savings, SA savings, RA savings 6 , and net amount withdrawn for investments 2 .   6 Refer to the cash set aside in the RA (excluding amounts such as interest earned, any government grants received), plus retirement withdrawals.   7 Refers to the CPF savings used for property, including accrued interest (P+I). If you have set aside the BRS and own a property bought using CPF savings, the P+I can be considered towards meeting the FRS for making CPF transfers to your parents and/or grandparents. The property you own must have remaining lease that can last you to at least 95 years old. If you have pledged your property for purposes of setting aside part of your retirement sum or to withdraw your retirement savings, the amount secured by the property can be considered towards meeting the FRS for this CPF transfer.

Knowledge Article: Question: What do I need to do to restore my Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) cover after I have obtained Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Residency again?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may wish to contact Great Eastern Life at dps-sg@greateasternlife.com for more information on your eligibility to re-join Dependants' Protection Scheme after you have obtained Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Residency.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I have to update or change my CPF nomination record when there are changes to my circumstances (e.g. marriage, child birth, divorce, death of my nominee)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You are encouraged to make a new CPF nomination to keep your nomination relevant to your latest circumstances.   See the infographic below for some examples of life milestones when you should consider reviewing your nomination.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need my own witnesses to be present if I am making my nomination at any CPF Service Centre?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Our Customer Service Executives can act as your witnesses.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to inform CPF Board when my family member passes away?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If the deceased person was a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident, there is no need to inform CPF Board of the death.   If the deceased person was a foreigner with a CPF account, you will have to inform CPF Board of his death .

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I report the death of a foreigner who was a CPF member?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can report the death of a foreigner who was a CPF member by post or by  making an appointment to visit our CPF Service Centre , with the following documents:    The deceased member’s original death certificate and current passport duly cancelled due to his passing, or a copy certified by an official from a Singapore Overseas Mission  with their official seal/stamp  A letter from the relevant authority confirming the deceased member’s identity number, if the death certificate does not show it  Evidence of your relationship with the deceased member  Your identity card or passport, and contact details

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to inform CPF Board of my new Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Residency?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You do not need to inform us of your latest particulars when you become a new Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident. Your Singapore identity card number will be used as your CPF account number to transact with us.   However, if you are already holding an existing CPF account (example: SA123456D or TC987654B), you would need to inform us so that we can combine your CPF accounts. Please submit the following documents/information to us where applicable by post or in-person at our CPF Service Centres.   To facilitate your transaction with us, we will combine your CPF accounts within seven working days after we have successfully verified your identity.   Recently obtained Singapore Citizenship   If you are: Documents/Information Required Additional document(s) Ex-Malaysian 1. Both sides of your Singapore Identity Car 2. Both sides of your Singapore Citizenship Certificate 3. Change of name document (example: deed poll), if you have changed your name 4. Your email address and contact number (we will contact you if we require more information) NA Ex-foreigner (excluding ex-Malaysian) Your old passport page(s) showing your personal particulars and passport number registered with us earlier Recently obtained Permanent Residency Malaysian 1. Both sides of your Singapore Identity Card 2. Your current passport page(s) showing your passport number, personal particulars and re-entry permit or Form 7 issued by Immigration and Checkpoint Authority 3. Change of name document (example: deed poll), if you have changed your name 4. Your email address and contact number (we will contact you if we require more information) Both sides of your Malaysia Identity Card Foreigner (excluding Malaysian) Your old passport page(s) showing your personal particulars and passport number registered with us earlier   By Post Our mailing details are as follows: Central Provident Fund Board Accounts Information & Services Department Robinson Road P.O. Box 3060 Singapore 905060   Please note that your documents must be certified true by an official from a Singapore Overseas Mission with his/her official seal/stamp duly affixed. You may wish to visit the Singapore Ministry of Foreign Affairs website to locate the Singapore Overseas Mission nearest to you.   In-person at our CPF Service Centres Please bring along your original documents and book an appointment to visit us at our CPF Service Centres .

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I make a CPF nomination if I am holding more than one CPF account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are a Singaporean/Permanent Resident (PR) and you are holding more than one CPF account, you will need to merge your CPF accounts before making the CPF nomination.   Maintaining only one CPF account will simplify your transactions with the Board. You can make a CPF nomination once your CPF accounts are merged.   You can find out what are the documents needed to merge your accounts and how to  submit them to us.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will CPF savings be distributed under the intestacy laws?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Member's CPF savings will be transferred to the Public Trustee's Office for distribution in accordance with the Intestate Succession Act (Cap 146) if he did not make a CPF nomination.   For a Muslim member, his CPF savings will be distributed in accordance with the Inheritance Certificate . His family can obtain the certificate from the Syariah Court, Family Link @ Lengkok Bahru, 8 Lengkok Bahru, #03-01, Singapore 159052.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will CPF savings be distributed under the intestacy laws?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Member's CPF savings will be transferred to the Public Trustee's Office for distribution in accordance with the Intestate Succession Act (Cap 146) if he did not make a CPF nomination.   For a Muslim member, his CPF savings will be distributed in accordance with the Inheritance Certificate . His family can obtain the certificate from the Syariah Court, Family Link @ Lengkok Bahru, 8 Lengkok Bahru, #03-01, Singapore 159052.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I make a top-up via PayNow QR?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To make a top-up via PayNow QR, you can follow these steps:   1. Submit an online application via the CPF website 2. Scan the PayNow QR code with your PayNow participating bank's app   It is important to make payment as soon as possible, as the QR code will expire at the end of the day of application. If the QR code expires, you will need to submit a new application and make payment using the new QR code generated at the end of the application.   To guide you on making a top-up via PayNow QR, watch the instructional video in your preferred language.   For POSB/DBS bank account holders, please refer to the top-up steps using Digibank.   Language English Chinese Malay Tamil   For UOB bank account holders, please refer to the top-up steps using UOB TMRW.   Language English Chinese Malay Tamil   For OCBC bank account holders, please refer to the top-up steps using OCBC Digital.   Language English Chinese Malay Tamil   Alternatively, you can submit an application via CPF Mobile app. Similarly, the PayNow QR code will be generated at the acknowledgement page. You just need to save the QR code on your device and upload it to your PayNow participating bank's mobile app to make payment.   To top up using PayNow via CPF Mobile app, you can refer to the steps listed below.   Language English Chinese Malay Tamil

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I nominate a trust company to receive my CPF savings for the benefit of my nominee?
Knowledge Article: Answer: A trust company is a legal entity which is capable of receiving monies (including CPF savings) in its own right. As such, you can nominate a trust company to receive your CPF savings. One example of such a trust company is the Special Needs Trust Company (SNTC), which can receive CPF savings as a nominee, who will then transfer these CPF savings to the trust funds set up by their clients.   Members should note that when appointing a trust company as a nominee, the trust company will receive the CPF monies in its own right.   Members would need to have a separate arrangement (such as a letter of intent) with the trust company on how to channel their CPF savings to their trust fund and use it to benefit the intended beneficiary.   CPF Board is not in the position to enforce or ensure that the trust company will use the CPF savings for the benefit of the intended beneficiary. This is strictly a private arrangement between you and the trust company.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to review and update my CPF nomination after making one?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes. Making a CPF nomination is not a one-time affair as your circumstances may change (e.g. marriage, childbirth, divorce etc). You are encouraged to review your CPF nomination so that it remains relevant to your latest circumstances.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I withdraw my online nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can withdraw your application so long as at least one of your witnesses has yet to complete the witnessing:   Log in to my cpf digital services using your Singpass at cpf.gov.sg/Activities . In transaction details, click on “withdraw this application” and confirm your intent to withdraw the application. Please note that after you withdraw your online nomination, your existing nomination status remains unchanged. If both your witnesses have completed their witnessing and you wish to make a new nomination, you can submit one via this link .

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I inform CPF Board of a change in my mailing address if I am not a Singapore Citizen (SC) /Permanent Resident (PR)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: With the closure of your CPF account as a non-Singapore Citizen (SC)/non-Permanent Resident (PR) from 1 April 2024, you do not have to inform CPF Board of any changes in your mailing address. You may refer to our webpage for more information on account closure.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I claim from MediShield Life / Integrated Shield Plan (IP) and MediSave for my medical expenses?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may inform the participating medical institution(s) that you wish to make a claim from your MediShield Life or Integrated Shield Plan and use your MediSave to pay for your medical expenses. The medical institution will provide you with a copy of the Medical Claims Authorisation Form to complete. It authorises them to check how much you can utilise from your healthcare plans and submit the medical claim on your behalf.   You may use the MediSave and MediShield Life claims calculator to estimate how much you can withdraw from your MediSave and / or claim from MediShield Life.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I provide new information or make changes to a previous report on wrongdoing?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To provide us with new information or make changes to a previous report on wrongdoing, please email us at volunteer@cpf.gov.sg and include the following information:   1. Your name 2. Contact number 3. FormSG response ID that you submitted previously

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I apply to make a top-up?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To make a top-up ,  you can refer to the following table:   Application mode Payment via Guide Web   Recurring cash top-ups via GIRO Guide One-time cash top-up  via PayNow QR Guide (PDF, 0.1MB) Video Guide CPF transfer Guide CPF Mobile app   PayNow QR OCBC Digital English Chinese Malay Tamil CPF transfer  Guide   Employers who wish to make cash top-ups for their employees can  apply online using Corppass . If you do not have Corppass, you may  write to us for an alternate application mode.   * If you are making a first-time CPF transfer to your loved ones, find out the supporting documents that you need to submit.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on reimbursement of examination fee incurred by my employee?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on reimbursement of examination fees given to your employee if the examination is taken for his self-interest or personal development. CPF contributions are not payable if the examination fees are incurred by your employee for official purposes, e.g. for employment-related training or certification. The reimbursement must not exceed the actual expenditure.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on compensations given under the Work Injury Compensation Act (WICA)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are not payable on compensations given to your employee due to work-related injuries or diseases under the  Work Injury Compensation Act (WICA). Medical leave wages (MLW) are payable for the days your employee is issued with medical leave or light duty. If your employee is on medical leave, CPF contributions are not payable on the MLW given to him. If your employee is given light duty, he will continue to earn wages. You will have to top-up his wages to the full Average Monthly Earnings (AME). MLW is the difference between AME and the actual wages earned. CPF contributions are payable on wages given for work done but not payable on MLW.

Knowledge Article: Question: What were the changes to the CPF contribution rates from 1 January 2024?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF contribution rates for employees aged above 55 to 70 have been increased to strengthen their retirement adequacy. The changes in CPF contribution rates for Singapore Citizens and Singapore Permanent Residents (from third year and onwards) took effect from 1 January 2024.   There is no change to the CPF contribution rates for other age groups.   Find out more about the revised CPF contribution rates .

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I view the Record of Payment (ROP) if I submit via CPF EZPay?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can view up to 24 months of past Record of Payment (ROP) online if you submit via CPF EZPay. Please refer to our guide .   As good record keeping practice, you should save a copy of your ROP. We do not provide retrieval of past ROPs. If you did not retain a copy of your past ROPs, you can seek other documents (e.g. company’s bank statement, payroll or financial statement).   Please write to us if you encountered technical difficulties to view the ROPs.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my CPF savings to pay for my housing loan after I turn 55?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can continue to use your Ordinary Account (OA) savings to pay for your housing loan after you turn 55. However, on your 55th birthday, a Retirement Account (RA) will be created for you and savings up to your Full Retirement Sum from your Special Account and OA will be transferred to your RA.   You can continue to use the following from your OA to pay your housing loan:   Your savings which you have applied to reserve in your OA before your 55 th birthday. This reserved amount 1 will not be transferred to your RA. Hence, you can continue to use it to pay your housing loan after turning 55 years old. To reserve your OA savings, you may refer to this  FAQ  for more information;  Your new CPF contributions to your Ordinary Account (if you continue working after 55). 1 When you start your monthly payouts under CPF Life or the Retirement Sum Scheme, your reserved OA savings will be transferred to your RA if you have not set aside your Full Retirement Sum. This transfer increases your RA savings and will enhance your monthly payouts.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much CPF savings can I use for my property purchase?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have already used your Ordinary Account (OA) savings for your property, you can check your latest CPF savings usage and usage limit on your  Home ownership dashboard .   If you are planning to buy a property, the amount of CPF savings you can use depends on the following:   You are buying a property with remaining lease that is able to cover the youngest owner using OA savings to at least 95 years old. You are buying a property with remaining lease that is unable to cover the youngest owner using OA savings to at least 95 years old.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I apply to withdraw the deceased member's CPF savings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will be notified if you are one of the nominees to receive the deceased member's CPF savings generally within 10 working days after the Board is informed of the member's death. To apply for withdrawal of the deceased member’s CPF savings, please choose the option that is applicable to you.   If you have not received any payment for the deceased member’s CPF savings , as an appointed nominee, you can apply to receive the deceased member's CPF savings by submitting the online form  “Withdrawal of savings from CPF member who has passed away” .     If you have received payment before, but you were notified of new balances in the deceased member’s CPF savings since the last payment to you , you can apply to receive the balance by submitting the online form  “Change payment details (for withdrawal of deceased member’s CPF savings)” .

Knowledge Article: Question: Will the deceased member's CPF savings continue to earn interest after his death?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Unclaimed CPF savings will continue to earn base interest in the respective accounts for up to 6 months. The CPF savings will not earn extra interest once we are notified of the member's death. Nominee(s) continue to have the right to claim the nominated savings at any time.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will the estimated income that I have provided for the computation of my Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contribution rate be used as the income to compute my MediSave payable for the year?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The income information you provided for Contribute As You Earn  (CAYE) is only used to compute the CAYE contribution rate. It will not be used as your actual income to compute your MediSave payable for the year.   You’ll still need to declare your Net Trade Income (NTI) to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) or CPF Board the following year. Your MediSave payable for the year will then be computed based on that NTI.

Knowledge Article: Question: When should I adjust my Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contribution rate?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can adjust your Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contribution rate by updating your estimated revenue or expense whenever you foresee any changes in revenue (e.g. increase in number of jobs in the current year) or expenses (e.g. increase in business cost, including the cost to engage other to assist in your jobs).

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I estimate my annual revenue and expenses for the year?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can estimate your annual revenue and expenses for the current year based on the actual revenue and expenses you earned last year. You can adjust your estimated annual revenue and expenses whenever you foresee any changes in revenue (e.g. increase in number of jobs in the current year) or expenses (e.g. increase in business cost, including the cost to engage other to assist in your jobs).

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I terminate my Home Protection Scheme cover?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can terminate your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover online using your Singpass.   Ensure that the below requirements are met, otherwise, your application will be rejected.   Should your co-owner(s) (if applicable) continue with HPS coverage, their total HPS share of cover must add up to at least 100% of the outstanding housing loan after the termination of your HPS cover. You must not have an active arrangement to use CPF monies for the monthly instalment payments of your housing loan. Stop your CPF monthly housing deduction arrangement before submitting your application to terminate your HPS cover. Learn more about how to stop your monthly deduction for your housing loan . After being notified that your CPF monthly housing deduction arrangement has been stopped successfully (generally within three to five working days after application), you may submit your application to terminate your HPS cover. Alternatively, three to five working days after application, you may check your Home ownership dashboard to verify that your monthly housing deduction arrangement has been stopped successfully before applying to terminate your HPS cover.   Find out more: What happens after I have terminated my HPS cover?

Knowledge Article: Question: I am a self-employed person making MediSave contributions. Why am I not given the Matched MediSave Contribution Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Matched MediSave Contribution Scheme is only for eligible self-employed persons (SEPs) who participate in the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) pilot. This is because the Matched MediSave Contribution Scheme is meant to help SEPs make a one-off transition to CAYE, which represents a change from the previous contribution model (yearly MediSave contribution after Notice of Assessment) to the CAYE model (smaller regular contribution as and when SEP receives payment from Government agencies as their corporate service buyers). SEPs who did not make any contributions under CAYE will not receive the matched contributions.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have set my Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) to 0%. Can I still participate in CAYE and receive the matched MediSave contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To make contributions under Contribute As You Earn (CAYE), you can update your CAYE contribution rate.   You can do so by logging in to the Self-employment dashboard using your Singpass, under Contribute As You Earn > Update contribution rate. Your updated CAYE contribution rate will apply to payments made from the next day, and you’ll be eligible to receive matched MediSave contributions based on the CAYE contributions you make.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I check if the amount of matched MediSave contributions paid is accurate?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can check the amount of matched MediSave contributions you’ve received and the contributions you’ve made under Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) by logging into the  Self-employment dashboard using your Singpass, under Contribute As You Earn > View matched amount .

Knowledge Article: Question: Why was the Matched MediSave Contribution Scheme (MMCS) extended for another year until 31 December 2021?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Many self-employed persons (SEPs) had to defer their income and MediSave contributions due to the extraordinary circumstances in 2020. This resulted in a longer transition to Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) than expected. The extension of the qualifying period for another year, till 31 December 2021, will allow more SEPs to fully benefit from the Matched MediSave Contribution Scheme (MMCS).

Knowledge Article: Question: How much MediSave contributions will be matched for self-employed persons who made contributions under Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Every dollar of contributions made for each self-employed person (SEP) from 1 January 2020 to 31 December 2021 under Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) will receive dollar-for-dollar matched MediSave contribution from the Government. The total amount of matched MediSave contributions an SEP may receive is capped at $600 across both years.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why do I need to make other payment arrangements in order to renew my licence when I am already on Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions are only based on an estimate of your MediSave payable for the current year. To renew your licence, you will need to pay your MediSave payable incurred in previous years via lump-sum payment(s) or monthly GIRO instalments.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why do I still have outstanding MediSave payable when I am already on Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions is an estimate of your MediSave payable for the year and may be lower or higher than your MediSave payable for the year. If your CAYE contributions are lower than your MediSave payable for the year, you’ll be required to top up the shortfall. You’ll also be required to make MediSave contributions for any outstanding MediSave payable incurred in previous years.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will I get into trouble if my actual income declared to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS)/ CPF Board in the following year is different from the income estimated on Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) digital services?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, as the revenue and expenses information on Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) digital services is an estimate of your business outlook for the year. You are still required to declare your actual Net Trade Income to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS)/ CPF Board to compute your MediSave payable for the year.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if the company I contracted with did not pay my service fees?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For any disputes on non-payment, short payment or late payment of service fees, you may wish to take up the dispute directly with the company or agency you have contracted with and seek mediation through the Tripartite Alliance for Dispute Management (TADM) or other industry facilitated mediation services.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I adjust my Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contribution rate?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If there are changes to your estimated revenue or expenses for the year, you may update and re-compute your Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contribution rate by logging in to the  Self-employment dashboard using your Singpass, under Contribute As You Earn > Update contribution rate . Generally, your updated CAYE contribution rate will apply to payments made from the next day.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I request to receive my hardcopy Yearly Statement of Account annually?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As part of our efforts to go green, members will receive their Yearly Statement of Account (YSOA) digitally instead of a hardcopy statement. We strongly encourage you to view your YSOA online to enjoy a richer and more interactive user experience.   You may log in to  my cpf digital services to view, download and print your CPF statements.

Knowledge Article: Question: Which self-employed persons must participate in Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Freelancers and sole-proprietors who are Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents and who have completed jobs/ projects with Government procurement entities as their service buyers, will automatically be enrolled onto Contribute As You Earn (CAYE). Self-employed persons (SEPs) who logged on to Vendors@Gov will see pop-up prompts informing them of their CAYE requirements.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is Contribute As You Earn?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Under the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) scheme, a MediSave contribution is required as and when a self-employed person (SEP) earns a service payment. Every time a service fee is paid to the SEP, the corporate service buyers (CSBs) or intermediaries making the payment will first deduct and credit a portion of the service fee to the SEP’s MediSave Account, before paying the remainder of the service fee to the SEP.   CAYE does not change the amount of MediSave contributions SEP have to make based on their net trade income.    SEPs who provide services to government agencies are automatically enrolled into CAYE.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to take into account the employer and employee's CPF contribution rates when making Voluntary Contributions (VC) for my employees?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You do not need to take into account the employer and employee’s CPF contribution rates when making Voluntary Contributions (VC) for your employees.   However, you will need a different CPF Submission No. (CSN) to make voluntary contributions for your employees. You should not use your existing CSN for mandatory CPF contributions to make your VC. Find out more on how you can make voluntary contributions for your employees.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long does it take before I can use Provident and Tax (PAT) system for CPF contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please continue with your existing submission mode until you have received email notification from CPF Board to confirm that your company can proceed to submit CPF contribution details via Provident and Tax (PAT).   For tax filing via PAT, the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) will inform you about their trial run separately before your actual submission.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I proceed to make payment if the PayNow QR code for paying my employees' CPF contributions expires?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The PayNow QR code to pay your CPF contributions must be scanned before 11:59pm on the day of submission. If your QR code has expired, you will not be able to make the payment, and you will need to resubmit your CPF contributions and get a new PayNow QR code.   After your payment has been made, your payment status will be updated as "Paid" in CPF EZPay instantly. Please make sure you have sufficient funds in your bank account before the payment is processed. If you have set a PayNow payment limit with your bank, do ensure that the limit is sufficient to pay your CPF contributions. Some banks may charge an administrative fee for unsuccessful payment attempts. Please perform a new submission and scan the QR code to make payment within the same day.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I check the status of my Direct Debit application?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have submitted the Direct Debit Authorisation (DDA) application online, you can check your application status online . We will also notify you of the status and effective date of the Direct Debit arrangement upon approval.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I change my company's Direct Debit account to pay CPF contribution?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To change your Direct Debit account for CPF contributions, simply submit a new application for Direct Debit Authorisation (DDA) for your new bank account.   CPF contributions will continue to be deducted from the existing bank account until the new Direct Debit Authorisation form has been approved. Once it is approved, the previous Direct Debit arrangement will then be terminated.   Please refrain from submitting a new online DDA application to change your bank account while the deduction for your current submission is pending. This is to avoid unsuccessful deduction which may incur late payment interest. If you wish to change the bank account for Direct Debit deduction, you should only submit the new online DDA application after the deduction is successful.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I apply to withdraw my retirement savings if I have a pension/annuity?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have a pension under the Singapore Government or annuity and want to withdraw your retirement savings, the process will depend on the country you are residing in.   If you are residing in Singapore   You can make an appointment to visit any CPF Service Centre and bring along your:   i. identity card for verification; and ii. documents of your pension or annuity.   For pensions, you will need the original pension letter bearing the Pension Office’s letterhead, dated within six months, stating:   i. you are receiving a guaranteed monthly pension amount; ii. the pension is payable for life; iii. the conditions which the pension may be revoked or terminated; and iv. amount of guaranteed lifelong monthly pension you are receiving.   You can visit the  Pensioner’s Portal for more information.   For annuities, you will need the original annuity policy(ies) and its terms and conditions, bought using cash or CPF monies under CPF Investment Schemes. The annuity must be issued by MAS-registered providers and satisfy the requirements under the Insurance Act. Upon approval of your application, we will request the insurance company to include the following endorsement in the policy contract, and you will need to submit a certified true copy of the endorsement to us before we process your application:   Where the Annuitant cancels the policy for cash surrender value, the Company is required to refund to the Annuitant’s CPF account an amount determined by the Board in accordance with the laws in force at the time the refund is required to be made.   Where a loan of the cash surrender of the policy is granted to the Annuitant, the Board shall have a first charge on the policy to secure the refund to the Annuitant’s CPF account of an amount determined by the Board in accordance with the laws in force at the time the refund is required to be made. The Company shall not be entitled to use part or all of any annuity payment to repay the outstanding loan.   If you are residing overseas   To apply, please   write to us using your Singpass with the supporting documents for our assessment. Upon assessment, please bring along your identity card for verification, the supporting document(s) stated above, and the application form to any of the  Singapore Overseas Missions .

Knowledge Article: Question: Who are the eGIRO participating banks for the Direct Debit Authorisation (DDA) online application?
Knowledge Article: Answer: eGIRO (Electronic GIRO) is a joint initiative by The Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS), and Participating Banks, with the support of the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), to digitise the GIRO application process and significantly reduce the turnaround time for setting up a GIRO arrangement.   Please refer to the list on eGIRO participating banks for DDA online application . ABS is working with the industry to onboard more banks onto eGIRO service and we will update the list accordingly.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I submit my CPF contributions via CPF EZPay, can I switch from one payment mode to another at any one time?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can choose to pay via Direct Debit or PayNow QR at the point of submission.

Knowledge Article: Question: What will happen to my Home Protection Scheme cover if I sell my flat, fully repay my loan or buy a new flat?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover will be affected depending on whether you:   Sell your flat We will terminate your HPS cover if you sell flat.   Fully repay your loan This also depends on whether you are fully repaying your:   Housing Development Board (HDB) Loan Your HPS cover will be automatically terminated when we are notified by HDB that you have fully repaid your loan, regardless of whether you are using CPF savings or cash. Any unused HPS premium will be paid to your CPF Ordinary Account.   Bank Loan If you are using your CPF savings to fully repay your loan, your HPS cover will be automatically terminated when we are notified by the bank that you have fully repaid your loan. Any unused HPS premium will be paid to your CPF Ordinary Account. However, if you are using cash to fully repay your loan, write to us to inform us of the full repayment. We will write to your bank to obtain your loan repayment details before terminating your HPS cover. Upon termination of your HPS cover, any unused premium will be refunded to your CPF Ordinary Account. Your HPS cover will not be terminated if you do not inform us that you have fully repaid your loan in cash.   Buy a new flat We will terminate your HPS cover for the old flat if you buy a new flat. Any unused HPS premium will be paid to your CPF Ordinary Account. You will need to apply for an HPS cover for your new flat. The HPS cover for your new flat is subject to your health condition. As such, you will need to declare and fully disclose all information regarding your health in your application.

Knowledge Article: Question: What if the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contribution was paid in error (i.e. paid wrong amount, or paid to the wrong self-employed person)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Corporate service buyers (CSBs) can request a refund of the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contribution from CPF Board within one year from the time the contribution was credited into the self-employed person’s MediSave account. After receiving a refund of the CAYE contribution paid in error, the CSB will be required to re-submit the correct CAYE contribution via the CAYE digital services.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens if the corporate service buyer provided an invalid NRIC for crediting of the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Under Contribute As You Earn, if the NRIC provided is invalid, you will be prompted to amend the NRIC if you are using the online submission mode. If you are using PACE (PayNow for CAYE), you’ll automatically receive a refund minus $0.55 per transaction (admin fee) for that record as a rejection fee as the bank will reject the payment.

Knowledge Article: Question: Under Contribute As You Earn (CAYE), what should corporate service buyers do to set-off monies from an upcoming payment?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To set-off monies (e.g. due to over-payment, or excess non-revenue payment made earlier) from an upcoming payment, corporate service buyers (CSBs) need to make the transaction via the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) online submission mode. This means that CSBs need to key in the full service fee payable to derive the MediSave payable via CAYE, and thereafter set-off any monies from the net service fee payable to the self-employed person.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens if payment to the self-employed person via the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) bank mode is unsuccessful?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For unsuccessful payments made via PACE (PayNow for CAYE) (e.g. due to invalid bank account number or invalid NRIC provided), the full service fee minus $0.55 per transaction (admin fee) will be returned to the corporate service buyer’s bank account via FAST. If the full service fee exceeds S$200,000, the payment will be rejected and the full service fee minus $0.55 per transaction (admin fee) will be refunded to the corporate service buyer’s bank account.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I continue to invest under the CPF Investment Schemes beyond age 55?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can continue to invest even after age 55, as long as you have set aside your Full Retirement Sum (FRS) in the Retirement Account. The FRS can be set aside fully with cash, or with cash (i.e. at least the Basic Retirement Sum) and property. In addition, you will not be able to invest the first $20,000 in your Ordinary Account (OA) and the first $40,000 in your Special Account (SA). This requirement applies to all members, even if you are aged 55 and above and have set aside the FRS, due to the inherent risk associated with investments which applies across all age groups. If you are eligible to withdraw your CPF, you have the flexibility to withdraw your OA/SA savings and invest as cash. Please also note that the stock and gold limits (PDF, 0.1MB) applicable to you may change.   Please refer to this FAQ for more information on how the retirement sum is set aside at age 55. To check your available CPF amount for investment, you can:   login into my cpf digital services with your Singpass > Select my cpf > My dashboards > Investment; access the ' CPF Mobile ' app with your Singpass; or visit any CPF Service Centres personally with your identity card.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I know if the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contribution amount and net service fee payment amount are made correctly?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can check your payment records by logging in to the  Self-employment dashboard  using your Singpass, under  Contribute As You Earn > Show all payments .    If you’ve previously informed CPF Board of your contact details, you’ll also receive a notification whenever a contribution to your MediSave Account has been made via Contribute As You Earn (CAYE). If you wish to update your contact details, you can do so via logging on to  my cpf  digital services  using your Singpass.

Knowledge Article: Question: I wish to check the amount claimed from my MediShield Life coverage for my recent hospitalisation. How can I do so?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can view the details of your MediShield Life claims (with transaction dates within the last 15 months from the date of enquiry) at cpf.gov.sg/healthcare :   1. Login to your Healthcare dashboard under  my cpf digital services with your Singpass   2. Proceed to 'Latest healthcare payments and claims'   3. Select and view the details of your recent healthcare payments and claims. To view more claims, click on 'View past 15 months'.   4. Click on 'View details' under MediShield Life to view the claim details.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens if the amount of MediSave contributions the self-employed person has made via Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) is lower than his MediSave payable for the year?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The self-employed person (SEP)’s MediSave payable for income earned in the year will be computed after the SEP has declared his actual income in the following year.   If the SEP’s total Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contribution is lower than his MediSave payable for the latest year, he will be required to top up the shortfall.   Example: Sam has made a total contribution of $2,100 via CAYE in 2023. The following year, Sam is informed that his MediSave payable for his work done in 2023 is $3,000. Sam will have to top-up the shortfall of $900. This example is illustrated within the table below: Estimated 2023 NTI $21,000 CAYE contributions in 2023 $2,100 (After 2023 NTI declaration) Declared 2023 NTI $30,000 MediSave payable for work done in 2023 $3,000 Shortfall Sam has to top up $900 (i.e. $3,000 - $2,100)

Knowledge Article: Question: Why do I still need to declare my income to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS)/ CPF Board when I have already done so on Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) digital services?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The revenue and expenses information on the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) digital services is an estimate of your business outlook for the year and used only to compute your CAYE contribution rate. It is not a declaration of your actual Net Trade Income (NTI) and you are still required to declare your actual NTI in the following year to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) / CPF Board to compute your mandatory MediSave payable.

Knowledge Article: Question: I would like a hardcopy of my CPF Yearly Statement of Account (YSOA). Where can I get it?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As part of our efforts to go green, you may login to my cpf digital services via your Singpass to view, download and save your YSOA for the past 10 years. We strongly encourage you to view your YSOA online to enjoy a richer and more interactive user experience.

Knowledge Article: Question: When will the CPFV app update be available for download?
Knowledge Article: Answer: On 14 July 2023, there will be a CPFV app update for you to download through your Mobile Devices’ App Store.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I withdraw my Retirement Account savings if my property lease cannot last me until I am 95?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, you will not be able to set aside your Full Retirement Sum (FRS) with a mixture of property (up to half the FRS) and cash with a property that cannot last you until 95. Therefore, you will not be able to withdraw part of your Retirement Account (RA) savings.   With Singaporeans living longer, it is important for you to have a property to live in during retirement. If you do not have a property that will last you to at least age 95, you may need to tap on your monthly payouts for your future housing needs such as rental cost, in the event that you outlive the lease.   However, exceptions can be made if you have bought property and turned 55 before 10 May 2019, provided your property: has more than 30 years of remaining lease at the date of your withdrawal application; and is not under the short-lease 2-room Flexi or Lease Buyback Scheme. If you meet the above conditions, you may be eligible to set aside your FRS with a mixture of property (up to half your FRS) and cash, and withdraw part of your RA savings down to your Basic Retirement Sum* using your property.   * Excluding interest, any government grants and top-ups made under the Retirement Sum Topping-Up Scheme.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the total employment contribution I received for the year?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can sum up the “Employee Contribution” under the “You” category and “Employer Contribution” under “Employer” category to derive the total employment contributions for the year.   For more details on the rates, see  rates for Singapore Citizens and Singapore Permanent Residents .

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I withdraw my discounted Singtel shares when I reach 55 years old?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You are required to set aside the Full Retirement Sum (FRS) in your Retirement Account (RA), before you can withdraw your discounted Singtel shares. The FRS can be set aside fully with cash, or with cash (i.e. at least the Basic Retirement Sum) and property.   Have you met your CPF withdrawal conditions?   Yes Log in to  my cpf Online Services with your Singpass > Select my cpf > My dashboards > Investment, look under “Discounted Singtel Shares” section and click on “Withdraw your shares”.   We will process your application within 15 working days once we receive your application.   After your discounted Singtel shares have been transferred to your CDP securities account, they will no longer be protected from any claims by your creditors and/or the Official Assignee.   No You can only withdraw your discounted Singtel shares if you have set aside the Full Retirement Sum (FRS) in your Retirement Account at age 55. However, you can sell your discounted Singtel shares, in which the sale proceeds will be credited into your CPF Ordinary Account.   To sell, please log in to  my cpf Online Services  with your Singpass > Select my cpf > My dashboards > Investment, look under “Discounted Singtel Shares” section and click on “Sell your shares”.

Knowledge Article: Question: Would Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) be applicable on invoices for goods provided by self-employed vendors?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) will apply to all taxable revenue, including profits made on goods provided. To avoid over-collection of CAYE contributions, self-employed persons (SEPs) can log in to the CAYE digital services to adjust their estimated expenses to include the costs of goods. The SEP’s CAYE contribution rate will then be adjusted accordingly.

Knowledge Article: Question: For GST-registered sole proprietors, are the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions computed based on the full service fee, inclusive of GST?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) will apply to the full amount of the service fee inclusive of GST. To avoid over-collection, self-employed persons can include the GST as part of their estimated expenses on the CAYE digital services.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are there any changes required to the corporate service buyer's payment system/process to reconcile the payments made via Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may consider changing your payment system/ process to reconcile payments made via Contribute As You Earn (CAYE), if necessary.   If you’re using the online submission mode (DDA mode), you may download the CAYE payment file via the CAYE Digital Services to reconcile the payment made to the SEPs.   Generally, if you’re using PACE (PayNow for CAYE), you will receive a return file from CPFB within five working days from the Funds Deduction Date.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can the courts order the sale (as opposed to a transfer (other than by way of sale)) of my share of the matrimonial property to my ex-spouse without any CPF refund?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Upon the sale of your share of the matrimonial property to your ex-spouse, the required CPF refund has to be first returned to your CPF account. The Court can then order the transfer or payment of the refunded CPF savings from your CPF account to your ex-spouse’s CPF account or to you in cash if it so decides.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I derive the interest indicated in my Year-in-Review?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please refer to the CPF interest page for more information on CPF interest. Details on extra interest and how CPF interest rates are determined can be found in our FAQs.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do corporate service buyers know if the payment to self-employed persons is successful?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Generally, for payment via PACE (PayNow for CAYE), you will receive a return file from CPF Board within five working days of the Fund Deduction Date indicated in your corporate payment file to the appointed bank, OCBC. This return file will indicate the amount of Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions and net service fee, the payment status, and rejection reason (for any unsuccessful payment).   For payment via the online submission mode, you can log into the CAYE Digital Services to view the payment status and CAYE contributions made to the self-employed person.

Knowledge Article: Question: For corporate service buyers using OCBC accounts, is there still a need to set up a Direct Debit Authorisation arrangement with OCBC to facilitate the deduction of service fee for bank mode payments?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You’ll need to sign up for GIRO with OCBC to authorise OCBC to deduct the full service fees from your agency’s bank accounts for the purpose of Contribute As You Earn.

Knowledge Article: Question: Under what scenarios will monies transmitted via Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) bank mode be returned to the corporate service buyer?
Knowledge Article: Answer: An admin fee of $0.55 per transaction will be deducted from the gross service fees before the remainder is returned to the corporate service buyer if: the self-employed person (SEP)’s bank account is closed or invalid; the SEP’s NRIC is invalid; or the CPF submission number in the bank file is invalid.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is the notification from CPF Board relating to the Yearly Statement of Account (YSOA) legitimate? Why am I receiving the notification?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Notifications are sent to members who have registered their contact details with CPF Board.   To verify whether the notification is legitimate, check that the notifications are sent from the following sender:   Mode of notification received Details Email ends with "@e.cpf.gov.sg" SMS gov.sg The SMS will also begin with "Central Provident Fund Board". CPF Mobile App CPF Mobile Singpass App Singpass   Find out  how you can protect yourself from phishing links .

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I get any money back after my Dependants' Protection Scheme cover ends when I reach the age limit?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) is a term-life insurance scheme which does not include any saving or investment component. Hence, there is no cash back when the member's DPS cover expires at age 65.   This is because DPS is designed to provide members with the maximum financial protection at the lowest possible premium.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do corporate service buyers with existing CPF Submission Number (CSN) for making CPF contributions to employees need to register for a Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) CSN?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Corporate service buyers (CSBs) with existing CPF Submission Number (CSN) are required to register for a Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) CSN for CAYE transactions. This is because the existing CSN that CSBs have is only for the purpose of making CPF contributions to employees. A CAYE CSN will enable self-employed persons (SEPs) to identify CSBs who made CAYE contributions on their behalf. The CSN for employee transactions cannot be used for CAYE transactions, and vice versa. CSBs who need to apply for a CAYE CSN may do so via  CAYE digital services .

Knowledge Article: Question: Do corporate service buyers need to factor in an approving authority to ensure accuracy of records submitted under Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Under Contribute As You Earn (CAYE), corporate service buyers are advised to factor in an approving authority within their internal processes before making payment to ensure accuracy of records submitted (i.e. no fraudulent transactions, no error in payment amount or self-employed person to be paid). Once submitted, CAYE payments are considered correctly paid.

Knowledge Article: Question: Does CPF Board accept credit notes to offset future payments if there have been erroneous payment of Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF Board does not accept credit notes for the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions. If the corporate service buyer (CSB) has made an erroneous payment, the CSB can request a refund of the CAYE contribution from CPF Board within one year from the time the contribution was credited into the self-employed person (SEP)’s MediSave account. The CSB will have to seek a refund of the remaining service fee made from the SEP directly and re-transmit the CAYE contributions.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to pay taxes for the amount I withdraw from my CPF accounts?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, CPF savings withdrawn are not taxable.   However, please note that if you have any unpaid taxes or MediShield Life premiums , we may recover the unpaid amount from the CPF savings you are withdrawing.   This is done to ensure that everyone fulfils their tax obligations and has sufficient coverage under MediShield Life.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the different MediShield Life premium subsidies and am I eligible for them?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Log in to Healthcare dashboard  'Coverage and premium details' to check how much MediShield Life subsidies you can receive.   The Government offers the following subsidies to keep MediShield Life premiums affordable:   (a) Premium Subsidies for lower- to middle-income Singapore Residents (from 15% - 50% of premiums)   You will be assessed based on your household monthly income per person, annual value of residence and multiple property ownership. You can update your household information via the MediShield Life e-Service to receive accurate premium subsidies.   (b) Pioneer Generation Subsidies for the Pioneer Generation (from 40% - 60% of premiums)   (c) Merdeka Generation Subsidies for the Merdeka Generation (from 5% - 10% of premiums)   You may refer to the MediShield Life Information Booklet for more information on the premium computation breakdown and details of the various components.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do all CPF members need Dependants' Protection Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Not all CPF members need Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS). Members should consider whether there are persons who are reliant on their current income. Some examples of members who may not need DPS include:   Those whose dependants have already grown up and become financially independent, e.g. children who reach adulthood and started working. Those who have already built up enough CPF or private savings, as such savings could be bequeathed to their dependants directly, to tide them over the first few years of expenses in the event of an untimely death. Those who already have their own private term or life insurance, which provides enough insurance protection and payout to tide dependants over the first few years of expenses in the event of an untimely death. Insurance premiums, including for DPS, become more expensive with age. Should members decide that they wish to opt out of DPS, they may do so by informing Great Eastern Life to terminate their DPS cover any time by completing the opt out form. Opting out of DPS will allow such members who may not need DPS to retain more of their CPF savings for their retirement income.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I derive the interest indicated in my Yearly Statement of Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please refer to the  CPF interest page for more information on CPF interest. Details on extra interest  and how  CPF interest rates are determined  can be found in our FAQs.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to refund my ex-spouse's CPF account if I take over the property?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you take over a property from your ex-spouse, he/she will have to refund the CPF principal amount withdrawn for the property, along with the accrued interest, when he/she is no longer the owner of the property.   However, the CPF laws were revised from 1 October 2007 to allow for more flexibility in such cases. The Court can now make an order for the property to be transferred from a member to his/her ex-spouse without requiring the full CPF refund to be made into the member's CPF account.   Should the ex-spouse sell the property, he/she is required to refund into his/her own CPF account the amount withdrawn from the member's CPF account (which were not refunded upon transfer) as well as the principal amount withdrawn from his/her own CPF account for the purchase of the property with accrued interest.   It would be for the Court to decide whether court orders extracted before 1 October 2007 could be amended or varied to benefit from the existing CPF laws. In this respect, please consult your lawyers.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I still withdraw my CPF savings if I do not have the Full Retirement Sum?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you can still withdraw some of your CPF savings even if you have not set aside your Full Retirement Sum (FRS).   If you are born in 1957 or after, you can withdraw additional amount from your Retirement Account (RA) from 65. Check how much CPF savings you can withdraw .   However, any remaining amount that is not withdrawable and left in your Ordinary and Special Account after your withdrawal will be automatically transferred to your RA to make up your FRS. This transfer is to ensure that the savings in your RA will be sufficient to provide you with monthly payouts to supplement your living expenses when you reach the payout eligibility age. This process will occur for every withdrawal until you have set aside your FRS.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my CPF savings to pay for the transaction fee and lodgement fees when I buy a property?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use your Ordinary Account savings to pay for the following when you purchase a property:   Transaction fee levied by the lawyer's appointed bank Lodgement fees levied by the Singapore Land Authority for the holding and disbursing of your CPF savings Check with your lawyers to learn more about other relevant costs and fees.   They can provide additional information and help you understand the costs involved in the process.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I withdraw my CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) investments when I reach 55 years old?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can apply to the Board to withdraw your CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA) and CPF Investment Scheme-Special Account (CPFIS-SA) investments as well as the cash balance in your Investment Account, as long as you have set aside your Full Retirement Sum (FRS) in the Retirement Account (RA). The FRS can be set aside fully with cash, or with cash (i.e. at least the Basic Retirement Sum) and property. Your CPF Investment Account will be closed once you apply to withdraw your investments.   Please refer to this FAQ for more information on how the retirement sum is set aside at age 55.   You will be able to view the link to submit your application through the Investment dashboard if you meet the eligibility conditions.   Please refer to the following information to find out what would happen after you have applied for withdrawal of investments under the CPFIS:     CPFIS-OA We will inform the agent bank to close your CPF Investment Account. The agent bank will contact you for the withdrawal of your investments and cash balance (if any) in your CPF Investment Account. Your investments will be transferred* to your own name and you may thereafter liquidate them as you wish and have the sale proceeds paid to you directly.   Once withdrawn, your CPFIS investments and cash balance in your CPF Investment Account will no longer be protected from any claims by your creditors and/or the Official Assignee.   * Central Depository (Pte) Ltd (“CDP”) imposes a transfer fee of $10.00 (excluding GST) for every share counter transferred from your CPF Investment Account to your CDP Account.     CPFIS-SA We will inform your product provider(s) to transfer your investments to your own name and you may thereafter liquidate them as you wish and have the sale proceeds paid to you directly.   Once withdrawn, your CPFIS investments will no longer be protected from any claims by your creditors and/or the Official Assignee.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if the company's shares that I have invested in using CPF monies are suspended or delisted?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If the shares of a company you have invested in using CPF monies are suspended or delisted, you have the option to continue holding them in your CPFIS portfolio. However, it is important to note that you will have to continue paying quarterly agent bank fees on these shares.   You should stay informed about the latest developments by checking the company’s website or SGX’s  Company Announcements . Understanding the reasons behind the suspension or delisting can help you assess the future viability of the company.   If you have decided that you no longer wish to hold the shares of the company, consider reaching out to the company to check if they have a buyback program in place. If that is not an option, please  Write to Us and we will see how we can assist you.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am a self-employed person. Can I contribute to my MediSave together with my employees' CPF using the CPF Payment Form (CPF 91)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You’re required to make your MediSave payable separately from your employees' CPF. This is because payments made using the CPF Payment Form (CPF 91) will be credited as employer contributions and will not be recognized as self-employed payments.   If you would like to make CPF contributions as a self-employed person, there are various ways to do so.
