Knowledge Article: Question: Why are there no deductions from my bank account even though I have successfully made a recurring cash top-up arrangement?
Knowledge Article: Answer: It could be due to one of the following reasons: If you have just made recurring cash top-up arrangements, the GIRO deduction might not have started yet. You may check the start month of your recurring cash top-up by accessing the Manage recurring cash top-ups for retirement form, under “Who you are making recurring top-ups to”. If you have updated your GIRO bank account after 8th of the month, deductions will start from the following month instead of the current month. Find out more .

Knowledge Article: Question: What if my net trade income for the year is zero or negative?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your net trade income (NTI) is zero or negative for the year, you do not need to make any MediSave contribution for the year.   You will still be required to pay your outstanding MediSave payable for the years you were self-employed.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I attend (and vote at) a Company's Annual/Extraordinary General Meetings (AGMs/EGMs) as a CPF investor?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF investors should refer to the company announcements on SGXNet (or Company website) for instructions on attending AGMs/EGMs.   Special Arrangements due to Covid-19 Measures Companies would not be able to proceed with physical general meetings during the Circuit Breaker period due to the Safe Distancing measures in place. Companies that hold AGMs/EGMs during this period may have special arrangements (e.g. "live" webcast). CPF investors who wish to participate in these meetings and/or vote on meeting resolutions should take note of the following:   Attendance CPF investors should refer to the company announcements on SGXNet (or Company website) for instructions on how to attend the virtual meeting. CPF investors should take note of the pre-registration deadlines (including the submission of questions to the Company which will be addressed publicly before or during the virtual meeting).   Voting Since CPF investors cannot physically attend general meetings to vote, they can instead vote through their respective CPF Agent Banks. CPF investors must submit their voting instructions to their agent banks at least seven working days before the general meeting . CPF investors should contact their respective Agent Banks (DBS, OCBC, UOB) to find out more about how to submit their voting instruction(s).

Knowledge Article: Question: I have invested in a company using CPF. How can I get the latest financial statement or annual report of this company, if the company has been delisted? And what should I do if the company does not respond to my request?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may approach the company for the financial statement or annual report directly. You can mail your request to their office address through registered post. The office addresses of companies can be found on ACRA's BizFile portal . If you do not hear back from the company, please approach your agent bank who will follow up with ACRA.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I have to pay for the Home Protection Scheme medical examination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The cost of the initial Home Protection Scheme medical examination will be borne by the Board.   However, if you wish to conduct any subsequent tests, examinations or obtain second opinions, the cost of such investigations would have to be borne by you. You can choose to proceed with subsequent tests at the same clinic or any other clinic of your choice.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to declare my health when I apply to adjust my Home Protection Scheme cover?
Knowledge Article: Answer: A new health declaration is required if you are adjusting your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) coverage upwards due to an increase in loan repayment period, loan quantum or share of cover. If you are not eligible for the additional coverage, you can continue to be insured under your existing cover*.   *You must not have had any serious pre-existing health condition that was not disclosed to us when you applied for your previous HPS cover.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I change my plan type after I have joined CPF LIFE?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can request to change your CPF LIFE plan type within 30 days from the date of your first* policy letter. If you wish to do so, please write to us .   A change of CPF LIFE plan type beyond the 30 days grace period is possible if   You are on a legacy plan (Basic, Balanced, Plus or Income Plan) and wish to change to the Escalating Plan or Standard Plan; or You wish to change from Standard to Escalating Plan Otherwise, changing of CPF LIFE plan after the grace period is not allowed as this will affect the payouts of other members on the scheme.   As changing of CPF LIFE plan is irrevocable, we encourage you to consider your options carefully.   *The letter sent to you when your original CPF LIFE plan was first issued.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to the deceased member's investments bought using his CPF savings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) investments are not covered under CPF nomination. When a member passes away, his CPFIS investments* and any cash balance in his Investment Account will form part of his estate. Doing so allows beneficiaries of the estate to decide how best to manage these assets, including the preferred timing for the sale of assets such as unit trusts and stocks. These decisions should be made by the beneficiaries as the decisions could affect the value of the CPFIS investments. CPF monies covered under CPF nomination can then be disbursed quickly without having to await the beneficiaries’ decision on the CPFIS investments.   The estate administrator/executor can contact the respective product providers or agent bank to claim the investments and cash balance. These investments, cash balance and death benefits may be used to settle the deceased member’s debts in accordance with the Probate and Administration Act.   * Except for insurance policies where the member had made an insurance nomination with the respective insurance company. The nominated beneficiaries can contact the insurance company to claim the death benefits.

Knowledge Article: Question: Where can I find a copy of the CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA) Profits/Losses Report?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please refer to the  CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA) Profits/Losses Report .

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I earn interest for the balances in my CPF accounts up to the date of my withdrawal?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will earn interest for the withdrawable amount up to the month before your withdrawal.   The interest earned will be credited into your CPF account at the beginning of each year and can be withdrawn from then on.   Find out how your CPF interest is calculated .

Knowledge Article: Question: How is members' investment performance in the CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please refer to the CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA) Profits/Losses Report if you wish to view members' investment performance in the CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA).

Knowledge Article: Question: Who can I include as my nominee?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can nominate any person (regardless of age or nationality) or organisation .   If you are nominating someone who is not a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident, please provide the nominee’s full name, foreign identification number and mailing address in your nomination form so that the Board can contact him swiftly when distributing your CPF savings. Find out more .

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on excess leave taken by my employee due to re-computation of leave entitlement when he leaves employment?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Any excess leave will reduce the wages in the month where the excess leave was taken. CPF contributions must be computed on the wages after deduction of the excess leave taken in that month. If CPF contributions have already been paid, you should apply for an adjustment or refund of the excess CPF contributions instead of offsetting it from the CPF contributions in the current month. Example John earns $1,000 per month and is entitled to 12 days of annual leave a year (equivalent to one day per month). He left employment on 30 June, and his pro-rated leave entitlement is six days. He has taken nine days of annual leave in May. Month Wages Leave taken in that month Excess Leave Deduction for excess leave Wages after deduction for excess leave May $1,000 9 3 $150 $850 June $1,000 0 0 $0 $1,000 To find out more on the definition and calculation of daily wages, please refer to the Ministry of Manpower website . As shown above, the employer should re-compute CPF contributions for May based on wages of $850. Since his employer would have already paid CPF contributions for May, his employer should apply for a refund/adjustment of CPF contributions for May. His employer should not offset the excess CPF contributions paid from the month of June.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to my Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) cover when my account is closed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) cover will be terminated as the scheme is only applicable to Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents.   Your DPS insurer will refund any unused DPS premiums for the current policy year to your CPF account. The unused DPS premiums will be paid to you along with your CPF savings, when you transfer your savings to your bank account.   If you wish to find out more, please contact your DPS insurer, Great Eastern Life at dps-sg@greateasternlife.com .

Knowledge Article: Question: Are all non-Singapore Citizens and non-Permanent Residents eligible for account closure?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, all non-Singapore Citizens and non-Permanent Residents should close their CPF account and transfer their CPF savings to their bank account by submitting the account closure form .

Knowledge Article: Question: If I run out of CPF monies to pay the premiums of my Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme (ASPFAIS) Part V insurance policies, what should I do?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You have the following options:   Use cash to pay the premiums; Convert your Part V insurance policies to a paid-up mode 1 ; or Activate the Automatic Premium Loan (APL) 2 or Extended Term Insurance (ETI) 3 feature(s) of your Part V insurance policies, if they have such features and if your insurance company allows you to do so. 1 Converting a policy to paid-up mode means that the policyholder will not need to pay premiums anymore. The sum assured of a paid-up policy is usually lower than that of the original policy. All supplementary riders attached will be terminated.   2 APL means that once the policy has accumulated sufficient cash value, if the policyholder is unable to pay the premium, he can borrow from the cash value. However, he is required to pay back the loan and compound interest. Once the loan plus compound interest exceeds the cash value of the policy, the policy will lapse.   3  ETI means that if the policyholder still wants the insurance protection but doesn't want to pay any more premiums, the existing cash value of his policy is treated as a single premium which is used to buy protection for future years. The number of years of protection he will get varies directly with the quantum of the cash value.

Knowledge Article: Question: Am I protected against email spoofing or phishing attempts if my email service provider is Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance (DMARC)-compliant?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No. While Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance (DMARC) can protect you against scammers who try to impersonate trusted senders, it cannot protect you from scammers who set up their own domains and try to mislead email recipients into mistaking them as legitimate senders. In general, it is good practice to be vigilant when we receive emails, especially if it is from a sender that we don’t know or weren’t expecting to get an email from.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I submit the "MediShield Life and CareShield Life Health Declaration for Permanent Resident Applicant" form?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please submit the MediShield Life and CareShield Life Health Declaration for Permanent Resident Applicant form online and log in using your Singpass.   Declaring for Self If you are the Person To Be Insured and you are aged 21 years or older, please select the option to declare for “Myself” under the section - Selection of Self or Family Member Declaration.   Declaring for family member If you are aged below 21 years, please get your parent/legal guardian to log in using his/her Singpass to the e-Service and select option to declare for “Family Member’ to declare the health status on your behalf.   If you are aged 21 years or older but do not have a Singpass, please get your family member to log in using his/her Singpass and select the option to declare for ‘Family Member’ to submit the HD form on your behalf.   No Singpass Alternatively, if you are not able to apply for Singpass or do not have a family member with Singpass that can help you submit the HD form online, you can write to us .   Form processing Time After you have submitted your  health declaration , please note the following: Your health declaration will generally be processed within seven working days. You can check the status of your health declaration via “ Activities ”. If the status is still showing ‘Pending review’ after seven working days, the Agency of Integrated Care (AIC) has evaluated your declaration and requires you to undergo a disability assessment. AIC will notify you of the details, or you can contact AIC at apply@aic.sg . If you are required to attend a disability assessment, please do so as soon as possible within the timeframe specified in AIC’s letter. After the assessment, your assessors will submit their report to AIC. Only after AIC has evaluated the report will the status of your health declaration be updated to “Completed”, and you can then schedule an appointment with ICA. Completion of Formalities with the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) Individual applicants should only schedule an appointment with ICA after their health declaration status shows “Completed”. For family unit applications under the same ICA reference number, please ensure that all members have a “Completed” health declaration status before scheduling an appointment with ICA.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will my CPF savings be transferred to my bank account when my CPF account is closed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can choose to receive your CPF savings in three ways when your CPF account is closed:   1. Bank transfers via Interbank GIRO (IBG) to your Singapore bank account   2. Telegraphic transfer to your bank account overseas   Please ensure that the bank accepts payment in Singapore dollars. Otherwise, we will convert the payment to US dollars. You will need to bear all bank charges, including any foreign exchange rate differences and conversion charges:   i.    for telegraphic transfer to an overseas bank account   ii.   if you provide insufficient bank account details resulting in an unsuccessful telegraphic transfer.   3. Cheque   i.    Please ensure your bank can clear cheques issued in Singapore Dollars   ii.   Upon receiving the cheque, please ensure that you bank it in within six months from the date of issuance  to avoid paying additional charges for re-issuance of cheques   iii.   You will need to bear all bank charges for overseas bank clearance of cheques.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I settle my outstanding MediSave payable by instalments through GIRO?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can settle your outstanding MediSave payable by instalments through GIRO.    If your bank account is with the participating banks , please complete the  Set up GIRO for MediSave contributions using your Singpass. You will be re-directed to the bank’s ibanking portal to complete the application. You can check the status of your online application through my cpf digital services - Activities with your Singpass.   If you wish to use an account from other banks, please download and submit the   “Apply for GIRO for MediSave Contributions” (FORM SE GIRO) (PDF, 0.1MB) to the CPF Board. Deduction will be made from the existing bank account until the new GIRO arrangement takes effect.   After your GIRO application is approved, we will inform you about your monthly instalment amounts via a notification. You can also view your GIRO instalment plan details via the  Self-employment dashboard after logging in with your Singpass.   If you are facing financial difficulties and need to defer your MediSave contributions, please contact us via our  Online Enquiry Form .

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use multiple policies to withdraw my retirement savings if I have more than one source of lifelong income?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, if you have multiple policies that provide you with lifelong income, you can use them to apply for withdrawal of your retirement savings.

Knowledge Article: Question: What will happen to my Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme investments if I did not open a CPF Investment Scheme Investment Account in time for the transfer?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As indicated in the National University of Singapore (NUS) letter to you, if you did not open a CPF Investment Scheme Investment Account by 27 December 2007, NUS is unable to transfer your Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme - Ordinary Account (ASPFAIS-OA) investment holdings and Part V insurance policies. As the Academic Staff Provident Fund (ASPF) scheme has closed down, your ASPFAIS Investment Account has been frozen and you will no longer be able to use your ASPF monies to transact under the ASPFAIS and service the premiums of your insurance policies bought under the ASPF Part V Scheme. You can still open a CPFIS Investment Account at any agent bank i.e. DBS, OCBC and UOB, and instruct NUS to transfer your ASPFAIS investments and Part V insurance policies to your newly-opened CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) Investment Account after 1 January 2008 . However, this transfer will be effected only on a monthly basis and any payments to be made in the meantime, including insurance premiums, would have to be paid in cash. For your investments bought under Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme - Special Account (ASPFAIS-SA), NUS would have transferred them over to CPF Investment - Special Account (CPFIS-SA) as long as you have a CPF Account. No CPFIS Investment Account is needed for the transfer of investment holdings under the SA.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can the nominee instruct the Board when to sell the discounted Singtel shares and at a certain price?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The nominee should ask for the discounted Singtel shares to be transferred to his Central Depository (Pte) Ltd (CDP) account if he wishes to sell the shares at a certain price.   From April 2022, if the nominee wishes for the shares to be transferred to his CDP account, he will need to instruct us within six weeks from the notification of the member’s death. If we do not receive any instructions from the nominee within six weeks, we will sell the shares. The sale proceeds will be disbursed to the nominee, together with other nominated CPF monies, in cash. Find out what are the conditions under which we would sell the deceased member's discounted Singtel shares .

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I choose to set aside my Full Retirement Sum with a mixture of property and cash, and withdraw part of my Retirement Account savings if I own a foreign property?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, you are not able to withdraw part of your Retirement Account savings if you own a foreign property. To secure the refund of your CPF savings when your property is sold or transferred in the future, your property must be located in Singapore.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can corporate service buyers recover the overpaid Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions due to overpayment of full service fee?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If there is over-payment, corporate service buyers (CSBs)  can request a full refund of the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions from CPF Board within one year from the time the contribution was credited into the self-employed person (SEP)’s MediSave Account (MA). The CSB will have to seek a refund of the remaining service fee made from the SEP directly. After receiving a refund of the CAYE contribution paid wrongly, the CSB will be required to re-submit the correct CAYE contribution via the CAYE Digital Services. Example: CSB A paid Mr Tan, their SEP vendor, a service fee of $120 through the bank mode. The bank deducted and paid $12 to Mr Tan’s MA and the net service fee of $108 to Mr Tan’s bank account. However, CSB A subsequently realised that the correct service fee amount agreed upon by both parties was $100. CSB A should: Put in a request on the CAYE digital services for a refund of the CAYE contribution ($12) by selecting the transaction that was made in error (e.g. based on Mr Tan’s NRIC and the payment reference number) and providing the relevant supporting documents. Seek the remaining $108 from Mr Tan directly. Submit another CAYE contribution transaction for Mr Tan based on the correct gross service fee of $100.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens if I used my Retirement Account (RA) savings to purchase annuity(ies) under the Retirement Sum Scheme (RSS) or used my annuity(ies) to apply for exemption from setting aside a retirement sum?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Once your CPF account is closed and your CPF savings are transferred to your bank account, the surrender value of your annuity, if any, will be paid directly to you by your insurer, in the event of termination of the annuity(ies), or to your beneficiary upon your demise.

Knowledge Article: Question: Who are my beneficiaries?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your beneficiaries are persons whom you have nominated to receive your CPF savings, including any CPF LIFE premium balance, when you pass away. If you have not nominated anyone to receive your savings, we will pay them to the Public Trustee for distribution according to the intestacy laws. You can make a nomination online using your Singpass.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to my Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover when my account is closed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: When you have renounced your Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Residency, your HPS cover will cease upon the sale of your HDB flat or at the end of the current HPS policy year, whichever is earlier. There will be no further renewal of your HPS cover, even if you are in the process of selling your HDB flat, as the scheme is only applicable to Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are Self-Help Group (SHG) contributions payable for an intern on an internship programme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For Chinese Development Assistance Council (CDAC) Fund, Eurasian Community Fund (ECF) and Singapore Indian Development Association (SINDA) Fund :   Contributions to the Self-Help Groups (SHGs) funds are payable for interns on internship programme if CPF contributions are payable. You may refer to this  FAQ for more information on whether CPF contributions are payable for student employees.   For Mosque Building and Mendaki Fund (MBMF) :   Please refer to the section on "Student Pay" at the MUIS website to find out whether MBMF is payable for an intern.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on the client referral fee given to your employee for recommending business clients to you?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are payable on client referral fees given to your employee for recommending business clients to you.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am an appointed nominee. How will the deceased member's CPF savings be paid to me if I am bankrupt?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are an undischarged bankrupt at the time you become entitled to receive the nominated monies, we are legally obliged to inform the Official Assignee (OA) and transfer the nominated monies to the OA upon their instruction. This is by virtue of the laws in Singapore relating to bankruptcy, which vest the property of a bankrupt in the OA upon the making of a bankruptcy order.   If the deceased member held any discounted Singtel shares, they would be sold upon the OA’s instruction.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I discover any wrongdoing by a CPF volunteer, what action should I take?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We do not tolerate any wrongdoings by volunteers in their course of advocating for CPF. If you come across any wrongdoings, it is important that you report so that appropriate action can be taken.   By reporting the wrongdoing, you can help to ensure that our volunteers are held accountable for their actions and that steps are taken to prevent similar incidents from occurring in the future.   All reports should be made in good faith, without any personal agenda, or ulterior motive, and when there are reasonable grounds to suspect that an incident of wrongful practice has occurred.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I attend the Home Protection Scheme medical examination at my preferred clinic?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can choose to attend a Home Protection Scheme (HPS) medical examination at your preferred clinic and thereafter provide the medical report* on your health condition to CPF Board, at your own expense. If the information is not sufficient, we may still require you to attend the HPS medical examination with CPF Board’s panel of clinics.   The HPS medical examination arranged by CPF Board is conducted by the Board’s panel of clinics. They are centrally located and equipped with the facilities and trained personnel for such medical examinations. The cost of the initial HPS medical examination will be borne by the Board.   *The medical report must be from a medical institution in Singapore   Find out more:   Can I provide my own medical report instead of attending the Home Protection Scheme medical examination? What tests am I required to undergo for the Home Protection Scheme medical examination?

Knowledge Article: Question: Is support available if I encounter problems with the new release of the CPFV app?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you experience any technical difficulties using the new CPFV mobile app, please refer to the error pop-up in-app and follow the FAQ guide displayed to troubleshoot. Alternatively, if you have questions on the Community Paying it Forward movement, please email us at volunteer@cpf.gov.sg .

Knowledge Article: Question: What are corporate service buyers required to do under Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Under Contribute As You Earn, corporate service buyers are required to deduct and transmit a portion of the service fee to the self-employed person (SEP)’s MediSave account, before paying the SEP the remainder of the service fee. This is done through either the bank or online submission modes.

Knowledge Article: Question: Under the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) scheme, will corporate service buyers only be making MediSave contributions for self-employed vendors?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Under the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) scheme, corporate service buyers do not need to make MediSave contributions for self-employed persons (SEPs) as SEPs are required to contribute to their MediSave Account.

Knowledge Article: Question: When are Government procurement entities required to implement Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Since January 2020, Government procurement entities are required to implement Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) for payment of service fee to self-employed vendors. Vendors@Gov will automatically identify vendors covered under CAYE when they log in through Corppass or Singpass. These vendors will be notified of their participation in CAYE via prompts.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) only piloted on Government procurement entities?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Government, as a service buyer, has taken the lead to implement and pilot Contribute As You Earn (CAYE). There are currently no plans to extend CAYE to the private sector.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why did the Government introduce Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) enables self-employed persons (SEPs) to make small regular contributions as and when they earn income. This reduces the MediSave contributions they have to pay in the following year (after SEPs declare their net trade income and have their MediSave computed).    CAYE can also help SEPs grow their money as they can start to earn an interest of up to 5% on their MediSave savings earlier.

Knowledge Article: Question: Under Contribute As You Earn (CAYE), what happens if the self-employed person is not registered on Vendors@Gov?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Corporate service buyers should ask the self-employed person to register at Vendors@Gov so that they are able to submit an e-invoice for the purpose of Contribute As You Earn.

Knowledge Article: Question: Under Contribute As You Earn (CAYE), what happens if the self-employed person has contributed up to the maximum mandatory contributions for the year?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There will be no further Contribute As You Earn deduction and the full service fee will be paid to the self-employed person.

Knowledge Article: Question: When is the deadline to make my MediSave contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: (a) For self-employed persons (SEPs) who were issued a Notice of Assessment (NOA)/ Non-tax advice by the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS):   Amount of Contributions Payable By  Computed based on your age and Net Trade Income (NTI) assessed by IRAS. You will be issued with a “Notice of Computation (NOC) of CPF Contributions (MediSave)” from IRAS 30 days from the date of issue of the NOC   (b) For SEPs who were not issued a Notice of Assessment (NOA)/ Non-tax advice by IRAS: For Relevant Years 2020 onwards Amount of Contributions Payable By  Computed based on your age and declared NTI to CPF Board  30 days from the date of issue of Notice of Contribution from CPF Board   For Relevant Years 2019 and earlier Amount of Contributions Payable By  Computed based on your age and declared NTI to CPF Board  31 May of the following year

Knowledge Article: Question: Will my data from the previous version of the CPFV app be carried over to the new update?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, your profile and data will be migrated to the new CPFV app. Any badges and points earned before 30 June 2023 will be recorded and reflected there. Do note that some data and progress information (e.g. challenges and topic completions) may not be compatible or relevant to the new app's features or functions. Hence, these will not be available in the new app.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if I have made a payment to a wrong Self-Help Group (SHG) for my employees?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For contributions paid to a wrong Self-Help Group, please submit a request to CPF Board for adjustment.

Knowledge Article: Question: Where can I find the application forms pertaining to self-employed matters?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can find the list of application forms applicable to the Self-Employed Scheme at CPF website > Tools and services > Forms and e-applications > Growing Your Savings > CPF contributions .

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the CPF Investment Scheme Risk Classification System?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Risk Classification System is developed to help you determine which of the various investment options may be most appropriate for your investment circumstances, through better understanding of the level and type of risk associated and your risk tolerance. It splits the investment risk associated with Unit Trust , Investment-Linked Products and Exchange Traded Funds included under CPF Investment Scheme Funds into two broad categories, "Equity Risk" and "Focus Risk".   Equity Risk Equity Risk is related to exposure to the "riskier" types of investments in the Funds. The greater the proportion of assets invested in stocks, the higher the Equity Risk (i.e. higher risk category). Conversely, the greater the proportion of investments in bonds and cash, the lower the Equity Risk (i.e. lower risk category).   Focus Risk Focus Risk reflects how focused the investments of the Funds are in particular geographical regions, foreign countries, foreign currencies, industries or individual companies. A Fund that invests in shares of companies from around the world would have lower Focus Risk (i.e. broadly diversified) than a fund that invests in shares of companies from one country only (i.e. narrowly diversified).   The CPF Board does not give any consideration to nor has made any investigation on the investment objectives, financial situation or particular needs of the reader, any specific person or any group of persons. Accordingly, no warranty whatsoever is given and no liability whatsoever is accepted for any loss arising whether directly or indirectly as a result of the reader, any person or any group of persons acting on any information, opinion or statement expressed in these FAQs.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is "Mailbox" and how do I access it?
Knowledge Article: Answer: “Mailbox” is a repository of your correspondences with CPF Board.     Please login to my cpf digital services – Mailbox with your Singpass and 2-Factor Authentication (2FA) to access the platform.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have updated my email address/mobile number with Singpass. Why are my Singpass contact details not updated with CPF Board?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Updates to your Singpass mobile number and email address  will not  be automatically updated with the Board.   You can instantly update your mobile number and/or email address via the  Account settings  page with your Singpass. An SMS or email One-Time PIN (OTP) will be sent to your new mobile number or email address for verification before the changes can take effect.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I still make top-ups or receive top-ups to my retirement savings if I have withdrawn my savings using my pension/annuity?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, you cannot top up or receive top-ups to your retirement savings if you have already withdrawn your retirement savings using your pension/annuity. However, you can top up your retirement savings if you choose to join CPF LIFE .

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if I receive a notification that is not meant for me?
Knowledge Article: Answer: This could happen because:   You are sharing contact detail(s) with your next-of-kin for handling of CPF matters; or Your contact detail is a recycled mobile number/email address registered by another member with us previously; or You are using a common business mobile number/email address shared within a company. If you did not intentionally share your contact details with another member or wish to stop this arrangement, please  write to us with a screenshot of the notification you have received.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I reserve my Ordinary Account (OA) savings for my child's tertiary education, so that the savings are not transferred to the Retirement Account (RA) when I turn 55?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As your Ordinary Account (OA) savings are meant to boost your retirement savings when you turn 55, you will not be able to reserve your OA savings for your child’s tertiary education. At age 55, your Special Account (SA) and OA savings will be transferred to your Retirement Account (RA) to meet the Full Retirement Sum (FRS) applicable to you. Your RA savings will continue to grow steadily and provide you with lifelong monthly payouts in retirement. You may find out more about the  prevailing interest rate here . You are eligible to withdraw in cash the remaining OA and SA savings after setting aside the FRS, or up to $5,000 if you are unable to set aside the FRS. You can then use the cash as you wish, including towards your child’s education.   You may wish to consider the MOE’s Tuition Fee Loan (TFL) to finance your child’s education. The MOE TFL is available to all full-time students of the polytechnics and universities and covers up to 75% and 90% of the tuition fees payable respectively. It is also interest-free during the course of study, unlike the CPF loan where interest starts to accrue from the time of withdrawal.   If you are unable to repay your MOE TFL due to further studies or financial difficulties due to unemployment or medical condition, you may appeal to defer repayment and interest. Your appeal will be considered on a case-by-case basis. While CPF may also allow for deferment in challenging times, the interest continues to accrue as it is essential to completely restore the savings meant primarily for retirement. For more information on the MOE TFL, please refer to this link .   Your child can also approach their educational institution to find out about the other financial assistance schemes available.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I provide my own medical report instead of attending the Home Protection Scheme medical examination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have an up-to-date medical report * on your health condition you may provide it to us at your own cost, instead of attending the Home Protection Scheme (HPS) medical examination. Please submit your medical report to us via Write to Us .   If the submitted information is insufficient for our assessment, we will notify you to proceed with the scheduled HPS medical examination.   *The medical report must be from a medical institution in Singapore.   Find out more:   I would like to submit a medical report to support my Home Protection Scheme application. What is the information required in the medical report?

Knowledge Article: Question: How will the proceeds of my Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme (ASPFAIS) Part V insurance policy and/or rider be distributed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: In general, premiums of Part V insurance policies and riders (if any) paid using Academic Staff Provident Fund (ASPF) monies or cash prior to the transfer of the policy to CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) would be treated as though the premiums were paid using CPF monies. This is because Section 22 of the First Schedule of the National University Singapore (Corporatisation) Act provides that all premiums paid or deemed to have been paid with ASPF moneys in respect of ASPF Approved Investment Scheme Investments and Part V Assurances shall, on and after the dissolution date, be deemed to have been paid with CPF monies. Hence, the proportion of the proceeds (except death benefits) corresponding to such premiums would be refunded to your CPFIS Investment Account.   However, the distribution of the full proceeds would depend on the premium payment mode after the transfer of the Part V policy to CPFIS. If, after the transfer of your policy to CPFIS:   All the premiums of your Part V insurance policy and rider are paid using your CPF Ordinary Account savings   If all the premiums of your Part V insurance policy and rider are paid using your CPF Ordinary Account savings, all proceeds would have to be refunded to your CPFIS Investment Account.   Your CPF monies are exhausted and you then use cash to pay the premiums of the Part V insurance policy and rider   If your CPF monies are exhausted and you used cash to pay the premiums of the Part V insurance policy and rider, the proceeds would be pro-rated based on CPF savings vis-à-vis cash used to pay for the premiums after the transfer. The CPF portion and cash portion of the proceeds will be respectively refunded to your CPFIS Investment Account and to you.   All the premiums of the Part V insurance policy and rider are paid using cash   If all the premiums of the Part V insurance policy and rider are paid using cash, the proportion of the proceeds corresponding to the premiums paid in cash after the transfer of the policy to CPFIS would be refunded to you in cash. The remaining proceeds would be refunded to your CPFIS Investment Account.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I commence my monthly housing instalment if my application to be covered under Home Protection Scheme has not been approved?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you can commence your monthly housing instalments even if your application for Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover is still pending. You do not need to wait for HPS approval to begin your payments.   Find out more: How do I apply to use my CPF savings for my housing loan monthly instalments?

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I choose to continue to submit my bank account details to receive payments for government service instead of PayNow (excluding PayNow Mobile Number and Virtual Payments Address), and what do I need to do to ensure I can continue to receive my service fee payments?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will only be able to use the bank account registered to your PayNow to receive service fee payments.   Please ensure that you have registered for PayNow (excluding PayNow Mobile Number and Virtual Payments Address) so that you receive your service fee payments promptly. If not, you will not be able to receive your service fee payments from early June 2024.   We encourage you to check with your bank to ensure your details are updated or if you need more information on how to sign up for PayNow (excluding PayNow Mobile Number and Virtual Payments Address).

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the CPF contribution rates for Singapore Citizens and Singapore Permanent Residents?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For more details on the CPF contribution rates, see rates for Singapore Citizens and Singapore Permanent Residents.

Knowledge Article: Question: Who do I contact for enquiries on Dependants' Protection Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For enquiries relating to Dependants' Protection Scheme, you may contact Great Eastern Life:   Address : The Great Eastern Life Assurance Company Limited                 1 Pickering Street, #01-01                 Great Eastern Centre                 Singapore 048659 Website : Great Eastern Life E-mail : dps-sg@greateasternlife.com Hotline : 68394565

Knowledge Article: Question: How do corporate service buyers identify if the vendor is under Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For self-employed persons (SEPs) who submit e-invoices, Vendors@Gov will automatically identify vendors covered under Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) who log in through Corppass or Singpass. These vendors will be notified of CAYE via prompts. The e-invoice file format will be modified to store two additional columns, CAYE indicator and SEPs’ NRIC, which will subsequently be loaded into NFS@Gov and interfaced to agencies.   For invoices outside of Vendors@Gov, corporate service buyers (CSBs) need to identify and tag SEPs manually via:  the NRIC used by the SEP to transact; or  the Unique Entity Number (UEN) issued by ACRA. CSBs can use the Enterprise Data Hub (EDH) to check whether the vendor’s business entity type is a sole proprietorship or partnership. If it is a sole proprietorship, CAYE will apply.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long does it take to process applications relating to Direct Debit?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please refer to the table for our service standards for processing applications relating to Direct Debit.   Service Processing Time Set up Direct Debit Authorisation for CPF contributions (online) For personal bank account, the approval takes only minutes.   For corporate bank account, the approver must approve the eGIRO request within the bank’s website within 48 hours before the application expires. *Terminate Direct Debit Authorisation for CPF contributions One working day

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my excess Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions to offset my outstanding MediSave payable?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CAYE contributions in excess of your MediSave payable for the year will be automatically used to offset your outstanding MediSave payable from previous years, if any 1 . Any excess thereafter will be refunded to your bank account. You can also choose to boost your healthcare savings by retaining the excess CAYE contributions in your MediSave Account to earn up to 5% interest per annum, and to offset future MediSave payable. To do so, please apply via the  Self-employment dashboard using your Singpass. 1 This will take effect for CAYE contributions made from 2023. Please write to us if you do not wish to use your CAYE contributions to offset your outstanding MediSave payable from previous years.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am a Singaporean or a Permanent Resident but I am not living in Singapore. What will happen to my Dependants' Protection Scheme cover?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will remain insured under the Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) as long as premiums are paid. DPS coverage is worldwide and a claim can be made when a member meets the claim criteria.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to update CPF Board of my new health condition which developed after my Home Protection Scheme cover has been issued to me?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have developed a new health condition after your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover has been issued, you do not need to inform CPF Board.   You are only required to declare your health condition at the point of your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) application. However, if there is a change in the state of your health before the HPS cover is issued, you must  inform CPF Board immediately.

Knowledge Article: Question: What do I need to do to restore my Dependants' Protection Scheme cover after I have obtained Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Residency again?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may wish to contact Great Eastern Life at dps-sg@greateasternlife.com for more information on your eligibility to re-join Dependants' Protection Scheme after you have obtained Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Residency.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the Dependants' Protection Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) is a term-life insurance scheme which provides insured members and/or their families with some money to get through the first few years should the insured members meet an untimely death, suffer from terminal Illness or total permanent disability.   DPS covers insured members up to 65 years old. Members up to 60 years old will be covered for a maximum sum assured of $70,000. For members above age 60 and up to age 65, DPS covers them up to a maximum sum assured of $55,000.   DPS is currently solely administered by Great Eastern Life.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to declare information regarding my health condition when I am not sure if the information is relevant for my Home Protection Scheme cover application?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are unsure about the relevance of the information, you are advised to still disclose it so that we can assess your eligibility for a Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover.   You will not receive any claims or any refund of paid premiums if an HPS cover was issued based on false/misleading information given or if you were not in good health before the cover commenced.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I withdraw my CPF savings if I have unpaid taxes or MediShield Life premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have unpaid taxes or MediShield Life premiums, we may be appointed by IRAS to recover the unpaid amount from the CPF savings you are withdrawing. If we are appointed to do so, you will receive an appointment notice from IRAS and we will pay IRAS the outstanding amount from your withdrawable savings to settle your unpaid taxes or MediShield Life premiums before the balance (if any) is paid to you.

Knowledge Article: Question: I was issued a bonus sum assured in 2003 and/or 2005. Will it be carried over to my Dependants' Protection Scheme policy under the newly enhanced scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF Board distributed surpluses in the form of bonus sum assured to the Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) members insured before DPS was privatised in 2005. Members can contact their DPS insurer, Great Eastern Life to check if they qualified for the bonus sum assured previously.   To standardise the sum assured for all insured members to the new amount of $70,000 from 1 April 2021 under the newly enhanced DPS, existing members who were eligible for the bonus sum assured will receive a one-time premium rebate in lieu of the bonus sum assured. The one-time rebate has been credited into members’ CPF Ordinary Accounts in May 2021.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I apply job at CPF Board?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may refer to our CPF website , Careers@Gov or MyCareersFuture for the list of available positions and apply online to the position(s) that is of interest to you. We will contact you if you are shortlisted for interview.   For more enquiries, please email to hr@cpf.gov.sg .

Knowledge Article: Question: My Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) is covered by NTUC Income prior to 1 April 2021. When my DPS cover is transferred over to Great Eastern Life from 1 April 2021, do I need to declare my health?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, members who are already insured under Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) prior to 1 April 2021 do not need to submit a new health declaration form for illnesses that developed on or after the commencement of their DPS covers under NTUC Income. Great Eastern Life is required to take over all obligations of DPS covers issued under NTUC Income. This means that Great Eastern Life will continue to cover any medical conditions that had developed on or after the commencement of members’ DPS covers under NTUC Income.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I qualify for the porting of my previous Home Protection Scheme cover to my new property?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have purchased a new flat and sold your previous flat, you may be eligible to port your previous Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover to your new property. To qualify for this, you must meet the following conditions:   Your previous HPS cover* was terminated due to the sale of your previous flat after purchasing a new flat, and You are not eligible for a new HPS cover for the new flat due to your current health condition. *You must not have had any serious pre-existing health condition that was not disclosed to us when you applied for your previous HPS cover.

Knowledge Article: Question: I do not have a Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) cover. Do I need to declare my health to be insured under DPS?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, the eligibility for a DPS cover is subject to you being in good health when your policy commences.   As with any life insurance, DPS cover may be deferred or declined if a member has any serious pre-existing illnesses before policy commencement. This is to ensure that the scheme remains viable and the premiums are kept affordable for all insured members.

Knowledge Article: Question: I would like to submit a medical report to support my Home Protection Scheme application. What is the information required in the medical report?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may submit a medical report to support your Home Protection Scheme application, at your own cost. Your report must be up-to-date from a medical institution in Singapore and include the following information:   Diagnosis and diagnosis date Reason(s) of hospitalisation, if any Details of treatment(s) Date(s) and details of surgery, if any Details of complications, if any, and treatment rendered Current condition and treatment(s) Investigation test results

Knowledge Article: Question: Can the deceased member's MediSave be used to pay his final hospitalisation bill?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, the deceased member’s entire MediSave can be used to pay the last hospital bill if he had signed the Medical Claims Authorisation Form (MCAF), which authorises the use of the deceased member’s MediSave to pay the hospitalisation bill, before his passing.   Any remaining MediSave after the payment of the last medical bill will be distributed to the deceased member’s nominee(s) if he had a valid nomination. This is provided that the MediSave deduction is completed before the distribution of the deceased member’s CPF balances.   If the deceased member had not signed the Medical Claims Authorisation Form (MCAF), his spouse, parents, child (if age 21 or older), or donee/deputy can sign the form at the hospital. You are encouraged to do this as soon as possible as hospitals have to submit the MediSave claim  before  the deceased member’s MediSave is distributed (typically within two weeks of the member’s passing). If the deceased member’s MediSave has been distributed, you will not be able to use his MediSave for the last hospital bill.   If there is no immediate family or donee/deputy, a caregiver who has been taking care of the deceased member during his lifetime may write to the Ministry of Health through the hospital to seek approval for the use of the deceased member’s MediSave for the last hospital bill.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I get tax relief for my voluntary top-up to my or my loved ones' MediSave Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: When you make voluntary cash top-ups to (i) your MediSave Account or (ii) your loved ones, you can enjoy tax relief for cash top-ups made in each calendar year of up to:   $ 8,000 if you make a top-up to yourself ; and an additional $ 8,000 if you make a cash top-up to your loved ones *. * Loved ones refer to parents, parents-in-law, grandparents, grandparents-in-law, spouse and siblings .   To qualify for tax relief for cash top-ups made to spouse/siblings, the recipient must (i) not have an annual income exceeding $8,000 1 in the year preceding the year of cash top-up (e.g. salary, tax exempt income such as bank interest, dividends and pension), or (ii) be handicapped.   Please note the above tax relief cap applies to both voluntary cash top-ups to MediSave Account and Special/Retirement Account. You can find out more on the conditions to qualify for tax relief.   1 The income threshold for tax relief for cash top-ups to spouse or sibling has increased from $4,000 to $8,000 and will apply to cash top-ups made on 1 January 2024 or after.   If you made a cash top-up to your spouse and/or sibling between 1 January 2024 and 16 February 2024 and wish to claim tax relief for the top-up made due to the increase in income threshold, you may s ubmit an application to update your tax relief records for top-ups made in 2024.

Knowledge Article: Question: My family member has passed on. How do I check if he was covered under the Dependants' Protection Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To check if your family member was covered under the Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS), you may contact the appointed DPS insurer, Great Eastern Life.   Great Eastern Life can be contacted at:   Address : The Great Eastern Life Assurance Company Limited 1 Pickering Street, #01-01 Great Eastern Centre Singapore 048659 Website : www.greateasternlife.com/DPS E-mail : dps-sg@greateasternlife.com Hotline : 6839 4565

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my Post-Secondary Education Account (PSEA) savings to repay my outstanding education loan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: From 1 March 2018, Post-Secondary Education Account (PSEA) holders can use their PSEA savings for full or partial lump sum repayment of their own education loan taken under the CPF Education Loan Scheme. For more information on the usage of PSEA, please refer to MOE website .

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I use my Post-Secondary Education Account (PSEA) savings to repay multiple education loans?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To repay more than one loan under the CPF Education Loan Scheme, please indicate details of the loan (institution name) in the order of repayment priority in the Loan Repayment Application Form. Withdrawal of Post-Secondary Education Account (PSEA) savings for loan repayment will be made in the order specified in the application form.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can taxi principal hirers who are not liable to make a MediSave contribution qualify for Drive and Save (DAS) co-contribution from their taxi operators?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Taxi principal hirers who do not have outstanding MediSave payable can still receive Drive and Save co-contributions if they make contributions to pre-pay their future MediSave payable 1 :   A contribution of at least $20 to their MediSave Account monthly, or A lump sum MediSave contribution of at least $240 in the past 12 months.  1  Taxi principal hirers may make contributions to pre-pay their MediSave payable via Manage your MediSave payable.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can corporate service buyers using the bank mode check the breakdown of the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions and net service fee to the self-employed person?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Corporate service buyers can view the status of the payment made and the amount split between the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions and net service fee made to the self-employed person by:   Referring to the return file provided by the appointed bank, OCBC; or Logging onto the CAYE online digital services with your Corppass ID and select View Transaction History > Transaction Type > Make CAYE Contributions.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long does the Home Protection Scheme medical examination take?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The entire Home Protection Scheme medical examination process generally takes up to 2 hours, excluding the time needed for registration.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am over 55 years old. I know that my CPF housing refund will go towards meeting my Full Retirement Sum (FRS) in my Retirement Account (RA). What happens to my balance housing refunds after meeting my FRS?
Knowledge Article: Answer: When you sell your property, the CPF housing refund will first go towards meeting your FRS in your RA. We will guide you on how to handle your balance housing refunds before you complete your sale. Here is what you can expect:   If HDB or your lawyer has contacted the Board about your sale before 1 July 2024: Your balance housing refunds will be given to you in cash within 5 to 10 working days after setting aside your FRS. If you would like to keep your balance housing refunds in your CPF account to earn risk-free interest, please submit a request through  Write to Us two weeks before completing your sale.    If HDB or your lawyer has contacted the Board about your sale on or after 1 July 2024: Your balance housing refunds will remain in your Ordinary Account (OA) for you to decide how you want to manage them. You can leave the balance housing refunds in your OA to earn risk-free interest,  transfer it to your RA for higher payouts in retirement, or withdraw in cash for your immediate needs.    If you need to withdraw more than the default online Daily Withdrawal Limit of $2,000, find out  more . If you need to withdraw more than the maximum online Daily Withdrawal Limit, find out  more .

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I pay my Dependants' Protection Scheme premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Dependants’ Protection Scheme (DPS) premium will be automatically deducted from your CPF savings on your annual policy renewal date.   If you do not have sufficient funds in your CPF savings to pay the annual premium, you can either make a cash top-up directly to the appointed DPS insurer, Great Eastern Life (GEL), or be insured for a lower amount (the minimum coverage is $5,000).   Alternatively, you can pay your DPS premiums directly in cash (via GIRO) to the DPS insurer GEL. Visit  GEL’s website for more information.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I check my education loan repayment history?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can check the repayment history for your education loan in the following ways:   Log in to your Education dashboard with your Singpass. If there are arrears, refer to this FAQ on how to make the payments. Refer to your bank account statement, or Check with the CPF lender(s) who had used their CPF savings for your education. They will need to log in to the CPF website with their Singpass and retrieve their "Transaction History".

Knowledge Article: Question: How to sell my discounted Singtel shares?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There are three ways to sell your discounted Singtel shares:   via Online Sale Facility Log in to my cpf Online Services with your Singpass. Select my cpf > My dashboards > Investment, look under “Discounted Singtel Shares” section and click on “Sell your shares”.   You will be directed to POEMS - an online trading platform managed by Phillip Securities Pte Ltd (‘Phillip Securities’). Once you have submitted your online instruction, Phillip Securities will sell your discounted Singtel shares. The proceeds of sale will be refunded to your CPF Ordinary Account within 6 working days.   You can find out more information on selling your discounted Singtel shares through the Online Sale Facility in this  document .     via Singapore Post Office Visit any  Singapore Post Offices  (‘SingPost’). For SingPost to process your instruction, you need to sell a minimum quantity of 10 shares. You would also need to produce the following documents at SingPost: Your identity card; and The latest copy of your CPF Statement of Account, which indicates the number of discounted Singtel shares held in your CPF account. If you are unable to sell your discounted Singtel shares in person, you may authorise a third party to sell the shares on your behalf. Your authorised person must bring the following documents to SingPost: A completed and signed ‘Account Opening and Authorisation for The Sale of STA & ST2 Shares Form’. All sections including ‘Third Party Authorisation’ are to be completed. This application form is available at all SingPost branches; Identity cards belonging to both authorised person and you; and  The latest copy of your CPF Statement of Account, which indicates the number of discounted Singtel shares held in your CPF account. You can find out more information on selling your discounted Singtel shares through SingPost in this  document .     via Singapore Exchange (SGX) Retail Broker Please approach your broker if you have a trading account with them. If you do not have a trading account, you can open one with any  SGX broking firm .   Internet trading platforms for most brokers do not cater for sale of discounted Singtel shares. Please check with your broker before selling your discounted Singtel shares.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I make changes to my housing monthly deduction?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Changing your housing monthly deduction depends on the type of loan you have taken.   For HDB loan   There are two ways for you to make changes to your housing monthly repayment arrangement.   Submit an online application under Commence the use of CPF/Vary CPF deductions for HDB housing loan instalment at  HDB’s website   with your Singpass. Your application will be processed generally within three working days upon the receipt of your request from HDB. Complete the CPF withdrawal form (PHS9) at HDB Branch. Please note that services at HDB office and Branches are by appointment only. If you wish to visit a HDB Branch, you can book an appointment via the e-Appointment system . Your application will be processed within three to five working days upon the receipt of your request from HDB. For bank loan   You can change your housing monthly deduction amount by submitting an  online application with your Singpass.   Please submit your application at least five working days before monthly instalment deduction date.

Knowledge Article: Question: I do not have a Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) cover. Why do I need to declare my health to be covered under DPS?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As with any life insurance, the Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) cover may be declined or deferred if a member has serious pre-existing illnesses before policy commencement. This underwriting practice is necessary to ensure that the scheme remains viable and the premiums are kept affordable for all insured members.   The DPS insurer will not consider claims from a member who has serious pre-existing illnesses, or has given false or misleading statements or withheld relevant information in the health declaration.   Please refer to  Great Eastern Life for more information on the examples of serious pre-existing illnesses that will affect your eligibility to be covered.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I check the status of my Dependants' Protection Scheme claim application?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may contact Great Eastern Life directly to check on the status of your Dependants' Protection Scheme claim application.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can i make a voluntary housing refund of the housing amount withdrawn if i am not selling my property?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can refund any amount, capped at the full principal amount you have withdrawn for the property with the accrued interest. You can submit your application:   1.  Online  by following the steps below: Read the disclaimer. If you accept, click the checkbox Click "Start" Log in with your Singpass Select a payment method Select a property, enter a refund amount Click "Next" Read the declaration. If you agree, click the checkbox and click "Confirm" Make the payment 2. Through CPF Mobile app by following the steps below: Log in to CPF Mobile app with your Singpass Select "Services" Select "Voluntary Housing Refund" and click "Continue" Select the property, key in a refund amount, and click "Next" Read the agreement. If you agree, click the checkbox Click "Next" Select the payment method Make the payment If you make the refunds by PayNow using the QR code or OCBC Digital, the transaction will be shown in your transaction history immediately after the payment.   Members who are unable to submit online or through the CPF Mobile app may write to us at  cpf.gov.sg/writetous  for assistance.

Knowledge Article: Question: My Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) cover was issued by NTUC Income. Will Great Eastern Life take over all obligations when my cover is transferred? What if I have developed medical conditions on or after the commencement of my cover under NTUC Income?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Great Eastern Life is required to take over all obligations of Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) covers issued under NTUC Income. This means that Great Eastern Life will continue to cover any medical conditions that had developed on or after the commencement of members’ DPS covers under NTUC Income.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I make my MediSave contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There are several ways you can contribute to your MediSave. The most convenient way is via GIRO, which allows automatic monthly deductions from your bank account.   Payment mode Details GIRO Using  my cpf digital services ( list of participating banks ) Log in with your Singpass. Submit the Set up GIRO for MediSave contributions application. Check the status of your GIRO application via Activities. Mail (for other banks) Download and complete the  Apply for GIRO for MediSave Contributions  form (FORM SE GIRO (PDF, 0.6MB)).             Mail it to the address printed overleaf of the GIRO application form. We will notify you of your GIRO application status once the bank has processed it. PayNow QR Request for an instalment plan or pay your MediSave payable in full via the  Manage your MediSave payable  form. NETS/ CashCard Pay by NETS or CashCard at any SingPost branches. You may view your MediSave contributions on the Self-employment dashboard. To access  my cpf  Digital Services – Self-employment dashboard, please log in to the  CPF website  using your Singpass.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am suffering from a terminal illness or have a total permanent disability. How do I claim insurance benefits under the Dependants' Protection Scheme? Can I claim my Home Protection Scheme benefits and withdraw my CPF savings at the same time?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For member's convenience, CPF Board has developed a one-stop application form for you to apply for Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) and Home Protection Scheme (HPS) benefits and withdraw your CPF savings, if applicable.   To do so, you will need to: Submit an online application after logging in via Singpass. The application form will allow you to concurrently apply for both HPS benefits and withdraw of your CPF savings if applicable. Download the medical certification form that is provided upon submission of the online application and have it completed by an accredited doctor . The medical institution will need to submit the completed medical certification to CPF Board within 90 days of your application. Otherwise, your application will be cancelled. If you are claiming HPS benefits, you are required to inform your employer to submit your employment information to CPF Board for claim assessment purpose. A FormSG link will be provided to you upon submission of the online application for your employer to complete. Corppass login is required. After CPF Board receives the completed medical certification and employment information (for HPS claim, if required), you will receive an email or SMS notifying you that the application is in progress. CPF Board will notify you on the outcome of your withdrawal application and HPS claim while Great Eastern Life will notify you separately on your DPS claim outcome.   If the medical certification is to be completed by a doctor from an overseas medical institution, please  write to us for assistance.   If you are mailing your documents from overseas, all documents (except for original documents) must be witnessed/certified true by an official of a  Singapore Overseas Mission with his official seal/stamp duly affixed.   If you are claiming for DPS benefits only, you can submit an application to Great Eastern Life directly.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I discharge a CPF charge that was created when I bought my private property with CPF savings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you used your CPF savings to buy a private property, a CPF charge would have been created. To discharge this charge, you need to refund the amount used for the property and the accrued interest to your CPF account. You can do so by:   Voluntarily refunding the amount used to your CPF account. After the refund is made, you will need to engage a lawyer to lift the CPF charge on your property. Please note that you will have to pay any legal cost incurred for this discharge. If you are above 55 and wish to withdraw your Retirement Account savings above the Basic Retirement Sum by pledging the property in future, a fresh CPF charge will be lodged to secure the refund of the withdrawal amount when the property is sold/transferred in future. Please note that the cost of lodgement of charge will be borne by you. Refunding the amount used to your CPF account when you sell your property. Your lawyers handling the sale will complete the discharge as part of the sale transaction.

Knowledge Article: Question: My family member has passed on and was covered under the Dependants' Protection Scheme. As the next-of-kin, how do I claim the DPS benefits?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Once the Board is notified of the member’s death by the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority, we will inform the Dependants' Protection Scheme insurer, Great Eastern Life, who will then send claim application details to the assigned nominee(s). However, if no nomination was made, the claim application details would be sent to the deceased member’s correspondence address instead.   The next-of-kin can also make a claim by directly submitting an application to Great Eastern Life .   Note : For members previously insured under NTUC Income, if the claim event date is before 1 April 2021, the next-of-kin can submit their claim application to NTUC Income directly.    NTUC Income can be contacted at: Email: healthcare@income.com.sg Phone: 6332 1133 Website for claim submission: https://www.income.com.sg/claims/life-insurance

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I claim the Dependants' Protection Scheme benefits?
Knowledge Article: Answer: A Dependants’ Protection Scheme claim can be made when a member passes away or suffers from terminal illness or total permanent disability.   If member passes away   The next-of-kin of the insured member can submit a claim application to Great Eastern Life directly.   If member suffers from terminal illness or total permanent disability   Find out more:   I am suffering from a terminal illness or have a total permanent disability. How do I claim insurance benefits under the Dependants’ Protection Scheme? Can I claim my Home Protection Scheme benefits and withdraw my CPF savings at the same time? If you are claiming for DPS benefits only, you can submit an application to Great Eastern Life directly.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I top up to myself, my children or my loved ones' MediSave Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can make a top-up via Top up MediSave Account using PayNow QR 1 .   You will be prompted to key in your Recipient’s NRIC/CPF Account Number if you are making a top-up to your loved ones.   You are encouraged to make top-ups early. All applications and payments should reach CPF Board by the last day of the calendar year to enjoy tax relief for the following year’s Tax Assessment. Backdating of top-ups to previous years is not allowed .   Please note that there is no tax relief for top-ups made to your children. Find out more about tax relief for your MediSave top-ups.   You can find out more on which voluntary top-up is applicable to you.   To make MediSave top-ups to yourself or a loved one, you are required to be up-to-date with your MediSave payable (paid in full or on an active GIRO plan) under the Self-Employed Scheme . You may make payment for your MediSave payable via the payment modes .   1 Subsequent or duplicate payments made using the same PayNow QR  code will be refunded. To ensure that your cash top-ups are processed successfully, please only scan the PayNow QR code and make payment once.  You will need to submit a new application each time you wish to make another top-up .

Knowledge Article: Question: My Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) claim has been approved. How will I receive my DPS claim payout?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Upon approval of the Dependants’ Protection Scheme (DPS) claim, Great Eastern Life (GEL) will disburse the DPS claim benefits to your PayNow account, which is linked to your Singapore NRIC and bank account. If you prefer not to receive your DPS claim benefits via PayNow, you may contact GEL directly. If payment made via PayNow is unsuccessful, GEL will contact you to check with you on your preferred payment mode.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I claim Dependants' Protection Scheme benefits under medical grounds on behalf of my next-of-kin who lacks mental capacity?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As an appointed donee/deputy for your next-of-kin, you can claim his insurance benefits and withdraw CPF savings due to Reduced Life Expectancy by completing this form and submitting the required documents as listed in the form. The form will allow you to concurrently apply for both Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) and Home Protection Scheme (HPS) benefits, as well as withdrawal of CPF savings .   Upon receipt of the completed form and supporting document(s), CPF Board and Great Eastern Life (for DPS) will review the application and follow up with you.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the MediSave contribution rates for self-employed persons (SEPs)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your MediSave payable is based on your age and net trade income for the year. You can use the Self-Employed MediSave Contribution Calculator to calculate the amount of MediSave you need to contribute.   View the MediSave rates applicable for 2026 (PDF, 75KB).   View the MediSave rates applicable for 2025 (PDF, 74KB).   View the MediSave rates applicable for 2024 (PDF, 74KB).   View the MediSave rates applicable for 2023 (PDF, 74KB).   View the MediSave rates applicable for the years 2016 to 2022 (PDF, 0.2MB).   View the MediSave rates applicable for 2015 (PDF, 23KB).   View the MediSave rates applicable for 2014 (PDF, 60KB).   View the MediSave rates applicable for 2013 (PDF, 54KB).   View the MediSave rates applicable for 2012 (PDF, 52KB).   View the MediSave rates applicable for 2011 (PDF, 28KB).   View the MediSave rates applicable for 2010 (PDF, 28KB).   View the MediSave rates applicable for the years 2007 to 2009 (PDF, 19KB).   View the MediSave rates applicable for the years 1992 to 2006 (PDF, 19KB).

Knowledge Article: Question: Does my doctor need to complete the required medical certification for my Dependants' Protection Scheme claim if I already have a medical report from a previous insurance claim?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you already have a medical report on hand, you can submit it to CPF Board through the link which will be provided after you submit an online claim form . The application form will allow you to concurrently apply for both Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) and Home Protection Scheme (HPS) benefits, as well as withdrawal of CPF savings . We will assess whether the report you have provided is sufficient and inform you accordingly.   If you are claiming for DPS benefits only, you may submit the report directly to Great Eastern Life (GEL). GEL will assess whether the report you have provided is sufficient and inform you accordingly.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I amend my bank account details or cancel the online application while it is pending activation?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You are unable to amend your bank account details by submitting a new application or cancel the online application while it is pending activation. You can update your bank account details after it has been activated, which will generally take 12 hours for PayNow NRIC-linked bank accounts, and up to two working days for other bank accounts.  If the changes made to your bank account details are unauthorised, please contact your bank to freeze your bank account immediately and  reset your Singpass . If you are age 55 and above, you can also activate the CPF Withdrawal Lock under  Account settings  to instantly disable online withdrawal.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have already made a nomination for Dependants' Protection Scheme prior to 1 April 2021. Do I need to make a new nomination after 1 April 2021?
