Knowledge Article: Answer: From 1 April 2021, Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) is solely administered by Great Eastern Life.   If your DPS policy was under NTUC Income, it has been automatically transferred to Great Eastern Life. As the DPS policies with NTUC Income has ceased after 31 March 2021, nominations of DPS policies previously made under NTUC Income is no longer valid. As such, if you had previously made a nomination under NTUC Income, under the Insurance Act, you will be required to make a new nomination. Your new insurer, Great Eastern Life, would have sent out the nomination forms to you.   If your DPS policy is under Great Eastern Life and you had made a nomination previously, there is no need for you to submit a new nomination, unless you wish to nominate new beneficiaries.   Please note that DPS claim benefits do not form part of CPF savings and will not be distributed based on your CPF Nomination.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I update my registered bank account details with CPF Board?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can update your registered bank account details with CPF Board to receive payments such as withdrawal of CPF savings and monthly payouts via my   cpf  digital services –  Account settings with your Singpass.   You will need to verify your identity using enhanced authentication measures to update your registered bank account details.   How to update your registered bank account details with CPF Board:   Log in to your CPF account with your Singpass. On the website menu, click on ‘Account services’ > ‘Your account information’ > ‘Update account settings’. Click the ‘Bank account’ tab and click ‘Update’. For PayNow , select ‘PayNow NRIC-linked bank account’ and submit the form. The bank account will be updated after 12 hours For Interbank GIRO , key in your bank account details and submit the form. The bank account will generally take up to two  working days to be activated after your bank confirms that the bank account belongs to you.

Knowledge Article: Question: What benefits do self-employed persons enjoy from making MediSave contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: When you contribute to MediSave, you enjoy:   Up to 6% interest 1 per annum on your MediSave savings Savings in the MediSave Account earn 4% interest 1 per annum, and the first $60,000 of your combined CPF balances earns an additional 1% interest per annum. Members aged 55 and above will also enjoy an additional 1% interest per annum on the first $30,000 of their combined CPF balance from 1 January 2016. Tax relief of up to 37% of your annual net trade income (NTI), the CPF Annual Limit of $37,740 or the actual amount contributed by you, whichever is lower. No tax relief is given if your assessed NTI for the year of assessment is zero or negative. Use of MediSave savings to pay for a variety of medical expenses Hassle-free licence application and renewal You may also be eligible for Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) payouts of up to $2,800 annually.    1  Based on the current 4% interest rate floor for MediSave savings. Refer to  CPF interest rates  for the current rates.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I check if I have made a Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To check your Dependants’ Protection Scheme (DPS) nomination, please contact your DPS insurer, Great Eastern Life directly.   Reminder: From 1 April 2021, DPS is solely administered by Great Eastern Life. If you had previously made a nomination under NTUC Income, you are to make a new DPS nomination. DPS claim benefits do not form part of CPF proceeds and will not be distributed based on your CPF Nomination.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have not made a nomination before. How do I make a nomination for my Dependants' Protection Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are at least 18 years old and wish to have the death claim benefits paid to specific person/organization i.e. beneficiary(s), you are advised to make a nomination by submitting the Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) nomination form (available on Great Eastern Life’s website ) to the insurer. Should you wish to amend your nomination thereafter, you can do so by submitting a new nomination.   Reminder: DPS claim benefits do not form part of CPF proceeds and will not be distributed based on your CPF Nomination.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have more than one source of trade income. Do I have to contribute to MediSave for all of them?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your MediSave contributions are based on the annual net trade income (NTI) from all your trades. If you have a yearly NTI of more than $6,000 from all your trades, you’re required to make contributions to your MediSave Account.   You can refer to this example of how MediSave payable is computed on multiple sources of NTI.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long does it take to activate my bank account details?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As part of CPF Board’s ongoing efforts to better safeguard CPF members’ savings against unauthorised online withdrawals, your new bank account will be activated after a 12-hour cooling period or verification by banks:    Bank account Activation time PayNow NRIC-linked bank account After 12-hour cooling period Other bank account (POSB, DBS, OCBC, UOB) After your bank confirms that the account belongs to you which generally takes up to two working days

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the Dependants' Protection Scheme claim criteria?
Knowledge Article: Answer: A Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) claim can be made when a member passes away or is certified to be suffering from terminal illness or total permanent disability.   For more information on DPS claim criteria, please refer to  Great Eastern Life .

Knowledge Article: Question: If I am granted sole custody of my child following a divorce, can I request to remove my ex-spouse's access to our child's CPF statement?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you can  write to us using your Singpass and attach the Court Order as a supporting document.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will I be notified about the status of my update bank account application?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will receive an SMS and email notification to the local mobile number and email address registered with CPF Board as well as a push notification on your CPF Mobile app upon the following:  Submission of the application to update your registered bank account Successful update of your registered bank account Unsuccessful update of your registered bank account You can also check the status of your online application under  Activities .   If the changes made to your registered bank account are unauthorised,  please contact your bank to freeze your bank account immediately and reset your Singpass. If you are age 55 and above, you can also activate the CPF Withdrawal Lock under Account settings to instantly disable online withdrawal.

Knowledge Article: Question: Which payments are under Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: All tax-liable payments to freelancers and sole proprietors are under Contribute As You Earn (CAYE), except  this list of payments . These requirements will be communicated to corporate service buyers (CSBs) through legislation and implementation guides. To facilitate the implementation of CAYE, Vendors@Gov will automatically identify vendors who are under CAYE when they log in through Corppass or Singpass. These vendors will be notified of their obligation via prompts. For invoices outside of Vendors@Gov, CSBs will need to identify self-employed persons covered under CAYE through: the NRIC used by the vendor to transact, or the Unique Entity Number (UEN) issued by ACRA. CSBs can use the Enterprise Data Hub (EDH) to check whether the vendor’s business entity type is a sole-proprietorship or partnership.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens if corporate service buyers fail to pay the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Corporate service buyers (CSBs) are required to self-rectify if any non-compliance is detected. Please refer to the  Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) implementation guide  issued by the CPF Board. CPF Board has conducted briefings to CSBs and will work closely with CSBs to ensure full adoption and compliance of CAYE.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is CPF EZPay Mobile?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF EZPay Mobile is a mobile application suitable for submitting CPF contributions for 10 or fewer employees, anytime and anywhere.   Here’s what you need to know about CPF EZPay Mobile:   Registration is not required. Simply download the app from Apple App Store or Google Play to begin. Please ensure that the developer of the application is  Central Provident Fund Board . Save and load your employee’s details, and easily amend them for your monthly submissions. Make payment via PayNow QR. To find out more about how to use CPF EZPay Mobile, you may refer to the  User Guide (PDF, 2.3MB) or watch the Video Guide on YouTube.   This app is now available for download from the Apple App Store or Google Play (only for Android phones running on Android OS. 5.0 and above)!

Knowledge Article: Question: Is there a need to amend the conditions of contract for contracts signed before the inception of Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) is mandatory under the law, there is no need to amend the conditions of contract for contracts signed before the inception of CAYE. For new contracts signed moving forward, the Ministry of Manpower and CPF Board will work with the Ministry of Finance to inform new vendors of the CAYE requirements.

Knowledge Article: Question: What bank accounts can I use to update my bank account details?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may update your  PayNow NRIC-linked bank account  to receive payments from CPF Board via PayNow. Alternatively, you may use any POSB, DBS, OCBC and UOB bank accounts belonging to you. As part of CPF Board’s ongoing efforts to better safeguard CPF members’ savings against unauthorised online withdrawals, we only accept these bank accounts as only these banks are able to provide automated bank account verification to CPF Board. This ensures that payment will only be made to a bank account which belongs to you.

Knowledge Article: Question: What tests am I required to undergo for the Home Protection Scheme medical examination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The medical tests required for the Home Protection Scheme medical examination depend on your health condition.   Generally, the medical examination includes the following:   General checks with height, weight, visual acuity, blood pressure readings and pulse rate Lipid profile Fasting blood glucose Urinalysis Find out more:   Do I have to pay for the Home Protection Scheme medical examination? What do I need to prepare for the Home Protection Scheme medical examination?

Knowledge Article: Question: What do I need to prepare for the Home Protection Scheme medical examination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You are required to fast for at least 8 hours before your Home Protection Scheme medical examination appointment. Plain water and your usual medication are fine.   For ladies, please note that urine test should be performed at least 5 days after the last date of menstruation. If you are menstruating on the day of your appointment, please inform the clinic staff or doctor as the urine test would not be accurate.   Find out more:   How do I reschedule my appointment for Home Protection Scheme medical examination?

Knowledge Article: Question: With the additional step to split the service fee under Contribute As You Earn (CAYE), would this result in a delayed payment of service fee that may exceed the credit terms?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Under PACE (PayNow for CAYE), please submit the payment file to OCBC at least five working days before the service fee is due, to ensure timely payment. This is because the earliest corporate payment value date that you can select will be one working day from the date of file transmission to OCBC using FAST. Using GIRO, it will take two working days for funds to be credited to the CAYE bank account from the date of file transmission to OCBC. Thereafter, it will generally take four working days for the CAYE contribution to be deposited into the SEP’s MediSave account. (Note: If the service fee payment to the SEP exceeds $200,000, the payment will be rejected and the full service fee payment minus $0.55 per transaction as a rejection fee will be returned to the corporate service buyer’s PayNow-registered bank account.) Please refer to this  document  for the illustration of the PACE (PayNow for CAYE) process. If you are using the online submission mode (DDA mode) to make payments, please log into the CAYE Digital Services at least four working days before the service fee is due to ensure timely payment. This is because the earliest deduction date that you can select will be two working days later (if the submission was made before 5pm). Payment to SEP will generally take up to two working days from the date of deduction. Please refer to this  document  for the illustration of the digital submission mode process.

Knowledge Article: Question: Under Contribute As You Earn (CAYE), corporate service buyers will only pay the net service fee directly to self-employed persons. Are there any legal implications?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Under Contribute As You Earn (CAYE), corporate service buyers (CSBs) will still be paying the full amount stated in the contract to the self-employed person (SEP), with a portion of the service fee credited to the SEP’s MediSave Account and the remainder paid to the SEP's bank account registered to PayNow (excluding PayNow Mobile Number and Virtual Payments Address). CSBs would be legally obliged to participate in CAYE under the CPF Act. For audit purposes, CSBs will be able to view the transaction details and amount of CAYE contributions made on the CAYE Digital Services.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I reschedule my appointment for Home Protection Scheme medical examination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: It depends on whether you have an upcoming appointment, or you have missed your appointment for your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) medical examination.   For upcoming appointments: You can check or reschedule your appointment online .   However, please note that you will not be able to reschedule to an appointment date that is within the next two days.   For missed appointments: You will not be able to view your appointment for HPS medical examination online or reschedule it if you have missed the appointment date.   Find out more:   What will happen if i missed my appointment for Home Protection Scheme medical examination?

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the criteria for inclusion of Shares under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: In considering the inclusion of shares under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS), the Board uses the following criteria:   The shares are offered by a company that is incorporated in Singapore; The shares are listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) Mainboard as primary listing; (The shares are not new Catalist shares or shares transferred from SGX Main Board to Catalist except for former SESDAQ shares. Please refer to the  FAQs on Transformation of SESDAQ to Catalist for details.) The shares are traded in Singapore Dollars; The company allows Agent Banks to appoint all CPF shareholders of the company as proxies to attend and vote at meetings; and The shares are not placed in the SGX watch-list.   You can refer to the SGX website for the list of shares included under the CPFIS.

Knowledge Article: Question: What will happen if I missed my appointment for Home Protection Scheme medical examination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have missed your appointment for Home Protection Scheme (HPS) medical examination, the Board may not be able to assess your eligibility and process your application. The Board will notify you on the outcome of your HPS application.   If you are not eventually issued an HPS cover and would like to be reconsidered for coverage under the scheme, you can submit a new HPS application using your Singpass.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will corporate service buyers know how much Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contribution to deduct from the service fee?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The amount of Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contribution to be deducted from the service fee depends on the self-employed person (SEP)’s CAYE contribution rate. The SEP’s CAYE contribution rate is automatically computed by the CAYE system based on the SEP’s MediSave contribution rate, estimated revenue and estimated expenses.  From 7 Jun 2024, please submit a corporate payment file to your corporate bank. Your corporate bank will then credit the total gross service fees to the CAYE bank account. OCBC will check with CPF Board’s CAYE system for the amount to be deducted and credited to the SEP’s MediSave Account (MA).  Under the online submission mode, you can key in the total service fee in the CAYE Digital Services, and the amount to be deducted and credited to the SEP’s MA would then be provided. You can then pay the MediSave contributions through the CAYE Digital Services and the service fee amount directly to the SEP. If an SEP queries about his/her CAYE contribution amount or rate, please direct the SEP to the CAYE Digital Services for SEPs where the SEP can log in to view his transaction details.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have already contributed up to the Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS). Why am I still required to participate in Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As a self-employed person, you’re still required to make MediSave contributions even if you have met the Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS). This is the same for employees.   The MediSave amount above the BHS will be transferred to your CPF Special Account (SA)* or Retirement Account (RA). The BHS cap and overflow arrangement are intentionally planned to avoid over savings in MediSave and to supplement your retirement savings. These overflows which end up in your SA or RA can be withdrawn according to the  withdrawal guidelines . If you’ve met the Full Retirement Sum in your SA or RA, the savings in excess of the BHS will be transferred to your Ordinary Account (OA). Savings in the OA can be used for other purposes such as housing repayment.   *The SA will be closed for members aged 55 and above from early 2025. Read more  here .

Knowledge Article: Question: How are the Basic Retirement Sum and Full Retirement Sum determined for each cohort?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Basic Retirement Sum (BRS) takes reference from a person's expenditure from a lower-middle retiree household, according to the latest Household Expenditure Survey (HES) . It assumes that the member owns a property that lasts him up to 95 and he does not need to pay rent in retirement.   The Full Retirement Sum (FRS) is set at two times of the BRS.   The BRS or FRS you need to set aside depends on when you turn 55 and is fixed for the rest of your life.   Find out why the retirement sums are adjusted yearly for successive cohorts .

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I make payment for composition amount and late payment interest?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Payment for composition amount and late payment interest can be made via the following methods:   Composition Amount   Pay composition amount Late Payment Interest   CPF EZPay CPF EZPay Mobile   Please refer to the  Payment Methods Guide (PDF, 0.1MB) for more information.   To check the transaction status for the payment of the composition amount, please follow these steps:   Go to cpf.gov.sg/employer Click on Login Select Other employer services Login with your Singpass Key in the CPF Submission Number and click on Proceed to continue On the top menu bar, click on Employer services and select ' Activities' at the bottom panel

Knowledge Article: Question: Why are the retirement sums increasing yearly?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The increase in retirement sums is due to the following:   Increase in cost of living As prices of goods and services rise over time, we will need to save more for retirement to ensure that our savings will still be sufficient to cover higher expenses in the future. Increase in life expectancy As people are living longer, we will need more savings to last throughout our retirement. Increase in standard of living As incomes increase over time, our basic retirement expectations and expenses will also naturally increase. Setting aside more savings allows us to receive higher monthly payouts to afford higher retirement expenses in future. However, if you are already 55, the yearly increase won't affect you. The  retirement sum you need to set aside depends on when you turn 55 and is fixed for the rest of your life.   It's important to keep in mind that the amount needed for retirement has increased over the years. For example, if the Full Retirement Sum had remained unchanged from $30,000 when it was first introduced in 1987 (previously known as the Minimum Sum), it would only provide a monthly payout of about $300 today. This amount would not be enough to cover daily living expenses and rent.   Overall, the goal of increasing retirement savings is to help individuals build a financial foundation that will enable them to support themselves through retirement.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the status of my request to make self-employed MediSave contributions via monthly instalments?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We will keep you informed about the status of your request to make self-employed MediSave contributions via monthly instalments, once it has been processed.   Please note our normal processing time: ·         Requests made via online appeal: generally 12 working days ·         Manual transactions: generally 15 working days   You can check the status of your request by clicking on this link .   You can view your approved GIRO instalment plan details on the  Self-employment dashboard . To access  my cpf  Digital Services – Self-employment dashboard, please log in to the  CPF website  using your Singpass.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens when my CPF account is closed and I have yet to transfer my CPF savings to my bank account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Once your CPF account is closed, any remaining savings in your account will stop earning the prevailing CPF interest.   As a transitory measure, these savings will earn interest based on the 3-month average of the three local banks’ savings account interest rates. This is because non-Singapore Citizens and non-Permanent Residents can transfer these monies to their bank account at any time. The applicable rate is 0.05% per annum from April 2024 and will be fixed for a 3-year period until 31 March 2027. From 1 April 2027, any remaining savings will no longer earn any interest.   You can still transfer the remaining savings to your bank account at any time.   Your participation in all the schemes administered by the CPF Board will also cease. Please refer to the section "Schemes' participation upon account closure"  for more information regarding schemes’ participation when your CPF account is closed.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can taxi principal hirers who are not liable to make a MediSave contribution qualify for Drive and Save (DAS) co-contribution from their taxi operators?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Taxi principal hirers who do not have outstanding MediSave payable can still receive Drive and Save co-contributions if they make contributions to pre-pay their future MediSave payable 1 :   A contribution of at least $20 to their MediSave Account monthly, or A lump sum MediSave contribution of at least $240 in the past 12 months.  1  Taxi principal hirers may make contributions to pre-pay their MediSave payable via Manage your MediSave payable .

Knowledge Article: Question: Why do I need to link my bank account to PayNow using my NRIC number?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Unlike mobile numbers, the NRIC number is an unchanged reference number issued by the Government and is the only accepted reference number for government payments via PayNow. Linking your bank account to PayNow using your NRIC number ensures that government payments will be made correctly to you.

Knowledge Article: Question: When will my CPF account be closed if I am not a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are not a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident before 1 April 2024 , your CPF account will be  automatically closed  in April 2024 and any remaining savings will stop earning the prevailing CPF interest.   As a concession, these savings will earn interest similar to commercial bank interest rates until 31 March 2027. Subsequently, no interest will be paid. You are encouraged to transfer the remaining savings to your bank account as soon as possible.   If you renounced Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Residency from 1 April 2024 , please close your CPF account and transfer your CPF savings to your bank account when your renunciation is completed, i.e. when you are no longer a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident.   If you do not do so, your CPF account will be automatically closed in the month following your renunciation; i.e. if you renounced your Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Residency in April 2024, your account will be closed in May 2024. Any remaining savings will stop earning the prevailing CPF interest.   As a concession, these savings will earn interest similar to commercial bank interest rates until 31 March 2027. Subsequently, no interest will be paid.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I even start to familiarise myself with digital services?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Government is stepping up efforts to help Singaporeans navigate our digital channels. You may find the following links from the SG Digital Office useful to kickstart your digital journey.   Starter Kit Booklet for all Digital Government Services Topics (PDF, 21.2MB) Other self-learning tools to help familiarise yourself with digital services

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the admission criteria that fund management companies (FMCs) and insurance companies need to meet, in order to be included under CPFIS?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please see the admission criteria for fund management companies (FMCs) and insurance companies .

Knowledge Article: Question: How long does it take to process applications relating to Healthcare?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please refer to the table below for the processing time of our various Healthcare services.   Service Normal Processing Time Top up or voluntary contribution to MediSave Account (to pay MediShield Life Premiums) PayNow QR : Generally processed almost instantly Please note that payment via eNETS Debit is discontinued from 23 April 2023.   Find out more . Change your Payer for MediShield Life Cover  Online: Within three working days Stop Premium Payment for your Dependant(s)' MediShield Life Cover  Make A Health Declaration for new Permanent Residents Applicant Online : Within seven working days Make A MediSave Claim Online : Within three working days from the day we receive the claim from the medical institution Make A MediShield Life Claim Online : Within seven working days from the day we receive the claim from the medical institution/insurer Apply for MediSave/MediShield Life Reimbursement from Employers/Insurers Online: Within five working days Top Up My/My Loved Ones’ MediSave Account using CPF Online : Immediate

Knowledge Article: Question: Compared to the MOE Tuition Fee Loan (TFL), isn't the CPF Education Loan a better option as I will pay the interest to my parents' Ordinary Account so that they can benefit from it?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The MOE TFL is interest-free during the course of study. This means that if you repay the loan fully right after graduation, you will not incur any interest at all for the MOE TFL. If you are unable to repay your MOE TFL due to further studies or financial difficulties due to unemployment or medical condition, you may appeal to defer repayment and interest. Your appeal will be considered on a case-by-case basis. For more information on the MOE TFL, please refer to this link .   On the other hand, if you borrow from your parent’s OA, the interest starts to accrue from the time the savings are withdrawn to pay the educational institutions. When you repay the accrued interest to your parents’ OA, you are simply restoring their OA to what government would have paid them anyway. There is no additional benefit to them. By not using your parent’s OA savings, government will be paying your parent an OA interest of up to 3.5% during your period of study and they will be able to accumulate more CPF savings for their retirement.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I check my voluntary top-up limit to my MediSave Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: When you make a MediSave top-up online, you will be shown the amount of MediSave top-up you can receive before you reach the top-up limit.   You can follow these steps to check how much you can top up to your MediSave Account:   Go to the Top up MediSave Account form Log in with your Singpass Select “I wish to make a top-up to Myself” under “Recipient details”   Your top-up limit will then be displayed.   If you are making a top-up to your loved ones, please check with your recipient directly on the amount he can receive.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I apply to be insured under the Home Protection Scheme (HPS) after I obtained Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Residency again?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may re-apply for a Home Protection Scheme cover online , using your Singpass, if your previous HPS cover has ceased and you are the owner of a HDB flat with an outstanding housing loan.   Your eligibility for HPS coverage is subject to approval and your current health condition.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the relevant reporting period (of audited expense ratio) that fund managers are required to submit?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For existing CPF Investment Scheme funds, the new Total Expense Ratio (TER) caps will take effect from 1 Jan 2016.  As such, the compliance with the new TER caps for each fund will be based on the audited report for the financial year of the fund ended in a month in 2016 . The implementation date for the new TER cap for a fund will be one day after the deadline of submission of the audited report for the fund.   The Board encourages Fund Management Companies (FMCs)/Insurers to assess early whether their funds can meet the new TER caps. If their funds cannot meet the new TER caps, FMCs/Insurers should inform the Board early.   However, FMCs/Insurers must factor in the period required for settling the purchase transactions and thus the last purchase date must be at least five working days before the implementation date. This means that after the last purchase date, if a CPF member buys a fund that does not meet the TER cap, FMCs/Insurers should not channel the subscriptions into that fund. If the funds cannot meet the TER cap, FMCs/Insurers should communicate the consequence clearly to their unitholders/policyholders, before the last purchase date. Please refer to the relevant reporting period (PDF, 0.1MB) for details.

Knowledge Article: Question: What will be the applicable Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contribution rate used?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Both the bank and online submission modes will use the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contribution rate applicable as at the date of submission for consistency.  If the self-employed person logs in to the CAYE digital services to update his CAYE contribution rate, the rate will only be effective the next day. Corporate service buyers using the online submission mode are to log in to the CAYE digital services to determine the CAYE contributions only when they are ready to transmit the service fee.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I pay CPF contributions using PayNow QR?
Knowledge Article: Answer: PayNow QR is a quick way for you to make payment for CPF contributions by scanning a QR code, via existing mobile banking apps. PayNow QR allows you to use corporate or personal accounts to pay your CPF contributions. You would have to scan the PayNow QR code using a PayNow participating bank ’s app in order for the payment to be processed successfully. Any payment made without using the issued PayNow QR code (e.g. making payment directly to CPF Board’s UEN or changing the details after scanning the PayNow QR code) or multiple payments made using the same PayNow QR code will be refunded with the reference code “CPF”.   The maximum amount you can transfer via PayNow QR is $200,000, subject to daily and monthly limits set by your bank. If your total CPF submission amount exceeds $200,000, you will need to perform another submission via CPF EZPay. For example, if your total CPF submission amount is $300,000, you will need to make two separate CPF submissions via CPF EZPay consisting of $200,000 and $100,000 respectively. Please make sure you have sufficient funds in your bank account before the payment is deducted. If you have set a PayNow payment limit with your bank, do ensure that the limit is sufficient to pay your CPF contributions. Some banks may charge an administrative fee for each unsuccessful payment attempt. Personal bank account On the day of submission, you must ensure that you scan the PayNow QR code and pay using your PayNow participating bank's app before it expires at 23:59 hrs. Once the QR code has expired, you will not be able to make the payment, and will need to resubmit your CPF contributions and get a new PayNow QR code. After your payment has been made, your payment status will be updated as "Paid" in CPF EZPay almost instantly. Corporate bank account Two-level authorisation (Maker and Checker) is required for PayNow Corporate account users. Maker needs to scan the PayNow QR code to prepare the transaction before 23:59 hrs on the day of submission. Thereafter, the Checker needs to login to the banking app to approve the transaction. Though there is no time limit for approving the transaction, it is advisable for the Checker to approve the payment immediately to avoid incurring late payment interest. If the Maker did not scan the PayNow QR code before it expires, you’ll need to resubmit your CPF contributions and get a new PayNow QR code. After your payment has been approved, your payment status will be updated as "Paid" in CPF EZPay almost instantly.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will the deceased member's CPF monies and assets be distributed if he was a bankrupt?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The treatment of a deceased bankrupt member's CPF monies and assets depends on whether there is a valid nomination:   If the deceased member had made a valid nomination, his remaining CPF savings and discounted Singtel Shares (if any), will be distributed in cash to his nominee(s).   If the deceased member had not made a valid nomination, his remaining CPF savings will be forwarded to the  Public Trustee's Office (PTO)  for distribution according to  intestacy  or  Muslim Inheritance laws .   The deceased member's discounted Singtel shares are due to his estate and the Official Assignee may lay claims on the shares.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the payment modes available under Contribute As You Earn (CAYE)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Corporate service buyers (CSBs) can make Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions via two payment modes:   PACE (PayNow for CAYE) CSBs submit a payment file to CPF Board. CPF Board returns an acknowledgement file to CSBs within one working day. After CSBs process the acknowledgement file, CSBs submit a corporate payment file to OCBC via their existing bank payment service. Once CSB’s bank transmits the gross service fee to the CAYE bank account, OCBC will pay the net service fee to the self-employed person (SEP)’s bank account via PayNow (excluding PayNow Mobile Number and Virtual Payments Address), and credit the required CAYE contribution to the SEP’s MediSave Account. Online submission mode (eNETS or GIRO DDA) CSBs will log into the CAYE Digital Services using their Corppass and key in the service fee to be paid to the SEP. The CAYE Digital Services will indicate the CAYE contribution required for each SEP. CSBs will only pay the CAYE contribution to SEP’s MediSave account via DDA. CSBs will pay the net service fee to SEP’s PayNow (excluding PayNow Mobile Number and Virtual Payments Address) separately.

Knowledge Article: Question: What actions do I (as a CPFIS investor) need to take due to reduction in Total Expense Ratio caps?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You do not have to take any action unless the fund(s) you have invested in cannot comply with the reduced Total Expense Ratio (TER) caps. In which case, the relevant parties (i.e. Fund Management Companies/insurers/investment administrators) will notify you by letters. As existing funds which are unable to comply with the new TER caps from 2016 will be downgraded to List B and will not be allowed to take in new CPF monies from then, you will be given the following options by the relevant parties:   Free switches to other funds included under CPF Investment Scheme within a specified period from the date of the letter (around one month) Redeem the units Continue to remain invested in these funds (if you choose this option, no further action is required from you) Note: Cash investors would not be affected. For info - List of funds will be updated when necessary. List A and B unit trusts (PDF, 0.2MB) List A and B Investment Link Products (ILPs) Sub-funds (PDF, 0.1MB)

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the differences between topping up my retirement savings, making a Voluntary Housing Refund and topping up my MediSave Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Find out what the differences between the various types of top-ups are below:   Topping up your retirement savings Voluntary Housing Refund Topping up your MediSave Account Top up/refund to Special Account (SA) for members below 55; or Retirement Account (RA) for members 55 or above. Ordinary Account (OA); and/or RA for members 55 or above and have not met their Full Retirement Sum (FRS) in their RA. MediSave Account (MA) Eligibility for tax relief You can enjoy tax relief if you made cash top-ups to yourself or your loved ones up to the current FRS . However, please note that tax relief would not apply if you made a CPF transfer. You will not be eligible for tax relief. For non self-employed persons: You get to enjoy tax relief for voluntary top-ups to MA.  If you are self-employed, you will enjoy  tax relief  on your  MediSave contributions   based on your annual net trade income (NTI). There will be no tax relief for your MediSave contributions if your assessed NTI for the year of assessment is zero or negative.   Top-up limit What is the maximum amount of top-ups I can receive? If you are below 55, you may top up your SA up to the current FRS. If you are 55 or above, you may top up your RA up to the current Enhanced Retirement Sum. You can check your top-up limit in your Retirement Dashboard . Can I voluntarily refund a portion of the CPF savings I used for my property? You can make a refund of any amount, capped at the full principal amount you have withdrawn for the property, along with the accrued interest. You may check the amount that you can refund through the Home Ownership Dashboard . Do note that after making a full voluntary housing refund of the CPF savings withdrawn and accrued interest, all CPF withdrawals including monthly housing loan instalments (if any) for the property will stop. What is the voluntary top-up limit to my MediSave Account? The maximum amount you can voluntarily top up to your MA is the difference between your Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS) and your current MA balance. Once your BHS has been reached, no further voluntary top-ups can be made to your MA. If you exceed your BHS from the top-up, the full amount of your top-up will be refunded to you. You can check your top-up limit with these steps. Withdrawal Top-ups are meant to boost your retirement income. They will be streamed out to you as monthly payouts and cannot be used for other purposes. You can continue to use your OA savings for the current or next property after making a voluntary housing refund. However, if you would like to use your OA for the same property, after making a voluntary refund of the full principal amount used and the accrued interest, you will need to re-apply to use your CPF savings. After turning 55 and setting aside the FRS, you can withdraw the remaining balance in your OA and SA in full or in part at any time. From 55, you can make retirement withdrawals from your OA and SA in full or in part, at any time for your immediate needs, provided you have set aside your FRS. MA savings are meant for your healthcare needs and cannot be withdrawn as cash. Application Top-ups can be made using cash and/or CPF transfers. How do I apply to make a top-up? Refund can only be made via cash. How can I make a voluntary refund of the housing amount withdrawn if I am not selling my property? Top-ups can only be made via cash. How can I top up to myself, my children or my loved ones’ MediSave Account?   Click this link to find out what the CPF interest rates are.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have made a top-up to my CPF accounts, do I still have to make MediSave contributions to offset my MediSave payable?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The contributions allocated to your MediSave Account via your top up to CPF accounts will not be used to offset your MediSave payable.   If you want to make MediSave contributions to offset your outstanding (via instalment plan or full payment) or future MediSave payable, you may do so via the  Manage your MediSave Payable  form.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to my investments when my CPF account is closed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The treatment of your investments when your CPF account is closed will depend on the investment scheme you have participated in.   CPF Investment Scheme – Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA) We will inform the agent bank to close your CPF Investment Account. The agent bank will then contact you for the withdrawal #  of your investments and cash balance (if any). Your investments will be transferred to your own name and you may thereafter continue servicing your investments using cash or liquidate them as you wish and have the sale proceeds paid to you directly.   Once transferred, your CPFIS investments and cash balance in your CPF Investment Account will no longer be protected from any claims by your creditors and/or the Official Assignee.   # Central Depository (Pte) Ltd (“CDP”) imposes a transfer fee of $10.00 (excluding GST) for every share counter transferred from your CPF Investment Account to your CDP Account.   CPF Investment Scheme – Special Account (CPFIS-SA) We will inform your product provider(s) to transfer your investment to your own name. Thereafter, you may liquidate them as you wish and have the sale proceeds paid to you directly.   Once transferred, your CPFIS investments and cash balance in your CPF Investment Account will no longer be protected from any claims by your creditors and/or the Official Assignee.   Special Discounted Shares (SDS) Scheme Your discounted Singtel shares will be automatically liquidated in the month following the automatic closure of your CPF account . The sales proceeds will be held together with your CPF savings, which you can transfer to your bank account at any point in time.   If you do not wish for your discounted Singtel shares to be automatically liquidated, please liquidate them before you renounce your Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Residency.

Thereafter, you may liquidate them as you wish and have the sale proceeds paid to you directly.   Once transferred, your CPFIS investments and cash balance in your CPF Investment Account will no longer be protected from any claims by your creditors and/or the Official Assignee.   Special Discounted Shares (SDS) Scheme Your discounted Singtel shares will be automatically liquidated in the month following the automatic closure of your CPF account . The sales proceeds will be held together with your CPF savings, which you can transfer to your bank account at any point in time.   If you do not wish for your discounted Singtel shares to be automatically liquidated, please liquidate them before you renounce your Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Residency.

Knowledge Article: Question: I used to declare my income to CPFB to determine my Workfare Income Supplement (WIS)/excess Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions for the year. Why is CPFB no longer accepting income declarations?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) has been appointed as the single collecting agency for all SEPs’ income information from Work Year 2023 (or Year of Assessment 2024). This means that all SEPs will now declare their net trade income (NTI), including all other sources of income derived from Work Year 2023, to IRAS. SEPs who receive a notification (via letter/form/SMS) to file tax from IRAS or meet the requirement to file tax (i.e. NTI above $6,000 and/or Total Income above $22,000), will need to complete and submit the tax return to IRAS directly. The income tax filing period is from 1 March to 18 April annually.   SEPs who do not receive a notification from IRAS or do not meet the requirement to file tax may declare their self-employed net trade income (NTI), including all other sources of income derived from Work Year 2023, to IRAS via  myTax Portal  which will be available from 1 March to 31 October annually for taxpayers to e-File tax returns.   SEPs will receive a Notice of Computation (NOC) from IRAS if they are required to make MediSave contributions, after IRAS has issued a Notice of Assessment for the relevant Year of Assessment.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why can't I find the bank account input details on Vendors@Gov?
Knowledge Article: Answer: From early June 2024, you will only be able to select PayNow (excluding PayNow Mobile Number and Virtual Payments Address) as the mode of payment.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is there support for patients undergoing cancer drug treatment that is not on the Cancer Drug List when the changes kicked in?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We encourage you to discuss with your doctor if there are suitable alternatives on the Cancer Drug List (CDL) that are subsidised and covered by insurance. However, if switching treatments is not feasible, there is support to help existing patients see through their current course of treatment:   MOH will provide additional financial support for all public healthcare institution (PHI) patients without an Integrated Shield Plan (IP), and who had started treatments that are unsubsidised or not on the CDL before 1 Sep 2022. If you are a subsidised patient and still face difficulties affording your bills, you can approach a Medical Social Worker (MSW) in your PHI for financial assistance such as MediFund. If you have an IP that is being renewed between 1 Apr 2023 and 30 Sep 2023, and have received cancer drug treatment between 1 Jan 2023 and 31 Mar 2023, insurers have committed to preserve your current IP coverage until 30 Sep 2023. If you are a private patient, you can also approach your doctor to refer you to subsidised care in a PHI, where you can apply for financial assistance. The PHI’s medical team will review your treatment plan and provide financial counselling (e.g. eligibility for subsidies) before you decide whether to transfer to a PHI. IP riders may also cover selected treatments beyond the CDL, though the extent of coverage may vary. A summary of each insurer’s IP and rider coverage for cancer drug treatments / services can be found in this  link . You may wish to check with your insurer, should you have further queries on your IP and rider coverage.

Knowledge Article: Question: When will I need to be registered for PayNow to continue receiving my net service fee payments without delay?
Knowledge Article: Answer: PayNow (excluding PayNow Mobile Number and Virtual Payments Address) will be the default payment mode from early June 2024. Please ensure that you are registered for PayNow (excluding PayNow Mobile Number and Virtual Payments Address) so that you receive your service fee payments promptly.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I make partial repayment or full repayment of my housing loan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The application process to use your CPF savings to make partial repayment or full repayment of your housing loan depends on the type of loan you have taken.   For HDB loan   Check that you have enough CPF Ordinary Account savings and the maximum amount of CPF savings that you can use for your property.   There are two ways to make a partial repayment or full repayment of your housing loan.   1. Submit an online application under Partial Capital Repayment/Redemption of Housing Loan at  HDB’s website  with your Singpass. Your application will be processed within three working days upon the receipt of your request from HDB. 2. Complete the CPF withdrawal form (PHS9) at HDB Branch. Please note that services at HDB office and Branches are by appointment only. If you wish to visit a HDB Branch, you can book an appointment via the  e-Appointment system . Your application will be processed within three to five working days upon the receipt of your request from HDB.   For Bank loan   To make partial or full repayment of your housing loan, you will need to:   1. Seek approval from your housing loan financier.   2. Check that you have enough CPF Ordinary Account savings and the maximum amount of CPF savings that you can use for your property. You can view you  Home ownership dashboard to find out your latest usage and usage limit for your property.   3. Submit an online application with your Singpass.   For full repayment of housing loan, you will need to upload a copy of the bank’s redemption statement and a copy of your lawyer’s legal bill (if any) in the application.   Your application will be processed within five working days.

Knowledge Article: Question: For PACE (PayNow for CAYE) payments, when do corporate service buyers need to submit a payment file to CPF Board to make Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions by the stipulated deadline?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Corporate service buyers using PACE (PayNow for CAYE) need to submit the payment file to CPF Board at least five working days before the service fee payment due date to ensure timely payment to the self-employed person (SEP)’s MediSave Account.

Knowledge Article: Question: With the closure of the Special Account for CPF members aged 55 and above, which account will my CPF contributions be allocated to?
Knowledge Article: Answer: With the closure of Special Account (SA), CPF contributions that go to the SA currently, as well as any increase in CPF contributions allocated to SA from 1 January 2025, will be fully allocated to the member’s Retirement Account (RA) instead, up to the Full Retirement Sum (FRS), to boost retirement payouts. For members who have set aside the FRS in the RA, these contributions will be channelled to the Ordinary Account (OA).   This will ensure that the additional contributions continue to earn the highest possible CPF interest rate to provide an even bigger boost to retirement payouts. RA balances currently earn a minimum interest rate of 4% a year, compared to a minimum of 2.5% in the OA. Plus, members aged 55 and above earn an extra interest of 2% per annum on the first $30,000 and 1% per annum on the next $30,000 of their combined CPF balances (capped at $20,000 for OA).

Knowledge Article: Question: If I am currently using my Special Account (SA) for Dependants' Protection Scheme premiums, how would I be impacted by the closure of SA?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Transition measures will be put in place after your Special Account (SA) has been closed , to ensure that members aged 55 and above who are currently using SA for DPS have sufficient time to make the necessary alternative arrangements.   Impacted members will be notified and advised on the necessary steps to take.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am aged 55 and above. What will happen when my Special Account is closed and what is the rationale for doing so?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Today, members aged 55 and above have two CPF accounts that hold savings intended for retirement payouts: the Special Account (SA) and the Retirement Account (RA). Both SA and RA savings earn the same long-term interest rate. However, some SA savings can be withdrawn on demand from age 55. As a principle, only savings that cannot be withdrawn on demand should earn the long-term interest rate, and savings that can be withdrawn on demand should earn the short-term interest rate.   To better align CPF interest rates to the nature of CPF savings in each CPF account, we will close your SA if you are aged 55 and above from early 2025. SA savings will be transferred to your RA, up to your Full Retirement Sum (FRS). These savings will continue to earn the long-term interest rate. If you have set aside your FRS, whether fully in cash or with a mixture of property and cash, any remaining SA savings will be transferred to your Ordinary Account (OA), where they remain withdrawable and will earn the short-term interest rate.   You can choose to transfer your OA savings to the RA at any time, up to the prevailing Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS) to earn long-term interest rates and receive higher retirement payouts. Once transferred, the RA savings can only be streamed out to you in retirement payouts. With the raised ERS from 1 January 2025 , more than 99% of the members aged 55 and above today would be able to transfer all their SA savings, that were channelled to the OA due to the closure of SA, to the RA.   You will be notified after the transfer of all SA savings to your RA and/or OA, and closure of your SA in early 2025. You will also be able to check the amounts transferred from your SA to your RA and/or OA from your CPF statement. No action is required from you now.   Watch the video on how the SA will be closed for you from early 2025.   More details on the implementation date will be shared in the second half of 2024.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are MediShield Life premium rebates?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Members pay higher premiums during their working ages. In return, they enjoy premium rebates that reduce the premiums they pay after age 66.   The premium rebates you receive depend on how long you have been insured under the scheme. The earlier you join the scheme, the higher the premium rebates you will receive.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to my CPF savings if I had made a CPF nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you had made a valid CPF Nomination, the following will be distributed to your nominees in the proportion as stated in your CPF nomination upon your death:   (a) CPF savings in your Ordinary, Special, MediSave and Retirement Accounts; (b) Unused CPF LIFE premiums; and (c) Discounted Singtel shares 1 .   The following are not covered by CPF Nomination:   (a) Properties bought with your CPF savings 2 ; (b) Payout from Dependants’ Protection Scheme (DPS) 3 ; and (c) Investments made under CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) 4 .   1 Discounted Singtel shares will form part of your estate if you do not make a CPF nomination.   2 The treatment of the deceased’s share of the property is dependent on the manner of holding. If the property is held under Joint Tenancy, ownership of property will be transferred to the surviving owner(s). If the property is held under Tenancy-in-Common, the deceased's share of property will form part of his estate.   3 You can make a DPS nomination with your DPS insurer or make a will to determine the beneficiaries of the DPS claim benefits. Without a DPS nomination or will, the benefits will be paid to the proper claimant(s). A proper claimant can be the executor of the deceased’s estate or a family member.   4 These will form part of your estate, except for insurance policies where if you have made a nomination with your insurance company, the death benefits from the policies will be paid to your nominated beneficiaries.   Watch this video to find out why you need to make a CPF nomination.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to my CPF savings if I had made a CPF nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you had made a valid CPF Nomination, the following will be distributed to your nominees in the proportion as stated in your CPF nomination upon your death:   (a) CPF savings in your Ordinary, Special, MediSave and Retirement Accounts; (b) Unused CPF LIFE premiums; and (c) Discounted Singtel shares 1 .   The following are not covered by CPF Nomination:   (a) Properties bought with your CPF savings 2 ; (b) Payout from Dependants’ Protection Scheme (DPS) 3 ; and (c) Investments made under CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) 4 .   1 Discounted Singtel shares will form part of your estate if you do not make a CPF nomination.   2 The treatment of the deceased’s share of the property is dependent on the manner of holding. If the property is held under Joint Tenancy, ownership of property will be transferred to the surviving owner(s). If the property is held under Tenancy-in-Common, the deceased's share of property will form part of his estate.   3 You can make a DPS nomination with your DPS insurer or make a will to determine the beneficiaries of the DPS claim benefits. Without a DPS nomination or will, the benefits will be paid to the proper claimant(s). A proper claimant can be the executor of the deceased’s estate or a family member.   4 These will form part of your estate, except for insurance policies where if you have made a nomination with your insurance company, the death benefits from the policies will be paid to your nominated beneficiaries.   Watch this video to find out why you need to make a CPF nomination.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the CPF monies and assets of a deceased member covered under a CPF nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The table below shows which of a deceased member’s CPF monies and assets are covered/not covered under a CPF nomination:   Covered under CPF nomination Not covered under CPF nomination i.       CPF savings in Ordinary, Special, MediSave  and Retirement Accounts ii.      CPF LIFE premium balance, if any iii.     Discounted Singtel shares i.       Properties bought using CPF savings ii.      Payouts from Dependants’ Protection Scheme iii.     Investments under CPF Investment Scheme   For more information, you can refer to the Losing a Loved One (PDF, 1.4MB) brochure .

Knowledge Article: Question: Why am I not eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme if I am older than 70 years old?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Matched Retirement Savings Scheme is designed to boost the retirement payouts of senior Singaporean Citizens who have not started or are just starting their retirement payouts, by helping them accumulate more savings. Doing this at a younger age allows top-ups to benefit from compound interest for a longer period and have a bigger impact on their eventual payouts. Hence, the age eligibility is capped at 70 years old in the assessment year.   Moreover, seniors above 70 years old would have already started receiving their payouts. The Government provides support for them in many other ways. For example, as members of the Pioneer Generation, they enjoy enhanced healthcare support. Seniors who own an HDB flat can tap on the Lease Buyback Scheme or Silver Housing Bonus Scheme to receive a cash bonus and a stream of retirement income for life. Eligible seniors may also receive quarterly cash supplements from the Silver Support Scheme . Seniors who need additional help to manage their daily costs of living can also apply for direct financial assistance via ComCare .

Knowledge Article: Question: My elderly parent would like to check his/her existing CPF nomination. How can I help him/her do so?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your parent can view his/her CPF nomination details online with his/her Singpass. Find out more information on how he/she can check his/her nomination details .   However, we would strongly encourage making a new nomination instead, especially if the previous nomination was made some time ago. Making a new nomination would ensure that your parent’s CPF monies are distributed according to his/her latest wishes upon his/her demise. The new nomination would supersede any earlier nominations made, and the same nominee(s) can be re-nominated, if desired. This would also provide the Board with the latest particulars of the nominee(s), and allow us to reach out to them more quickly to claim the monies.   Making a new nomination is easy and convenient. Find out how a member can make a CPF nomination .

Knowledge Article: Question: How is the withdrawable amount computed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The amount you can withdraw from your CPF account depends on the year you are born and the balances in your CPF account. For members born in 1958 or after:   Amount you can withdraw from 55   If the savings in your Special Account and Ordinary Account are: $5,000 or less, you can withdraw all your Special Account and Ordinary Account savings. Between $5,000 and your Full Retirement Sum, you can withdraw: $5,000; and Any Retirement Account savings* above your Basic Retirement Sum, if you pledge your property with a remaining lease that can last you to at least 95 years old. More than your Full Retirement Sum, you can withdraw: $5,000, or your SA and OA savings above your Full Retirement Sum, whichever is higher; and Any Retirement Account savings* above your Basic Retirement Sum, if you pledge your property with a remaining lease that can last you to at least 95 years old. *Excluding interest earned, any government grants received and top-ups made under the Retirement Sum Topping-Up Scheme.   See examples of how the withdrawable amount is computed .   Additional amount you can withdraw from 65   The additional withdrawable savings from 65 is computed based on 20% of your RA savings excluding any cash top-ups, CPF transfers and government grants, less the unconditional $5,000 you can withdraw from 55. This ensures that you do not deplete your retirement savings further, so that you will have a stream of monthly payouts for your living expenses in old age.   Example of a member born in 1958: Retirement Account balance at 65 1 : $107,400 (A) Cash top-ups/CPF transfers made under the Retirement Sum Topping-Up Scheme2: $20,000 (B) Government grants 2  (e.g., Deferment Bonus, matching grants under the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme): $600 (C) Unconditional $5,000 withdrawable from 55: $5,000 (D) Additional withdrawal amount from 65: [(A – B – C) x 20%] – D: $12,360 Notes:   1 If you are an existing CPF LIFE member who had joined the scheme before you turned 65, the balances used to compute your additional withdrawable savings from 65 will include your CPF LIFE premium balance.   2 Cash top-ups, CPF transfers and government grants are meant to be streamed out to you as monthly payouts in retirement.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have already joined CPF LIFE. How can I increase my monthly payouts?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have already joined CPF LIFE, you can consider the following options to increase your monthly payouts:   Using your withdrawable CPF savings to increase your CPF LIFE premium If you are born in 1958 or after, you can withdraw additional amount of up to 20% of your retirement savings from 65, which includes the first $5,000 that you can withdraw at any time from 55. If you are born in 1957, you can withdraw additional amount of up to 10% of your retirement savings from 65, as you can already withdraw up to 10% of your CPF savings from 55. You can use this withdrawable amount  to increase your CPF LIFE premium. If you would like to do so, please instruct us via the  Plan my monthly payouts service. Topping up and increase your CPF LIFE premium You or your loved ones can make cash top-ups and CPF transfers to your Retirement Account (RA) up to the current Enhanced Retirement Sum by logging in with your Singpass at cpf.gov.sg/rstuform . The more RA savings you use to join CPF LIFE, the higher your monthly payouts. Deferring your monthly payouts (up to 70) Consider deferring your payouts if you are still working or have other income. Your monthly payouts will increase by up to 7% for each year that you defer. Monetising your property If you own a property, you can also consider monetising your property .   If you wish to enquire on your revised payout, please write to us .

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the Ordinary Wage (OW) ceiling?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The  Ordinary Wage (OW) ceiling  limits the amount of OW that attract CPF contributions in a calendar month for all employees.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I still have to contribute to my MediSave if I am both a self-employed person as well as an employee working in another company?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you earn an annual net trade income of more than $6,000, you are required to contribute to your MediSave Account as a self-employed person (SEP).   CPF contribution is based on your total income. Therefore, an SEP who is also an employee at the same time, is required to contribute to MediSave as an SEP. This is the same for employees who hold more than one job and are required to pay CPF contributions for all the wages they receive.   However, you can apply to limit the MediSave payable on your self-employed income if your total employment income (excluding Additional Wages*) for the year exceeds the maximum total annual income. You may refer to this FAQ for more information on the conditions for this application.   *Additional Wages are wage supplements which are not granted wholly and exclusively for the month. Examples are the annual bonus, leave pay, incentive and other payments made at intervals of more than a month.   To limit your MediSave contributions, you may  write to us .

Knowledge Article: Question: What is baby bonus?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Baby Bonus Scheme supports parent's decision to have more children by helping to lighten the financial costs of raising children. It was introduced on 1 April 2001 and enhanced on 1 August 2004. The latest enhancements on 17 August 2008 extended increased benefits to the first and second child benefits to Singapore citizens beyond the fourth child. Please visit our website www.babybonus.msf.gov.sg for more details.

Knowledge Article: Question: How does CPF Board appreciate volunteers under the Community Paying it Forward movement?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Through our CPF Volunteering (CPFV) mobile app, volunteers can enjoy a gamified experience and gauge the impact of their sharing through fun elements to understand how this act of “Paying it Forward” has helped members in their retirement planning. Besides badges and titles upon completion of tasks and missions, they are also rewarded with in-app points, that can then be redeemed for digital accessories to customise their avatars. We are deeply appreciative of these extraordinary individuals who have stepped forward to help fellow CPF members be better prepared for their retirement. Apart from an annual appreciation event, we will also extend thank-you emails to those who have been exceptional in touching the lives of CPF members under this movement. To encourage our volunteers to do more in spreading kindness and spurring more Singaporeans to take actions to plan for their retirement, our volunteers are also entitled to CPFV seasonal event prizes and benefits from our corporate partners, such as Resorts World Sentosa, Shopee, ComfortDelGro Taxi, Ya Kun, Lazada, NTUC Income and MoneyOwl, an NTUC Social Enterprise. Additionally, we also aim to host regular learning workshops with our senior advisor and engagement sessions amongst the volunteers. Participants who opt to attend the learning workshops can enhance their knowledge regarding CPF’s schemes and policies. During the sessions, they may also ask and clarify any doubts they have. Volunteers may register for the engagement sessions to become familiar with a larger community of like-minded individuals.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will I be paid for my efforts as a CPF volunteer?
Knowledge Article: Answer: In the spirit of the C ommunity P aying it F orward movement, CPF volunteers are not paid when they do good by helping others within their social circles better understand CPF schemes and make informed decisions on the use of their CPF savings. Nevertheless, the CPF Board acknowledges the efforts of volunteers and show appreciation to them in many other ways, such as digital rewards, seasonal sponsored prizes and appreciation event.

Knowledge Article: Question: Where can I find out more about this CPF Volunteering initiative?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To learn more about the purpose of CPF Volunteering initiative, watch why and how our volunteers have been paying it forward.   Alternatively, you can also read our infographic for more information on C ommunity P aying it F orward.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the things I need to prepare to make an online nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To make an online nomination, you will need:   A valid Singpass Witnesses’ particulars: Full name* as per NRIC NRIC Email and/or Singapore registered mobile number (for receiving of SMS notification to perform witnessing) Nominee(s)’ particulars: NRIC/FIN (e.g. passport or foreign identification card number) Full name* as per NRIC/foreign identification document Mailing address** (for foreigners only) Email address (optional) * It is important to provide full names of your nominees and witnesses as indicated on their NRICs, including comma, hyphen and space accordingly. However, you should exclude the Hanyu Pinyin, Alias and married name. See examples of NRIC names .   ** Mailing address is required for foreigners to facilitate us in contacting them when distributing your CPF savings. Mailing address for Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents will be based on the address registered with Immigration & Checkpoints Authority (ICA).

Knowledge Article: Question: Will the nominee(s) be notified to claim the deceased member's CPF savings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We will contact the nominee(s) generally within 10 working days from the day we are notified of the member's passing, to provide them with details on the withdrawal process.   In some rare cases, there may be ongoing investigations related to a member’s nomination and the Board would require additional time. Interested parties can contact the Board at cpf.gov.sg/writetous to find out the status of the case.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I amend my online application under the CPF Education Loan Scheme after submission?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The application under the CPF Education Loan Scheme cannot be amended once it has been submitted. However, you may cancel the application and submit a new one.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I stop the use of CPF savings for my tuition fees and make a lump sum or full repayment for the education loan before I graduate?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF lender (whose CPF savings is used) will need to submit an online application to revoke the use of his/her CPF savings via " Forms and e-applications " using his/her Singpass, if he/she no longer wish to use his/her CPF savings to pay your tuition fees for future semesters.   After the revocation application is approved, please inform us of your intention to make a lump sum or full repayment through Write to us .

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I check the status of my application for a Home Protection Scheme cover?
Knowledge Article: Answer: This depends on how you submitted the Home Protection Scheme (HPS) application form.   CPF website (Form Ref: HPS/45) If you have recently submitted an online application for a Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover (Ref: HPS/45) via the CPF website, you can check the status of your application online using your Singpass.   For existing HDB flat owners:   Once your HPS application is approved, we will deduct the HPS premium from your CPF Ordinary Account (OA). You can view your HPS coverage status through the Home ownership dashboard , under the section "Protection against losing your home." You can expect to receive your HPS certificate generally within one to two weeks after successful premium deduction.   We will inform you if you are not eligible for HPS coverage. If your OA funds are insufficient, we will inform you and provide alternative options of making the premium payment.   For new HDB flat owners:   After your HPS application is approved, we will deduct the HPS premium from your CPF OA generally within two weeks from the date you officially become the legal owner of the flat. You can view your HPS coverage status through the Home ownership dashboard under the section "Protection against losing your home." Your HPS certificate will generally be sent to you within one to two weeks after successful premium deduction.   We will inform you if you are not eligible for HPS coverage. If your OA funds are insufficient, we will inform you and provide alternative options of making the premium payment.   HDB (Form Ref: HPS/9) If you have recently submitted an HPS application via HDB using Form HPS/9, we will process your HPS application generally within five working days. In some cases, if we need to further assess your eligibility for HPS coverage, it might take a little longer.   For existing HDB flat owners:   Once your HPS application is approved, we will deduct the HPS premium from your CPF Ordinary Account (OA). You can view your HPS coverage status through the Home ownership dashboard , under the section "Protection against losing your home." You can expect to receive your HPS certificate generally within one to two weeks after successful premium deduction.   We will inform you if you are not eligible for HPS coverage. If your OA funds are insufficient, we will inform you and provide alternative options of making the premium payment.   For new HDB flat owners:   After your HPS application is approved, we will deduct the HPS premium from your CPF OA, generally within two weeks from the date you officially become the legal owner of the flat. You can view your HPS coverage status through the Home ownership dashboard , under the section "Protection against losing your home." Your HPS certificate will generally be sent to you within one to two weeks after successful premium deduction.   We will inform you if you are not eligible for HPS coverage. If your OA funds are insufficient, we will inform you and provide alternative options of making the premium payment.   If you require clarification on the status of your application, please write to us .

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I apply to use Post-Secondary Education Account (PSEA) savings to repay my outstanding education loan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may submit an online request using your Singpass under the Loan Repayment Application via the Ministry of Education (MOE) website. Please note that your request will be submitted to MOE directly.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I apply to use CPF savings under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You are required to submit only ONE application form for each CPF lender  for your entire course of study at the approved educational institution. You do NOT need to re-apply or submit a new application every semester unless you have enrolled into another approved educational institution.   If you are a Singapore Citizen or Singapore Permanent Resident , you may apply for a CPF education loan online through " Forms and e-applications " using your Singpass. You must read the accompanying Terms & Conditions, and Procedures & Guidelines before you complete the online form.   The Board will notify the lender of the amount of CPF savings paid out to the educational institution. For subsequent semesters, the tuition fees will automatically be paid to the institution. This is subject to the amount available for withdrawal from the lender's Ordinary Account (OA) at the point of deduction. An administrative fee of $10.90 (inclusive of GST) will be charged for each deduction from the lender's OA.   Important Notes   Both the lender (whose CPF funds would be withdrawn) and you must each have your own Singpass and a valid email account. An email* with a link will be sent to the lender's email address provided in the application form the next day, if the application is in order. Otherwise, you will be informed that your application has been rejected. The lender* must log in through the provided link or the Endorse CPF education loan form in the CPF website,   using his/her own Singpass, within 14 days from the date the application was submitted, to agree to the use of his/her CPF savings. Otherwise, the online application will be automatically rejected. *This is not applicable if you are applying to use your own CPF savings for the tuition fees payment.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I have already made payment, can I amend or delete my submission?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are making payment via:   Direct Debit (i) Submission status shows “Submitted” You can login to CPF EZPay View / Amend / Delete Submission to amend or delete your submission. You can change CPF contribution amounts for employees, delete employee, or amend other payment amounts e.g. CPF Late Payment Interest. However, you will not be able to amend the Ordinary Wages, Additional Wages or Update Staff Information such as Date of Birth. If you wish to change them, please delete the current submission and create a new submission instead. Do remember to re-submit your CPF contributions after you have amended or deleted your submission. Any amended submission will remain in Draft mode and will not be sent for Direct Debit deduction until you complete the entire submission process again. All CPF submissions made on a day are processed at 5:15pm on the same day and the submission status will be updated as "Processed". You can no longer amend or delete the submission after it has been processed. (ii) Submission status shows “Processed” You can no longer amend or delete the submission as your submission has been processed. All CPF submissions made on a day are processed at 5:15pm on the same day and the submission status will be updated as "Processed". If you have underpaid CPF contributions, you may pay the difference using a Submit ad hoc CPF payments in CPF EZPay for the affected employee(s) in the affected month(s). You should key in the CPF shortfall amount you wish to pay but still declare the full wages earned for the month. If you have overpaid the CPF contributions or paid for the wrong employee(s), you may apply for a refund immediately and no later than one year from the date of payment, subject to the availability of funds in the member's CPF account.
