Direct Debit (Recommended) PayNow QR (supports personal or corporate bank account of participating banks) Find out more on these payment modes available to you. If your bank is not an  eGIRO or a PayNow participating bank, please write to us for assistance.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the changes to the CPF EZPay (FTP) Specifications from 26 September 2022?
Knowledge Article: Answer: From 26 September 2022, the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) will cease the collection of Foreign Worker Levy (FWL) and any FWL late payment interest through CPF EZPay. This is in line with MOM’s plans to consolidate levy payments under MOM. Find out more about levy payment methods . For employers making submissions via CPF EZPay (FTP), please take note of the changes to the FTP Specifications from 26 September 2022 and ensure compliance. After the cut-off date, FTP submissions containing payment for FWL and/or FWL late payment interest will be rejected.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am using a payroll software to compute CPF contributions, can I submit the file directly to CPF Board?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can upload the submission file for your CPF contributions directly via CPF EZPay (FTP) (PDF, 3.7MB) if your file complies with our file specifications. If you are unsure, please check with your payroll software vendor for more information.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am receiving my monthly payouts. Does the online Daily Withdrawal Limit affect my monthly payout amount?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, the online Daily Withdrawal Limit does not affect the monthly payout amount you are receiving. The online Daily Withdrawal Limit only applies to CPF lump sum withdrawals made under  withdrawals for immediate needs for members aged 55 and above .

Knowledge Article: Question: How much do I need to refund to my CPF account if the selling price is not enough to cover the outstanding housing loan and the required CPF housing refund?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If the selling price of your property is not enough to cover the outstanding housing loan and the required CPF housing refund, and the property is sold at market value, you will only need to refund the selling price less the outstanding housing loan to your CPF account. You do not need to top up the CPF housing refund shortfall in cash, as long as the property is sold at market value.   The refunded amount will be returned to your CPF account in proportion to the amount you used, which is calculated as the required CPF housing refund for an individual owner divided by the required CPF housing refund for all owners, multiplied by the selling price less the outstanding loan. For a property co-owned by two people, the owners will receive the housing refund in the following proportions:   Amount returned to owner A’s CPF Account: Amount returned to owner B's CPF Account:

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the interest rate for loans taken under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Interest on the outstanding CPF education loan is computed based on the prevailing Ordinary Account (OA) interest rate.   You can refer to the  CPF Interest Rates for more information.

Knowledge Article: Question: What other financing options do I have if I am not allowed to use CPF savings for unsubsidised courses under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are not allowed to use CPF savings for unsubsidised courses under the CPF Education Loan Scheme, you may wish to apply for a study loan with commercial banks, or approach your institution for financial assistance schemes that they can offer to you.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if there is a change in payer for my tuition fees under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If there is a permanent change in CPF lender (CPF member whose CPF savings is withdrawn), please perform the following steps:   1. You have to apply to use the new lender’s CPF Ordinary Account (OA) savings for your education by submitting a new application through " Forms and e-applications " using your Singpass. You may check the opening schedule of this application via  Application schedule to apply for CPF education loan .   2. The current lender has to apply to revoke the use of his/her CPF savings for your education through " Forms and e-applications "  using his/her Singpass.   Once we have successfully processed the application to use the new lender's CPF OA and revoked the current lender’s CPF OA usage, the next deduction of fees will come from the new lender's CPF OA. Otherwise, we will continue to deduct the tuition fees from the current lender's CPF OA. Please note that an administrative fee of $10.90 (inclusive of GST) will be charged for each deduction from the lender's CPF OA.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I receive my cash benefits via GovCash?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There are three options which you can choose to receive your cash benefit via GovCash:   Option 1: Use LifeSG to transfer to PayNow-NRIC linked bank account   If you have an existing bank account, you can link your account to PayNow-NRIC with your bank. Thereafter, login to LifeSG mobile app (LifeSG) using your Singpass to transfer your GovCash to your PayNow-NRIC linked bank account. The LifeSG app can be downloaded from the Apple App store or Google Play Store.   Option 2: Use LifeSG for Scan & Pay   You can use LifeSG to scan participating merchant’s QR code for purchases or scan your friend/family’s QR code to transfer your GovCash to them. You can only make purchases at merchants that accept PayNow/NETS QR code using the LifeSG app. You can look out for the PayNow/NETS logo on the SG QR label that is displayed by the merchants.   Option 3: Withdraw from OCBC ATMs   You can withdraw your cash benefit at OCBC ATMs islandwide. You just need to enter:   a) Your unique 8-digit Payment Reference Number (PRN) b) Your NRIC number; and c) pass the facial verification   You do not need to have an OCBC bank account to use this service.   You will receive the PRN via a letter and your Singpass app (if any) or SMS after your cash benefits has been paid. You can also log into the e-services with your Singpass to view your PRN by selecting “GovCash PRN” that is found at the menu on the left. This will only be available after the payment has been made.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long will it take for the withdrawal amount to be refunded to my CPF account if the PayNow transaction was unsuccessful?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The amount will be returned to your CPF account generally within two working days.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I am an undischarged bankrupt member, how do I sell my shares, property funds, bonds or Exchange Traded Funds (ETFs) that I have purchased under CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) before I became a bankrupt?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have a trading account with a stockbroking firm that has been frozen due to your bankruptcy, you will have to reactivate your trading account to sell your investments. If you no longer have a trading account, you will need to open a new trading account with a stockbroking firm (PDF, 0.1MB) before you can sell your investments.   However, it is at the stockbroking firm's discretion whether they will allow an undischarged bankrupt to reactivate/open a trading account. To assist the stockbroking firm to consider your request favourably, you may wish to provide them with your latest CPFIS Statement from your agent bank which lists the investment holdings that you intend to sell.   You do not need to seek the CPF Board or Official Assignee's approval to sell the shares held in your CPF Investment Account.

Knowledge Article: Question: What if I lose the endorsement email or did not receive the endorsement email for the use of my CPF savings under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF lender can log in to the CPF website using their own Singpass and endorse the application using the Endorse CPF education loan form.    A reminder email would be sent generally within the next three days if the lender has not endorsed the application.    Should you have any queries on the application process, you may reach us at cpf.gov.sg/writetous .   Note: The lender is also advised to ensure that their email settings are in place and the email address used by the borrower in the application is accurate.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the crediting sequence for my education loan repayments if I pay via PayNow?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are not under any GIRO arrangement or your GIRO application is still being processed, any payment made will be used to offset the outstanding education loan in the following order:   Current month instalment Arrears (if any) Partial/ Full lump sum repayment If you have an active GIRO arrangement, we will deduct the current month’s instalment from your bank account. If you would like to make additional payments towards the arrears, the cash payments will be used to pay the outstanding education loan in the following order:   Arrears (if any) Partial/ Full lump sum repayment As long as your GIRO is active, the Board will attempt to deduct the current month’s instalment from your bank account. If the deduction failed due to insufficient funds in your account, we will notify you of the missed payment. You may proceed to make the necessary payments via PayNow only after receiving our notification.

Knowledge Article: Question: I do not have enough CPF savings to buy my next property as I am waiting for the CPF refunds from sale of my property. What can I do?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can consider taking a bridging loan from any banks so long as HDB and/or the bank allows. It is important to note that the total amount of CPF savings withdrawn and the loan (including the bridging loan) cannot be more than the purchase price or valuation price of the property at the time of purchase, whichever is lower.   Once you sell your existing property, your CPF savings will be refunded to your CPF accounts. You can then use the funds to pay off the bridging loan after completing the legal documentation and settling any outstanding cash amount.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I did not apply to use my CPF savings when buying my HDB flat, can I apply to be exempted from the Home Protection Scheme and use my CPF savings for monthly housing instalments now?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Since this is the first time that you are using your CPF savings for your HDB flat, we will need you to provide further information and documents related to your housing loan, such as details of your financier and outstanding housing loan amount.   Please note that before applying for exemption, you need to apply for Home Protection Scheme first. This is to avoid any delay in commencing the use of your CPF Ordinary Account (OA) savings for your monthly housing instalments.   You will need to submit an application to use your CPF savings for monthly housing instalment and apply for an HPS cover. Thereafter, you may approach your insurer(s) of your private insurance policies to submit your application to be exempted from HPS.   If your HPS exemption application is successful, your existing HPS cover will be terminated. You will get a full premium refund into your (OA) provided that the exemption application is received (by the Board) within one month from the issuance of the HPS cover. Otherwise, a pro-rated refund will be credited to your OA upon the termination of your HPS cover.   Find out more: What can I do if I do not want to be insured under the Home Protection Scheme?

Knowledge Article: Question: What can I do if I do not want to be insured under the Home Protection Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are using CPF for your monthly housing instalments, you can apply to be exempted from the Home Protection Scheme (HPS) if your private insurance policy can adequately cover your outstanding housing loan up to the full term of loan or age 65, whichever is earlier, in the event of death, terminal illness or total permanent disability.   Here is what you need to do: Contact your private insurance provider to submit your application to be exempted from HPS. Submit supporting documents to your insurer that show details of your current* housing loan, such as the commencement date, balance loan amount, balance term of loan and mortgage rate. You can find this information on your housing loan statement. *Within six months of the submission date of your exemption application. We will only accept applications submitted by insurers. Once we receive the application and necessary documents, we will assess your eligibility for exemption from HPS and inform you of the outcome generally within five working days. If you are successful in the exemption application, your existing HPS cover will be terminated. You will receive a full premium refund credited to your CPF Ordinary Account (OA), provided that the exemption application is received by the Board within one month from the issuance of the HPS cover. Otherwise, a pro-rated refund will be credited to your OA upon the termination of your HPS cover.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am making payment via PayNow QR, what does the different payment status under View/ Amend/ Delete Submission screen in CPF EZPay mean?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If the PayNow payment status in CPF EZPay shows ‘ Paid ’, it means that the payment was successful. If the PayNow payment status shows ‘ Pending Payment ’, it means that payment has not been made. For personal bank accounts , the PayNow QR code to pay your CPF contributions must be scanned before 23:59 hrs on the day of submission. If your QR code has expired, you will not be able to make the payment, and you will need to resubmit your CPF contributions and get a new PayNow QR code. For corporate bank accounts , the Maker needs to scan the PayNow QR code before 23:59 hrs on the day of submission. Thereafter, the Checker needs to login to the banking app to approve the transaction as soon as possible. PayNow submissions with ‘Pending Payment’ status cannot be deleted. The system will auto-update the ‘Pending Payment’ status to ‘Not Paid’ after two months.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much should I refund to my CPF account if I have a Court order extracted before 1 January 2013 directing a sale / transfer / disposal of my property?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have a Court Order extracted before 1 January 2013, the amount to be refunded depends on your age at the time of sale, transfer or disposal of your property.   If you are below 55   You will need to refund the CPF principal amount withdrawn plus accrued interest upon sale, transfer or disposal.   If the selling price (including the option monies) after paying the outstanding housing loan is not enough to fully refund the CPF principal amount withdrawn together with the accrued interest, you do not need to top up the shortfall in cash, provided the property is sold at market value. However, any option monies (e.g. option fee and option exercise fee) received from your buyer in cash upon the sale of your property are considered part of selling price and need to be refunded to your co-owner's and your CPF accounts before the transaction can be completed.   If you are 55 and above   Please check with us on the amount to be refunded upon sale, transfer or disposal.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am a Singapore Citizen working in India. Do I need to contribute to the India's Employees' Provident Fund (EPF)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Singapore Government is aware that Singapore Citizens working in India have been required to contribute to India's Employees' Provident Fund (EPF) and has been negotiating with India's Employees' Provident Fund Organisation (EPFO) to exempt Singapore Citizens from this requirement. As of 1 January 2016, Singapore Citizens working in India will no longer have to contribute to the EPF. If you have previously contributed to the EPF, you will be able to withdraw your past contributions, but only after your employment contract in India ends. Please visit Ministry of Trade and Industry website for more information. The relevant forms should be sent to the Certifying Authority (MFA, MTI) for certification. Members can approach MFA or MTI for assistance. For more information on the India-Singapore Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement or contributions to India's Employment Provident Fund by Singapore Citizens, please contact MTI at MTI_email@mti.gov.sg .

Knowledge Article: Question: I do not want my Special Account savings to be transferred to either the Retirement Account or the Ordinary Account. Can I withdraw it?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Savings from the Special Account (SA) that are transferred to your Retirement Account (RA) are not withdrawable as they are meant to provide you with payouts in retirement. Once you have set aside your Full Retirement Sum in RA, you may withdraw the remaining SA savings that are transferred to the Ordinary Account (OA).   You may also continue to withdraw your RA savings above the Basic Retirement Sum (BRS) if you own an eligible property with remaining lease that lasts you until you are 95 or older.

Knowledge Article: Question: Once I set aside my Full Retirement Sum, my Special Account savings will be transferred to the Ordinary Account which pays lower interest. What can I do to continue earning the interest rate that the Special Account pays?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you wish to earn higher interest and receive higher retirement payouts, you may transfer your Special Account (SA) savings that were channelled to the Ordinary Account (OA) due to the closure of SA, to the Retirement Account (RA), up to the prevailing Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS). The RA interest rate is the same as the SA.   From 1 January 2025, the ERS will be raised to four times of the Basic Retirement Sum to allow members to save more in the RA and receive higher payouts , if they want.   With the change, the ERS in 2025 would be $426,000 1 , up from $308,700 in 2024. Hence, if you are aged 55 and above in 2025, you can save up to $426,000 in the RA.   The raised ERS would allow more than 99% of members aged 55 and above today to transfer all their SA savings to the RA.   Please note that CPF transfers are irreversible and the savings are set aside to boost your monthly payouts in retirement. Thus, the amount transferred cannot be withdrawn for any other purpose such as housing, investment, or immediate needs after age 55. Read more on how the top-ups will be used .   You can also invest the OA savings in low-risk investments, such as T-bills and fixed deposits, under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS).   1 This is the limit for the savings set aside in the RA (excluding amounts such as interest earned, government grants received, plus retirement withdrawals).

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the service standards for processing applications relating to CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please refer to the table for our service standards for processing applications relating to the CPF Education Loan Scheme.   Service Normal Processing Time Apply for CPF Education Loan 3 working days upon receipt of application and enrolment confirmation from educational institution Manage education loan repayments - Change monthly instalment Within 3 working days Manage education loan repayments - Make repayment Within 3 working days Revoke the use of CPF savings for education Within 5 working days Manage education loan repayments - Waive loan(s) Within 15 working days Manage education loan repayments - Defer repayment  Within 3 working days

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the service standards for processing applications relating to CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please refer to the table for our service standards for processing applications relating to the CPF Education Loan Scheme.   Service Normal Processing Time Apply for CPF Education Loan 3 working days upon receipt of application and enrolment confirmation from educational institution Manage education loan repayments - Change monthly instalment Within 3 working days Manage education loan repayments - Make repayment Within 3 working days Revoke the use of CPF savings for education Within 5 working days Manage education loan repayments - Waive loan(s) Within 15 working days Manage education loan repayments - Defer repayment  Within 3 working days

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I start my monthly payouts if I am not on CPF LIFE?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To start payout: Login to my cpf Online Services with your Singpass Click on Forms and e-applications > Retirement Income > Monthly payouts > "Plan my monthly payouts "

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I terminate my Direct Debit arrangement for payment of CPF contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you no longer wish to pay your CPF contributions by Direct Debit, please submit your request to  terminate your direct debit arrangement .   After the CPF Board has processed the request, we will inform you accordingly. Please also notify your bank on the termination so that they can update their records.

Knowledge Article: Question: What browser settings are required for me to use CPF EZPay?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your browser’s default settings should be sufficient to allow you to use CPF EZPay. If you are unable to access CPF EZPay, please check that you have the following features enabled: Cookies Java Script TLS (Transport Layer Security) Versions 1.0, 1.1 or 1.2

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the supported web browsers for CPF EZPay?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF EZPay is best viewed using the following browsers :   Apple Safari 16.6 and above G oogle Chrome 123 and above Micro soft Edge 122 and above Mo zilla Firefox 123 and above

Knowledge Article: Question: Is it safe to submit my employee details through the internet using CPF EZPay?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The information you submit is encrypted using 2048-bits SSL, which is a common standard used by major online merchants, financial institutions, and brokerages worldwide to transmit secured documents via the Internet.   Only designated staff assigned by you will be able to log in to use CPF EZPay. After each successful submission, an acknowledgement email will be sent to your designated email address. You can also log in to enquire about the submission status and view the Record of Payment online. Therefore, it is safe to submit your employees’ details using CPF EZPay.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I inform CPF Board when I am issued with a new Unique Entity Number (UEN)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are issued with a new Unique Entity Number (UEN), you will need to apply for a new CPF Submission Number (CSN) under the new entity to make your CPF contributions.   You are also required to inform us via Write to us if you no longer have any employees in your service under the old UEN.   After you are issued with the new CSN, you are required to set up your Direct Debit arrangement .

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I include new co-owners for my Housing & Development Board (HDB) flat and how do they apply to be insured under the Home Protection Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You would first need to contact or visit the Housing Development Board (HDB) Branch Office managing your flat to include your new co-owners.   After your new co-owners have obtained legal ownership of the flat, they may apply for a Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover. The process to apply for an HPS cover differs, depending on the type of loan that they are taking. For Housing & Development Board (HDB) Loan Your co-owners may apply for an HPS cover when applying to withdraw their CPF savings for the monthly housing instalments via HDB. For Bank Loan Your co-owners may apply for an HPS cover online  using their Singpass. This can be done at the same time when they are applying to withdraw their CPF savings for the monthly housing instalments.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the minimum monthly instalment rate under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The minimum monthly instalment rate under the CPF Education Loan Scheme is $100. The instalment rate stated in the repayment notification will be $100 if this rate is expected to enable you to fully repay the loan within six years. You are encouraged to fully repay the loan within six years to reduce the interest incurred for the loan. If you have a bigger outstanding loan amount, a higher monthly instalment rate will be stated, to enable you to repay within a period of six years.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is this volunteer and partner engagement about?
Knowledge Article: Answer: In line with the  Singapore Together movement to encourage Singaporeans to partner the government in building a shared future, we are involving individuals like you, to share CPF information with members to support their retirement planning. Through a C ommunity P aying it F orward movement, you can do good by helping others within your social circles to improve their understanding of CPF schemes and make informed decisions on the use of their CPF savings. Training will be provided to facilitate accurate sharing of CPF information.   If you are interested in joining this initiative, you can download our CPF Volunteering (CPFV) mobile app and register with us by tapping on “Sign up now”. It is available on both  App Store and  Google Play (search for keyword: CPFV).   You can also scan the QR code to download the app and register with us.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens if there are not enough savings in my Ordinary Account for payment of tuition fees?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will be informed in writing if there are not enough savings in your Ordinary Account for the payment of the tuition fees. You will need to make alternative arrangement to pay the tuition fees in cash, or consider other financing options such as the MOE Tuition Fee Loan (TFL) or use of the student's Post-Secondary Education Account (PSEA) savings.   The MOE TFL is available to all full-time students of the polytechnics and universities and covers up to 75% and 90% of the tuition fees payable respectively. It is also interest-free during the course of study, unlike the CPF loan where interest starts to accrue from the time of withdrawal.   If you are unable to repay your MOE TFL due to further studies or financial difficulties due to unemployment or medical condition, you may appeal to defer repayment and interest. Your appeal will be considered on a case-by-case basis. While CPF may also allow for deferment in challenging times, the interest continues to accrue as it is essential to completely restore the savings meant primarily for retirement. For more information on the MOE TFL, please refer to this link .

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is there a need to annuitise the non-withdrawable Ordinary and Special Account savings as CPF LIFE monthly payout?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have not met your Full Retirement Sum, your Ordinary and Special Account (OSA) savings may not be withdrawn as a lump sum and are meant to be streamed out as monthly payouts.   Currently, if you are an existing CPF LIFE member, you need to instruct us to annuitise your OSA savings to receive higher CPF LIFE monthly payouts.   With the changes from October 2023, we will automate this process and make it easier for you to enjoy higher CPF LIFE monthly payouts.

Knowledge Article: Question: What can I withdraw from my CPF after the closure of my Special Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: After the closure of your Special Account (SA) , you can continue to withdraw any amount from your Ordinary Account, after setting aside your Full Retirement Sum in your Retirement Account (RA). You can also continue to apply to withdraw your RA savings down to your Basic Retirement Sum if you own a property in Singapore with remaining lease that lasts you until you are 95 or older. Find out more information on the withdrawal of CPF savings for property owners .

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the conditions that I have to meet before I can apply to waive the education loan repayment?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may apply to waive the repayment of the education loan with your Singpass, if you have met the following conditions:   1. You are aged 55 and above;  and 2. You have set aside the  Full Retirement Sum (FRS) in the Retirement Account. The FRS can be set aside fully with cash, or with cash (i.e. at least the Basic Retirement Sum) and property. You can approach us to check whether you are able to waive the repayment if you are withdrawing some of your CPF savings under the Reduced Life Expectancy Scheme.   Please refer to this FAQ for more information on how the Retirement Sum is set aside at age 55.   If you have used your CPF savings for your own education and have met the waiver conditions, the Board will waive the repayment when you apply for withdrawal of your CPF savings. If you do not wish to withdraw your CPF savings but wish to waive the repayment of your CPF savings for your own education, you can apply to do so if you meet the waiver conditions.   If you have used your CPF savings for your child / spouse / sibling / relative's education , you will need to meet the waiver conditions to apply to waive the repayment.   You should only apply to waive repayment if you have no intention of continuing the use of your CPF savings for the student’s current course of study. Hence, if the student is still in midst of study, you have to first revoke the use of CPF savings for future payments for the student's current course before applying to waive repayment. Alternatively, you may submit your application to waive repayment after the student has completed his/her studies.   Please note that the waiver will include the total CPF savings withdrawn and the interest that would have otherwise been earned had the savings not been withdrawn under the scheme. It does not include the amount that has already been repaid by the student and the amount used for the student's current course of study (if applicable). The waiver application once approved, is irrevocable.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am reaching age 65. How do I start my monthly payouts?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We will send you a notification three months before your 65 th birthday, to guide you to explore your monthly payouts options and submit your instructions through the Plan my monthly payouts service.   If you do not submit any instructions on your payouts by 70, your monthly payouts will automatically start in the month of your 70 th birthday.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am reaching age 65. How do I start my monthly payouts?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We will send you a notification three months before your 65 th birthday, to guide you to explore your monthly payouts options and submit your instructions through the Plan my monthly payouts service.   If you do not submit any instructions on your payouts by 70, your monthly payouts will automatically start in the month of your 70 th birthday.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I register or apply to use Provident and Tax (PAT)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To register or apply to use PAT:   Register at Provident and Tax website with CrimsonLogic. Apply for Direct Debit  online with us. Once your application has been successfully processed, we will notify you on when you can start making submissions on PAT.   If you are already a PAT user but have a new Subsidiary, please follow these steps:   Apply for a CPF Submission Number online . Apply for Direct Debit  online . After completing these steps, you will be able to use the PAT services for your new Subsidiary. For more information on the PAT services, you can visit CrimsonLogic’s PAT website .

Knowledge Article: Question: Why are some funds reserved in my CPF Ordinary Account for the Dependants' Protection Scheme premium?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To ensure that working CPF members are financially protected by the Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS), the necessary amount will be reserved in your CPF Ordinary Account (OA) during the premium payment grace period. This means that you will not be able to use or withdraw up to that amount of OA savings during this period.   If you prefer to pay your premiums in cash, contact the DPS insurer ( Great Eastern Life ) to top up the full premium in cash. The reserved amount in your CPF OA will be released after your cash payment is processed.   In the event that you need to use the reserved amount for other purposes, please  write to us  for assistance. However, please note that your DPS cover could lapse if no payment is made within the grace period stipulated by the DPS insurer.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why do I need to own a property before I can withdraw part of my Retirement Account savings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you do not own a property*, it's important to consider rental costs when planning for your retirement. This means you may need to set aside more savings for higher monthly payouts to cover these living expenses.   On the other hand, if you own a property*, you need not worry about rental costs in retirement. In addition, you would also have the option to generate extra retirement income by monetising your property. This is why members who own property* can choose to set aside their Full Retirement Sum (FRS) with a mixture of property (up to half the FRS) and cash and withdraw part of their Retirement Account savings down to their Basic Retirement Sum^ if they have other immediate retirement cash needs.   *The property must be in Singapore and lasts you until at least age 95.   ^ Excluding interest, any government grants and top-ups made under the Retirement Sum Topping-Up Scheme.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I apply for Housing & Development Board (HDB)'s financial assistance measures?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Housing & Development Board (HDB) has several measures to help HDB mortgagors who are in financial difficulty to service their monthly housing payments. These include rescheduling of loan, reducing or deferring payments, and paying arrears by instalments. Mortgagors who have difficulty servicing their mortgage payments can call the toll-free HDB Branch Office Service Line at 1800-225-5432 for advice on the financial assistance measures that best suit their needs. They can also approach their HDB Branch Office managing their flats for assistance.

Knowledge Article: Question: I did not use CPF savings for the matrimonial property but pledged the property to make up my retirement sum. Can the Court order a transfer of this property to my ex-spouse?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, the Court can still order the transfer of the property to your ex-spouse upon the refund of your pledged amount to your CPF account. The Court may also order for the transfer with a partial refund or without a refund. However, upon subsequent disposal of the property by your ex-spouse, they will have to refund the pledged amount to their CPF account (if it was not earlier refunded to your CPF account).

Knowledge Article: Question: What are your obligations after the court order is granted, before and following the transfer or payment of CPF savings to your ex-spouse in a divorce?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You are obliged to comply with the court order and shall not withdraw or transfer or attempt to withdraw or transfer any amount that your ex-spouse is entitled to under the court order.   In the event of a transfer or payment of CPF savings upon the making of housing refunds pursuant to a disposal of the property, loans or grants taken by you which are repayable or refundable to the Government must be repaid or refunded first before the transfer or payment of CPF savings can take place. Grants include housing grants from Housing and Development Board (HDB) and Home Ownership Plus Education (HOPE) grant from the Ministry of Social and Family Development. Keep in mind that transferring or paying CPF savings to your ex-spouse might impact your participation in CPF schemes. If necessary, consider making alternative financial arrangements.

Knowledge Article: Question: Is my ex-spouse entitled to have a share of my CPF savings upon our divorce?
Knowledge Article: Answer: While CPF savings may be considered as matrimonial assets and a share may be given to your ex-spouse, there is nothing in the laws that give your ex-spouse an automatic entitlement. It is up to the Court to decide whether your ex-spouse is entitled to any part of your CPF savings, taking into account the matters set out in section 112 of the Women's Charter / section 52(3)(d) of the Administration of Muslim Law Act. For more information, please visit the  Family Justice Courts’ website or Syariah Court’s website .

Knowledge Article: Question: If I have not fully withdrawn the $5,000 that I could withdraw unconditionally when I reached age 55, what will happen when my Special Account is closed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: At the point your Special Account (SA) is closed , any savings in your SA that form part of your $5,000 unconditional withdrawal amount will be transferred to your Ordinary Account, which you can continue to withdraw anytime.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will the closure of my Special Account affect how much I can withdraw from my CPF?
Knowledge Article: Answer: When your Special Account (SA) is closed, the amount that you could have withdrawn from your SA will be transferred to your Ordinary Account and remains withdrawable. Find out more information on what you can withdraw from your CPF after the closure of your SA .

Knowledge Article: Question: If I own a property, can I still withdraw the Special Account (SA) savings that have been transferred to my Retirement Account when my SA is closed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: After your Special Account is closed , you can continue to withdraw your Retirement Account savings above the Basic Retirement Sum (BRS) if you own an eligible property. Find out more information on the withdrawal of CPF savings for property owners .

Knowledge Article: Question: What will happen to my sales proceeds after the sale of my property?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The distribution of sale proceeds depends on the type of your property and loan taken.   Private properties bought on or after 1 September 2002 or refinanced on or after 1 September 2002 and HDB flats   Generally, the selling price will be used to pay for the following in this order:   Outstanding housing loan Required CPF refund  Other sale expenses, e.g., legal fees If the selling price (including the option monies) after paying the outstanding housing loan is not enough to make the required CPF refund, you do not need to top up the shortfall in cash, provided the property is sold at market value. However, the option monies (e.g. option fee and option exercise fee) received from your buyer in cash upon the sale of your property are considered part of the selling price and need to be refunded to your co-owner’s and your CPF accounts before the transaction can be completed.   The refunded amount will be returned to your co-owner's and your CPF accounts in the following proportions:   Amount returned to owner A's CPF Account:   Amount returned to owner B's CPF Account:   Private properties bought before 1 September 2002 and not refinanced after 1 September 2002   The selling price will be used to pay for the following in this order:   1. CPF principal amount withdrawn up to 80% of the lower of the purchase price or valuation price of the property at the time of purchase plus the CPF savings used for the legal and stamp fees 2. On equal ranking: CPF principal amount withdrawn for the remaining 20% of the lower of the purchase price or valuation price of the property at the time of purchase. Bank's outstanding housing loan and interest 3. CPF principal amount withdrawn beyond the lower of the purchase price or valuation price of the property at the time of purchase and the accrued interest   If the sale proceeds (including the option monies) are not enough to make up the required CPF refund and the outstanding housing loan, the sale proceeds will be used to settle the required CPF refund and the outstanding housing loan in the order agreed by you, your bank and the Board. Any option monies (e.g. option fee and option exercise fee) received from your buyer in cash upon the sale of your property are considered part of the selling price and need to be refunded to your co-owner's and your CPF accounts before the transaction can be completed.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the Retirement Account for?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The savings in your Retirement Account (RA) is meant to provide you with payouts in retirement. You can start your payouts anytime from your payout eligibility age of 65.   Find out  how your RA is created when you turn 55 .

Knowledge Article: Question: If I reserve an amount in my Ordinary Account to pay for my house, will it affect the amount that I can withdraw?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, the amount that you can withdraw from your CPF savings will be affected if you have reserved an amount in your Ordinary Account to pay for your house. This is because the savings reserved for your housing payments cannot be withdrawn in cash.   It is also important to note that the amount reserved for housing will not be transferred to your Retirement Account to make up your retirement sum. This may affect your monthly payouts when you reach your payout eligibility age. Therefore, it is important to plan your finances carefully and consider the impact of reserving funds for housing on your future retirement plans.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I have outstanding housing arrears payments, how do I apply to use my CPF savings to pay for it?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The application process to use your CPF savings for outstanding arrears payment depends on the type of loan you have taken.   For HDB loan   There are two ways to pay your outstanding arrears payment. Submit an online application under Payment of Outstanding instalment by CPF for Housing Loan/ Upgrading Cost at  HDB’s website with your Singpass. Your application will be processed within three working days upon the receipt of your request from HDB. Complete the CPF withdrawal form (PHS9) at HDB Branch. Please note that services at HDB office and Branches are by appointment only. If you wish to visit a HDB Branch, you can book an appointment via the e-Appointment system . Your application will be processed within three to five working days upon the receipt of your request from HDB. For Bank loan   You can pay your outstanding arrears by submitting an  online application with your Singpass.   Your application will be processed within three working days.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I stop my housing monthly deduction for my housing loan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Stopping your monthly housing deduction for your housing loan depends on the type of loan you have taken.   For HDB loan   There are two ways for you to stop your housing monthly deduction.   1. Submit an online application under Commence the use of CPF/Vary CPF deductions for HDB housing loan instalment at  HDB’s website  with your Singpass. Your application will be processed generally within three working days upon the receipt of your request from HDB. 2. Complete the CPF withdrawal form (PHS9) at HDB Branch. Please note that services at HDB office and Branches are by appointment only. If you wish to visit a HDB Branch, you can book an appointment via the  e-Appointment system . Your application will be processed within three to five working days upon the receipt of your request from HDB. For bank loan   You can stop your housing monthly deduction for your housing loan by submitting an  online application with your Singpass.   Your application will be processed generally within three working days.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am currently using my CPF savings to service my housing loan. Can I continue to use my withdrawable CPF savings for housing payments?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you can use your Ordinary Account savings, including any withdrawable amounts, to pay for your housing loan.   You can view your Home ownership dashboard to check the savings you can use for your housing payments under the "Amount allowed for this property" section. This will give you a clear idea of how much more you can use before reaching the usage limits.   While you use your CPF savings for housing, it is also important to consider the impact on your retirement savings and ensure that you have enough for your retirement needs.

Knowledge Article: Question: How does CPF Board compute the CPF usage limits for properties which do not cover the buyers to the age of 95?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The maximum amount of CPF savings that can be used is pro-rated depending on the remaining lease of the property that can cover the youngest buyer to the age of 95. This will help buyers set aside sufficient CPF savings for their housing needs during retirement (e.g. a replacement property).    Make an informed decision on your property purchase by using the  CPF housing usage calculator . This useful tool lets you compute the allowable CPF usage you can use for your next property purchase.

Knowledge Article: Question: If my foreign employees request to contribute to CPF, can I make CPF contributions for them?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF is a comprehensive social security system that is intended to support Singapore Citizens and Singapore Permanent Residents (SPRs). From 1 January 2003, CPF contributions are exempted for foreign employees as they may not retire here in Singapore. Therefore, CPF contributions are only payable for Singapore Citizens and SPRs. For foreigners who wish to save voluntarily for their own retirement, they may instead consider Supplementary Retirement Scheme (SRS ).

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the Memorandum of Mortgage?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Memorandum of Mortgage (PDF, 77KB) sets out the priority arrangement between the Board and the bank in respect of the refund of proceeds arising from a disposal of the property where the mortgagee bank has the first charge. The Memorandum of Mortgage has been registered with Singapore Land Authority (SLA) under the registration number: IA/991901M.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the benefits in keeping the savings in my CPF accounts?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you do not need the funds, keeping your savings in your CPF accounts lets you earn risk-free interest rates* of up to 6% per annum , allowing your savings to grow with compound interest.   You can also use your CPF savings to increase your monthly payouts in retirement . Check out the options to increase your monthly payouts using your withdrawable savings under the “Withdraw for immediate retirement needs” section in your Retirement dashboard .   *Based on the current 4% interest rate floor on Special and Retirement Account monies.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I look out for if I am buying a property?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are buying a property, here are the four rules-of-thumb to keep in mind.     Read on to learn how these rules can impact your finances. The following is a case study that compares the buying decisions of John and Jane and how a property purchase can affect their financial health.     Additionally, here are some other things that you should also look out for.   Your eligibility to buy a property   For HDB flat, check your eligibility criteria at HDB website .   For private property, check your eligibility criteria at  URA website .   Your CPF Ordinary Account (OA) balance   It is important to find out how much OA savings you have to finance your purchase. Your existing OA balance and your future monthly CPF contributions to your OA will help you decide an affordable home price. You can use our First home calculator to estimate a housing loan and property price based on your income and your ability to service the loan.   You can check your CPF OA balance on  Member dashboard  by logging in at our CPF website using your Singpass. Otherwise, you may visit any of the CPF Service Centre.   Your finances   Work out the amount of cash savings you have and the amount of housing loan you can get.   Encumbrances on the property that you are buying   For HDB flat, check with HDB or the seller if you are buying a resale flat from the open market that they will be refunding their CPF principal amount withdrawn and accrued interest used towards the flat so that the CPF charge can be lifted.   For private property, check with your lawyer to make sure your property is free of any charges (i.e., CPF charge, mortgage charge) upon completion.   Apply to use your OA savings   Apply  through HDB if you are taking an HDB loan or your lawyer if you are taking a bank loan.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme this year. Will I still be eligible if there are changes to my circumstance during the year?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you will still be eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme for the year even if your circumstances change (e.g. increase in monthly income) during the year. However, do note that renouncing your Singapore citizenship during the year will make you ineligible for the scheme and matching grant. Find out about the conditions which you need to meet to receive and keep the matching grant.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if I need to withdraw more than the online Daily Withdrawal Limit of $2,000?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Withdrawal of more than $2,000 can be done by first adjusting the online Daily Withdrawal Limit to your desired amount, then wait for 12 hours for the higher limit to take effect. Find out more about this  12-hour cooling period .

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I apply to be insured under the Home Protection Scheme after I obtained Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Residency again?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may re-apply for a Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover online , using your Singpass, if your previous HPS cover has ceased and you are the owner of an HDB flat with an outstanding housing loan. Your eligibility for HPS coverage is subject to approval and your current health condition.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why should my share of Home Protection Scheme cover minimally match my share of responsibility to service the housing loan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Home Protection Scheme (HPS) claims are paid based on the insured sum of the insured. If you are covered for less than your share of responsibility in servicing the housing loan and a claim event happens, the HPS payout will not be enough to cover your share of the outstanding housing loan, and your co-owner might not have the financial means to continue to service the remaining housing loan.   Example If you are 100% responsible for servicing the loan and you are only covered for 50% HPS share of cover, in the event of a claim, we will pay only 50% of your outstanding housing loan up to the insured sum. Your co-owner will need to continue servicing the remaining housing loan.   To avoid this situation, both you and your co-owner may each choose to be covered for 100% HPS share of cover of the outstanding housing loan. In the event of a claim, we will settle 100% of your outstanding housing loan up to the insured sum, terminate your co-owner’s HPS cover which is no longer necessary, and refund any unused premium to his/her Ordinary Account.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am a bankrupt and I remember I owe more MediShield Life premiums than what is shown in my notification and my Healthcare dashboard. How much should I pay?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We may have filed a claim with the Private Trustee or Official Assignee to recover your outstanding MediShield Life premiums (including interest and penalties) incurred prior to the date of your Bankruptcy Order. The amount filed will not be shown in your notifications as the amount may be recovered from your bankruptcy estate.   The notifications you receive are for the MediShield Life premiums incurred after the date of your Bankruptcy Order. You can apply for a Apply / Change GIRO for Payment of MediShield Life Premiums  or seek a family member's help to perform Change of Payer for MediShield Life Cover  to pay your outstanding premiums.   To make a voluntary top-up to your MediSave Account, you must obtain approval from the Private Trustee or Official Assignee. You can contact them at 1800 225 5529 (during office hours) or visit www.mlaw.gov.sg .

Knowledge Article: Question: Is it necessary to input the referrer's details in the CPF online services?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We strongly encourage you to provide the  referrer's details if someone has introduced you to our CPF schemes or services. This will allow us to express our gratitude to the person who has made a positive impact on you and our volunteering movement.   If your referrer has not registered with us as a volunteer, they can sign up by downloading our CPF Volunteering (CPFV) mobile app from the App Store or Google Play (search for keyword: CPFV) and tap on “Sign up now”. They can also scan the QR code to download the app and register with us.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will the deceased member's CPF savings be distributed to a nominee who is certified to lack mental capacity permanently?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The deceased member’s CPF savings would be paid to a Donee or Deputy appointed to act on the nominee's behalf under the Mental Capacity Act.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am an undischarged bankrupt. Can I still choose to withdraw my Retirement Account savings using my property?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Whether you can withdraw your Retirement Account (RA) savings using your property depends on whether you own an HDB or private property.   For HDB property owners   You can choose to set aside your Full Retirement Sum (FRS) with a mixture of property (up to half your FRS) and cash, and withdraw part of your RA savings down to your Basic Retirement Sum (BRS*) if your HDB property can last you until 95.   For private property owners   You can choose to set aside your FRS with a mixture of property (up to half your FRS) and cash, and withdraw part of your RA savings down to your BRS* if your private property can last you until 95 and the expected housing refund  is enough to restore your Full Retirement Sum (FRS).   However, if you have not used your CPF savings for your property, or the expected housing refund is not enough to restore your FRS, you will not be able to withdraw your RA savings. This is because no additional charge can be created on your property. If you need more information, you can approach the Official Assignee.   It is important to note that the amount of RA savings you can withdraw excludes interest earned, any government grants received and top-ups to your retirement savings . It also depends on your RA balance at the point of withdrawal. For example, if you are on CPF LIFE and have started your monthly payouts, any new inflows received in your RA will be used to increase your CPF LIFE premium to provide you with higher monthly payouts, and you will not be allowed to withdraw them in a lump sum.   * Excluding interest, any government grants and top-ups made under the Retirement Sum Topping-Up Scheme.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the purpose of providing referrer's details in the CPF Online services?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The C ommunity P aying it F orward movement was launched in April 2021 to encourage individuals to share useful CPF information with others. This will help members better understand CPF and make informed decisions on the use of their CPF savings.   To thank volunteers who have made a positive impact, we have introduced a “Referrer Name” field in selected CPF online services. If someone has shared a CPF scheme or service with you, please provide the referrer’s details, which can include the referrer’s name, email address, or mobile number registered under the CPFV mobile app. By doing so, we can extend our appreciation to these individuals and assess the effectiveness of this initiative.   It is important to note that inputting referrer's details will not affect your application nor request   *List of selected online services that contain the referrer's details section: Cash top ups and CPF transfer Voluntary housing refund CPF nomination Plan my monthly payouts Application for CPF LIFE Start monthly payouts

Knowledge Article: Question: When will the deceased member's CPF savings be paid to me?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The service standards for processing of a deceased member’s CPF savings are shown in the table below:   Deceased member’s nomination status Service Normal processing time With nomination Distribution of deceased member's CPF savings to nominee(s) 17 working days* Without nomination Transfer of CPF savings by the Board to the Public Trustee 17 working days** * Generally, an additional seven working days is required if the deceased member had held discounted Singtel shares. Processing time also excludes two working days required for transmission of funds. ** From the date the Board is notified of member’s death.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have applied to withdraw the deceased member's CPF savings. Can I change my payment details?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can change your payment details for your application to withdraw the deceased member’s CPF savings by submitting the form applicable to you:   If you are a Singapore citizen or Permanent Resident, please update your bank account details with CPF Board via my cpf digital services - Account settings with your Singpass.   If you are not a Singapore citizen or Permanent Resident,  please complete the form  “Change payment details (for withdrawal of deceased member’s CPF savings or account closure)” (Form NAC/SUPP/F) and mail it back to us.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I apply to adjust my CPF Contributions from the firm's account to a self-employed person's account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may submit an online application via  my cpf  digital services using Singpass to adjust your CPF Contributions from the firm’s account to your self-employed account.   The adjustment request must be made within one year from the date of payment.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will I be notified when my CPF savings have been paid to me via PayNow?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes. With PayNow, you will be notified when your CPF savings have been paid to you.   If you have registered an email address under “My Notifications”, you will receive an email when the status of your online application is updated.   If you do not have a registered email with us , but have a mobile number in our record, you will receive an SMS notification.   You can also check the status of your application under " Activities ".   In addition, if you have opted to receive SMS alerts with your bank, you will receive an SMS notification on your mobile number registered with your bank when the payment is made to your PayNow registered NRIC-linked bank account.

Knowledge Article: Question: Does the online Daily Withdrawal Limit affect the total amount that I can withdraw from my CPF account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, the online Daily Withdrawal Limit does not affect your total withdrawable amount. There is no change to the withdrawal rules under  withdrawals for immediate needs for members aged 55 and above .

Knowledge Article: Question: My co-owner and I each applied for 50% Home Protection Scheme (HPS) coverage. What should I do if my co-owner's HPS cover is rejected due to health reasons?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your co-owner's Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover is rejected due to health reasons, you are encouraged to increase your HPS share of cover to 100% of the outstanding housing loan. This will ensure that the total outstanding loan is fully covered by HPS. However, please note that any increase in HPS cover is subject to approval and you being in good health. It is important to ensure that your home loan is adequately covered by HPS.

Knowledge Article: Question: What share of the Home Protection Scheme cover should I apply for?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The share of Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover of the outstanding housing loan i.e. the HPS insured sum that you need to obtain depends on your share of responsibility to service the monthly housing instalments.   Paying the monthly housing instalments solely You should be insured under HPS for 100% of the housing loan.   Paying the monthly housing instalments with other co-owners Your share of HPS cover of the outstanding housing loan should at least match the proportion of the monthly housing instalment which is payable with your CPF savings and/or cash. The total share of cover of the outstanding housing loan in your household must add up to at least 100%. However, you and your co-owner(s) can also individually choose to insure a higher share of cover of the outstanding housing loan, up to 100% each. HPS pays benefits based on the share of the cover of the insured in the event of a claim.   It is important to note that a higher share of cover (i.e. higher HPS insured sum) will result in a higher annual premium that will be deducted from your CPF Ordinary Account. Therefore, please consider your need for financial protection and long-term retirement needs when deciding your share of cover.   o Example   Monthly housing instalment = $1,500   You are using $1,000 from your CPF and $200 cash.   Your co-owner is paying $300 from his CPF to service the loan.   Your share of the cover should be at least:   $1,200 / $1,500 x 100% = 80%   You can however, opt for up to 100% share of cover.   Your co-owner's share of the cover should be at least:   $300 / $1,500 x 100% = 20%   Your co-owner can also opt for up to 100% share of cover.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why do I need to update my contact details to adjust the online Daily Withdrawal Limit or make a CPF lump sum withdrawal?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Notifications via SMS or email will be sent to you whenever there are adjustments to the online Daily Withdrawal Limit, or when you make a CPF lump sum withdrawal. As such, you will have to update your contact details under  Account settings to receive these notifications. These notifications help provide immediate alerts and prevent any unauthorised adjustments or CPF lump sum withdrawals without your knowledge.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I did not apply to use my CPF savings when buying my HDB flat, can I apply to be covered under the Home Protection Scheme and use my CPF savings for monthly housing instalments now?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Since this is the first time that you are using your CPF savings for your HDB flat, we will need you to provide further information and documents related to your housing loan, such as details of your financier and outstanding housing loan amount.   You will need to submit an application to request to use your CPF savings for your monthly housing instalment and apply for an HPS cover.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is my co-owner allowed to withdraw part of his Retirement Account savings while I am not allowed to do so?
Knowledge Article: Answer: In households where the property does not last all co-owners until age 95, only the co-owner(s) who are covered by the lease until age 95 can choose to set aside their Full Retirement Sum (FRS) with a mixture of property (up to half the FRS) and cash, and hence withdraw their Retirement Account savings down to their Basic Retirement Sum*.   * Excluding interest, any government grants and top-ups made under the Retirement Sum Topping-up Scheme.   Find out more about the importance of having a property lease that lasts until you are 95 years old .

Knowledge Article: Question: Will my CPF savings withdrawn under the CPF Investment Scheme be used to make up my Full Retirement Sum when I turn 55?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, your CPF savings withdrawn under the CPF Investment Scheme will not be used to make up your Full Retirement Sum (FRS) . Your FRS is made up using your Special Account (SA) and Ordinary Account (OA) savings.   Find out how your FRS is set aside when you turn 55 .

Knowledge Article: Question: What will happen if I am not eligible for a Home Protection Scheme cover?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have a serious pre-existing medical condition and are not eligible for Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover, you can still use your CPF savings to pay your monthly housing instalment.   If you were previously covered under HPS, you may be eligible to port your previous HPS cover to your new property.   Find out how you can qualify for porting your previous HPS cover:   How do I qualify for the porting of my previous Home Protection Scheme cover to my new property?   You may also consider applying for insurance coverage from private insurers.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if I have omitted to declare certain health condition in my Home Protection Scheme application?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please write to us  to declare any health condition which you have omitted in your earlier Home Protection Scheme (HPS) application. Your declaration should include details of your health condition and a copy of your medical report, if any.   We will assess your eligibility for an HPS cover based on the additional health information declared.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why am I required to attend a medical examination for my Home Protection Scheme application?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your eligibility for Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover is subject to approval and you being in good health. To assess your eligibility for HPS cover, we may arrange a medical examination for you and/or request a copy of the medical report on your health condition.   You will be notified by CPF Board if you are scheduled for an HPS medical examination. You may check or reschedule your appointment online via e-Medical Appointment Service .   Find out more:   Can I provide my own medical report instead of attending the Home Protection Scheme medical examination?

Knowledge Article: Question: If my employee/platform worker/insured has used his/her MediSave and/or MediShield Life for medical expenses, do I need to reimburse my employee/platform worker/insured?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As an employer/platform operator/insurer, you are required to reimburse your employee/platform worker/insured's MediSave and/or MediShield Life if you have the contractual obligation to provide for their medical expenses.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if I need to withdraw more than the maximum online Daily Withdrawal Limit?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Daily Withdrawal Limit only applies to online CPF lump sum withdrawals made under withdrawals for immediate needs for members aged 55 and above . From 25 September 2024, if you need to withdraw an amount above $50,000, you may consider doing so online over multiple days. Alternatively, you may also wish to consider booking an appointment (Select ‘Retirement Income’ then ‘Withdrawal above maximum online Daily Withdrawal Limit’) to withdraw your preferred amount in person at CPF Service Centres. Generally, the next available appointment would be in a week’s time; subsequently, members will receive their withdrawn CPF savings in their bank account registered with us generally within 5 working days. To minimise any potential delay during the withdrawal process, we encourage members intending to make large withdrawals to plan in advance.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is the interest earned on Retirement Account not withdrawable?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The interest earned on Retirement Account savings is meant to build up your retirement savings and increase your monthly retirement payouts. Hence, it is not withdrawable in a lump sum.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I terminate my/my dependant's GIRO arrangement for MediShield Life and/or CareShield Life premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can approach your bank to terminate your GIRO arrangement for MediShield Life and/or CareShield Life premiums.

Knowledge Article: Question: What type of CPF withdrawals does the online Daily Withdrawal Limit apply to and how do I change the online Daily Withdrawal Limit?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Daily Withdrawal Limit applies to online CPF lump sum withdrawals made under withdrawals for immediate needs for members aged 55 and above.   A default online Daily Withdrawal Limit of $2,000 a day is applied to all CPF members aged 55 and above. You can adjust the online Daily Withdrawal Limit up to a maximum of $200,000, at any time under Account settings via Singpass authentication. Please note that any increase to the online Daily Withdrawal Limit will be subject to enhanced authentication measures and a 12-hour cooling period .   If you do not plan to withdraw soon, you may wish to consider activating the CPF Withdrawal Lock or lowering your DWL to better safeguard your CPF savings.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I have withdrawn under the Reduced Life Expectancy scheme, can I still apply to withdraw a lump sum at age 55 and payout eligibility age for my immediate retirement needs?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, you will no longer be able to withdraw a lump sum at age 55 and payout eligibility age for your immediate retirement needs as the withdrawal savings are already paid out to you earlier under the Reduced Life Expectancy scheme.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I have withdrawn under the Reduced Life Expectancy scheme, can I continue to use my Ordinary Account savings to service my housing loan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you can continue to use your Ordinary Account savings to service your housing loan, subject to existing housing rules, even if you have withdrawn under the Reduced Life Expectancy scheme.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why do I need to declare my health condition when I apply for my Home Protection Scheme cover?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You must declare your health condition fully and truthfully when you apply for your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover because that is how the mortgage protection insurance works. Your eligibility for an HPS cover is subject to approval and you being in good health.   This is in line with the industry practice where applicants have to truthfully declare their health conditions and may need to attend a medical examination.   Any HPS cover issued based on false/misleading information could be voided at any time, and any insurance claim would be denied. In such a situation, any premiums paid will also not be refunded. To avoid this, members need to declare fully and truthfully their health conditions when applying for HPS.

Knowledge Article: Question: What if I do not declare my health condition when I apply for a Home Protection Scheme cover?
Knowledge Article: Answer: It is important to declare your health condition fully and truthfully when applying for a Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover. Failing to do so will result in your HPS cover being voided at any time and any claim being denied. In such cases, any premiums paid will not be refunded to you.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why can't the refund be paid to a non-local bank account since I have provided the bank statement for verification?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To better protect employers from scams, we will only refund to the employer’s Direct Debit account, or OCBC and UOB bank accounts where CPF Board is able to perform automated bank account verification with the banks. This ensures that payment will only be made to a bank account belonging to the employer.   If you have a bank account with any of the eGIRO participating banks , you should apply for DDA online as the refunds made via cheques may take a maximum of 14 working days to reach you.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why can't the refund be paid to a non-local bank account since I have provided the bank statement for verification?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To better protect employers from scams, we will only refund to the employer’s Direct Debit account, or OCBC and UOB bank accounts where CPF Board is able to perform automated bank account verification with the banks. This ensures that payment will only be made to a bank account belonging to the employer.   If you have a bank account with any of the eGIRO participating banks , you should apply for DDA online as the refunds made via cheques may take a maximum of 14 working days to reach you.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will the payouts be made directly to persons with disabilities?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If the person with disabilities is 18 years old or above, and is of sound mind at point of disbursement, the disbursement will be made to the person with disabilities via his/her bank account. If the person with disabilities is below 18 years old, the disbursement will be made to the legal guardian or the court-appointed deputy (if he has one), when the deputy or legal guardian applies to the Board on behalf of the person with disabilities. If the person with disabilities is 18 years old or above and lacks mental capacity: If he made a valid Lasting Power of Attorney to appoint a donee, CPF Board would make payment to the donee when he steps forward to apply on behalf of the person with disabilities. If he had not made a valid Lasting Power of Attorney, a third party may apply to the court to be appointed as the Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS) nominee's deputy, and the Board will make payment to the court-appointed deputy when he applies to the Board on behalf of the person with disabilities.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the potential risks if I use an email service which does not comply to Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance (DMARC) policies?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your email service does not comply to Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance (DMARC) policies, there is a higher risk of receiving spoofed emails sent from scammers impersonating trusted senders such as CPF Board. This is because such a service provider might not take action to verify who is sending the email before it goes into your inbox.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I apply for a GIRO payment plan for my/my dependant's outstanding MediShield Life and/or CareShield Life premiums?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use your own or a third party’s bank account to apply for a GIRO payment plan for your/your dependant's outstanding MediShield Life and/or CareShield Life premiums by clicking on Set up GIRO for healthcare premiums to submit the request.  The duration of a standard GIRO payment plan for the outstanding MediShield Life and/or CareShield Life premiums can be up to 12 months.

Knowledge Article: Question: Where can I find advice on tax issues?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For tax issues, such as queries on IR8A form, please visit IRAS's website .

Knowledge Article: Question: If I have made a CPF nomination, how will my CPF savings be paid to my nominees?
Knowledge Article: Answer: By default, your nominee(s) will receive the CPF savings due to them in cash or GIRO.   If you have made a CPF nomination, you can check your details to find out how your CPF savings will be distributed to your nominee(s).   Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS)   If you have made a nomination under the Special Needs Savings Scheme, your children will receive your CPF savings on a monthly basis upon your demise. Find out more about SNSS Nomination .   Please contact the Board if you have any enquiries on the above.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the changes to the use of CPF for housing effective from 10 May 2019?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please refer to the  press release  for information on the changes to the use of CPF for housing effective from 10 May 2019.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much do I need to refund when I sell my property after I made a voluntary housing refund?
Knowledge Article: Answer: On sale of your property, the selling price will be distributed, in the following order:   1. Outstanding housing loan 2. CPF principal amount withdrawn for the property, and its accrued interest 3. Other sale expenses, e.g. legal fees   The amount to refund depends on how much you have voluntarily refunded:   Full voluntary housing refund of all your CPF principal withdrawn with accrued interest   If you had made a full voluntary housing refund of all your CPF principal withdrawn with accrued interest and did not use further CPF savings for your loan repayments, you do not need to make any refund to your CPF account on sale of your property.   Check your  Home ownership dashboard  for the amount of CPF to be refunded (if any).   Partial voluntary housing refund of all your CPF principal withdrawn with accrued interest   If you made a partial voluntary housing refund of your CPF principal withdrawn with accrued interest and/or continued to use further CPF savings for your loan repayments, you need to refund the remaining CPF principal amount withdrawn for your property, including the accrued interest (P+I) on  sale of your property .     Check your  Home ownership dashboard  for the amount of CPF to be refunded (if any).

Knowledge Article: Question: I received an anonymous call claiming that I can sign up for a new CPF Scheme that allows me to withdraw my CPF savings, and the caller offered to meet me to sign an application form. Is it a scam?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, it is a scam. CPF Board officers will not solicit sign-ups for CPF Schemes which involve the withdrawal of CPF savings. Members who wish to perform transactions with the Board should use my cpf digital services instead.   In the unfortunate event that you fall prey to a scam, we recommend taking the following actions immediately: Alert your bank to freeze the affected bank account. Reset your Singpass password if you think your Singpass has been compromised. For further assistance, please contact the official Singpass 24/7 helpdesk at 6335 3533. If you are 55 and above, activate the CPF Withdrawal Lock under Account settings to disable online CPF withdrawals instantly. File a police report and provide all details.

Knowledge Article: Question: I submitted reimbursements via E-File today. I realised there was a mistake in my submission only after I submitted the excel file. What should I do?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can override your previous submission by resubmitting the amended submission file within the same day before 5:30pm.   For further clarification, please  write to us .

Knowledge Article: Question: How does the Board calculate the accrued interest on the amount of CPF used for my property?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Accrued interest is the interest amount that you would have earned if your CPF savings had not been withdrawn for housing. The interest is computed on the CPF principal amount withdrawn for housing on a monthly basis (at the current CPF Ordinary Account interest rate) and compounded yearly. You can view the applicable CPF interest rates for the various periods.
