Knowledge Article: Question: What happens if my nominee and I (e.g. husband and wife) nominate each other and both of us pass away simultaneously?
Knowledge Article: Answer: In the event of simultaneous death, the older person is deemed to have died first.   Please see below for examples to illustrate the above.   Example 1: Where you and your nominee have nominated each other only   If you are older than your nominee, your CPF savings will be paid to your younger nominee's estate.   If you are younger than your nominee, it is deemed that your older nominee has died first and there is therefore no nominee. Your CPF savings will be forwarded to the Public Trustee’s Office for distribution to your family members in accordance with the Intestate Succession Act (Cap 146) for Non-Muslims, and the Administration of Muslim Law Act for Muslims.   Example 2: Where you and your nominee (e.g. spouse) have nominated each other, and other people   Assuming you appointed the nominees as follows: Spouse - 60% Mother - 30% Son - 10%   If you are the older spouse, 60% of your CPF savings will be paid to your spouse's estate. Your mother and son will receive 30% and 10% of your CPF savings respectively.   If you are the younger spouse, it is deemed that your spouse has died first. His/her share of your CPF savings will be passed on to the surviving nominees in the same proportion as their specified shares.   Your mother and son will receive your CPF savings as follows : Mother - 75% [original 30% + 3/4 of your spouse's share (equivalent to 45%) Son - 25% [original 10% + 1/4 of your spouse's share (equivalent to 15%)

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens if my nominee and I (e.g. husband and wife) nominate each other and both of us pass away simultaneously?
Knowledge Article: Answer: In the event of simultaneous death, the older person is deemed to have died first.   Please see below for examples to illustrate the above.   Example 1: Where you and your nominee have nominated each other only   If you are older than your nominee, your CPF savings will be paid to your younger nominee's estate.   If you are younger than your nominee, it is deemed that your older nominee has died first and there is therefore no nominee. Your CPF savings will be forwarded to the Public Trustee’s Office for distribution to your family members in accordance with the Intestate Succession Act (Cap 146) for Non-Muslims, and the Administration of Muslim Law Act for Muslims.   Example 2: Where you and your nominee (e.g. spouse) have nominated each other, and other people   Assuming you appointed the nominees as follows: Spouse - 60% Mother - 30% Son - 10%   If you are the older spouse, 60% of your CPF savings will be paid to your spouse's estate. Your mother and son will receive 30% and 10% of your CPF savings respectively.   If you are the younger spouse, it is deemed that your spouse has died first. His/her share of your CPF savings will be passed on to the surviving nominees in the same proportion as their specified shares.   Your mother and son will receive your CPF savings as follows : Mother - 75% [original 30% + 3/4 of your spouse's share (equivalent to 45%) Son - 25% [original 10% + 1/4 of your spouse's share (equivalent to 15%)

Knowledge Article: Question: What is email spoofing?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Email spoofing is a form of cyberattack in which emails are manipulated to make it seem as if they are sent by a trusted source. Email spoofing is used in phishing attempts because people are more likely to open an email when they think it has been sent by a known sender. Email scammers try to trick recipients into opening or responding to the message.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I am 55 and would like to make a CPF transfer, in what order will my savings be transferred?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF transfers to your Retirement Account (RA)   If you are 55 or above, your CPF savings will be transferred to your RA in the following order: Special Account (SA) Ordinary Account (OA) CPF transfers to your  loved ones   If you are 55 or above, your CPF savings will be transferred to your loved ones in the following order: OA SA RA* *If you use your RA savings for the transfer, you may no longer have enough savings to meet your Full Retirement Sum (FRS). In that case, the next time you apply for a withdrawal from your OA and SA, a portion or all of the savings will be used to meet your FRS in the RA.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have several email addresses. Can I use the utility tool to check if they are Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance (DMARC)-compliant?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We have designed the utility tool (beta version) to provide additional assurance that it is safe to receive and open emails sent by CPF Board. To prevent misuse of the tool, we require you to login with your Singpass and the tool will use the email address that you have registered in CPF Board’s records. You will thus not be able to use the tool to check if other email addresses are Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance (DMARC)-compliant.

Knowledge Article: Question: Which email service providers can identify and filter incoming Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance (DMARC)-compliant emails?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your email service provider is Yahoo or Gmail, your email domain is able to identify and filter incoming Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance (DMARC)-compliant emails. This list is not exhaustive and there are other email service providers which are DMARC-compliant.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the terms and conditions to use my CPF savings to buy a Housing & Development Board flat or a private property?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can refer to the terms and conditions to use your CPF savings to buy a property.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am 55, can I transfer my Ordinary Account savings to my Special Account to earn a higher interest rate?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, you will not be able to make CPF transfers to your Special Account (SA) after you turn 55. Instead, your transfers will be made to your Retirement Account (RA), which was created for your retirement needs.   Did you know? If you wish to earn higher interest on your Ordinary Account (OA) savings (which earns at least 2.5% interest* per annum) and boost your monthly payouts, you can make a CPF transfer to your RA (which earns at least 4% interest* per annum), up to the current Enhanced Retirement Sum. Do note that for CPF transfers to RA, your SA savings (if any) will be transferred first followed by your OA savings.   * Based on the current interest rate floor on Ordinary and Retirement Account monies.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have withdrawn my CPF savings on Reduced Life Expectancy. Why do I need to refund the CPF principal amount and accrued interest when I sell my property?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF savings that you had previously withdrawn for your property did not form part of the amount approved for withdrawal of CPF on Reduced Life Expectancy. Therefore, upon the sale of your property, the CPF principal amount withdrawn for the property and the accrued interest will need to be refunded to your CPF account. You can apply to withdraw the refunded amount under Reduced Life Expectancy if you are eligible to.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will the increase in the annual matching grant from $600 to $2,000 per year from 2025 help seniors better meet their retirement needs?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Eligible seniors can top up more to their CPF retirement savings and receive the higher matching grant amount. Correspondingly, they will also receive higher monthly CPF payouts. For instance, a senior aged 55 in 2025 who makes a cash top-up of $2,000 per year over the next 10 years will see an increase in CPF retirement savings of at least $48,000 (inclusive of matching grants and CPF interest) in 2035, which translates to about a $260 increase in monthly CPF payouts*.   *Estimation for a male member that starts payout at age 65 on the CPF LIFE Standard Plan.

Knowledge Article: Question: How does the closure of my Special Account affect the amount of tax relief that I can earn when I top up my Retirement Account in cash?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For members 55 and above, with the closure of your Special Account (SA) , your SA savings which are non-withdrawable will be transferred to your Retirement Account (RA), up to your Full Retirement Sum (FRS) to increase your monthly payouts.   Tax relief is only for cash top-ups up to the current FRS, and this has not changed. You can continue to enjoy tax relief on such top-ups within the current FRS.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I make a cash top-up to receive the matching grant under Matched Retirement Savings Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can make a cash top-up to yourself or your loved ones via the CPF website or CPF mobile app . Your cash top-up will generally be credited almost instantly upon successful payment.   Consider making regular monthly or yearly cash top-ups conveniently via GIRO , without the hassle of completing the application form every time you top up.   You may want to check whether you or your loved ones are eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme before making a cash top-up.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much CPF savings can I invest?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can find out how much CPF savings you can invest by logging in to my cpf digital services   with your Singpass > Select  my cpf > My dashboards > Investment. You can also refer to the list of instruments available for investment under the CPF Investment Scheme ( PDF, 0.1MB) to learn about the instruments that you can invest in.   The first $60,000 of your combined CPF accounts earns extra interest. To enable members to earn extra interest, monies in excess of $20,000 in your Ordinary Account and $40,000 in your Special Account can be invested. This requirement applies to all members, even if you are aged 55 and above and have set aside the Full Retirement Sum, due to the inherent risk associated with investments which applies across all age groups.   Details on the instruments included under the CPF Investment Scheme   You can refer to Annex A (PDF, 48KB) for more details on the instruments included under the CPF Investment Scheme. You may wish to refer to the risk classification tables for unit trusts (PDF, 0.1MB), investment-linked insurance products (PDF, 0.2MB) and exchange traded funds (PDF, 40KB) which CPF monies can be invested in.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have withdrawn my CPF savings on Reduced Life Expectancy. Can I withdraw any further CPF savings after refunds from the sale of my property are credited?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Once refunds from the sale of your property have been credited, you can submit an  online request with your Singpass to CPF for an assessment of your eligibility for further withdrawal under Reduced Life Expectancy.   If you have previously withdrawn your CPF savings on Reduced Life Expectancy, you may be eligible to withdraw further savings from your Special and Ordinary accounts. However, this is subject to your medical condition remaining unchanged.   We will review your request and inform you of your eligibility status.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I use my CPF to apply for Singapore Government Bonds and Treasury Bills (T-bills) at primary auctions? Can the application be submitted using online or ATM services?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA) Please apply for the bonds and T-bills through your CPFIS-OA agent bank. Application is restricted to your CPFIS-OA agent bank to facilitate the settlement process for bonds and T-bills purchased under CPFIS-OA.   DBS/POSB : Apply through DBS/POSB's internet banking portal or digibank mobile. OCBC : Apply through OCBC’s internet banking portal or OCBC Digital application. UOB : Apply for SGS bonds in person at any UOB branch. Apply for T-bills through UOB’s internet banking portal For step-by-step guide on how to submit your application through your CPFIS-OA agent bank’s electronic portal, you may visit their website, DBS (scroll to dropdown menu “How to apply?”),  OCBC (scroll to section “Invest digitally into T-bills & SGS bonds with your CPF”) and UOB (scroll to section "Things you should know").   After the T-bills auction closes, you can check the aggregate results of the auction at the Monetary Authority of Singapore’s website . If your application is successful, the T-bills allotted to you will be reflected in the CPF investment account statement sent by your agent bank.   For CPF Investment Scheme-Special Account (CPFIS-SA) You may apply for the bonds and T-bills via any of the CPFIS bond dealers (i.e. DBS, OCBC or UOB).   DBS/POSB : Apply in person at any DBS/POSB branch. OCBC : Apply through OCBC’s internet banking portal or OCBC Digital application. UOB : Apply in person at any UOB branch. For step-by-step guide on how to submit your application through the CPFIS bond dealer’s electronic portal, you may visit their website, OCBC (scroll to section “Invest digitally into T-bills & SGS bonds with your CPF”).   After the T-bills auction closes, you can check the aggregate results of the auction at the Monetary Authority of Singapore’s website . If your application is successful, the T-bills allotted to you will be reflected in your Special Account investment portfolio statement .

Knowledge Article: Question: Is there a deadline for me to claim the deceased member's CPF savings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You are encouraged to claim the deceased member's CPF savings as early as possible. You can do so anytime by submitting an online application .

Knowledge Article: Question: What actions should Fund Management Companies/insurers take if their existing CPF Investment Scheme List A funds are unable to comply with the Total Expense Ratio (TER) caps?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Fund Management Companies (FMCs)/insurers have undertaken to comply with the Total Expense Ratio (TER) caps for funds included under CPF Investment Scheme. If their List A funds are not able to comply with the new TER caps from 2016, FMCs/insurers will be required to compensate the funds for the difference between the actual expense ratios and the new TER caps . The funds would then be downgraded to List B with effect from the implementation date (see relevant reporting period , (PDF, 0.1MB)). Under List B, funds are not allowed to take in new CPF monies.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if I would like to use the CPF Housing Top-Up Grant for my Housing & Development Board flat?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The steps you need to take depend on the type of loan you have taken.   For HDB loan   You will need to complete the CPF withdrawal form (PHS9) at an HDB Branch. Please note that services at HDB office and Branches are by appointment only. Book an appointment to visit any of the HDB branches via the e-Appointment system . Your application will generally be processed within three to five working days upon the receipt of your request from HDB.   For bank loan   You can submit your request online via cpf.gov.sg/hdbbankloan . Your application will generally be processed within five working days upon the receipt of your request.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am a family member of a deceased CPF member, but I am not a nominee. How can I access the member's CPF account information?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If CPF Board is notified of the death of the member before 1 February 2024   Only authorised persons appointed by a deceased member can view the deceased member’s CPF information. If you are an authorised person, please submit a request to view the deceased member’s CPF information.   If CPF Board is notified of the death of the member on or after 1 February 2024   If you are an eligible family member under the intestacy laws, please submit a request via FormSG with supporting documents to prove your relationship with the deceased member. The Board will review your request within 10 working days and inform you how to access the deceased member’s CPF account information.   If you do not have Singpass, you can apply for a Singpass online.   If you are not a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident, please submit a  request .   To check your eligibility to access the deceased member’s CPF account information, please refer to the FAQ .

Knowledge Article: Question: Who is a proper claimant and when can they claim monies due to the deceased member/nominee's estate?
Knowledge Article: Answer: A proper claimant is a beneficiary, usually a family member, of the deceased member/nominee. The proper claimant can claim monies due to the deceased member/nominee's estate via an application process in the scenarios as stated below, where individual items do not exceed $50,000:   Dividends, sale proceeds and other monies in respect of discounted Singtel shares belonging to a deceased member who passed away before 1 January 1996 or did not make a nomination , and who does not have any personal representatives; or Nominated CPF savings that would have been paid to the deceased nominee who had passed away before he could receive it. For more details, please write to us .

Knowledge Article: Question: How long will my monthly payouts last if I am not on CPF LIFE?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are not automatically included CPF LIFE and did not  opt to join CPF LIFE to enjoy lifelong payouts, you will receive monthly payouts which will stop when your CPF savings run out. Your monthly payouts are calculated to last you up to 20 years, with the extra interest earned on your retirement savings helping to extend the payout duration up to 90 years old.   Find out why you should be concerned about outliving your savings.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is Supplementary Retirement Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Supplementary Retirement Scheme (SRS) is part of the Government's multi-pronged strategy to address the financial needs of a greying population. It is a voluntary scheme that complements the CPF. Participants can contribute a varying amount to SRS (subject to a cap) at their own discretion. The contributions may be used to purchase various investment instruments. The SRS offers attractive tax benefits. Contributions to SRS are eligible for tax relief, investment returns are accumulated tax-free (with the exception of Singapore dividends), and only 50% of the withdrawals from SRS are taxable at retirement.   You may wish to find out more information on SRS .

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to the CPF savings if the nominee passed away before he could receive the CPF savings of the deceased member?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF savings would form part of the deceased nominee's estate and would be paid to the Executor/Administrator appointed under the Grant of Probate (GP)/Letters of Administration (LA).   If there is no Executor/Administrator appointed, the CPF savings may be paid to a proper claimant if the sum does not exceed $50,000.

Knowledge Article: Question: Where can I find more information on what happens to my CPF accounts when I turn 55 and the available options I have in planning for my retirement?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will receive a letter from CPF Board a few months before your 55 th  birthday, providing you with more information.   The letter will give you details on how to make an appointment to attend the CPF Retirement Planning Service (CRPS), which is a one-to-one session where you will get personalised information about the CPF rules that will affect you when you turn 55.   If you prefer, you can also view your  personalised retirement planner online , which is available six months before your 55th birthday.  Find out more about the CPF planner – retirement income.   Finally, you can attend our  talks  to learn more about planning for your retirement.

Knowledge Article: Question: What will happen if I do not instruct CPF Board to start my monthly payouts?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We encourage you to use the personalised Plan my monthly payout s service to help you decide what best fits your retirement needs, and to submit your instructions. If we do not receive any instructions from you, we will start your payouts automatically when you reach 70 and your monthly payouts will be paid to the bank account provided under your  Account settings .   If you are born in 1958 or after and have not met your FRS, there will be another transfer of your Special Account (SA) and/or Ordinary Account (OA) savings to your Retirement Account (RA) to set aside your Full Retirement Sum (FRS) in cash. You can use the  Plan my monthly payouts service to know if this transfer applies to you and how much will be transferred to your RA. This service is applicable to you three months before you reach 65.   Once your monthly payout starts, please also note that any remaining amount from the additional withdrawable amount of up to 20% of your retirement savings will be transferred to your OA for your future withdrawals.    Note: If you belong to the small group of members who have previously joined CPF LIFE before reaching age 65, your payouts will start automatically at 65, or the age (up to 70) you have chosen to start your payouts.

Knowledge Article: Question: What do I need to declare when I apply for my Home Protection Scheme cover?
Knowledge Article: Answer: When applying for your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover, you need to fully disclose all information regarding your health condition, including:   All your past and current illnesses, Any surgery/treatment/medical test that you had previously undergone or will be undergoing, and Any physical or mental impairment. If you are unsure about the relevance of the information, you are advised to still disclose it. This includes any medical information that you may have provided to the officer during your appointments at HDB/financial institution/solicitor’s office, but which you did not include in your health declaration.   Please note that we may arrange a medical examination for you and/or request a copy of the medical report on your health condition to assess your eligibility for an HPS cover.   If you have an up-to-date medical report , you can submit a copy to us as a supporting document. Please note that the cost of obtaining the medical report will be borne by you.   Find out more:   I would like to submit a medical report to support my Home Protection Scheme application. What is the information required in the medical report?

Knowledge Article: Question: How are monthly payouts calculated if I am not on CPF LIFE?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are not on CPF LIFE, your monthly payouts are calculated to last for up to 20 years based on the prevailing base interest rate earned on your Retirement Account savings when you start your payouts.   As Singaporeans live longer, more than half of those aged 65 today are expected to live more than 20 years. To protect you against the risk of outliving your payouts, the extra interest  paid by the Government (up to 2% per year) on your retirement savings is used to extend your payouts beyond 20 years, up to age 90* or another five years, whichever ends later.   *Up to age 90, or another five years, whichever ends later.   You can use the payout estimator to estimate the amount of monthly payouts you can receive from your retirement savings.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I am eligible for the porting of my Home Protection Scheme cover, what is the sum assured that I am insured for and the period of cover?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are eligible for porting your previous Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover, we will issue you a new cover based on the lower of:   the remaining sum assured of your previous HPS cover or the outstanding loan for your new flat, and the remaining cover period of your previous HPS cover or the new cover period for the new flat. The same terms and conditions for your previous HPS cover will continue to apply to your new HPS cover.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is there another transfer of monies from my Special Account (SA) and/or Ordinary Account (OA) to my Retirement Account (RA) before I start my monthly payouts?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As Singaporeans are now working longer, CPF contributions made after age 55 become an essential part of their retirement savings. The increase in senior worker CPF contribution rates further reinforces this. This additional transfer will help to boost your retirement savings and provide you with higher monthly payouts.   If you have already set aside your Full Retirement Sum in cash in your Retirement Account, the transfer will not occur.

Knowledge Article: Question: My current registered bank account with CPF Board is also my PayNow NRIC-linked bank account. Do I still need to update my registered bank account with CPF Board to receive my CPF withdrawals via PayNow?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, it is necessary to do a one-time update of your registered bank account to "PayNow NRIC-linked bank account" via Account settings  if you wish to receive CPF payments via PayNow. If you do not update your registered bank account to PayNow, you will receive the payments within five working days of your withdrawal application via Interbank GIRO.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I increase or prolong my monthly payouts if I am not on CPF LIFE?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you're not on CPF LIFE, you have a few options to increase or prolong your monthly payouts from your retirement savings:   1. Boost your retirement savings by making cash top-ups or CPF transfers.   2. Start your monthly payouts later (up to age 70) to increase your retirement savings with risk-free interest rates* of up to 6% per annum.   Note: If you have started your payouts, you can still request to defer them until age 70 to give your savings more time to grow.   3. Join CPF LIFE to receive monthly payouts for as long as you live.   *Based on the current 4% interest rate floor on Retirement Account monies.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is there a need for the government to recover the excess Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) paid to workers?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme supports lower-wage Singaporean workers’ income and retirement savings via cash and CPF contributions. To ensure that the WIS scheme remains fair, the excess WIS (both the cash and CPF portions) will be recovered from future WIS payment(s) that the worker may receive.   For fraudulent cases, the recovery will be carried out immediately after the worker’s conviction or before conviction if the worker offered restitution in writing. Cash refund in lieu of CPF will be required if there are insufficient balances in the worker’s CPF accounts. Interest accrued on the outstanding cash amount may also be recovered. The worker will be issued a Notice to Attend Court if the WIS payments are not refunded.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if I face difficulty logging into my cpf digital services?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Here are some ways for you to troubleshoot when encountering login issues: Check your internet connection to ensure it is stable. Clear your browser cache before trying again (please refer to this link for instructions on how to clear the cache for all major browsers). Relaunch CPF website and try to log in again. Check that your browser is updated. my cpf digital services is compatible with the latest two versions of these commonly used browsers . Check that your device date-time setting is set to “Automatic” or the current date and time Try logging in to other government websites to determine if the issue occurs on these other platforms. If the issue persists, please write to us for further assistance.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the bank account that is linked to PayNow with my NRIC number?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The information about your bank account that is linked to PayNow with your NRIC number is maintained with the bank and not known to CPF Board. Check with your bank directly on the specific bank account that is linked to PayNow with your NRIC number.   CPF Board only needs your NRIC number to make CPF payments to your PayNow NRIC-linked bank account.

Knowledge Article: Question: Who do I contact for further details on my Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions and net service fee payment amount?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To view your Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions and other payment details, you may log in to the Self-employment dashboard   using your Singpass, under Contribute As You Earn > Show all payments . You can also  contact us through these channels .   For more details on the net service fee, please contact the company or agency you have contracted with directly. If there are any non-payment, short payment or late payment of service fees, you may wish to take up the dispute directly with your buyer and seek mediation through the Tripartite Alliance for Dispute Management (TADM) or other industry facilitated mediation services.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the alternatives available if I am not eligible for a Home Protection Scheme cover?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are not eligible for a Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover due to serious medical condition, you may wish to consider applying for insurance coverage from private insurers.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much premium do I need to pay to be covered under Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The DPS premium payable yearly will be based on the age you have reached, at the point of payment.   Age (as of payment date) Yearly Premium^ for $70,000 sum assured 34 years and below $18 35 – 39 years $30 40 – 44 years $50 45 – 49 years $93 50 – 54 years $188 55 – 59 years $298 60 - 64 years $298 (for sum assured of $55,000)   ^Premiums are payable on member’s DPS policy commencement date and on subsequent yearly policy renewal dates.

Knowledge Article: Question: What would happen to my Integrated Shield Plan if I renounce my Singapore Citizenship/Permanent Residency?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The MediShield Life (MSHL) component of your Integrated Shield Plan would terminate at the end of the current policy year. To continue with your policy, you need to check with your insurer (PDF, 0.1MB) whether they will insure you fully (without the MSHL component).

Knowledge Article: Question: What file types are acceptable for submission via CPF EZPay (FTP)? Why do I keep getting a file extension error when trying to perform submission?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Only text files conforming to our  FTP file specifications (effective 1 Jan 2022) (PDF, 0.3MB) which end with a ".dtl", ".txt" or ".dat" extensions are acceptable. Please check that your file ends with one of these extensions. If you encounter file extension error when trying to perform submission, please check to see if any of the folders within the path contains ".". The reason is because the system will treat anything behind "." as the extension of the file. To know more about CPF EZPay (FTP), you can refer to our user guide (PDF, 3.7MB).

Knowledge Article: Question: I am interested to register as a CPF volunteer. How do I sign up?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can sign up with us as a CPF volunteer in a few easy steps:   1. Download the CPF Volunteering (CPFV) mobile application, available on both Apple App Store and Google Play Store . You can also scan the QR code to download the app and register.     Enter your mobile number to get started on registration 2. Complete the Sign-up form to be a volunteer: Your orientation and training resources will be availed to you via our CPFV app.

Knowledge Article: Question: In what order should I reimburse my employee/platform worker/insured if he/she has paid for his/her medical expenses using cash, MediSave and MediShield Life?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Subjected to the contractual obligations, the order you are required to reimburse your employee/platform worker/insured is as follows:   Amount paid in cash Amount utilised from your employee/platform worker/insured's MediSave  Amount utilised from your employee/platform worker/insured's MediSave-approved Integrated Shield Plan or MediShield Life Reimbursing your employee/platform worker/insured in this order minimises his/her cash outlay, and preserves his/her MediSave for future use.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have received a notification on topping up my and/or my loved ones' retirement savings. How do I know that this notification is indeed sent by CPF Board?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To ensure that the notifications you received is sent by CPF Board, you should do the following checks:   Confirm that the sender's email address is correctly spelt and ends with @cpf.gov.sg or @e.cpf.gov.sg. Verify that the sender's ID for SMS is correctly displayed as "gov.sg". The SMS will also begin with "Central Provident Fund Board". Ensure that the domain links in the notification end with "cpf.gov.sg", which directs you to the official CPF website. Examine the content of the notifications for any indications of phishing, such as urgent language, threats or requests for personal information. If you are unsure about the legitimacy of the notification, do not provide any personal information or click on any links. The Board will only send digital notifications to the email address registered in our records. You may verify or update your contact details in CPF Account settings with your Singpass.   If you receive any suspicious calls or digital notifications that seem to be spoofing the CPF Board, please report them to us via our CPF official hotline or Writetous .   Additionally, you can refer to resources provided by CPF Board for more information on how to avoid falling prey to phishing scams and how to protect yourself from phishing links .

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is there a combined tax relief cap for top-ups to the Special Account/Retirement Account and MediSave Account from 1 January 2022?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The combined tax relief for cash top-ups to the Special/Retirement Account and MediSave Account (MA) was introduced for greater consistency across CPF schemes. This allows members to better understand and take action to benefit from these schemes.   The tax relief eligibility conditions for cash top-ups made before 1 January 2022 had differed 1 for top-ups to retirement savings and top-ups to MA. With this change 2 , the tax relief eligibility conditions for cash top-ups made on or after 1 January 2022 across both schemes have been aligned.   1 Before 1 January 2022, the tax relief eligibility conditions for cash top-ups differed between both scheme in terms of (i) tax beneficiary [giver for Retirement Sum Topping-Up (RSTU); recipient for Voluntary Contribution to MediSave Account (VCMA)]; and (ii) tax relief cap for top-ups to self/loved ones (capped at $7k/$7k for RSTU, tax relief cap for VCMA depended on both the Basic Healthcare Sum and the amount of mandatory CPF contributions for the year).   2 The changes related to cash top-ups to MA do not apply to MA contributions made as a self-employed person (SEP). If you would like to make MA contributions as a SEP, visit the  Self-Employed Scheme page for more information on topping up your MA.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will I receive my retirement savings if my application to withdraw my retirement savings using my pension/annuity is approved?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your application to withdraw your retirement savings using your pension/annuity is approved, your retirement savings will be paid to your bank account provided under your Account settings .

Knowledge Article: Question: I was notified by the Medical Institution that my employee/platform worker/insured's medical bill was cancelled or amended. I would like to make amendments to the reimbursement I made previously. What should I do?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please  write to us for assistance if you would like to make amendments to the MediShield/MediSave reimbursement which you submitted previously.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to my CPF LIFE plan if my application to withdraw all my retirement savings using my pension/annuity is approved?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your application to withdraw all your retirement savings using your pension/annuity is approved, you can decide whether to terminate your CPF LIFE plan and receive a refund of the premium balance (if applicable); or keep your CPF LIFE plan and receive monthly payouts for as long as you live.

Knowledge Article: Question: As a bankrupt, can my CPF savings be used to pay for my children's tertiary education?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may use your CPF savings for your children's tertiary education under the CPF Education Loan scheme as long as you have the available withdrawal limit.

Knowledge Article: Question: As a bankrupt, can I use my CPF savings for my own tertiary education?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may continue to use your CPF savings for your own tertiary education if your application has been approved before your bankruptcy.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I import my employee's details in CPF EZPay if I'm using Microsoft Excel?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please follow these steps when importing your employee's details from Microsoft Excel Template File for submission via CPF EZPay: Login to CPF EZPay Select For UEN-registered entities or For individuals trading under own name and log in with your Singpass. Key in your CPF Submission Number (CSN). At Submit Contribution , select CPF EZPay . At Contribution Details For , key in the Month and Year . Select Submit via Employee Database and select Continue . Select Import Employee Details . Select Import from MS Excel Template file . Click on Choose File to select the file which you wish to import. Next, select Import File and you will be directed to Preview of Imported Records . Select Confirm & Save . A pop-up message " Importing this file will replace ALL employee details in your Employee Database. Do you want to continue "   will be displayed. Select OK and you will be directed to the Update Employee Database page.   The confirmation message " File imported successfully. Please update the field " PR Start Date "  for all your Permanent Resident employees "   will be displayed on the same page. Please ensure that you have keyed in the PR Start Date for any Singapore Permanent Resident employees to ensure correct auto-computation of CPF contributions. Note: To understand the fields inside the sample template, please click on the  help icon. Please fill up all the mandatory fields marked with "*" in our sample template and ensure that your file is saved as a .csv file. You may also copy and paste details from your payroll MS Excel file into our .csv template. To do so, please click on Download Sample Template to download our template, and copy the employee details from your existing spreadsheet into our template.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why are CPF transfers not eligible for the matching grant under Matched Retirement Savings Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Matched Retirement Savings Scheme is designed to encourage cash top-ups to senior Singapore Citizens with lower retirement savings to help them save more. Thus, only cash top-ups to eligible members will be matched.   Members making CPF transfers can still benefit from the higher interest rate in the Retirement Account.

Knowledge Article: Question: Will I be eligible for Matched Retirement Savings Scheme if I am turning 55 later this year?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you will be eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme as long as you are 55 in the assessment year and meet the  eligibility criteria .   If you are turning 55 this year and your Retirement Account has not been created at the time we assess your eligibility, your total Special Account and Ordinary Account savings will be assessed instead.

Knowledge Article: Question: What supporting documents will I need if I'm making a first-time CPF transfer to my loved ones?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For first-time CPF transfers to your loved ones, you will need to submit the following supporting documents via Mailbox .   CPF transfer to Supporting documents Spouse Marriage certificate, if your marriage is registered overseas Parent(s) Your birth certificate Grandparent(s) Your and your parent(s)’s birth certificates Sibling(s) Your and your sibling(s)’s birth certificates Parent(s)-in-law Your overseas marriage certificate* and your spouse’s birth certificate. Grandparent(s)-in-law Your overseas marriage certificate, your spouse’s and your spouse’s parent(s)’s birth certificates   *Not required if your marriage is registered in Singapore   Supporting documents are not required for cash top-ups.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is PayNow (excluding PayNow Mobile Number and Virtual Payments Address) the default mode of bank payments moving forward?
Knowledge Article: Answer: PayNow (excluding PayNow Mobile Number and Virtual Payments Address) aligns with the government's drive for digital transformation and the Smart Nation initiative, as it promotes the adoption of digital payment. It also provides citizens a more secured mode of payment as they do not need to provide their bank account details to receive their service fee payments.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much can I withdraw under the Reduced Life Expectancy scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Under the Reduced Life Expectancy scheme, you can withdraw a lump sum of up to $5,000* or more, depending on the extent of your reduced life expectancy as certified by an accredited doctor .   You may also need to keep a reduced retirement sum in your Retirement Account from which you will receive regular monthly payouts.   *The amount you can withdraw depends on your available CPF balances, excluding top-ups made under the Retirement Sum Topping-up Scheme, government grants and your MediSave Account savings.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I know about topping up my retirement savings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Here are the 3 things you need to know about topping up your retirement savings. Tax relief is subject to terms and conditions .   .

Knowledge Article: Question: What are Advice Codes and how do I use them when I upload my submission file via CPF EZPay (FTP)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are submitting more than one file within the same day for the same CPF Submission Number (CSN), you will need to assign a different Advice Code for each file. Advice Codes act as a file numbering system to differentiate files created for different groups of employees belonging to the same CSN. To know more about CPF EZPay (FTP), you can refer to our user guide (PDF, 3.7MB).

Knowledge Article: Question: What are CareShield Life/ElderShield supplements?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Members insured under CareShield Life and ElderShield can consider purchasing Supplements from private insurers to have additional benefits such as higher payouts or coverage for less severe disability.   There are no restrictions on the number of supplement policies one can be covered. Supplement premiums can be paid using MediSave, up to a limit of $600 per calendar year per person insured. Premiums for Supplements range widely and commensurate with the type of benefits they offer. You may refer to the  FAQ for Supplements for more information.   For more information on your CareShield Life/ElderShield Supplements, please contact your insurer:   Singapore Life Limited Address: 4 Shenton Way, #01-01, SGX Centre 2, Singapore 068807 Website: singlife.com Email: cs_life@singlife.com Hotline: 6827 9933 Income Insurance Limited Address: 75 Bras Basah Road, Income Centre, Singapore 189557 Website: income.com.sg Hotline: 6332 1133 The Great Eastern Life Assurance Company Limited Address: 1 Pickering Street #13-01, Great Eastern Centre, Singapore 048659 Website: greateasternlife.com Email: wecare-sg@greateasternlife.com Hotline: 1800-248-2888   You can check your CareShield Life/ElderShield supplement plan by following these steps:   a. Visit the CPF website . b. Log in using your Singpass. c. Hover over "my cpf" and click on "Healthcare" under "My dashboards". d. Click on “Long-term care insurance” on the anchor links or scroll down to the “Long-term care insurance” section.   If you are covered under a Supplement plan, this section will show the insurer of your Supplement plan (i.e. Singlife, Great Eastern, or Income Insurance). Do contact your insurer to find out which Supplement plan you are covered under.   If you do not have any Supplement plan, this section will not reflect any information.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the documents that CPF Board requires if the Court has accepted an application to make or revoke a nomination and how should these documents be submitted?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Make a CPF nomination for members who lack mental capacity   If the Court accepts the application to make a CPF nomination on behalf of a member, the court may appoint a person to carry out the making of the nomination.   If you are the person appointed by the Court to carry out the making of the nomination, please complete the relevant CPF nomination form and indicate that you are the authorised person ordered by the Court to make the CPF nomination on behalf of the member who lacks capacity. The CPF nomination form must be affixed with the Court's Seal.   The witnesses to the nomination may be our Customer Service Executives (CSEs) at any of our Service Centres . If 2 other witnesses are chosen, please note that the witnesses to the CPF nomination must be at least 21 years old and not lack capacity. Please note that the witnesses cannot be the nominees or the authorised person signing on behalf of the member.   We encourage you to hand-deliver the completed CPF nomination form (affixed with the Court's Seal), with a certified true copy of the Order of Court and your NRIC to any CPF Service Centre. Alternatively, you may wish to send the documents to the Board by post. You can mail the documents to:   Attention: Nominations Department   Central Provident Fund Board Robinson Road P.O. Box 3060 Singapore 905060   Revoke a CPF nomination for members who lack mental capacity If the Court accepts your application to revoke the CPF nomination, and makes the order revoking the CPF nomination, please furnish the Board with a copy of the Order of Court and your NRIC (both documents to be certified as true copies by your lawyers).   We encourage you to hand-deliver the completed CPF revocation form (affixed with the Court's Seal), with a certified true copy of the Order of Court and your NRIC to any CPF Service Centre. Alternatively, you may wish to send the documents to the Board by post. You can mail the documents to:   Attention: Nominations Department   Central Provident Fund Board Robinson Road P.O. Box 3060 Singapore 905060   You should seek your lawyer's advice as an application to court is required.

Knowledge Article: Question: What will happen to my Home Protection Scheme cover if I make a partial repayment of my loan?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We will automatically adjust your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover accordingly if:   You made a partial repayment towards your HDB loan, regardless of whether you used cash or CPF savings to do so, or You made a partial repayment towards your bank loan, using CPF savings. However, if you have taken a bank loan and have used cash for the partial repayment, please submit your application online using your Singpass to adjust your HPS cover, after your bank has recognised the partial repayment. We will then write to your bank to obtain your latest loan details.  Your HPS cover would be adjusted based on the latest loan detail as at application date. No backdated adjustments will be made. It is important to promptly inform us of any partial repayment made in cash, so that your HPS cover can be promptly adjusted. Otherwise, you may end up being over-insured or under-insured, which would not be to your benefit.     Once the adjustment is made, your existing HPS cover will end, and any unused premium will be paid to your CPF Ordinary Account (OA). You will be issued a new HPS cover based on the latest loan details after partial repayment. The premium for the new cover will be deducted from your OA.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to my CPF savings if I did not make a CPF nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: When you are no longer around, we will pay your CPF savings to the Public Trustee's Office for distribution in cash to your family member(s) in accordance with the intestacy laws or inheritance certificate (for Muslims) in Singapore. This ensures that the welfare of your dependants is provided for.   The following assets are due to the beneficiaries of the deceased's estate:   a. Discounted Singtel shares;   b. Properties bought with your CPF savings 1 ;   c. Payout from Dependants’ Protection Scheme (DPS) 2 ; and   d. Investments made under CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) 3 .   1 The treatment of the deceased’s share of the property is dependent on the manner of holding. If the property is held under Joint Tenancy, ownership of property will be transferred to the surviving owner(s). If the property is held under Tenancy-in-Common, the deceased's share of property will form part of his estate.   2 You can make a DPS nomination with your DPS insurer or make a will to determine the beneficiaries of the DPS claim benefits. Without a DPS nomination or will, the benefits will be paid to the proper claimant(s). A proper claimant can be the executor of the deceased’s estate or a family member.   3 These will form part of your estate, except for insurance policies where if you have made a nomination with your insurance company, the death benefits from the policies will be paid to your nominated beneficiaries.   Watch this video to find out why you need to make a CPF nomination.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to my CPF savings if I did not make a CPF nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: When you are no longer around, we will pay your CPF savings to the Public Trustee's Office for distribution in cash to your family member(s) in accordance with the intestacy laws or inheritance certificate (for Muslims) in Singapore. This ensures that the welfare of your dependants is provided for.   The following assets are due to the beneficiaries of the deceased's estate:   a. Discounted Singtel shares;   b. Properties bought with your CPF savings 1 ;   c. Payout from Dependants’ Protection Scheme (DPS) 2 ; and   d. Investments made under CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) 3 .   1 The treatment of the deceased’s share of the property is dependent on the manner of holding. If the property is held under Joint Tenancy, ownership of property will be transferred to the surviving owner(s). If the property is held under Tenancy-in-Common, the deceased's share of property will form part of his estate.   2 You can make a DPS nomination with your DPS insurer or make a will to determine the beneficiaries of the DPS claim benefits. Without a DPS nomination or will, the benefits will be paid to the proper claimant(s). A proper claimant can be the executor of the deceased’s estate or a family member.   3 These will form part of your estate, except for insurance policies where if you have made a nomination with your insurance company, the death benefits from the policies will be paid to your nominated beneficiaries.   Watch this video to find out why you need to make a CPF nomination.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I derive the share of excess contributions to be refunded to my employee?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For example, if your employee is a Singaporean Citizen who is below 55 years old and has received a total of $40,000 of CPF contributions for 2023, the excess contributions to be refunded to your employee can be estimated based on the calculation below:   Step 1: Total excess CPF contributions refunded to the employer   = Total CPF contributions paid – CPF Annual Limit   = $40,000 – $37,740   = $2,260   Step 2: Employee’s share to be refunded   = (Total excess CPF contributions refunded ÷ applicable CPF contribution rate) x applicable employee CPF contribution rate   = ($2,260 ÷ 37% 1 ) x 20% 1   = $1,221* (cents should be dropped)   * You can also verify the above estimated employee’s share of refund by computing the difference between the total employee’s share of contributions paid and employee’s share of contributions payable. The employee’s share of contributions payable can be computed using the  Additional Wage ceiling Calculator .   1  This rate is applicable for an employee who is a Singapore Citizen or Singapore Permanent Resident (3rd year onwards) and is 55 or below.

Knowledge Article: Question: When can I apply to withdraw my retirement savings if I have a pension/annuity?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can apply for withdrawal of your CPF retirement savings if you have a pension/annuity, as long as you are:   i. 55 or above; and   ii. currently receiving lifelong monthly payouts from your pension/annuity.

Knowledge Article: Question: Who can make cash top-ups to recipients who are eligible to receive the matching grant under Matched Retirement Savings Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Anyone, including yourself, loved ones , employers or members of the community, can help members eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme receive the matching grant by making cash top-ups.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I check the status of my application to withdraw my retirement savings using my pension/annuity?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your application to withdraw your retirement savings using your pension/annuity is approved, you will receive a withdrawal advice by mail after we have processed the payment to your bank account. Alternatively, you can also check the status of your application by logging on to cpf.gov.sg .

Knowledge Article: Question: Why do I need to update my registered bank account with CPF Board to my PayNow NRIC-linked bank account to make PayNow withdrawals if I have already withdrawn via PayNow previously?
Knowledge Article: Answer: With PayNow, you can withdraw CPF savings for immediate retirement needs from age 55 to your bank account almost instantly. As part of CPF Board’s ongoing efforts to better safeguard CPF members against scams, to make a PayNow withdrawal, you will need to do a one-time update of your registered bank account with CPF Board to your PayNow NRIC-linked bank account via Account settings . This update will be subject to a 12-hour cooling period and enhanced authentication, similar to existing safeguards when you update your personal account details. Once your PayNow NRIC-linked bank account has been activated with CPF Board, it will be used to receive your CPF withdrawals and monthly payouts.   This update is required even if you have withdrawn via PayNow previously, as a one-time exercise to strengthen security against scams. We recognise the inconvenience but seek your understanding that this additional safeguard is necessary to provide a greater level of security to CPF members.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is Additional Wage ceiling and how do I calculate it?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Additional Wage (AW) ceiling limits the amount of AW that attract CPF contributions. The AW ceiling is applied on a per employer per calendar year basis. The Additional Wage ceiling is computed as follows:   $102,000 - Total Ordinary Wage subject to CPF contributions for the year   The AW ceiling formula above does not take into account the revision of Ordinary Wage ceiling of $6,300 from Sep 2023. Please refer to this  FAQ on how to compute the AW ceiling for the year 2023.   You can access the following resources to help you with the computation:   a.  AW ceiling Calculator   b.  Examples on the Computation of the AW ceiling (PDF, 0.6MB)

Knowledge Article: Question: I am reaching age 65 and received an email message from CPFB on my monthly payout details. How do I verify that the email is legitimate?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To verify whether the email you received from us is legitimate, please check the following:   The sender's email address is correctly spelt and ends with @cpf.gov.sg or @e.cpf.gov.sg. You are directed only to our official CPF website (link starting with cpf.gov.sg) The content of the email: Look for any signs of phishing attempts, such as urgent language, threats, or requests for personal information. The Board will only send digital notifications to the email address registered in our records. You may verify or update your contact details in CPF Account settings with your Singpass.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will the Dependants' Protection Scheme claim benefits be distributed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For claims under medical grounds, the Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) benefits will be paid out to the insured member directly.   For death claims, if the insured member has made a DPS nomination, or has a will which is made known to the DPS insurer, the beneficiary(s) according to the nomination or will (whichever takes effect at the later date) will receive the benefits.   If no nomination or will is made, the benefits will be paid to proper claimant(s). A proper claimant can be the executor of the deceased's estate or family member, e.g. spouse, parent, child, or sibling.   For more details, please approach the appointed DPS insurer, Great Eastern Life.

Knowledge Article: Question: I received a recommendation for this e-service from a family member or friend, but I am uncertain if they have registered as a CPF volunteer. What should I do?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can ask your family member or friend who recommended the e-service to you for their referrer’s details.   If they had not signed up to be a volunteer, you can encourage them to do so by downloading our CPF Volunteering (CPFV) mobile app from the App Store or Google Play (search for keyword: CPFV) and tapping on “Sign up now”.   You can also scan the QR code to download the app and register with us.

Knowledge Article: Question: When is the best time to top up to grow my savings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You should top up as early as possible to maximise the growth of your CPF savings through the power of compound interest.   Additionally, you can earn more interest if you top up earlier in the year. For example, if you top up in January each year instead of in December, you can earn up to 20%* more interest on your top-ups in 10 years.   * Based on the current 4% interest rate floor on Special and Retirement Account monies and extra interest of up to 2% per annum on the first $60,000 of your combined CPF balances, with $8,000 annual top-up and $0 starting balance.   Do top up early in the year to ensure that your top-ups are processed before the year end as the normal processing time may take longer in December if there is a surge in applications.

Knowledge Article: Question: What does the CPF Volunteering (CPFV) mobile app offer?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Our CPF Volunteering (CPFV) app serves as a one-stop platform for volunteers and partners of CPF Board to:     Register with us as a volunteer of CPF Board     Receive CPF updates and access onboarding and training resources on CPF     Network with other like-minded individuals     Be guided on how they can pay it forward through various opportunities to do good     View personal achievements and impact of one’s contributions

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if I wish to refinance the housing loan for my property?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will have to authorise your lawyer (by signing the Letter of Authorisation, Declaration, Consent & Agreement) to submit your application on your behalf if you wish to refinance the housing loan for your property.   The following documents are required:   1. Final/latest statement from the existing financier; and 2. Letter of offer from the new financier stating the type and quantum of the new loan.   Please note that your current CPF monthly instalment payment to the existing financier (if any) will cease upon the approval of the application submitted by your lawyer.   If you are an HDB flat owner intending to use your CPF savings for the monthly instalment payment, but are not currently covered under the Home Protection Scheme (HPS) , you will need to submit an HPS application online using your Singpass after receiving notification that your application has been processed. Your eligibility for HPS cover is subject to approval and your good health. While your HPS application is being processed, you can use your CPF savings to pay your monthly housing loan instalments.   If you are already insured by HPS or exempted from HPS, you can find out more below:   What will happen to my Home Protection Scheme cover if I have refinanced my housing loan?

Knowledge Article: Question: What incentives are there for me to top up to my loved ones under the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme when the tax relief is removed from 2025?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Topping up to your loved ones’ CPF accounts helps them to build up more retirement savings and increases their monthly payouts in retirement. From 1 January 2025, recipients of cash top-ups who are eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme (MRSS) can also receive a matching grant of up to $2,000 per year (an increase from $600 per year) from the Government, which will further boost their retirement savings.   You may continue to enjoy tax relief of up to $16,000 a year for eligible cash top-ups that do not attract MRSS matching grants ($8,000 per year for top-ups to yourself and another $8,000 per year for top-ups to your loved ones).   Learn more on how this works .

Knowledge Article: Question: Why did I receive a refund of excess CPF contributions paid to my employee(s) without applying for a refund?
Knowledge Article: Answer: From February 2024, CPF contributions paid in excess of the CPF Annual Limit will be automatically refunded to the employer’s bank account under the Direct Debit arrangement maintained with CPF Board. For excess CPF contributions paid in 2023, they will be refunded in 2024.   The CPF Board will notify both the employer and the employee on the refund details after the transaction is processed. You are required to refund the employee’s share of excess contributions, if any, directly to your employee.   As employers, you are required to ensure accurate CPF contributions up to the CPF Annual Limit per year for each employee by applying the  Ordinary Wage (OW) ceiling and Additional Wage (AW) ceiling .

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I update my personal particulars (including change of address) for my Integrated Shield Plan (IP)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As your Integrated Shield Plan (IP) is administered by the private insurer you have chosen to cover you, please approach your  insurer (PDF, 0.4MB) directly on all matters relating to your IP or by updating your particulars on your insurer’s web portal.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is required before making an SNSS nomination?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Before you apply for SNSS nomination, you are required to obtain an eligibility letter from Special Needs Trust Company (SNTC). SNTC will issue the letter to you after confirming your nominee’s eligibility for the SNSS. You may then proceed to any of our Service Centres to make the SNSS nomination.   For more details on SNSS, please visit SNTC’s website .

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the purpose of the Dependants' Protection Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF members who are working and earning an income may have dependants who are reliant on their income. If such CPF members suddenly meet with an accident or contract a terminal illness that results in the loss of their income, the dependants who are reliant on them may be left in the lurch. The impact is greater when the member has not yet accumulated enough CPF or other savings which could be bequeathed to their dependants to tide them over the first few years of their untimely demise. Therefore, Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) is useful to such working CPF members. This is also the reason why DPS coverage is automatically extended to members upon their first CPF contribution between age 21 and 65.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens to my MediShield Life/ElderShield plans when my account is closed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are a non-Singapore Citizen/non-Permanent Resident covered under MediShield Life/ElderShield   before 1 April 2024,   (i) your cover(s) will cease unless you inform us of your intention to continue your cover(s) via Write to Us and make alternative payment arrangements for the premiums to be paid.   (ii) ElderShield policyholders with paid-up policies will remain covered. No further action is required.   For more details on MediShield Life   For more details on ElderShield

Knowledge Article: Question: I have renounced my Singapore Citizenship/Permanent Resident status, what will happen to my ElderShield cover?
Knowledge Article: Answer: ElderShield policyholders who have renounced their Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Resident status before 1 April 2024 You can retain your ElderShield policy as long as your policy was paid up before 1 April 2024 or you continue to make payment for your premiums.   As foreigners would no longer have CPF accounts from 1 April 2024 onwards, you will have to make alternative premium payment arrangement to continue payment, if you wish to retain your cover. If you are using your own MediSave Account to pay for the premiums and no alternative payment arrangements are made to continue, your ElderShield policy will lapse, with no refund of past premiums paid. However, in scenarios where there were a minimum number of premiums paid, your ElderShield cover will be converted to a policy with reduced payouts.   ElderShield policyholders who renounce their Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Resident status on and after 1 April 2024 In line with the closure of CPF accounts, your ElderShield policy will be automatically terminated and there will be no refund of premiums paid. This is as per how MediShield Life and CareShield Life policies are terminated upon renunciation of Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Resident status.   I am (i) residing overseas or (ii) have renounced my Singapore Citizenship/Permanent Resident status. How do I pay my CareShield Life/ElderShield/MediShield Life premiums?

Knowledge Article: Question: Isn't it against the law for CPF Board to reveal a member's personal details publicly?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Members’ data are safe with the Board and there are high standards in place to prevent its unintended disclosure.    Where it is in the public interest, the law allows the CPF Board to release a member’s personal details. For example, where misleading information is put out and widely disseminated, we must be able to provide the public with relevant facts. This approach applies to all public agencies. It helps the public gain a fuller picture of the case and counter the misinformation, both of which are necessary to maintain the trust placed in public agencies.   CPF Board is committed in ensuring your data is protected. You may refer to our privacy statement for more details.

Knowledge Article: Question: When do I need to apply to adjust my Home Protection Scheme cover?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You need to apply to adjust your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover if:   Your loan repayment period or loan amount has increased for your housing loan taken with HDB or a bank: If you have extended the repayment period or taken out a larger loan, it is crucial to review your HPS cover. This ensures that you are adequately protected and that your share of the HPS cover is sufficient to pay your share of the outstanding loan in case of a claim. Your share of responsibility in repaying the housing loan has changed: If there is a change in your share of responsibility for repaying the loan, it is necessary to adjust your HPS cover accordingly. This ensures that your coverage accurately reflects your current financial obligations. You have taken a bank loan and have used cash to make a partial repayment of the housing loan: This ensures that your HPS cover is adjusted to align with your outstanding housing loan. Please submit your application online  using your Singpass to adjust your HPS cover. Your HPS cover would be adjusted based on the latest loan details as at application date. No backdated adjustments will be made.  If your HPS cover requires adjustment, the HPS premium will also be adjusted accordingly and we will issue you a new HPS cover.   Specifically, if you are increasing your HPS coverage due to an increase in loan repayment period, loan amount, or your share of cover, a new health declaration is required. If you are not eligible for the additional coverage, you may continue to be insured under the cover that was previously extended to you.

Knowledge Article: Question: What should I do if I wish to amend an online nomination I have submitted?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can amend your nomination if either or both your witnesses have not witnessed your nomination. You can do so by withdrawing your nomination and submitting a new one.   If both your witnesses have already witnessed your nomination, you will not be able to withdraw and amend the nomination. However, you can submit a new nomination after your earlier nomination is processed. Your new nomination will supersede your earlier nomination.   You can only submit one nomination within the same day. This includes the nomination that has had its witnessing process completed that day.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance (DMARC)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: DMARC, which stands for “Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance”, is an email authentication, policy, and reporting protocol. It is designed to give email domain owners like CPF Board the ability to protect their domain (e.g., “cpf.gov.sg”) from unauthorised use by email scammers. As the Board uses DMARC together with other email security measures, recipients’ email service providers which have security measures in place, are able to verify that emails are from a legitimate sender (CPF Board) and we are able to tell such service providers how to handle emails that do not pass verification checks, e.g., reject or quarantine the email.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am a nominee of a deceased CPF member. How can I access the member's CPF account information?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If CPF Board is notified of the death of the member on or after 1 February 2024   If you are a nominee of the deceased CPF member, you can view the deceased member's CPF information on the Deceased CPF Member Dashboard , by logging in with your Singpass. Please wait at least 10 working days from the notice of death.   If you do not have Singpass, please submit a request instead.   If you are a family member but not a nominee, you can visit this FAQ to find out how you can also access the deceased member's CPF account information.   If CPF Board is notified of the death of the member before 1 February 2024   Only authorised persons appointed by the deceased member can view his CPF account information. If you are an authorised person, please  submit a request to view the deceased member’s CPF account information.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I increase my internet or mobile banking transfer limit?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can increase your internet or mobile banking transfer limit via your bank’s internet or mobile banking portal. Please refer to the guides below: Payment via PayNow: 1.  POSB/DBS – Digibank Language English Chinese Malay Tamil 2. UOB – UOB TMRW Language English Chinese Malay Tamil 3.  OCBC – OCBC Digital Language English Chinese Malay Tamil 4. Standard Chartered 5. HSBC 6. Maybank 7. Citibank You may also wish to refer to the list of PayNow participating banks .

Knowledge Article: Question: What information relating to my witnesses do I need to provide when I make a nomination online?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will need to provide the following information of your witnesses when making an online nomination:   NRIC Full Name* as per NRIC Email and/or Singapore registered mobile number (for receiving of SMS notification to perform witnessing) *It is important to provide your witnesses' full name as indicated on his NRIC, including comma, hyphen and space accordingly. However, you should exclude the Hanyu Pinyin, Alias and married name. See examples of NRIC names.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the types of Voluntary Contributions (VC) I can make for my employees?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can make Voluntary Contributions (VC) to:   Your employee(s)' Special /Retirement Account only under the Retirement Sum Topping Up Scheme (RSTU) (tax relief available to both employer and employee). Your employee(s)' three CPF accounts (no tax relief given for both employer and employee). # Your employee(s)' MediSave Account via the Additional MediSave Contribution Scheme (AMCS) (tax free for employees and tax benefits available to employers). # Please note that your employees must be Singapore Citizens or Singapore Permanent Residents only.   # The VC made will be treated as the current month's contribution. Backdating of VC to an earlier date is not allowed.   You can find out more on the types of VC you can make for your employees.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have outstanding MediSave payable. Why am I not allowed to make partial payment to offset my MediSave payable under the Manage your MediSave Payable form (MMSP)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: This is to encourage and make it easier for self-employed persons to be up-to-date with their MediSave payable. You can conveniently request instalment plan or make full payment for your MediSave payable via  Manage your MediSave Payable  (MMSP). This allows for hassle-free licence application/renewal while being up-to-date with your MediSave payable.

Knowledge Article: Question: How are the excess CPF contributions derived and from which month of my employee's CPF contributions be refunded?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The excess CPF contributions are derived by subtracting the CPF Annual Limit of $37,740 from the total mandatory CPF contributions paid for the year, and refunded from the latest month which excess CPF contributions were paid on the Ordinary Wage.   You may refer to an  example .

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the applicable limits if I wish to make Voluntary Contributions (VC) for my employees?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can make three types of Voluntary Contributions (VC) for your employees:   Type of VC VC Limit   i) Cash top-ups to your employee(s)’ Special or Retirement Account     For members below 55: up till the current Full Retirement Sum (FRS) For members 55 and above: up till the current Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS) Learn more about how you can earn tax deductions for cash top-ups made on your employee(s)’ behalf.   ii) VC to your employee(s)’ three CPF Accounts Up to the CPF Annual Limit ($37,740 per employee per year) less the mandatory contributions received by the employee for the calendar year. Backdating of VC to an earlier date is not allowed. Do consider the mandatory CPF contributions you will be making for your employee, before making VC. If the total mandatory CPF contributions and VC received by the employee exceeds the CPF Annual Limit in the calendar year, VC in excess of the CPF Annual Limit will be refunded without interest.   iii) VC to your employee(s)’ MediSave Account only under the Additional MediSave Contribution Scheme (AMCS).   Up to $2,730 per employee per year. Any VC in excess of this limit will be refunded without interest to the employer in the following year. Backdating of VC to an earlier date is not allowed. AMCS contributions are not subject to the CPF Annual Limit and the employee(s)’ Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS).

Knowledge Article: Question: I have previously signed up as a CPF volunteer via an online form. Do I need to sign up again?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You need to download and sign up via our CPF Volunteering (CPFV) mobile application even though you had previously signed up via our online form. By doing so, you will be able to participate in the  C ommunity P aying it F orward movement with like-minded individuals, access CPF online resources on the go, experience a gamified journey, view your personal achievements and the impact of your contributions.   You can download our CPF Volunteering (CPFV) mobile app and tapping on “Sign up now”. It is available on both App Store and Google Play (search for keyword: CPFV).   You can also scan the QR code to download the app and register with us.

Knowledge Article: Question: When should I submit my top-up application if I want to be eligible for tax relief in the next assessment year?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your online top-up application and payment will need to reach us by 31 December of the year.   It is important to note that the tax relief is granted based on the calendar year in which the top-up is made, regardless of the actual date of submission.   We would also encourage you to top up earlier in the year. Find out  why you should top up as early as possible .

Knowledge Article: Question: I encountered an error informing me that the name I keyed for my nominee was different from his NRIC/CPF Account No. How can I resolve this?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your nominee is a Singaporean or Singapore Permanent Resident, you should key in the full name as per his NRIC. This includes any punctuation such as the comma (,), hyphen (-), and slash (/).   However, you should exclude the Hanyu Pinyin, Alias and Married name. See examples of NRIC names.   If you are still encountering problems in submitting your nomination, we recommend that you check the following:   Check for the correct spacing of characters in the names of your nominee. For example: John?Tan should not be written as John??Tan or John?Tan? D/O should not be written as D / O, and likewise for S/O Avoid copy-pasting the details from another program or app as there might be hidden characters that might get copied. Key in the nominee’s particulars directly instead. If you are using an iOS device (such as iPhone or iPad), disable the “Smart Punctuation” feature in iOS (iOS device Settings > General > Keyboard > Turn off Smart Punctuation). This feature might create unrecognisable characters in the application form. Avoid opening multiple browser tabs. Use only one browser tab and clear your browser cache. Consider using a different device to submit your nomination if submission via your original device is still unsuccessful. If you are still encountering the same error despite the above, you can write to us with the following details:   A screenshot of the name of your nominee(s), The time and date when the error occurred, and The device that you are using to submit your online nomination.
