Under the Terms & Conditions of the CPF Education Loan Scheme, the loan must be fully repaid within 12 years, which starts one year after you graduate or leave the course of study. Any outstanding balance has to be paid in full before the end of the 12th year. Hence, if you repay at a lower monthly instalment, not only do you incur additional interest due to the prolonged repayment period, you may have to make a lump sum repayment of your outstanding loan at the end of the 12th year. If you would like to reduce the monthly instalment (subject to a minimum repayment of $100), you may submit your application online through " Manage education loan repayments " under "Forms and e-applications" using your Singpass.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I increase the monthly instalment for my Education Loan repayment?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You are encouraged to increase the monthly instalment for your education loan repayment if you are financially able to do so. This will enable you to fully repay the loan within a shorter period and hence minimise the interest you have to pay. If you would like to increase the monthly instalment, you may submit your application online through " Manage education loan repayments " under "Forms and e-applications" using your Singpass.

Knowledge Article: Question: Where can I check the status of my request to change monthly instalment rate under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may check the status of your request to change the monthly instalment rate under the CPF Education Loan Scheme at CPF website by logging in to " Activities " using your Singpass.

Knowledge Article: Question: Would I receive any acknowledgement after submitting my GIRO application form for the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Generally, you will receive an acknowledgement notification within two weeks upon receipt of your GIRO application form. The notification will indicate the start date of deduction and the monthly instalment rate. Generally, GIRO applications will be processed within 4 working days for e-application and 21 working days for hardcopy application. Upon receipt of your bank's approval of your GIRO application, we will send a notification to inform you on the approval, together with the start date of the deduction and the monthly instalment rate. In the meantime, please repay your education loan through " Manage education loan repayments " under "Forms and e-applications".

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I apply to defer the repayment under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may submit an application online to defer your education loan repayment through " Manage education loan repayments " under "Forms and e-applications" using your Singpass. You must read the Terms & Conditions and must obtain the consent of the CPF lender(s) whose Ordinary Account savings were used, before applying for deferment.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I apply to waive the repayment under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may submit an application online to waive the education loan repayment through " Manage education loan repayments " under "Forms and e-applications" using your Singpass.   For more information on the waiver of education loan repayment and the conditions to meet in order to waive the repayment, please refer to this  FAQ .

Knowledge Article: Question: Do CPF Mobile's security features scan my device or collect my personal information?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We take your privacy seriously. CPF Mobile's security features are limited to the detection of malware activity and no additional personal data from your device is collected. We seek your understanding that these features are necessary to protect CPF members from malware or suspected malicious apps. You can read up more on how to avoid falling prey to malware scams .

Knowledge Article: Question: When is the application period for the approved educational institutions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may refer to the Application schedule to apply for CPF education loan for the application period of the approved educational institutions.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I check or register for an event?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You may visit the  CPF Events page to view and register for CPF events.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why am I receiving this notification pertaining to my child's MediShield Life outstanding premium?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Under MediShield Life Act/Regulations, parents are liable to pay for their child's MediShield Life premiums until the child is 21 years old. As such, we are writing to inform you of your child's outstanding premium amount. Please top up your child's MediSave Account to pay the premiums. Alternatively, perform a Change Payer request to take over the premium payment using your MediSave. You may view the payment options in the link below: “How can I view and pay my/my dependant(s)'s CareShield Life/ElderShield and MediShield Life premiums?”    If premiums remain outstanding, your child's outstanding premium amount may be deducted from your MediSave account subsequently.

Knowledge Article: Question: What are the differences between topping up my retirement savings, making a Voluntary Housing Refund and topping up my MediSave Account?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Find out what the differences between the various types of top-ups are below:   Topping up your retirement savings Voluntary Housing Refund Topping up your MediSave Account Top up/refund to Special Account (SA) for members below 55; or Retirement Account (RA) for members 55 or above. Ordinary Account (OA); and/or RA for members 55 or above and have not met their Full Retirement Sum (FRS) in their RA. MediSave Account (MA) Eligibility for tax relief You can enjoy tax relief if you made cash top-ups to yourself or your loved ones up to the current FRS . However, please note that tax relief would not apply if you made a CPF transfer. You will not be eligible for tax relief. For non self-employed persons: You get to enjoy tax relief for voluntary top-ups to MA.  If you are self-employed, you will enjoy  tax relief  on your  MediSave contributions   based on your annual net trade income (NTI). There will be no tax relief for your MediSave contributions if your assessed NTI for the year of assessment is zero or negative.   Top-up limit What is the maximum amount of top-ups I can receive? If you are below 55, you may top up your SA up to the current FRS. If you are 55 or above, you may top up your RA up to the current Enhanced Retirement Sum. You can check your top-up limit in your Retirement Dashboard . Can I voluntarily refund a portion of the CPF savings I used for my property? You can make a refund of any amount, capped at the full principal amount you have withdrawn for the property, along with the accrued interest. You may check the amount that you can refund through the Home Ownership Dashboard . Do note that after making a full voluntary housing refund of the CPF savings withdrawn and accrued interest, all CPF withdrawals including monthly housing loan instalments (if any) for the property will stop. What is the voluntary top-up limit to my MediSave Account? The maximum amount you can voluntarily top up to your MA is the difference between your Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS) and your current MA balance. Once your BHS has been reached, no further voluntary top-ups can be made to your MA. If you exceed your BHS from the top-up, the full amount of your top-up will be refunded to you. You can check your top-up limit with these steps. Withdrawal Top-ups are meant to boost your retirement income. They will be streamed out to you as monthly payouts and cannot be used for other purposes. You can continue to use your OA savings for the current or next property after making a voluntary housing refund. However, if you would like to use your OA for the same property, after making a voluntary refund of the full principal amount used and the accrued interest, you will need to re-apply to use your CPF savings. After turning 55 and setting aside the FRS, you can withdraw the remaining balance in your OA and SA in full or in part at any time. From 55, you can make retirement withdrawals from your OA and SA in full or in part, at any time for your immediate needs, provided you have set aside your FRS. MA savings are meant for your healthcare needs and cannot be withdrawn as cash. Application Top-ups can be made using cash and/or CPF transfers. How do I apply to make a top-up? Refund can only be made via cash. How can I make a voluntary refund of the housing amount withdrawn if I am not selling my property? Top-ups can only be made via cash. How can I top up to myself, my children or my loved ones’ MediSave Account?   Click this link to find out what the CPF interest rates are.

Knowledge Article: Question: My top-up is not reflected in my CPF account. Was the top-up unsuccessful?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your top-up is not reflected in your CPF accounts after the expiry of our usual processing time , it might be due to one of the following reasons:   You may have missed out in making payment for your cash top-up application. Find out how to submit a new application . You may have missed out in submitting supporting documents for first-time CPF transfers to a loved one. Find out what the required supporting documents are . We may require additional time to verify your application. We will contact you within five working days to request for more information.

Knowledge Article: Question: What happens when I am reaching 65?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Three months before your Payout Eligibility Age of 65, you will receive a notification from CPFB on what you need to know when you approach 65. The notification will direct you to the personalised Plan my monthly payouts (PMP) service where you can instruct us to start or defer your payouts, view your estimated payouts, explore options for higher payouts, and confirm your bank account details.   To receive higher payouts:   If you wish to have higher monthly payouts, you can use your available CPF savings to increase your payouts through the same PMP service . The savings you can use include your available Ordinary, Special Accounts (OSA) savings, and an additional amount of up to 20% of your retirement savings (applicable for members born in 1958 or after). It is important to note that using more CPF savings to increase your payouts will correspondingly reduce the amount available for your future lump sum withdrawal from 65. You can have a better understanding of the impact on your withdrawable savings through the Plan my monthly payouts (PMP) service as well.   For existing CPF LIFE members   If you have previously joined CPF LIFE before reaching age 65, your monthly payouts will automatically start from the month you turn 65, unless you use the personalised Plan my monthly payouts (PMP) service to instruct us to defer your CPF LIFE monthly payouts. Please note that you can only defer your CPF LIFE monthly payouts up to age 70.   The PMP service will also allow you to view your estimated payouts, explore your options for higher payouts or confirm your bank account details.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is there a transfer of monies from my Retirement Account (RA) to my Ordinary Account (OA) once I start my monthly payouts?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are born in 1958 and after, when you turn 65, you can withdraw an additional amount of up to 20% of your retirement savings, excluding any cash top-ups, CPF transfers and government grants; for immediate needs. This withdrawable amount can also be used to increase your monthly payouts via the Plan my monthly payouts service. If this additional withdrawable amount in your Retirement Account is not withdrawn nor used to increase your monthly payouts, it will be transferred to your Ordinary Account for your future withdrawal when your payouts start.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why do I need to log in using my Singpass to access the Monthly Payout Estimator to estimate my CPF LIFE monthly payouts now?
Knowledge Article: Answer: From July 2024, you will have to log in using Singpass when using the Monthly Payout Estimator . By logging in, your CPF account details, such as birth year and CPF balances, will automatically be retrieved to estimate your monthly payouts, providing you with a more seamless experience when using the estimator. You can still adjust the CPF details.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I access the Monthly Payout Estimator if I do not have a Singpass?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will need to log in via Singpass to access the Monthly Payout Estimator .   If you do not have a Singpass account, you can register for one by following the instructions on the Singpass website . Alternatively, if you have questions on your payout amounts, please write to us .

Knowledge Article: Question: I am below 55. Can I use this Monthly Payout Estimator to estimate my monthly payout?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Monthly Payout Estimator  is designed to help members between the ages of 55 and 79 to estimate their monthly payout based on their desired retirement lifestyle.   If you are below 55, y ou can log in with your Singpass and try out t he CPF planner – retirement income . This online tool can help you in setting your retirement income goal, visualising your projected retirement savings and payouts, and simulating the impact of actions you can take to achieve your goal. You may also perform selected transactions such as making retirement top-ups.   With the planner, retirement planning is easy with just a few steps and takes only 15 minutes to complete.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are my information tracked when I log in using my Singpass to estimate my monthly payout?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No. The Monthly Payout Estimator is a tool to estimate your monthly payouts. We do not store any information that is keyed into the estimator.

Knowledge Article: Question: How long does it take to process applications relating to Direct Debit/GIRO matters?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The applications relating to Direct Debit/GIRO matters will generally be processed within the service standards as stated in the table below. We strive to process all submitted applications within the service standard and will let you know if more time is needed.   Service Normal Processing Time GIRO Application Online: Within minutes Hardcopy: Within 21 working days *Terminate GIRO for MediSave contributions Online: Within two working days   *Request to terminate Direct Debit/GIRO arrangement will be processed if there is no pending Direct Debit/GIRO deduction (i.e. have not generated payment file to bank to effect deduction for MediSave payable). Otherwise, processing can only commence two working days after deduction date. Please inform the Board of the terminated Direct Debit/GIRO arrangement if you have performed the termination over at the bank instead.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have made a voluntary top-up to my CPF accounts, why does the voluntary contribution allocated to my MediSave account not offset my MediSave payable?
Knowledge Article: Answer: With effect from 29 May 2024, the member and self-employed person’s “Contribute to my three CPF accounts” forms have been combined and renamed as “Top up CPF accounts”. This is to simplify the process in making voluntary top-ups, regardless of whether you are earning income as a self-employed person. You will continue to enjoy self-employed tax relief on these voluntary top-ups if you meet the eligibility criteria .   As these top-ups are voluntary in nature, the voluntary contribution allocated to your MediSave Account will not be used to offset your mandatory MediSave payable, and consequently will not meet the MediSave requirement for Workfare for self-employed persons. The intent is for self-employed persons to prioritise their mandatory MediSave contributions over voluntary contributions, and help self-employed persons to first set aside sufficient savings for their healthcare needs. Self-employed persons who wish to make mandatory contributions towards their MediSave payable, and to qualify for Workfare, should do so via the  Manage your MediSave payable , instead of making voluntary contributions.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I update my mode of payment to receive cash benefits from the Government?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There are two options which you can choose to update the mode of payment for your government cash benefits: Option 1: Register for PayNow-NRIC You can register for PayNow-NRIC if you have a bank account with the  participating banks . Please refer to your respective bank's website for specific details on how to link your NRIC to PayNow. Please note that PayNow-Mobile number is not accepted. You are encouraged to register for PayNow-NRIC as government cash benefits will be credited to your PayNow-NRIC-linked bank account by default. PayNow is a secure funds transfer service that allows customers to receive money into their bank account via NRIC/FIN and/or mobile number. With PayNow, the recipient's bank information will be kept private. The recipient will need to provide their mobile number or NRIC/FIN to the sender to send money. Other PayNow users will not have access to your personal details unless it is provided by you. Option 2: Provide your bank account details You may provide your bank account details by logging in to our e-services with your Singpass. The bank account that you have provided will only be used if you do not have a PayNow-NRIC linked bank account. Bank crediting is only available via the three local banking groups DBS/POSB, OCBC, UOB, and your bank account must be a personal or joint account registered with your NRIC number. The Government will validate the bank account details that you have registered with your bank. If you have closed your bank account, ceased being a joint account holder, or have provided the wrong bank account details, we will inform you to update your bank account details. You will receive a notification sent to your Singpass app. If you do not have the app, a letter will be sent to your NRIC address. This notification will not be sent via SMS, WhatsApp or any other platforms.

Knowledge Article: Answer: There are two options which you can choose to update the mode of payment for your government cash benefits: Option 1: Register for PayNow-NRIC You can register for PayNow-NRIC if you have a bank account with the  participating banks . With PayNow, the recipient's bank information will be kept private. The recipient will need to provide their mobile number or NRIC/FIN to the sender to send money. The bank account that you have provided will only be used if you do not have a PayNow-NRIC linked bank account. The Government will validate the bank account details that you have registered with your bank. You will receive a notification sent to your Singpass app. If you do not have the app, a letter will be sent to your NRIC address. This notification will not be sent via SMS, WhatsApp or any other platforms.

Knowledge Article: Question: My mobile number is already registered to my bank account on PayNow. Can the Government credit my Government cash benefits to me via PayNow-Mobile instead of via PayNow-NRIC?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We can only credit your Government cash benefits to you via your PayNow-NRIC-linked bank account. NRIC is an unchanged proxy issued by the Government, compared to mobile numbers which may be easily changed. To ensure that the money is credited to the correct recipient’s bank account, only NRIC will be accepted as the proxy for Government benefits via PayNow.   Eligible seniors who have linked their NRIC to PayNow, with a PayNow-GIRO-participating bank will receive the benefits in this bank account.

Knowledge Article: Question: My mobile number is already registered to my bank account on PayNow. Can the Government credit my Government cash benefits to me via PayNow-Mobile instead of via PayNow-NRIC?
Knowledge Article: Answer: We can only credit your Government cash benefits to you via your PayNow-NRIC-linked bank account. NRIC is an unchanged proxy issued by the Government, compared to mobile numbers which may be easily changed. To ensure that the money is credited to the correct recipient’s bank account, only NRIC will be accepted as the proxy for Government benefits via PayNow.   Eligible seniors who have linked their NRIC to PayNow, with a PayNow-GIRO-participating bank will receive the benefits in this bank account.

Knowledge Article: Question: I lost my letter containing the Payment Reference Number (PRN), can someone else take my money?
Knowledge Article: Answer: It is not possible to withdraw the money with just the Payment Reference Number as GovCash uses the Singpass Face Verification technology to authenticate users during the withdrawal of the Government benefits from OCBC ATMs. The Face Verification technology incorporates a liveness-detection capability that blocks the use of photographs, videos or masks during the verification process.   This security feature prevents any fraudulent withdrawal of the Government benefits by third party using photographs or videos belonging to the beneficiary and ensuring only the eligible Singaporean can perform the withdrawal of his or her Government benefits.

Knowledge Article: Question: I lost my letter containing the Payment Reference Number (PRN), can someone else take my money?
Knowledge Article: Answer: It is not possible to withdraw the money with just the Payment Reference Number as GovCash uses the Singpass Face Verification technology to authenticate users during the withdrawal of the Government benefits from OCBC ATMs. The Face Verification technology incorporates a liveness-detection capability that blocks the use of photographs, videos or masks during the verification process.   This security feature prevents any fraudulent withdrawal of the Government benefits by third party using photographs or videos belonging to the beneficiary and ensuring only the eligible Singaporean can perform the withdrawal of his or her Government benefits.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is GovCash and is it safe?
Knowledge Article: Answer: GovCash is a payment mode that allows Singapore citizens to withdraw their Government benefits in cash from over 500 OCBC ATMs located across Singapore.   Singaporeans who prefer to seek assistance with their GovCash withdrawals can visit the ATMs located within OCBC's branches during operating hours, where OCBC Digital Ambassadors will be present to guide them. In addition, GovCash also allows recipients to use the scan-and-pay function and PayNow transfer option through the LifeSG mobile app.   GovCash is as secure as receiving payments via cheque. It adopts the Singpass Face Verification technology to authenticate users, including a liveness-detection capability that blocks the use of photographs, videos, or masks during the verification process. Users are also required to key in their unique 8-digit Payment Reference Number (PRN) during the withdrawal of the Government benefits at the OCBC ATMs.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is GovCash and is it safe?
Knowledge Article: Answer: GovCash is a payment mode that allows Singapore citizens to withdraw their Government benefits in cash from over 500 OCBC ATMs located across Singapore.   Singaporeans who prefer to seek assistance with their GovCash withdrawals can visit the ATMs located within OCBC's branches during operating hours, where OCBC Digital Ambassadors will be present to guide them. In addition, GovCash also allows recipients to use the scan-and-pay function and PayNow transfer option through the LifeSG mobile app.   GovCash is as secure as receiving payments via cheque. It adopts the Singpass Face Verification technology to authenticate users, including a liveness-detection capability that blocks the use of photographs, videos, or masks during the verification process. Users are also required to key in their unique 8-digit Payment Reference Number (PRN) during the withdrawal of the Government benefits at the OCBC ATMs.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the cut-off date for self-employed MediSave contributions to be eligible for tax relief?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To be eligible for tax relief for the year, the  MediSave  contributions made by self-employed persons must be credited to their CPF accounts by the last working day of the year.     If you have made  MediSave  contributions during the year, the contribution amounts will be automatically transmitted to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) for tax relief in the following year.     There is no tax relief for your  MediSave  CPF contributions if your assessed net trade income for the year of assessment  is zero or negative.     For more details on tax deductions, please visit the IRAS website or call the Individual Income Tax / Property Tax Helpline at 1800-356-8300.

Knowledge Article: Question: When is the deduction date of my recurring cash top-up arrangements?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The deduction from your bank account takes place on the 15th of the month (or the next working day if 15th falls on a Saturday, Sunday or Public Holiday).   If you set up a new GIRO to make recurring cash top-ups: GIRO deduction for your recurring cash top-up will take effect from the following month upon successful application of your recurring top-ups.   If you have updated your GIRO bank account for recurring cash top-ups: Deductions from your GIRO bank account for your recurring cash top-up(s) will take effect from the current month if you have updated your bank account before the 8th of the month. Otherwise, the deductions will be made from your new bank account from the following month.   Note: Please ensure that you maintain sufficient funds in your bank account for GIRO deductions. Some banks may charge an administrative fee for each unsuccessful deduction.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I check my existing recurring cash top-up arrangements?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can check your existing recurring cash top-up arrangements, including the recipients, amount of cash top-ups, and frequency (monthly or yearly) by accessing the Manage recurring cash top-ups for retirement form, under “Who you are making recurring top-ups to”.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the GIRO bank account used for my recurring cash top-up arrangement?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have an existing GIRO arrangement, you can view your current bank account used for your GIRO by accessing Set up GIRO for cash top-ups for retirement form , under “Select bank”.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is the deduction still happening after I have successfully deleted my recurring cash top-up arrangement?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To ensure that your deduction request takes effect from current month onwards, delete it at least three working days before the current month deduction . Else, the deduction will still proceed.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I update or terminate my GIRO bank account for recurring cash top-ups?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can update your GIRO bank account for your recurring cash top-up by setting up a new GIRO arrangement . If you have existing recurring top-up arrangements, the deductions could still be from your previous GIRO bank account for the current month. Find out more .   You can terminate your GIRO arrangement for your recurring cash top-up by submitting this form . All monthly and/or yearly GIRO deductions for top-ups to your recipient(s) will cease.

Knowledge Article: Question: I do not have enough funds in my CPF Ordinary Accounts (OA) for my housing instalment payment because my CPF contributions are credited after the instalment deduction date. What should I do?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The monthly instalment deduction date is fixed for all CPF members. If your CPF contributions are always credited after the deduction date, you may consider making a cash payment for one month's instalment. This will ensure that there are sufficient funds in your OA for subsequent months’ instalment payments.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I amend or cancel the online application that I had earlier submitted for housing loan payments to the banks?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can amend your earlier application (e.g. change amount or deduction date) for your housing loan payments to the banks by cancelling your previous application and re-submitting a new application. Please follow these steps:   Log in  with your Singpass. Select your property, click cancel under “Existing request” and click “Next” to confirm cancellation. Submit a new application with the updated details.

Knowledge Article: Question: I used to declare my income to CPFB to determine my Workfare Income Supplement (WIS)/excess Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) contributions for the year. Why is CPFB no longer accepting income declarations?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) has been appointed as the single collecting agency for all SEPs’ income information from Work Year 2023 (or Year of Assessment 2024). This means that all SEPs will now declare their net trade income (NTI), including all other sources of income derived from Work Year 2023, to IRAS. SEPs who receive a notification (via letter/form/SMS) to file tax from IRAS or meet the requirement to file tax (i.e. NTI above $6,000 and/or Total Income above $22,000), will need to complete and submit the tax return to IRAS directly. The income tax filing period is from 1 March to 18 April annually.   SEPs who do not receive a notification from IRAS or do not meet the requirement to file tax may declare their self-employed net trade income (NTI), including all other sources of income derived from Work Year 2023, to IRAS via  myTax Portal  which will be available from 1 March to 31 October annually for taxpayers to e-File tax returns.   SEPs will receive a Notice of Computation (NOC) from IRAS if they are required to make MediSave contributions, after IRAS has issued a Notice of Assessment for the relevant Year of Assessment.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am currently under CPF LIFE and have deferred my monthly payouts. What should I do if I want to change my payout start age?
Knowledge Article: Answer: It depends on whether you are starting your payouts at an earlier age or later age.   For members who want to start payouts at an earlier age If you wish to receive your payouts earlier (for example, currently deferred and will start at age 69, but wants to start at age 67 instead), please let us know only one month before your desired payout start date, and not anytime earlier, via the Plan my monthly payouts service. For members who want to start payouts at a later age We will send you a notification three months before your original payout start date. If you prefer to delay your payouts to a later age (for example, currently deferred and will start at age 68, but wants to start at age 69 instead), you can submit your request via the Plan my monthly payouts service when you receive the notification.

Knowledge Article: Question: What security measures does CPF Mobile have in place to safeguard users from malware threats?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To safeguard your data and facilitate safe transactions, CPF Mobile is equipped with security features to prevent scammers from accessing your CPF account.   Access to CPF Mobile is restricted if your mobile device is rooted/jailbroken, contains known/potential malware apps or has granted risky app accessibility permissions on your device. These features are designed to help you to identify and prevent unauthorised access, thereby protecting you from potential exposure to malware scams and other security threats.   Our aim is to provide you with user-friendly services while ensuring a secure experience. You can be assured that CPF Mobile’s security features are limited to the detection of malware activity and no personal data from your device is collected.   For more information on what to do when you receive a notice on potential vulnerabilities and the anti-scam security measures available to you, please refer to the FAQs below:   Why am I receiving a notice on potential vulnerabilities when I launch CPF Mobile? What are the new anti-scam security measures available to CPF members?

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to pay Skills Development Levy (SDL) for my employees working overseas?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No. You only have to pay Skills Development Levy (SDL) for employees working in Singapore. If your employee is working overseas, you need not pay SDL for him.

Knowledge Article: Question: What is the CPF Withdrawal Lock, and how can I activate it?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF Withdrawal Lock allows members aged 55 and above to instantly disable online CPF withdrawals by setting the Daily Withdrawal Limit to $0, and is part of CPFB’s suite of anti-scam measures.   If you do not need to withdraw immediately, you may want to consider activating the CPF Withdrawal Lock to better safeguard your CPF savings.    You can easily activate the CPF Withdrawal Lock at any time online under Account Settings . Follow the three simple steps below.     Please visit the FAQ below to find out more on how to deactivate the CPF Withdrawal Lock: How do I deactivate the CPF Withdrawal Lock?

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I deactivate the CPF Withdrawal Lock?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you would like to deactivate the CPF Withdrawal Lock, you may increase the online Daily Withdrawal Limit to your desired amount (up to the maximum withdrawal limit), via Account settings ; which requires enhanced authentication and 12 hours to take effect. Thereafter, you will be able to make online CPF withdrawal applications.   Alternatively, if you wish to make a CPF withdrawal without deactivating the CPF Withdrawal Lock, you can book an appointment to visit us to withdraw your preferred amount in-person at any CPF Service Centre. Generally, the next available appointment for withdrawal transactions would be in a week’s time; subsequently, members will receive their withdrawn CPF savings generally within five working days.   Please visit the FAQ below to find out more on what is the CPF Withdrawal Lock, and how to activate it: What is the CPF Withdrawal Lock, and how can I activate it?

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I clear my browser's cache?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can clear your browser's cache after each session by following the steps on this page for major browsers .

Knowledge Article: Question: How does CPF Board determine the amount of Special Account (SA) savings to be transferred to my Retirement Account and Ordinary Account when my SA is closed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The amount of Special Account (SA) savings that will be transferred to your Retirement Account and Ordinary Account are based on   whether you have set aside your Full Retirement Sum, which can be fully in cash or with a mixture of property and cash, and the amount of withdrawable savings in your SA at the point your SA is closed.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much interest will I earn on the Special Account (SA) savings that are transferred to my Retirement Account and Ordinary Account in the month my SA is closed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As CPF interest is computed monthly, your Special Account (SA) savings (excluding contributions and refunds received in the month) that are transferred to your Retirement Account (RA), up to the Full Retirement Sum, will earn RA interest for that month. Remaining SA savings which are withdrawable and transferred to your Ordinary Account (OA) will earn OA interest for that month.   If you wish to earn higher interest and receive higher retirement payouts, you may transfer your SA savings to the RA, up to the prevailing Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS) before your SA is closed by early 2025 1 . The amount transferred to RA (excluding contributions and refunds received in the month) will earn the RA interest rate in the month of transfer. The RA interest rate is the same as the SA.   1 Please note that (i) CPF transfers are irreversible and the savings are set aside to boost your monthly payouts in retirement, and (ii) the normal processing time for CPF transfers is five working days upon receipt of application, and can take longer if the volume of applications is high.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much savings in my Special Account (SA) are withdrawable and will be transferred to my Ordinary Account when my SA is closed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have set aside your Full Retirement Sum (FRS), fully in cash or with a mixture of property and cash: All the savings in your Special Account (SA) are withdrawable and will be transferred to your Ordinary Account (OA) when your SA is closed.   If you have not set aside your FRS: The amount of SA savings transferred to OA ensures that your total withdrawable CPF savings from your OA and SA remain unchanged after SA closure. Your withdrawable CPF savings are based on your year of birth:  Year of Birth Withdrawable Any Time After Age 55 1 1953 and before 50% of your CPF savings 1954 40% of your CPF savings 1955 30% of your CPF savings 1956 20% of your CPF savings 1957 10% of your CPF savings 1958 and after $5,000 of your CPF savings 1 Some of your OA savings will be transferred to your Retirement Account (RA) to make up your FRS when you make a withdrawal. This transfer will take place for every withdrawal until you have set aside your FRS.

Knowledge Article: Question: To help me plan ahead, can I get an estimate of the amounts that will be transferred to my Retirement Account and Ordinary Account when my Special Account is closed?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Prior to the closure of your Special Account (SA), you may view the estimated amounts that will be transferred from your SA to your Retirement Account and/or Ordinary Account by logging in to your Retirement dashboard .

Knowledge Article: Question: How is the amount of CPF savings I can withdraw from age 55 determined?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have set aside your Full Retirement Sum (FRS), fully in cash or with a mixture of property and cash: You can withdraw any amount from your Special Account (SA) and Ordinary Account (OA)   If you have not set aside your FRS: You can withdraw some of your CPF savings from your SA and OA based on your year of birth:  Year of Birth Withdrawable Any Time After Turning Age 55 1 Additional Withdrawable Any Time After Turning Age 65 2 1953 and before 50% of your CPF savings N.A. 1954 40% of your CPF savings N.A. 1955 30% of your CPF savings N.A. 1956 20% of your CPF savings N.A. 1957 10% of your CPF savings Up to 10% of your Retirement Account (RA) savings at 65, excluding any cash top-ups, CPF transfers and government grants 1958 and after $5,000 of your CPF savings Up to 20% of your RA savings at 65, excluding any cash top-ups, CPF transfers and government grants, less the $5,000 withdrawable from 55 1 Some of your SA and OA savings will be transferred to your RA to make up your FRS when you make a withdrawal. This transfer will take place for every withdrawal until you have set aside your FRS.  2 Amount withdrawable is computed based on your RA and any CPF LIFE premium balances at 65. If there is any remaining amount not withdrawn or used to increase your monthly payouts, it will be transferred to your OA for your future withdrawals in the same month as you start your monthly payouts.

Knowledge Article: Question: I have plans to withdraw more than $50,000. When is the latest I can apply to withdraw my monies to ensure that the withdrawal application is not impacted by the lower maximum online Daily Withdrawal Limit?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Any withdrawals submitted before 25 September 2024 will not be impacted by the lower maximum Daily Withdrawal Limit.   The amount withdrawable by CPF members aged 55 and above remains unchanged and is subject to the current withdrawal rules . From 25 September 2024, if you need to withdraw an amount above $50,000, you may consider doing so online over multiple days or book an appointment (select ‘Retirement Income’ then ‘Withdrawal above maximum online Daily Withdrawal Limit’) to withdraw your preferred amount in person at CPF Service Centres. Generally, the next available appointment would be in a week’s time; subsequently, members will receive their withdrawn CPF savings in the bank account registered with us generally within 5 working days. We encourage members intending to make large withdrawals to plan in advance.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is CPF Board lowering the maximum online Daily Withdrawal Limit to $50,000 now?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The lowering of the maximum online Daily Withdrawal Limit (DWL) to $50,000 is part of an ongoing process to strengthen safeguards against scams.   As published in SPF’s Mid-Year Scams and Cybercrime brief, there were over 26,000 reported scams in Singapore in the first half of 2024, of which less than 0.1% involved CPF withdrawals. Majority of these scam victims who withdrew their CPF savings had raised their DWL above the default $2,000 before making the CPF withdrawals. While the proportion of scam cases involving CPF withdrawals was small and the withdrawals were all authorised by the victims, the impact on the victims can be significant, especially if they had increased their DWL to make larger withdrawals.   To strengthen safeguards against scams, CPF Board will lower the maximum DWL from $200,000 to $50,000 with effect from 25 September 2024. This will provide more friction against scams, and more time to prevent further losses without inconveniencing the vast majority of members making legitimate withdrawals today.

Knowledge Article: Question: Why is the maximum online Daily Withdrawal Limit set at $50,000 now?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Since the implementation of the default online Daily Withdrawal Limit of $2,000 in November 2023, vast majority of CPF members have maintained an online Daily Withdrawal Limit of $50,000 or less. Lowering the maximum online Daily Withdrawal Limit to $50,000 could provide more friction against scams and introduce more time between transactions to prevent further losses, while still ensuring minimal inconvenience for the vast majority of members making legitimate withdrawals today.

Knowledge Article: Question: My current online Daily Withdrawal Limit is more than $50,000. What will happen to my Daily Withdrawal Limit when the maximum online Daily Withdrawal Limit is lowered to $50,000?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your Daily Withdrawal Limit (DWL) is more than $50,000, it will automatically be lowered to $50,000 with effect from 25 September 2024. Individualised notifications will be sent to members with DWL above $50,000 to notify them ahead of 25 September 2024.   The amount withdrawable by CPF members aged 55 and above remains unchanged and is subject to the current withdrawal rules . From 25 September 2024, if you need to withdraw an amount above $50,000, you may consider doing so online over multiple days or book an appointment (select ‘Retirement Income’ then ‘Withdrawal above maximum online Daily Withdrawal Limit’) to withdraw your preferred amount in person at CPF Service Centres. Generally, the next available appointment would be in a week’s time; subsequently, members will receive their withdrawn CPF savings in their bank account registered with us generally within five working days. We encourage members intending to make large withdrawals to plan in advance.   If you do not plan to withdraw your CPF savings soon, you may wish to consider activating the CPF Withdrawal Lock or lowering your DWL to better safeguard your CPF savings.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am currently studying and have not graduated from the institution. I would like to make a full or partial repayment on my education loan. What do I need to do?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you can make a full or partial repayment to the education loan.   The lending member must first revoke the use of his/her CPF savings for your education by completing the online revocation application at cpf.gov.sg/RevocationForm . In the form, the member must select the option "Student is making an early repayment of the education loan, while still studying" .   Once the revocation is processed,  we will notify the lending member on the status and email you to proceed with the repayment online.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I update my registered bank account when I have a pending withdrawal application?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Please do not update your registered bank account until you have received your CPF savings in your bank account to avoid any delay or disruption in receiving your payment. If bank details are updated while the payment is still in progress, you may receive a cheque payment instead, which will be mailed to your mailing address within approximately five working days.

Knowledge Article: Question: When can I opt in to increase CPF contributions as a platform worker?
Knowledge Article: Answer: From November 2024, you can opt in for increased CPF contributions using the platform worker opt-in form and check your opt-in status on the CPF website.

Knowledge Article: Question: Are CPF contributions payable on reimbursements to platform workers for expenses?
Knowledge Article: Answer: CPF contributions are not payable on payments from platform operators meant to reimburse additional expenses already incurred by workers. For example, this can include reimbursements for fuel due to cancelled jobs, and cleaning expenses if customers made a mess in the vehicle.

Knowledge Article: Question: As a taxi driver who takes both ride-hail and street-hail jobs, how should I make CPF contributions for my earnings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will need to make CPF contributions on ride-hail and street-hail earnings separately.   For ride-hail earnings, platform operators will deduct and make CPF contributions for you.   For street-hail earnings, you will need to contribute MediSave on your own in the following year after you have declared your net trade income to IRAS. CPF Board will inform you of your MediSave payable once IRAS has assessed your income.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I apply for refund on CPF contributions paid above the CPF annual ceiling of $102,000?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If your total net earnings under a single platform operator exceed $102,000, your platform operator will apply for a refund on the excess CPF contributions from CPF Board. After receiving the refund, your platform operator will refund your share of excess CPF contributions to you.   If your total earnings across multiple platform operators exceed $102,000, you can apply for a refund on your share of the contributions.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can I declare actual expenses different from Fixed Expense Deduction Amount? Will my CPF contributions be adjusted?
Knowledge Article: Answer: For the convenience of both platform workers and platform operators, CPF contributions will be based on gross earnings less Fixed Expense Deduction Amount (FEDA), and are not based on declared expenses.   This benefits both platform workers and platform operators as you will not have to keep receipts to track and compute actual expenses for your platform work and submit them to your platform operators. Your platform operators will also not have to incur additional operating costs to re-compute the CPF contribution based on actual expenses.   FEDA is applied to all platform workers to simplify the computation of CPF contribution for both platform operators and platform workers, regardless of income levels and delivery modes. As such, we will not adjust the CPF contributions based on declared expenses.

Knowledge Article: Question: Can my platform operator’s contributions be used to offset outstanding MediSave contributions from my past self-employed work?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your CPF contributions (including platform operator’s share, if any) are meant for platform work done from 2025.   You will need to make separate arrangements to settle any outstanding MediSave contributions on past income earned as a self-employed person.    You may reach out to CPFB to arrange affordable instalment plans  on your past MediSave obligations.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do i need to apply for a new CPF Submission Number (CSN) if my platform is a subsidiary company with a different Unique Entity Number (UEN) from the parent company?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you are required to apply for a new CPF Submission Number (CSN) if your platform is a subsidiary company with a different Unique Entity Number (UEN) from the parent company. To apply for a CSN, please refer to How do i obtain my CSN as a new platform operator ?

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to apply for Platform Workers CPF Transition Support (PCTS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You do not need to apply for Platform Workers CPF Transition Support (PCTS).     We will automatically assess your eligibility for PCTS based on the net earnings declared by your platform operator when making CPF contributions.     We will credit your PCTS payment to your PayNow NRIC-linked bank account if you have one. Otherwise, it will be credited to the bank account that you have registered to receive Government benefits, or via GovCash if you had not registered a bank account with us. Crediting of PCTS will not go through your platform operators.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to inform my platform operator once I have opted in to increase my CPF contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You do not need to inform your platform operator once you have opted in.   If you have opted in, the increased CPF contributions (by both platform worker and platform operator) will be made from your opt-in effective month.   From November 2024, you can use the Opt-in Status Checker to confirm whether you have opted in and view your opt-in effective month.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I need to submit CPF contributions for my platform workers if they have not opted in for increased CPF contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you will need to deduct the platform workers’ share of CPF contribution as and when they earn for all platform workers, regardl ess of their opt-in status and submit the monthly CPF contributions on your platform workers’ behalf.     The CPF contribution rate is lower for platform workers who have not opted in. You will deduct only the platform workers' share of CPF contributions from their net earnings and submit these CPF contributions every month. These will be allocated to their MediSave account only.   You will not need to contribute the platform operator’s share of CPF contributions.    You can refer to the contribution table  for platform workers who have not opted in.

Knowledge Article: Question: Do I still need to declare my income to IRAS and contribute MediSave in the following year for my self-employed work?
Knowledge Article: Answer: From 2025, If you are only receiving platform earnings in the year, platform operators would have deducted and paid the CPF contributions on your platform earnings for you every month. Therefore, you do not need to make your own MediSave contributions on such platform earnings in the following year.   If you derive self-employed income from non-platform work (e.g. giving tuition, or taxi street-hail jobs), you will still need to pay MediSave contributions on these sources of income in the following year on your own, as per status quo, after you have declared your net trade income to IRAS. CPF Board will notify you of the MediSave contributions you need to make.   For tax purposes, you will still need to declare your net trade income derived from platform work and any non-platform work in the year as a self-employed person (SEP) to IRAS .

Knowledge Article: Question: Does the CPF annual ceiling apply to my net earnings as a platform worker?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, you will be subject to the same CPF annual ceiling of $102,000 as employees. You do not need to make any CPF contributions on net earnings exceeding $102,000 in a year.   As CPF contributions are computed separately for each platform operator you work with, this annual ceiling applies on a per-platform basis.   If your total net earnings for the year across all platforms have exceeded CPF annual ceiling of $102,000, you can apply for a refund on your share of the contributions.

Knowledge Article: Question: How and when will I be notified on my Platform Workers CPF Transition Support (PTCS) payments?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you have registered your contact details with CPF Board, you will receive a notification  via SMS or email when your Platform Workers CPF Transition Support (PCTS) payment has been credited.

Knowledge Article: Question: How are CPF contribution rates applied when a platform worker moves to the next age group?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The contribution rates of your platform worker moving to the next age group shall be applied from the first day of the month after the month of his 35 th , 45 th , 50 th , 60 th , 65 th and 70 th birthday.   For example, for a platform worker whose 50 th birthday falls in May, he is deemed to have 50 years of age in May, and we will use the contribution rate for the “Above 45-50” age group for May. As contribution rates are applicable on a monthly basis, you will apply the contribution rate for the “Above 50-60” age group from June.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I change the mode of payment for my Platform Workers CPF Transition Support (PCTS)? / I have already registered for PayNow-NRIC to receive my Government cash benefits. Do I still need to provide my bank account details?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No further action is required from you if you have already registered for PayNow-NRIC with the participating banks. You are encouraged to register for PayNow-NRIC with a PayNow-GIRO-participating local or foreign bank in Singapore to receive your Platform Workers CPF Transition Support (PCTS) payments promptly. Payment will be made by default to your PayNow-NRIC-linked bank account.   If you do not have a PayNow-NRIC-linked bank account, you can update your bank account details by logging in to our e-services  with your Singpass. Payment instructions received will be used for future government benefits. The Government will validate the bank account details that you have registered.   If you have closed your bank account, ceased being a joint account holder, or have provided the wrong bank account details, we will inform you to update your bank account details. You will receive a notification sent to your Singpass app. If you do not have the app, a letter will be sent to your NRIC address. This notification will not be sent via SMS, WhatsApp or any other platforms.   If you have not linked your NRIC to PayNow or have not provided a valid bank account to the Government, you will receive future Government cash benefits via GovCash. GovCash  is a payment mode where you can withdraw your Government benefits in cash from OCBC ATMs.   Citizens who are on GovCash will receive their cash benefits 2-3 weeks later than those who have linked their NRIC to PayNow or have provided a valid bank account.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I ensure that the CPF contributions I received are accurate?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can use the platform worker CPF Contribution Calculator to check if your CPF contributions are correct by keying in your net earnings.

Knowledge Article: Question: How can I provide or update my mobile number to receive SMS notification on my Platform Workers CPF Transition Support (PCTS) payment?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To receive SMS notifications on your Platform Workers CPF Transition Support (PCTS) payment, you may update your mobile number via my cpf digital services - Account Settings with your Singpass.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I calculate my CPF contributions based on net earnings as a platform worker?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your CPF contribution is calculated based on your net earnings (after fixed expense deduction amount ) and the contribution rate applicable to your age, earnings and opt-in status.   Illustration   Step 1: Determine your gross earnings: $3,000     Step 2: Apply your Fixed Expense Deduction Amount (FEDA): 60% expense for cars   Step 3: Compute your net earnings: $3,000 x (1-60%) = $1,200     Step 4: Key in your net earnings into platform worker CPF Contribution Calculator to find out your contributions and allocation.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I check which platform workers have opted in for increased CPF contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Platform workers born before 1995 may opt in to increased CPF contributions via the CPF website. They may do so at any time, as there is no deadline to do so. Opt-in is irreversible.    As CPF contribution rates depend on platform workers’ opt-in status, you will need to validate your platform workers’ latest opt-in status before calculating their CPF contributions.    The monthly query with CPF Board via Secured File Transfer Protocol (SFTP) will inform you of the latest opt-in status of your platform workers. There is no need to include platform workers born in or after 1995 in the query, as it is mandatory for them to make the increased CPF contributions. You may refer to this step-by-step guide to conduct monthly query on your platform worker's opt-in status .   CPF Board will inform you of the opt-in status of your platform workers on the 20th of each month, via the monthly query. You can refer to the illustration below for the opt-in status query timeline.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I check which platform workers have opted in for increased CPF contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Platform workers born before 1995 may opt in to increased CPF contributions via the CPF website. They may do so at any time, as there is no deadline to do so. Opt-in is irreversible.    As CPF contribution rates depend on platform workers’ opt-in status, you will need to validate your platform workers’ latest opt-in status before calculating their CPF contributions.    The monthly query with CPF Board via Secured File Transfer Protocol (SFTP) will inform you of the latest opt-in status of your platform workers. There is no need to include platform workers born in or after 1995 in the query, as it is mandatory for them to make the increased CPF contributions. You may refer to this step-by-step guide to conduct monthly query on your platform worker's opt-in status .   CPF Board will inform you of the opt-in status of your platform workers on the 20th of each month, via the monthly query. You can refer to the illustration below for the opt-in status query timeline.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I contribute CPF as a platform operator?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You can write to us to onboard as a platform operator.   An onboarding guide will be available to platform operators from Nov 2024.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I determine the CPF contribution rates as a platform operator?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF contribution rate depends on platform workers’ earnings, age and opt-in status. You can verify the amount using the platform workers CPF Contribution Calculator .   You can also refer to the  details of the CPF contribution rates for platform workers:   Pages 1-5: Contribution rates for platform workers who are mandated or have opted in (2025-2029) Page 6: Contribution rates for platform workers who have not opted in .   Opt-in Status Query   For platform workers born before 1995, their CPF contribution rates depend on platform workers’ opt-in status. You will need to check your platform workers’ latest opt-in status before calculating their CPF contributions.    The monthly query with CPF Board via Secured File Transfer Protocol (SFTP) will inform you of the latest opt-in status of your platform workers. There is no need to include platform workers born in or after 1995 in the query, as it is mandatory for them to make the increased CPF contributions. You may refer to this step-by-step guide to conduct monthly query on platform workers' opt-in status .   CPF Board will inform you of the opt-in status of your platform workers on the 20 th of each month, via the monthly query. You can refer to the illustration below for the opt-in status query timeline.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I obtain my CPF Submission Number (CSN) as a new platform operator? How long does it take?
Knowledge Article: Answer: To obtain your CPF Submission Number (CSN) as a new platform operator, you can attach a copy of the completed  form and submit to us via our write to us page. Upon submission of the form, your CSNs will be issued to you within five working days.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I opt in to increase my CPF contributions as a platform worker and how soon will it take effect?
Knowledge Article: Answer: From November 2024, you can opt in using the platform worker opt-in form.   If you opt in on or before the 15 th of a month, the increased contributions will start from the next month.   If you opt in after the 15 th of a month, the increased contributions will start two months later.   For example, if a platform worker opts in on 15 April, the increased contributions will start from 1 May. If a platform worker opts in on 16 April, the increased contributions will start from 1 June.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I qualify for Platform Workers CPF Transition Support (PCTS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will qualify for Platform Workers CPF Transition Support (PCTS) if you meet the following criteria:   Are a Singapore Citizen; Born in 1995 or later; or born before 1995 and  opted in to increase your CPF contributions; Net income from platform work and other employment sources does not exceed $3,000 for the month (Net income refers to gross earnings minus the Fixed Expense Deduction Amount); and Have an increase in your share of CPF contributions to the Ordinary and Special Accounts as compared to the previous year. PCTS is intended to offset part of the year-on-year increase in a platform worker’s own share of his CPF contributions to his Ordinary and Special accounts, during the phase-in period when platform workers’ CPF contribution rates are gradually increased to aligned with employees’. Hence:   Platform workers aged above 65 will not be eligible as they will not see an increase in their own share of CPF contributions if they opt in to increased CPF contributions. In 2025, platform workers aged above 60 to 65 will also not see an increase in their own share of CPF contributions and thus they will not be eligible. As PCTS is intended to offset the increase in CPF contributions, a platform worker will not receive PCTS for the months where his net earnings for a platform operator are  $500 or less , as he does not have to make his own share of CPF contributions.

Knowledge Article: Question: How do I receive my Platform Workers CPF Transition Support cash benefits via GovCash?
Knowledge Article: Answer: There are three options which you can choose to receive your Platform Workers CPF Transition Support cash benefits via GovCash:   Option 1: Use LifeSG to transfer to PayNow-NRIC linked bank account If you have an existing bank account, you can link your account to PayNow-NRIC with your bank. Thereafter, login to LifeSG mobile app (LifeSG) using your Singpass to transfer your GovCash to your PayNow-NRIC linked bank account. The LifeSG app can be downloaded from the Apple App store or Google Play Store.   Option 2: Use LifeSG for Scan & Pay You can use LifeSG to scan participating merchant’s QR code for purchases or scan your friend/family’s QR code to transfer your GovCash to them. You can only make purchases at merchants that accept PayNow/NETS QR code using the LifeSG app. You can look out for the PayNow/NETS logo on the SG QR label that is displayed by the merchants.   Option 3: Withdraw from OCBC ATMs You can withdraw your cash benefits at OCBC ATMs islandwide. You just need to enter: a) Your unique 8-digit Payment Reference Number (PRN) b) Your NRIC number; and c) pass the facial verification   You do not need to have an OCBC bank account to use this service.   You will receive the PRN via SMS or email after your cash benefits has been paid.You can also log into the  e-services  with your Singpass to view your PRN by selecting “GovCash PRN” that is found at the menu on the left. This will only be available after the payment has been made.

Knowledge Article: Question: How is the platform worker’s share of CPF contributions on my CPF Contribution Alert derived?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Your platform worker’s share of CPF contributions on the CPF Contribution Alert is derived by applying the applicable CPF contribution rate to the total CPF contributions made by your platform operator.   You will receive one Contribution Alert for each contribution made by your platform operator(s). As the platform worker’s share of CPF contributions indicated on the CPF Contribution Alert is meant to be indicative, please use the  platform worker CPF Contribution Calculator to determine the exact breakdown of your platform worker's share of CPF contributions based on your net earnings per month.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much can I expect to receive with the Platform Workers CPF Transition Support (PCTS) scheme?
Knowledge Article: Answer: From 2025 to 2028, Platform Workers CPF Transition Support (PCTS) will provide monthly cash support to lower-income platform workers to offset part of the year-on-year increase in the platform workers' share of CPF contributions to their Ordinary and Special Accounts (OSA).   The amount of PCTS you can receive is based on age, platform earnings and other income, as well as the offset rate for the year:   2025 2026 2027 2028 100% offset of OSA increase from previous year 75% offset of OSA increase from previous year 50% offset of OSA increase from previous year 25% offset of OSA increase from previous year   You can use the online PCTS calculator  to estimate how much you can receive.   To provide an illustrative example:

Knowledge Article: Question: How much tax relief will I get for CPF contributions made as a platform worker?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are mandated or have opted in for increased CPF contributions:   you will be allowed tax relief for your share of the mandatory CPF contributions. You will not have to pay tax on your platform operators’ share of mandatory CPF contributions. during the transitional period from 2025 to 2028, tax relief will also be allowed on voluntary CPF contributions to all three accounts, subject to a cap (based on the difference in the contribution rate in 2029, and at the contribution rate as at 31 December of the relevant year in which the voluntary contribution is made). once the mandatory CPF contribution rates have fully aligned with that for employees by 2029, only mandatory CPF contributions will be eligible for tax relief, similar to employees who do not enjoy tax relief for their voluntary CPF contributions to three CPF accounts.  If you are not mandated and do not opt in for increased CPF contributions, you will enjoy the same tax relief as self-employed persons. If you make voluntary CPF contributions to all three CPF accounts, both your mandatory and voluntary CPF contributions will continue to be eligible for tax relief of up to 37% of your net trade income or $37,740, whichever is lower.    Regardless of your opt-in status, you are eligible for CPF cash top-up relief if your platform operator makes cash top-ups on your behalf to your Retirement Account/ Special Account/ MediSave Account. This is aligned with the current treatment for employees.

Knowledge Article: Question: How much voluntary contributions can I make as a platform worker?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The maximum amount you can voluntarily contribute is the difference between the CPF Annual Limit of $37,740 and the mandatory CPF contributions made for the calendar year.   Do remember to consider your mandatory CPF contributions which you will be receiving for the calendar year, before making voluntary contributions. If the total mandatory CPF contributions and voluntary contributions exceed the CPF Annual Limit in the calendar year, any excess voluntary contributions will be refunded without interest in the following year.

Knowledge Article: Question: How should platform workers’ share be deducted from earnings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Platform operators should generally deduct the platform workers’ share of CPF contribution as and when they earn and submit monthly CPF contributions on platform workers’ behalf.   CPF contribution rates are lower for platform workers with net earnings less than $750 per month. If you had withheld your platform workers’ earnings based on a higher CPF contribution rate (i.e. using the rate applicable to platform workers’ earning above $750), you should refund the difference to your platform workers, before submitting the CPF contributions.

Knowledge Article: Question: How to calculate CPF contributions for platform workers working with multiple platform operators?
Knowledge Article: Answer: All platform operators will calculate and contribute CPF for platform workers separately (i.e. per-platform basis).   For example, Mr Lim works for platform operator A having a net earning of $3,000 and platform operator B, having a net earning of $6,000. Platform operator A will contribute CPF contributions on the $3,000 while platform operator B will contribute CPF contributions on the $6,000.    Note: If a platform worker provides both delivery and ride-hail services with the same platform operator (i.e. same UEN), his earnings should be combined.

Knowledge Article: Question: How to calculate the CPF contributions based on net earnings of platform worker?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The CPF contribution is calculated based on platform workers’ net earnings (after fixed expense deduction amount) and the contribution rate applicable to their age, earnings and opt-in status.    Illustration     Step 1: Determine a platform worker’s gross earnings: $3,000  Step 2: Apply the Fixed Expense Deduction Amount (FEDA): 60% expense for cars  Step 3: Compute the net earnings: $3,000 x (1-60%) = $1,200 Step 4: Key in the net earnings into platform worker CPF Contribution Calculato r to find out the contributions.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will Fixed Expense Deduction Amount (FEDA) be applied for platform workers that use multiple modes of transport or for incentives which are not based off any one mode of transport?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Platform operators should apply the Fixed Expense Deduction Amount (FEDA) based on the mode of transport declared by the platform worker, including if multiple modes of transport were used.   For payments or benefits not tied to one specific mode of transport, the lowest FEDA will be applied.   Illustration:   Platform worker A initially used a motorbike for food delivery, and subsequently switched to a bicycle.   He earned multiple payments for the month:   Earnings from jobs completed on bicycle= $1,000 [FEDA: 20%] Earnings from jobs completed on motorbike = $2,000 [FEDA: 35%] Bonus payment for completing a certain number of jobs (using both bicycle and motorbike) = $1,000 [FEDA: 20%, i.e. lower of FEDA for bicycle and motorbike] Net earnings: $1,000 * (1-0.2) + $2,000 * (1-0.35) +  $1,000 * (1-0.2) = $2,900

Knowledge Article: Question: How will platform workers’ CPF contributions be allocated to the CPF accounts?
Knowledge Article: Answer: If you are born on or after 1 Jan 1995 or have opted in, your CPF contributions will be allocated to your Ordinary Account, Special Account and MediSave Account. You can view the allocation rates  here .   If you are born before 1 Jan 1995 and have not opted in, your CPF contributions will be allocated to your MediSave Account only.

Knowledge Article: Question: How will the Fixed Expense Deduction Amount be applied if I use different modes of transport?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The Fixed Expense Deduction Amount (FEDA) used for calculation of CPF will be based on the mode of transport for the respective job(s) completed.    For example:    Example 1: Platform worker X uses a bicycle when working for platform operator A, and a car when working for platform operator B.    Platform operator A will use the FEDA of 20% to compute the platform worker's net earnings for CPF contributions. Platform operator B will use the FEDA of 60% to compute the platform worker's net earnings for CPF contributions.    Example 2: Platform worker Y uses motorcycle from 1 to 15 Jan, and switches to bicycle from 16 to 31 Jan.   For jobs completed on 1 to 15 Jan on motorcycle, the platform operator will use the FEDA of 35% to compute the platform worker's net earnings for CPF contributions. For jobs completed on 16 to 31 Jan on bicycle, the platform operator will use the FEDA of 20% to compute the platform worker's net earnings for CPF contributions.

Knowledge Article: Question: I already have a CPF Submission Number (CSN) to make contributions for my employees. Can I use the same CSN to make contributions for my platform workers?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No. Each CPF Submission Number (CSN) has a unique payment code that identifies the different payment types made by platform operators to the Board.   For example, you will use the following to submit CPF contributions:   123456789- PTE -01 for employees 123456789- PWA -02 for platform workers who are mandated or opted in, and the contributions will be allocated to all CPF accounts 123456789- PWM -03 for platform workers who are not opted in, and the contributions will be allocated to their MediSave account only   Please apply for new CSNs for the purpose of making CPF contributions for platform workers. You can attach a copy of the completed form and submit to us via the  write to us page.

Knowledge Article: Question: I am a part-time platform worker. Will I be eligible for Platform Workers CPF Transition Support (PCTS)?
Knowledge Article: Answer: As eligibility is not based on working hours, even if you are a part-time or ad-hoc platform worker, you can qualify for the Platform Workers CPF Transition Support (PCTS) as long as you meet the following criteria at the point of assessment:   Are a Singapore Citizen; Born in 1995 or later; or born before 1995 and opted in  to increase your CPF contributions; Net income from platform work and other employment sources does not exceed $3,000 for the month (Net income refers to gross earnings minus the Fixed Expense Deduction Amount); and Have an increase in your share of CPF contributions to the Ordinary and Special Accounts as compared to the previous year. As PCTS is intended to offset the increase in CPF contributions, a platform worker will not receive PCTS for the months where his net earnings for a platform operator are  $500 or less , as he does not have to make his own share of CPF contributions.   In addition, platform workers aged above 65 will not be eligible as they will not see an increase in their own share of CPF contributions if they opt in to increased CPF contributions. In 2025, platform workers aged above 60 to 65 will also not see an increase in their own share of CPF contributions, and thus they will not be eligible.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I am concurrently a full-time employee doing platform work, do I still need to make CPF contributions on platform earnings?
Knowledge Article: Answer: Yes, your platform operator will deduct the required CPF contributions from your net earnings from platform work. There is no change to your CPF contributions as an employee. Your employer must still deduct and make CPF contributions for you.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I am concurrently a full-time employee doing platform work, will my employers be notified of my platform work because of the CPF contributions?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No. Your employers will not be notified of your CPF contributions from platform work.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I am working for more than one platform operator, can I choose to contribute CPF on the earnings from only one of my platform operators?
Knowledge Article: Answer: No, CPF contributions will be made by all platform operators you work with (i.e. per-platform basis).   However, if your total net earnings for the year across all platforms have exceeded CPF annual ceiling of $102,000, you can apply for a refund on your share of the contributions.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I do not opt in to increase my CPF contributions as a platform worker, will I be subject to the same CPF contribution rate as today?
Knowledge Article: Answer: The maximum CPF contribution rate for platform workers who do not opt in will remain at 8% to 10.5%, depending on their age and income. They will also only need to make MediSave contribution if they earn above $500 in a month from a platform.   Some platform workers may see a difference in CPF contribution rate due to changes in the way CPF contribution is computed and collected. Today, platform workers’ earnings are aggregated across platforms and assessed annually when computing the applicable MediSave contribution. Moving forward, platform operators will be making CPF contribution on a monthly basis and based on earnings on each platform.   CPF contribution rates are tiered based on income – a platform worker earning below $750 will have a lower CPF contribution rate. Overall, whether platform workers’ CPF contribution rate is lower or higher as compared to today depends on their individual circumstances. For example, if platform workers have multiple income streams from different platforms, and if their income for each platform is low, platform workers will be subject to the lower CPF contribution that is now applied on a per platform basis.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I do not opt in to increase my CPF contributions as a platform worker, will I still receive CPF contributions from my platform operator?
Knowledge Article: Answer: You will continue to be required to make CPF MediSave contributions, but will not receive the platform operator’s share of CPF contributions.   Your platform operator will deduct only your share of CPF contributions from your net earnings and submit these CPF contributions every month. These will be allocated to your MediSave account only.   You will not receive the platform operator’s share of CPF contributions and there is no allocation to your Ordinary and Special Accounts.   You can refer to the contribution and allocation tables here.   You can use the platform worker CPF Contribution Calculator to check the contributions you will receive.

Knowledge Article: Question: If I work for multiple platforms, how will CPF contributions be calculated for each platform?
Knowledge Article: Answer: All your platform operators will calculate and contribute CPF for you separately (i.e. per-platform basis).   For example, Mr Lim works for platform operator A having a net earning of $3,000 and platform operator B, having a net earning of $6,000.
